Title: Germany's Coronavirus Death Rate Remains Low Despite High Case Numbers

Germany has seen a significant surge in coronavirus cases, with over 10,000 confirmed cases as of last week. However, the country's fatality rate remains remarkably low, at just 0.5%, the lowest in the world. This is despite being the fifth-highest country in terms of confirmed cases. Experts attribute this to Germany's extensive testing regimen, which has allowed for early detection and isolation of cases.

Germany's ability to test early and often has been crucial in containing the spread of the virus. According to Christian Drosten, director of the Institute of Virology at Berlin's Charité hospital, Germany has been testing around 120,000 people per week for COVID-19, the most extensive testing regimen in the world. This has led to a lower number of undetected cases compared to other countries where testing is less prevalent.

Germany's decentralized healthcare system, where each of its 16 federal states is responsible for its own health care systems, has also contributed to the country's ability to test widely. The Robert Koch Institute, Germany's equivalent to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, makes recommendations but does not dictate testing protocols, allowing for a more open market for testing.

The country's early detection and testing have also been facilitated by the development of the first COVID-19 test used in the public domain, developed by Drosten's team. This test was rolled out to laboratories throughout Germany in January, allowing for widespread testing to begin.

While some Berlin residents have expressed concerns about the availability of testing and the preparedness of the healthcare system, experts like Drosten believe that Germany's testing infrastructure has provided a more accurate read of confirmed cases. The country's fatality rate remains low, and experts estimate that the number of unknown cases is not high.

However, as the number of cases continues to rise, Germany's testing capacity may soon be stretched to its limits. Despite this, experts like Drosten remain confident that the country has had a robust response to the coronavirus pandemic, and are most concerned about countries in Africa that are not well-equipped to handle the crisis.

Title: Black Lives Matter Global Network's Financial Arrangement Raises Questions About Transparency

The Black Lives Matter Global Network (BLM) has been criticized for its financial arrangement with ActBlue, a digital payment platform, and Thousand Currents, a fiscal sponsor. FactCheck.org and Politifact confirmed that BLM is not a recognized IRS charity, and instead, raises funds through Thousand Currents. This arrangement has raised concerns about transparency, with critics suggesting that it blocks full transparency.

According to FactCheck.org, ActBlue helps raise funds for BLM by directing donations to Thousand Currents, their fiscal sponsor. The partnership between ActBlue and Thousand Currents was announced in 2016, with Thousand Currents providing fiduciary oversight, financial management, and administrative services to BLM.

Jenesha de Rivera, director of finance and administration at Thousand Currents, stated that the foundation has applied to become its own 501(c)(3) organization, but BLM did not provide a copy of its Form 1023, which is used to apply for 501(c)(3) status. An IRS spokesperson noted that copies of the form are only publicly available if the organization is approved for 501(c)(3) status.

Fiscal sponsorships are common, according to the National Council on Nonprofits, and allow a cause to attract donors even when it is not yet recognized as tax-exempt under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). In this case, ActBlue Charities and Thousand Currents have a legal obligation to make reasonable efforts to ensure that the funds they receive are spent consistent with 501(c)(3) restrictions, according to Benjamin Leff, a professor who specializes in nonprofits.

Judicial Watch's Tom Fitton suggested that the fiscal sponsorship route blocks full transparency, particularly when it comes to the partnership with ActBlue. However, FactCheck.org notes that a Thousand Currents audit for 2019 shows that the organization held nearly $3.4 million in net assets for BLM and had released nearly $1.8 million to the group in the last fiscal year. The audit also provides a breakdown of how the foundation spent that $1.8 million in buckets, including on consultants and salaries.

Title: The Complexity of Racism and Nationalism in American Politics

The article discusses the complexities of racism and nationalism in American politics, using the example of the 491st sin being unforgivable, as mentioned in the Gospel according to St. Matthew. The author argues that the accusation of racism is often used as a powerful tool to discredit political opponents, but it can also be misused and oversimplified.

The article highlights the distinction between racists and nationalists, noting that not all nationalists are racists. The author suggests that libertarians, who prioritize IQ scores and meritocracy, can be guilty of racism, while religious Christians who judge people based on their virtues are not necessarily racists.

The article also touches on the idea that nationalism can be a complex and multifaceted concept, and that it is not necessarily equivalent to racism. The author notes that nationalists can prioritize the interests of their own country and its citizens without being racist, and that some people may be nationalists who accept and respect people of all races.

The article concludes by noting that the accusation of racism is often used as a political tool, and that it can be oversimplified and misused. The author advises against using this accusation lightly, as it can be damaging and unfair to individuals and groups.

Title: Four Cities Vote to Legalize Marijuana, Public Support Reaches Highest Level in History

The recent elections saw four cities vote to legalize marijuana, with Portland, Maine, becoming the first East Coast city to do so. While these votes are largely symbolic, as the states of Michigan and Maine still consider pot illegal, it marks another victory in the legalization movement. According to a Gallup Poll released in October, 58% of Americans back legalization, a 10-point increase from a year earlier. A Pew study from April found similar results, with support for legalization at its highest level in American history.

Analysts and advocates attribute the sudden jump in support to the successful legalization efforts in Colorado and Washington, which have brought the issue to the forefront of a national conversation. Additionally, the federal government's decision to allow states to move forward with legalization and not aggressively enforce federal marijuana crime laws has contributed to the growing support.

The National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Law's executive director, Allen St. Pierre, notes that the country is moving closer to legalization, with 21 states allowing medical marijuana and 17 having decriminalized it. In the next two elections, voters in five states are expected to have a say in the issue, with ballot initiatives expected in California, Maine, Oregon, Massachusetts, and Alaska.

The legalization of marijuana has taken a similar trajectory to same-sex marriage, which has also seen a flood of public support in recent years. A July Gallup poll found that 52% of Americans say they would vote in favor of same-sex marriage, with 14 states and the District of Columbia having legalized it.

While both issues have seen growing support, they have also faced opposition from similar groups, including those who are most religious and those over 55. However, liberals and young people are most likely to support both issues. William Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, notes that the two issues should not be too closely linked, as Republicans and conservatives are more likely to oppose same-sex marriage, while those against marijuana legalization tend to be "ambivalent." Despite these differences, support is growing for both issues, and the liberalization of these issues comes at a time when the country remains mostly conservative.

Title: New Hampshire Primary to Provide Clues on Rubio's Debate Performance, Clinton's Momentum, and GOP Field

The New Hampshire primary is set to take place on Tuesday, and it will provide answers to several questions that have been on the minds of political observers. The first-in-the-nation primary will give insight into the performance of Marco Rubio, Hillary Clinton's momentum, and the size of the Republican field.

Rubio's Debate Performance: Rubio's campaign has been working to dispel the perception that he is a "broken record in an empty suit" after his performance in the ABC debate on Saturday. However, it is unclear whether his shaky performance will have an impact on voters. Few tracking polls were in the field after the debate, making it difficult to measure the damage. The results of the New Hampshire primary will provide a clearer picture of Rubio's standing.

Clinton's Momentum: Hillary Clinton is expected to lose to Bernie Sanders, and the margin of victory will determine the extent of her momentum heading into the Nevada caucuses. A big win for Sanders would give him a significant boost, while a closer race could allow Clinton to claim a small comeback.

GOP Field: The Republican field is expected to shrink after the New Hampshire primary. Governors John Kasich, Jeb Bush, and Chris Christie have all said they will move on to South Carolina, but if they do not place in the top tier, they may face pressure to drop out. The results of the primary will determine the size of the GOP field going forward.

Overall, the New Hampshire primary will provide crucial information on the performance of the candidates and the direction of the campaigns.

Title: Trump Calls for Delay on Immigration Overhaul, Citing Need for Stronger Republican Majorities

Article: Washington - President Donald Trump has expressed his opposition to pursuing an immigration overhaul until after the midterm elections, stating that Republicans should wait until they have stronger majorities in Congress to tackle the issue. In a tweet, Trump wrote that Democrats are "just playing games" and have no intention of solving the decades-old problem, and that Republicans should focus on electing more senators and congressmen/women in November.

The planned vote on a House bill, which had been delayed until next week, is now in jeopardy. The bill, which would provide $23.4 billion for border security and cut family-based immigration, had been seen as a compromise between Republicans and Democrats. However, Trump's tweet has thrown cold water on the effort, and some Republicans are now questioning the bill's future.

Rep. Patrick McHenry, the chief deputy whip, said that the planned vote will move ahead despite the flagging support for the effort, citing party leaders' promise to GOP moderates. However, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader, has rejected labeling the bill a compromise, stating that its provisions on Dreamers and the zero-tolerance policy are too harsh for her party to accept.

The bill's future is now uncertain, with some Republicans expressing disappointment and frustration with Trump's tweet. Rep. Don Bacon, who supports the compromise bill, said that Trump's tweet "doesn't help" and that the House should move forward with the legislation. On the other hand, Rep. Louie Gohmert, a hard-line immigration conservative, welcomed Trump's pushback against the bill, stating that it's time to move on and get a better bill later.

The compromise bill would provide $23.4 billion for border security, cut family-based immigration, and eliminate a diversity-visa lottery program. It would also provide six years of legal status to young immigrants. The vote on the plan was delayed after rank-and-file House Republicans pressed leaders to make additional changes to the measure.

Title: The Lie of Conservative Racism: A Challenge to Leftist Beliefs

Article:

The notion that every Trump supporter and President Donald Trump are racists has become a common refrain among liberal leftists, as well as columnists, hosts, and hosts on CNN and MSNBC. This labeling extends beyond Trump supporters to include all whites and America itself, with the assumption that whites are divided between those who admit to being racist and those who do not. However, many conservatives and some liberals know this to be a significant lie.

The question is whether leftists genuinely believe this. It is impossible to know for certain, but it is clear that if something is repeated often enough and is essential to one's worldview, it will eventually be believed. To demonstrate the falsity of this claim, ask any white conservative, including those who support Trump, the following three questions:

1. Would you rather have nine white leftists or nine black conservatives on the U.S. Supreme Court?
2. Would you rather your child marry a black Christian conservative or a white non-Christian liberal?
3. Do you have more in common with and are you personally more comfortable in the company of a white leftist or a black conservative?

Dennis Prager, a nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist, has asked these questions of thousands of Trump supporters at lectures and on his radio show. Not once has a white Trump-supporting conservative expressed a preference for whites in each case. This presents a powerful challenge to the left's belief that all white conservatives are racists.

However, leftists have too much at stake to confront the truth about conservatives. The left has historically relied on lying about opponents, from Stalin labeling Trotsky a "fascist" to modern-day accusations of racism against Trump supporters. Some liberals and conservatives may lie, but the truth is a value shared by both sides. For a leftist to commit to the truth would mean ceasing to be a leftist.

The questions posed by Prager are important because they perform a vital service for conservatives. They help conservatives see the left's charge of conservative racism as a lie, much like medieval Jews came to see the blood libel charge as a fabrication. Every conservative knows their responses are heartfelt and true, and these questions can help them come to see the left's accusations as a medieval-style blood libel.

Dennis Prager is a nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist, and his latest book, "The Rational Bible," is a commentary on the book of Exodus.

Title: Trump Backtracks on Promise to Prosecute Hillary Clinton

In a sudden departure from his campaign rhetoric, President-elect Donald Trump has stated that he will not recommend prosecution of his former presidential rival Hillary Clinton. During the campaign, Trump repeatedly vowed to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Clinton, often using inflammatory language and chants of "lock her up" to rally his supporters. However, in a meeting with New York Times reporters and editors, Trump said he has "suffered greatly" and does not want to "hurt the Clintons."

Trump's comments mark a significant shift from his campaign promises, which could come as a shock to some of his most ardent supporters. The President-elect stated that the issues have been investigated "ad nauseum" and that people could argue the Clinton Foundation has done "good work." He also expressed a desire to move forward and not dwell on past controversies.

Trump's former campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, echoed his sentiments, saying that the President-elect's decision not to pursue further investigations sends a strong message to fellow Republicans. However, some Democrats have criticized the move as a sign of executive overreach and a departure from the principles of the rule of law.

Legal experts have also weighed in on the matter, with some expressing concern that Trump's comments could undermine the independence of the Department of Justice. Steve Vladeck, a CNN legal contributor and professor at the University of Texas School of Law, noted that the President-elect's comments do not augur well for the preservation of the line between law and politics over the next four years.

Despite the controversy, Trump's decision not to pursue prosecution of Clinton may be seen as a conciliatory gesture by some, particularly those who have been critical of the President-elect's divisive rhetoric during the campaign. However, the move is likely to be met with skepticism by many who see it as a departure from Trump's campaign promises and a sign of his willingness to put politics over principle.

**San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee Dies at 65**

San Francisco Mayor Edwin Lee, a former civil rights attorney and the first Asian-American to hold the city's top post, passed away on Tuesday at the age of 65. Lee had been mayor since 2011 and had suffered a heart attack on Monday night while shopping at a Safeway grocery store.

According to US House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco in Congress, Lee's office did not release the cause of his death. Lee was rushed to Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital in critical condition and died at 1:11 a.m. Tuesday after attempts to save his life.

London Breed, the president of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, became acting mayor after Lee's death, citing succession rules in the city's charter. Breed is the city's first black female chief executive.

Lee was a Seattle native and the son of Chinese immigrants. He graduated from Bowdoin College in 1974 and earned his law degree from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1978. He began his career as a civil rights attorney and later worked in city government, serving as human rights commission director, city purchaser, and public works director.

Lee was elected to his own term as mayor in 2011 and re-elected in 2015. He was known for his commitment to building bridges and solving problems, and was a strong advocate for undocumented immigrants, declaring San Francisco a sanctuary city.

Lee's death has been met with widespread tributes and condolences from city officials, including Pelosi, who called him a "man of the people" and a "true champion for the people." The San Francisco Giants, the city's professional baseball team, also paid tribute to Lee, calling him their "number one fan."

Title: State Department Delays Release of Hillary Clinton's Daily Meeting Schedules Until After Election

The United States State Department has announced that it will not release Hillary Clinton's daily meeting schedules from her time as Secretary of State by the time of the election. According to the Associated Press, the schedules will be released by December 30 of this year, more than a month after the country decides on its next leader.

The schedules have been in the news this week after the AP analyzed a sample of the meetings, finding that most of the meetings with private individuals involved people who had donated to the Clinton Foundation. The AP had requested the schedules in 2010 and 2013, and then sued the State Department to obtain them. The AP's analysis only looked at meetings with individuals outside the government, and Clinton has criticized the report, saying it is flawed because it does not consider the full picture.

Clinton stated that she would be proud to meet with the individuals she met with, regardless of whether they donated to the Clinton Foundation. Her campaign spokesman, Brian Fallon, criticized the AP for only looking at a limited subset of the data, analyzing only 154 meetings by the time they published their findings.

The Trump campaign has also weighed in on the issue, with a spokesman saying it is unacceptable that the State Department is refusing to release the full schedule before the election. The Clinton Foundation's official website states that the charity brings together businesses, governments, NGOs, and individuals to improve global health and wellness, increase opportunity for girls and women, reduce childhood obesity, create economic opportunity and growth, and help communities address the effects of climate change. Bill Clinton has said that if Hillary is elected president, the foundation will stop accepting foreign or corporate donations.

Title: Treasury Warns of Debt Ceiling Crisis, Urges Congress to Act

The United States Treasury Department has announced that it is running out of options to avoid hitting the debt ceiling, which is expected to be reached in the middle of October. In a letter to Speaker John Boehner, Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew emphasized the need for Congress to take action to prevent a potential financial crisis.

The Treasury Department has used various accounting maneuvers to avoid hitting the debt ceiling, but these measures are no longer sufficient. Lew warned that if Congress does not act soon, the government could be left with only $50 billion in cash, which would not be enough to cover essential programs such as Social Security payments, military personnel salaries, and Medicare.

The Bipartisan Policy Center has predicted that the government's cash reserves will dwindle to a critical level by mid-October, making it essential for Congress to take action. However, forecasting government cash flows is inherently uncertain, and unexpected changes in economic conditions or policy changes could affect the estimate.

The debt ceiling debate has been a contentious issue in the past, with Republicans seeking to use it as leverage to negotiate spending cuts. However, President Obama has repeatedly stated that the debt ceiling should not be used as a bargaining chip. The current debate is focused on a budget resolution, with the defunding of Obamacare tied to the resolution rather than the debt ceiling.

While hitting the debt ceiling does not necessarily mean the government would default, the market would likely react as if it did. The Treasury Department is urging Congress to take action to prevent a potential financial crisis and ensure the government can continue to pay its bills.

Title: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Republican-Led States' Efforts to Defund Planned Parenthood

The Supreme Court has declined to consider appeals from Republican-led states seeking to defund Planned Parenthood, allowing federal appeals court rulings to stand that allowed patients to contest laws in Louisiana and Kansas that stripped the reproductive health organization's Medicaid funds. The decision represents a setback for conservative interest groups that have sought aggressive action against Planned Parenthood and abortion providers.

Three conservative justices, Associate Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Neil Gorsuch, dissented, arguing that the court should have taken up the issue. Chief Justice John Roberts and new Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh did not join the dissent.

The court's refusal to hear the case means that Planned Parenthood's patients will continue to have access to Medicaid services, including reproductive health care and other essential services. The decision is a significant victory for the organization, which is the nation's largest provider of abortions.

Similar defunding efforts have been blocked in Arizona and Indiana and are being contested in Ohio and Texas. Only in Arkansas has a federal court allowed the state to deny funds. The laws were passed by state legislatures opposed to Planned Parenthood's provision of abortions, blocking funding for services such as contraception and cancer screenings.

The federal Medicaid Act allows patients to seek out any qualified provider, with the key word being "qualified." Louisiana and Kansas sought to block Planned Parenthood's funding based on allegations, including disputed claims that the group sold fetal tissue and body parts for profit.

Opponents of abortion rights expressed disappointment at the high court's inaction, but noted that other cases are percolating in lower courts that could give the justices another chance. Catherine Glenn Foster, president of Americans United for Life, said the group will continue to fight to protect states from being forced to use their limited public funds to subsidize abortion businesses.

Dr. Leana Wen, president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, hailed the court's decision to leave lower court rulings alone. "As a doctor, I have seen what's at stake when people can't access the care they need and when politics gets in the way of people making their own health care choices," Wen said.

The Supreme Court has upheld abortion rights in a series of decisions dating back to 1973. Its most recent ruling struck down restrictions on abortion clinics and providers in Texas two years ago.

**New Inflammatory Disease Linked to COVID-19 Emerges in Children**

A mysterious inflammatory disease, similar to Kawasaki syndrome, has been reported in children across the United States, with a significant number of cases emerging in New York, the nation's coronavirus epicenter. The disease, known as pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome, has been linked to COVID-19, although a causal connection has not been definitively proven.

According to Dr. Charles Schleien, chair of pediatrics at Northwell Health in New York, his hospital has seen about 40 cases of the disease since mid-April, with most patients showing antibodies similar to the coronavirus, indicating they had been infected but had no symptoms of COVID-19. Several others tested positive for the virus but did not exhibit symptoms.

The disease shares some characteristics with Kawasaki syndrome, which typically affects children under 5 years old. Symptoms include prolonged fever, a rash, conjunctivitis, swelling of the palms or soles of the feet, and lymph node enlargement. While the age range for this new disease stretches into adolescence, Dr. Schleien has seen cases in minors as old as 14.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is studying the rare disease and does not have statistics on its incidence. The agency is working with domestic and international partners to better understand and characterize the syndrome, its prevalence, and risk factors.

The children's hospital next to Stanford University may have discovered the first case of the new disease in a 6-month-old baby who was initially diagnosed with Kawasaki, then tested positive for the coronavirus. Dr. Yvonne Maldonado, a professor of pediatric infectious diseases at the university, hosted a webinar to address the case and discussed the possibility that the virus may trigger an intense inflammatory response in some people.

While the exact prevalence and risk factors for the disease are still unknown, Dr. Maldonado emphasized the importance of practicing social distancing and encouraging it on children. She also reassured parents that the disease is rare and treatable, with hospital stays typically lasting two to four days.

Title: Senate Republicans Silence Elizabeth Warren, Elevate Her as Democratic Hero

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and debate, Senate Republicans have silenced Senator Elizabeth Warren, a prominent critic of President Donald Trump, after she read a letter written by Coretta Scott King, the widow of Martin Luther King Jr., opposing the nomination of Jeff Sessions for a federal judgeship. Warren cited the letter during a debate on Sessions' nomination as Donald Trump's attorney general, stating that Sessions had used his office to chill the free exercise of the vote by black citizens in the district he now seeks to serve as a federal judge.

The move has galvanized the Democratic base, with many seeing it as an attempt to suppress Warren's voice and silence her criticism of Trump's administration. Warren's male colleagues, including Senators Tom Udall and Jeff Merkley, were allowed to read from the letter without interruption, sparking accusations of hypocrisy.

Warren is now forbidden from participating in the floor debate over Sessions' nomination, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell citing Rule 19, a rarely used chamber regulation that prohibits senators from impugning each other. Warren has responded by saying she has become a "nonperson" during the discussion of Sessions' nomination.

The incident has sparked a national conversation about the role of women in politics and the importance of free speech. The hashtag #LetLizSpeak has trended on Twitter, with millions of people watching Warren's reading of the letter outside the Senate chamber. MoveOn members have contributed $250,000 to Warren's re-election campaign in just 12 hours.

Warren's actions have also sparked a debate about the role of the Senate and the importance of decorum. Some have argued that Warren's actions were a breach of Senate rules, while others have seen it as a necessary act of defiance in the face of what they see as an unjust and oppressive administration.

The incident has also highlighted the ongoing controversy surrounding Sessions' nomination and the concerns about his views on civil rights and voting rights. Warren's actions have given voice to those concerns and have sparked a national conversation about the importance of protecting the rights of all Americans.

Title: Kissinger Sees Trump as "Extraordinary Opportunity" for US Foreign Relations

Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger believes that President-elect Donald Trump's unconventional rise to power presents an "extraordinary opportunity" for the United States and its foreign relations. In an interview on "Face the Nation," Kissinger expressed optimism about Trump's potential to shape a foreign policy plan, citing his ability to analyze the American situation, develop a strategy, and execute it against his own party's leadership.

Kissinger acknowledged that many experts and politicians had raised concerns about Trump's lack of political experience and brazen rhetoric during the campaign. However, he believes that Trump's appeal and ability to connect with voters could be leveraged to shape a foreign policy plan. "I give him huge credit for having analyzed an aspect of the American situation, developed a strategy, carried it out against the leadership of his own party, and prevailed," Kissinger said.

The former secretary of state also noted that other nations are now faced with the challenge of determining how to engage with Trump as the world leader. He believes that Trump's presidency presents an opportunity for nations to reassess their relationships with the United States and address issues like the complex relationship between the US and China, which he sees as having the potential for mutual benefit.

However, Kissinger also acknowledged that Trump's instinctive approach may need to be tempered with more careful analysis and consideration of the complexities involved. "I think he operates by a kind of instinct that is a different form of analysis as my more academic one," he said. "But he's raised a number of issues that I think are important, very important. And if they're addressed properly, could lead to good – great results."

Title: Republican National Committee Chairman Warns of Consequences for Non-Supportive Republicans

The Republican National Committee (RNC) Chairman, Reince Priebus, has warned that Republicans who refuse to support presidential nominee Donald Trump may face consequences in the future. Speaking on CBS's "Face the Nation," Priebus stated that every Republican who ran in the 2016 election needs to get behind Trump. Those who do not, including Ohio Governor John Kasich, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, and Texas Senator Ted Cruz, may see diminished support from the party moving forward.

Priebus emphasized that those who participated in the nomination process and agreed to support the nominee should get on board. He suggested that the party may re-evaluate its nomination process and make it more difficult for those who do not support Trump to seek the White House again in the future.

Kasich, who did not attend the Republican National Convention in July, stated that it is "very unlikely" he will vote for Trump. Bush and Cruz have also expressed similar sentiments, with Cruz famously withholding an endorsement of Trump during the convention.

Priebus denied that he was threatening Kasich, Cruz, or anyone else, but his comments suggest that the party will put roadblocks in front of the electoral hopes of those who do not offer a full-throated endorsement of Trump.

Kasich emphasized the importance of getting out the vote for Republicans like Senator Rob Portman, who is running for re-election in Ohio. He stated that he will not vote for Hillary Clinton and will let his actions speak louder than his words.

The article does not provide information on Priebus's stance on Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson, as Kasich noted that it is a long way until Election Day.

Title: Trump Breaks Silence on Comey Testimony, Claims "Total and Complete Vindication"

Article:

President Donald Trump broke his silence on Friday, claiming "total and complete vindication" after former FBI Director James Comey's testimony before Congress the day before. Trump's tweet also appeared to accuse Comey of lying under oath and labeling him a "leaker." The accusation, which alleges that Comey committed perjury in his congressional testimony, is the latest broadside Trump has launched against his former FBI director.

Trump's tweet sparked surprise among White House aides, with at least two senior officials expressing surprise at the president's missive slamming Comey. The tweet is part of a larger counteroffensive against Comey, with Trump's outside legal team planning to file a complaint with the Department of Justice inspector general about the so-called leak, in which Comey handed off memos describing his conversations with Trump to a friend who then passed them to The New York Times.

Trump's lawyer, Marc Kasowitz, was criticized for the move, which followed a bellicose statement on Thursday in which Kasowitz accused Comey of lying under oath and inappropriately disclosing the contents of his conversations with Trump. Former Obama ethics adviser Norm Eisen tweeted that the move was an "abuse of process" and warned Kasowitz of "serious consequences."

Trump's tweet did not provide any new information or evidence to support his claims, and many of his fellow Republicans sought to frame Comey's accounts as a misinterpretation rather than a total fabrication. House Speaker Paul Ryan said Trump is "new at this" and "not steeped in the long-running protocols that establish the relationships between DOJ, FBI, and White Houses."

Trump's allies are also eager to shift the conversation to Comey's conduct, with former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski making the president's case on TV news networks. Lewandowski criticized Comey for relaying his notes from meetings with the president to the media through an intermediary, suggesting that the former director should be prosecuted if such a move was part of a regular pattern of behavior.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said Trump's behavior with Comey was "certainly inappropriate" and "an abuse of power," but stopped short of discussing impeachment. Trump is expected to address the controversy further when he holds a joint news conference with the president of Romania on Friday afternoon in the Rose Garden.

Title: ISIS Takes Control of Ramadi, Highlighting Iraq's Military Weakness and Dependence on Shia Militias

The city of Ramadi, the provincial capital of Iraq's western Anbar province, has fallen to ISIS forces, marking the biggest victory for the militant group in nearly a year. This development highlights the fundamental weakness of the Iraqi military and its deep dependence on radical Shia militias. The Iraqi army's inability to hold onto Ramadi, despite being under-resourced for over a year, demonstrates the profound impact of corruption and mass defections during last June's ISIS offensive.

The Iraqi army's core problem is its lack of effective, battle-hardened units to take on ISIS on its own. Even elite special forces units, such as the Golden Division, have been defeated due to being stretched thin across multiple battlefields. This forces the Iraqi army to rely on allies, including the Kurdish peshmerga in the north and violent sectarian Shia militias in the rest of the country.

The militias have proven effective against ISIS on the battlefield, but their political wings are often rivals of Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's Dawa party. The militias were not involved in the fight for Ramadi, as Abadi wanted the army to take the lead and the United States was concerned about the militias' track record of brutalizing Sunni civilians.

The Anbar provincial council has now formally requested militia assistance, which is on its way. The militias are seen as the only speedy mechanism left to help the Iraqi army in Ramadi. Despite ISIS's victory, the militant group remains likely to lose its territory in Iraq, surrounded by enemies and vulnerable to American airstrikes. However, the campaign to defeat ISIS will be a long and difficult one, with the Iraqi army still having a long way to go to become a competent force.

The deep political divides between the Iraqi army and militia leadership are not going away and could lead to a different sort of conflict after ISIS. The anti-ISIS campaign will likely have more setbacks like this one, continuing to devastate Iraq and potentially deepening the Sunni-Shia divides that gave rise to ISIS in the first place.

Title: Private Prison Companies See Surge in Profits Amidst Increased Immigration Enforcement

The Trump administration's plans to expand the capacity of immigrant detention centers have sparked concerns among many, but for private prison companies, it's a windfall. As of November, 65% of ICE detainees were held in facilities operated by private prison companies, which generate revenue through a fee-per-detainee-per-night model. This business model incentivizes companies to minimize costs to maximize profits for their shareholders.

Since Trump's election, private prison stocks have seen a significant surge, and two new for-profit detention centers are set to open in Georgia and Texas. Another private prison company, Management & Training Corp., is seeking a contract with ICE to reopen the Willacy County Correctional Institution, a facility that previously held up to 2,000 ICE detainees in Kevlar tents between 2006 and 2011.

Historically, ICE has relied heavily on the private prison industry during times of detention system expansion, and it is likely that this trend will continue with the current administration's plans to deport millions of undocumented residents. The more aggressive the White House is in pursuing its deportation goals, the larger the detention camps will need to be, and private prison companies stand to benefit.

Private prison companies do not generate profits by prioritizing humane conditions. Detainees may find themselves in facilities previously criticized by other federal agencies for patterns of abuse and neglect. While some may be guilty of overstaying their visas or committing similar crimes, others may be innocent individuals caught in the crossfire of a broader immigration debate.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Scalia Criticizes Obama's Immigration Policy

Article:

Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia expressed skepticism towards President Barack Obama's decision not to enforce certain immigration laws, stating that the Founding Fathers would have "rushed to the exits" if presented with such an idea. Scalia made these comments in his dissenting opinion on the Supreme Court's decision to strike down most of the key provisions of Arizona's SB 1070 immigration law.

Scalia criticized the Obama administration's new policy, which ends the deportation of many young adults brought into the country illegally, saying it is unclear whether states would have entered the union if the Constitution included a clause allowing the president to choose whether to enforce immigration laws. He also questioned whether Arizona's decision to pass its own immigration law was in contradiction to federal law, stating that the state was simply trying to protect its sovereignty.

The Supreme Court upheld a key provision of Arizona's law, requiring police to check the immigration status of those they arrest or stop for questioning, but struck down other parts of the law, citing federal jurisdiction. Scalia argued that the Obama administration's policies, rather than scarce resources, are the problem Arizona faces.

In his dissent, Scalia noted that the new Department of Homeland Security directives will require significant administrative resources, including 1.4 million background checks and biennial rulings on requests for dispensation. He expressed skepticism about the husbanding of scarce enforcement resources being the justification for the new policy.

Title: Congress Faces Difficult Decisions on Government Funding and Debt Ceiling

Congress is approaching a critical deadline to prevent a government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling, with Republicans facing a difficult decision on funding and spending. The House and Senate must pass a continuing resolution by September 30 to keep the government open and funded at current levels, which is likely to be tied to a bill to raise the debt ceiling. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has set a September 29 deadline for the debt ceiling increase, which must be "clean," meaning it should not be tied to spending cuts or reforms demanded by conservatives.

To pass the bill, Republicans will need support from Democrats, giving the minority leverage. Republicans are opposed to funding the government with a continuing resolution because it blocks or postpones their priorities, including funds for President Trump's border wall, significant increases in military spending, and cuts to non-defense discretionary spending. However, the House has only managed to approve four spending bills, and the Senate has not approved any, making a continuing resolution a more likely outcome.

Conservative leaders, such as Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), have expressed resignation to a continuing resolution, citing the difficulty in getting everything done in a piece-by-piece basis. The Senate will still be under pressure to secure a spending deal even with a continuing resolution, as new budget caps under a previous long-term budget deal are set to kick in in January, reducing spending below existing levels unless Congress passes a new law.

Raising the debt ceiling is a difficult vote for most members of Congress, but particularly for Republicans, with 69% of voters opposed to it in a June Harvard-Harris poll. The failure to raise the debt ceiling could lead to a default on the nation's debt, sparking a new financial and economic crisis. Some Republicans, such as Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), are still pushing for some sort of policy reform to hitch to the debt ceiling.

The difficult decisions come as Republicans grapple with a narrative that they are unable to govern, having yet to finalize a major piece of legislation in the first six months of the Trump administration. The GOP will likely have to choose between allowing the government to shut down and default on its debt and making unpopular decisions.

Title: California Utility Shuts Off Power to Hundreds of Thousands to Prevent Wildfires

California residents woke up to darkness on Wednesday as Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) began shutting off power to nearly 800,000 customers in an effort to prevent wildfires during hot and windy weather. The utility company said it cut power to over 500,000 customers in Northern California and plans to gradually turn off electricity to nearly 800,000 customers to reduce the risk of wildfires.

The power outages are expected to affect 34 northern, central, and coastal California counties, with gusty winds of 56 to 72 km/h (35-45 mph) forecasted to sweep the state. The California Department of Forestry and Fire Prevention has increased staffing in preparation for extreme fire weather.

PG&E said it will take up to five days to restore power after the danger has passed, as every inch of power line must be checked to ensure it is not damaged or in danger of sparking a blaze. The utility company has warned of the possibility of widespread outages, prompting residents to prepare for the worst.

The power outages have caused disruptions to daily life, with classes cancelled for thousands of schoolchildren and at the University of California, Berkeley, Sonoma State University, and Mills College. The California Department of Transportation has installed generators to avoid closing the Caldecott Tunnel linking the East Bay to San Francisco and the Tom Lantos Tunnel on State Route 1 in Pacifica.

Residents have been advised to prepare for the outages by having supplies of water for several days, keeping sensitive medicines in cool places, driving carefully due to traffic lights being out, and checking food in freezers and refrigerators for spoilage after power is restored. PG&E has set up community centers offering air conditioning, restrooms, bottled water, and electronic charging stations during daylight hours.

The power outages come as residents in the region's wine country north of San Francisco mark the two-year anniversary of deadly wildfires that killed 44 and destroyed thousands of homes. The California Department of Transportation has activated its emergency centers, and authorities have urged people to be prepared.

Title: The Consequences of a President's Policies and Priorities

The re-election of President Barack Obama has sparked concerns about the future of the country's economy, healthcare, and individual freedoms. The president's policies have been criticized for exacerbating the effects of the recession, increasing the national debt, and expanding the role of the federal government in healthcare and other areas.

According to the article, Obama's presidency has seen a significant increase in federal entitlements, with costs reaching approximately $1.7 trillion annually. This has led to a growing number of individuals receiving these benefits, with half of the country supporting the president's re-election in hopes of receiving more federal cash.

The article also highlights Obama's commitment to expanding the federal government's role in healthcare, with the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) now in place. This means that federal bureaucrats will direct physicians in their treatment of patients, and medical records will be accessible to the government.

Furthermore, the article notes that Obama's second term will likely see a significant increase in the national debt, with the president planning to borrow and spend an additional $5 trillion. This will result in higher interest payments and increased taxes for individuals.

The article concludes by expressing concerns about the long-term consequences of Obama's policies and priorities, including the potential erosion of individual freedoms and the growth of a European-style welfare state.

Title: Wisconsin's Political Personality: A State of Contrasts

Wisconsin is a state known for its unique political personality, defying trends and swinging in unexpected directions. The state has been home to politicians from both the left and the right, including Robert "Fighting Bob" La Follette, a progressive senator, and Joe McCarthy, a conservative senator behind the Communist witch hunts of the 1950s. This dichotomy is not limited to the past, as the state's current senators, Ron Johnson and Tammy Baldwin, represent the widest ideological gulf of any state's senators, according to a 2013 National Journal ranking of voting records.

Wisconsin's political landscape is characterized by its ability to pivot in unexpected directions. According to Rutgers University political science professor Ross Baker, "Wisconsin defies political trends. It doesn't swing, it pivots." The state's voters are sharply polarized, with a small swing vote deciding elections. This polarization has been exacerbated in the last decade, making it difficult for politicians to find common ground and compromise.

The state's political history is marked by its ability to elect politicians from both sides of the aisle. Paul Soglin, a civil rights and anti-Vietnam War activist, was elected mayor of Madison in 1973, while William Dyke, an ultra-conservative, was elected mayor in 1971. The state has also been home to liberal politicians like William Proxmire, who was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1957, and Russ Feingold, who served from 1993 to 2011.

Governor Scott Walker's recent bid for the Republican presidential nomination is a prime example of Wisconsin's political unpredictability. Walker's ability to win two elections as governor and survive a recall election in a swing state with a strong liberal tradition is a testament to the state's unique political personality.

According to University of Wisconsin-Madison political science and journalism professor Michael Wagner, the state's politics "look pretty schizophrenic to people on the outside — and the inside, too." Wagner attributes the state's polarization to the increasing divide between voters, which has become more exacerbated in the last decade. The state's lack of diversity, with whites making up 88% of the population, also plays a role in the polarization.

The consequences of this polarization are evident in the state's inability to find common ground and compromise. According to Wagner, "compromise is not possible with such polarization." This lack of cooperation has led to a lack of progress in Washington, with politicians prioritizing winning over finding solutions.

Wisconsin's unique political personality is a reflection of its complex history and demographics. As the state continues to navigate its political landscape, it remains to be seen whether it will continue to defy trends and pivot in unexpected directions.

Title: The Erosion of Constitutional Guardrails: A Threat to Democracy

The concept of "guardrails" has taken on a new meaning in the political arena, as The Wall Street Journal's Kimberley Strassel has pointed out. In the context of driving, guardrails serve as a safety measure to prevent accidents and ensure a safe journey. Similarly, in politics, guardrails are essential to prevent the abuse of power and ensure accountability. However, it appears that many politicians have abandoned these constitutional guardrails, leading to a worrying trend.

Strassel highlights the examples of former President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, who have demonstrated a willingness to bypass Congress and impose their will through executive actions. This lack of restraint is not limited to the Democratic Party, as some Republicans have also shown a disregard for constitutional limits. The article notes that politicians seem to believe that being "strong" and "leadership" are synonymous with disregarding constitutional restraints.

The article also touches on the Clinton Foundation, which has been criticized for its questionable charitable activities. While some may argue that the foundation is a legitimate organization, others believe it is a means for the Clintons to maintain their political influence and personal interests. The article questions the lack of accountability and transparency surrounding the foundation's activities.

The erosion of constitutional guardrails is not limited to individual politicians. The article notes that both parties have been guilty of using the IRS to target their political opponents, rather than upholding its intended purpose of collecting taxes and regulating the economy. The article also highlights the reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank, which was quietly done without much fanfare, despite being a significant departure from the original intent of the Constitution.

The article concludes by lamenting the lack of attention given to constitutional restraints and the importance of humility in politics. It notes that politicians who prioritize modest, constitutional approaches to governance often go unnoticed, while those who promise grand, sweeping changes tend to garner more attention and support. The article ends by emphasizing the need for a return to constitutional principles and the importance of holding politicians accountable for their actions.

Title: Voters Prioritize Washington Gridlock as Nation's Most Pressing Problem Ahead of 2013 Elections

The latest Battleground Poll, conducted by Republican pollster Ed Goeas and Democratic pollster Celinda Lake, reveals a grim political environment in the United States as the country heads into the 2013 elections. The survey of 1,011 registered likely voters found that 73% believe the country is on the wrong track, with 26% citing government gridlock as the most important problem, surpassing jobs and the economy.

According to the poll, 87% of voters disapprove of Congress's performance, while only 9% approve. The survey also found that 50% of those polled disapprove of their own member of Congress, with 39% approving and 11% unsure. Republicans in Congress received worse ratings than Democrats, with 65% of voters having an unfavorable view.

The government shutdown last month, largely driven by the demands of tea party activists, played a significant role in these numbers, both strategists said. The poll also found that only 54% of those polled had an unfavorable impression of the tea party, 11 points lower than the disapproval level for Republicans.

The survey also presents bad news for President Obama, with his approval rating standing at 44%, and 52% disapproving. Obama's personal ratings are also down, with 47% of those surveyed having a favorable view and 50% holding unfavorable views. This marks the first time in the Battleground survey that Obama has had both a majority unfavorable image and majority disapproval of his job performance.

The poll results suggest that the key question is whether President Obama has lost the ability to lead the country. According to Goeas, once a president's numbers decline in their second term, they never come back up, and once a president loses the trust of the American people, they never gain it back. The current issues with healthcare have the potential to further erode Obama's trust with the American people.

Title: Trump's Corporate Tax Rate Remark Sparks Debate in Congress

Article:

Washington, D.C. - President Donald Trump's recent comment about a potential scaled-back tax cut for corporations has sparked behind-the-scenes debate in the U.S. Congress. The remark, made on Saturday, suggested that the corporate tax rate in the final legislation could be 22 percent, rather than the 20 percent proposed in the Senate and House of Representatives' tax bills.

The comment has whetted the interest of some Republicans who see a slight upward bump in the proposed corporate tax rate as capturing needed federal revenue that would help solve other problems with the legislation. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, who is expected to head a bicameral House-Senate negotiating committee, stated that the 20 percent rate should be the goal.

However, White House legislative affairs director Marc Short clarified that Trump's comment was not an endorsement of raising the corporate rate, but rather a reflection of conversations he had with Republican senators. Short emphasized that the administration believes 20 percent is the right number and that they are not comfortable going higher.

The debate over the corporate tax rate is significant, as it could impact the overall cost of the tax overhaul. Analysts say that a one percentage point change in the corporate rate equals about $100 billion in revenues over a decade. The corporate income tax rate could be a ready source of revenue for lawmakers as they move toward a final bill that can lose no more than $1.5 trillion in revenue over the next decade under Senate rules.

The debate is also significant because it could impact the overall cost of the tax overhaul. Republicans are considering a more costly deduction for state and local taxes than the $10,000 property tax deduction contained in the House and Senate bills. One version would allow taxpayers to choose a $10,000 deduction for either property or income taxes. House lawmakers also want to adopt the House bill's repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax, which would cost about $40 billion in revenue over a decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation.

Title: Trump Signals Immediate Talks with Democrats on Border Security, Warns of Challenges

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that talks with congressional Democrats on border security measures will begin immediately, but warned that reaching a compromise within the next three weeks will not be easy. The president's statement came after he signed a bill to fund the government until February 15, ending the longest shutdown in U.S. history.

In a series of tweets, Trump emphasized the importance of building a wall along the southern border, citing the approaching caravan of Central American migrants as justification. He stated that a powerful wall would prevent them from attempting the long and dangerous journey. The president also reiterated his commitment to securing funding for the wall in upcoming talks with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.

Trump's tweets covered a range of topics, including border security, the indictment of Roger Stone, and the Republican National Committee's pledge of support for the president in the 2020 election. He also emphasized that only "fools or people with a political agenda" would oppose building a wall or steel barrier to protect the country from crime, drugs, and human trafficking.

In a separate tweet, Trump clarified that his decision to sign the bill was not a concession, but rather a move to take care of millions of people affected by the shutdown, with the understanding that negotiations will resume in 21 days.

Title: Kushner Urges Governors to Take Charge of Supplies, Amid Scrutiny Over His Role in Pandemic Response

Article:

Jared Kushner, President Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, has been thrust into the spotlight as the administration's point man on the coronavirus pandemic. In a rare appearance in the White House briefing room, Kushner urged governors to take charge of their own supplies and not rely solely on the federal government for help.

Kushner, a real estate executive with no public health expertise, has been working closely with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to oversee the distribution of medical supplies to hospitals and healthcare providers. He has emerged as a key player in the administration's efforts to combat the pandemic, but his lack of experience has drawn scrutiny.

Kushner's comments have sparked controversy, with some governors and experts questioning his role in the response. Kansas Governor Laura Kelly, a Democrat, dismissed Kushner's remarks, saying that the national stockpile is intended to be a backup for states, not a federal reserve. The Department of Health and Human Services has since changed its language on the national stockpile to reflect Kushner's description.

Trump has defended Kushner, saying he is "talking about our country" and that the federal government needs the supplies as well. However, some experts have raised concerns about Kushner's lack of experience and the lack of transparency in his role.

Kushner's connections to the president and his ability to work with FEMA and the U.S. military have been seen as strengths, but some have questioned his ability to oversee a response of this scale. Craig Fugate, who ran FEMA during the Obama administration, said that the federal government cannot base decisions on requests and that the coronavirus is moving too fast for states to keep up.

Ethics groups have also raised concerns about Kushner's role, saying that it is akin to overseeing a shadow task force with no oversight. Andy Slavitt, the Obama-era administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, called the current crisis an all-hands-on-deck effort and said that roles need to be clear and execution more coordinated.

**Obama Visits Orlando, Calls for Action on Gun Violence and Terrorism**

President Barack Obama visited Orlando, Florida, on Thursday, where he met with survivors of the recent mass shooting at a gay nightclub and relatives of the 49 people killed. The President urged Congress to pass measures to make it harder to legally acquire high-powered weapons like the semi-automatic rifle used in the attack.

During his visit, Obama laid flowers at a memorial for the victims and held and hugged grieving family members and parents, who asked, "Why does this keep happening?" He emphasized the need for the United States to act to control gun violence and fight homegrown terrorism.

The President also praised the Senate's decision to hold votes on preventing individuals with possible terrorist ties from buying guns. "I'm pleased to hear that the Senate will hold votes on preventing individuals with possible terrorist ties from buying guns," he said.

The mass shooting, which occurred on Sunday, was carried out by Omar Mateen, a U.S.-born gunman claiming allegiance to various Islamist militant groups. Mateen, 29, was killed by police after exchanging text messages with his wife and posting on Facebook during the attack.

The FBI has not found any direct link between Mateen and militants abroad, according to CIA Director John Brennan. The agency has been investigating Mateen's background and motivations.

The attack has sparked a new debate over how the United States responds to Islamist militant violence at home and abroad. Republican Senator John McCain has said he views President Obama as "directly responsible" for the Orlando attack due to his failure to prevent the rise of Islamic State. However, McCain later clarified his statement, saying he was referring to Obama's national security decisions, not the President himself.

The attack has also put pressure on Congress to act on gun control measures. Democrats have been pushing for stricter gun control laws, while Republicans have blocked several Democratic-backed measures in the past. The Senate is expected to hold votes on Monday on four gun control measures, including expanding background checks and preventing people on U.S. terrorism watch lists from buying guns.

Title: Congress Shows Signs of Productivity Despite Polarization

Article:

The 113th Congress, which began after the 2010 tea party wave and President Obama's reelection, has shown signs of increased productivity despite the rancor and polarization on Capitol Hill. This development is a departure from the 112th Congress, which was the least productive in over 60 years.

The year started with a bipartisan group of senior senators working together to address the filibuster, a contentious Senate tool. In March, the Violence Against Women Act was passed, a long-delayed measure that had been stalled for years. More recently, House and Senate lawmakers worked together to pass a bill to keep the government funded through the end of the fiscal year, without the usual protests that accompany such measures.

While not all legislative initiatives have yielded the desired results, bipartisan activity is underway on major issues like strengthening gun control, immigration reform, and a "grand bargain" on taxes and entitlement programs. This increased willingness to compromise is a departure from the past, where polarization and ideological differences have made it difficult to find common ground.

Many of the obstacles to congressional deal-making have been building for years and are not unique to Washington's current dysfunction. The sharp divide among lawmakers reflects the polarization among voters who sent them to Congress. Deep-pocketed advocacy groups with intense ideological focuses have also hardened lawmakers' positions, making it more difficult to depart from the party line.

The increasing amount of money needed to run for Congress means lawmakers spend more time fundraising and less time studying issues or forging relationships with colleagues, the foundation of deal-making. The frequency of "wave" elections, where electoral victories create cliques of lawmakers with narrow mandates, has also contributed to the gridlock.

Members elected in these waves are less likely to make deals that go against what their constituents want, says former Rep. Steven LaTourette (R-OH). "On 'Obamacare,' you don't hear a lot of the 2010 class say, 'Well, let's save the good parts and jettison the rest.' It's'repeal, repeal, repeal,' because that was the war drum on the campaign trail."

Despite the tough constraints, today's congressional deal-makers are not coming from either party's moderate wing, as many have been defeated or left office due to frustration with the toxic atmosphere on the Hill or fear of a primary challenge. Instead, it's up to lawmakers respected on both sides, like Sen. Tom Coburn (R-OK) and Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), to get things done.

Getting lawmakers from both ends of the spectrum to sit down together can be aided by what might be called political entrepreneurs, like Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), who are willing to tackle sensitive issues before their parties are willing to do the same. Bringing disparate politicians together on new ideas is another matter, often done through old-fashioned bargaining in the backroom, where lawmakers can make concessions key to compromise.

The public's general disdain for gridlock and voters' outspokenness on individual issues are other factors that may force more compromise. "Sometimes deal-makers gain strength when there is some kind of social pressure to do something," says congressional historian Julian Zelizer.

Title: Republicans and Independent Break Ranks to Condemn President's Language, but Party Leaders Push Patriotism Messages

The House vote on Tuesday saw only four Republicans and one independent break ranks to condemn the president's language, a stark reminder of the party's shift away from its once-welcoming stance towards Latino and African-American voters. Instead, party leaders are pushing messages of patriotism, with some attempting to sidestep the racial implications and others seemingly less concerned about potential backlash.

Kellyanne Conway, the president's counselor, criticized the four Republicans who voted against the president, calling them a "dark underbelly" of people in the country. Others, like Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, sought to reframe and soften the message, emphasizing that opposition to socialist policies has nothing to do with gender, religion, or race, but rather the content of those policies.

The election is still over 15 months away, and Democrats will eventually have a standard-bearer to define the party in opposition to the president. Some Democrats worry that criticism of the four Republicans will resonate with a segment of their voters and independents who may be uneasy with the policies and rhetoric of both parties.

The Democrats who fared best in the midterms were those who downplayed the president while highlighting issues like protecting health insurance for people with pre-existing conditions. Many strategists rallying behind former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. believe the party can't count on increasing turnout among young people and minorities and needs to lure back voters it lost to the president.

Title: Republicans Fail to Secure Enough Support for American Healthcare Act, Will Try Again

Article:

The Republican-led effort to pass the American Healthcare Act (AHCA) on Thursday did not garner enough support, and the bill will be put to the test again on Friday morning. According to White House Director Mick Mulvaney, President Trump told House Republicans that it is now or never, and the time for negotiating is over. If the bill does not pass this time, the party will be stuck with the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare.

The bill, which aims to replace the ACA, has faced opposition from both Democrats and some Republicans. Conservatives are rejecting the bill, calling it "Obamacare 2.0" or "Obamacare Lite," as it does not fully repeal the ACA. Moderates are concerned that rolling back the Medicaid expansion would leave many without insurance, while others criticize the bill for not doing enough to control rising premium costs.

Despite efforts to make changes to the bill, including a manager's amendment and discussions about removing Obamacare "essential benefits," the bill remains unpopular among some Republicans. At least three senators, Rand Paul, Mike Lee, and Tom Cotton, have already expressed their opposition, and four other senators have objected to the treatment of the Medicaid expansion in the bill. If three Republican senators vote against the bill, it will die in the Senate, which has a slim 52-48 Republican majority.

The House Republicans need 215 votes to pass the bill, and some are hesitant to cast a difficult vote for a measure that may be destined to fail. The list of House Republicans who cannot support the bill in its current form is subject to change, with many still undecided or open to negotiations. The outcome of the vote remains uncertain, with the stakes high for both the party and individual lawmakers.

Title: Republicans Abandon Health Care Bill, Admit Defeat on Replacing Obamacare

The House Republicans have scrapped a vote on their health care replacement plan, acknowledging that it would not pass due to defections from both the right and center. House Speaker Paul Ryan admitted that "Obamacare is the law of the land" and that the party will be living with it for the foreseeable future.

The failure of the health care bill is a significant setback for President Trump's leadership and House Speaker Ryan's ability to control their conference. The bill's inability to garner support from both parties has left the Republican Party's image as a governing party in question.

Trump and Ryan have shifted their focus to tax reform, putting health care on the backburner for the time being. Trump described the experience as a "learning experience" and expressed optimism about the potential for a bipartisan bill in the future.

The failure of the health care bill has raised questions about Trump's ability to deliver on his campaign promises and his lack of legislative and policy experience. The bill's inability to pass has also put a cloud over the legislative path forward, making it unclear whether Republicans will try again.

The Freedom Caucus, a group of hard-line conservatives, had refused to budge from their ideological objections to the bill, and moderates had also expressed concerns about the bill's impact on their constituents. The bill's failure has left the Republican Party's leadership scrambling to regroup and reassess their strategy.

In a statement, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi celebrated the defeat, saying it was a "victory for us" and a testament to the strength of the Affordable Care Act. The failure of the health care bill has significant implications for the Republican Party's agenda and Trump's presidency, and it remains to be seen how they will move forward.

Title: President Trump Embraces Government Shutdown as "Proud Owner" of Border Wall

President Donald Trump has taken ownership of the ongoing government shutdown, which is now his third, and seems to be accepting of the possibility of an extended closure. According to White House aides and Trump allies, the president prioritizes building a border wall and appearing as a "border warrior" over concerns about the shutdown's impact.

The shutdown, which began on December 22, is a result of Trump's refusal to sign a spending bill that does not include funding for his signature border wall. The president has dug in on his position, meeting with hard-line conservatives and signaling through his top aides that he is willing to accept a prolonged shutdown.

Some Republicans, such as Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, have criticized Trump's decision, calling it a "made-up fight" to make him look like he is fighting for the wall. However, others, like Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, have rallied behind the president, arguing that Democrats are responsible for the shutdown and that the wall is necessary for national security.

The shutdown has also become a political tool for Trump's reelection campaign, with the president's supporters being urged to donate to "Build the Wall" and share petitions. The White House has long seen the border wall as an indicator of Trump's ability to keep promises and deliver results.

While the wall remains a contentious issue, Trump's allies believe that the shutdown is a necessary step to demonstrate his commitment to the issue and to make Democrats look obstructionist. The president's opponents, however, see the shutdown as a reckless and unnecessary move that will harm the country and its citizens.

Title: House Republicans Gain Momentum to Force Votes on Immigration Bills Amid Frustration with Leadership

Article:

A growing number of House Republicans are pushing to force votes on various immigration bills, despite Speaker Paul Ryan's opposition. Representative Jeff Denham (R-CA) has led the effort to gather support for a discharge petition, which would put forward floor votes on immigration. As of Thursday, Denham claimed to have enough support to force a vote, but he continues to negotiate behind closed doors to find a compromise bill that leadership can bring up.

The Republican leadership is not pleased with the development, with Ryan stating that the process would "lose control" on the House floor. However, it appears that rank-and-file members are increasingly frustrated with deferring to leadership. James Wallner, a political scientist and former executive director of the Senate Steering Committee, noted that when members "look behind the curtain and the emperor has no clothes, then it becomes contagious, and that's what leaders don't like."

The House seems poised for another fight on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which has been a contentious issue. House Republican leaders have made it clear that they do not want their members to sign on to the discharge petition, fearing it will devolve into chaos and reveal deep discord in the party.

Despite the opposition, support for the petition is growing, with Denham driving the process. He is eager to pass a DACA fix, and he is not alone in pushing past leadership's timeline. A bipartisan group of senators defied Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and voted to overturn the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) controversial ruling to dismantle net neutrality.

The fight will have a difficult road ahead, requiring a vote in the House and Senate and the signature of the president or a veto-proof majority. President Trump is unlikely to sign such a bill. The article highlights three methods for rank-and-file lawmakers to take control: the Congressional Review Act, Rule 14, and discharge petitions. While these methods are available, they are not always used, as lawmakers often prioritize party unity and control.

The article concludes that it is not easy for rank-and-file lawmakers to force leadership's hand, but there are ways to do it. The current situation may be a sign that lawmakers are becoming frustrated with deferring to leadership and are seeking more control over the legislative process.

Title: Lori Lightfoot Wins Chicago Mayoral Election, Becomes First Black Woman and Openly Gay Person to Lead City

Chicago's former federal prosecutor, Lori Lightfoot, has won the city's mayoral election, defeating longtime political insider Toni Preckwinkle. Lightfoot's victory marks a historic milestone, making her the first black woman and openly gay person to lead the nation's third-largest city.

Lightfoot, who had never held public office before, campaigned on a platform of ridding City Hall of corruption and helping low-income and working-class residents who felt "left behind and ignored" by the city's political elite. Her message resonated with voters tired of political scandals and insider deals, who felt the city's leaders had prioritized downtown development at the expense of neighborhoods.

Lightfoot promised to break the city's "endless cycle of corruption" and ensure that politicians no longer profit from their positions. She also vowed to invest in neighborhoods on the West and South Sides and bring transparency and accountability to City Hall.

Preckwinkle, who served in the City Council for 19 years and was chairwoman of the Cook County Democratic Party, emphasized her experience and ability to "transform institutions and communities." She argued that Lightfoot lacked the necessary experience for the job and was too focused on "talking about change" rather than actually implementing it.

The campaign between the two women was marked by contentious ads and debates, with Preckwinkle criticizing Lightfoot's work as a corporate lawyer and her experience in police oversight positions under former Mayor Rahm Emanuel. Lightfoot responded by accusing Preckwinkle of being too close to the city's political establishment and trying to take advantage of her opponent's lack of experience.

Despite their differences, both candidates expressed support for similar ideas to boost the city's finances, including a casino in Chicago and changing the state's income tax system to a graduated tax. Lightfoot will be sworn in as mayor on May 20, making Chicago the largest U.S. city to elect a black woman as mayor.

Title: Rand Paul Stages Longest Senate Filibuster in Recent Memory, Raising Concerns Over Drone Strikes

Article:

Kentucky Senator Rand Paul staged a marathon 12-hour filibuster in the Senate, pushing against the confirmation of President Barack Obama's nominee to run the CIA, John Brennan. Paul's effort, which began on Wednesday and ended early Thursday, was the longest talking filibuster in recent Senate history. The libertarian senator spoke for over 12 hours, railing against the potential use of drone strikes against U.S. citizens on American soil.

Paul's filibuster gained momentum as the day wore on, with several of his colleagues joining him to express concerns over the Obama administration's refusal to rule out the use of drones against Americans in the U.S. or to disclose more information about drone policy. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, among others, joined Paul on the floor, using quotes from Ronald Reagan, Shakespeare, and even rapper Jay-Z to make their points.

The filibuster was not without its strategic moments, with Paul admitting to using the Senate's candy drawer to keep his energy up and not drinking much water to avoid needing to take a break. Despite his exhaustion, Paul acknowledged that he had not taken a steam bath like Strom Thurmond, who held the record for the longest filibuster at 24 hours.

The unusual display of endurance and determination by Paul and his colleagues has sparked a national conversation about the use of drones and the balance between national security and individual liberties.
