Title: Trump to Request $8.6 Billion for Border Wall in 2020 Budget Proposal

President Donald Trump is set to request $8.6 billion for his long-promised wall along the U.S.-Mexico border when he submits his 2020 congressional budget on Monday. The funding would be used to build or replace approximately 700 miles of barriers along the border. The proposal is expected to spark another funding standoff with Congress, as Democrats have already expressed opposition to the plan.

According to Reuters, the funding would be pulled from the Department of Homeland Security budget and the military construction budget at the Pentagon. The proposal would also include $3.6 million in military construction funding to help fund projects affected by the wall.

In addition to wall funding, Trump's proposal would call for the hiring of an additional 2,800 law enforcement and other personnel to reinforce the border and 100 immigration judge teams.

The proposal is likely to face stiff opposition in the Democrat-held House, with Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer stating that the $8.6 billion ask is a "non-starter." They argue that Trump's previous attempts to secure funding for the wall have caused harm to millions of Americans and caused widespread chaos.

Congress must approve funding for fiscal 2020 by October 1, or funding could lapse and the government could shut down. Trump's requests for border funding have shifted during his time in office, with his administration's proposal for fiscal year 2019 seeking $18 billion for the wall.

The proposal has drawn criticism from some, with Larry Kudlow, Trump's top economic adviser, acknowledging that the request for wall funding is likely to spur another fight with Congress. However, he emphasized the importance of border security and the need for a "constructive immigration policy."

Title: Democrats Unveil Platform, Emphasize Economic Growth and Middle-Class Security

The Democratic National Convention kicked off in Charlotte, North Carolina, with Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, chair of the Democratic National Convention, outlining the party's plan to get the country back on track. Villaraigosa emphasized that the election is a choice between building an economy from the middle out versus building it from the top down.

The Democratic Party will finalize its platform by the end of the convention on Thursday night, according to Villaraigosa. The platform will outline the party's stance on key issues and provide a clear plan for the country's future. National Committee Secretary Alice Germond highlighted the transparency of the Democratic platform, stating that by the time President Obama delivers his acceptance speech on Thursday evening, everyone will have a copy of the platform.

The Obama campaign's National Press Secretary, Ben LaBolt, emphasized the importance of addressing the middle class and securing its future. LaBolt noted that the recent Gallup poll found that Americans were not impressed with Mitt Romney's acceptance speech, which was seen as lacking substance and focused on attacking President Obama. LaBolt stated that the Obama campaign will use the convention to answer questions about the middle class and have an honest conversation about the country's progress since 2008.

The Obama campaign is touting its accomplishments, including stopping an economic catastrophe, saving the auto industry, and passing a landmark healthcare law. LaBolt emphasized that the president will use his speech on Thursday to lay out his plans to continue moving forward and securing the middle class.

Title: Obama's Final Acts: A Shift in Tone and Policy

Article:

In his final days in office, President Barack Obama took two significant actions that have been met with controversy and criticism. The first was the commutation of Chelsea Manning's sentence, a move seen as a betrayal of national security and a disregard for the lives of American soldiers and allies. Manning, a former Army intelligence analyst, was convicted of leaking classified information to WikiLeaks, which led to the release of sensitive military and State Department documents. The leak put the lives of American troops and local allies at risk, with intelligence sources suggesting that the Taliban launched a "killing spree" against those who fit the description of individuals working with the United States.

The second action was the United States' decision to abstain from a United Nations Security Council vote on a resolution condemning Israel, a move seen as a betrayal of the country's long-standing ally. This decision was met with widespread criticism and concern, with some arguing that it was a deliberate attempt to harm Israel's interests.

Both actions have been criticized for their perceived hypocrisy, with some arguing that they are a departure from Obama's previous stance on national security and his commitment to protecting American interests. The commutation of Manning's sentence, in particular, has been seen as a betrayal of the country's national security and a disregard for the lives of American soldiers and allies.

The article suggests that these actions may be a reflection of Obama's true beliefs and values, rather than a calculated attempt to curry favor with the international left. The author argues that Obama's actions are a demonstration of his authenticity and a return to his roots as a man of the left.

Title: US Secretary of State John Kerry Seeks Broad Coalition to Fight Islamic State

Article:

US Secretary of State John Kerry is currently in Saudi Arabia, attempting to forge a broad coalition of partners to join the US fight against the Islamic State, a key part of a strategy unveiled by President Obama in his national address yesterday. The US is seeking support from Middle Eastern nations to establish military bases and overflight for airstrikes, as well as better coordination to stop individuals from sending money to extremist groups.

Kerry will push to stop ISIL oil smuggling through the Jordanian and Turkish borders, where authorities have pledged to do all they can to stop it, but Washington will work with them more intently over the next few weeks on intelligence sharing and border control, according to Voice of America.

The talks include leaders from Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Jordan, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman, and Qatar. Obama said last night that the US will be joined by a broad coalition of partners, and Kerry will travel across the Middle East and Europe to enlist more partners in this fight, especially Arab nations who can help mobilize Sunni communities in Iraq and Syria to drive these terrorists from their lands.

Saudi Arabia is key to a successful coalition, especially because of their religious significance with Sunnis, the US official told VOA. Islamic State fighters are Sunni. However, the challenges do not stop there. Many of the countries crucial to the coalition are deeply skeptical of the US commitment to follow through on its promises to oust the Islamic State, after it balked at airstrikes last year against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

The US is also seeking to arm "moderate" Syrian rebels, but this is fraught with uncertainty. The recent US airstrikes in Iraq have destroyed weapons and vehicles the US had previously supplied to the Iraqi Army, which collapsed in the face of the IS offensive on Mosul earlier this summer.

After his tour through the Middle East, Secretary of State Kerry will move to Europe, where he should get a warmer response from governments worried by the fact that hundreds of Europeans have left to fight in Syria. France has played the most public supporting role so far, pledging to act in an international coalition if international law is followed. The UK has also agreed to send a limited amount of arms to Kurds in Iraq to fight the Islamic State.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Agrees to Cooperate with Federal Investigators

Article:

George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser, has agreed to cooperate with federal investigators as part of his plea deal, according to court documents released on Monday. The 30-year-old energy consultant was arrested in July on charges of lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russians. As part of his plea deal, Papadopoulos acknowledged that he lied to agents during a January interview about his interactions with three Russian nationals.

Papadopoulos initially claimed that he knew the Russians prior to joining the Trump campaign in March 2016, but investigators obtained his emails and social media exchanges, which showed that he was lying. He discussed arranging meetings between Russian government officials and the Trump campaign, and one of his contacts, a London-based professor, told him in April that the Russian government had obtained "thousands" of Hillary Clinton's emails.

The White House downplayed the revelations, stating that Papadopoulos played a small part on the campaign and that the Trump team did not collude with the Russian government. Papadopoulos' plea deal and earlier arrest remained a closely held secret until Monday, just hours after the Office of Special Counsel Robert Mueller unsealed an indictment against former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his business associate, Rick Gates.

The revelation that Papadopoulos was serving as a "proactive cooperator" has sparked widespread speculation about how much he has done to help the Mueller team. Some experts believe that Papadopoulos may have worn a wire or recorded conversations with Trump associates as part of his cooperation agreement. Recordings of these conversations could have been used to approach additional subjects.

Legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin said on CNN that the government's disclosure strongly suggests that Papadopoulos was wearing a wire or recording conversations with Trump associates. "What this says to me is that Papadopoulos between July and October was wearing a wire. He was recording conversations secretly with people who are subjects and targets of this investigation," he said.

The exact nature of Papadopoulos' cooperation remains unclear, but his agreement to cooperate with investigators has sparked a new chapter of possibilities in the investigation.

**Barr's Nomination for Attorney General to Face Scrutiny Over Mueller Investigation**

The Senate Judiciary Committee is preparing to hold hearings on William Barr's nomination for attorney general, with special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation expected to be a major focus. Several Senate Democrats plan to question Barr about his views on the investigation, specifically a memo he wrote last year to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, in which he criticized Mueller's investigation into possible obstruction of justice as "fatally misconceived."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has expressed concerns about Barr's nomination, stating that his memo suggests the president is above the law. Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) has also expressed concerns, saying he will ask Barr if he will stop political interference in the special counsel's probe and whether he will recuse himself from overseeing the investigation if he cannot provide an "ironclad" commitment to protecting Mueller.

The nomination comes at a critical time, with the Justice Department in transition and Mueller's probe entering its 20th month. The investigation has resulted in seven guilty pleas and one conviction, including that of President Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort.

Senate Republicans are preparing for a potentially confrontational hearing, with Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) predicting that Democrats will try to block Barr's confirmation. Despite this, Senate Republicans remain confident that Barr will be confirmed, citing their expanded majority in the midterm elections.

Barr met with Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and former Committee Chair Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), who expressed support for Barr's nomination and said Barr reassured him of his respect for Mueller.

Title: Healthcare Marketplace Renewals to Begin November 15, with Potential for Increased Prices

The Affordable Care Act's healthcare marketplace will reopen for renewals on November 15, with individuals who are renewing or enrolling for the first time having until December 15 to secure a new plan for the 2015 coverage year. The renewal process is still being finalized, with details expected to be released in the coming weeks.

For those who prefer to stay with their current plan, the process will be similar to renewing employer-sponsored coverage, with the option to "do nothing" and automatically renew their coverage. The federal online marketplace is being updated to allow for renewals, with the goal of making the process as easy as possible for consumers.

According to Andrew Slavitt, principal deputy administrator for Medicare, which oversees the insurance marketplaces, the government is working to simplify the renewal process. "We're putting in place the simplest path for consumers this year to renew their coverage," he said.

The number of insurance carriers participating in the marketplaces is increasing, with 30 carriers requesting entrance into the marketplaces for 2015, compared to 19 last year. This means more options for consumers, with 1.6 times more plans being offered. However, prices for 2015 are likely to remain varied, with some plans increasing by about 30 percent and others decreasing by the same amount, depending on the market and policy.

According to Erica Hutchins Coe, a McKinsey expert, "We are definitely seeing a lot of volatility in pricing." The exact impact of these changes on individual consumers remains to be seen, with the renewal process still in its early stages.

Title: Ferguson October: A Weekend of Protests and Civil Disobedience in Missouri

Ferguson, Missouri, was the site of a weekend of protests and civil disobedience, known as Ferguson October, as activists, students, clergy, and concerned citizens gathered to demand change and justice. The event was sparked by the death of John Crawford, who was shot and killed in a Wal-Mart store in Ohio. Protesters took over four Wal-Mart stores in solidarity with Crawford's family and to highlight the systemic racism and police brutality that led to his death.

The protests were not limited to Wal-Mart stores, as activists also disrupted a St. Louis Rams game and confronted fans who yelled "I am Darren Wilson," a reference to the officer who killed Michael Brown. The protests also included sit-ins, marches, and civil disobedience, with many participants being arrested.

The Ferguson October protests were not just about John Crawford's death, but about the broader issues of systemic racism and police brutality that affect the Black community. The protests were also about the need for change and the importance of staying woke and vigilant.

The article highlights the role of young people in the protests, who are taking over public spaces and using creative tactics to make their voices heard. The article also notes that the protests are not just about the past, but about the future and the kind of America that people want to build.

The article also touches on the theme of the power of local governments and the limitations of federal jurisdiction, but notes that the real issue is not about the power of government, but about the symbols and substance of the movement. The article concludes that the Ferguson October protests are about what kind of America people want to build and whether they are willing to fight for it.

Title: Alejandro Mayorkas Denies Allegations of Improperly Helping Company Obtain Visa

Alejandro Mayorkas, the director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee on Thursday, denying allegations that he improperly helped a company run by Hillary Clinton's brother obtain a visa. Mayorkas is under investigation by the department's inspector general, which is looking into his role in helping secure a foreign investor visa for Tony Rodham's Gulf Coast Funds Management, even after the application was denied and an appeal rejected.

Mayorkas stated that he "made no orders" in these cases and that he only offers guidance based on the "facts" and "the law." He also emphasized that he has "never, ever in my career exercised undue influence to influence the outcome of a case." Mayorkas expressed surprise and confusion about the investigation, saying he had "no idea" he was under investigation and "quite frankly, I still don't understand it."

The investigation is focused on Mayorkas' role in helping secure a foreign investor visa for Tony Rodham's Gulf Coast Funds Management, which is part of the EB-5 program. The program allows foreigners to get visas if they invest $500,000 to $1 million in projects or businesses that create jobs for U.S. citizens. The amount of the investment required depends on the type of project. Investors who are approved for the program can become legal permanent residents after two years and can later be eligible to become citizens.

The inspector general's office has confirmed that it is investigating Mayorkas' role in helping secure the visa, and has identified subsequent allegations of conflicts of interest, misuse of position, mismanagement of the EB-5 program, and an appearance of impropriety by Mayorkas and other USCIS management officials. The investigation is ongoing, and the inspector general's office has not yet made any findings of criminal misconduct.

The controversy surrounding Mayorkas' nomination has sparked a heated debate among lawmakers, with Republicans calling for the hearing to be postponed until the investigation is complete. However, Senate Democrats have expressed confidence in Mayorkas' qualifications and have moved forward with the hearing. If confirmed, Mayorkas would temporarily lead the Department of Homeland Security, which has 240,000 employees.

Title: Congress Weighs Options to Halt President's Immigration Action

Congress is considering its options to halt President Obama's executive action on immigration, despite the president's use of a fee-based agency to carry out most of the key work. The Congressional Research Service (CRS) has concluded that federal courts have recognized broad congressional powers to stop the president by denying him funding for his proposed actions.

The CRS, in a letter to Senator Jeff Sessions, stated that federal courts have established that Congress can dictate how an agency spends its funds, even if the agency is fee-based. The agency's funds are technically part of the overall government fund and are reappropriated to the agency, making them subject to congressional restrictions.

Congress is facing a two-week deadline to finish its business and end its session. Lawmakers must pass the annual spending bills, respond to President Obama's immigration moves, and decide whether to extend a series of expired tax breaks. They also must find money to support the president's commitment of thousands of U.S. troops to Iraq.

Some lawmakers, such as Representative Tom Cotton, argue that Congress should use its power of the purse to block the president's executive action. Cotton, an Arkansas Republican, believes that the employment picture alone should be enough to rally Congress to block the president's action. He suggests tying all of this year's spending bills to a decision to block the deportation amnesty, tying only homeland security money to the deportation amnesty, or kicking the issue into next year, when Republicans will control both the House and Senate.

Others, such as Senator Ted Cruz, have called on Senate GOP leaders to refuse to confirm almost all of Mr. Obama's nominations to judicial or executive offices until the president rescinds his policy.

The House Appropriations Committee has poured cold water on the defunding strategy, stating that the annual spending process cannot curb U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, the federal agency that will handle most of the president's amnesty. The agency is almost entirely fee-based, meaning it has sources of funding independent of taxpayers.

However, CRS analysts argue that Congress does have power over fee-based agencies, citing the Supreme Court's establishment that Congress can dictate how an agency spends its funds. The agency's funds are technically part of the overall government fund and are reappropriated to the agency, making them subject to congressional restrictions.

Congress is scheduled to shut down by December 11, leaving less than two working weeks for lawmakers to finish their business. Republican leaders are struggling with choices over which issues to clear now, while Democrats retain control of the Senate, and which issues to punt into next year.

Title: Former President Bill Clinton's Thoughts on the Presidential Race

Former President Bill Clinton recently shared his thoughts on the current presidential race, discussing the Democratic narrative and the economy. In an interview, Clinton stated that President Obama inherited an "impossibly high" expectation regarding jobs and economic growth. He noted that Obama was handed a difficult situation and managed to prevent it from getting worse, but that the economy is still in a challenging state.

Clinton emphasized that the incumbent president always owns the economy, and therefore, Romney's job is to criticize Obama's economic policies. He also pointed out that Obama was given an "eighty-eight catastrophic economic situation" and that his actions had made it worse. Clinton believes that Romney has not done a good enough job of responding to this narrative.

Clinton also touched on the idea that the unemployment numbers are not entirely accurate, as they do not account for those who have given up looking for work. He believes that Romney has lost sight of this important aspect of the economy.

The former president also discussed the upcoming presidential debates, stating that they will be Romney's last best chance to turn things around. He believes that many Americans will watch the debates to make up their minds, and that Romney has a chance to surprise and show his likability.

Overall, Bill Clinton's comments provide insight into the current state of the presidential race and the economy, as well as the challenges facing the candidates.

Title: Senate Republicans Propose $1-Trillion Economic Stimulus Plan, Democrats Block Bill

The Senate Republicans have released a $1-trillion economic stimulus plan, which includes a proposal to distribute a $1,200 payment for each individual or $2,400 for joint returns. However, Democrats blocked the bill, citing concerns that it is too generous to big corporations and too stingy for working families.

The plan includes several key provisions, such as requiring President Donald Trump to invoke the Defense Production Act to order private companies to manufacture respirators, masks, and other needed equipment. It also allocates nearly $40 billion to help states stabilize school funding and help colleges continue operating during the crisis.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer stated that the parties are "very close" to reaching a deal, but emphasized the importance of getting the details right. The proposal would provide individuals with up to $1,200 ($2,400 for joint returns) and no less than $600 ($1,200 for joint returns). Families would receive an additional $500 for each qualifying child.

The plan would have an income limitation starting at $75,000 for individuals and $150,000 for joint returns. The amount individuals would receive would be reduced by 5% of the amount of a taxpayer's income that exceeds $75,000. The federal government is likely to utilize tax filings as a deciding factor on who qualifies for a stimulus check.

The current proposal is for a one-time lump sum payment, with officials floating the idea of a second stimulus check if economic conditions do not improve. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin stated that the government will get the stimulus checks out "as soon as Congress passes this," with specific dates likely to change during the appropriations process.

Individuals who have set up a direct deposit with the IRS can expect the sum quicker than those who have to wait for a check in the mail. The last time the federal government sent checks to Americans was in 2008, under President George W. Bush.

The aid package signed by Trump also includes paid sick and family leave, free coronavirus testing, and bolstered unemployment insurance. Payments on student loan interest are also on hold, as the president said last week during his declaration of a national emergency. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will suspend foreclosures and evictions on FHA-insured mortgages.

Title: California Lawmakers Pass Landmark Bill to Reshape Gig Economy

Article:

California lawmakers have passed a landmark bill, Assembly Bill 5 (AB5), which aims to reshape the gig economy by requiring companies like Uber and Lyft to reclassify their workers as employees instead of contractors. The bill, which passed the state Assembly in a 61-16 vote, now heads to Democratic California Governor Gavin Newsom's desk.

Shares of Lyft climbed 2.3% on Wednesday afternoon, while Uber was up 1.4%, as investors reacted to the news. The bill's author, Assemblywoman Lorena Gonzalez (D-San Diego), said the legislation would ensure key benefits and protections, such as minimum wage, insurance, and sick days, for over 1 million low-wage workers in California.

Uber and Lyft maintain that the bill will not immediately change independent contractors into employees. Tony West, Uber's chief legal officer, said the bill builds on legal tests already established in California around how drivers should be classified. West stated that drivers may not necessarily fall under the new rules laid out in AB5, citing a three-part test that requires companies to prove that contractors are doing work outside the usual course of their business.

West said Uber intends to follow AB5 should it be put into law next year, but will continue to try to prove that it does not fall under its legal framework. He warned that there could be some costs to the company's business should Uber unsuccessfully challenge AB5.

Uber and Lyft have told drivers that they may need to institute shifts if drivers are classified as employees, which would limit when ride-hailing drivers can start and stop accepting rides. In a notice to drivers, Lyft also said drivers might only be allowed to work for one ride-hailing service at a time.

The bill has received broad support from Democratic presidential candidates, including Sens. Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and Kamala Harris, as well as South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg. The bill's passage has also attracted staunch opposition from gig economy companies, which fear it could upend their traditional business model of hiring inexpensive contractors.

In an effort to push back against the bill, Uber and Lyft proposed establishing a $21-an-hour minimum wage for drivers in California. The ride-hailing companies, as well as DoorDash, have also pledged $90 million on a ballot initiative for the 2020 election that would exempt them from AB5. West said Uber is open to investing more on the initiative and is working to include other businesses that face similar issues with AB5.

Lyft spokesperson Adrian Durbin said the bill has the potential to hurt drivers who prefer a flexible work schedule. The outcome of AB5 remains uncertain, but its passage has significant implications for the gig economy and the millions of workers who rely on it.

Title: Mueller's Team Leaves Open Possibility of New Charges Against Manafort, Files Sentencing Recommendation for Cohen

The special counsel's office has left open the possibility of filing new charges against Paul Manafort, former campaign chairman for President Donald Trump, for allegedly lying during his interviews with the special counsel's office. Manafort's lawyers have stated that he believes he was honest during the interviews.

The latest development comes as the special counsel's office filed a recommendation for the sentencing of Michael D. Cohen, Trump's former lawyer, alongside a scathing attack from Manhattan prosecutors who rejected Cohen's request to avoid a prison term and accused him of using his power and influence "for deceptive ends." The prosecutors are seeking a four-year prison sentence for Cohen, who is scheduled to be sentenced next week for lying to Congress about the extent of Trump's business dealings in Moscow, as well as campaign finance violations and other charges.

Manafort was convicted by a Northern Virginia jury in August of eight counts of financial fraud and agreed to a plea deal on the verge of a second trial. He met with the special counsel's office at least a dozen times before they declared that he had violated the plea agreement. Prosecutors have accused Manafort of lying about his interactions and meetings with Konstantin V. Kilimnik, a Russian Army-trained linguist who served as Manafort's right-hand man in Ukraine for over a decade. The filing revealed that some of the information related to Kilimnik was uncovered in emails and testimony, and claimed that Manafort lied about his involvement with witnesses who might testify against him.

Title: Democratic National Committee Takes Over Iowa Caucus Count Amidst Delayed Results

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has stepped in to assist the Iowa Democratic Party (IDP) in counting the results of the botched Iowa caucuses, which took place on Monday. The move comes as state party officials remain unable to provide a timeline for releasing the remaining results.

According to ABC News, the DNC has been contacting precinct chairs to verify the results, a process that has not been done in previous caucuses. Polk County Democratic chairman Sean Bagniewski and Des Moines precinct chairman Carl Voss confirmed that the DNC had reached out to them to request copies of their tally sheets.

DNC chairman Tom Perez tweeted that the committee is working around the clock to assist the IDP in ensuring that all votes are counted accurately and as quickly as possible. "What happened last night in Iowa should never happen again," Perez wrote.

The IDP has been under scrutiny since Monday night, when an app commissioned by the IDP and created by Shadow Inc. failed to collect votes correctly. Only 71% of results have been released so far, with the remaining 29% still pending. IDP chairman Troy Price refused to provide a timeline for when the remaining results will be verified and made public, stating, "We're going to take the time we need to get these results done."

The DNC's involvement in the counting process is a rare move, as the committee typically does not intervene in state-level party affairs. The situation highlights the importance of accurate and timely results in the Democratic primary process.

Title: Bernie Sanders' Support Among White Men in Michigan Primary Shines Light on Economic Frustrations

Bernie Sanders' victory in the Michigan primary has sent shockwaves through the Democratic race, with a significant portion of his support coming from white men. According to exit polls, Sanders won 62% of white men, who made up one-third of voters in the primary. This demographic has been a key factor in Sanders' success, with many feeling that he speaks to their economic frustrations.

Jim, a union member who asked to remain anonymous due to his union's endorsement of Hillary Clinton, expressed his frustration with the current state of the economy. "We haven't gotten raises. Our pensions have been cut. Our healthcare's increased," he said. Sanders' message resonates with Jim and many others who feel that he is fighting for them.

In Michigan, Sanders won voters who believed that trade deals have cost American jobs, with 58% of voters agreeing with this sentiment. He also won voters who live in households with union members, with 33% of voters identifying as such. While Clinton and Sanders split these voters, black union members who went for Clinton likely accounted for some of the difference.

Ryan, a member of a building trades union in Cleveland, feels that Sanders' message is a breath of fresh air. "She's [Clinton] seen as the centrist candidate, and she's a big-money candidate. And big money and centrism hasn't been working for middle-class America for the past 30 years," he said.

Dave Passalacqua, executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America Local 4340 in Cleveland, is still undecided but appreciates Sanders' grassroots approach to fundraising. "There's that old saying: politicians should be like NASCAR, everyone wear their patch," he said. "You know, let's see what the patches are and [Sanders] doesn't need to wear a patch, because it's his own thing."

While some union members, like Jim Goggin, an organizer for the Delaware Valley Health Care Coalition, are skeptical about Sanders' chances of winning, they acknowledge that his message is appealing. "It's pie in the sky, I mean, everything Bernie says, I think would be fantastic," he said. "But the fact of the matter is, that I am also a realist, and I know that you can't do that."

Regardless of who wins the nomination, all four men interviewed said they would support the Democratic nominee in November.

Title: Debating COVID-19 Reopening Strategies: A Considered Approach

The ongoing debate about how to reopen society in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic has led to three distinct groups emerging: those who believe the virus is not serious and want to reopen everything as soon as possible, those who believe it is extremely serious and want everything to remain closed, and those who believe it is serious and want a considered reopening strategy. This article explores the assumptions underlying policy recommendations and proposes a strategy coined by Israeli scientists, known as the "controlled avalanche" approach.

The controlled avalanche strategy involves protecting the elderly and vulnerable populations, allowing herd immunity to develop among the least vulnerable, and reducing the infection fatality rate. This approach has been shown to reduce overall mortality by over 40%, reduce the maximum number of people in need of ICUs by over 60%, and decrease the time required to allow freedom to low-risk populations by months.

The strategy is based on several key assumptions, including the development of therapeutics that reduce the infection fatality rate and the availability of vaccines. It also assumes that the government will be able to shoulder increased debt and that shoppers will continue to socially distance.

The controlled avalanche approach has been shown to be effective in reducing deaths and achieving herd immunity, particularly among the elderly and vulnerable populations. While it is not a foolproof strategy, it may be a better approach than simply hoping for the best while watching the world economy implode.

The article concludes that the honest debate is happening within the third group, those who believe the virus is serious and want a considered reopening strategy. The controlled avalanche approach is a key consideration in this debate, as it has the potential to reduce mortality rates and achieve herd immunity while also protecting the economy.

Title: Trump Administration Abandons Defense of Affordable Care Act, Raising Uncertainty for Pre-Existing Condition Protections

The Trump administration's decision to withdraw from defending the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in an ongoing court challenge could have significant implications for the healthcare industry and the millions of Americans who rely on the law's protections. The move comes as insurers are proposing individual market premiums for 2019, injecting uncertainty into an already uncertain environment.

The lawsuit, led by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, argues that the individual mandate, which was repealed by Congress in 2017, makes the entirety of the ACA unconstitutional. If the argument prevails, it would render unconstitutional provisions that ban insurance companies from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions.

According to the Department of Health and Human Services, as many as 130 million adults under the age of 65 in the U.S. have pre-existing conditions that could result in their not being able to get insurance coverage in the private market. The Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that about a quarter of the country's under-65 population has pre-existing conditions.

The ACA made it illegal for insurance companies to deny coverage to people with pre-existing conditions, and the Trump administration's decision to withdraw from defending the law could upend insurance markets for next year and change the dynamic of this fall's elections.

The move has sparked concerns among healthcare experts and advocates, with Larry Levitt, senior vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, stating that insurers hate uncertainty and will respond by increasing premiums. Nicholas Bagley, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, called the decision "troubling" and "galling," saying it is unusual for the Justice Department to refuse to defend existing law in court challenges.

The Justice Department has opted not to defend existing law in other matters, including the Defense of Marriage Act in 2012. America's Health Insurance Plans, the trade association for health insurance companies, supports the pre-existing condition protections under the ACA and will file an amicus brief in support of the law.

On Capitol Hill, congressional Republicans' reaction to the Trump administration's decision was muted, with many lawmakers voicing skepticism that the courts would ultimately rule against a law already upheld by the Supreme Court. Health care is already a dominant issue in this year's elections, with voters regularly citing it as a leading determinant for how they will vote.

The Trump administration's decision to abandon the Affordable Care Act's defense has raised concerns about the future of pre-existing condition protections and the impact on the healthcare industry.

Title: CNN's Brian Stelter Discusses Republican Candidates' Media Bashing and Political Polarization

Article:

CNN's senior media correspondent, Brian Stelter, discussed the phenomenon of Republican presidential candidates attacking the liberal media on his show AC360. According to Stelter, this tactic is not about the media being biased, but rather a way for politicians to deflect tough questions and show strength by putting the press on the defensive.

Stelter pointed to the recent CNBC debate as an example of how effective media bashing can be, with multiple candidates using the issue to garner applause from conservative audiences. He also noted that while most journalists strive to eliminate bias from their reporting, many conservatives do not take them at their word.

Stelter also attributed the growing political polarization in the United States to conservative distrust of the media. According to Pew Research, those who identify as conservative tend to trust fewer mainstream media sources. Fox News and some candidates have benefited from this trend, with some even mocking the moderators and asking supporters for donations.

Stelter concluded his segment by inviting University of Virginia's Larry Sabato to defend the CNBC moderators, who were criticized for their questioning style. Sabato emphasized that the moderators were simply trying to get candidates to tell the truth, and that some of the criticism was likely for show.

The full transcript of the discussion can be found on CNN's Anderson Cooper 360.

Title: North Korea Conducts Most Powerful Nuclear Test to Date, Raising Tensions with the US

North Korea has conducted its most powerful nuclear test to date, detonating a hydrogen bomb with a 100-kiloton yield, according to experts. The test, which was confirmed by the US Geological Survey, registered a 6.3-magnitude earthquake at the Punggye-ri testing site. This is the country's sixth nuclear test and its first during the Trump administration.

The test was conducted to examine and confirm the accuracy and credibility of the weapon, according to the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), North Korea's state-run media organization. The agency released pictures of the country's leader, Kim Jong Un, looking at a hydrogen bomb loaded onto an intercontinental ballistic missile that could theoretically hit most major US cities.

Experts believe that North Korea wants the ability to target the United States, and this bomb can do significant damage. Jeffrey Lewis, an expert on North Korea's missile program at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, stated, "A thermonuclear weapon does more damage, and this bomb can do quite a bit of damage." Vipin Narang, a nuclear expert at MIT, added that even with "relatively inaccurate intercontinental ballistic missile technology, [North Korea] can destroy the better part of a city with this yield."

The test has sparked a strong reaction from the international community, with President Donald Trump tweeting his displeasure and Secretary of Defense James Mattis issuing a warning. "Any threat to the United States or its territories, including Guam, or our allies will be met with a massive military response – a response both effective and overwhelming," Mattis said.

Regional allies South Korea and Japan have also reacted strongly, with South Korean President Moon Jae-in convening a meeting of his national security team and his national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, stating that Seoul wants the "most powerful sanctions" placed on North Korea at the United Nations. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also issued a statement condemning the test.

It remains to be seen how the US will respond to this provocation, with some experts believing that a military strike is unlikely. However, the test has raised tensions between North Korea and the US, and it is unclear what incentive North Korea has to stop its nuclear program, especially now that it has tested a powerful hydrogen bomb.

Title: Illinois' Automatic Pay Raise for State Workers to Cost Taxpayers $261 Million Amid Pandemic-Induced Economic Challenges

Article:

Illinois state workers received an automatic pay raise on July 1, which is expected to cost taxpayers $261 million. This development comes as nearly 1.4 million Illinoisans have filed for unemployment since the COVID-19 pandemic shuttered much of the economy in March. In contrast, other state governments have taken measures to cut costs, such as canceling pay raises, furloughs, and 15% agency spending cuts for fiscal year 2021.

The Illinois state budget, signed by Governor J.B. Pritzker, increases spending by $2.4 billion over last year and relies on $5 billion from a nonexistent federal bailout to partially close a $6 billion deficit. This move has sparked concerns about the state's fiscal responsibility.

The debate around state aid is ongoing, with some advocating for more assistance and others opposing it. However, a compromise solution could be to offer aid conditioned on sound financial management to protect taxpayers from tax increases or service failures. This approach is already seen in relief packages following the 2010 Greek debt crisis, the 2007-2009 U.S. bank bailouts, and the corporate financial assistance under the CARES Act.

The federal government should consider conditioning aid on three hallmarks of healthy state finances: sound pensions, truly balanced budgets, and sufficient rainy-day savings. States should be required to eliminate unfunded pension liabilities over 25 years, maintain balanced budgets, and have restrictions on rainy-day fund withdrawals.

Without these reforms, fiscally irresponsible states like Illinois would likely misuse aid money, perpetuating inefficient and ineffective practices. Federal lawmakers have an opportunity to provide aid while encouraging states to address their fiscal challenges.

Title: Minneapolis Sports Bar Owner Devastated After Looting and Vandalism

A Minneapolis sports bar owner, Korboi Balla, has been left heartbroken after his business was destroyed during the recent protests and looting in the city. Balla had invested his life savings into opening the bar, which was originally set to open in March but was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. With the city giving the green light for restaurants to reopen on June 1, Balla was finally preparing to open his doors. However, his plans were shattered when looters targeted his business, leaving it in ruins.

"I don't know what we're going to do," Balla told CBS News, fighting back tears. "It hurts, man. It's not fair, it's not right. We've been working so hard for this place. It's not just for me, it's for my family."

Balla's wife, Twyana Balla, shared her husband's devastation on social media, stating that they do not have insurance for their business and are now facing a significant financial burden. "I'm hearing people say 'F*** the business, they have insurance WELL WE DON'T AND THIS IS ALL OUT OF POCKET,' Twyana Balla wrote. "Let someone come run in your home and loot for the cause then let's see you be ok with it! Justice for George Floyd but not this kind of justice."

The couple has launched a GoFundMe campaign to raise funds to rebuild their bar, which has already raised over $173,000 in its first 24 hours. The Minneapolis-St. Paul area has seen over 170 businesses damaged or looted since the death of George Floyd on Monday, according to police reports.

Title: Clinton's Campaign Enters Final Week Amid Email Controversy and Trump's Attempts to Capitalize

The 2016 US presidential campaign is entering its final week, with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton facing renewed scrutiny over her use of a private email server during her time as secretary of state. The FBI's review of new emails from longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin, found on the computer of her estranged husband Anthony Weiner, has revived the issue and given Republican nominee Donald Trump a chance to attack Clinton's character.

Clinton's campaign is now focusing on turning the spotlight back on Trump, aiming to brand him as morally and intellectually unfit for the presidency. The campaign will rely on its superior ground game and polling, which suggests Clinton still has several routes to surpass the 270 electoral votes needed to win.

Trump, on the other hand, is seizing on the new emails to bolster his theme that Clinton is dishonest, secretive, and steeped in scandal. He will need to use this momentum effectively to mount a stunning comeback on November 8. The Republican nominee must improve his position on the political map, forging ahead in Florida and Ohio, cutting his deficit in North Carolina, and capitalizing on an advantage in Iowa.

The campaign's final week is expected to be marked by intense scrutiny and controversy, with many Democrats furious at FBI Director James Comey for reviving the email issue. The question now is whether this hurricane of a campaign will have a final, stunning twist – a November surprise – before it finally blows itself out.

Title: Global Terrorism: A Complex and Evolving Threat

The recent terrorist attacks in Orlando, Florida, and Paris, France, have left the world reeling. The question on everyone's mind is whether these attacks are the work of a lone wolf or a coordinated ISIS plot. While the authorities will likely uncover the truth soon, for now, the sense of security has been shattered, and the goal of terrorism has been achieved.

The United States has experienced its share of terrorist attacks, including the 9/11 attacks and more recent incidents in San Bernardino and Orlando. However, the country is also grappling with an epidemic of domestic violence, with mass killings occurring in cities like Dallas, Roseburg, Charleston, and Newtown. This complexity makes it difficult to pinpoint a single cause or solution.

Many countries have been hit by terrorist attacks in recent years, with violence perpetrated against strangers as they go about their daily lives. France, in particular, has been a hotbed of ISIS-coordinated terrorism, with experts attributing this to its colonial history in the Middle East and a cultural intolerance towards diversity.

The United States, on the other hand, has a history of assimilating culturally diverse populations, with a strong tradition of pluralism. However, the country is currently experiencing a surge in xenophobia and nationalism, with some Americans supporting Donald Trump's proposal to ban Muslims and build a wall to keep out immigrants from Mexico and Central America.

Despite these challenges, the United States still values diversity and has a strong commitment to it. American Muslims, in particular, are still accepted and integrated into society, with many believing in the importance of diversity.

France, on the other hand, is in the midst of a serious homegrown Islamic terrorism crisis, with many people advising politicians to take drastic measures. In the United States, politicians like Donald Trump are also advocating for harsh measures, but it is unclear how much more the public will tolerate before turning to draconian solutions.

Ultimately, the death and destruction caused by terrorism will end when radical extremists fail to achieve their goal of dividing the world and instead bring people together in solidarity. Social media connects people instantly to the victims of terrorism, and the vast majority of the human population feels tremendous empathy for those affected. As the world continues to grapple with this complex and evolving threat, it is essential to remember that our common humanity is the greatest strength against terrorism.

Title: Democratic Party's Internal Divisions May Mirror Republican Party's Struggles

The article discusses the potential for internal divisions within the Democratic Party, mirroring the Republican Party's current struggles. The author suggests that the Democratic Party's establishment and media outlets are eager to see the Republican Party "crash and burn," but neglect to consider the potential consequences of their own party's internal conflicts.

The article highlights the divisions within the Democratic Party, citing the example of Senator Bernie Sanders and his supporters feeling that the Democratic National Committee rigged the primary process against him. The author notes that Senator Elizabeth Warren's endorsement of Hillary Clinton was delayed until June, and that her views on economic policy and regulation of business may not align with those of the Democratic Party's more liberal members.

The article also touches on the potential for Supreme Court nominations to become a point of contention within the Democratic Party, as Hillary Clinton may face pressure to choose a nominee that aligns with the views of the party's more liberal members.

The author concludes that the Democratic Party's internal divisions may be just as intense as those within the Republican Party, and that the media's focus on the Republican Party's struggles may be misplaced. The article does not take a stance on the political views or policies of the parties, but rather presents a neutral analysis of the potential for internal divisions within the Democratic Party.

Title: New York Governor's Remarks Spark Discussion on Human Life's Value

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo recently sparked a thought-provoking discussion on the value of human life during a press conference about the slow reopening of the state. He posed the rhetorical question, "How much is a human life worth?" and emphasized that a human life is priceless. This statement has sparked a wider conversation about the inconsistencies in the state's policies and actions regarding human life.

The governor's words come at a time when the state is grappling with the consequences of its decisions on vulnerable populations, including nursing home residents and those in abortion clinics. The recent revelations about mistakes involving nursing homes have raised concerns about the state's handling of the pandemic. Additionally, the ongoing debate around abortion and assisted suicide has highlighted the complexities of the issue.

The Sisters of Life, a group based in New York, have been working to promote the value and dignity of human life. They emphasize that every human life is precious and that people should be treated with respect and compassion. The group has seen an increase in women approaching them for help and support, including those from inside abortion clinics who feel pressured to terminate their pregnancies.

The governor's remarks have sparked a much-needed conversation about the inconsistencies in the state's policies and actions. While some may argue that the governor's words are a step in the right direction, others may see them as a missed opportunity to address the deeper issues surrounding human life. Regardless, the discussion is a crucial step towards acknowledging the value and dignity of every human life.

It remains to be seen how the governor's words will be translated into action and what concrete steps the state will take to ensure the protection and promotion of human life.

Title: Congressional Leaders Signal Revisit of Immigration Issue in January, But Dreamers Feel Betrayed

Article:

Congressional leaders have signaled that they will revisit the immigration issue early next year, vowing to complete legislation in January. However, this announcement has not satisfied the "Dreamers," who had set a year-end deadline for a legalization bill and are now feeling betrayed by Democratic leaders who failed to force a government shutdown showdown over their demands.

Hundreds of Dreamers, some risking arrest, took to the hallways in Congress to march and conduct lie-downs in office corridors to protest their perceived abandonment. They are pushing for the passage of the Dream Act, which would grant tentative legal status to more than 2 million illegal immigrants and allow 1.7 million of them to earn green cards signifying permanent legal presence.

The negotiations over the government spending bill, which is set to expire on Friday, have stalled, with House Republicans proposing a four-week extension of current funding and Democrats insisting on parity between defense and domestic programs. The Dream Act is still part of the negotiations, but Republican aides say Democrats signaled days ago that it was not one of the major sticking points.

Dreamers are frustrated that Democratic leaders, including Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, have not delivered on their promises to protect them. "Time and time again, politicians have failed to stand by our community," said Cata Santiago, a Dreamer who was arrested last week while protesting in Schumer's congressional office. "Now, at the peak of the Dream Act fight, Chuck Schumer and the Democrats won't hold their promises to protect us."

While some Republicans, such as Senator Jeff Flake, have expressed support for the Dream Act, others, like Representative Dave Brat, argue that Democrats are pushing for a government shutdown by threatening an all-or-nothing Senate filibuster. "The American people sent us the Republican majorities in the House, the Senate, and the White House. And we have to get eight votes on the Democrat side, and we should compromise, right?" Brat said.

The fate of the Dream Act remains uncertain, but Dreamers are determined to keep pushing for a permanent fix. "It's very easy for Sen. Flake to send out a tweet this morning and say, 'Dreamers in January.' His kids aren't getting deported. He's going home to his wife. He's celebrating Christmas," said Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, a leading voice for the Dreamers.

Title: Obama Administration Announces New Gun Control Measures

The Obama administration has introduced two new gun control measures, including a ban on the importation of military surplus weapons and a proposal to require background checks for those associated with corporations and trusts. The announcements were made by Vice President Joe Biden on Thursday, as part of a series of executive actions aimed at reducing gun violence.

The new rules, which will take effect after a 90-day comment period, will prohibit private entities from importing military-grade firearms, which have been approved for re-importation since 2005. Only museums and government agencies will be eligible to re-import these weapons. The administration also proposes requiring individuals associated with corporations and trusts to undergo background checks if they want to register guns.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has criticized the measures, stating that they will not reduce crime and that the focus should be on prosecuting violent criminals rather than law-abiding gun owners. The NRA claims that neither the re-importation of firearms nor the corporate gun registration is a known source of weapons for criminals.

The new measures come after Congress failed to pass any gun control legislation earlier this year, despite an aggressive push from the White House. The administration has also made progress on 22 of the 23 executive actions announced in January, with the exception of an effort to finalize regulations requiring insurers to cover mental health at parity with medical benefits.

The Obama administration's efforts to address gun violence have been met with resistance from the NRA and many Republican lawmakers, who argue that the measures will infringe on Second Amendment rights. While the administration has made progress on some fronts, the fight for stricter gun control legislation remains ongoing.

Title: China Seizes Opportunity as US Withdraws from Paris Climate Agreement

The United States' decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement has sparked widespread anger and anxiety globally, with one notable exception: China. Beijing is capitalizing on the void left by the US, giving it a chance to expand its standing on the world stage and benefit diplomatically and economically.

This is not the first time President Trump's actions have inadvertently benefited China. After the US withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, China inserted itself into trade talks among other nations, emerging as a more reliable trading prospect. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Chinese President Xi Jinping criticized the West for its flirtation with protectionism and presented China as a paragon of free trade and an inviting place for foreign investment.

As the US pulls out of the global effort to curb carbon emissions, China's profile as a forward-looking world leader will only grow. It is set to become closer to the US's allies that feel abandoned by Trump's recent actions and take a more aggressive lead in building a green economy.

The reshuffling of the world order in the wake of Trump's announcement was evident, with top Chinese and European leaders criticizing the US's withdrawal side by side. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and German Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized the importance of cooperation on climate change, with Merkel stating that the European Union and China will play a crucial role in this area.

The enhanced cooperation between Europe and China is likely to go beyond climate change, as they find common ground on issues like trade and investment. China's One Belt, One Road initiative, a massive infrastructure project connecting China to 64 countries, is a prime example. While concerns about China's compliance with global trade norms remain, building goodwill through cooperation on climate change can help ease these concerns.

The US and Europe are experiencing their worst rift since the Iraq War in 2003, with Trump's "America First" agenda alienating many allies. The impact of Trump's withdrawal from the Paris agreement is bigger than just China's relationship with Europe, as it creates a vacuum for Beijing to fill.

China has been eager to capitalize on Trump's protectionist tendencies, and its economy has liberalized significantly in recent decades. However, it is a country that disregards global trade rules, from denying market access to foreign companies to subsidizing key industries. Nevertheless, when the most powerful politician in the world calls for 45% tariffs against other countries, China's actions seem less egregious.

In the realm of sustainable development, China is set to surpass the US, investing more than $88 billion in clean energy in 2016, compared to the US's $59 billion. As the US decides renewable energy investment is not a priority, the gap between the two nations will grow rapidly. America First is turning out to be anything but.

Title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Aspects of Affordable Care Act, White House Assures Program Will Remain in Place

The White House has assured Americans that the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, will remain in place while the lawsuit is appealed, despite a federal judge's ruling striking down certain aspects of the healthcare legislation. The ruling, issued by U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor in the Northern District of Texas, declared that the individual mandate, which requires individuals to purchase health insurance or face a penalty, is unconstitutional.

The Trump administration had previously stopped defending the healthcare law, and a coalition of ACA-supporting states took up the defense. The Justice Department had urged the judge not to rule during the health law's open enrollment season, which runs from November 1 to January in some states.

The ruling is expected to be appealed by California and other states to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which is dominated by Republican nominees. The expected lengthy court fight between Republican and Democratic state officials over the ruling likely would end up at the Supreme Court, which has twice voted to uphold other challenges to the ACA.

The ruling has no immediate effect, and consumers who buy insurance through federal or state marketplaces can still purchase 2019 coverage through Saturday. However, if the ruling is upheld after the appeal process, subsidies that people collect to buy health coverage would no longer be available, and Medicaid, which has extended insurance coverage to millions of low-income and working-class Americans, could be in jeopardy.

The ruling has sparked concerns about the fate of the healthcare system, with some experts warning that it could throw the individual insurance market and the whole healthcare system into chaos. The Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that 52 million adults from 18 to 64, or 27 percent of that age group, would be denied coverage under the practices that were in effect in most states before the ACA was passed.

The Trump administration has called the ruling "great news for America" and has urged Republican and Democratic congressional leaders to pass a "strong law that provides great healthcare." However, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., has expressed no interest in any kind of compromise and vowed to intervene in the appeals process when Democrats take control of the House next month, calling it "absurd" that the judge declared portions of the health law unconstitutional.

Title: The Importance of Participatory Democracy in the United States

The presidential election cycle has become a spectacle, with many Americans engaging in heated discussions and debates on social media and in print. However, the majority of voters consider democracy to be a passive act, limited to voting every four years or during contested races. This limited participation can lead to a lack of engagement and a failure to address the country's pressing issues.

According to statistics, voter turnout for presidential elections averages around 55%, while midterm elections see an average turnout of around 45%. This limited participation can be attributed to the fact that many voters only engage in the political process during presidential elections, neglecting other important races and elections.

The current political process has become more like a reality TV show, with a focus on sensationalism and drama rather than respectful discourse. Instead of relying on presidential candidates to solve the nation's problems, citizens should be more active and engaged in the political process. This includes participating in thoughtful discussions on important issues, donating time and money to organizations that support a healthy democratic process, and encouraging neighbors to engage in bipartisan dialogue.

The country's populace needs to move beyond cherry-picking news articles and engage in a dialogue with neighbors to achieve a bipartisan society and political process. After the presidential election, serious issues such as economic prosperity, national security, the environment, and unity will remain. No single candidate can solve these issues, and it is up to the American people to find collective solutions through participatory democracy.

In conclusion, it is essential for Americans to recognize the importance of participatory democracy and engage in the political process beyond just voting. By doing so, citizens can work together to address the country's pressing issues and create a more united and prosperous society.

Title: House Energy and Commerce Committee Votes on Climate Change Legislation

The House Energy and Commerce Committee recently considered the Electricity Security and Affordability Act (H.R. 3826), which would suspend the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) proposed climate rules for power plants. The bill passed, but an amendment acknowledging the reality of climate change and its causes was rejected by the committee.

The amendment, proposed by Representative Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.), stated that greenhouse gas pollution "threatens the American public's health and welfare" by contributing to climate changes. However, the amendment did not pass, with 24 Republican committee members voting against it. Committee Chair Rep. Fred Upton (R-MI) and Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) were among those who voted against the amendment, with Upton previously stating that he does not believe climate change is caused by human activity.

This is not the first time House Republicans have rejected amendments acknowledging the reality of climate change. In 2011, they voted down amendments calling on Congress to accept that climate change is real, man-made, and a human health threat.

According to ClimateProgress, the Republicans who voted against the amendment have received a total of $9.3 million in career contributions from the oil, gas, and coal industries.

Title: Abortion Clinic Regulation: A Matter of Public Health and Safety

The recent trial of Philadelphia abortionist Kermit Gosnell has shed light on the substandard care and unsanitary conditions at his clinic, leading to the deaths of at least two patients. This incident is not an isolated case, as at least 15 states have launched investigations into abortion clinics and providers over the past three years, resulting in some cases of women's deaths. Americans United for Life has been advocating for meaningful and comprehensive regulation and oversight of abortion clinics for over a decade.

In recent years, eight states have enacted new regulations or made significant improvements to existing regulations, with Alabama and Virginia being the latest examples. The "Abortion Patients' Enhanced Safety Act" model legislation, promoted by Americans United for Life, requires abortion clinics to meet the same health and safety standards as facilities performing other outpatient surgeries.

The debate over Virginia's abortion clinic standards highlights the ongoing battle to ensure women's health and safety above profit margins and self-interested promotion of unrestricted and unregulated abortion. Virginia officials and pro-life advocates argued that abortion clinics should be licensed, inspected regularly, and maintain sanitary and safe facilities, while advocates of Big Abortion claimed that these regulations would be too costly and burdensome.

Documentation obtained by the Family Foundation of Virginia from the Virginia Board of Health confirms that health and safety violations at abortion clinics are widespread and ongoing, despite plans to correct previous deficiencies. The continued lack of oversight and regulation has led to the maiming and killing of women, as seen in the case of Kermit Gosnell.

The "right" to abortion, as defined by the U.S. Supreme Court, does not give rise to a corollary "right" for abortion providers to practice without meaningful oversight and regulation. It is essential to prioritize women's health and safety above the financial interests of the abortion industry.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates' Imitation of Trump's Rhetoric Raises Concerns

Article:

The Democratic presidential candidates are drawing criticism for their imitation of Donald Trump's rhetoric, despite their efforts to distance themselves from the current president. California Senator Kamala Harris, in particular, has faced scrutiny for her contradictory statements on healthcare and her Trumpian approach to policy.

Harris initially endorsed "Medicare for All" and stated that people who like their private insurance would not be allowed to keep it. However, she later waffled on the issue, saying she does not support ending private health insurance. Her debate performance raised concerns about her ability to communicate effectively with voters.

The senator's stance on healthcare is not the only issue sparking controversy. Her decision to raise her hand in support of abolishing private insurance, just like Senator Bernie Sanders, has been criticized for being unclear and confusing. Her subsequent claim that she does not support ending private insurance, citing a grammatical error in the debate moderator's question, has been met with skepticism.

Harris's debate performance also drew attention for her decision to wrap herself in an unpopular policy from the 1970s, namely compulsory busing. This policy, which aimed to engineer racial balance in schools, was widely unpopular and contributed to the conservative ascendancy in the 1980s. Her decision to use this issue as a cudgel against Joe Biden, who lacks the courage to ask her about reviving the policy, has been criticized for being divisive and lacking substance.

The article concludes that many Democratic presidential candidates are imitating Trump's rhetoric, including his use of hyperbole and divisive language. Harris's performance has raised concerns about her ability to communicate effectively with voters and her commitment to clear and concise policy-making.

Title: Trump Touts Plastic Production, Blames China for Environmental Concerns

The Trump administration has been promoting the production of plastics, with President Donald Trump taking credit for a new plastic manufacturing plant in Pennsylvania. The plant, built by Royal Dutch Shell, will produce pellets used in the production of various plastics, including those used in cars and wind turbines. Trump has been touting the plant as a job creator and a way to make the US more self-sufficient in plastics production.

However, the move has been met with criticism from environmentalists, who argue that the production of plastics contributes to pollution and waste. The plant is also being built with the promise of over $1 billion in tax credits from state taxpayers.

Trump has been blaming China for the world's plastic waste problem, stating that the country is responsible for a large portion of the plastic waste in oceans. However, this claim has been disputed by environmental groups, who argue that the US is also a major contributor to the problem.

Meanwhile, corporate America is also taking steps to reduce its use of plastics. Coca-Cola and Pepsi are attempting to improve their environmental images and reduce the number of plastic bottles they produce. Google has announced plans to include recycled plastic in its products by 2022, and Amazon has moved towards paper-padded packaging.

The Trump administration has also been touting its efforts to combat plastic waste, including signing the Save Our Seas Act. However, the bill does not specifically address the production of plastics, and the administration has been criticized for its lack of action on the issue.

The Trump campaign has also been selling 10-packs of plastic straws, with the slogan "Liberal paper straws don't work. STAND WITH PRESIDENT TRUMP and buy your pack of recyclable straws today." The campaign has raised over $450,000 from the sales.

Title: Colbert Challenges Elizabeth Warren on Single-Payer Healthcare Funding

Article:

On his CBS late-night show, Stephen Colbert questioned Senator Elizabeth Warren on the issue of single-payer healthcare, which she strongly supports. The comedian pressed Warren on the topic of funding, asking if middle-class Americans would have to pay more taxes to support the program proposed by Warren and Bernie Sanders. Warren initially dodged the question, prompting Colbert to drill down further, leading to a humorous exchange.

Colbert asked Warren to explain how she would pay for the program, and she responded by stating that costs would increase for the wealthiest Americans and big corporations. Colbert interrupted, asking if she meant taxes, and Warren confirmed that middle-class families would see their costs decrease. However, Colbert cut her off again, suggesting that she was not addressing the issue of middle-class tax hikes.

The exchange highlights the political challenge Warren faces in promoting single-payer healthcare. While many Americans support the idea of universal healthcare, the reality of increased taxes and potential disruptions to private insurance plans is a significant obstacle. According to a Harvard professor, state single-payer efforts in Vermont and Colorado failed due to concerns about tax increases.

Warren's plan would also eliminate private healthcare plans for nearly 180 million Americans, which could be a major political liability. Polling suggests that many Americans value their current insurance coverage and providers, with 82% of Democrats rating the quality of their healthcare as good or excellent. A recent Gallup poll found that 71% of Democrats believed their healthcare coverage was good or excellent, and 61% were satisfied with their healthcare costs.

A Kaiser poll found that 86% of Americans with private coverage were satisfied with it. The disruption of healthcare is deeply unpopular, and Warren's plan faces significant challenges in addressing these concerns.

Title: Death of Kate Steinle Highlights Complexity of Immigration Issues

The tragic death of Kate Steinle, a 31-year-old woman, on a San Francisco pier has sparked a renewed debate about immigration and crime. The suspect, Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, a Mexican immigrant who was in the country without documentation, has been arrested and charged with her murder. Lopez-Sanchez has a history of felony convictions, including four for drug offenses, and has been deported five times.

While Lopez-Sanchez's actions are a horrific example of violent crime, it is essential to separate him from the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the United States. The majority of these individuals are not criminals and are contributing members of society. Research from the Immigration Policy Center shows that crime rates in the United States decreased from 1990 to 2010 as the size of the immigrant population, including undocumented immigrants, grew.

The Washington Post analyzed Donald Trump's comments about Mexican immigrants being drug dealers and "rapists" and found that he was incorrect. Being in the country without authorization is a civil infraction, not a crime. Most undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work and provide a better life for themselves and their families.

The incident highlights the need for smarter and better immigration enforcement. Deporting as many undocumented immigrants as possible is not the answer. Lopez-Sanchez had been deported five times, and yet he was still in the country without authorization. The Department of Homeland Security's decision to rethink its deportation priorities, focusing on recent arrivals and serious criminals, is a step in the right direction.

The government will now focus its enforcement efforts on three categories: convicted criminals, recent border crossers, and terrorism threats. This approach aims to target those who are a real threat to public safety. The incident also underscores the need for a more effective and efficient immigration system, as the country spends more on immigration enforcement than all other law enforcement agencies combined.

Title: Debate Moderator Apologizes to Scott Brown for Incorrect Geography Question

In a recent Senate debate, moderator James Pindell asked Republican candidate Scott Brown about what he thinks is going "right" and "wrong" in Sullivan County, New Hampshire. Brown responded by highlighting economic challenges facing areas north of Concord, citing opportunities in tourism and ski areas. Pindell interrupted Brown, pointing out that the question was about Sullivan County, specifically, and not the North Country. Brown maintained that the challenges he mentioned applied to any area past Concord.

Pindell later interrupted Brown again, correcting him that Sullivan County is actually west of Concord, not north. Brown stuck to his original answer, stating that the challenges he mentioned applied to every county in the state. The state Democratic Party posted a video of the exchange, labeling Brown "clueless" in the description.

However, later that night, Pindell admitted that Brown's geography was correct, noting that Brown was referring to Mt. Sunapee, a ski resort in Sullivan County north of Concord. Pindell apologized to Brown and both campaigns, acknowledging that he was incorrect and Brown was right.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Indicted on Corruption Charges

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been charged with three corruption cases, marking the first time a sitting head of state in Israel will face criminal charges. The indictment follows a four-day hearing last month with the prime minister's defense team.

The charges against Netanyahu include bribery, fraud, and breach of trust. The first case accuses him of engaging in a quid pro quo deal with businessman and media mogul Shaul Elovich, allegedly spearheading regulations that helped Elovich gain approximately $500 million in return for favorable media coverage. The Netanyahus have argued that the deal does not constitute a bribe and that they only sought balanced coverage.

The second case accuses Netanyahu and Arnon Mozes, the publisher of the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper, of trying to limit the circulation of a rival paper in return for favorable media coverage. The case, known as Case 2000, accuses Netanyahu of fraud and breach of trust.

The final case accuses Netanyahu of fraud and breach of trust for allegedly using his public role to receive gifts from Hollywood mogul Arnon Milchan and billionaire James Packer.
