If convicted, Netanyahu could face up to 10 years in prison for bribery and a maximum of three years for fraud and breach of trust. However, he is not required to step down as a result of the charges and can ask the parliament for immunity. The parliament has 21 days to try to nominate any one of its 120 lawmakers to establish a coalition, and if that effort fails, an election would be triggered within 90 days.

The indictment casts further uncertainty over Netanyahu's political future, as Israel appears to be headed toward an unprecedented third election in less than a year.

Title: June Jobs Report Shows Mixed Signals, but Experts Warn of Economic Stagnation

The latest jobs report has been met with enthusiasm from Republicans, who are touting the 4.8 million new jobs added in June and a declining unemployment rate of 11.1%. However, experts are cautioning that the numbers may not be as rosy as they seem.

According to the report, the official unemployment rate has fallen, but a closer examination of the data reveals that the increase in jobs is largely due to temporary layoffs being reversed, rather than new permanent employment opportunities. The "core" unemployment rate, which includes permanent layoffs and those who are not actively looking for work, has increased to 5.9%, up from 5.0% in February.

Moreover, the report's numbers are already outdated, as the surveys were conducted during the first two weeks of June, missing the surge in coronavirus cases and economic activity that has occurred since then. Private economic indexes have shown a stalling of spending across the country, and weekly unemployment claims have plateaued at levels much higher than those seen during the Great Recession.

Experts warn that the economy is likely to slow down or even reverse its progress without further government intervention. The expiration of the small business loan program and the super-unemployment benefit at the end of July will leave many Americans without a safety net, making it difficult for them to make ends meet.

The article concludes that the government must continue to provide financial support to citizens, including the universal checks and small business grants, to prevent economic disaster. Republicans' reluctance to extend these programs is seen as a misguided attempt to force people back into the workforce, rather than addressing the underlying economic issues.

Title: California Senator Dianne Feinstein Introduces New Gun Control Legislation

Article:

California Senator Dianne Feinstein is set to introduce new gun control legislation today, aimed at reinstating the "assault" weapons ban of the Clinton era. The proposed bill goes beyond simply banning "scary-looking" guns, covering a wide range of handguns, rifles, and shotguns. Firearms lawfully purchased and included in the legislation as "banned" must be registered.

The bill specifically targets certain semi-automatic rifles, handguns, and shotguns that can accept a detachable magazine and have one or more military characteristics, as well as those with a fixed magazine that can accept more than 10 rounds. It also eliminates the easy-to-remove bayonet mounts and flash suppressors from the characteristics test and bans firearms with "thumbhole stocks" and "bullet buttons" to address attempts to "work around" prior bans.

The legislation also bans large-capacity ammunition feeding devices capable of accepting more than 10 rounds. To protect legitimate hunters and existing gun owners, the bill exempts over 900 specifically-named weapons used for hunting or sporting purposes and requires grandfathered weapons to be registered under the National Firearms Act.

The bill's language emphasizes protecting legitimate hunters and existing gun owners, but critics argue that the registration requirements and exemptions may create a gray area. The term "assault weapon" is also often debated, as it is not a specific weapon type but rather a political term used to describe semi-automatic rifles.

It remains to be seen whether Feinstein's legislation will gain traction. Some have criticized the bill as an extreme Obama-era stance on the Second Amendment, which many Democrats have deemed out of touch and wrong-headed.

Title: Clinton and Sanders Spar Over Debate Dates as Wisconsin Primary Looms

Article:

The Democratic presidential front-runner, Hillary Clinton, and her challenger, Bernie Sanders, are engaged in a heated debate over debate dates as the Wisconsin primary approaches. Sanders has challenged Clinton to a debate in New York, her adopted home state, ahead of its April 19 primary. The Clinton campaign has offered alternative dates, which the Sanders campaign sees as less than optimal for viewership.

Clinton told NBC's "Meet the Press" that she is "confident" about the debate happening, while Sanders' campaign spokesman, Michael Briggs, accused the Clinton campaign of "silly political games" and called for the debate to take place on April 10, 11, 12, or 13. Briggs also claimed that the Clinton campaign had "disingenuously" announced a debate date that Sanders had already committed to for a major rally in New York City.

Meanwhile, the Republican presidential front-runner, Donald Trump, and his opponents, Ted Cruz and John Kasich, are campaigning in Wisconsin ahead of the state's primary. Trump has doubled down on his comments that the US should "do a better deal" with Japan, South Korea, and other allies, saying they should pay more for America's protection while taking a greater role in their defense. He also reiterated his stance against raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour, saying it would make companies less competitive.

Kasich, who has won only Ohio, told ABC's "This Week" that the Republican convention could be a "civics lesson" for the country, with kids learning how to elect presidents. Trump, however, called for Kasich to drop out of the race, arguing he shouldn't be allowed to continue accumulating delegates if he has no chance of being the nominee.

The article does not take a stance on the debate or the presidential candidates' positions, instead focusing on presenting the facts and quotes from the candidates.

Title: Military Deployment to Puerto Rico Sluggish, Despite Urgent Need for Assistance

The United States has deployed around 5,000 National Guard forces and active military personnel to assist in Puerto Rico, which is a significant distance from the 3.5 million people affected by Hurricane Maria. For context, 22,000 troops were deployed to Haiti after the 2010 earthquake, and Puerto Rico is a US territory. The pace of military deployment has been slow, but it appears to be gaining momentum.

In the first six days after the hurricane made landfall, the Navy deployed only two ships, citing concerns about damaged ports. However, reports of isolated US citizens struggling without electricity and running low on food and water have prompted the Pentagon to increase its relief efforts, despite not being specifically requested by territorial officials.

The issue of port crowding has been raised as an excuse for military inaction and the reluctance to waive the Jones Act. However, much of the delay seems to be due to a lack of preparedness. The hospital ship USNS Comfort, for example, was docked in Norfolk, Virginia, with a minimal crew, requiring up to five days to stock up and get underway. The ship was finally ordered to move a week after the storm, but it is still preparing to depart.

In comparison, the Comfort was deployed to Haiti immediately after the 2010 earthquake. The White House has finally allowed foreign-built or flagged ships to deliver supplies during the emergency, but has restricted members of Congress from making official visits to the hurricane-battered US Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Congressional sources from both parties have expressed frustration with the restrictions, citing the dire situation on the ground.

The San Juan Airport is open, but flights in and out are severely restricted due to damaged infrastructure. While the argument for restricting Congressional flights has some validity, it also prevents any oversight or evaluation of conditions on the ground.

Title: Hillary Clinton Discusses High Expectations for Women in Public Eye

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recently appeared on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" to discuss the challenges she faced as a high-achieving woman in the public eye. Clinton noted that expectations for women are often extremely high, and that there is a lack of understanding and acceptance of different approaches and styles.

Clinton stated that she is not as naturally skilled as her husband, former President Bill Clinton, or President Barack Obama, and that her own approach to politics is rooted in her deep conviction to ensure opportunities for everyone in the country. She invests a significant amount of energy and emotion into her work, which can sometimes be nerve-wracking.

Clinton also highlighted the importance of understanding and accepting different approaches and styles, noting that men have more flexibility and can be successful in various ways. She emphasized that women are often expected to perform at a higher level all the time, which can be challenging and stressful.

The discussion was sparked by host Joe Scarborough's observation that his co-host, Mika Brzezinski, was doing more preparation for the interview than he was. Clinton acknowledged that she has put a lot of effort into her work and that it can be overwhelming at times.

Title: America's Progress on Racism and Sexism: A Reality Check

The recent speech by Britney Spears at the GLAAD Media Awards highlighted the importance of acceptance and inclusivity. However, the article's author takes issue with the notion that the United States is the most racist or sexist country in the world. According to the author, this claim is not supported by objective standards.

The author notes that while discrimination exists, progress has been made in the United States. For instance, a 2014 survey found that only 6% of Americans were opposed to having a racially different neighbor, ranking the country 47th among industrialized nations. Additionally, the country has made significant strides in terms of interracial marriage rates, which have increased more than fivefold since 1967.

The author also points out that the United States has elected a racial minority as its head of state, a feat that no other major power has achieved. Furthermore, the country admits more immigrants than any other country, making it a beacon of diversity.

The author argues that the idea that America is uniquely hostile to "being different" is an interesting thesis, but one that may have had some basis in fact 50 or 100 years ago. However, the author is skeptical of this claim and believes that it is not supported by current data.

In conclusion, the author believes that while America is not without its problems, it is not the most racist or sexist country in the world. Rather, it is a country that has made significant progress and continues to work towards a more inclusive and accepting society.

Title: Senate to Hold Briefing on Election Security Amid Growing Concerns About Foreign Interference

The United States Senate will hold a private briefing on election security on Wednesday, a move that has been pushed for by Democrats for months. The briefing is expected to include officials from the Department of Homeland Security, the FBI, and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, according to The Hill.

The briefing comes as concerns about foreign interference in the 2020 elections continue to grow. Both Republicans and Democrats have expressed concerns about potential interference by Russia and other foreign powers, and some Senate committees have passed bipartisan election security bills. However, GOP lawmakers have been more reluctant to take up concrete measures, partly due to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's opposition.

McConnell has expressed concerns about the potential for federal overreach in election security legislation, stating that it could undermine state and local control of elections. He has also been hesitant to consider election security bills, which some Democrats see as a way to placate President Trump, who has discouraged talk about election security due to its connection to questions about his 2016 victory.

The briefing is seen as a victory for Democrats, who hope it will convince their Republican colleagues to consider passing additional legislation. However, it remains to be seen whether the information shared during the meeting will be enough to spur further action.

The Republican-controlled Senate has allowed several election security bills to fall by the wayside, including the Protecting American Votes and Elections Act, the Defending the Integrity of Voting Systems Act, and the Foreign Influence Reporting in Elections Act. Despite warnings from high-level government officials, including special counsel Robert Mueller and FBI Director Christopher Wray, the Senate has taken a do-nothing approach to election security.

The lack of action on election security has major consequences, as Democrats argue that it leaves the country vulnerable to potential breaches. Intelligence agencies and other bodies are working to bolster American defenses before the 2020 election, but Republican leadership appears content to sit idly by despite numerous warnings about the need for more resources to prevent potential breaches.

Title: President Trump Criticizes 2015 Iran Nuclear Agreement, Gives Congress a Final Chance to Fix It

Article:

President Trump has sharply criticized the 2015 international nuclear agreement with Iran, stating that Congress and other nations must set stricter conditions for Iranian behavior to keep the U.S. from withdrawing from the pact. The President emphasized that the agreement is under continuous review and can be canceled by him at any time. He also highlighted the need to address Iran's sponsorship of terrorism, missile program, and efforts to destabilize the Middle East.

The President's ultimatum to fix the agreement's many flaws, including allowing Iran to enrich uranium and operate a plutonium-producing heavy-water reactor, has been met with skepticism. The chances of Congress and European leaders making substantial changes to the agreement are extremely remote. The President has given Congress 60 days to decide whether to reimpose severe economic sanctions on Iran, which were lifted by the nuclear agreement.

The agreement's shortcomings include weak inspection provisions, Iran's missile program, and support of terrorism. Any legislation or renegotiation must address these issues, but it is unlikely that Congress will pass legislation with substantial fixes or that other nations will agree to changes.

The President's decision to not withdraw from the agreement immediately is seen as an attempt to work with Congress and follow the law. However, he can reimpose most sanctions on Iran himself if Congress fails to act, and additional sanctions can be imposed as part of a withdrawal decision.

The article concludes that the nuclear deal with Iran is all but dead, and the President will likely put it out of its misery in about two months.

Title: Department of Health and Human Services Reverses Obama-Era Rule on "Sex" Definition

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has announced a new rule that defines "sex" as biological sex for the purposes of the Affordable Care Act's nondiscrimination policy. This move reverses an Obama-era policy that had redefined "sex" to include "gender identity" and "termination of pregnancy" for the same purpose.

The new rule, which takes effect immediately, updates the definition of "sex" to align with court rulings that deemed the previous definition unlawful. The Obama-era regulation had been challenged in court, with a federal judge in Texas vacating the rule in 2017. The HHS Office for Civil Rights Director, Roger Severino, stated that the new rule "carries forward the Obama administration's decision not to include'sexual orientation' as a protected category under the definition of sex discrimination."

The revised definition of "sex" means that medical professionals will no longer be required to treat individuals according to their gender identity, rather than their biological sex. This change is intended to ensure that healthcare providers can make decisions based on the biological realities of sex, particularly in programs administered or funded by HHS.

The decision to reverse the Obama-era rule has been met with criticism from progressive activists and allies in the media, who argue that it will harm the transgender community. However, the move is seen as a fulfillment of a key promise made by President Trump to undo Obama-era policies that redefined "sex" to include "sexual orientation" and "gender identity."

Title: Clinton Maintains Lead in National Polls, but Faces Fresh Criticism Over E-mails

Article:

Hillary Clinton has maintained an average lead of over 5 percentage points over Donald Trump in national polls since the Democratic convention, with a double-digit lead in several traditional battleground states. However, her presidential campaign is facing fresh criticism over newly discovered emails and documents related to her time as Secretary of State. The latest revelations have sparked accusations of preferential treatment for major Clinton Foundation donors and a "pay-to-play" culture during her tenure.

Despite the ongoing controversy, James Carville, a longtime Clinton confidant and political strategist, believes the Democratic Party is poised for a significant victory in the 2016 presidential election. Carville, who guided Bill Clinton's 1992 presidential campaign, attributes the Democratic Party's strong position to demographic changes in the country, which are unfavorable to the Republican Party.

Carville notes that the Republican Party is struggling this cycle due to its reliance on non-college whites, which has proven unsuccessful in presidential years. He also attributes the party's struggles to the lingering effects of the last Republican president's disastrous war and recession, as well as the party's appeal to a shrinking demographic.

Carville also believes that Trump's hard-core supporters are not the same people who voted for Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, or Jeb Bush, and that Trump's message of nationalism and xenophobia has resonated with some Republicans who feel their influence is shrinking. He notes that many Americans, particularly those who are 53-year-old white men without a college education, feel their lives have not turned out as expected and are attracted to Trump's message of blame and anger.

Title: President Obama Highlights Importance of Unity and Fairness in the Face of Adversity

President Barack Obama has emphasized the importance of Americans putting aside their differences and working together in the face of adversity. In a recent speech, he highlighted the country's progress in recovering from the Great Recession and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and emphasized the need for a champion for the aspirations of all Americans.

According to Obama, the key to America's prosperity lies in the strength of its middle class, where everyone gets a fair shot, does their fair share, and plays by the same rules. He believes that the current economic plan, which asks the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more, has led to real progress, with the creation of nearly 5.5 million new jobs, rising home values, and a decrease in foreign oil dependence.

In contrast, Obama criticized the opposing party's vision, which he believes would lead to a return to the policies that caused the economic crisis in the first place. He argued that the current plan would benefit the wealthy at the expense of the middle class and would not address the country's pressing issues.

Obama emphasized the importance of education, innovation, and nation-building at home, rather than abroad. He also highlighted the need to reduce the deficit by cutting spending and asking the wealthiest Americans to go back to the income tax rates they paid during the Clinton administration.

The president appealed to Americans to vote for him on Tuesday, emphasizing that the future they hope for is within their sights. He believes that the America they believe in is within their reach, where everyone has the opportunity to succeed, regardless of their background or circumstances.

**Students and Parents from Florida High School Arrive in Tallahassee to Lobby for Assault-Style Rifle Ban**

A group of students and parents from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, where 17 teens and staff members were killed in a shooting last week, arrived in Tallahassee, Florida, to lobby for a ban on assault-style rifles. The visit comes as the nation grapples with the second-deadliest school shooting in U.S. history, prompting a national debate about gun rights and stricter firearms controls.

The students, who traveled from Parkland, Florida, were welcomed with waves, cheers, and somber applause from fellow teens. Diego Pfeiffer, a senior at Stoneman Douglas, addressed the crowd, saying, "We're here to make sure this never happens again."

The visit coincides with the Republican-controlled Florida House of Representatives rejecting a bid to bring up a bill to block the sale of assault-style rifles in the state. Tyra Hemans, a 19-year-old senior, said, "I am not going back to school until lawmakers, and the president, change this law."

The students and parents are expected to stage a rally at the statehouse on Wednesday, about 450 miles north of the school. Fourteen students and three educators were killed, and 15 others were wounded in the February 14 attack. Nikolas Cruz, 19, a former student expelled from Stoneman Douglas High for disciplinary problems, was arrested and charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder.

The incident has sparked a youth-led protest movement, with prominent celebrity supporters like George Clooney and his wife Amal, Steven Spielberg, and Oprah Winfrey contributing $500,000 each to help fund a planned March 24 gun control march in Washington. A Washington Postal News opinion poll showed 77% of Americans believe the Republican-dominated U.S. Congress is doing too little to prevent mass shootings.

The incident has also led to increased scrutiny of the Florida Department of Children and Families, which had opened an inquiry into Cruz's case in 2017 after he was reported to have been cutting himself. The case was closed in November of that year with the finding that he was receiving sufficient support.

The incident has also sparked a debate about gun ownership and the Second Amendment, with some calling for stricter regulations and others advocating for the right to bear arms. The U.S. Military Academy at West Point made a rare posthumous letter of acceptance to Peter Wang, a student killed in the shooting, who had aspired to attend the elite academy.

Title: Senate Finance Committee Considers Overhauling Tax Code, Five Tax Breaks in Jeopardy

Article:

The Senate Finance Committee is working to overhaul the tax code, with only 15 days left for senators to defend the entire Tax Code. Instead of debating which tax breaks to eliminate, Chairman Max Baucus (D-Mont.) and top Republican Orrin Hatch are taking a "blank slate" approach, eliminating virtually every special tax provision and leaving it up to colleagues to explain why each provision should stay. This approach is expected to result in significant changes to the tax code, with some tax breaks potentially being rewritten or eliminated entirely.

Five tax breaks are particularly vulnerable to being rewritten or scrapped, including the mortgage interest deduction and the carried interest tax rate for hedge fund managers. The mortgage interest deduction allows homeowners to deduct up to $1 million in mortgage interest each year, including for vacation homes. This provision is one of the biggest tax expenditures, costing over $1 trillion over 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

Critics argue that the deduction is too generous, particularly for those who can afford to spend $1 million on a home. President Barack Obama has proposed capping all deductions, including the mortgage interest write-off, at 28%. Lawmakers could also pare back the deduction, focusing it more on middle-class homeowners.

Lobbyists are already working to protect the deduction, citing the slowly rebounding housing market and the potential negative impact on housing prices, especially in vacation communities. Jamie Gregory, deputy chief lobbyist of the National Association of Realtors, said, "We finally have housing and the economy headed in the right direction, and we don't think this is a good time to be messing around with it."

Another tax break in jeopardy is the carried interest tax rate for hedge fund managers. This provision allows hedge fund managers, private equity executives, and others working on Wall Street to pay a special tax rate on profits-based compensation, known as carried interest. Instead of paying ordinary income taxes, which top out at almost 40%, carried interest is taxed as a capital gain, generally at a rate of 20%. Top earners started paying an additional 3.8% tax on their investment income this year.

Democrats have long complained that the break is unfair and that Wall Street executives' pay should be taxed as ordinary income. With the crush of tax reform, they may finally get their way if lawmakers decide it's not worth spending much time worrying about the plight of hedge fund and private equity managers. The industry has repeatedly beaten back Democrats' efforts to kill the break, saying higher rates would only hurt the economy.

Title: FBI Admits to Ignoring Tip About Nikolas Cruz's Potential to Harm Others Before Parkland Shooting

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has acknowledged that it failed to act on a tip received over a month before the Parkland, Florida, school shooting that left 17 people dead. The tip, made on January 5, 2018, warned of Nikolas Cruz's potential to harm others, citing his gun ownership, desire to kill people, erratic behavior, and disturbing social media posts.

According to the FBI, the tip was not forwarded to the Miami field office and no further investigation was conducted. The agency stated that "protocols were not followed" and the tip was not properly investigated.

The revelation is likely to generate scrutiny over how law enforcement handles investigations in similar cases. FBI Director Christopher Wray has promised to investigate the matter and review the processes for responding to public tips.

Florida Governor Rick Scott has called for FBI Director Wray's resignation, stating that the agency failed to act on the tip and undermine the "see something, say something" initiative. Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel has also announced that his department received about 20 calls regarding Cruz in the past few years, although he did not provide details about the calls.

The FBI's admission comes after President Donald Trump blamed "neighbors and classmates" for not reporting Cruz's behavior to authorities. However, the FBI's statement suggests that many people did report their concerns, but the warnings were not thoroughly pursued or fell on deaf ears.

The FBI's failure to act on the tip is the latest piece of evidence that many people saw red flags in Cruz's behavior, including his expulsion from school for bad and erratic behavior. The agency's inability to identify the individual who posted a YouTube comment threatening to become a "professional school shooter" in the fall of 2017 also raises questions about the effectiveness of its database reviews and checks.

The incident highlights the importance of proper investigation and follow-up on tips and warnings about potential threats.

Title: Uninsured Rate Among Low- and Middle-Income LGBT Americans Falls by Quarter

The uninsured rate among low- and middle-income LGBT Americans decreased by 8 percentage points, from 34% in 2013 to 26% in 2014, according to a new report from the Center for American Progress. The decline was most significant among those with the lowest incomes, many of whom qualified for large subsidies to purchase private coverage.

The report, which relies on two surveys of LGBT Americans earning less than 400% of the poverty line (approximately $44,000 for an individual), found that the uninsured rate among this group fell from 34% to 26% between 2013 and 2014. This decline is slightly faster than the drop among the general population, where the uninsured rate fell by about a quarter.

The gains were particularly large among lower-income groups, which were eligible for bigger insurance subsidies or the Medicaid expansion. The uninsured rate for LGBT individuals earning between 139% and 200% of the poverty line (approximately $15,000 to $22,000 for an individual) fell by 18 percentage points. This group receives the most generous subsidies to buy private insurance, with the health care law limiting their contribution to monthly premiums to no more than 6% of their income.

The CAP survey shows that 26% of LGBT Americans under 400% of the poverty line are uninsured, compared to 20% of the general population. LGBT people face unique obstacles in gaining coverage, including the lack of federal law requiring companies to offer health benefits to same-sex partners and anti-LGBT bias in hiring, which may push individuals into unemployment or low-wage jobs without benefits.

As a result, only 38% of LGBT people under 400% of the poverty line have an offer of insurance through their own or their spouse's employer, compared to 58% of the general population. Within the LGBT community, there are also disparities in coverage rates, with gay and bisexual individuals having higher insured rates than lesbian women, and transgender populations having a particularly high uninsured rate. The CAP report notes that the uninsured rate among transgender populations has decreased significantly under the Affordable Care Act, although the 2013 survey only included a smaller number of transgender individuals.

Title: "Catastrophic Flooding in Texas Expected to Worsen as Waters Rise"

The US state of Texas is bracing for the worst as catastrophic flooding continues to affect the region following Hurricane Harvey. The storm made landfall as a category-four hurricane on Friday, bringing unprecedented flooding to the city of Houston and surrounding areas. According to reports, a record 30 inches of rain has already fallen in Houston, with forecasters predicting the total rainfall could nearly double later this week.

The city's mayor, Sylvester Turner, has activated the entire Texas National Guard to assist in search and rescue operations, with over 3,000 people already rescued in and around Houston. At least nine people have been reported dead in incidents related to the storm, with six members of the same family reportedly killed while trying to flee rising floodwaters.

The National Hurricane Center has warned of "catastrophic and life-threatening flooding" across southeastern Texas, with additional rainfall accumulations of 15 to 25 inches expected. The National Weather Service has predicted the worst of the floods will occur on Wednesday and Thursday, although there is still uncertainty about the storm's path.

The flooding has caused widespread disruption, with many schools and businesses closed, and the city's two main airports completely flooded. The Texas Gulf Coast is a key center of the US oil and gas industry, with some of the largest refineries in the country halting operations.

Residents of Houston and surrounding areas are struggling to cope with the disaster, with many forced to wade through waist-deep water to access basic necessities. Anthony Rogers, 54, summed up the mood, saying the authorities had been "useless" in responding to the crisis.

The situation is being compared to the devastating effects of Hurricane Katrina in 2005, which left thousands of people stranded in squalid conditions at New Orleans' stadium. Tens of thousands of people have been ordered to leave parts of Fort Bend County, about 35 miles south-west of Houston, where a river is set to crest this week.

The city of Dallas has set up a "mega shelter" at its convention center to house 5,000 evacuees, but Houston authorities have not issued a mass evacuation order. The mayor has defended the decision, citing the "crazy" logistics of planning an evacuation of 2.3 million people.

Police Chief Art Acevedo has said officers are focused on protecting the city from looters, with four people arrested on Monday.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Rules Out 2020 Presidential Run and DNA Testing

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has announced that she will not run for the 2020 presidential election and has also declined to take a DNA test to prove her Native American ancestry. The issue of her heritage has been a topic of controversy in her previous Senate campaigns and could have created problems in a potential White House bid.

In an interview with "Fox News Sunday," Warren stated, "I'm not running for president." When asked about the calls for genetic testing to resolve the controversy, Warren shared a family history, as told by her parents and grandparents, and said, "It's a part of who I am, and no one's ever going to take that away."

Warren, a champion of the Democratic Party's progressive wing, has been accused of claiming Native American heritage to help secure jobs, including one as a Harvard law professor. She has acknowledged identifying as a minority but denies using her status to advance her career. President Trump has repeatedly referred to Warren as "Pocahontas," a notable American Indian woman in colonial history, to highlight the controversy.

In the interview, Warren shared a personal family story about her parents' love story and their struggles during the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl. She emphasized that she knows who she is because of the stories told by her family members, including her parents, grandparents, aunts, and uncles.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Sides with Conservative Colleagues on Prisoner's Supervised Release

Article: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, one of the four liberal justices on the Supreme Court, joined her conservative colleagues in a majority decision on Monday. The decision concerns a prisoner, Jason Mont, who was sentenced for violating his supervised release, even though his release expired while he was incarcerated.

Ginsburg sided with Justices Clarence Thomas, John Roberts, Samuel Alito, and Brett Kavanaugh in the majority, ruling that Mont can be sentenced for violating his supervised release, even if the release expires while he is incarcerated ahead of facing new charges. The decision was a surprise, as Ginsburg has often been at odds with her conservative colleagues on various issues.

In a separate case, Ginsburg and Thomas had a tense disagreement over the Sex Selective and Disability Abortion Ban, with Thomas arguing that the ban was necessary to prevent eugenics and Ginsburg countering that the ban was an attack on women's reproductive rights. However, in the case of Mont's supervised release, the two justices found common ground.

The case involves Mont, who was released from federal prison in 2012 after serving time for drug and firearm offenses. He was placed on supervised release, but broke the law again and tested positive on several drug tests. The District Court issued a warrant and set a supervised-release hearing, which Mont challenged, arguing that the court lacked jurisdiction since his supervised release had expired. The court concluded that it had authority to supervise Mont and revoked his supervised release, ordering him to serve an additional 42 months' imprisonment.

In a dissenting opinion, Justice Neil Gorsuch joined liberal Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Stephen Breyer, and Elena Kagan, arguing that time in pretrial detention does not constitute supervised release. The case highlights the complexities of the criminal justice system and the ongoing debates surrounding supervised release and the role of the courts in supervising defendants.

Title: Senators' Pet Projects: Immigration Bill Includes Visas for Meat Industry, Ski Instructors, and More

The recently passed bipartisan immigration bill contains several provisions that benefit specific industries and states, including additional visas for the meat industry, ski instructors, and others. These provisions were inserted by senators who represent states with significant interests in these industries.

One such provision, pushed by South Carolina Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, adds up to 20,000 additional visas for meat cutters and trimmers. The meat industry employed 158,480 Americans nationwide in May 2012, according to the Labor Department. In South Carolina, the industry generated $698 million in 2011, nearly 27% of all agricultural cash in the state.

The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union opposes this provision, citing concerns about labor shortages in the industry. "The way we view this is it's an earmark for meat and poultry, and we strongly, strongly oppose it," said Tim Schlittner, a union spokesman. "It appears to have been dropped in the bill at the 11th hour. Quite frankly, we're taken back by its inclusion."

Colorado Democratic Senator Michael Bennet inserted a provision to make it easier for ski resorts to hire foreign ski instructors. The provision allows ski instructors to come to the U.S. under the same program that professional athletes use, which allows them to stay in the U.S. for up to a decade. Ski areas are hiring fewer foreign workers for jobs such as housekeeping and lift-operating since the recession, but finding certified ski instructors, especially those who speak other languages, has been a problem.

New York Democratic Senator Charles Schumer pushed for special treatment for Irish workers, citing a 1965 change to immigration law that inadvertently made it difficult for Irish immigrants to obtain visas. An aide to Senator Schumer said the provision would benefit Irish people with at least a high-school degree.

Florida Republican Senator Marco Rubio inserted provisions to allow foreigners to come to the U.S. for 90 days to work on relief operations after state or federal disasters and to repair cruise ships made abroad. Florida drew $6.7 billion in direct spending from the cruise industry in 2011, according to the Cruise Lines International Association.

The construction industry, which has been critical of immigration bill provisions, fared better than expected. Senators Rubio and Jeff Flake (R., Ariz.) were unable to get a cap lifted that limits construction visas to 15,000, but they did include a provision allowing foreigners to work in higher-skilled jobs such as electricians, plumbers, and welders.

Title: Trayvon Martin's Parents Ask President Obama to Investigate Son's Death, Urge Peaceful Protests

Trayvon Martin's parents, Sybrina Fulton and Tracy Martin, have asked President Barack Obama to investigate their son's death with a "fine-tooth comb" and ensure that all the facts are clear. The request comes after a Florida jury found George Zimmerman not guilty of murdering Trayvon Martin last weekend. The verdict has sparked widespread outrage and protests across the country.

In their first television interviews since the verdict, Fulton and Martin appeared on various news programs, including CBS This Morning and NBC's Today, to discuss the case and its impact on their family and the nation. They urged President Obama to investigate the circumstances surrounding Trayvon's death and to ensure that justice is served.

"We're asking the Department of Justice to answer that question for us," said Benjamin Crump, the family's attorney. "Can a private citizen with a gun profile and follow our children home? Because the United States Supreme Court doesn't even allow the police to profile people based on race, so this is an issue, we need to know because we need to know what to tell our children."

Trayvon's parents also expressed their disappointment and devastation over the verdict, with Fulton stating that she was "shocked" and "devastated" by the outcome. They also urged those protesting the decision to remain peaceful and not to damage their own property.

"We have always maintained to do things decent and in order, and we think the protests should be peaceful protests," Fulton said on NBC. "We're not saying for them not to protest, because they have a right to protest, they have a right to be heard. But we just want to make sure that it is peaceful, that nobody gets hurt, that nobody gets arrested, that you don't damage your own property."

The Department of Justice is currently investigating whether it will bring a civil rights case against Zimmerman, but the White House has said that President Obama will stay out of the decision. Trayvon's parents are also exploring legal options, including a civil suit, and are asking the Justice Department to weigh in.

The case has sparked a national conversation about racial profiling, gun control, and the need for greater understanding and empathy. Trayvon's parents hope that their son's death will serve as a wake-up call for the nation to address these issues and ensure that similar tragedies do not occur in the future.

Title: Former Presidents Bush and Obama Share Laughter and Respect at White House Portrait Unveiling

Article:

Former President George W. Bush made a rare public appearance alongside President Barack Obama at the unveiling of his official portrait in the White House. The event brought together the 43rd and 44th presidents, as well as their spouses and family members. Bush's humor and wit stole the show, as he joked about the symmetry between his portrait and that of George Washington, and advised Obama to "gaze at his portrait" whenever he had a big decision to make and ask himself, "What would George do?"

The ceremony was a rare moment of camaraderie between the two presidents, who have had their differences in the past. Obama thanked the Bush family for their assistance during the transition period in 2008 and shared words of wisdom from the Bush daughters to his own daughters, Malia and Sasha. The Obamas were joined by former President George H.W. Bush and first lady Barbara Bush, as well as former chief political strategist Karl Rove and other Bush administration officials.

Despite their political differences, the presidents showed respect and appreciation for each other's service. Obama acknowledged the challenges faced by his predecessor, including the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the loss of America's prestige, and the worst recession since the 1930s. White House spokesman Jay Carney noted that while there may have been differences in the past, there is a great deal of respect and appreciation held by everyone participating in the ceremony.

The event was a moment of levity and camaraderie, with both presidents putting aside their differences to celebrate their shared experiences as leaders of the free world.

Title: Balancing Privacy and Convenience in the Digital Age

The article discusses the importance of privacy in the digital age, citing examples of celebrities like Scarlett Johansson who have had their personal information compromised. The author argues that while it is understandable to be concerned about privacy breaches, it is also important to recognize that many individuals voluntarily share their personal information with companies like Amazon and Facebook.

The author notes that while it may be true that some companies may not use the information they collect in a malicious way, the government's access to personal data raises more significant concerns. The article highlights the example of the National Highway Traffic Safety Agency's proposal to make black box recorders mandatory in all cars, which could potentially reveal sensitive information about individuals.

The author concludes that while some privacy is sacrificed in the name of convenience and progress, it is essential to maintain the freedom to choose when to share personal information and when to keep it private. The article encourages readers to be aware of the trade-offs between privacy and convenience and to make informed decisions about what they are willing to share.

Note: The article does not take a stance on any political party or ideology, and the language used is neutral and objective. The author presents a balanced view of the issue, acknowledging both the importance of privacy and the need for convenience and progress.

Title: Police Use of Non-Lethal Weapons on Protesters Intensifies Amid Demonstrations Against George Floyd's Death

Police across the United States have employed a range of non-lethal weapons to disperse protesters demonstrating against the death of George Floyd, who died in Minneapolis police custody. These weapons, often described as "non-lethal," include tear gas, pepper spray, and rubber bullets. While intended to minimize harm, these methods have sometimes resulted in serious injuries to protesters.

Tear gas, a chemical compound powder, is frequently used by police to disperse crowds. It produces a burning sensation in the eyes and mouth, incapacitating those affected. Pepper spray, another chemical irritant, is used in handheld devices and projectiles, causing similar effects. Police have also fired pepper balls, small projectiles containing chemical irritants, which can be shot from launchers or modified paintball guns.

In addition to these methods, police have deployed flashbang grenades, which explode with a bright light and sound to stun and disorient demonstrators. Protesters have also been hit by rubber, plastic, and "sponger" bullets, with some journalists reporting being shot with 40mm hard plastic projectiles during a protest in Minneapolis.

A 2017 survey published by the British Medical Journal found that injuries from "kinetic impact projectiles" caused death in 2.7% of cases. Protesters have reported being shot with wooden bullets, with images online showing wooden dowel-shaped rods sliced into small, bullet-sized projectiles. The Columbus Police Department did not respond to requests for comment.

In Los Angeles, police have used rubber projectiles, with Mayor Eric Garcetti stating that the police department will minimize their use going forward. The use of these non-lethal weapons has sparked concerns about the effectiveness and safety of their deployment, as well as the potential for harm to protesters and bystanders.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot's Medical Documents Suggest He Concealed Illness from Employers

German prosecutors have revealed that the co-pilot of the Germanwings airliner that crashed into the Alps, killing all 150 people on board, had concealed an illness from his employers. According to a statement from the Dusseldorf prosecutors' office, police found medical documents indicating an existing illness and corresponding medical treatment, including a torn-up sick note valid for the day of the incident. This suggests that the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, may have concealed his illness from his employer, Lufthansa, and his occupational environment.

The statement did not disclose the nature of Lubitz's illness, although German media outlets have reported that he may have suffered from depression. The Dusseldorf University clinic said Lubitz visited the facility in February and March, most recently on March 10, but denied he was treated there for depression.

The investigation is ongoing, and the German Federal Aviation Office has requested access to Lubitz's medical records, which will then be sent to French investigators. The cockpit voice recorder revealed that Lubitz deliberately locked the pilot out of the cockpit and initiated a descent that led to the tragic crash.

Lufthansa has stated that Lubitz was "100% fit to fly" on the day of the incident, but Germanwings said it received no sick leave note for that day. The airline has set up a family assistance center in Marseille, France, and will provide briefings with family members starting on Saturday.

The investigation is ongoing, and the exact motive behind Lubitz's actions remains unclear.

Title: Polls Show Christie and Clinton Neck-and-Neck in Hypothetical 2016 Match-Up

Article:

A recent email sent to the author's inbox highlighted a hypothetical 2016 presidential match-up between New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and Hillary Clinton. The poll results showed Christie trailing Clinton, but within the margin of error. However, it is essential to note that neither candidate has officially announced their candidacy, and the first contest, the Iowa caucuses, is still over a year away.

Polls taken at this early stage are often unreliable, as they can be influenced by various factors and may not accurately reflect the candidates' chances of winning. History has shown that many politicians who were once considered strong contenders ultimately failed to secure their party's nomination. Examples include Rudy Giuliani, Colin Powell, Mario Cuomo, Gary Hart, Edmund Muskie, and others.

While the author acknowledges the importance of polls in understanding political trends and voter sentiment, they also recognize that it is premature to draw conclusions from these early polls. The author is eager to engage with voters and examine strategies as the election season unfolds, but for now, it is too early to speculate about the outcome of the 2016 presidential election.

Title: Trump to Meet with Putin in Hamburg: A High-Stakes Encounter

Article:

On Friday, US President Donald Trump will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Hamburg, Germany. The meeting has raised concerns among many, including the potential for a tense and unpredictable encounter. The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, will be the only other American official present, along with Tillerson's counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, and two translators.

The meeting is expected to be a closely watched event, with many wondering what will be discussed and what agreements, if any, will be reached. The Russian team is seen as united and sophisticated, while the US team is perceived as fractured and unpredictable.

In an ideal scenario, the US president would acknowledge Russian meddling in the 2016 election, support investigations into the matter, and make it clear that such interference will not be tolerated in the future. The president would also emphasize the importance of denying the Kremlin the legitimacy and recognition it craves, and would use US cyber capabilities to expose hidden bank accounts and investments of senior Kremlin officials.

However, this is not what is expected to happen. Instead, the meeting is likely to be a free-wheeling discussion with no clear agenda or concrete outcomes. The US president's national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, has indicated that the meeting will be a "listening exercise" with no specific goals or objectives.

The meeting comes at a time when the US and Russia are at odds over several issues, including Russian meddling in the 2016 election and the conflict in Ukraine. The US has imposed sanctions on Russia in response to its actions, and the meeting is seen as an opportunity for the two leaders to discuss these issues and potentially find common ground.

The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, and many are bracing for the worst. The US president's tweets and statements in the aftermath of the meeting will be closely watched, and many are expecting a tweet storm or a press conference to follow.

Title: Indiana Primary Polls Show Uncertainty Ahead of Tuesday's Vote

The upcoming Indiana primary election is shrouded in uncertainty, with Donald Trump holding a double-digit lead in some polls, while Ted Cruz is within striking distance in others. The lack of public polling data in the state, with only seven surveys conducted in the past month, has contributed to the uncertainty.

The polls that have been released show varying results, with Trump leading in six of the seven public polls, but Cruz's campaign has dismissed the results, citing the media's attempts to convince voters that the race is hopeless. The Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne (IPFW) poll, which showed Cruz with a 16-point lead, stands out as an outlier, with pollster Andy Downs attributing the result to the long 15-day field period and the lack of demographic weighting.

The IPFW poll's methodology differs from other surveys, which typically weight their results to ensure a representative sample. Downs declined to weight the poll, citing the lack of available demographic targets, which has been a challenge due to the state's infrequent competitive GOP presidential primary elections.

The other public polls show Trump ahead, but by varying margins. The most recent reliable poll, conducted by NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist, showed Trump with a 15-point lead over Cruz. Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, attributed the poll's results to the Cruz campaign's recent maneuvers, including a deal with Ohio Gov. John Kasich and naming Carly Fiorina as his running mate.

The uncertainty surrounding the polls has led to differing opinions on the outcome of the election. Fiorina, Cruz's running mate, dismissed the polls, saying they have been "way off" in the past. Miringoff, however, defended the Marist poll's track record, citing its accuracy in previous primaries.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar Calls for Impeachment of Justice Brett Kavanaugh Amid New Allegations

Article:

Representative Ilhan Omar (D-MN) has called for the impeachment of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, citing a recent New York Times article alleging that friends of Kavanaugh pushed his penis into the hand of a female student at a college party. The article, adapted from a forthcoming book by Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly, titled "The Education of Brett Kavanaugh: An Investigation," claims that an eyewitness saw the incident occur.

However, the Times later added to the article that the female student did not recall the incident, according to friends, and declined to comment. The book reports that the female student declined to be interviewed and friends say that she does not recall the incident.

Despite the walk-back of the allegation, Omar took to Twitter to express her support for impeachment proceedings against both President Trump and Kavanaugh. "Nothing terrifies this corrupt president more than the idea of Congress upholding the rule of law. We must open impeachment inquiries against Trump *and* Kavanaugh immediately. It's our constitutional duty," she tweeted.

The Times' article has sparked controversy, with some critics questioning the omission of the fact that the alleged victim did not recall the incident. MSNBC's Morning Joe host Joe Scarborough questioned why the Times did not include this information in the original article, stating, "Everybody makes mistakes. We were on the phone yesterday asking each other, wait a second, there's a woman who [Max] Stier claims was abused by Kavanaugh. Has she denied this? Has she claimed this happened? Why is there this glaring omission in the New York Times story?"

The article also failed to mention that the person making the new allegation, Max Stier, had served on former President Bill Clinton's defense team during impeachment proceedings. Kavanaugh had served on independent counsel Kenneth Starr's team.

Title: The Polarization of the United States: A Growing Concern

The United States has been experiencing growing polarization over the past decade and a half, with some arguing that it is the most divided since the Civil War. The BBC created a video exploring the division of Americans into two distinct political tribes, sparking questions about the factors contributing to this phenomenon.

The video suggests that factors such as neighborhood and hyper-partisan news and social media play a significant role in shaping an individual's political views and opinions. This can lead to ideological isolation, where individuals remain within their own echo chambers, fueled by anger or disenchantment towards the opposing side, and feel less inclined to engage with opposing viewpoints.

Historically, American politics has operated in a cyclical manner, with moderates making up the majority of voters. However, over the past two decades, the ideological divide has grown significantly, with Democrats and Republicans moving further apart in their willingness to find common ground.

The question remains whether America can find common ground in the future. Each individual has their own vision for what is best for the country, but understanding the complexities of issues and determining effective solutions requires a significant amount of time and effort. Ideally, Americans and the media can strive for integrity in sharing information, allowing voters to understand that they are in this together, regardless of their political affiliations.

Title: Sen. Amy Klobuchar Criticizes Restrictive Abortion Laws, Promises Action to Counter Measures

Article:

Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Democratic presidential hopeful from Minnesota, has spoken out against recent abortion laws passed in Republican-led states, vowing to take action to counter such measures if she wins in 2020. Several states, including Georgia, have enacted "heartbeat bills" that prohibit abortion once a fetal heartbeat is detected, typically around six weeks into pregnancy. Alabama, meanwhile, has banned nearly all abortions at any point in time, even in cases of rape or incest.

Klobuchar described these new laws as "dangerous" and "a place we have never seen before." She noted that these restrictions would effectively make it impossible for women to access abortion services, while also highlighting efforts to strip funding from Planned Parenthood, which would reduce access to contraception.

The sponsor of the Alabama law has stated that the goal is to provoke a legal challenge, aiming to overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision, which established abortion as a constitutional right. If that happens, individual states would be free to decide whether to keep abortion legal.

In response, Klobuchar promised to codify Roe v. Wade into law if the Supreme Court overturns it. On the other hand, some Republicans have expressed concerns over bills proposed in states like Virginia and New York, which expand abortion access, allowing it at any point during pregnancy under certain circumstances.

The Virginia bill, which sparked controversy when Delegate Kathy Tran said it would permit abortion up until birth, ultimately failed in the state legislature. New York passed the Reproductive Health Act in January, removing certain restrictions on third-trimester abortions and allowing the procedure at any point in a woman's pregnancy under certain circumstances.

When asked about laws permitting late-term abortions, Klobuchar clarified that she supports such legislation in cases where the mother's life or health are at risk. "That is exactly what the Supreme Court ruling says, and I am OK with that," she said.

Title: Sanders' Rise in New Hampshire Election Sparks Concerns About Clinton's Baggage

Article:

Bernie Sanders' recent surge in the New Hampshire primary has sparked concerns among some Democrats about Hillary Clinton's baggage and the potential risks it poses to her campaign. While some may not support Sanders as their ideal candidate, his rise in the polls has helped to puncture the aura of inevitability surrounding Clinton's campaign. This is not because Sanders is expected to win the general election, but because his presence in the race highlights the need for more serious and viable candidates to challenge Clinton.

Clinton's campaign has faced numerous controversies, including the ongoing email imbroglio, which has raised questions about her handling of classified information and her husband's involvement in a multimillion-dollar slush fund. The situation has led to a series of denials, reversals, and revelations, leaving many wondering what new explosive information might come to light in the future.

The article also touches on Bill Clinton's past scandals, including his alleged infidelity and his association with Jeffrey Epstein, a billionaire investor accused of sex trafficking. Flight logs from Epstein's private jet show at least 10 trips by Bill Clinton, including several with a woman believed to have procured underage girls for Epstein and his friends.

While some may view these scandals as old news, they remain a concern for many voters. The article concludes that it is only a matter of time before one of these time bombs explodes, potentially damaging Clinton's campaign and her chances of becoming the first female president.

Title: Former Trump Lawyer's Guilty Plea Raises Questions About Distractions in Politics

The recent guilty plea of Michael Cohen, former lawyer to President Trump, has sparked a flurry of reactions from critics and supporters alike. While Cohen's admission of guilt has led to a sense of vindication for those who have been critical of the President, it is unclear whether this development will change anyone's mind about Trump's actions.

The article argues that the obsessive focus on scandal and personal corruption is a distraction from the real issues facing the country. The author notes that the government is currently dealing with pressing issues such as the Russian military's attempts to hack conservative think tanks, ongoing wars in Afghanistan, Syria, and Yemen, and China's aggressive expansion in the South China Sea. Instead of focusing on these critical issues, the media and the public are fixated on "gory details of illicit but consensual sex between adults" and "gossipy West Wing intrigue."

The author suggests that this type of voyeuristic focus is a harmful distraction and that it is not productive to dwell on personal scandals. The article concludes that Trump's dalliances are a sideshow, and that the focus should be on the issues that truly matter.

Title: Trump Criticizes China and EU for Weak Currencies, Threatens Tariffs on Chinese Imports

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has criticized China and the European Union for their weak currencies and interest rates, stating that they are undermining America's "competitive edge." Trump took to Twitter to express his concerns, saying that the United States is being taken advantage of and that he is prepared to impose tariffs on all Chinese imports.

According to Trump, China and the European Union are manipulating their currencies and interest rates lower, while the United States is raising its interest rates, which is taking away its competitive edge. He also mentioned that the United States should not be penalized for doing well.

In an interview with CNBC, Trump stated that he is "ready to go" with tariffs on $500 billion of Chinese goods, which is roughly the value of all U.S. imports from China last year. He also expressed his frustration with the Federal Reserve's recent rate increases, saying that they are hurting the economy.

This development marks a shift in Trump's approach to trade, as he has previously focused on using tariffs as leverage to convince China and other nations to open up their markets. Trump's comments have sparked concerns about the potential for a currency spat, as the United States has traditionally avoided commenting on the dollar or the path of U.S. monetary policy.

The Treasury Secretary, Steven Mnuchin, will be heading to Buenos Aires for talks with G-20 counterparts, where he will likely face questions about the U.S. dollar policy and whether he sees the Fed as independent. The president's comments have put a ceiling on the recent U.S. dollar rally, according to a foreign-exchange strategist at ING Bank NV.

It is worth noting that the Treasury Department's semi-annual report released in April refrained from naming any country a currency manipulator based on specific criteria. The report did not mention China or the European Union as currency manipulators.

The development has sparked concerns about the potential impact on the global economy, as the United States and China are the world's two largest economies. The Trump administration has already imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum, and is considering a widely-criticized move to levy duties on auto-imports.

Title: California Senator Diane Feinstein Plans to Introduce Legislation to Ban Certain Firearms

Article:

California Senator Diane Feinstein plans to introduce legislation in January to ban the import, export, manufacturing, sale, and transfer of what she calls "assault weapons." The proposed bill would also ban ammunition clips holding more than 10 bullets. Feinstein stated that the purpose of the legislation is to get "weapons of war off the streets of our cities."

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, a strong advocate for gun control, has expressed support for the proposed bill. He believes that gun control should be President Obama's top priority, citing the high number of Americans killed with illegal guns. However, a recent Gallup poll shows that support for an assault weapons ban is at an all-time low, with 53% of Americans opposing the ban and 43% supporting it.

The proposed legislation would not apply retroactively, but would instead ban the sale, transfer, transportation, and possession of the affected weapons and ammunition clips prospectively. Feinstein did not specify which specific weapons would be affected, as the term "assault weapon" is often considered a political term.

Bloomberg also stated that mass shootings occur in the United States because of a lack of gun control, which is not supported by facts. He pointed to several international examples of mass shootings that occurred in countries with stricter gun control laws.

In contrast, a recent Gallup poll found that 44% of Americans prefer that gun laws remain as they are, while 11% favor less strict laws. The poll also found that support for making gun laws "more strict" is at its lowest point, with 43% in favor and 53% opposed.

President Obama has hinted that he may use his executive powers to push through new gun control measures before the new Congress starts.

Title: New York City Introduces Innovative Rat Control Method: A Machine and a Pool of Liquid Alcohol

New York City, known for being one of the most rat-infested cities in the US, has introduced a new weapon in its war against rodents. The city has deployed a machine that lures rats with bait and sends them through a trap door into a pool of alcohol-based liquid. The device, imported by Rat Trap, is designed to humanely and environmentally friendly eliminate the rodent population.

The machine, which can hold up to 80 rat carcasses, was demonstrated by sanitation workers in Brooklyn, showing several dead rats floating in a green liquid. During a month-long trial, a total of 107 rodents were lured and killed. The city has also trialed a liquid bait that makes rats infertile as part of its $32 million program to cull thousands of rodents.

The reported rat sightings have increased by almost 38% to 17,353 last year, according to OpenTheBooks, a non-profit watchdog group. Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams has described the new solution as "humane and environmentally friendly" and plans to roll it out in some of Brooklyn's most rat-infested districts.

However, animal rights group PETA has expressed concerns about the effectiveness of the method, stating that it will be "cruel and frightening." Elisa Allen, PETA's director, argues that the method will not curb overall rodent populations, as rats will continue to breed and rebound when animals remain fertile.

Title: Republican Senators Criticize Trump's Request to China to Investigate Biden

Article:

Several Republican senators have spoken out against President Donald Trump's request to China to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden's business dealings. Senator Susan Collins, along with Senators Mitt Romney and Ben Sasse, have expressed their disapproval of the president's actions. Collins stated that she believes Trump made a "big mistake" by asking China to get involved in investigating a political opponent, calling it "completely inappropriate."

The controversy surrounds Trump's request to China to investigate Hunter Biden's business dealings in the country, which was made after the president stalled nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine. The move was seen as an attempt to pressure Ukraine to investigate the Bidens over their business dealings in the country.

Other Republican senators, such as Ron Johnson and Marco Rubio, have also weighed in on the issue. Johnson stated that he "winced" at the suggestion that Trump was holding back military aid from Ukraine in exchange for an investigation into the Bidens. Rubio suggested that Trump's request to China was likely a joke, saying that "he's pretty good at getting everybody fired up."

Representative Jim Jordan, a top Trump ally in the House of Representatives, also expressed skepticism about the president's request, stating that he doesn't think China will actually investigate the Bidens. Trump has defended his requests to Ukraine and China, saying that as president, he has an obligation to look into possible corruption.

The controversy has sparked an impeachment inquiry by House Democrats, who are investigating Trump's actions and whether they constitute an abuse of power.

Title: Ethan Couch's Capture Raises Questions About Equal Justice in the United States

The capture of Ethan Couch, the 16-year-old who was sentenced to probation and rehab after killing four people in a drunk-driving crash in 2013, has once again raised questions about equal justice in the United States. Couch was extradited from Mexico after being caught Monday night, accused of breaking his parole agreement. The case has sparked outrage and highlighted the perceived disparities in the way the justice system treats rich and poor individuals.

The term "affluenza" was coined during the trial, suggesting that Couch's wealthy upbringing and lack of consequences for his actions contributed to his behavior. The case has been compared to the Trayvon Martin shooting and the acquittal of George Zimmerman, with many Americans believing that the justice system treats rich and poor individuals differently.

The Pew Research Center recently reported that only 32% of Americans believe the country has made enough changes to its justice system, with 59% believing more change is needed. The capture of Couch has raised public awareness about glitches in the promise of equal protection, which can act as a check on the law.

Experts say that events like Couch's capture raise questions about the application of rules and cultural factors, which can affect the outcome of cases. "What we see is how apparently neutral rules are always applied case by case, whether it's parole officers or judges or police officers, based on cultural factors," said Daniel Filler, a law professor at Drexel University.

The case has also highlighted the need for policy changes to address biases in the justice system. "Every time you add a layer of risk that someone will detect misconduct, I think you increase the chances that misconduct [in the justice system] will be reduced," said Filler.

The capture of Ethan Couch has once again brought attention to the need for a more equitable justice system, where all individuals are held accountable for their actions, regardless of their background or socioeconomic status.

Title: Tea Party Groups Shift Focus to Immigration Bill, Potentially Imperiling Obama's Hopes for Swift Approval

The Tea Party movement is shifting its attention from the IRS targeting scandal to the immigration bill, which could hinder President Obama's hopes for a swift approval. The Senate recently passed its version of the legislation, and the bill now rests with the House, where Republicans plan to introduce their own version. Obama has urged the House to "get this done" before the August recess, but House lawmakers are already receiving pressure from conservative groups to slow down the process.

Tea Party groups are preparing to mount demonstrations during the summer break, similar to their efforts during the 2009 August recess, which helped stall the passage of the Affordable Care Act. Conservative groups, including the Cincinnati Tea Party, have sent a letter to House Speaker John Boehner urging him to declare the Senate package "dead on arrival." They argue that the bill would make life harder for U.S. workers and give up to 11 million illegal immigrants a chance at legal status.

The Tea Party's stance on immigration is split, with some influential conservative economists arguing that the legislation would be a boon for the economy. However, Tea Party supporters warn that mass legalization would trump any security improvements and make life harder for U.S. workers.

Tea Party activists have already begun staging protests at the offices of key Republican lawmakers, including Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who helped draft the bill. Activists in South Carolina have expressed a desire to see Graham face a primary challenge, citing his failure to align with their conservative values.

House Republicans have announced that they will proceed with their own bills on immigration, which will prioritize border security. A Boehner spokesman stated that the House will not simply pass the Senate bill and will instead introduce legislation that reflects their principles on border security. The debate is likely to continue, with the Tea Party's efforts potentially imperiling Obama's hopes for swift approval.

Title: Trump's Rally Viewership Numbers Dip, Fox News Shifts Focus to Regular Programming

The viewership numbers for President Donald Trump's rallies have been steadily declining, with some events not even being aired live on major networks. According to sources, Fox News, Trump's preferred network, has stopped airing most evening events in full, opting instead to show clips and highlights from his speeches. This shift in coverage has raised concerns among White House officials and Republican campaign staff, who believe it will make it harder for the president to reach a national audience.

Fox News has traditionally been a reliable platform for Trump's campaign rallies, but the network has been hesitant to give up its prime-time real estate to the president's events. The network's decision to cut away from live coverage of Trump's rallies has been met with frustration from some, who believe it will make it harder for the president to connect with his base.

The decline in viewership numbers is attributed to the sheer number of rallies Trump has been holding, which has made it difficult for Fox News to justify dedicating prime-time airtime to the events. Additionally, the network's decision to air Trump's speeches in full has been seen as a way to avoid the repetition and potential ratings drop that comes with repeated coverage.

The loss of national coverage is also a concern for Republican candidates, who believe it will make it harder for them to reach a wider audience and gain support. A Senate Republican campaign staffer noted that the coverage of Trump's rallies often leads to new sign-ups and small-dollar donations, and that being able to be onstage with the president in front of a prime-time audience is crucial for reaching conservatives across the country.

While Trump has not publicly faulted Fox News for its recent changes to its programming, some have speculated that the network's decision to cut away from live coverage of his rallies may be a sign of a shift in the way it approaches Trump's events.

Title: American Service Members Foil Potential Train Attack in France

A dramatic incident unfolded on a train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris on August 21, as two American service members, Alek Skarlatos and Spencer Stone, thwarted what could have been a devastating attack. The incident left two people injured, including Stone, who was shot and cut with a sharp blade.

According to reports, the suspect, a 26-year-old Moroccan man, entered the train car carrying an AK-47 and a handgun. Skarlatos, an Oregon Army National Guard specialist returning from Afghanistan, and Stone, a U.S. Airman, quickly sprang into action. Skarlatos stated, "I looked over at Spencer and said, 'Let's go,' and he jumped. I followed behind him by about three seconds. Spencer got the guy first, grabbed the guy by the neck, I grabbed the handgun."

The suspect was arrested in Arras on Friday night and taken to the headquarters of the antiterrorism police outside Paris for questioning. French officials identified the man as a security risk, but he was not under surveillance and had spent little time in France. The suspect allegedly denied having terrorist aims, claiming he intended to rob the passengers.

The violent encounter was over in less than two minutes, but the arsenal described by French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve suggests otherwise. The minister stated that the suspect was armed with a Kalashnikov assault rifle, a Luger automatic pistol, nine cartridges, and a sharp blade, which he used to wound Stone.

The quick actions of the two American servicemen and the suspect's malfunctioning automatic rifle prevented what could have been a catastrophic outcome. As British businessman Chris Norman, who helped restrain the suspect, noted, "It could have been a real carnage."

Title: Trump Proposes Immigration Deal, Marking a Retreat on Three Policy Areas

The White House announced a new immigration proposal from President Trump, which marks a retreat on three areas of policy. The proposal aims to break the gridlock that has stalled immigration reform for over a decade. In each of these areas – the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, Temporary Protected Status (TPS), and a new path for asylum for children in Central America – President Trump had previously canceled the Obama administration's initiatives.

The proposal would restore each of these programs and give them permanence through legislation, which President Trump had previously been unable to achieve with Congress during his tenure. In exchange, he is seeking $5.7 billion for his plans to build a border wall, as well as changes to make it easier to deport illegal immigrant families and cut down on abuses of the asylum system.

The proposal also includes items both sides generally agree on, such as more technology to scan for drugs in vehicles at legal border crossings and a boost in the number of immigration judges to cut into the backlog of cases.

Vice President Mike Pence described the proposal as a "compromise offer" and said President Trump has been "persuaded this is the right thing to do." The proposal marks a significant shift from President Trump's previous stance on DACA, as he had previously sought to phase out the program. Instead, he is now proposing to write it into law for those already using it, giving them a guaranteed three years of protections.
