The proposal also includes restarting the Central American Minor program, which was designed to give children looking to get asylum in the U.S. a chance to apply from their home countries rather than make the dangerous trek north. This program was previously canceled by the Trump administration, drawing criticism from Democrats.

Democrats, however, have rejected the proposal, saying it is disingenuous and puts Dreamers and TPS recipients in danger. They would prefer a full pathway to citizenship for the 1.5 million people who could qualify for DACA and the hundreds of thousands under TPS. The Senate is slated to vote on the proposal next week, but House Democrats are unlikely to go along.

Title: Trump Jr.'s Speechwriting Controversy: A Matter of Context and Permission

The recent controversy surrounding Donald Trump Jr.'s speechwriting has sparked debate about plagiarism and ethics. In response to the allegations, some critics have pointed out similarities between Trump Jr.'s speech and an essay written by Frank Buckley, a speechwriter who also helped craft Trump Jr.'s speech. However, it appears that Buckley repurposed one of his previous insights with permission, making the issue less clear-cut.

The debate has drawn parallels to a similar situation involving former President Barack Obama, who was accused of plagiarism during his 2008 campaign. At the time, Obama was criticized for using unoriginal passages without attribution, with Hillary Clinton stating, "If your whole candidacy is about words, they should be your words." However, Obama's speechwriters have since pointed out that the standard of acceptability for this type of borrowing is permission, and since Obama's speechwriters did not receive permission from the original author, the issue was deemed a non-issue.

In a similar vein, Trump Jr.'s speechwriting controversy appears to be a matter of permission as well. If the standard is that permission is required for borrowing, and it is unclear whether permission was granted in this case, then Trump Jr. is not guilty of plagiarism. The debate highlights the importance of context and the need to consider the circumstances surrounding the borrowing of ideas and language.

Title: Halvorson Emerges as Front-Runner to Replace Jesse Jackson Jr. in Chicago District

Article:

Debbie Halvorson, a white former congresswoman with an "A" rating from the National Rifle Association (NRA), is the leading candidate to replace former Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. in a majority-black Chicago district plagued by gun violence. Despite being defeated by Jackson in a primary last year, Halvorson's familiarity and experience in the district make her a strong contender. With 16 other candidates vying for the Democratic nomination, Halvorson's narrow but crucial base of support in suburban and rural areas could be enough to secure her a spot.

Halvorson's opponents, all African-American, are focusing on her stance on gun control, painting her as an NRA ally who is out of touch with the district's concerns about gun violence. However, Halvorson has described herself as a conservative Democrat who voted with her party over 90% of the time in Congress, supporting measures like cap-and-trade, healthcare reform, and economic stimulus. Her opponents have not directly attacked her on her gun stance, instead focusing on promoting themselves.

The crowded primary means that Halvorson only needs to win around 20% of the vote to secure the Democratic nomination, which is tantamount to winning the seat given the district's liberal makeup. Black leaders, concerned about Halvorson's position in the polls, are planning to make gun control a central issue in the contest, aiming to portray her as an NRA-backed candidate who is too conservative for the seat.

Title: Young Conservatives Push for GOP to Embrace Same-Sex Marriage, Citing Need to Attract Younger Voters

Article:

A group of young conservatives is urging the Republican Party to reevaluate its stance on same-sex marriage, arguing that the party's current approach is driving away younger voters who share their values. The activists, who organized an event in Arlington, Virginia, believe that embracing same-sex marriage could help the GOP attract a new generation of voters who are increasingly supportive of the issue.

According to Gallup polling, a record 60 percent of Americans now support same-sex marriage, a 20-point jump since 2009. Among younger Americans, the issue is even more settled, with 70% of 18-29-year-olds supporting same-sex marriage.

Conservative activists argue that the GOP's current stance on same-sex marriage is driving away potential voters who share their values on issues like limited government, strong families, and fiscal conservatism. They point to the example of lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender (LGBT) individuals who identify as Republicans but feel unwelcome in the party.

The issue is not yet a make-or-break issue for voters, with only 26% saying it is a deciding factor in their vote. However, among those who do prioritize the issue, support for traditional marriage helps Republicans more than it hurts, with 37% of those who oppose gay marriage saying a candidate must agree with them, compared to 27% who support recognition of same-sex marriage.

While some Republican analysts doubt that the 2016 elections will see a major shift on the issue, others believe that harnessing a digital campaign and emphasizing issues like job security and growing the economy could help attract younger voters.

In swing states like Florida, where the youth population is large, the issue could play a significant role in the election. However, it is unclear whether same-sex marriage will be a deciding factor nationally.

The conservatives at the rally do not expect same-sex marriage to be the tipping point in the 2016 election, but they want to see more Republicans embrace the issue. They believe that as the nation develops over time, the issue will become more mainstream and the GOP will be on the right side of history.

**Trump Submits Written Answers to Mueller's Questions in Russia Probe**

U.S. President Donald Trump has submitted written answers to questions from Special Counsel Robert Mueller in the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election and possible collusion with the Trump campaign. Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, announced the submission on Tuesday.

According to Giuliani, Trump answered questions focused on Russia and the pre-election period, but declined to answer questions about potential obstruction of the investigation after the election. Giuliani stated that Trump did not plan to answer questions about his actions as president, such as the firing of former FBI Director James Comey.

The submission came as Trump left Washington to spend the Thanksgiving holiday in Florida. A person familiar with the matter said Trump signed the answers on Tuesday. A spokesman for Mueller declined to comment.

The investigation, which began in May 2017, is focused on determining whether the Trump campaign colluded with Russia during the 2016 election. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the election to help Trump win.

Among the topics Trump answered questions about was a June 2016 meeting between his son, Donald Trump Jr., and a group of Russians, which has been a subject of investigation. Trump has denied knowing about the meeting.

Mueller has already brought charges against some former Trump aides and Russian individuals and entities. U.S. prosecutors are also preparing to pursue a criminal case against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who has ties to the Trump campaign.

Giuliani stated that Trump provided "unprecedented cooperation" with the probe over the past year and a half, noting that more than 30 White House-related witnesses had been questioned and 1.4 million pages of material turned over. However, he also said that "much of what has been asked raised serious constitutional issues and was beyond the scope of a legitimate inquiry."

It is unclear whether Mueller would subpoena Trump to testify, which could lead to a legal and political battle.

Title: Presidential Debate to be One of the Most-Watched Political Events in American History

The upcoming presidential debate between Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump is expected to be one of the most-watched political events in American history, with viewership potentially approaching 80 million viewers, similar to the 1980 debate between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter. The debate will be a crucial opportunity for the candidates to make their case to the public and sway undecided voters.

According to a recent poll, one-third of voters consider the presidential debates to be very important in helping them decide whom to support for president. The nominees will have a large audience to make their case, and the debate will likely be filled with political and personal attacks, as well as departures from the truth.

For Hillary Clinton, the key to success lies in pulling undecided voters into her camp or keeping them from supporting Donald Trump. She will need to focus on issues that matter to today's Democratic coalition, including social justice and immigration reform. Clinton will also need to remind black and Hispanic voters of Trump's history of questioning President Barack Obama's birthplace.

Clinton's biggest challenge is her low popularity, with her being the second least popular major-party presidential nominee in modern polling history. However, Trump is even less popular, making it crucial for him to redefine himself as a presidential candidate.

Trump's biggest advantage is his unpredictability, which can be both a blessing and a curse. He will need to be disciplined and prepared to avoid distractions and focus on his policy proposals. Trump's biggest opening is Clinton's unpopularity, and he will need to weave her use of a personal email server and issues with the Clinton Foundation into his answers.

The debate will be a crucial moment for both candidates to showcase their leadership skills and policy knowledge. Trump will need to demonstrate a command of policy sufficient to run the federal government, while Clinton will need to show that she can effectively address the concerns of the Democratic coalition.

Title: House Republicans Divided Over Bill to Allow Undocumented Immigrants to Serve in the Military

The House of Representatives is currently debating a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants, known as Dreamers, to serve in the military. The proposal, sponsored by Representative Ruben Gallego, D-Ariz., has sparked a heated debate among lawmakers, with some Republicans strongly opposing it.

The bill would give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military, allowing them to become U.S. citizens. Cesar Vargas, a co-director of the Dream Action Coalition, has been advocating for this cause, citing his own personal experience as an undocumented immigrant who was brought to the United States as a child. Vargas wants to become a military lawyer and believes that serving in the military would be a way for him to give back to the country that has given him so much.

Some lawmakers, including Representative Jeff Denham, R-Calif., have supported the bill, arguing that it would be a way to give back to the country and allow young people who were brought to the United States as children to serve in the military. However, other Republicans, led by Representative Mo Brooks, R-Ala., have strongly opposed the bill, claiming it would be a "severe threat" to national security and would allow illegal aliens to compete with American citizens for military service positions.

Brooks and other Republicans have pointed to previous times the House has voted to declare the Obama administration's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program as unconstitutional. They argue that the bill would undermine the country's immigration laws and would put American citizens at a disadvantage.

Representative Gallego has defended the bill, saying that it is not about giving people a right to serve in the military, but about giving them the opportunity to serve and repay their country. He has also pointed out that the bill is not a new pathway to citizenship, but rather a way for young people who were brought to the United States as children to serve in the military and become U.S. citizens.

The bill is expected to be taken up by the full House this week and then must go to the Senate, where Arizona Senator John McCain leads the Armed Services Committee. McCain has said that there will not be a similar provision included in his committee's version of the bill.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Freezing Vehicle Fuel Economy Requirements and Unwinding California's Emissions Authority

The Trump administration has proposed freezing vehicle fuel economy requirements at the 2020 level and unwinding California's authority to limit tailpipe emissions in the state. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) jointly proposed capping fuel economy requirements at a fleet average of 37 miles per gallon starting in 2020, which is lower than the Obama administration's plan to increase the fleetwide fuel economy to roughly 47 mpg by 2025.

The proposal also seeks to revoke California's authority under the Clean Air Act to set rules more stringent than the federal ones limiting tailpipe greenhouse gas emissions and an electric-vehicle sales mandate. This move is seen as an aggressive attempt to dismantle one of the most potent efforts to combat climate change.

The proposal is part of a 60-day public comment period, which is expected to attract a strong response from California's leaders and environmentalists who view the plan as a setback to efforts to curb climate change. Automakers have expressed concerns about having to accommodate a patchwork of federal and state standards.

The proposal presents several options for modifying the Obama targets, with the most severe scenario being the proposed freeze starting in 2020. The EPA and NHTSA argue that the proposed freeze will have a "negligible" impact on air quality and boost the earth's temperature by 3/1000th of one degree Celsius by 2100. They also claim that the preferred plan for fuel economy will reduce society-wide spending by $502 billion for vehicles built between 1975 and 2029.

However, critics argue that the administration's cost estimates are flawed and that there is no evidence that efficiency regulations have depressed sales and added fatalities. California, 16 states, and the District of Columbia have already filed a lawsuit challenging the plan's scientific underpinnings.

The proposal is expected to face strong opposition from environmentalists and California's leaders, who are vowing to defend their smog-fighting authority in court. The final rule could be finalized by the end of 2018 or early next year.

Title: Trump Warns Iran Against Killing Protesters Amid Growing Demonstrations

The United States President, Donald Trump, issued a warning to the Iranian government on Sunday, urging them to stop killing protesters and allow reporters to operate freely. In a tweet, Mr. Trump stated, "To the leaders of Iran - DO NOT KILL YOUR PROTESTERS. Thousands have already been killed or imprisoned by you, and the World is watching. More importantly, the USA is watching. Turn your internet back on and let reporters roam free! Stop the killing of your great Iranian people!"

The warning comes as protests across Iran continue to grow, with demonstrators taking to the streets to express their anger and frustration over the country's handling of the recent downing of a Ukrainian airliner, which killed all 176 people on board. The incident occurred just after Iran launched ballistic missiles at U.S. military bases in Iraq, bringing the two nations to the brink of war.

The Iranian government initially denied responsibility for the plane crash, but later admitted to the mistake. The admission has sparked widespread outrage and anger among the Iranian people, with many taking to the streets to demand accountability and justice.

Demonstrators have been chanting slogans such as "They are lying that our enemy is America, our enemy is right here," referring to the Iranian government, and "Death to the dictator," in reference to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

In response to the growing protests, the Trump administration has reiterated its willingness to negotiate with the Iranian government to end its nuclear weapons program. However, U.S. officials have also sought to capitalize on the situation by driving a wedge between the government and the Iranian people.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" program that the Iranian people want the same things as people around the world: prosperity and the ability to live their lives and raise their children. He believes that the Iranian government is corrupt and that the people are finally standing up to hold them accountable.

Title: Trump Administration Introduces New Rules to Disclose Healthcare Prices, Faces Industry Pushback

The Trump administration has introduced new rules aimed at promoting transparency in the healthcare industry by requiring insurers and hospitals to disclose upfront prices for common tests and procedures. The move is intended to encourage competition and reduce costs for patients. However, the healthcare industry is pushing back against the changes, citing concerns that the government is overstepping its authority and that the plan could backfire by driving up prices.

Under the new rules, hospitals will be required to disclose the prices they would accept for cash payments, as well as the prices for 300 common services that can be scheduled in advance, such as knee replacements and MRI scans. Insurers will also be required to create individualized estimates of out-of-pocket costs for patients, taking into account deductibles and copayments.

The rules are part of an executive order signed by President Donald Trump this summer, aimed at promoting transparency and competition in the healthcare industry. The administration claims that the changes will allow patients to make informed decisions about their healthcare and find quality services at the lowest cost.

However, insurance companies and hospitals are pushing back against the changes, arguing that the government is overstepping its authority and that the plan could backfire by driving up prices. They claim that the government is forcing them to publicly disclose rates they negotiate as part of private contracts, which is beyond the purview of authorities.

The rules will not take effect until 2021 for hospitals, and the timing is unclear for insurers. The changes do not directly affect doctors. If the industry challenges the rules in court, it could be a long time before consumers see any major changes.

The administration believes that transparency will lead to lower prices, but insurance companies and hospitals argue that it could have the opposite effect. The debate highlights the complexities of the healthcare system and the challenges of making it more transparent and patient-friendly.

Title: Grand Jury Decision Not to Indict NYPD Officer in Eric Garner's Death Sparks Outrage and Calls for Reform

The grand jury decision not to indict a New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner has sparked widespread outrage and calls for reform. The incident has highlighted the concerns of many minority communities that law enforcement is not working with them and dealing with them in a fair way.

U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has announced that the Department of Justice will investigate the Garner and Michael Brown cases. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand stated that the death of Eric Garner is a tragedy that demands accountability, while New York Governor Andrew Cuomo emphasized the importance of respecting the legal process and rule of law, while also acknowledging the need for additional investigations and reviews.

The death of Eric Garner has put a spotlight on police-community relations and civil rights, two of the most critical issues facing the nation today. The incident has also sparked a national march in Washington, D.C. on December 13 to halt police brutality and demand justice for the Garner family.

The grand jury decision has been met with criticism from many, including Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, who stated that it should shock the conscience of every single American who cares about justice and fair play. The decision not to bring charges against the officer has been seen as a failure of the justice system, with many calling for a national march to deal with a national crisis.

The officer involved in the incident, Daniel Pantaleo, has expressed remorse and condolences to the Garner family, but his apology has been met with skepticism by Garner's wife, who feels that the officer's actions were not remorseful enough. The Garner family has expressed frustration and disappointment with the grand jury decision, with Garner's mother stating that the justice system has failed them and many others.

The incident has also sparked a response from the NYPD, with Police Commissioner Bill Bratton assigning extra police to Staten Island following the decision. Staten Island Borough President James Oddo has called for calm and respect for the grand jury's conclusion, while also acknowledging the right to peacefully protest and advocate for change.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has also issued a statement, expressing their support for the officer involved and calling for calm and respect for the legal process.

Title: Las Vegas Shooting: Death Toll Rises to 50 as Police Name Suspect

The death toll from the mass shooting at the Route 91 Harvest music festival in Las Vegas has risen to 50, with 406 people taken to hospital. The attack occurred on Sunday night when a gunman opened fire from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel, targeting a crowd of concertgoers.

Eyewitnesses described the scene as chaotic, with people running for their lives and trying to find shelter. Many reported hearing what sounded like machine-gun fire, with bullets hitting the pavement and causing panic. Some described seeing people trampled and others hiding behind cars and buildings.

"I started kicking down fences to take shelter behind the buildings," said William Walker, a concertgoer from Ontario, California. "It sounded like something was wrong with the speakers, then once he stopped everyone took it more seriously."

Desiree Price, from San Diego, recalled seeing two girls hiding behind a car with her, and they all ran together. "We huddled together. That's why I have their blood on me. One girl was shot in her leg, the other had it in her shoulder. It didn't stop, so we all ran – we kept going."

Many witnesses reported hearing the gunshots coming from different directions, and getting closer each time the shooter reloaded. "We were under a big spotlight and someone said, 'Turn off the light,'" said William Walker. "They shut it off and you could see and hear bullets hitting the ground. People piled up behind cop cars, and ex-military guys were saying, 'Give me a gun, I'm going to get these fuckers.'"

The streets between the concert grounds and the nearest medical center were a non-stop convoy of ambulances and police. Many survivors were left shaken and trying to find their way back to their hotels, which were under lockdown.

"I'm still shaking," said Krista Metz, a survivor. "Every time I start thinking about it, I start shaking again."

The investigation is ongoing, with police still searching for the suspect.

Title: Bipartisan Support for Licensing Reform Unites Republicans and Democrats

Article:

A rare area of agreement has emerged between Republicans and Democrats: licensing reform. Democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang, who is running on a platform centered around a Universal Basic Income, has released a plan to ease licensing requirements, aiming to "get America moving again." Yang's proposal seeks to increase state-by-state recognition of occupational licenses, a practice currently adopted by only three states: Arizona, Montana, and Pennsylvania.

Licensing requirements often trap workers in the states where they began their careers, as licenses are not recognized out-of-state. This can be a significant obstacle for workers who want to relocate to a new state and stay in the same profession. According to a 2017 paper by labor economists Janna Johnson and Morris Kleiner, workers in licensed professions are 36% less likely to move across state lines compared to those in non-licensed professions. The same study found that workers in licensed professions lose out on between $178 million and $711 million by not being able to move to a different state.

Yang's plan also proposes a tax credit, capped at $1,000, for moving expenses. This is not a new concept, as the tax code previously provided for an above-the-line deduction for similar claims, although it was eliminated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017. Garrett Watson, Special Projects Manager at the Tax Foundation, believes that Yang's proposed tax credit for moving expenses could help energize the economy, but notes that it would need to be part of a broader set of reforms.

Watson emphasizes that reducing licensing burdens, zoning laws that drive up the cost of housing, and other non-tax issues would also need to be addressed to make a significant impact. Despite the challenges, Yang's proposal has sparked a rare moment of bipartisanship, highlighting the need for a more comprehensive approach to addressing the issue of licensing reform.

Title: Trump's Town Hall Performance: A Focus on Style Over Substance

Article:

Donald Trump's town hall appearance on Sunday evening, moderated by Greta Van Susteren, left many viewers with a lasting impression: Trump's ability to sell himself as a charismatic leader, but lacking in substance. The event, which lasted for an hour, saw Trump reiterate his stance on various issues, including his plans to repeal ObamaCare, renegotiate trade deals, and create jobs.

While Trump's performance was engaging and entertaining, it lacked concrete details and specifics on how he plans to achieve his goals. He touched on various topics, such as his plan to pay off the national debt, but failed to provide any concrete solutions or details on how he would accomplish this.

Trump's answers were often vague and focused on his ability to "make deals" and "get things done." He emphasized his business experience and his ability to "create jobs," but did not provide any specific examples or details on how he would achieve this.

The event was more focused on Trump's personality and charisma than on providing substance and answers to the questions posed by the audience. Trump's opponents, such as Ted Cruz, are running a more grassroots campaign, focusing on specific policies and issues, whereas Trump is relying on his marketing skills to win over voters.

In conclusion, Trump's town hall appearance was an hour of performance, lacking in substance and concrete answers. While he may be able to "sell" himself as a charismatic leader, his lack of specifics and details may ultimately hurt his chances of winning the Republican nomination.

Title: Trump's Unorthodox Approach to Foreign Policy Surprises Critics and Detractors

President Donald Trump, elected primarily on domestic issues, has taken a significant imprint on foreign affairs in his first 16 months in office. Trump's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal and the relocation of the U.S. Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem are just the latest developments in his unorthodox approach to foreign policy.

While Trump's major achievements at home have been limited to the passage of a large tax cut in December and the confirmation of Neil Gorsuch as a Supreme Court justice over a year ago, his international actions have been more extensive. Trump has set out to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula with a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, pulled out of the Paris climate agreement and the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and made gains against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Trump also gave the Pentagon authority to ramp up troop levels in Afghanistan in an August speech.

Republican strategist Alex Conant acknowledged that Trump has exceeded the expectations of his critics in foreign policy, stating that Trump is "very unorthodox, but that's not to say he hasn't seen some early successes." Trump's approach seems to be driven less by any putative Trump doctrine and more by instinct. Few experts are sure of Trump's exact position on the ideological spectrum when it comes to foreign policy, given his zigzags on issues like North Korea and Syria.

Trump loyalists see this trait as an asset, showing a useful flexibility. Detractors, however, insist that the president's approach breeds new instabilities. Joel Rubin, who served as a deputy assistant secretary of State during the Obama administration, said that Trump "really lacks a clear, coherent approach around which adversaries, allies, and the agencies—the three As—can orient themselves."

The president's unorthodox approach has been met with skepticism from some experts, who argue that it lacks a clear direction and breeds uncertainty. However, Trump's supporters argue that his approach has yielded some successes, such as the planned summit with Kim Jong Un, which is seen as a historic event.

Trump's approach has also been praised by some for its unpredictability, which can be seen as a strength in a rapidly changing world. James Jay Carafano of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, argued that the idea of Trump as a chaotic figure was exaggerated, stating that the president is "not a scattershot president. This is not a presidency lurching from fire to fire. This is a president going out very deliberately and pursuing policy."

While Trump's foreign policy record may not have significant electoral benefits, it can be seen as a way to tout his accomplishments and demonstrate his commitment to keeping his promises. As the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem opened on Monday, Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner stated, "When President Trump makes a promise, he keeps it." The idea that Trump keeps his promises is repeated often by his allies, even as it is fiercely contested by critics.

Title: The Polarization of Washington: A Different Path

The article explores the idea that the polarization and gridlock in Washington can be attributed to a single event: Al Franken's narrow victory in the 2008 Minnesota Senate race. The author argues that if Franken had lost, the political landscape would have been different, and the Obama administration would have had to negotiate with Republicans to pass healthcare reform.

The article suggests that without a Democratic supermajority, Obama would have been forced to negotiate with Republicans, leading to a more incremental approach to healthcare reform. This would have tempered the Republican opposition and potentially led to a different outcome in the 2010 midterm elections.

The author notes that Obama's decision to push for healthcare reform despite the divided government was a political gamble that paid off, but it also contributed to the polarization of the country. The article concludes that Obama's actions, while understandable, did not take into account the growing energy on the right and the rise of the tea party movement.

The article also touches on the idea that Obama's presidency was not destined to face an intransigent Republican opposition, citing his high approval ratings and the fact that he won 40% of non-college-educated whites in the 2008 election. The author suggests that Democrats had the political tools to pass a more moderate agenda, but instead chose to focus on healthcare reform.

Overall, the article presents a thought-provoking analysis of the polarization of Washington and the role that Al Franken's election played in shaping the political landscape.

Title: Sterling's First Amendment Rights Not Violated, but Recording and Leaking of Conversation Raises Concerns

The controversy surrounding Donald Sterling's racist remarks has sparked debate about the intersection of free speech and privacy. While Sterling's First Amendment rights were not violated, his ideas failed to sell in the marketplace of ideas. The NBA, as a private club, can discipline Sterling for his actions, but the real concern lies in the recording and leaking of the conversation.

According to Marc J. Randazza, a lawyer and free speech advocate, the recording of Sterling's conversation may have been illegal, and the leaking of it was morally wrong. He argues that the First Amendment protects individuals from government punishment for their speech, but not from criticism or discipline from private entities like the NBA.

Randazza also highlights the importance of privacy and the potential consequences of a world where intimate conversations can be recorded and leaked. He notes that people often share their thoughts and ideas with close friends and family, and that this can be a way to test and refine one's opinions before sharing them publicly. However, the ease with which recordings can be made and disseminated has raised concerns about the erosion of privacy and the potential for abuse.

The article raises important questions about the balance between free speech and privacy, and whether individuals have a right to expect privacy in their personal conversations. While Sterling's views were widely condemned, the real issue may be the lack of privacy and the potential consequences of a world where intimate conversations can be recorded and leaked.

Title: New Congress Takes Office, Republicans Eager to Get to Work

The 115th Congress has officially begun, with Republicans in full control of both chambers and the White House for the first time in almost a decade. The new Congress was sworn in by re-elected Speaker of the House Paul Ryan in a Congressional ceremony. Republicans have been waiting for this moment for a long time, and they are eager to get to work.

According to Republican lawmaker Cory Gardner from Colorado, the American people signaled a desire for a new direction on November 3rd. The top priority for Republicans is to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. Gardner vowed to "repair the damage" of the law, which he believes has led to soaring premiums, failing insurance markets, and dwindling choices.

House lawmakers are also planning to introduce bills to roll back thousands of federal regulations imposed by the Obama administration, covering areas such as the environment, drilling, and businesses. Additionally, the confirmation of Donald Trump's cabinet nominees is expected to be a major focus, with Democrats vowing to make it difficult.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich expressed concerns that the incoming administration might "lose their nerve" in taking on the Democrats. He warned that the administration needs to stake out positions that will not be liked by the Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Donna Brazile and the Left.

Congressional Republicans have already backed down from a controversial plan to revise congressional oversight, which was met with criticism from both sides. The plan aimed to strengthen the independent Congressional Ethics Office, but top Republicans worried it could look bad given Trump's promise to "drain the swamp" in Washington.

Meanwhile, President-elect Trump will face a slew of foreign policy challenges when he takes office on January 20. These include dealing with Russia, particularly in the wake of hacking during the presidential election, as well as the battle to defeat ISIS, the ongoing chaos in Syria, and the recent announcement by North Korea that it is close to testing an intercontinental ballistic missile that can reach the US. Trump has tweeted about North Korea's missile ambitions, stating that "it won't happen" on his watch.

Title: Justice Department Declines to Charge Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe

The Justice Department announced on Friday that it will not pursue charges against former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, who was accused of lying to investigators about a leak to the media. The decision comes after an investigation by the department's inspector general found that McCabe "lacked candor" when he told investigators that he did not know who authorized an aide to talk to the Wall Street Journal about the FBI investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

In a letter to McCabe's attorneys, the department stated that "based on the totality of the circumstances and all of the information known to the government at this time, we consider the matter closed." McCabe's lawyers welcomed the decision, saying that "at long last, justice has been done in this matter" and that McCabe and his family can now move on with their lives without the cloud of an investigation hanging over them.

The allegations against McCabe stemmed from a report by the Justice Department's Office of Inspector General, which found that McCabe had been less than truthful in his responses to investigators about his knowledge of the leak. McCabe had been fired in March 2018, hours before he was set to retire, after investigators concluded that he lacked candor about an episode involving the release of information to a reporter.

McCabe has consistently maintained that he did nothing wrong and has called himself the victim of political vengeance. His lawyers have also argued that his firing was a politically motivated act of retribution by then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions and President Trump.

The decision not to pursue charges against McCabe comes a day after Attorney General William Barr publicly criticized Trump's tweets, saying they "make it impossible for me to do my job." McCabe has also sued the Justice Department, alleging that his firing was unlawful and politically motivated.

The controversy surrounding McCabe's firing has been a contentious issue, with some Republicans accusing him of political bias within the FBI and others defending him as a dedicated public servant. The Justice Department's decision to decline charges against McCabe brings an end to the investigation, but the controversy is likely to continue to be a topic of debate.

Title: Virginia Democrats Face Political Quandary Amidst Scandal and Upcoming Elections

Virginia Democrats are grappling with a delicate situation as the state's political landscape is set to unfold amidst the ongoing scandal surrounding Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax's alleged misconduct. The controversy has sparked a heated debate among party members, with some calling for Fairfax's resignation and others advocating for him to remain in office.

The situation is particularly sensitive given the upcoming 2020 presidential primary, which will feature a record number of black and female candidates. The optics of having Fairfax, the only one of the three accused of a crime, remain in office while Governor Ralph Northam and Attorney General Mark Herring face criticism for their past behavior, would be difficult, according to State Senator J. Chapman Petersen.

The Democratic Party's success in the 2017 elections and the 2018 midterm elections, which saw them win 40 seats in the House, was largely due to the support of women and African-Americans. With Republicans barely holding onto their legislative majority in the Virginia Capitol, Democrats are counting on these same groups to propel them to victory in the upcoming election.

Some Democrats believe that the party must begin the process of rebuilding by turning to their most loyal constituency: black women. The appointment of State Senator Jennifer McClellan, a longtime Richmond legislator and close friend of Senator Tim Kaine, has been suggested as a potential solution if Fairfax were to resign or be impeached. However, it is unclear whether Governor Northam has the authority to appoint a successor under Virginia's Constitution and state law.

McClellan, who is black, has statewide ambitions and has been praised by former state Democratic chairman and legislator C. Richard Cranwell as an "exceptionally good" lieutenant governor candidate. The situation highlights the complex and delicate nature of the political landscape in Virginia, as Democrats navigate the challenges of the upcoming election and the ongoing scandal surrounding Fairfax's alleged misconduct.

Title: House Votes to Leave States Alone on Medical Marijuana

The House of Representatives has voted to prohibit the federal government from interfering with medical marijuana laws passed by 32 states and the District of Columbia. The vote, led by Republican Representative Dana Rohrabacher, garnered 218 votes, with 49 Republicans among them. The bill aims to allow states to regulate their own medical marijuana policies without federal interference.

Representative Rohrabacher, who worked for former President Ronald Reagan, acknowledged that times have changed and that strict federal policies are doing more harm than good. He stated that it is immoral for the government to interfere with a doctor's decision to prescribe medical marijuana to alleviate suffering.

Not all Republicans agreed with Rohrabacher's stance. Representative Frank Wolf, who chairs the House committee that wrote the appropriations bill, questioned the "medical" nature of medical marijuana, citing opposition from various medical organizations. Representatives John Fleming and Andy Harris also expressed concerns about the potential harm of marijuana use, particularly in young people.

On the other hand, Representative Paul Broun argued that the components in marijuana are useful for some conditions and less dangerous than some prescribed narcotics. The vote surprised even those who had been lobbying for it, with the proposal receiving more votes than ever before.

While the proposal has only cleared the House, Representative Rohrabacher and his Democratic co-sponsors acknowledged that they do not have Senate supporters lined up yet to move the language in that chamber. Representative Jared Polis, whose state of Colorado allows non-medical marijuana, emphasized that the will of the House is important but noted that Congress is catching up with where the country already is on this issue.

Title: Polls Suggest Trump's Approval Rating Remains Low, Democrats Weigh Options

The latest polling data has left some on the left encouraged, while others remain critical of President Joe Biden's approach. The polls suggest that Trump's approval rating remains low, particularly in key swing states like Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa, which he won in 2016. While it is true that state-level polls underestimated Trump's support in 2016, the current polling data does not look good for the president.

The head-to-head polling does not provide a clear picture of events 18 months in the future, but it does indicate that Trump's approval rating is not improving. The public appears to be largely dissatisfied with his performance, and the strongest pattern suggests that better-known Democrats tend to perform better than lesser-known candidates.

Some argue that Biden's claim that Republicans in Congress will negotiate with a Democratic president in good faith is unrealistic. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that he will continue to block any legislation from a Democratic president and has promised to pack the Supreme Court if a vacancy arises during an election year.

Others believe that Biden's approach is an attempt to woo prized Obama-to-Trump voters and upscale white suburbanites who are appalled by Trump's behavior. However, this strategy may also appeal to the donor class of the Democratic Party, who may be putting their faith in Biden's promise of bipartisanship.

Regarding Pete Buttigieg's speech, some argue that he is an heir to Obama's cautious and intellectual worldview, but with a more liberal internationalist approach. Buttigieg is motivated by values and fears that threats to liberty abroad will ultimately threaten liberty at home. Others contend that Buttigieg wants to set a generous narrative of national identity against Trump's cramped and cruel vision, but has yet to find the words, music, and policies to make his appeal convincing.

Overall, the polling data suggests that Trump's approval rating remains low, and Democrats are weighing their options for the 2020 election.

Title: Pollsters Grapple with Same Issues as 2016, Raising Questions About Election Forecasts

Article: Polls are a staple of election coverage, and this year is no exception. However, the 2020 presidential election is shaping up to be an unusual year, with the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, economic uncertainty, and social unrest. Despite this, several recent headlines have caught attention, suggesting that the Trump campaign may be gaining momentum.

According to Politico, over 50 Republican officials from around the country believe that President Donald Trump's chances of winning are looking up, citing a rebounding economy and a fading pandemic. This optimism is echoed by veteran GOP pollster Neil Newhouse, who estimates that there may be a "shy Trump supporter" who is unwilling to admit their support for the president on the phone. This phenomenon, also known as the "shy voter," may have contributed to the flawed polling of 2016, where national polls showed Hillary Clinton winning the popular vote by 3 percentage points, but Trump ultimately won the Electoral College.

The Trump campaign has picked up on the "shy voter" theme, leading to another grabby headline: "Trump has a point about the polls." However, experts warn that pollsters are still grappling with the same issues that plagued them in 2016, including inadequate consideration of non-college-educated white voters. Courtney Kennedy, director of research at the Pew Research Center, notes that some fundamental structural challenges remain in place, making it crucial for both campaigns and voters to approach polls with caution.

In other words, when it comes to polls, caveat emptor - buyer beware. The warning is clear: if pollsters don't fix their problems, both campaigns and voters must behave as if the polling might be off.

Title: Romney Shifts Strategy to Focus on Broader Issues, Emphasizing Policy Prescriptions

Mitt Romney, sensing an opening in the Middle East and criticism from conservatives for lacking policy details, is revamping his campaign strategy to make the election a referendum on "status quo versus change," according to his chief strategist, Stuart Stevens. The shift includes a greater emphasis on Romney's policy prescriptions, a departure from his initial focus on the economy.

Romney's new strategy aims to highlight his plans for various issues, including foreign policy, the threat from China, debt, and the tone in Washington. The big question will be: "Can we do better on every front?" Romney's new ads, "The Romney Plan" and "Failing American Families," focus on his plans to help the middle class, crack down on China, and open up new markets.

The ads are a concession to internal critics who argued that negative ads were necessary to move the campaign's numbers. Romney will also emphasize policy solutions in his speech to the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce in Los Angeles, highlighting his plan to improve legal immigration and fix the country's immigration system.

Stevens believes Romney is doing better than many pundits recognize, and the Middle East unrest and economic unease will help the Republican regain momentum and quiet concerns among GOP insiders.

Title: Bolton Deputy Kupperman Refuses to Testify in Trump Impeachment Inquiry, Seeks Court Ruling

The impeachment inquiry into President Trump's actions has hit a roadblock, as Charles Kupperman, a former deputy to John Bolton, failed to appear for a scheduled deposition on Monday. Kupperman, who served as a top aide to Bolton, has filed a lawsuit, citing conflicting orders from the White House and the House of Representatives. He is seeking a court ruling on whether he should comply with the House subpoena or the White House's request to stay away.

The House Intelligence Committee, led by Rep. Adam Schiff, has rejected Kupperman's lawsuit, calling it a stall tactic. Schiff stated that the committee will not wait for the court to resolve the issue and will move forward with their impeachment inquiry. Other lawmakers, including Reps. Jim Jordan and Mark Meadows, have left open the possibility that Kupperman may appear at some point, but did not provide a timeline for when that might happen.

Kupperman's lawyer, Charles Cooper, said his client is seeking a court ruling on which constitutional obligation to follow, citing the need to avoid a "momentous Constitutional dispute." The lawyer denied any coordination with the White House, stating that the lawsuit was not discussed or coordinated with anyone from the White House.

Legal experts, including Nicholas Rostow, a former legal adviser to the National Security Council, believe that the congressional subpoena may take precedence over the White House's claim, but noted that the court may take a different view.

Those who know Kupperman describe him as a straight shooter who follows procedures and is not swayed by politics or ideology. Former Trump administration officials and experts on Kupperman's work suggest that he is known for his conservative views, but also for his commitment to upholding the facts and doing what he believes is right.

The controversy surrounding Kupperman's refusal to testify has sparked debate about the role of the National Security Council and the limits of executive privilege. The House impeachment inquiry will continue, with or without Kupperman's cooperation.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Rejects Republican Efforts to Delay Obamacare Implementation

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has refused to budge on his stance against defunding or delaying the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), according to Republican Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. Cruz, who has been leading the charge to defund the healthcare law, made his argument on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday.

Cruz stated that Reid's position is "I'm not willing to compromise. I'm not willing to even talk." He believes that Reid is unwilling to negotiate and is instead pushing for the full implementation of Obamacare, which would result in a government shutdown. Cruz has proposed a compromise bill that would delay the implementation of the healthcare law for a year.

Cruz emphasized that he is currently fighting to defund Obamacare, but believes that delaying its implementation is a more realistic goal. He believes that the House's recent vote to delay the law's implementation is a step in the right direction.

Host David Gregory questioned Cruz's efforts, stating that he has failed to move anyone in the Senate towards his position and that the public is not protesting in the streets against the Affordable Care Act. Cruz responded by saying that the only people who are not listening to his argument are the career politicians in Washington, and that Reid is using brute political force to push his agenda.

Some of Cruz's fellow Republicans have criticized his efforts, stating that shutting down the government would harm the party. However, Cruz believes that he is following in the footsteps of former Senator Phil Gramm, who opposed the Clinton healthcare initiative in 1993 and successfully persuaded his fellow Republicans to reconsider their stance.

The debate over Obamacare's implementation continues, with no clear resolution in sight.

Title: Democrats Show Flexibility on Revenue Target in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

In a shift from their initial stance, House Democrats are showing signs of flexibility on the revenue target in the fiscal cliff negotiations. While they remain committed to raising tax rates on top-wage earners and protecting entitlement programs, they are open to negotiating a middle ground on the amount of revenue generated.

Incoming House Democratic Caucus Chairman Xavier Becerra stated that as long as a balanced approach is achieved, the party is willing to consider a revenue target other than the $1.6 trillion initially proposed by President Barack Obama. This flexibility is a departure from the party's hardline stance on tax rates and entitlements.

Several Democratic lawmakers have expressed willingness to consider a revenue target between $1.2 trillion and $1.4 trillion, which is lower than the administration's initial request but higher than the $800 billion offered by Republicans. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas) said she could accept a deal in the $1.2 trillion range, while Representative Bill Pascrell (D-New Jersey) believes the president would not go lower than $1.2 trillion.

Other Democrats, such as Senator Max Baucus (D-Mont.) and Representative Linda Sanchez (D-California), have also expressed optimism about finding middle ground. Sanchez noted that there is plenty of room to negotiate between the $1.6 trillion and $800 billion targets.

The flexibility shown by House Democrats could be crucial in the ongoing negotiations, as they will likely be called upon to move a year-end budget package across the finish line to offset potential GOP defections. While the party remains committed to its core goals, it appears willing to compromise on the revenue target to achieve a balanced approach.

Title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls Distance Themselves from Obama's Policies

The 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls are distancing themselves from the policies of former President Barack Obama, despite his enduring popularity among Democratic voters. Many voters are searching for an Obama-esque standard-bearer to run against President Trump, but the candidates are criticizing Obama's record on immigration, healthcare, and trade.

During the Democratic presidential debate, former Vice President Joe Biden defended Obama's record, saying he is proud of his time serving with him and does not think he has anything to apologize for. However, he did distance himself from Obama's immigration policy, stating that the number of deportations was a poor yardstick for the administration's accomplishments.

Other candidates, such as Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker, have been more critical of Obama's record. Harris described the Affordable Care Act as an "unacceptable status quo," while Booker trashed Obama's immigration legacy.

New York Mayor Bill de Blasio faulted the Obama Justice Department's handling of the 2014 killing of Eric Garner, a black man who died in a chokehold by city police during his arrest for selling cigarettes on the street.

Despite the criticism, Obama's popularity among Democrats remains high, with some Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez stating that he misses Obama. The moment could have given pause to the 10 candidates about to take the stage and sow doubts about Obama's legacy.

Criticizing Obama's time in the White House is a dangerous undertaking for any of the 2020 hopefuls, as it risks alienating the party's voters who romanticize those not-so-long-ago days. It is particularly treacherous for Biden, who is running as Obama's political heir with the promise of restoring the normalcy of the Obama era.

Obama voters were irked by the attacks on the former president's policies at the debates, with some expressing disappointment and frustration. However, some Democratic strategists believe it is smart for Biden to keep Obama close, as the good in the eyes of primary voters far outweighs the bad.

The Democratic Party has moved dramatically to the left since Obama was in office, with some of the strongest challengers to Biden being far-left champions like Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. Another powerful contender, Senator Kamala Harris, is more moderate but also embracing parts of the far-left agenda, including a variation of Medicare for All.

In conclusion, the 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls are distancing themselves from Obama's policies, despite his enduring popularity among Democratic voters. While some candidates are criticizing Obama's record, others are defending it, highlighting the complex and nuanced views within the party.

Title: Colin Kaepernick's Anthem Protest Sparks Controversy and Debate

Article:

Colin Kaepernick, the San Francisco 49er quarterback, has been at the center of a heated controversy after he refused to stand for the national anthem before a recent game. The athlete has been using his platform to protest the treatment of black people and people of color in America, stating that he will not stand for the flag and anthem until he feels that the country represents what it is supposed to represent.

Kaepernick's decision has sparked a strong reaction from fans, with some supporting his right to protest and others criticizing his actions. The athlete has been accused of disrespecting the flag and the anthem, while others see his actions as a necessary step towards bringing about change.

The debate surrounding Kaepernick's protest highlights the complex and sensitive issue of racial inequality in America. While some argue that the national anthem is a symbol of American values and patriotism, others see it as a symbol of oppression and inequality.

Kaepernick's decision to sit during the anthem is not the first time an athlete has used their platform to protest social injustice. Dizzy Dean, a Hall of Fame pitcher, once said, "It ain't braggin' if you can do it." Similarly, Muhammad Ali, a legendary boxer, used his platform to speak out against racial inequality and social injustice.

The national anthem, originally an English drinking song, has a complex history. It was written by Francis Scott Key in 1814, and its lyrics have been the subject of much debate and controversy over the years. Some argue that the anthem is a symbol of American values and patriotism, while others see it as a symbol of oppression and inequality.

Regardless of one's stance on the issue, it is clear that Colin Kaepernick's decision to sit during the national anthem has sparked a much-needed conversation about racial inequality and social justice.

Title: First Lady Michelle Obama Urges Supporters to Donate to Democrats in Midterm Elections

First Lady Michelle Obama has joined the White House fundraising efforts, urging supporters in Chicago to contribute the maximum amount to help Democrats in the upcoming midterm elections. Her appeal came as her husband, President Barack Obama, concluded a three-day fundraising trip on the West Coast, generating millions of dollars for Democratic committees.

During her speech, Mrs. Obama emphasized the importance of financial support, stating, "We need you to write the biggest, fattest check that you can possibly write. Writing those checks is the single-most impactful thing that you can do right now." The President and First Lady, along with Vice President Joe Biden, have increased their fundraising schedule in recent weeks as the November congressional contests approach.

The Democrats' chances of taking control of the House appear slim, and Republicans are seeking to gain the six Senate seats needed to take over the chamber. Despite President Obama's low approval ratings, he remains a draw at high-dollar fundraisers, which he has attended in New York, Texas, Colorado, Washington state, and California in the past month.

The President's recent fundraising trip included stops in Seattle, San Francisco, and Los Angeles, including a star-studded event at the home of "Scandal" and "Grey's Anatomy" creator Shonda Rhimes. He has also appeared at events for two Democratic super PACs, despite his past opposition to outside groups with unlimited fundraising potential. The events do not have official price tags, and organizers say they are not really fundraisers, but attendees are generally understood to be high-dollar donors who write big checks before leaving.

In her remarks, Mrs. Obama acknowledged that "there's too much money in politics," but emphasized that Democrats cannot afford to fall behind Republicans in that key area. She also expressed her continued faith in her husband's ability to bring about positive change, stating, "When folks ask me whether I still believe everything we said about hope and change back in 2008, I tell them that I believe it more strongly than ever before. While we still have plenty of work to do, we have truly made so much of that change we've been talking about."

Title: Congressional Divisions Emerge Over NSA Phone Data Collection

The US Congress is deeply divided over the National Security Agency's (NSA) collection of phone data, with some lawmakers pushing to end the program and others defending it as a necessary tool to combat terrorism. Representative Justin Amash, a Michigan Republican, led the charge against the program, citing concerns over the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against unreasonable search and seizure. He found an unlikely ally in Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican and one of the principal authors of the Patriot Act.

Sensenbrenner stated that his original intention was not to create a program that allows the government to demand the phone records of every American. "The time has come to stop it," he said.

On the other side of the debate, Representative Mike Rogers, a Michigan Republican, defended the program, saying it is an important tool for protecting against terrorist attacks. "This is not a game, this is real. It will have real consequences," he said.

The debate has also drawn in high-ranking officials from the defense and intelligence establishment. The director of the National Security Agency, Gen. Keith Alexander, provided classified briefings to lawmakers, while the White House issued a statement urging lawmakers not to approve the measure.

The divisions in Congress reflect the ambivalence in the nation, with a CBS News poll showing that 67% of Americans believe the government's collection of phone records is a violation of privacy, while 52% believe it is a necessary tool to help find terrorists.

Title: Clinton's Decision to Fundraise for Super PAC Raises Questions Among Progressives

The decision by Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential frontrunner, to personally raise money for a super PAC supporting her campaign has sparked criticism from progressive activists who see it as a contradiction to her populist rhetoric. Clinton's campaign has explained the decision as a matter of political necessity, citing the need to compete with Republican candidates who are also using super PACs.

Clinton's move has highlighted the contrast between her and her only declared rival, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, who has aggressively opposed super PAC donations. Sanders has stated that Clinton's decision to personally court super PAC donors is "unfortunate" and that the system needs to be changed.

Progressive activists and supporters of Senator Elizabeth Warren have expressed concerns that Clinton's decision is a sign of her being out of touch with middle-class voters. They argue that her close ties to Wall Street and her decision to personally fundraise for a super PAC run counter to her populist rhetoric.

The decision also underscores the Democratic Party's evolving relationship with super PACs. While Democrats initially opposed Citizens United, the Supreme Court decision that paved the way for super PACs, they have since become more accepting of the system. Clinton's campaign has emphasized that they will strictly follow the law as they solicit funds for Priorities USA, a super PAC backing her candidacy.

The 2016 money race is well underway, with declared Republican candidates and expected candidates showing no signs of distancing themselves from super PAC money. The stiff competition against Republican money is a reality that some progressive leaders say they cannot ignore.

Title: Mueller's Office Disputes BuzzFeed Report Alleging Trump Directed Cohen to Lie to Congress

Article:

In a rare public statement, special counsel Robert Mueller's office disputed a recent report from BuzzFeed News that alleged President Donald Trump directed his former attorney, Michael Cohen, to lie in his testimony before Congress. The report claimed that Trump instructed Cohen to conceal the Trump Organization's pursuit of a luxury residential high-rise in Moscow during his presidential campaign.

Mueller's office stated that BuzzFeed's description of specific statements, documents, and testimony obtained by their office regarding Cohen's Congressional testimony are not accurate. The statement did not provide specifics or a sweeping denial of the story's overall theme, leaving many questions unanswered.

BuzzFeed responded by saying they remain confident in the accuracy of their report and are continuing to investigate what Mueller's office is disputing. The news organization's editor-in-chief, Ben Smith, urged Mueller's office to clarify what specifically is inaccurate in the story.

The dispute has sparked intense reactions from both sides. Trump called the news a "sad day for journalism" but a "great day" for the country, while his supporters praised the Mueller team for disputing the report. Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, praised Mueller's office for correcting the "false story" and attacked the press, calling for an investigation into who leaked information to BuzzFeed.

The controversy surrounding the report has revived discussions about the possibility of impeaching Trump and emboldened House Democrats who vowed to investigate the allegations. The report also reignited questions about the Trump Organization's dealings with Russia and the potential involvement of the Russian government in the 2016 election.

Title: US Politicians Demand Interpreter Testify on Trump-Putin Summit Talks

Article:

US opposition politicians are calling for Donald Trump's interpreter, Marina Gross, to testify before Congress about his summit talks with Vladimir Putin. The lead Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Robert Menendez, has requested that Gross be subpoenaed to appear before the committee. The controversy surrounding the summit has sparked debate over the role of interpreters in diplomatic meetings and the potential implications for national security.

Gross, a US State Department employee with years of experience translating at the highest level, was the only other American official present during the private meeting between Trump and Putin in Helsinki. Democrats argue that her presence makes her a key witness to the conversation between the two leaders and that her testimony could provide crucial insight into what was discussed.

However, the idea of questioning an interpreter is highly unusual and has sparked concerns about the potential implications for diplomatic protocol. Republican Senator Bob Corker, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, questioned the idea, stating that interpreters are not policy experts and that notes taken during the meeting may not be allowed in the future.

In Russia, the head of the foreign affairs committee in the upper house of parliament, Konstantin Kosachev, warned that questioning an interpreter would set a dangerous precedent that threatened the "whole idea of diplomacy." An Arabic interpreter and senior adviser to four US presidents and seven secretaries of state, Gamal Helal, also expressed concerns about the potential implications, stating that it would be a "horrible precedent" if a president was not free to talk one-on-one with a head of state.

The summit itself has been shrouded in controversy, with Trump having to correct his own words from the press conference and sparking concerns about Russia's potential interference in American elections. The US intelligence community has concluded that Russia did interfere in the 2016 election, while Trump has denied this, saying he misspoke and accepts the intelligence agencies' findings. The US Justice Department has charged 12 Russian intelligence officers with hacking Democratic officials in 2016.

The debate over Gross's testimony is ongoing, with some arguing that her presence in the meeting makes her a crucial witness to the conversation between Trump and Putin, while others believe that questioning an interpreter sets a dangerous precedent for diplomatic protocol.

Title: Democratic Lawmakers Boycott Trump's State of the Union Address

Article:

Several Democratic lawmakers have announced they will boycott President Donald Trump's State of the Union address on January 30, citing various reasons. Florida Rep. Frederica Wilson, who was elected in 2010, stated she will not attend the event due to Trump's "recent racist and incendiary remarks about Haiti and African nations." Wilson joins Reps. Maxine Waters, John Lewis, and Earl Blumenauer in boycotting the event.

Rep. Waters, D-Calif., stated she will not attend the address because she does not believe Trump's words are trustworthy. "Why would I take my time to go and sit and listen to a liar?" she said on MSNBC. Rep. Lewis, D-Ga., cited Trump's reported comments about African countries being "s--holes" as his reason for skipping the event. "I can not in all good conscience be in a room with what he has said about so many Americans," he said on MSNBC.

Rep. Blumenauer, D-Ore., had previously announced he would not attend the event before Trump's remarks became public. He stated it would be a waste of time and that he would be staying home instead.

In response to accusations of racism, Trump told reporters, "I'm not a racist, I am the least racist person you have ever interviewed. That I can tell you."

The boycott is not the only protest planned by Democrats. Rep. Jackie Speier, D-Calif., plans to wear black in solidarity with victims of sexual harassment, while other lawmakers plan to invite victims of sexual assault to attend the event. Some lawmakers have also considered holding mock trials with women who have accused Trump of sexual misconduct.

This is not the first time lawmakers have boycotted the State of the Union address. In 2016, Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, skipped former President Barack Obama's last State of the Union address, and three conservative Supreme Court justices, Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Antonin Scalia, were also absent.

Title: Florida Senate Rejects Assault Weapon Ban, Votes to Arm Teachers After Deadly School Shooting

The Florida Senate has rejected a proposal to ban assault weapons and voted in favor of a measure to arm some teachers, just weeks after the deadliest high school shooting in U.S. history. The vote was a largely party-line decision, with two Republicans joining all 15 Democrats in supporting the assault weapon ban.

The bill, known as the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School Public Safety Act, is expected to pass the state Senate on Monday and then go to the Florida House. The bill raises the minimum age to buy a rifle or shotgun to 21 from 18 and bans the use, sale, or possession of bump stocks, which were used in the October 1 shooting deaths of 58 people in Las Vegas. The bill also includes $400 million in funding for schools to address mental health issues.

An amendment to remove a provision to train and arm some teachers failed. The bill does not address the issue of background checks for gun buyers, which was a key demand of students and activists who have been pushing for stricter gun control measures.

The vote comes after the February 14 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, which killed 14 students and three faculty members. The accused shooter, Nikolas Cruz, had a history of run-ins with the law and school officials, and the Broward County school system and sheriff's department have been criticized for not acting on red flags about his mental health problems and potentially violent behavior.

Students from the school have been at the forefront of the push for stricter gun control measures, with many taking to social media to express their disappointment and frustration with the Senate's decision.

Title: The Politics of Compulsion: A Habit We Need to Break

The recent election cycle has once again highlighted the pervasive influence of politics in our daily lives. The article argues that this habit of living and dying by elections is detrimental to our well-being and happiness. The author suggests that politicians often make grand promises to improve our lives, but these promises are rarely kept, leading to a never-ending cycle of promises and disappointments.

The article criticizes both major political parties for their tendency to boss people around in the name of some greater good. Republicans are seen as less inclined to do so, but Democrats are accused of being overly intrusive and controlling. The author notes that even well-intentioned policies, such as the Affordable Care Act, can become overly burdensome and intrusive.

The article also touches on the topic of moral guidance, suggesting that the decline of moral law and the rise of bureaucratic regulations have led to a loss of character and personal responsibility. The author argues that people are no longer taught the importance of personal conduct and character, and instead are left to navigate life's challenges on their own.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for individuals to take back control of their lives and assert their right to freedom, virtue, and contentment. It suggests that politicians will not relinquish their power voluntarily and that it is up to citizens to demand a more limited and respectful government.

Title: Kentucky's Experience with Obamacare: A Complex Picture

The Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has been a contentious issue in the United States, with many politicians using it as a campaign talking point. However, in Kentucky, a state that has implemented the ACA's Medicaid expansion, the story is more nuanced. Despite being a Republican stronghold, Kentucky has seen a significant increase in enrollment in the state-run exchange, kynect, with over 413,400 people signed up by mid-April.

According to Stephen Voss, an associate professor of political science at the University of Kentucky, Obamacare is likely to be a "wash" as a campaign issue in the state. While Kentuckians may disapprove of the ACA, they also recognize the benefits it brings, particularly through kynect. The program has provided health insurance to over 1 in 10 residents, with 75% of enrollees having no health insurance prior to signing up.

The ACA's Medicaid expansion has been particularly popular in Kentucky, with 80% of kynect customers covered by the program. This is especially welcome in Hazard, a town in eastern Kentucky that has been devastated by the collapse of the coal industry. The town has seen over 10,000 jobs lost in the past year, with unemployment rates reaching 14.5%. The Medicaid expansion has provided a vital lifeline for many residents, including Stephen Kelly, who recently moved to Hazard and signed up for Medicaid through kynect.

Kelly, who has a wife and two sons, was previously uninsured and had not had a physical or lab tests in some time. He is grateful for the coverage, but also acknowledges that it has affected others who already had insurance, such as his parents. His father, who lives in Harlan, Kentucky, is seeing his insurance costs skyrocket.

The ambivalence towards the ACA is reflected in a recent poll by The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation, which found that 55% of Kentuckians disapprove of the health-care law, but a majority also want their representative in Congress to work to improve it rather than repeal it. Similar results were seen in other states with hotly contested Senate seats, including Louisiana, North Carolina, and Arkansas.

Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader, has been a vocal critic of the ACA, urging its repeal and replacement. However, his Democratic opponent, Alison Lundergan Grimes, has taken a more nuanced approach, avoiding discussion of the health-care law and instead focusing on its benefits. As the election approaches, Senator Robert Stivers, a Republican, predicts that people will experience "sticker shock" when they receive their health insurance enrollment notices in October, which could benefit McConnell's campaign. However, until then, the ACA's popularity is likely to remain a complex issue in Kentucky.

Title: Former Vice President Biden's Marijuana Policy Stance Raises Concerns Among Democrats

Article:

Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s stance on marijuana policy has come under scrutiny as he considers a run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination. As a leader in the "war on drugs" in the 1980s and 1990s, Biden championed laws that imposed tough mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses, including possessing large amounts of marijuana. This led to an era of mass incarceration, disproportionately affecting minority communities.

According to John Hudak, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, Biden's history on criminal justice issues is his biggest liability in the 2020 primary. Hudak noted that Biden's position on marijuana policy is no longer in line with the mainstream of Democratic politics.

Biden has apologized for parts of his record, specifically the 1980s law that imposed harsher penalties for crack cocaine than powder cocaine, which disproportionately affected African-American communities. However, his stance on marijuana policy remains a concern for some Democrats.

Two Democratic senators who oppose legalizing marijuana at the federal level, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, represent battleground states in the Midwest, where politics are less progressive than the coastal states that have led the way to legalizing cannabis for adults.

Title: ASEAN Foreign Ministers Express Concern Over South China Sea Developments

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers gathered in Vientiane, Laos, for their annual retreat, where they expressed serious concerns over recent developments in the disputed South China Sea. The ministers reaffirmed the importance of maintaining peace, security, and stability in the region, which is strategically important for global trade and commerce.

The South China Sea is at the center of a territorial dispute between China and several ASEAN countries, including Vietnam, the Philippines, and Malaysia. Tensions have escalated since China began a massive land reclamation program in 2013. Recent satellite imagery suggests that China has installed surface-to-air missiles in a disputed area in the Paracels chain, prompting accusations that Beijing is militarizing the area.

In a joint statement, the ASEAN foreign ministers expressed their concerns over recent and ongoing developments in the South China Sea, noting that the activities have "eroded trust and confidence, increased tensions, and may undermine peace, security, and stability in the region."
