Vietnam's foreign minister, Pham Binh Minh, called for the "non-militarization" of the South China Sea, while Cambodia's foreign minister, Hor Namhong, said ASEAN would seek a meeting with China over the matter.

The meeting also addressed other regional issues, including the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula and the threat of Islamic extremism. Malaysia's foreign minister, Anifah Aman, emphasized that the threat of Islamic extremism is "real" and "no longer fictitious or mere imagination."

The ministers also discussed ways to promote economic cooperation within the ASEAN Economic Community, which was established at the end of last year. The community aims to create a single market and production base, promoting economic growth and development in the region.

Title: Same-Sex Couple Receives Marriage License from Rowan County Courthouse

A dramatic scene unfolded at the Rowan County Courthouse in Kentucky this morning, as a gay couple, James Yates and William Smith, received a marriage license after five previous attempts. The couple arrived at the courthouse as the sun rose, walking past protesters who were both supportive and opposed to their union. The scene was emotional and contentious, with some chanting "Love has won. Love has won."

The couple's journey was made possible after Kim Davis, the county clerk, was held in contempt by a federal judge on Thursday for refusing to issue marriage licenses in defiance of the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling. With Davis absent, Deputy Clerk Brian Mason issued the license to Yates and Smith, who became the first same-sex couple to receive a marriage license from Rowan County.

Yates expressed relief and gratitude, stating, "I don't want her in jail. No one wanted her in jail. We just wanted the licenses given out. This isn't a blessing. It's an official license." Smith added, "This means, at least for this area, civil rights are civil rights and they're not subject to beliefs."

However, Davis's husband, Joe Davis, was among a group of protesters who gathered outside the courthouse, calling the issue a moral fight. He emphasized that they do not hate the couple, but rather want to preserve their religious beliefs. "We don't hate these people. That's the furthest thing from our hearts. We don't hate nobody. We just want to have the same rights that they have. They're saying, 'Hey, we're gonna make you accept us.' But they don't want to accept our beliefs. But they want us to accept theirs."

It remains unclear whether the marriage licenses issued today are legally valid, as they do not bear Davis's signature.

Title: Attorney General Jeff Sessions Responds to President Trump's Criticism

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has fired back at President Donald Trump's repeated insults, stating that he took control of the Department of Justice the day he was sworn in and has since achieved unprecedented success in advancing the President's agenda. Sessions emphasized that the actions of the Department of Justice will not be influenced by political considerations and that he demands the highest standards, taking action when they are not met.

The statement comes after Trump attacked Sessions in an interview with "Fox and Friends" host Ainsley Earhardt, saying that Sessions never took control of the Justice Department and that he would not have hired him if he had known he would recuse himself from the FBI investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Trump also criticized Sessions for his decision to recuse himself, saying it was a sign of weakness and lack of loyalty.

Sessions' response is a rare instance of him directly addressing Trump's attacks. He has previously only responded once, when Trump tweeted about the Department of Justice's investigation into potential FISA abuse. Sessions defended the department's actions, stating that he had initiated the appropriate process to ensure complaints against the department would be fully and fairly acted upon.

The tensions between Trump and Sessions have been ongoing since Sessions' recusal from the Russia investigation, which Trump believes is the root of his current political problems. Trump has repeatedly criticized Sessions for his decision to recuse himself, saying it was a betrayal of his trust and a sign of weakness. Despite this, Trump has not fired Sessions, with his lawyer Rudy Giuliani stating that Trump has "some grievances" with Sessions but will not fire him before the Mueller investigation is over.

Title: President Obama Promotes Infrastructure Investment Plan to Boost Job Creation

President Obama visited the port of Miami on Friday to promote his plan to encourage private sector investment in infrastructure, aimed at increasing job creation in the United States. The "Rebuild America Partnership" plan consists of three components: the creation of a $10 billion national infrastructure bank, the establishment of new "America Fast Forward Bonds" for infrastructure investment, and the expansion of funding for the TIGER and TIFFIA infrastructure programs.

During his speech, the president emphasized the importance of investing in infrastructure to strengthen the economy and create jobs. "There are few more important things we can do to create jobs right now and strengthen our economy over the long haul than rebuilding the infrastructure that powers our businesses and our economy - our roads, our bridges, our schools, and our ports," Obama said.

The president also toured a tunnel project at the port of Miami, which is undergoing a $2 billion renovation funded by government and private money. He highlighted the importance of creating jobs that cannot be outsourced and emphasized the need for good construction jobs that provide people with good pay and opportunities to raise their families.

According to Alan Krueger, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, the program will total $21 billion, but it will not increase the deficit. Details of the program's costs will be outlined in the president's budget, which will be presented on April 10.

The president's speech concluded with a call to action, urging Americans to work together to rebuild the country and make it a better place for future generations. "Let's rebuild this country we love. Let's make sure we're staying on the cutting edge. Let's make sure we've always got the best ports. Let's make sure we've got the best airports. Let's make sure we've got the best rail lines. Let's make sure we've got the best roads. Let's make sure we've got the best schools," he said.

Title: Charlotte Police Claim 70% of Arrested Protesters Had Out-of-State IDs, Blame Outside Entities for Chaos

Article:

The Charlotte-Mecklenburg Fraternal Order of Police has attributed the recent unrest in Charlotte to outside entities, stating that 70% of those arrested had out-of-state IDs. According to Todd Walther, the organization's spokesman, these individuals were not local protesters but rather "instigators" who came from outside the city. The claim is based on an analysis of arrest records, which showed that approximately 70% of those arrested had IDs from outside North Carolina.

This assertion is not entirely surprising, as similar claims were made during the Ferguson protests 18 months ago. At that time, it was reported that liberal billionaire George Soros had donated $33 million to social justice organizations, which helped turn the local protest into a national flashpoint.

Soros has been accused of funding and mobilizing groups across the United States, including the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement. According to an investigation by The Washington Times, Soros's Open Society Foundations (OSF) had given at least $650,000 to BLM. The documents obtained by DCLeaks.com revealed that OSF's funding was intended to "dismantle" America and recast it according to Soros's vision.

The article also highlights the financial connections between Soros and Hillary Clinton, with Soros being a major donor to her presidential campaign. Soros's philanthropic network, Open Society Policy Center, spent $8.2 million on lobbying Washington in 2015, focusing on issues such as international human rights, immigration, foreign aid, and criminal justice reform.

The article concludes by suggesting that the sudden appearance of out-of-state protesters in Charlotte may be a deliberate attempt to shift the focus away from Hillary Clinton's declining poll numbers and onto domestic division.

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama's Handling of Foreign Policy Amidst Middle East Unrest

Article:

In a sudden shift in focus, the presidential campaign has turned to foreign policy, with Republican nominee Mitt Romney criticizing President Barack Obama's handling of recent attacks on U.S. diplomatic posts in Cairo and Benghazi, Libya. Romney offered condolences to the families of the American diplomatic workers who died in the attacks, but quickly turned to a sharp critique of Obama's strategy.

Romney accused the Obama administration of sympathizing with the instigators of the violence in Cairo, citing a statement released by the American embassy there. However, a timeline of events suggests Romney was mistaken in that allegation, as the violence came after the initial statement was published. The embassy later tweeted that they stood by their original statement and condemned the protests.

Obama, meanwhile, issued a warning to the perpetrators of the attacks, stating that the U.S. will bring those responsible to justice and that no act of terror will go unpunished. He also emphasized the importance of upholding American values and not apologizing for them.

The debate has sparked mixed reactions, with some Democrats pushing back against Romney's criticism, saying he is injecting politics into a still-developing international crisis. Former Ambassador Nick Burns, who served in the administrations of Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, expressed dismay at Romney's decision to politicize the situation.

Republicans have largely refrained from criticizing their party's nominee, with Sen. John McCain of Arizona stating that he agrees with Obama's policy towards the Middle East being weak. The Wall Street Journal editorial page also defended Romney's stance, saying he is not pandering to Islamists.

This week's shift to foreign policy comes after more than a year of a near-singular campaign focus on jobs and the economy. The topic re-entered the political discussion following the Republican National Convention, when Democrats highlighted support for American troops currently in war zones and the president's successful foreign policy actions. According to recent polls, voters consistently say Obama would better handle America's relationships with other countries if re-elected.

Title: Hillary Clinton's History of Deception and Misstatements Raises Questions About Her Trustworthiness

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, has faced numerous challenges to her trustworthiness throughout her political career. From her involvement in the White House travel office firings to her claims about her secret email setup as secretary of state, Mrs. Clinton has left a trail of deceit and deception stretching back a quarter-century.

The latest controversy surrounding Mrs. Clinton's health and her near-collapse at a 9/11 commemoration ceremony in New York has brought all of those issues back to the forefront. Republican strategist Ed Rollins traced Mrs. Clinton's problem with veracity back to her 1992 interview on "60 Minutes," where she defended her husband, Bill Clinton, from accusations of having an extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers.

Mrs. Clinton's early scrapes with telling the truth include her involvement in the firings at the White House travel office in 1993, which were believed to be intended to make room for hiring friends of the Clintons. The independent counsel investigating the scandal, known as Travelgate, found that Mrs. Clinton's statements denying her involvement were "factually inaccurate."

As secretary of state, Mrs. Clinton's use of a private email server has been a major controversy. FBI Director James B. Comey outlined scores of lies Mrs. Clinton told the public about her secret email server, including claims that she used only one device, that she never received or sent emails marked classified, and that she turned over all her work-related emails to the State Department.

Mrs. Clinton has also been accused of mischaracterizing FBI Director Comey's statements about her answers during an FBI interview. She claimed that Mr. Comey said her answers were truthful and consistent with what she had told the American people, but Mr. Comey did not say that. He said her answers during the FBI interview were truthful, but her claims about not handling classified information were "not true."

Mrs. Clinton has also been accused of exaggerating her experiences, including her claim that she landed under sniper fire in Bosnia as first lady in 1996 and running for cover across the tarmac. A news video of her arrival in Bosnia disproved her account, showing Mrs. Clinton and her daughter Chelsea, then 16, greeted by a welcoming party on the runway.

Some of Mrs. Clinton's breaks with the truth have seemed trivial, such as her claim that "all my grandparents" were immigrants, when only one of her grandparents was an immigrant. She has also changed her position on several issues, including the Keystone XL pipeline, same-sex marriage, the Cuba embargo, charter schools, and driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.

Relatives of three of the Americans killed in the Sept. 11, 2012, terrorist attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi have said that Mrs. Clinton told them the attack was caused by a YouTube video that mocked Islam, despite her knowing it was an organized terrorist strike. Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly denied talking about the video to the family members when she met them at Andrews Air Force Base for the arrival of the caskets.

The controversy surrounding Mrs. Clinton's health and her near-collapse has brought all of these issues back to the forefront, raising questions about her trustworthiness and whether she is honest and trustworthy.

**Car Loans for Low-Income Americans Reach Crisis Levels**

The cost of owning a car has become increasingly unaffordable for many low-income Americans, with over 7 million people already 90 or more days behind on their car loans, according to the New York Federal Reserve. The problem is attributed to the financial crisis, which led to a shortage of affordable used cars, typically 10-year-old vehicles, due to reduced production. As a result, prices for these vehicles have risen by nearly 75% since 2010, making it even harder for low-wage earners to keep up with payments.

The average monthly auto payment for Americans making under $40,000 has remained flat since 2017, while those in higher wage brackets have seen their payments rise, according to Cox Automotive Inc analysis. This indicates that poorer Americans are stretched so thin they cannot afford to pay more.

Weak lending standards in recent years have contributed to the rising delinquency rates, which are approaching record highs despite a solid economy. Auto lenders are belatedly tightening lending standards, but it may already be too late, said Warren Kornfeld, a senior vice president on Moody's financial institutions team.

Research from the New York Fed showed that while delinquency rates among borrowers with high credit scores have remained steady and low, for subprime borrowers, they have been rising, pushing up the overall delinquency rate. Around 8% of loans originated by lower-score buyers with a credit score below 620 were categorized as seriously late, a development that is surprising during a strong economy and labor market.

For many Americans, owning a car is essential for getting and keeping a job. However, the rising cost of car ownership is making it difficult for low-income individuals to keep up with payments. The average American car is the oldest on record, and the available inventory of vehicles costing under $10,000 will not return to more normal levels until 2022, according to IHS Markit and CarGurus Inc analysis.

The National Alliance of Buy Here, Pay Here Dealers (NABD) president, Ken Shilson, said American consumers have become too comfortable with debt and subprime customers have been "poisoned" by easy access to capital for much of the long economic expansion. However, he added that those customers will be forced by tighter underwriting to seek even older vehicles.

The situation is particularly challenging for individuals like Hollis Heyward, a 30-year-old father of two who makes $10 an hour working at a warehouse in Freeport, Illinois. He had to rework his loan with a local used-car dealer, Good People Automotive, to make his monthly payment more manageable.

Title: Unemployment Rate Drops to 7.8 Percent; 114,000 Jobs Added to Payrolls

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has reported that the unemployment rate in the United States has fallen to 7.8 percent in September, down from 8.1 percent in August. This decline is attributed to a sharp increase in the number of Americans who found part-time jobs and counted themselves as employed. The jobless rate has officially fallen below 8 percent for the first time since January 2009.

According to the BLS, 114,000 jobs were added to private and public payrolls in September. However, the job growth was relatively weak, and the decline in the jobless rate is partly explained by an increase in the number of Americans who found part-time jobs and counted themselves as employed.

The unemployment rate is based on a "household survey," while the figure on job growth comes from a survey of employers. The Financial Times notes that the sampling error on the business establishment survey is plus or minus 100,000 jobs, while the sampling error on the household survey is plus or minus 280,000 jobs.

The BLS report also notes that the broader unemployment rate, which includes everyone in the official rate plus "marginally attached workers" and people who are employed part-time for economic reasons, remained unchanged at 14.7 percent.

The jobless rate decline has sparked reactions from politicians, with President Obama stating that it is a "reminder that this country has come too far to turn back now" and that "we are moving forward again." Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney, on the other hand, has criticized the report, saying that it is not a "real recovery" and that the country has lost over 600,000 manufacturing jobs since President Obama took office.

The BLS report is likely to be a hot topic on the campaign trail, with both sides using it to support their economic policies.

Title: Bush's Presidential Bid Faces Skepticism and Competition

The 2024 presidential election is still nearly 10 months away, but Jeb Bush's team is already facing skepticism and stiff competition. According to Scott Reed, the top political adviser to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the smart money is taking it slow and waiting to see who runs and how the candidates develop their platforms. While raising money is crucial, it's not the only factor in the game.

Bush's advisors claim he never believed he would be able to clear the field and are instead focusing on building a broad coalition of support within the Republican party. They emphasize his ability to deliver a positive message about conservative reforms and their potential to restore opportunity and prosperity for more Americans.

Bush's allies have used the phrase "shock and awe" to describe his plan to secure the support of major donors and policy experts, aiming to make him the sole credible contender for the Republican establishment's blessing. While he has been successful in driving away potential opponents, his fundraising prowess will not be publicly disclosed until July.

Recent polls show Bush performing similarly to other Republican contenders, such as Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker and Kentucky Senator Rand Paul, against potential Democratic opponent Hillary Rodham Clinton. He also trails Walker in Iowa, which has a history of rejecting candidates seen as inevitable nominees.

Some Republicans, like City Council member Colleen Platt in University Park, Iowa, question whether Bush's family legacy is enough to justify his candidacy. Additionally, the Tea Party grassroots remains skeptical of Bush due to his past focus on business and philanthropic interests.

Overall, Bush's presidential bid faces an uphill battle as he navigates the complex landscape of the 2024 election.

Title: Biden Denies Inappropriate Behavior Allegations, Promises to Listen to Accusations

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has denied allegations of inappropriate behavior made by a former Democratic candidate in Nevada, Lucy Flores. Flores accused Biden of planting a "big, slow kiss" on the back of her head during a 2014 campaign event. In a statement, Biden denied any wrongdoing, stating that he has offered countless handshakes, hugs, and expressions of affection throughout his career, but never intended to make anyone uncomfortable.

Biden also expressed his commitment to the #MeToo movement and his willingness to listen to any accusations of misconduct. He emphasized his dedication to fighting for the rights of women and ensuring they are treated with equality.

Flores, however, has expressed disappointment with Biden's response, stating that she wants him to acknowledge his behavior was wrong and change his actions. The episode has led to a flood of pictures and videos showing Biden interacting with women at campaign events and administration functions, with some critics arguing that he has a history of inappropriate behavior.

A recent article by Vox.com catalogued several alleged episodes of misconduct by Biden, including instances of him embracing and whispering in the ears of women, as well as touching their faces and necks. The article argued that the media has given Biden a pass for years, but that this will not be the case in the 2020 election.

Meanwhile, other Democratic presidential hopefuls, including Bernie Sanders, Kamala Harris, and Kirsten Gillibrand, are also facing scrutiny over their handling of sexual misconduct allegations against their staff members. The allegations have highlighted vulnerabilities that could become major liabilities in the primary and general elections.

Title: Understanding the Constitution: A Guide to the Foundation of the United States

The United States celebrates its independence on July 4th with grandeur and fanfare, but often overlooks another significant date, September 17th, which marks the adoption of the United States Constitution. This landmark document has endured for over two centuries, outlining the framework of the republic and its governance. Without a proper understanding of the Constitution, it is challenging to comprehend the country's history, the decisions made by the Supreme Court, and the actions of government agencies.

The Constitution has been in place since 1789, a remarkable achievement considering the average lifespan of a constitution is only 17 years, according to Thomas Ginsburg, Zachary Elkins, and James Melton, authors of "The Lifespan of Written Constitutions." The document has withstood wars, periods of great transformation, and upheaval, earning praise from notable figures like William Gladstone, who called it "the most wonderful work ever struck off at a given time by the brain and purpose of man."

For those who have never read the Constitution or haven't done so in a while, it is an accessible and manageable task. The document is approximately 4,500 words long and can be read in about half an hour. The Heritage Foundation has published a comprehensive guide, "The Heritage Guide to the Constitution," which provides expert analysis, relevant court cases, and an overview of the Constitution's creation.

The guide is not only useful for law students but also for any citizen seeking to understand the law of the land. As former U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese III notes, "It is our fundamental law because it represents the settled and deliberate will of the people, against which the actions of government officials must be squared. In the end, the continued success and viability of our democratic Republic depends on our fidelity to, and the faithful exposition and interpretation of, this Constitution, our great charter of liberty."

As the next September 17th approaches, it is essential to recognize the significance of the Constitution and its role in shaping the country's history and governance.

Title: White House Signals Potential Delay of Obamacare Individual Mandate

Article: The White House press secretary, Jay Carney, hinted that the individual mandate under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) might be delayed due to issues with the healthcare law's enrollment website. This is the first official indication that the administration may consider a delay. The individual mandate requires uninsured Americans to sign up for health insurance, with penalties for those who do not comply. Carney did not directly confirm a delay, but stated that if people cannot access the website, they will not be penalized.

The potential delay comes after the administration's earlier refusal to consider a delay, with the White House calling those who sought a delay "suicide-bombing kidnapping arsonists." The government shutdown, which was linked to the Affordable Care Act, has been ongoing for three weeks.

The White House's explanation for the website issues has been met with skepticism, with NBC's Chuck Todd pressing Carney on the matter. The administration has claimed that the website was overwhelmed by traffic, but this has been disputed by experts and critics.

The article also highlights the lack of success stories from the Affordable Care Act's enrollment process, with only three of the 13 individuals presented as examples actually enrolled in the exchanges. The article questions whether anyone will be held accountable for the mounting issues and mistakes surrounding the healthcare law.

The article does not take a stance on the politics of the Affordable Care Act or the government shutdown, instead focusing on the factual developments and implications of the potential delay.

Title: Montana GOP House Candidate Greg Gianforte Charged with Misdemeanor Assault After Altercation with Reporter

Montana law enforcement officials have charged Republican House candidate Greg Gianforte with misdemeanor assault following an alleged physical altercation with a reporter on Wednesday evening. The incident occurred at Gianforte's campaign headquarters in Bozeman, where he allegedly slammed Ben Jacobs, a reporter for The Guardian, to the floor.

According to an audio recording released by The Guardian, Gianforte initially brushed aside Jacobs' question about the Congressional Budget Office score of the House GOP's American Health Care Act, which passed the House earlier in the month. Jacobs then asked to continue the conversation, but Gianforte allegedly became aggressive, telling Jacobs to leave and eventually body-slamming him to the ground.

Gianforte's office offered a different account of the incident, stating that Jacobs had encroached on a private interview and aggressively shoved a recorder in Gianforte's face. However, eyewitness accounts from Fox News reporters contradict Gianforte's story, with one reporter describing Gianforte grabbing Jacobs by the neck and slamming him to the ground.

The Gallatin County Sheriff's Office investigated the incident and determined there was probable cause to issue a citation to Gianforte for misdemeanor assault. Gianforte faces a maximum sentence of six months in jail, a $500 fine, or both.

The incident has sparked widespread condemnation from Democrats, who are calling on Gianforte to withdraw his candidacy and for Republicans to condemn his conduct. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee launched an 11th-hour Facebook ad campaign highlighting the episode in an effort to sway voters heading to the polls on Thursday.

Gianforte is expected to appear in court before June 7. The special election pits Gianforte against Democrat Rob Quist in a contest to replace former GOP Rep. Ryan Zinke, who is now heading President Trump's Interior Department. Gianforte is seen as a slight favorite in the race.

Title: Trump Disputes Wall Street Journal Account of Interview, Claims He Said "I'd Have a Good Relationship" with Kim Jong Un

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump disputed a recent interview with the Wall Street Journal, claiming he said "I'd have a good relationship" with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, rather than stating he already has a good relationship with him. Trump took to Twitter to express his disagreement, stating that the Journal's account was "FAKE NEWS" and that the outlet knew exactly what he meant but wanted a story.

The White House released a portion of the audio from the interview, which appears to support Trump's claim that he used the conditional tense when discussing his potential relationship with Kim. The Wall Street Journal, however, stands by its account, releasing its own audio that it says backs up its version of the events.

The Trump administration's clarification of the interview comes amid heightened tensions between the U.S. and North Korea. The two leaders have exchanged threats and insults, with Trump referring to Kim as a "maniac" and Kim calling Trump a "mentally deranged dotard." Despite this animosity, Trump has welcomed the recent intra-Korean talks, which could potentially lead to a reduction in tensions.

The North Korean leader has announced his country's participation in the upcoming Winter Olympics in South Korea, a move seen as a step towards easing tensions. However, the threat from North Korea remains, with the country developing a nuclear-tipped missile capable of hitting the United States.

Title: House Republican Candidates Embrace Tough Stance on Immigration in TV Ads

House Republican candidates are airing a significant number of TV ads that emphasize a hardline stance on immigration, a significant shift from the 2014 midterm elections. According to an analysis by Kantar Media, Republicans have aired over 14,000 campaign ads promoting a Trump-style immigration platform this year. This surge in ads highlights the concerns of House GOP leaders that passing a legislative fix for undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children, known as DREAMers, could put GOP candidates at risk heading into the fall election.

The ads feature Republican candidates promising to "end sanctuary cities" and "build the wall," as seen in an ad by Troy Balderson, a GOP state senator running for Congress in Ohio. In contrast, Democrats are focusing on ads that promise to protect Obamacare, shore up Social Security, and expand Medicare, as seen in an ad by California Democrat Paul Kerr.

The competing messages demonstrate the significant divide between the two parties, with Republicans focusing on immigration and Democrats emphasizing healthcare. The ads are not just talking about issues differently, but are touting completely different issues to motivate activists and win hotly contested primaries.

According to Kyle Kondik, a political analyst with the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, the two parties are essentially talking to different countries, especially in primaries. Republicans appeal to a whiter, older, and more rural electorate, while Democrats court a more diverse, younger, and urban constituency.

The GOP focus on immigration is particularly striking, given that it was not among the top 10 issues Republicans spent their ad dollars on at this point in the 2014 midterms. In that cycle, GOP contenders attacked President Obama, bashing the Affordable Care Act and promising to rein in government spending.

While some strategists warn that the GOP's full-throated embrace of Trump's anti-immigration positions in primaries could come back to haunt them in the fall, others argue that it will help energize the Republican base. However, a Pew Research Center poll in January found that 74% of Americans support granting permanent legal status to the DREAMers, and 60% oppose expanding the wall along the U.S. border with Mexico.

In contrast, Democratic candidates have focused overwhelmingly on healthcare in their advertising, running more than 26,000 ads on the subject. Of those, more than 8,500 Democratic spots promise to protect or expand Medicare, according to Kantar data.

Title: Trump's Lawyers Move to Block Congressional Subpoena for Financial Information

Article:

Attorneys for President Trump and the Trump Organization have filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, seeking to block a congressional subpoena that demands financial information from Mazars USA, a longtime accounting firm for the company. The subpoena, issued by House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings, seeks financial statements and supporting documents from 2011 to 2018 for Mr. Trump, the Trump Organization, and other associated entities.

The lawsuit claims that the subpoena lacks a "legitimate legislative purpose" and that Mr. Cummings has "ignored the constitutional limits on Congress's power to investigate." The lawsuit also argues that the subpoena threatens to expose "confidential information" and asks the court to declare the subpoena "invalid and unenforceable."

This is the latest move by Mr. Trump's legal team to push back against what they call "presidential harassment" from the newly empowered Democratic majority in the House. The lawsuit claims that House Democrats are using their newfound majority to investigate "every aspect" of Mr. Trump's personal finances, businesses, and family, and that they are "singularly obsessed" with finding politically damaging information on the president.

The subpoena was issued after Mr. Trump's former lawyer and fixer, Michael Cohen, testified to the committee about the president's financial information. Mr. Cummings has said that the White House is engaged in "unprecedented stonewalling on all fronts" and that they have not produced a single document or witness to the oversight committee this year.

In a separate battle, Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal has given the IRS a new April 23 deadline to turn over six years' worth of Mr. Trump's personal tax returns, as well as returns for some associated organizations. Treasury Secretary Steven T. Mnuchin had previously sent a letter saying he would miss the original April 10 deadline and questioned the legislative purpose behind the request.

The article does not take a stance on the validity of the subpoena or the motivations behind the lawsuit, instead presenting the facts and quotes from both sides.

Title: US-China Trade Tensions Escalate: Tariffs to Affect $50 Billion in Imports and Impact Consumers

The United States has announced plans to impose tariffs on Chinese goods, which would have a significant impact on American consumers who rely heavily on imports of electronics, clothing, and other products. The tariffs, which would affect at least $50 billion in imports annually, are a response to China's alleged theft of intellectual property and unfair trade practices.

According to Joseph Parilla of the Brookings Institution, the steel and aluminum tariffs, which were implemented earlier, would affect imports of around $33 billion, excluding Canada and Mexico, which are expected to be exempt from the measures. In contrast, the China tariffs would have a more significant impact on American consumers.

Chinese companies have been investing heavily in the United States, with deals worth tens of billions of dollars annually in the past. However, last year, these investments fell sharply to $8.7 billion as China cracked down on capital outflows. Chinese companies have purchased non-strategic assets like movie theaters and the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York, as well as cutting-edge technology companies related to autonomous driving.

The Trump administration has accused China of stealing intellectual property and forcing the transfer of technology, which it sees as a long-term economic and security threat to its rise as a superpower. The business community, which has long defended trade with China, has grown increasingly dissatisfied with the adverse treatment of American companies in the Chinese market.

However, some American business groups have expressed concern that the tariffs could lead to a broader escalation of trade tensions and the imposition of trade barriers around the world.

Title: Obama's Economic Agenda Takes Center Stage in Austin Visit

The recent visit of President Barack Obama to Austin, Texas, has been met with skepticism by Republican officials, who view it as a campaign-style stunt that will not significantly impact the economy or create jobs. The Republican National Committee released a statement calling the trip "Obama's Jobs Strategy: Pivot Back to the Economy Every So Often."

In his State of the Union address, President Obama outlined an economic agenda that includes a renewed focus on manufacturing, increased funding for early childhood education, a higher minimum wage, and greater investment in infrastructure. While some Republicans have expressed support for certain aspects of the agenda, there is little indication that the majority of it will be passed in the current Congress.

Despite the skepticism, President Obama's aides believe that events like the Austin visit are necessary to keep pressure on Republicans and demonstrate to Americans that the president is still pushing for his agenda. The risk for the president is that these events may be perceived as costly excursions that do not actually improve the economy. However, aides point out that the president would likely face criticism if he did not push for his agenda.

The president's political advisers recall the lessons of his first two years in office, when he rarely traveled around the country, staying in Washington to shepherd his healthcare legislation through Congress. His approval ratings and mood suffered as a result, leading aides to believe that frequent travel is essential to maintain public support.

During his visit to Austin, President Obama was scheduled to meet with local residents and technology entrepreneurs, as well as tour a facility of Applied Materials, a company based in Silicon Valley that manufactures equipment for the production of silicon chips for computers, phones, and other high-tech devices.

Title: At Least 57 Prisoners Killed in Riot at Altamira Prison in Northern Brazil

Article:

A violent riot broke out at the Regional Recovery Center in Altamira, Brazil, on July 29, 2019, resulting in the deaths of at least 57 prisoners. The incident occurred when organized crime groups clashed, with 16 of the victims being decapitated, according to prison officials. The fight started around 7 a.m. between the Rio de Janeiro-based Comando Vermelho and a local criminal group known as Comando Classe A.

The conflict led to a fire spreading rapidly through the prison, with inmates held in old container units that had been adapted for the prison while another building is under construction. The fire prevented police forces from entering the building for several hours, and two prison staff members were held hostage, but were eventually released.

Authorities have not found any firearms following the riot, only makeshift knives. As a result, 46 inmates will be transferred to other prisons, with 10 going to stricter federal facilities.

The incident highlights the ongoing issues with violence in Brazil's prisons, with President Jair Bolsonaro having campaigned on a promise to curb the widespread violence. The prison in Altamira had a reported 343 detainees for a maximum capacity of 163, according to a July 2019 report from the National Justice Council. However, prison authorities dispute the notion that the prison is overcrowded, citing a threshold of 210% capacity.

The incident is the latest in a series of violent incidents in Brazil's prisons, including a May 2019 riot in which 55 inmates died in several prisons in the neighboring state of Amazonas. In early 2017, more than 120 inmates died in prisons across several northern states when rival gangs clashed over control of drug-trafficking routes.

Title: Former Vice President Al Gore Optimistic About Climate Change Debate, Citing Progress in "Winning the Conversation"

Former Vice President Al Gore expressed optimism about the future of the climate change debate, stating that activists are winning the conversation and that Republicans are growing weary of global warming deniers. In an interview with The Washington Post, Gore compared the current climate change debate to previous social movements, such as the civil rights movement and the anti-apartheid movement, where activists eventually won public support and policy changes.

Gore pointed to the debate over smoking as an example of how public opinion can shift rapidly. He recalled that Senator Frank Lautenberg's efforts to ban smoking in airplanes were initially met with skepticism, but eventually gained widespread support. Gore believes that a similar shift is happening with climate change, citing private conversations with Republicans who are starting to accept the reality of global warming.

However, Gore acknowledged that the process of "winning the conversation" has been stalled in the past due to a "shrinking group of denialists" who become enraged when the topic is discussed. He compared this phenomenon to a family with an "alcoholic father" who becomes violent when the subject is mentioned, causing everyone to avoid the issue to maintain peace.

Gore credited President Barack Obama's aggressive new climate change strategy, which includes limiting pollution from existing coal-fired power plants and establishing carbon pollution standards for active plants, as a significant step forward. He expressed encouragement for the policy moves and believes that the ability of denialists to stop progress is waning daily.

The article also mentioned a recent effort by Organizing for Action, a political group formed from President Obama's re-election campaign, to hold members of Congress accountable for their positions on climate change. The group delivered unicorn statues to Republican deniers in Congress as part of a larger push to raise awareness about the issue.

Title: US Demands Iranian Ship Carrying Aid to Yemen Change Course and Head to Djibouti

The United States is urging an Iranian ship carrying humanitarian aid to Yemen to change its course and head to Djibouti, where the United Nations is overseeing humanitarian deliveries. The ship, the Iran Shahed, had moved through the Strait of Hormuz and was now in the Gulf of Oman, according to the marinetraffic.com site. However, it was not under any naval escort at the moment, according to Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steven Warren.

The US military is tracking the ship after Tehran reportedly said it would send warships to escort the vessel to Yemen. Warren stated that the US is aware of the Iranians' statement that they plan to safeguard the vessel, but emphasized that the aid should be delivered to the UN humanitarian aid distribution hub in Djibouti.

The Iranian Red Crescent had announced last week that it would send a ship carrying 2,500 tons of humanitarian aid to Yemen, where Tehran-backed Huthi rebels are fighting pro-government forces supported by a Saudi-led coalition. Warren noted that the Iranians have stated that this is humanitarian aid, and encouraged them to deliver it to the UN hub in Djibouti, which would allow the aid to be rapidly and efficiently distributed to those in Yemen who require it.

When asked if the US military would try to search the ship or prevent it from docking in Yemen, Warren declined to comment. The warnings from Washington raised the possibility of a potential confrontation at sea after tensions flared in recent days in the Strait of Hormuz. The US Navy had bolstered its presence in the Gulf after Iran seized a Marshall Islands-flagged vessel in the vital waterway. Iranian authorities later released the ship, citing a commercial dispute with Denmark's Maersk group, which chartered the vessel.

Warren emphasized that if the Iranians are planning some sort of stunt in the region, it would be unhelpful and could potentially threaten the ceasefire in Yemen that has been so painstakingly brought about. He called on the Iranians to do the right thing and deliver their humanitarian aid in accordance with UN protocols, which is through the distribution hub established in Djibouti.

Title: Warren Calls for Congressional Action to Allow Indictment of Sitting Presidents

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has called on Congress to pass a law making it clear that the Justice Department can criminally indict a sitting president and charge them with obstructing justice. Warren's statement comes in response to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and his statement this week that Justice Department policy prevented him from bringing charges against a sitting president.

According to Warren, "no president is above the law," and Congress should make it clear that presidents can be indicted for criminal activity, including obstruction of justice. She criticized Trump's attorney general, William Barr, saying he had "acted like Trump's personal defense attorney."

Warren's statement highlighted 10 instances in which Trump allegedly tried to have Mueller fired or impede the investigation, which she described as "a crime." She urged Congress to pass a law making it clear that presidents can be indicted for criminal activity, including obstruction of justice, and to amend statutes relating to such obstruction to allow for indictment when a president abuses the powers of office.

Warren also promised that if she is elected, she would ensure her appointees reverse a Justice Department opinion that argues a sitting president cannot be indicted. She emphasized that "Donald Trump is not a king. No president is. And our democracy only works if everyone can be held accountable."

Title: NSA Ruling Reveals Routine Violations of Metadata Query Standards

A recent ruling by a federal judge has revealed that the National Security Agency (NSA) had been consistently violating standards for querying metadata, despite repeated assurances to the contrary. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), a free speech and privacy rights group, obtained the ruling after Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, fought to declassify the information.

The ruling, which dates back to 2009, concluded that the NSA's querying of metadata did not meet the standard for querying, citing a 2009 ruling that found the requirement had been "so frequently and systematically violated that it can fairly be said that this critical element of the overall regime has never functioned effectively."

Senator Wyden, an outspoken critic of NSA surveillance, praised the declassification of the ruling, stating that while the NSA had increased privacy protections for domestic and unrelated communications, the collection itself was a "serious violation of the Fourth Amendment." Mark Rumold, a representative from the EFF, commended the administration for releasing the document with relatively few redactions, but criticized the time and difficulty in obtaining it.

The ruling focused on a program under which the NSA searches domestic Internet links for communications where at least one side is overseas, and there are "strong selectors" indicating insider knowledge of someone who has been targeted for foreign-intelligence collection. A senior intelligence official defended the NSA's oversight, stating that around 300 employees were assigned to identify even inadvertent violations of the rules and that the court conducted "vigorous" oversight.

The EFF's Rumold argued that the ruling illustrates the surveillance court's inability to effectively monitor the NSA due to its dependence on the agency's representations and lack of investigative powers. The ruling highlights the ongoing concerns about the NSA's surveillance practices and the need for greater transparency and accountability.

Title: Republicans Express Skepticism Over Immigration Reform in 2014

Article:

Conservative Republicans have expressed doubts about tackling an immigration bill this year, citing a lack of trust in President Obama's commitment to implementing strict security measures. At a Heritage Foundation event, Republican House members emphasized that any immigration reform efforts must prioritize border security before moving forward.

Representative Raul Labrador, an Idaho Republican, stated that the administration must prove itself before Republicans will consider taking action. "We need to have the trust with this administration, and that trust is not there, and until we have that trust, there will be no immigration reform, and it would be a mistake for leadership to push that," Labrador said.

House Speaker John A. Boehner released principles last week, calling for increased security measures and legal status for illegal immigrants, as well as a pathway to citizenship for young adult illegal immigrants. However, Boehner himself has not committed to moving forward with a bill this year.

Representative Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, believes the principles are a helpful starting point for a dialogue with the Hispanic community on conservative principles, but acknowledged that it may not be the right time to move forward with a broad bill.

The Senate passed a comprehensive immigration bill in June, which included citizenship rights for most illegal immigrants, but the legislation has faced challenges. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, expressed doubts about finding a compromise between the House and Senate versions, stating, "I don't see how you get to an outcome this year with the two bodies in such a different place."

Democrats had hoped the release of the principles would pave the way for an agreement this year, but the two sides remain far apart on key issues. House Republicans want to tackle the issue through a series of bills, while the Senate passed a single, comprehensive measure. The biggest sticking point is the question of citizenship, with the Senate bill offering a pathway to citizenship for most illegal immigrants in 13 years, while the House principles specify a path to citizenship only for young illegal immigrants, known as the "Dreamers."

Title: Trump's Dominance Fades as Rivals Shine in First Republican Debate

The first Republican presidential debate on Thursday night in Cleveland saw Donald Trump, the self-proclaimed outsider, struggle to maintain his dominance as rivals took center stage. Trump, who had been leading in polls and dominating media attention, was part of the cast, waiting his turn to speak, as one rival after another had their moment to shine.

The debate, moderated by Fox News, saw Trump facing questions on his numerous insults to women, which he responded to with a petulant remark about Megyn Kelly not being "very nice" to him. He also refused to commit to supporting the eventual Republican nominee, saying he would only do so if it's someone he respects.

Trump's anti-politician posture, which had allowed him to defy the usual political laws of gravity, seemed to fade as he was drawn into the fray, sidestepping questions like the biggest politician of all. The debate saw Trump tussling with Rand Paul on single-payer health care and wrangling with Jeb Bush on the tone of his own rhetoric, but he was unable to eclipse the other personalities onstage in the same way he has done all summer.

Meanwhile, other candidates, such as Ohio Governor John Kasich, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, and Senator Ted Cruz, found ways to hold the camera and make their mark. Kasich benefited from a friendly local crowd and a compact message about balancing budgets and creating jobs, while Walker talked about winning three times in a blue state and hardening his stance on immigration. Cruz discussed religious liberty and his father's conversion to Christianity, prompting Walker to talk about his Baptist faith.

The debate also saw a notable performance from businesswoman Carly Fiorina, who was controlled, crisp, and gimlet-eyed, and asked a pointed question of Trump, "Since he has changed his mind on amnesty, on health care, and on abortion, I would just ask, what are the principles by which he will govern?"

The debate marked a turning point for Trump, who may return to controlled appearances, friendly rallies, and one-candidate news conferences, where he excels at dominating. However, with nine more debates and countless media interviews ahead, it remains to be seen if he can continue to make up the rules as he goes along.

Title: Senator Rand Paul Secures Assurance from Attorney General Eric Holder on Drone Use Against Non-Combatant Americans

Article:

Senator Rand Paul declared victory after receiving a letter from Attorney General Eric Holder, which assured him that the president cannot use a drone to kill a non-combatant American on U.S. soil. This assurance came after Paul's 13-hour filibuster, which delayed a vote on CIA director nominee John Brennan.

The letter, sent to Paul, stated that the answer to his question "Does the President have the authority to use a weaponized drone to kill an American not engaged in combat on American soil?" is no. Paul responded to the letter, saying, "We're proud to announce that the president is not going to kill unarmed Americans on American soil."

The senator's filibuster drew praise from both sides of the political spectrum, but also drew criticism from some Republicans who claimed he stirred unnecessary fear about the use of drones. Senator John McCain, R-Ariz., argued that some of the concerns raised about drone missile attacks on Americans were "ridiculous." Senator Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., displayed a sign showing the number of Americans killed in the U.S. by Al Qaeda versus the number killed in the U.S. by drones, which is zero.

Paul, however, argued that he was raising concerns about how future presidents might use their drone authority. He told Fox News, "I don't think the laws of war apply to America. I think the Bill of Rights do." Paul and other lawmakers are concerned about the potential for drones to be used against American citizens, citing the possibility of an unscrupulous government using them against its own population.

The use of armed drones in U.S. airspace has sparked concerns about the potential for abuse, with some lawmakers pushing legislation to regulate their use. Representative Zoe Lofgren, D-Calif., and Ted Poe, R-Texas, introduced a bill to regulate domestic drones, requiring officials to obtain a warrant to perform many kinds of surveillance and prohibiting law enforcement drones from being equipped with firearms or explosives in U.S. airspace.

The debate surrounding drone use is ongoing, with some lawmakers pushing for greater regulation and others arguing that the technology is necessary for national security.

Title: Pollsters Face Criticism Over Party Affiliation and Sampling Methods

Pollsters are facing criticism from Republicans that surveys are skewed in favor of Democrats, with some accusing them of intentionally trying to demoralize GOP voters. However, pollsters insist that their methods are unbiased and that they are simply sampling people who answer their phones. Despite the controversy, pollsters acknowledge that they have a difficult job and must make judgments about how to handle the data.

Polls over the past week have shown President Obama leading Republican challenger Mitt Romney by 1-8 percentage points in the popular vote. Polling firms downplay the effect of an imbalance, and many differ on whether to cancel it out by giving added weight to GOP responses. However, they all acknowledge that they have a difficult job and must make judgments about how to handle the data.

Polls' random samplings are designed to yield an accurate representation of voter demographics by party, gender, ethnicity, and other categories. However, this is easier said than done, especially when surveys usually sample fewer than 1,500 people. The question for pollsters becomes whether to tweak the data to give added weight to responses from groups that often go underrepresented in polls, such as Republicans, young voters, and minorities.

Charles Franklin, who runs the Marquette University Law School poll, adjusts weights for gender, age, and ethnic balance but not for political party. He argues that an increase in participation by a certain party can be an indicator that it is more energized than the other side. Democrats historically hold a turnout edge in presidential elections, but their advantage often fluctuates.

Scott Rasmussen, founder of Rasmussen Reports, said, "We absolutely know that party affiliation is the best single indicator of how someone is going to vote." In addition to cries of party bias, pollsters are also dealing with issues brought on by technology and changing demographics. Many polls continue to collect their data from calls to landlines rather than cellphones, which could increase responses from older voters who rely on their home phones and minimize participation among younger voters.

The different methods and varieties of approaches among the various pollsters mean poll watchers need to take individual surveys with a grain of salt. "Look across all of the polling," Franklin said. "Don't just try to believe that one poll is always right or that one is always the best. If you see all of the polls pointing in the same direction, that's certainly more reliable."

Title: Global Climate Strike: Thousands of Young People and Adults Skip School and Work to Raise Awareness

Article:

On Friday, thousands of young people and adults around the world participated in the largest climate strike to date, with 4,638 events scheduled in 139 countries. The global protest, organized by 16-year-old Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg and the "Fridays for Future" movement, aimed to raise awareness about climate change and urge leaders to take action.

The event saw people of all ages, from primary school pupils to adults, skipping school and work to join the demonstration. Protesters held signs with pithy and pointed messages, such as "We are skipping our lessons to teach you one" and "When leaders act like kids, kids act like leaders." Many also used humor to convey the urgency of the issue, with some referencing Nelly's 2002 hit song "Hot in Herre" with the lyrics "It's getting hot in here, so take off all your coal."

Social media platforms were flooded with images of climate strike crowds across the globe, with Twitter and Facebook being filled with shots of protesters holding signs and chanting slogans. The event was also marked by a sense of urgency and frustration, with many calling for immediate action from leaders to address the climate crisis.

The "Fridays for Future" movement, founded by Thunberg, emphasizes the importance of taking action now to address the worsening climate crisis. The movement's website states, "With the worsening climate destruction, the goal of going to school begins to be pointless. Why study for a future that may not be there?"

Thunberg also testified at a Capitol Hill hearing on Wednesday, urging U.S. lawmakers to take "real action" on climate change. The event was a global call to action, with protests taking place in cities and towns across the world, from Abuja, Nigeria, to Canberra, Australia.

Title: Virginia Governor Makes Juneteenth an Official Holiday, Commemorating the End of Slavery in the US

Virginia Governor Ralph Northam has announced that Juneteenth, a day commemorating the end of slavery in the United States, will become an official holiday in the state. The holiday, also known as Emancipation Day or Freedom Day, is celebrated annually on June 19. Texas was the first state to make it a holiday, in 1980.

As a paid day off for all state employees, Juneteenth will be observed on June 19. Governor Northam believes Virginia will be the second state to do so. The holiday commemorates June 19, 1865, when news finally reached African Americans in Texas that President Abraham Lincoln had issued the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing slaves living in Confederate states two years earlier.

The announcement came less than two weeks after Governor Northam ordered the removal of a statue of General Robert E. Lee along Richmond's Monument Avenue, one of the country's most iconic monuments to the Confederacy. Earlier this year, he signed legislation scrapping Lee-Jackson Day, a state holiday named after two Confederate generals.

Governor Northam was joined at his news conference by musician Pharrell Williams, who is from Virginia. Williams emphasized that Juneteenth deserves the same level of recognition and celebration as Independence Day. "Here's our day, and if you love us, it'll be your day too," Williams said.

State House Republican Leader Todd Gilbert echoed similar sentiments, stating, "July 4th is the birthday of our nation, but Juneteenth is the day where it truly began to fulfill its promise of freedom for all. For the first time since enslaved Africans landed at Jamestown in 1619, the chains of bondage were finally cast off."

Joseph Rogers, a 29-year-old activist who has been a regular protester in Richmond during more than two weeks of demonstrations over George Floyd's killing, hailed Governor Northam's announcement.

Title: House Republicans Unveil "Plan B" to Avert Fiscal Cliff, But Senate and White House Reject Proposal

House Republicans have introduced a new plan to address the fiscal cliff, which would raise taxes on income above $1 million and extend rates on the rest of Americans. The plan, unveiled by Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) at a closed party meeting on Tuesday, aims to provide cover for House Republicans if the nation goes over the fiscal cliff and income tax rates jump on everyone. However, the Senate and White House have already rejected the proposal, arguing it is still weighted too heavily in favor of the wealthy.

According to sources, Boehner informed President Barack Obama of his plan during a phone call on Monday night, which prompted Obama to tell Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that talks between the White House and Boehner had stalled. White House aides Rob Nabors and Gene Sperling visited Capitol Hill on Tuesday to address the Senate and House Democratic caucuses.

The plan is expected to be voted on this week, but it is unclear whether it will be enough to jump-start negotiations again. The fiscal cliff deadline is just 13 days away, when taxes will go up on everyone and tens of billions of dollars in spending cuts will kick in. The Boehner plan shows that talks between the White House and Boehner have reached at least a temporary impasse.

As of Monday evening, the two sides seemed to be inching toward an agreement, with Boehner moving off his insistence that tax rates not rise on the wealthy and offering the president $1 trillion in fresh revenue – a significant concession. However, it remains to be seen whether this latest development will be enough to break the impasse and avoid the fiscal cliff.

Title: US Presidential Candidates Avoid Discussing Deficit and Debt in Campaign

Article:

The 2020 US presidential election has seen a notable absence of discussion on the country's ballooning annual budget deficits and overall debt. Despite the significant challenges posed by the growing national debt, which now stands at $22.4 trillion, or approximately $68,000 per American, the topic has been largely ignored by both Democratic and Republican candidates.

The Democratic contenders have been reluctant to make the deficit a campaign issue, as their proposed policies, such as expanding Medicare and offering government help to reduce student debt, would present significant budget challenges. Republicans, on the other hand, have been accused of abandoning their commitment to balanced budgets and reducing the national debt, having backed President Donald Trump's massive tax cuts and increased military spending.

Many economists warn that the rising debt will lead to higher interest costs and increased pressure on future governments to make deep spending cuts or risk defaulting on debt payments, which could have far-reaching consequences. Senator Rob Portman, a former White House budget director, lamented the lack of interest in addressing the issue, stating, "I don't think in this election cycle there seems to be much of an interest in addressing the issue."

The Congressional Budget Office has warned that the prospect of such high and rising debt poses substantial risks for the nation. Despite the strong economy, the government has failed to reduce deficits, with the deficit expected to exceed $1 trillion by 2022.

In the first set of Democratic primary debates, none of the 20 candidates offered ideas to control debt or deficits, and a moderator's question about how to pay for the expansion of public benefits went unanswered. Senator Kamala Harris responded by pointing out that Republicans had passed a tax bill that benefits the top 1% and biggest corporations, but did not provide a plan to address the debt.

The last time the budget was balanced was under Democratic President Bill Clinton in 1998 and for the next three years. Since then, both parties have shown little interest in offering detailed policies to tackle the debt, instead focusing on other issues like healthcare, immigration, and climate change.

The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget's head, Maya MacGuineas, described the current political climate as an "era of hyper-partisanship" where both parties engage in "free lunchism" to appeal to voters, rather than addressing the nation's fiscal challenges.

Title: Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber's Resignation Amidst Scandal

Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber's sudden resignation on Tuesday, following a tumultuous week, has left many wondering about the circumstances surrounding his decision. The governor's secretary reportedly received a call from Kitzhaber, only for him to change his mind, leading to a dramatic turn of events. By Thursday, state troopers were seen outside his door, hinting at the gravity of the situation.

According to Oregon political observers, Kitzhaber's downfall can be attributed to his hubris, which clouded his judgment in both personal and political matters. His decision to resign was seen as a necessary step to avoid further tarnishing his legacy and the state's agenda.

Kitzhaber's predicament is reminiscent of the failure of the state's healthcare exchange website under the Affordable Care Act, which was initially praised as a model for the nation. Similarly, Kitzhaber's administration was known for its bold and ambitious initiatives, but ultimately fell short.

The governor's personal life has also been under scrutiny, particularly his relationship with his fiancée, Cylvia Hayes. Hayes, 20 years his junior, has been linked to Kitzhaber since his 2002 campaign and became engaged in August. However, her private consulting work during his 2010 campaign raised eyebrows, and she failed to disclose some of her income from the state. The governor also attempted to erase his personal emails from public records, sparking further questions.

The latest developments have led to a criminal investigation by the state Attorney General and an FBI investigation, making it clear that Kitzhaber's situation has reached a critical point. Despite his re-election last year, the scandal has undermined his ability to lead the state, and few lawmakers were willing to work with him going forward.

Oregon Democratic Rep. Kurt Schneider noted that "love is blind," implying that Kitzhaber's personal life has clouded his judgment. State Sen. Elizabeth Steiner Hayward described the situation as a "Greek tragedy," worrying that it would tarnish the governor's legacy.

In the end, Kitzhaber's resignation was seen as a necessary step to protect the state's agenda and avoid further scandal. His successor, Secretary of State Kate Brown, is expected to bring stability and continuity to the office, making her a strong candidate to lead the state forward.

**Christie and Fiorina Exit 2016 Presidential Race**

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and former HP executive Carly Fiorina have suspended their presidential bids, following disappointing performances in the New Hampshire primary. Christie finished sixth, while Fiorina finished seventh.

Christie met with his staff in Morristown, New Jersey, and held a conference call to announce his decision to drop out. In a statement on Facebook, he expressed no regret, stating that he ran to emphasize the importance of government working for the people, not the other way around.

Fiorina, the only female GOP candidate in the 2016 race, also announced her decision to suspend her candidacy. She emphasized her commitment to continue fighting for American citizens and restoring citizen government.

Christie's exit marks the end of the road for two candidates who showed promise earlier in the race. He was banking on a strong performance in New Hampshire, but was outflanked by other governors in the race. Despite his tough-talking approach, his criticism of Senator Marco Rubio at the debate seemed to hurt Rubio more than help Christie.

Fiorina's campaign struggled to gain momentum, despite her standout performance in the first undercard debate. Her business experience and outsider status were touted as strengths, but her momentum stalled by the end of the year.

Both Christie and Fiorina's exits leave the crowded GOP field open for other candidates to vie for support.

Title: Senate Republicans and Democrats Disagree on Gun Control Measures

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican, expressed skepticism about Democratic efforts to pass new gun-control bills, particularly those that expand background checks. During an appearance on CNN's State of the Union, Graham stated that the current system is broken and that expanding background checks would not address the issue. He pointed out that there were 76,000 people who failed background checks last year, but less than 1% were prosecuted. Additionally, he cited an example from 2010 where 9,000 people who failed background checks were felons on the run, but none were prosecuted.

Graham also emphasized that the current system needs to be fixed before any new measures are implemented. He noted that the Sandy Hook massacre, which occurred in 2012, would not have been prevented by any of the proposed legislation. The senator stated that he would not join the five Senate Republicans who have pledged to filibuster any legislation that infringes on the Second Amendment, but would only do so if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid did not allow alternative amendments.

Meanwhile, Senate Democrats have shifted their focus to background checks since bans on semi-automatic weapons are no longer on the table. Senator Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, told NBC's "Meet the Press" that background checks are the "sweet spot" because they would do a lot of good and have a good chance of passing. Schumer is working with both Democrats and Republicans, as well as pro- and anti-National Rifle Association (NRA) groups, to come up with a background check bill that would be acceptable to 60 senators and be strong enough to get the job done. Reid is expected to bring legislation to the floor next month.

Title: Report Says Trade Deal Would Boost U.S. Economy, But Opponents Disagree

The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) has released a report stating that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would have a positive impact on the U.S. economy, increasing real GDP by nearly $43 billion annually and supporting an additional 128,000 full-time jobs by 2032. The report concludes that the deal would have a small but positive effect on the economy, with the biggest winner being agriculture and food, which would see a $10 billion boost, or a 0.5% increase.

The ITC's findings are in line with the views of the American Farm Bureau Federation, which has praised the deal as "good for America." However, not everyone agrees. Lori Wallach of Public Citizen argues that the report shows the pact could have disastrous effects, with 16 out of 25 U.S. economic sectors suffering losses.

The report also notes that the biggest loser would be manufacturing, natural resources, and energy, which would be down by a collective $10 billion, or 0.1%, after 15 years. The ITC's assessment is based on a methodology that has been criticized in the past for overstating the benefits of trade deals.

The TPP is a proposed trade deal between the United States and 11 other countries, aimed at opening markets for U.S. exporters and farmers, and protecting intellectual property. The deal is still pending congressional approval, and President Obama has strongly supported it. However, some critics argue that the deal could have negative effects on the U.S. economy and jobs.

The debate over the TPP is just one aspect of the broader discussion around trade in this year's election cycle. Republican candidate Donald Trump has called the deal "a horrible deal," while Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders has referred to trade deals as "disasters."

Title: Hillary Clinton Returns to Iowa, Fueling Speculation About 2016 Presidential Run

Hillary Clinton, a leading contender in many early presidential polls, returned to Iowa on Sunday, sparking renewed speculation about her potential 2024 presidential bid. The former Secretary of State and First Lady appeared alongside her husband, former President Bill Clinton, at the annual steak fry hosted by U.S. Senator Tom Harkin, a must-attend event for Iowa Democratic activists.

Clinton's speech at the event revealed little about her intentions, but did nothing to dampen the widespread belief that she will indeed run. The event was attended by a crowd of enthusiastic Democrats, many of whom were already sporting "Ready for Hillary" gear.

Clinton's appearance was met with cheers and chants of her name, and she poked fun at the speculation surrounding her potential candidacy. "I've got a few things on my mind these days," she teased, hinting at her ongoing consideration of a run.

While Clinton did not make any official announcements, her presence in Iowa has fueled speculation that she is serious about running. Some attendees, like Cindy Pollard, a 57-year-old precinct captain, were already convinced that Clinton will run. "I've been ready," she said, sporting a Hillary Clinton t-shirt from her 2008 presidential campaign.

Others, like Linda Dedecker, an accountant from Ames, were more cautious, saying they were considering supporting Clinton but needed to see more before making a decision. "I don't know who else is going to run," she said.

The event also drew attention to the push to get Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren into the race as a progressive alternative to Clinton. One Warren supporter emphasized the importance of not anointing Clinton as the front-runner before anyone has officially declared their candidacy.

Overall, Clinton's appearance in Iowa has kept the speculation surrounding her potential candidacy alive, with many attendees convinced that she will run and others waiting to see what she will do next.

Title: President Trump Criticizes Democrats on Immigration and Border Security

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Monday to express his frustration with the Democratic Party's handling of immigration and border security. He emphasized that Mexico has the power to stop large groups of migrants from entering the country and urged Congress to pass border legislation to address the issue.

Trump stated that Mexico's border laws are effective, allowing them to stop migrants from entering their country, whereas the United States has no effective border laws, which allows people to pass through. He also claimed that the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is "dead" because Democrats did not act on it and that building a wall and securing the borders with proper legislation is necessary.

The President's comments come after a report revealed photos of over 1,000 migrants from Central America traveling through Mexico on their way to the United States, with Mexican immigration officials not intervening to stop the flow. Trump had previously threatened that there would be "NO MORE DACA DEAL" on Sunday.

In his tweets, Trump also mentioned the need for Congress to pass border legislation and use the "Nuclear Option" if necessary to stop the massive inflow of drugs and people. He also stated that Border Patrol Agents and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) are great, but the weak Democratic laws do not allow them to do their job.

Title: Candidates Make Last-Ditch Efforts to Derail Trump's Momentum Ahead of Super Tuesday

In the lead-up to the Super Tuesday primaries, Republican presidential candidates Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and John Kasich are making a last-ditch effort to sideline each other and mount a viable challenge against front-runner Donald Trump. The candidates are calling on their opponents to drop out of the race, with Kasich's campaign even issuing a defiant call for Rubio to suspend his campaign.

According to a Quinnipiac University poll, Trump is leading Rubio by 16 points among primary voters in Florida, a state considered crucial for Rubio's campaign. Kasich's campaign is trying to capitalize on Rubio's struggles, with a tweet from Kasich's spokesman saying Rubio should withdraw from the race and support Kasich.

Rubio, who has yet to win a primary contest, is trying to position himself as the best candidate to win a general election in November and take on Trump. He acknowledged during a forum with Megyn Kelly that Trump is the frontrunner, but expressed confidence in his own campaign's ability to compete.

The candidates will face off in a CNN-Telemundo debate on Thursday night, which could be their last chance to define themselves as the anti-Trump candidate. A sweep by Trump on Super Tuesday would be devastating for the remaining candidates, as Texas, Georgia, and other delegate-heavy states hold contests.

Texas Sen. Cruz argued that he is the best alternative candidate, citing his own win in the Iowa caucuses. However, Trump has argued that if other candidates drop out, their support will not necessarily gravitate to the other non-Trump candidates, and he will pick up some of that support as well.

The pressure is mounting on candidates Kasich and Ben Carson, whose campaigns have performed poorly in the first four contests. Carson has appeared immune to the pressure, declaring "things are starting to happen" after a poor showing in Nevada. Kasich, on the other hand, is refusing to give up, saying he is not listening to "lobbyist insiders" who are calling for him to drop out.

Title: Longtime Washington Representative Dan Heck Announces Retirement from Congress

Article:
