Representative Dan Heck (D-Wash.) has announced his decision to retire from Congress, citing his weariness from the process of compiling the intelligence committee's recent impeachment report. In a statement, Heck expressed his disappointment and frustration with his colleagues' handling of the report, stating that he will "never understand how some of my colleagues, in many ways good people, could ignore or deny the president's unrelenting attack on a free press, his vicious character assassination of anyone who disagreed with him, and his demonstrably very distant relationship with the truth."

Heck, who has served in Congress since 2013, has led recruitment efforts for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and has personally drafted many newly elected Democratic freshman members. He has also run unsuccessfully for chairman of the committee.

Washington's 10th District, which Heck represents, is considered Democratic-leaning territory. He won reelection last year with 62% of the vote, and Hillary Clinton carried the district by an 11-point margin in 2016.

With Heck's retirement, a crowded field of candidates is likely to emerge to succeed him. Under Washington's top-two primary system, all candidates will run together on the same ballot in the August 4 primary, with the top two finishers advancing to a head-to-head general election. Possible Democratic candidates for the seat include Olympia Mayor Cheryl Selby, Phil Gardner, Heck's district director, and state Representatives Beth Doglio, Christine Kilduff, and Mari Leavitt. Heck already had a Democratic challenger next year, truck driver Joshua Collins.

Title: Pope Francis' Visit to the United States: A Week of Controversy and Expectations

Article:

Pope Francis' visit to the United States has sparked a mix of excitement and controversy, with various groups and individuals having different expectations and concerns. The Pope's trip began in Cuba, where he was greeted by Fidel Castro and his brother Raul, who praised the Pope's criticism of capitalism and his efforts to promote social justice. The Pope also met with President Obama, who is seeking to use the Pope's visit to promote his own agenda and legacy.

In Washington, the Pope is expected to address a joint session of Congress, where he will likely face criticism from some lawmakers who disagree with his views on social issues such as abortion and same-sex marriage. The Pope will also meet with President Obama at the White House, where he will be joined by a diverse group of guests, including gay and lesbian advocates, abortion rights supporters, and others.

Some Catholic bishops have expressed concerns about the Pope's visit, citing the potential for controversy and the need for the Pope to address issues such as religious liberty and the threat of government-mandated abortion coverage. Others have welcomed the Pope's visit, seeing it as an opportunity to promote dialogue and understanding between different faiths and cultures.

The Pope's visit to Philadelphia will be a highlight of his trip, where he will give a speech at Independence National Historical Park. The speech is expected to be a major opportunity for the Pope to address the concerns of his critics and promote his message of social justice and compassion.

Overall, Pope Francis' visit to the United States is a complex and multifaceted event, with different groups and individuals having different expectations and concerns. As the Pope navigates the complexities of American politics and culture, he will be seeking to promote his message of social justice and compassion, while also addressing the concerns of his critics and promoting dialogue and understanding between different faiths and cultures.

Title: Debate Rages Over Iran Nuclear Deal: Can a "Better Deal" Be Negotiated?

The debate over the Iran nuclear deal is intensifying, with some lawmakers and experts calling for a "better deal" and others warning that rejecting the current agreement could lead to a ramped-up uranium enrichment program. The controversy stems from the perception of Iran and its nuclear program, with some viewing it as a country that should not be entangled with the United States, while others believe it is possible to negotiate a better deal.

Critics of the deal argue that there is historical precedent for renegotiating and amending international agreements, citing nearly 80 multilateral agreements that Congress has either rejected or required amendments. They believe that Iran is intent on getting a deal with the US and could be brought back to the negotiating table after the shock of a congressional rejection.

However, senior administration officials involved in the Iran negotiations say there is no chance the deal could be renegotiated and warn that rejection would likely result in a ramped-up uranium enrichment program. They argue that the deal already blocks Iran's paths to a nuclear weapon and that any further demands for a "better deal" are unrealistic.

Some nonproliferation experts share this view, saying that the Iranian nuclear program was already too advanced years ago to reduce it any more than what the deal reached in July 2015. Others are less certain that the deal blocks Iran's paths to a nuclear weapon, but believe a renegotiated deal could be possible.

The debate has sparked concerns about the potential consequences of rejecting the deal, with some experts warning that it could create distance between the US and the world and diminish the distance between Iran and the world. Others believe that the "better deal" advocates are not genuinely seeking a stronger deal, but rather want to thwart any US agreement with the Iranian government.

The debate is likely to continue as Congress prepares to vote on the deal in September, with proponents and opponents of the agreement presenting their cases to lawmakers.

Title: Study Reveals Higher Lead Exposure in Children Relying on Private Wells

A recent study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences has found that American children whose homes rely on private wells for drinking water are 25 percent more likely to have high lead levels in their blood compared to those with access to regulated community water services. The research, which analyzed data from almost 60,000 children in North Carolina, found that those relying on private wells had blood lead concentrations that were 20 percent higher, on average, than children with community water service.

The study also found that children living in older, lower-value houses and those in majority-Black neighborhoods were more likely to have higher lead levels and a higher risk of elevated blood lead. The researchers attributed this increased exposure to the corrosion of indoor plumbing and well components, which is more common in private wells.

The study's author, Jackie MacDonald Gibson, chair of the department of environmental and occupational health at the Indian University school of public health, emphasized that there is no safe lead level and that childhood exposure has been linked to reduced IQ, ADHD, school failure, and criminality. Gibson also noted that private wells are excluded from the Safe Drinking Water Act, which requires community water utilities to monitor lead levels, but households with private wells must monitor their own water quality and replace parts and install corrosion-control systems, which is often not done due to lack of awareness, knowledge, and financial resources.

The study highlights the need for an overhaul of the Safe Drinking Water Act to provide support for households relying on private wells, including financial support, education, and support on proper testing. The study's findings underscore the importance of addressing lead exposure in private wells, which affects not only the health of children but also perpetuates intergenerational poverty and social inequality.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Recalls Attorney General Jeff Sessions' Enthusiasm for Trump-Putin Summit

George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser, has made new claims about the 2016 presidential campaign. In a recent interview on ABC's "This Week," Papadopoulos stated that Attorney General Jeff Sessions was "quite enthusiastic" about the prospect of a summit between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Papadopoulos claimed that during a 2016 roundtable meeting, he told the group that he had a connection who could establish a summit between the two leaders. According to Papadopoulos, President Trump nodded at him but didn't seem committed, while Sessions showed enthusiasm.

However, Sessions has testified that he pushed back on the idea. Papadopoulos was sentenced to two weeks in prison on Friday for lying to investigators probing Russian interference in the 2016 election. He pleaded guilty in October 2017 to lying to federal investigators about his contacts with Joseph Mifsud, a London-based professor who supposedly told him in 2016 that Russia had damaging information on Hillary Clinton, Trump's Democratic opponent.

Papadopoulos also denied sending an email about possible dirt on Clinton to John Mashburn, a Trump campaign and White House official who has reportedly testified to congressional investigators that he thought he got such an alert from Papadopoulos. Papadopoulos stated that if he did send the email, evidence would have been introduced by now, and if it was sent, there would be a copy somewhere else.

Regarding the special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, Papadopoulos said he has no idea if there was actual collusion between Russian officials and the Trump campaign. He stated that his testimony might have helped move something towards that, but he has no idea. Trump himself has repeatedly denied any collusion.

Title: Presidential Campaigns Adjust to COVID-19 Pandemic, Cancel Large Events and Shift to Virtual Operations

The COVID-19 pandemic has forced presidential campaigns to adapt to the new reality, with both the Trump and Biden campaigns canceling large events and shifting to virtual operations. The Trump campaign has been eager to get its Las Vegas fundraiser with casino mogul Sheldon Adelson on the books, but it has been scrapped, along with the first lady Melania Trump's solo fundraiser in Los Angeles. The Biden campaign has also canceled its upcoming fundraisers, including two in Chicago, and will hold its events online indefinitely.

The Trump campaign has given its employees the option to work from home, while the Biden campaign has taken a more drastic measure, instructing its staff to work from home starting this weekend. The Sanders campaign has also announced that all staff will work from home.

Field organizing has become more complicated due to the pandemic, with the Republican National Committee (RNC) initially planning a National Week of Training next week, which will now be held online and over the phone. The Trump campaign is relying on its digital infrastructure and database of contact information to reach key voters online.

The Biden campaign has taken dramatic steps, closing all field offices to the public and organizing voters across the country through phone banking, text messaging, virtual events, and other distributed organizing models. The Sanders campaign has also halted door-to-door canvassing and will instead use digital formats and outreach wherever possible.

While Trump campaign officials are concerned about the impact of the president's response to the pandemic on his reelection hopes, they remain optimistic. The Biden campaign, on the other hand, is using the crisis as an opportunity to cast itself as a steady leader who will return the country to normalcy after a turbulent Trump presidency.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Foreign Policy: A New Era of Confrontation and Uncertainty

The Trump administration has taken a bold and unconventional approach to foreign policy, departing from the traditional methods of his predecessors. In his first year in office, President Donald Trump often relied on the advice of his national security aides, adding troops to the war in Afghanistan, delaying plans to move the U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, and preserving a nuclear-containment deal with Iran. However, Trump has now come to trust his own instincts and is pushing the boundaries of traditional foreign policy and national-security decision-making.

Trump's latest move was to withdraw from the 2015 agreement that curbed Iran's nuclear program, despite warnings from European allies and international experts. This decision has sparked concerns about the potential risks of a more confrontational approach, with some critics arguing that it may lead to chaos and instability in the Middle East.

Trump's allies, however, believe that his approach is already paying dividends, particularly in his dealings with North Korea. The president's aggressive rhetoric and threats have reportedly rattled North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, leading to a potential breakthrough in negotiations. Trump's supporters argue that his approach sends a clear signal that the United States will not accept inadequate deals and will use maximum pressure to get a better outcome.

The Trump administration's revamped national security team is intent on harnessing the president's style and using it to implement his campaign promises. However, the administration faces an uphill battle in persuading European allies to work with the U.S. after dismissing its attempts to save the deal with Iran. European leaders have distanced themselves from the U.S. decision, vowing to work with Iran to salvage the agreement.

Trump's approach has also raised concerns about the potential risks of a broader regional conflict, particularly with Iran's two biggest rivals, Israel and Saudi Arabia. Some analysts believe that the U.S. withdrawal from the Iran deal may increase the likelihood of clashes in the Middle East.

While Trump's approach may be unconventional, it is reminiscent of President Ronald Reagan's strategy for confronting the Soviet Union in the 1980s. Reagan belittled Moscow as the "Evil Empire" and was once caught on microphone joking about bombing the Soviet Union in five minutes. However, Reagan eventually negotiated a historic and unexpected agreement to reduce the number of nuclear weapons built by the U.S. and Soviet Union.

In conclusion, Trump's approach to foreign policy is a departure from the traditional methods of his predecessors, and its consequences are still uncertain. While some believe that his approach may lead to chaos and instability, others argue that it may be a necessary step towards achieving a better outcome. Only time will tell if Trump's unconventional approach will yield the desired results.

Title: Trump Administration and Republicans to Propose Corporate Tax Rate Cuts, Leaving Individual Rates Unchanged

Article:

The Trump administration and top Republicans in Congress are set to unveil a plan to cut the corporate tax rate, with the goal of reducing the current rate of 35% to a range of 18-23%. The proposal is expected to be released on Wednesday and is part of the administration's efforts to overhaul the tax code, a key campaign promise made by President Donald Trump.

The "Big Six" team, comprising top Trump aides and congressional Republican leaders, is expected to refrain from cutting the top individual tax rate of 39.6%, a move that may be difficult for some Republicans in the House of Representatives to accept. The plan is also expected to include measures to bring back an estimated $2.6 trillion in U.S. corporate profits held overseas, with companies required to pay rates of 3.5% for reinvested profits and 8.75% for on cash and equivalents.

The proposal is expected to generate controversy, with some critics arguing that it favors the wealthy and big corporations at the expense of middle-class taxpayers. Senator Ron Wyden, the top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, has already expressed concerns that the plan would benefit the "most fortunate and biggest corporations."

The Big Six team is still undecided on several key issues, including whether to allow businesses to write off new investments immediately, how to lower tax rates for small businesses, and whether to cut middle-class taxes by doubling the standard deduction for individuals and families. Lobbyists say that resolving these issues will determine how aggressively Republicans can cut corporate taxes.

The plan is also expected to avoid eliminating tax loopholes and deductions, which could help pay for the tax cuts. Instead, the administration plans to forecast a flood of new tax revenue in coming years, based on aggressive assumptions of tax-fueled economic expansion. However, Senate Republicans have shown signs of moving away from "dynamic" scoring of tax legislation, which could mean that the plan would balloon the federal budget deficit.

The proposal is expected to be met with skepticism from some Republicans, who may be concerned about the impact on the federal budget and the potential for increased deficits. However, the Trump administration and Republicans are pushing forward with the plan, which they believe will boost economic growth and create jobs.

Title: Trump's Military Appointments: A Historical Precedent or a Cause for Concern?

The appointment of retired military personnel to high-ranking positions in the Trump administration has sparked controversy, with some critics labeling it as a "militarization" of the government. However, this phenomenon is not unprecedented. In fact, it has been a common practice in the past, with both Republican and Democratic administrations appointing retired generals and admirals to key roles.

President-elect Donald Trump has nominated retired lieutenant general Michael Flynn as national security adviser, retired Marine general James Mattis as defense secretary, and retired Marine general John Kelly as secretary of homeland security. These appointments have been met with criticism, with some arguing that they will lead to a greater likelihood of war. However, historical evidence suggests otherwise.

In the past, retired generals and admirals have been appointed to high-ranking positions, including under the Obama administration. General David Petraeus was appointed CIA director, while General James Jones served as national security adviser. Retired generals and admirals have also been appointed to cabinet positions, such as General Eric Shinseki as head of the Department of Veterans Affairs and Admiral Dennis Blair as director of national intelligence.

The criticism of Trump's appointments is not new, as it has been a common practice in the past. In the 20th century, many retired generals and admirals went on to serve in the executive branch, including General George Marshall, who was appointed secretary of state and later secretary of defense. General Omar Bradley was head of the Veterans Administration while still on active duty.

The concern about Trump's appointments is that they will lead to a greater likelihood of war. However, historical evidence suggests that retired generals and admirals are not the ones who advocate for military intervention. In fact, they are often more cautious and prefer to avoid sending troops into harm's way.

In contrast, lawyers and politicians with no outside-the-Beltway experience have been appointed to key roles, with mixed results. The Obama administration, for example, appointed former senator and lawyer Joe Biden as vice president, former senator and lawyer Hillary Clinton as secretary of state, and later, former senator and lawyer John Kerry as secretary of state. While these appointments may have had their benefits, they have not necessarily led to success.

The current state of affairs, with the collapse of several Middle Eastern nations, the failed reset with Russia, and the Iran deal, is not exactly evidence of success at the State Department. The national debt is nearing $20 trillion, economic growth is stagnant, and labor participation rates are at record lows. These issues are not the result of generals' appointments, but rather the result of lawyers and politicians with no outside-the-Beltway experience.

In conclusion, the appointment of retired military personnel to high-ranking positions is not unprecedented and has been a common practice in the past. While some may argue that it will lead to a greater likelihood of war, historical evidence suggests otherwise. It is worth noting that lawyers and politicians with no outside-the-Beltway experience have not necessarily led to success, and it may be time to consider alternative approaches.

Title: Democratic Majority for Israel PAC Purchases Ads in Nevada, Criticizing Bernie Sanders' Electability and Health

The Democratic Majority for Israel PAC (DMFI) has purchased tens of thousands of dollars in cable and network ad time in Nevada, ahead of the February 22 presidential nominating caucuses. According to Federal Communications Commission (FCC) filings, the ads are scheduled to run for a week, starting on Saturday. The total size of the buy is over $175,000, although the exact amount is not yet publicly disclosed.

The ads are a continuation of DMFI's efforts to question Bernie Sanders' electability and health. The group ran similar ads in the run-up to the Iowa caucuses, which questioned Sanders' ability to prevail in a general election contest and raised concerns about his health. The new ads in Nevada will be different from the ones that ran in Iowa, according to Mark Mellman, a Democratic consultant who runs DMFI PAC.

The group's funding comes primarily from a handful of high-dollar donors, including Stacy Schusterman, a Tulsa oil and gas heiress, who gave DMFI PAC nearly $1 million in December, and Mark Gary Lauder, a venture capitalist, who contributed $495,000.

DMFI's latest broadside against Sanders comes as he tries to gain momentum in the race for Democratic delegates in the party's third presidential nominating contest. Despite strong showings in Iowa and New Hampshire, Sanders trails former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg by a pair of delegates.

Title: US Appeals Court Orders Judge to Respond to Flynn's Request to Dismiss Charges

The US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has instructed Judge Emmet Sullivan to respond to a petition filed by Michael Flynn's lawyers, seeking to force Sullivan to grant the Justice Department's request to dismiss the charges against the former national security adviser. The department, in a major reversal, asked Sullivan to drop the charges on May 7, which drew accusations from Democrats and retired career prosecutors that Attorney General William Barr was politicizing the US criminal justice system.

Flynn, a retired Army lieutenant general who also advised Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, pleaded guilty in 2017 to lying to the FBI about his conversations with Russia's US ambassador Sergey Kislyak in the weeks before Trump took office. Flynn was charged as part of former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 US election to boost Trump's candidacy.

Flynn later sought to withdraw his plea and accused the FBI of tricking him. The department's decision to ask Sullivan to drop the charges followed public pressure from Trump and the Republican president's political allies. Sullivan last week signaled reluctance to drop the charges, appointing a retired judge to advise whether Flynn should face an additional criminal contempt charge for perjury. The judge has scheduled an in-person court hearing in the case for July 16.

Flynn served as national security adviser in the first weeks of Trump's presidency before being fired for misleading Vice President Mike Pence about his dealings with Kislyak.

Title: The Conventional Wisdom on Syria is Wrong: Letting Assad Win Could Have Prevented the Chaos

The recent terrorist attacks in Orlando, Istanbul, Dhaka, Baghdad, Medina, and Nice have been linked to the ongoing conflict in Syria. Many believe that if the United States had intervened more aggressively in the Syrian civil war, the Islamic State (ISIL) might not have gained a foothold. However, this conventional wisdom is incorrect. Providing lethal aid to the opposition would have likely accelerated the war, rather than slowing it down.

The Syrian civil war began with a weak moderate opposition, which was no match for the well-trained Syrian army backed by Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah. The U.S. could have provided weaponry, but most intended recipients would have had little training or combat experience, and the weapons would have likely changed hands. The opposition was also disorganized and lacked coherent leadership, with no clear leader or unified command.

Assad and his allies had a clear objective: to keep him in power. In contrast, the U.S. found itself in a difficult position, unwilling to back either side and without a plausible alternative. The administration believed it could keep its hands clean by not intervening militarily, but the body count continued to rise.

The U.S. chose a third way, imposing sanctions on the Syrian government, freezing Syrian assets, and blocking commercial ties with Damascus. The U.S. also helped establish supply routes and funneled money, intelligence, and non-lethal aid to handpicked rebels, many of whom would later change sides. However, the U.S. did little to prevent states like Qatar and Saudi Arabia from sending vast sums of materiel and money to Assad's opposition, including its most extreme elements.

The main problem with U.S. policy toward Syria is not that the administration did too little early in the conflict, but that it did too much. If the U.S. and its partners had not intervened, Assad would have stamped out the civil war before it began, and the death toll would be lower, Syria would be more stable, and ISIL might never have taken its current form.

Seth Cantey, an assistant professor of politics at Washington & Lee University, argues that the U.S. should have let Assad win, as this would have prevented the chaos and instability that has engulfed the region.

Title: North Dakota Senator Heidi Heitkamp and Challenger Rep. Kevin Cramer Debate Ahead of Midterm Elections

In the final debate before the November midterm elections, North Dakota Senator Heidi Heitkamp and her Republican challenger, Rep. Kevin Cramer, discussed various issues, including the need for civility in American politics. The debate comes after the arrest of a Florida resident, Cesar Sayoc, who was charged with sending dangerous packages to CNN and Democratic leaders who have criticized President Trump.

Both Heitkamp and Cramer agreed that no one is to blame for Sayoc's actions except for him. Heitkamp referenced the example of Rep. Steve Scalise, who was shot and wounded by a left-wing partisan last year, saying that the message is clear: everyone should take responsibility for their words.

Cramer emphasized the importance of debates as an opportunity to celebrate political civility, citing North Dakota as an example. The two candidates have been in a fierce race, with Heitkamp facing a tough battle to hold onto her seat in the U.S. Senate in a state where Trump won by 36 points.

Despite the challenges, Heitkamp's campaign has received over $12 million in donations in the first two weeks of October, mostly from individual donors. Former Vice President Joe Biden is set to campaign for Heitkamp, kicking off her statewide tour in Fargo next week.

On policy issues, both candidates agreed on the need for a border wall and increased security to deter illegal immigrants from entering the country. They also shared similar views on the Paris Climate Accord, disagreeing with Trump's decision to pull out of the agreement.

However, they sparred over the Affordable Care Act, with Cramer advocating for giving money to states to provide better health care options, while Heitkamp suggested fixing areas of the law that aren't working.

Title: Labor Leader Warns of Political Consequences for Hillary Clinton Over Pacific Trade Pact

The president of the AFL-CIO, Richard Trumka, has vowed to defeat President Obama's key trade legislation in the House next month, warning Hillary Clinton of serious political consequences if she fails to take a stand against the Pacific trade pact. The "fast-track" bill, which would grant the president authority to negotiate trade agreements without congressional input, passed the Senate on Friday with 13 Democratic votes.

Trumka expressed disappointment and frustration with the Senate vote, stating that "thirteen Democrats left their base" by supporting the bill. He believes that the legislation will cost jobs and lower wages, and that Democrats will be held accountable for their decision.

The AFL-CIO has been actively lobbying against the legislation, which would require Congress to approve or reject the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) without amendments. Many labor unions have frozen campaign donations as they work to defeat the bill.

Trumka also expressed concerns about Hillary Clinton's stance on the issue, stating that she will need to take a clear position on the TPP if she wants to win the support of working-class voters. He noted that if Clinton backs the trade pact and the fast-track authority, it will be "tougher to mobilize working people" and could affect her chances of getting elected.

The labor leader also expressed disappointment with President Obama's record on labor issues, stating that he has been "seriously handicapped" in his ability to deliver for working Americans due to opposition from the Republican Party. However, Trumka acknowledged that Obama has fought hard for fast-track and TPP, and wished he had fought harder for other labor-friendly initiatives.

The battle between the AFL-CIO and the Obama administration highlights the complicated politics of the president's attempts to pass legislation through a Republican-controlled Congress during his final two years in office. It also raises questions about Hillary Clinton's stance on the TPP and her ability to win the support of working-class voters in the upcoming presidential election.

Title: Trump Announces Executive Order to Suspend Immigration Amid Pandemic

The United States President, Donald Trump, has announced an executive order to temporarily suspend immigration to the country in response to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The order, which will be in effect for 60 days, will stop the issuance of permanent residency visas, commonly known as green cards, but will not affect temporary workers. There are reportedly exceptions for workers in "essential" professions and family members of U.S. citizens.

According to Trump, the decision was made to "protect the jobs" of Americans amid an unprecedented spike in unemployment caused by lockdown measures aimed at limiting the spread of the virus. Immigration has already been curbed significantly during the outbreak due to travel restrictions and a pause in most visa processing procedures.

The move has sparked debate among economists and politicians, with some arguing that limiting immigration will have little to no impact on the economy's recovery. Others see the order as a political tactic to distract from the administration's response to the virus and to fulfill a key element of Trump's 2016 election platform.

The order's details are still unclear, with Trump stating that the initial 60-day freeze could be extended indefinitely depending on economic conditions. The administration is also considering a "secondary order" that could further limit immigration in the future.

The move has been met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. Some argue that the order is a sincere attempt to protect American jobs, while others see it as a political ploy to impose an anti-immigrant agenda. The pandemic has provided an opportunity for Trump to enact his wish list of immigration policies, according to some critics.

The debate surrounding the order highlights the complexities of the issue and the challenges of balancing economic and social concerns during a global health crisis.

Title: Israel's Election Results Remain Uncertain as Netanyahu's Likud and Gantz's Blue and White Party Are Neck-and-Neck

Israel's election results are still unclear, with initial vote counting showing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party and Benny Gantz's Blue and White party tied, according to Israel's Kan public broadcaster. Three surveys suggest that Netanyahu's Likud did not secure enough seats to form a right-wing majority government coalition without the support of Blue and White or Avigdor Liberman's Yisrael Beytenu party.

An exit poll on Channel 12 reported that Likud and Blue and White are tied with 32 seats each. Official results are not expected to be announced until Wednesday afternoon local time.

Both Netanyahu and Gantz have been cautious not to declare victory, with Netanyahu stating that the election is "very close" and Gantz urging Israelis to end his long reign as prime minister. The election is seen as a referendum on Netanyahu, who has served as Israel's longest-running prime minister.

The election is unprecedented, with Israel holding elections twice in the same year. Netanyahu's Likud party won the election in April, but his inability to form a government coalition sent millions of Israelis back to the polls on Tuesday.

The election was marked by drama, with at least 29 arrests and 69 investigations launched against individuals suspected of voting fraud and other violations. Israeli media reported that the Blue and White website was shut down due to a cyberattack hours before polls closed, with over 500 attempted breaches detected from various servers abroad.

Both parties are waiting for the final vote to be counted, with official results expected in the next week. Forming a government can take another month or more after that. If no government is formed, Israelis will go to a third round of elections. For now, Israelis are waiting to see if a government is formed and what it will look like.

**Beijing Secures Bid to Host 2022 Winter Olympics**

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has awarded Beijing the 2022 Winter Games, making it the first city to host both the summer and winter competitions. The decision was announced on Friday, with Beijing beating out Almaty, Kazakhstan, in a close vote. The 44-40 decision marks a significant milestone for Beijing, which will host the games in partnership with Zhangjiakou, a nearby city.

The celebration was brief, with many Chinese citizens expressing a sense of déjà vu, having hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics. The city's residents are less enthusiastic about the winter games, with some citing the high cost and lack of interest in winter sports. According to a historian at Hong Kong University, Chinese citizens are becoming less nationalistic and are more focused on enjoying the games as a leisure activity.

Beijing's bid to host the 2022 Winter Olympics is seen as a way to create development opportunities and bring the games to the large Chinese market. The city's disposable income has nearly doubled since 2008, and the ski resorts outside Zhangjiakou are now packed on winter weekends with Beijing residents who are eager to enjoy the sports.

The Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics will feature 12 venues, half of which will be recycled from the 2008 Summer Games. The combined operating and capital budget for the games is projected to be $3.9 billion, with a focus on reusing and converting existing venues. The games are expected to bring significant investment to the surrounding areas, with a projected $56.4 billion in investment, mostly for Zhangjiakou and the surrounding rural areas.

Overall, Beijing's bid to host the 2022 Winter Olympics is seen as a way to create development opportunities and bring the games to the large Chinese market, with a focus on addressing the needs of the emerging middle class.

Title: Trump's Presidential Victory Marks Shift in American Politics

The outcome of the presidential election has resulted in a significant shift in American politics, with billionaire developer Donald Trump securing an unexpected victory. Trump's win is a repudiation of Washington and the pundit class, which had predicted a tight but clear victory for Hillary Clinton. The result is a unified Republican control of the House and Senate, with Trump's presidency holding the prospect of a sharp swerve in the nation's direction on core issues such as foreign policy, trade, immigration, healthcare, and the environment.

The election saw a surge in Republican support, particularly among white voters without college degrees, who turned out in large numbers to support Trump. This shift in voter demographics has mixed up the nation's long-standing order of electoral swing states, with Trump taking Florida, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania.

Trump's victory is a reflection of voter discontent and Republican loyalty to their party's nominee, despite ambivalence about Trump expressed by GOP leaders. The result will be at least four years of a Washington unified under the direction of one party.

Trump's supporters, such as trucking company manager Al Fortune, expect him to promote job creation, conservative healthcare reform, and energy independence from the Middle East. Exit polls showed Trump won 80% or more of voters who rated "change" as their top priority.

Now, it will be up to Trump to deliver on his voters' expectations, with many expecting him to move decisively. Trump's victory is likely to set off a battle of bitter recriminations among Democrats, with the liberal faction pushing for radical change in the party agenda.

Trump's presidency also represents a major change in GOP identity, focusing unabashedly on white Americans and rejecting mainstream Republican principles such as free trade. While this approach may have won him the White House in 2016, the changing face of the US, with a fast-growing Hispanic population and a declining percentage of whites, may challenge this approach in coming years.

Title: Chicago's Homicide Rate Remains High Despite Strict Gun Laws

Chicago's Easter weekend saw a surge in violence, with 40 people shot, nine fatally, sparking renewed calls for stricter gun control measures. However, some argue that the city's declining homicide rate could be attributed to the gradual relaxation of its gun laws. In 2013, the city saw 415 homicides, an 18% decrease from the previous year.

The city's strict gun laws, which were deemed unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in 2010, were lifted in February, allowing Illinois residents to carry concealed weapons. The Illinois legislature still maintains some restrictions, including a ban on gun sales, but some argue that these measures are ineffective.

In contrast, Georgia has taken a different approach. The state has been reviewing its gun laws, aiming to strike down archaic restrictions. Starting July 1, law-abiding residents will be allowed to carry guns into taverns, churches, and government buildings under certain circumstances. Georgia Governor Nathan Deal, a Republican, emphasized that the new law respects private property owners' rights to set rules for their land and buildings.

Opponents of the expanded gun rights predict that the new law will lead to increased violence, but this has not been the case in other states that have relaxed their gun laws. Virginia, for example, lifted its ban on guns in bars four years ago, and violent crime at drinking establishments dropped 5%. In Fairfax County, Virginia, there were only eight homicides last year, while Alexandria and Arlington County reported five and zero homicides, respectively.

The District of Columbia, with its strict gun restrictions, saw 103 homicides last year. Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel has called for stricter gun control measures, but some argue that the city's declining homicide rate could be attributed to the gradual relaxation of its gun laws.

Title: Government Shutdown Looms as Congress Fails to Reach Agreement

The federal government is on the brink of shutting down at midnight, with no clear solution in sight. The House-passed bill is expected to fail, and both Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer are not discussing a plan B. The likelihood of a government shutdown is high, with some experts predicting it could be the first since 2013.

The main sticking point is the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which shelters undocumented children of immigrants from deportation. Democrats are united in their demand to address DACA in any legislation, while Republicans, led by President Donald Trump, refuse to couple it with a bill to avoid the shutdown.

The Senate and House will start from scratch after the House bill fails, making it challenging to pass a new package before the deadline. Democrats are not in the mood for compromise, citing their leverage and the potential to win the blame game. Republicans, on the other hand, are under pressure to show they can govern effectively, given their control of the House, Senate, and White House.

The unpredictability of Trump's stance on the issue adds to the complexity of finding a solution. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that the focus will now shift from finding a solution to preparing for the political fallout from a shutdown.

The White House's decision to hold a press briefing, featuring Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, suggests it is positioning for a likely shutdown. With no clear solution in sight and no interest in finding one, the momentum is on the side of a shutdown.

Title: Lawmakers and Aides Worry About Health Insurance Premiums Under Obamacare

Lawmakers and aides on Capitol Hill are concerned about the potential impact of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) on their health insurance premiums. A provision in the law, known as the Grassley Amendment, will require lawmakers and aides to purchase health insurance through the government exchanges, which could lead to a significant increase in costs. This has sparked fears that some may choose to retire or leave their positions early to maintain their current health insurance coverage.

According to sources, several aides have already given notice that they will be leaving their positions due to concerns about Obamacare. Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike are discussing the issue, with some expressing concerns about the potential brain drain on Capitol Hill. Rep. John Larson, a Connecticut Democrat, believes the problem will be resolved, while Rep. Pete Sessions, a Texas Republican, says lawmakers are having "quiet conversations" about the threat.

Alabama Rep. Jo Bonner noted that the threat is already real, especially for veteran lawmakers and staff. If they leave this year, they can continue to be covered under the current health care plan, but if they stay, they will be forced to navigate the government exchanges, which could lead to exorbitant costs.

Lawmakers and aides on both sides of the aisle are aware of the problems with the provision, and Speaker John Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have discussed potential fixes. However, Boehner believes Reid must take the lead on crafting a solution, as Republicans opposed the bill and do not feel responsible for making changes.

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law in 2010, contained the Grassley Amendment, which states that the government can only offer members of Congress and their staff plans that are "created" in the bill or "offered through an exchange" unless the bill is amended. Currently, aides and lawmakers receive their health care under the generous Federal Employee Health Benefits Program, with the government subsidizing upward of 75% of the premiums. In 2014, most Capitol Hill aides and lawmakers are expected to be put onto the exchanges, and there has been no guidance on whether the government will subsidize those premiums, which could lead to a steep spike in health insurance costs.

Title: Conservative Group Targets McConnell with Ads Over Fiscal Cliff Deal

A conservative advocacy group, ForAmerica, has launched a series of online ads in Kentucky, targeting Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell for his role in negotiating the fiscal cliff deal. The ads, which feature McConnell's image alongside those of Vice President Joe Biden and President Barack Obama, ask the question "Whose side are you on?" The ads are part of a five-figure ad buy and will run on Google display ads, Facebook, The Daily Caller, and Drudge Report.

The ads are a response to McConnell's involvement in the fiscal cliff negotiations, which resulted in a deal that included tax increases. ForAmerica President Brent Bozell has been vocal in his opposition to the deal and is holding McConnell accountable for signing off on it.

Bozell stated that the ads are meant to make it clear that McConnell's actions were "100 percent unacceptable" and that conservatives will hold him responsible. He also expressed skepticism about McConnell's recent statements that the talk of tax increases is over, saying that Republicans cannot be trusted to stand by their promises.

McConnell is up for reelection in 2014 and is facing a potential conservative primary challenge. The ad buy is seen as a way for ForAmerica to put pressure on McConnell and other Republicans who supported the fiscal cliff deal.

Title: Pennsylvania Voters Declare Hillary Clinton Winner of First Presidential Debate, but Remain Pessimistic About Choices

Article:

A recent focus group conducted by Republican pollster Frank Luntz in Philadelphia brought together 27 undecided voters from Pennsylvania to watch the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. The group, which was paid to participate, declared Clinton the winner, but their reactions were marked by deep pessimism about their choices in November.

The voters described Clinton as a "liar," "corrupt," "secretive," and "self-centered," while labeling Trump as "scary," "fake," an "egomaniac," and a "shape-shifter." When asked to react to their performances, the voters described Trump's as "strong start, weak finish," "bombastic," "sloppy," and "verbose," while Clinton's was characterized as "firm," "powerful," "strong," and "informed."

Trump struggled to defend himself against attacks from Clinton over his denigration of women, insensitivity on race relations, and an assertion that he avoided paying federal taxes for years. The Republican nominee repeatedly interrupted Clinton and drew sardonic laughs from both the audience in New York and the voters in Pennsylvania when he claimed to have a "winning temperament."

The voters' reactions were tracked on a monitor throughout the debate, and even those leaning towards Trump disapproved of his windy response when Clinton ticked off possible reasons Trump may not want to disclose his tax returns. The monitor showed a significant drop in support for Trump as the debate progressed.

Clinton wove the so-called birtherism issue into a larger narrative, accusing Trump of having "a long record of engaging in racist behavior." Many of the voters in the room agreed with her, especially among those already leaning towards her. After the debate, the voters rated Clinton's response on issues of race higher than Trump's, and several people flatly labeled the Republican nominee a racist.

The group included women and men who were reluctant to support either candidate, including a lifelong conservative voter who would rather sit out than vote for Trump, a millennial who supported Bernie Sanders in the primary but has been persuaded by Clinton, and a middle school teacher who says Trump "lost" her when he began denigrating Muslims.

Despite the outcome, some voters left the debate impossibly conflicted and even more pessimistic than when they arrived. One attorney from Philadelphia said Trump's criticism of Clinton steered her away from the Democrat but not in his direction. She expressed frustration with the lack of viable options and considered voting for Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson.

Title: Study Finds Facebook's Fact-Checking Efforts May Have Unintended Consequences

A recent study conducted by researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) has found that Facebook's efforts to combat fake news may have had an unintended consequence: people assume that unmarked articles are accurate. The study, which involved over 6,000 participants, showed that people are more likely to believe unmarked false news stories than marked ones.

The study's authors, led by David Rand, a professor at the MIT Sloan School of Management, found that the use of "false" tags to flag inaccurate content did significantly reduce participants' willingness to share fake stories. However, the study also found that unmarked false stories were believed to be true and shared 36.2% of the time.

The researchers attribute this phenomenon to the "implied truth effect," where people assume that if some articles have warnings, those that don't must be accurate. This assumption can lead to a false sense of security, as people may believe that unmarked articles have been fact-checked and verified.

The study's findings suggest that Facebook's efforts to combat fake news may not be as effective as intended. The platform's sheer scale and the amount of content posted on it make it difficult for fact-checkers to keep up with the stream of misinformation. As a result, even if the warnings do reduce belief in the tagged stories, the problem of misinformation remains.

The study's authors propose a potential solution to this problem: employing more fact-checkers and recruiting ordinary Facebook users to help verify content. Facebook is already considering this approach, having announced plans to hire part-time "community reviewers" to help corroborate or debunk content flagged by its automated systems.

The study's findings highlight the complexity of the issue of fake news and the need for a more comprehensive approach to addressing it. While Facebook's efforts to combat misinformation are well-intentioned, they may not be enough to solve the problem.

Title: Trump Considers Three Republican Politicians for Vice-Presidential Pick

Article:

Donald Trump has named three Republican politicians as potential candidates for his vice-presidential pick at the party's national convention in Cleveland later this month. The individuals in question are Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa, Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, and Governor Mike Pence of Indiana. Trump spent time with Pence and his family on Sunday and was scheduled to meet with Ernst on Monday.

Ernst, a first-term senator and military veteran, gained attention in 2014 for her campaign ad featuring her growing up on an Iowa farm and promising to "cut pork" in Washington. She also delivered the Republican response to Barack Obama's State of the Union address in 2015.

Cotton, 39, has been less frequently mentioned as a potential Trump VP, but Trump praised him on Twitter, saying he was "great on Meet the Press" and had a "solid" interview with Chuck Todd. Cotton was more vocal in his criticism of Hillary Clinton, calling her responsible for many of the worst decisions of the Obama administration.

Trump's tweet about Todd's questioning echoed another tweet he sent on Monday, in which he blamed the "dishonest media" for a furor over a tweet he sent and then deleted on Saturday, which showed Clinton next to a six-pointed star against a background of dollar bills, prompting accusations of antisemitism. The image was later found on a white supremacist message board, predating Trump's tweet.

Other potential candidates under consideration include former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, and Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama. Trump has said the pick will likely be announced at the convention in Cleveland, which starts on July 18, but some sources suggest he may announce it sooner to generate excitement.

Trump's tweet about the VP selection process read, "The only people who are not interested in being the VP pick are the people who have not been asked!" Trump has also been in touch with aides to Senator Ted Cruz, who has been trying to win a speaking slot at the convention.

Title: White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer Faces Uncomfortable Task After "Saturday Night Live" Spoof

The White House has been rattled by a recent "Saturday Night Live" sketch featuring Melissa McCarthy as a gum-chomping, super soaker-wielding Sean Spicer. The portrayal of Spicer, the press secretary for President Donald Trump, did not go over well internally, with sources close to the president saying that Trump does not like his people to look weak. The sketch, which aired over the weekend, was seen as problematic by the White House because it was accurate and showed Spicer in a negative light.

Spicer has been struggling to strike the right balance between representing an administration that considers the media the "opposition party" and developing a functional relationship with the press. The "SNL" sketch, which was seen by some in Trump's orbit as devastating, has added to the challenges facing Spicer.

Spicer has been trying to put a positive spin on the situation, joking about the sketch and saying that he takes the job seriously but doesn't take himself too seriously. However, he has the uncomfortable task of facing reporters once again in the briefing room, where the elephant in the room will be the unflattering McCarthy caricature.

Spicer has been fighting to repair his reputation since his first day on the job, when he took no questions and made false statements about the crowd size at Trump's inauguration. He has been operating under a cloud ever since, and his relations with the press have been strained.

Title: Boehner's Relationship with House Republican Hard-Liners Key to Government Shutdown

House Speaker John Boehner's role in the government shutdown can be attributed to his relationship with a group of around 30 House Republican hard-liners. Boehner has had to navigate the diverse opinions of his 233-member caucus, which has made it challenging to find common ground.

Boehner's initial plan for a temporary government funding bill was met with resistance from the hard-liners, who wanted to take a harder stance on defunding the Affordable Care Act. This led to a government shutdown, which Boehner celebrated as a victory for the American people.

Some of the hard-liners, who hold safe seats in deep-red districts, are not feeling pressure from their constituents to compromise. Instead, they are urging Boehner to stand firm against the Affordable Care Act.

The question remains whether Boehner will ultimately bring up a "clean CR" – a short-term spending bill with Obamacare funding intact – which is believed to have enough support to pass easily on the House floor. However, some hard-liners, such as Indiana Representative Marlin Stutzman, argue that this would be detrimental to the Republican conference and Boehner's negotiating ability.

Boston College political scientist David Hopkins believes that Boehner is being cautious because he is aware that the hard-liners could find a way to depose him as speaker. With Republicans having a slim majority in the House, the hard-liners have more power than their numbers would suggest, and at least 50 other Republicans are hesitant to distance themselves from them.

The remaining Republicans have not publicly discouraged the hard-liners, and as long as they continue to support them, there is no reason to expect Boehner to deviate from their stance.

Title: Freedom Caucus Leaders Consider Going Rogue on Tax Reform

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative Republicans, may put out its own tax plan if the White House and congressional leaders fail to release a unified proposal, according to Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows and Vice Chairman Jim Jordan. The leaders met with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn on Thursday to express their concerns about the slow progress on tax reform.

Meadows, in a brief interview, downplayed the possibility of the group releasing its own legislation, stating that the White House has assured him that action is imminent. However, conservatives are eager to deliver on a major campaign promise and are willing to forge ahead on their own if necessary.

The Freedom Caucus is concerned that the Big Six, a group of top Republicans leading the tax effort, may release a plan without considering conservative views, which could lead to a divided Republican party. Meadows emphasized the importance of promoting real dialogue and ensuring that any tax plan is negotiated in good faith.

The meeting appears to have persuaded conservatives to hold off on releasing their own plan, at least for now. Meadows stated that the only way a Freedom Caucus plan would be introduced is if there is inaction from the Big Six and weeks of negotiations without progress.

The debate on tax reform is ongoing, with disagreements on specifics such as business expensing and the corporate tax rate. The Freedom Caucus is pushing for a more aggressive cut in the corporate tax rate, while the Big Six is concerned about the math behind such a move. The White House is urging Republicans to release a unified plan, but the Freedom Caucus is seeking a seat at the table and wants to influence the text.

Title: California Democrats Overcome Quirks in Electoral System, Advance in Key Congressional Races

Article:

In California, Democrats overcame the state's unique electoral system, which allows the top two vote-getters to advance to the general election regardless of party affiliation, and managed to mount challenges to Republicans in most key Congressional races. The system had raised concerns that Democrats might be locked out of competitive polls in conservative suburbs south of Los Angeles. However, Democratic candidates made it through to the final vote, as did Republican John Cox, who will face off against Democratic Governor candidate Gavin Newsom in the November election.

In the 48th Congressional District, a dramatic battle for a place on the final ballot took place, with two Democrats, Harley Rouda and Hans Keirstead, separated by fewer than 100 votes, leaving the race too close to call. If Republican Scott Baugh takes the final spot, it could set up a general election fight between Rohrabacher and his fellow Republican, potentially ending Democrats' chances to take the seat.

In New Jersey, establishment-backed Democrats muscled past liberal challengers in key congressional races, setting up contests in November that will test whether more moderate candidates will fare better against Republicans in swing districts. In southern New Jersey, conservative Democrat Jeff Van Drew appeared set to prevail over left-leaning candidates, and will face Republican Seth Grossman in the general election.

The results of the primaries in California and New Jersey will have significant implications for the November midterm elections, with Democrats hoping to gain a majority in the 435-seat U.S. House of Representatives by flipping 23 seats. Control of the House would likely stall much of Republican President Donald Trump's policy agenda, while ushering a new era of committee oversight and investigation into the administration.

Title: Defense Secretary Hagel Weighs Possibility of Ground Forces in Iraq, But No Combat Troops Planned

Article:

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has acknowledged that he may consider recommendations to deploy ground forces in Iraq to support local forces in their fight against the Islamic State (ISIS), but emphasized that any such deployment would not involve combat troops. Hagel made the comments during a seminar on national security strategy at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California.

Hagel's remarks come as President Barack Obama reiterated that he has not changed his stance on not deploying U.S. ground forces in Iraq. Obama stated that he has not received any recommendations from Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Martin Dempsey to send U.S. troops to fight in Iraq. However, the President did not rule out the possibility of deploying ground troops in extreme circumstances, such as if ISIS were to obtain a nuclear weapon.

Hagel emphasized that any potential deployment would be limited to supporting local forces and would not involve combat troops. "There will be no American combat troops in Iraq or Syria," he said. He also stated that he does not foresee a circumstance where it would be in the U.S.'s interest to take on the fight against ISIS with a large military contingent.

The Defense Secretary also discussed the ongoing threat posed by the Khorasan Group, a terrorist organization linked to ISIS. He noted that the group is planning and plotting attacks against U.S. interests, particularly in Europe, and that the U.S. is targeting them as a result.

The seminar, which was attended by several high-ranking officials, including Republican Senator John McCain, former Defense Secretaries Leon Panetta and Robert Gates, and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson, focused on the issue of whether the White House and Pentagon have a sufficient strategy to deal with ISIS. McCain criticized the administration's strategy, stating that "no one outside the Joint Chiefs of Staff believes we have a strategy" to defeat and degrade ISIS.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Announces Plans to File Impeachment Resolution Against President Trump

Rep. Rashida Tlaib, a freshman progressive Democrat from Michigan, has announced her plans to file a resolution to impeach President Trump. The move is seen as a departure from House leadership, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other senior Democrat leaders have expressed caution on the matter. Tlaib made the announcement surrounded by supporters, who wore shirts and held signs with statements such as "He's a Racist" and "#TimeToImpeach."

Tlaib stated that she believes the impeachment process is necessary to address the "constitutional crisis" and "economic justice issues" that are hindering the ability of Congress to work on other important agendas. She emphasized that she believes her party agrees that the president needs to be impeached, although there may be disagreements on the pace and timing.

The move is contrary to the desire of Pelosi and other senior Democrat leaders, who have expressed concerns about the potential disruption to the country and the need to wait for the results of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. Pelosi has stated that the party is waiting for the facts to be known before making a decision on impeachment.

Tlaib's decision comes at a time of internal turmoil within the Democrat Party, as some members are pushing for a measure addressing anti-Semitic remarks made by freshman Democrats Rep. Ilhan Omar and Rep. Tlaib herself. The party is also dealing with controversy surrounding Tlaib's campaign records, which show she paid herself $17,500 after the midterm elections, potentially violating FEC rules.

The resolution is expected to be introduced later this month, with Tlaib stating that "our democracy must be protected."

Title: Record Hispanic Turnout Helps Lift President to Victory, Immigration Reform Returns to Fore

Article:

A record Hispanic turnout helped President Barack Obama secure victory on Tuesday, prompting top Republicans to signal a renewed interest in addressing immigration reform. This sudden shift in focus marks a significant departure from the party's previous stance, which had allowed conservative firebrands to dominate the agenda. The renewed interest in tackling the issue could represent a fundamental shift for Republicans, who are increasingly concerned about Latinos abandoning their party.

The renewed focus on immigration reform comes as Republicans are under pressure to adjust to changing demographics. Latinos played a crucial role in Obama's victory, with a record Hispanic turnout and a massive margin for the Democratic incumbent. Senator Jerry Moran, running for the National Republican Senatorial Committee chairmanship, acknowledged the need for the party to reassess its approach to minority and Latino voters. "In some fashion, the way we have dealt with immigration gives us a black eye. And we need to figure out how to talk about issues and pursue policies that matter to Latino, Hispanic voters," Moran said.

Latino leaders are also holding Obama accountable for his promise to deliver on immigration reform. Eliseo Medina, secretary-treasurer of the Service Employees International Union and a leader of Latino mobilization in battleground states, warned that the Latino community is "wide awake, cranky, and taking names." Obama had promised to introduce a comprehensive immigration reform bill during his first year in office but failed to follow through. However, he took executive action last summer to allow certain young immigrants to stay in the country.

The president is expected to pursue a broad proposal early next year, with Democratic officials stating that Obama is confident immigration reform will get done. Vice President Joe Biden expressed optimism about the issue, saying it's "a different day." The renewed interest in immigration reform marks a significant shift for Republicans, who are under pressure to adapt to changing demographics and address the concerns of Latino voters.

Title: White House Withholds Email on Susan Rice's Talking Points, Claims it's Not About Benghazi

The White House has revealed that it withheld an email from Congress and the media regarding Susan Rice's infamous "talking points" about the 2012 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya. According to White House Press Secretary Jay Carney, the memo did not deal directly with the attack, but rather focused on the general dynamic in the Muslim world at the time.

The email, sent by Ben Rhodes, President Obama's assistant and deputy national security adviser, on September 14, 2012, outlined the White House's goals for Rice's appearance on Sunday television talk shows. The main objective was to "reinforce the president and the administration's strength and steadiness in dealing with difficult challenges." A second goal was to link the Benghazi attack and other diplomatic site attacks across the Middle East to an obscure anti-Muslim video and to insist that the protests were not "rooted" in a "broader failure of [administration] policy."

The email was part of the White House's efforts to shape the narrative around the Benghazi attack, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens. The email and other documents obtained by a government watchdog group provide the clearest evidence to date that top presidential aides sought to use anti-American protests sweeping across the Middle East in 2012 to push an image of President Obama's foreign policy as "steady and statesmanlike" just weeks before his re-election.

The White House withheld the Rhodes memo from congressional and media inquiries, citing that it was "explicitly not about Benghazi." However, critics argue that the email and other documents reveal a pattern of White House involvement in shaping the narrative around the Benghazi attack and its aftermath.

Title: Unemployment Claims Surge, Economic Aid Stalls, and Health Officials Offer Optimistic Outlook

The United States is facing a growing unemployment crisis, with nearly 17 million Americans filing for jobless benefits in just three weeks. Many states are struggling to keep up with the surge in unemployment requests, with Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia stating that the processing time will vary by state.

In Washington, Senate Republicans pushed for an additional $250 billion in aid to help small businesses, but were blocked by Democrats, who are demanding a $500 billion bill to support healthcare providers and state and local governments. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R) emphasized the need for swift action, while Senator Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) called the proposal a "political stunt."

The unemployment rate is expected to hit 15% soon, and White House officials are considering reopening certain businesses in areas unaffected by the outbreak. However, governors have issued stay-at-home orders through the end of May or later, making it difficult for the federal government to implement a plan.

Health officials are cautiously optimistic, with Dr. Anthony Fauci predicting a death toll of 60,000, down from earlier estimates of 100,000 to 240,000. Fauci emphasized the importance of being prepared to identify, isolate, and trace new cases.

Meanwhile, a bipartisan group of senators is calling on China to close all wet markets where fresh meat and produce are sold in unsanitary conditions, following the admission by the Chinese CDC that the origin of the new coronavirus is the illegal wildlife sold in a Wuhan seafood market.

Title: Obama Reiterates Commitment to Executive Action on Immigration, Despite Congressional Opposition

Article:

President Barack Obama reiterated his commitment to taking executive action on immigration reform during a joint news conference with Myanmar dissident leader Aung San Suu Kyi on Friday. The president stated that he is determined to act before the end of the year, unless Congress passes legislation to address the issue. Obama emphasized that the current system is "broken" and has been "stalled" for 10 years, and that he will not stand idly by while it remains in disarray.

The president's comments come as Republicans in Congress are threatening to derail his plans, with Speaker John Boehner warning that the president's decision will set off an "adversarial relationship" with Congress. However, Obama appeared to respond with his own warning, stating that he is against any approach to governance where a single disagreement becomes a "deal-breaker" on every issue.

Obama also reiterated a previous promise that if congressional Republicans put forward a reform proposal, he will revoke any executive actions he has taken. The president's comments come as a rift is developing within the Republican party about the best way forward, with at least 50 conservative lawmakers pushing to leverage the upcoming spending bill to force Obama to stand down.

The president has not yet decided on the timing of his announcement, but reports suggest it could come as early as next week. The proposed plan is expected to grant amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants, including parents of children who are U.S. citizens or legal residents, and give them the right to obtain work documents. Democrats and immigration rights supporters are rallying behind the president's decision, citing the actions of previous presidents who have taken unilateral action on major issues.

It is worth noting that the details of the plan are still being finalized, and officials have not yet confirmed the exact scope of the amnesty and work permits that will be granted.

Title: Budget Negotiations Fail to Address Underlying Issues, Risking Recession and Economic Chaos

The ongoing negotiations between President Obama and House Republicans to avoid the fiscal cliff are unlikely to solve Washington's budget woes and may instead cast the nation into another recession or worse. The Budget Act of 2011 requires a nine-year $1.2 trillion deficit reduction program or cuts in annual defense and non-entitlement outlays, which could trigger catastrophic consequences for the economy. The expiration of the Bush Tax cuts, the 2 percentage point payroll tax holiday, and other programs will add to the $136 billion in annual spending reductions and $532 billion in additional taxes, potentially causing unemployment to rise above 15%, state government finances to collapse, and hundreds of banks to fail.

To avoid calamity, President Obama and House Republicans are likely to agree to raise taxes on high-income Americans by $100 to $150 billion and curb spending by an equal amount. However, these efforts will prove insufficient, and the economy may still slide into recession, depriving the federal government of tax revenues and further pushing up the budget gap.

The federal deficit exceeds $1 trillion, up from $161 billion in 2007, the last year before the financial collapse. Spending is up $1 trillion, with outlays for Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and other entitlements increasing by an amount equal to the entire 2013 defense budget. By the end of the decade, runaway entitlement spending will require shutting down the military or crippling many other domestic spending programs to head off ballooning deficits.

Experts suggest that the only reasonable solution is to raise the Social Security retirement age to 70 and pattern US health care reforms after other national systems that better contain costs. The Germans and Dutch spend one-third less on health care than the United States, thanks to more aggressive price regulation, better rationing, and lower spending on lawsuits.

Democrats are reluctant to require Americans to work longer, while Republicans refuse to admit more competition in the health care industry. Without a significantly higher retirement age, effective price controls in health care, and tort reform, federal spending and the national debt will continue to skyrocket.

The article also highlights the need for major changes in trade and energy policies to boost domestic demand and growth. The ongoing trade deficit with China and oil imports continue to pose significant challenges, and the federal government's reliance on deficit spending will only exacerbate the problem. The article concludes that absent major changes in these areas, budget deficit reduction is not possible without another long, hard recession, and the country is headed for economic chaos by the end of the decade.

Title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Louisiana Abortion Law, But Chief Justice Roberts' Opinion Raises Concerns

The United States Supreme Court has struck down a Louisiana law requiring abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, a victory for reproductive rights. The 5-4 ruling, announced on Monday, saw Chief Justice John Roberts voting with the liberal justices to preserve the court's precedents and protect abortion access. However, legal writer Mark Joseph Stern argues that Roberts' reasoning in the case, June Medical Services v. Russo, is not as favorable to abortion rights as it may initially appear.

According to Stern, the outcome is a triumph for Louisiana's three remaining clinics, which can now remain open thanks to the Supreme Court. However, Roberts' opinion itself is far from an unalloyed endorsement of a constitutional right to choose. In fact, the chief justice cut back protections for women seeking abortions and laid the groundwork for a future erosion, if not outright reversal, of Roe v. Wade.

The Supreme Court's ruling in June Medical Services was similar to its 2016 ruling in Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, which struck down a similar law in Texas. In Whole Woman's Health, the Court ruled that Texas' admitting privileges law imposed an "undue burden" on the constitutional right to abortion. Since Louisiana's law is indistinguishable from Texas', it should have been plainly unconstitutional under Whole Woman's Health. However, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals effectively defied precedent by upholding the Louisiana regulation.

Since major changes have occurred on the U.S. Supreme Court since 2016, the big question was whether Roberts, who dissented in Whole Woman's Health, would nonetheless invalidate Louisiana's law on the grounds of stare decisis, or respect for precedent. And that's exactly what Roberts did – with a catch. The Court actually splintered 4-1-4: Justice Stephen Breyer wrote for the four liberals, the chief justice wrote an opinion concurring in the judgment, and the four other conservatives dissented.

Stern notes that because the chief justice's opinion is narrower than Breyer's, it is "controlling" – that is, it's the law of the land. Advocates on both sides of the abortion debate will thus be scrutinizing Roberts' concurrence for years to come. And it gives both sides reason for encouragement.

According to Stern, Roberts' decision in June Medical does not necessarily mean that Roe v. Wade won't be overturned at some point. In short, Roberts – alone among the conservatives – agreed with the liberals that Louisiana can not pretend its law creates no real burden for abortion patients in the face of ample evidence that it would shutter clinics. But the chief justice then whittled down the holding of Whole Woman's Health, replacing its balancing test with a stingier rule that may give states broader leeway to restrict abortion.

Title: Republicans Defend New Tax Loophole Amidst Criticism of Favoritism Toward Wealthy

The Republican-led Congress has introduced a new tax loophole, which has sparked controversy over its potential benefits to wealthy individuals and corporations. The loophole, which allows pass-through businesses to deduct 20% of their income from their taxes, has been defended by Republican leaders as a necessary measure to ensure fairness in the tax code.

According to Senator Bob Corker, who owns a real estate partnership in Tennessee, the loophole was not added to win over his vote. The provision has become crucial for the Republican party, as they can afford to lose only two votes and Senator John McCain will be absent due to health reasons.

Republicans insist that the loophole was not "airdropped" into the tax bill during conference committee negotiations and that its main purpose was to ensure pass-through businesses were not treated unfairly. They argue that corporations would be getting a significant tax cut, reducing their tax rate from 35% to 21%.

However, critics argue that the loophole is further evidence of congressional leaders prioritizing the wealthy at the expense of almost everyone else. According to the Joint Committee on Taxation, the 20% deduction for pass-through income would cost the government $414.5 billion in lost revenue over 10 years.

In comparison, the federal government spends around $14 billion annually on the Children's Health Insurance Program, which covers nearly nine million low-income children. The tax bill's generosity towards real estate titans stands in stark contrast to its stinginess towards average wage earners and its potential damage to taxpayers in high-cost states.

Average wage earners would see modest tax cuts in the early years, which would evaporate after 2025. Homeowners and others in high-cost states like California, New Jersey, and New York would see their once-sizable deductions for state and local taxes shrink to a maximum of $10,000 a year, potentially reducing home values. Additionally, the tax bill would permanently change how tax brackets are adjusted for inflation, pushing more people into higher tax brackets over time, even with modest salary increases.

Title: Trump's Inclusive Approach to Former Rivals and Shift in Policy Stance

The article discusses President-elect Donald Trump's surprising inclusiveness in reaching out to former rivals who had criticized him during the campaign.
