Despite initial skepticism, Trump has shown flexibility in rethinking some of his campaign promises, abandoning support for waterboarding and expressing an open mind on climate change. He has also agreed to keep two key parts of ObamaCare.

The article highlights Trump's willingness to work with establishment Republicans, including Mitt Romney, who had called him a "fraud," and Nikki Haley, who had questioned his disavowal of the KKK. Trump has even called a temporary truce in his rhetorical war on the media, describing the New York Times as a "jewel."

However, the article notes that not everyone is pleased with Trump's evolving views. Some critics, like Kathleen Parker, have called out Trump's "many campaign lies," while others, like Fareed Zakaria, have expressed skepticism about Trump's sudden change of heart.

The article also touches on the controversy surrounding Trump's potential conflicts of interest, including his real estate empire and his son-in-law Jared Kushner's potential role in his administration. While some have raised concerns about nepotism and the potential for conflicts of interest, others have noted that Trump has the right to use his family members in informal roles.

Overall, the article presents a balanced view of Trump's post-election evolution, highlighting both his inclusive approach and his willingness to adapt his policy stances, while also acknowledging the skepticism and criticism he has faced from some quarters.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage Sparks Debate Over Religious Rights

The Supreme Court's landmark decision to legalize same-sex marriage across the United States has sparked a heated debate over religious rights and freedoms. While the ruling is seen as a major victory for the LGBTQ+ community, many religious groups and individuals are concerned about the potential implications for their beliefs and practices.

In his majority opinion, Justice Anthony Kennedy emphasized the importance of religious freedom, stating that religious groups have the right to object to same-sex marriage and advocate for their beliefs. However, some conservative justices and religious leaders have criticized the ruling, arguing that it does not go far enough in protecting religious liberties.

Justice Clarence Thomas, in his dissent, warned that the ruling could have "ruinous consequences" for religious institutions and individuals who disagree with same-sex marriage. He argued that the decision could lead to demands for religious organizations to participate in and endorse same-sex marriages, citing historical precedent for such demands.

Chief Justice John Roberts also expressed concerns about the potential conflicts between religious liberties and the new right to same-sex marriage. He noted that "hard questions" will arise when people of faith exercise their religious liberty in ways that conflict with the new right, and asked what happens when a religious college provides student housing only to heterosexual couples or a faith-based adoption agency refuses to place children with same-sex spouses.

The ruling has also sparked concerns among religious leaders, with Archbishop William Lori of Baltimore stating that the decision will affect "thousands" of state and local statutes across the country and could lead to "a lot of legal controversies" for religious institutions. Evangelical leaders have also pledged to fight the legal implications of the ruling, stating that they will not allow the government to coerce or infringe upon their religious beliefs.

The debate over religious rights and freedoms is likely to continue in the coming years, with both sides vying for their beliefs to be respected and protected.

Title: Ferguson Residents Remain on Edge as Grand Jury Decision on Officer Wilson's Fate Looms

Ferguson, Missouri, is bracing for a potential grand jury decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson for the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown. The decision, expected as early as Monday, has left residents on edge, with protesters taking to the streets again on Saturday evening.

According to a federal law enforcement official, the St. Louis County grand jury is expected to reconvene on Monday, but the timing of a decision remains unclear. Protesters gathered at the Ferguson police station, chanting slogans such as "No justice, no peace" and "Mike Brown means we've got to fight back." Two people were arrested for unlawful assembly, according to St. Louis County Police spokesman Brian Schellman.

Authorities have set up barricades around the building where the grand jury has been meeting and in a nearby shopping center parking lot, where police have established a makeshift command center. Police and protesters are planning ahead, with police leaders meeting with protest group leaders to agree on 11 rules of engagement, including avoiding excessive force and communicating to de-escalate tense situations.

President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder have called for calm, with the president urging people not to use the grand jury's decision as an excuse for violence. Holder has urged law enforcement officials to minimize the potential for confrontations during demonstrations.

Michael Brown's father has also appealed for calm, saying in a video statement that hurting others and destroying property is not the answer. Missouri Governor Jay Nixon has declared a state of emergency and will call in the National Guard if violence or unrest erupts.

Some schools in the area are preparing for the possibility of unrest, with the Jennings school district deciding to close its schools on Monday and Tuesday to avoid having students in school during potential demonstrations. Officer Wilson has reportedly resigned from the Ferguson police force, regardless of the grand jury's decision.

Title: Allocating Capital and Labor: A New Approach to Economic Planning

The concept of allocating capital and labor is a crucial aspect of any economic system. In a market-based economy, capital is allocated based on the pursuit of profit, often leading to a focus on high-return investments. However, this approach can lead to social and regional inequalities. A new approach is needed to allocate capital and labor in a way that strengthens equality and promotes social welfare.

One potential solution is the establishment of sectoral councils, where workers from firms within a sector elect representatives to make plans for the sector as a whole. This approach would allow for the distribution of capital within the sector to meet overall plans, while also promoting productivity and quality across firms. Additionally, sectoral councils could be plugged into regional councils or urban councils, creating a multi-layered planning system.

The idea of sectoral councils is not a new concept, and it has been discussed by economists such as Friedrich Hayek. Hayek argued that markets are essential for revealing information about what people want and what skills they possess. However, this argument has been criticized for prioritizing the capacities of entrepreneurs over those of ordinary workers.

Socialism, on the other hand, aims to tap into the potential capacities of ordinary people, rather than just entrepreneurs. Socialism recognizes that workers are not just commodities, but individuals with the capacity to learn and adapt. When workers are given the opportunity to run their own factories, they may not know what to do with them, but socialism is concerned with developing their capacity to learn and coordinate complex systems.

The productivity growth in capitalism is often cited as an argument against socialism, with some claiming that the incentives provided by capitalism drive innovation and efficiency. However, it is not difficult to imagine workers on the job coming up with ideas to improve processes, which could match or even surpass the productivity growth seen in capitalist systems. Moreover, there are many other benefits to be gained from a more participatory and democratic approach to economic planning.

In conclusion, allocating capital and labor is a complex issue that requires a new approach. Sectoral councils and socialism offer a way to allocate capital and labor in a way that promotes social welfare and equality, rather than undermining it. By recognizing the capacities of ordinary workers and providing them with the opportunity to learn and adapt, socialism can help to create a more equitable and prosperous society.

Title: Helicopter Carrying Kobe Bryant Crashes in California, Dense Fog Cited as Possible Factor

The helicopter carrying Kobe Bryant, his daughter, and seven others crashed in Calabasas, California, on Sunday, with dense fog reportedly playing a role in the incident. The helicopter, a Sikorsky S-76, was given special flight clearance to fly through the fog from Orange County to the Los Angeles area, according to audio records between the pilot and Burbank Airport's air traffic control.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) official stated that the pilot was responsible for determining whether it was safe to fly in current and expected conditions, and that the pilot would have had to determine that the weather was good enough to fly. The FAA official added that the pilot would have had to determine flight visibility, which would have been a challenge due to the dense fog.

Los Angeles police Sgt. Yvette Tuning, LAPD's Air Support Division Watch commander, noted that police helicopters do not typically fly in foggy conditions. She stated that the weather had been good most of the winter, but on the day of the crash, the fog was dense and made it difficult for police helicopters to operate.

The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner's Office announced that three bodies were recovered from the scene, but the remains have not been identified. The investigation is ongoing, with federal transportation safety investigators on their way to the scene. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) will examine the pilot's history, the helicopter's maintenance records, and the records of its owner and operator.

The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Office stated that there were nine people listed on the helicopter's manifest, and all were believed to be dead. The crash occurred when the helicopter turned southeast and climbed to over 2,000 feet before descending and crashing into the hillside at around 1,400 feet. The helicopter was flying at around 184 mph and descending at a rate of more than 4,000 feet per minute when it struck the ground.

Witnesses described the fog as "dense" and "real low," making it difficult to see the helicopter as it crashed. The rugged terrain complicated efforts to recover the remains, with the medical examiner estimating it will take at least a couple of days to complete the task before identifications can be made.

Title: Maryland Rep. Elijah E. Cummings Dies at 68 Due to Complications from Longstanding Health Challenges

Article:

Maryland Representative Elijah E. Cummings passed away on Thursday at Johns Hopkins Hospital due to complications from his longstanding health challenges. He was 68 years old. Cummings was a prominent figure in the US House of Representatives, serving as the chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee. He was known for his powerful oratory skills and his advocacy for the poor and marginalized communities in his black-majority district, which includes a large portion of Baltimore and surrounding suburbs.

As chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, Cummings led multiple investigations into President Donald Trump's governmental dealings, including probes in 2019 related to the president's family members serving in the White House. Trump responded to Cummings' investigations by criticizing the Democrat's district as a "rodent-infested mess" where "no human being would want to live." Cummings replied that government officials must stop making "hateful, incendiary comments" that only serve to divide and distract the nation from its real problems, including mass shootings and white supremacy.

Cummings' long career in Maryland politics spanned decades, starting in the Maryland House of Delegates, where he rose through the ranks before winning his congressional seat in a special election in 1996. He was an early supporter of Barack Obama's presidential bid in 2008 and was a firm believer in needle exchange programs as a way to reduce the spread of AIDS.

Born on January 18, 1951, Cummings was told in grade school that he was too slow to learn and would never become a lawyer. However, he proved his doubters wrong, becoming a lawyer and one of the most powerful orators in the Maryland House of Delegates. He was known for his ability to develop his theme and raise the emotional heat until it became like a sermon from the pulpit.

Cummings chaired the Congressional Black Caucus from 2003 to 2004, employing a hard-charging, explore-every-option style to put the group in the national spotlight. He cruised to big victories in the overwhelmingly Democratic district, which had given Maryland its first black congressman in 1970 when Parren Mitchell was elected.

Title: Broad-Based Ownership Models Gain Momentum as a Solution to Income Inequality

The United States is currently experiencing the highest level of income inequality in its history, with the top 10% of the wealthiest individuals holding two-thirds of the national wealth. This has led to a decline in economic confidence and a sense that the American Dream is out of reach for many. However, a movement is underway to address this issue through broad-based ownership models, which aim to shift wealth from the hands of the few to the many.

Employee-owned businesses, for example, have been shown to pay 5-12% more in wages than traditionally owned companies, with workers having more than double the retirement accounts and being one-fourth as likely to be laid off. Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs) have been particularly successful, with companies like Recology in San Francisco, a $800 million waste collection and recycling firm, being 100% owned by its 3,000 employees.

Other models of broad-based ownership include social enterprises, municipally owned enterprises, and emerging hybrids like B Corporations, which aim to balance social and environmental goals with financial returns. The nation's largest banks can play a key role in promoting these models, as they are already committed to investing in low- and moderate-income communities under the Community Reinvestment Act.

With the coming wave of company sales from aging baby boomer entrepreneurs, there is a unique opportunity to promote employee ownership. At least 7 million owners of privately held businesses will reach retirement age between now and 2030, and it is crucial that these companies are sold to employees rather than private equity firms, which would further concentrate wealth among the wealthy.

The 50 by 50 initiative aims to create 50 million employee owners by 2050, with a diverse group of organizations already working towards this goal. Cities like New York are also taking steps to promote worker cooperatives, with a $3.3 million allocation over two years to develop worker-owned businesses.

Community Development Finance Institutions (CDFIs) can also play a crucial role in facilitating and financing business conversions to ESOPs or cooperatives. For example, the Cooperative Fund of New England and Coastal Enterprises, Inc. of Maine joined forces to finance a $5.6 million worker buyout of three rural Maine businesses, converting them into a 45-member worker-owned cooperative.

Legislation like H.R. 2096, the Promotion and Expansion of Employee Ownership Act, would provide further tax incentives for conversion and technical assistance for making the transition. Sixty-eight percent of Americans support employee ownership, and it's no surprise why – employee ownership offers greater protection against layoffs, keeps companies rooted locally over the long term, and works to spread wealth to many.

As more cities and states develop cooperative economic models, financing of broad-based ownership is no longer on the fringe of economic debate; it's just good business.

Title: US Faces New Challenges After Egyptian President Morsi's Ouster

The ouster of Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi by the country's powerful military has released the United States from its delicate position of being caught between a democratically elected leader and the democratic forces seeking his removal. The US will still face tough questions on how to respond to a military coup in a key Middle East partner and major recipient of US military aid.

The days ahead are likely to remain agitated and tense in Egypt, and the US will likely face criticism from Morsi's supporters, who will claim the US acquiesced to the illegal removal of an elected leader who had just marked the first year of a four-year term. The Egyptian military acted to deflect accusations that the manner in which it removed Morsi amounted to a coup. The commander-in-chief of the Egyptian armed forces, Gen. Abdel Fatah al-Sissi, told Egyptians in a televised address that the chief justice of Egypt's constitutional court – and not a military leader – would fill the presidency until new presidential elections can be held.

The new interim president is set to be sworn in on Thursday. The military said it acted in the "public service" not just to end the country's chaotic political crisis but to implement a "roadmap to democracy" that would have the support of Egypt's political factions and foster the "reconciliation" that Morsi failed to promote. Although he did not mention Morsi by name, Sissi said the president had "responded with negativity" up to the last minute to the military's demands for a resolution of the political crisis.

The Egyptian military also sought to assure the United States, in a phone call to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, that it has no interest in holding onto power. As Egypt's turmoil reached a crescendo in recent days, the US attempted to appear neutral among the dueling parties, with both the White House and the State Department emphasizing that "we don't take sides" and calling on all factions to "engage with each other" and find a nonviolent political solution to their differences.

However, by Wednesday afternoon, with events in Cairo moving fast and Morsi's ouster looking likely, US officials began shifting their stance. At the State Department, spokeswoman Jen Psaki reminded reporters that democracy is about more than elections. She spoke critically of Morsi over what she said was his failure to "take steps" to address Egyptians' concerns – even as she held her fire toward the military.

Morsi's televised speech on Tuesday, in which he defiantly refused to meet protesters' demands and vowed never to step down, was a particular disappointment to the US, Psaki said. "He had the opportunity [in the speech] to lay out certain steps" to address the crisis, she said, "and he didn't take the opportunity to do that."

Thousands of Egyptians celebrated publicly on Wednesday night, but it was unclear what path Morsi's many supporters planned to take. Meanwhile, the US military was preparing for the worst in Egypt, dispatching part of a Marine crisis response team stationed in Spain to Sigonella, Italy, to shorten the team's distance from Egypt in case its intervention was needed. The United States also ordered the evacuation of its embassy in Cairo, news reports said.

In May, the US quietly approved the annual $1.3 billion in US military aid to Egypt, despite qualms over progress in the country's democratization process, and it seems unlikely to suspend that aid even after a coup. The Egyptian military has close ties to the Pentagon, and the emphasis on civilian leaders and a "roadmap" to democracy appears likely to blunt any criticism in Washington.

Now that Morsi is out, the US is likely to insist that it continues to take no sides and only supports "the Egyptian people," some regional analysts say. "They'll continue trying to maintain this idea of a neutral position because they want to avoid looking like they are intervening in Egypt's politics," said James Phillips, a Middle East expert at the Heritage Foundation in Washington.

Title: Obama Administration Announces Policy Change for Young Illegal Immigrants

The Obama administration has announced a new policy change, stating that it will stop deporting young illegal immigrants who meet certain conditions. According to the policy, individuals who were brought to the United States as children, are 30 or younger, have lived in the country for at least five years, have no criminal record, and meet certain education or military service requirements will be eligible for work permits.

The policy change is seen as a move to improve the administration's image among Latino voters, who were a key demographic in the 2008 election. However, some critics argue that the policy is a stunt aimed at boosting Obama's re-election chances, rather than a genuine attempt to address the complex issue of immigration reform.

The policy change is expected to affect around 800,000 individuals, known as "DREAM'ers," who would have benefited from the DREAM Act had it not been blocked by Congress. The administration's move is seen as a response to a similar proposal put forth by Republican Senator Marco Rubio, which would also stop deporting DREAM'ers and issue work permits, but does not offer a pathway to citizenship.

The policy change has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising the administration's move as a step in the right direction, while others are skeptical of the administration's motives and the potential impact on the broader immigration debate.

Title: Trump Administration Weighs Options on Paris Climate Agreement

The Trump administration is considering a new option to declare the Paris climate agreement a treaty and send it to the Senate for ratification, a move that could potentially derail the deal. This option emerged as a middle ground in the ongoing debate between those who want the US to remain part of the agreement and those who want to withdraw.

According to memos circulated among top staffers, declaring the Paris agreement a treaty would require a two-thirds vote in the Senate, which is unlikely given the current Republican majority. The memo, drafted by Christopher C. Horner and Marlo Lewis Jr., senior fellows at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, argues that this option would affirm the US as a nation of laws, not men, and discourage future administrations from attempting to circumvent the system.

On the other hand, supporters of the Paris agreement, including lawyers in the State Department, argue that sending the agreement to the Senate would give up important powers and leave the US open to congressional meddling. They claim that the legal obligations under the agreement are relatively few and are generally process-oriented, with few risks to remaining part of the deal.

The Paris agreement is the main international vehicle for combating climate change, and the US committed to it in 2015 under the Obama administration. The agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and pursue efforts to limit it even further to 1.5 degrees.

As the administration weighs its options, the debate has become increasingly tense, with some arguing that staying in the agreement would tie the US's hands and others claiming that withdrawing would leave the country open to legal challenges. Energy Secretary Rick Perry has expressed support for renegotiating the agreement, while Environmental Protection Agency chief Scott Pruitt and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley are pushing for withdrawal.

The next test for the Paris accord will be in mid-May, when finance ministers of the Group of Seven major economies meet in Italy. The heads of state will meet at the end of the month, and the leaders are hoping for a communique reaffirming the Paris agreement, while opponents within the US are hoping to prevent that.

Title: Trump Supporters' Loyalty Tested Amidst Controversies and Criticisms

Article:

A recent poll by Monmouth University found that 41% of Americans approve of President Trump's job performance, with 61% of those supporters saying they cannot imagine anything that would make them disapprove of him. This loyalty is not without its critics, however. Gregory Kline, a 46-year-old lawyer from Severna Park, Maryland, who identifies as a Republican, expressed frustration with Trump's behavior, stating that people are not "deaf and dumb" but rather "don't care" about his erratic actions.

Kline, who did not vote for Trump, believes that part of the president's support comes from frustration with the left, particularly the media. He noted that when there is an attack by Muslim terrorists, the media often reaches for pundits who say most Muslims are good, but when it is a white supremacist, "every conservative is lumped in with him."

Michael Dye, a 52-year-old engineer and treasurer for the Republican Party in Annapolis, Maryland, expressed disappointment with Trump's response to the recent neo-Nazi march through the University of Virginia, his alma mater. Dye, who voted reluctantly for Trump, believes that the president should have condemned the march more strongly, stating that it is "naïve" to think that the original protesters were solely motivated by the removal of a statue.

While some Trump supporters are unwavering in their support, others are more conditional. Trump's poll numbers have dropped significantly since he took office in January. For those who are less committed, it seems that nothing Trump could do would change their minds.

Title: Candidates Make Final Push Ahead of Election Day

As Election Day approaches, both presidential candidates are intensifying their campaigns, with Republicans mobilizing to defend against potential voter fraud and Democrats preparing to protect against efforts to suppress voting rights. The campaigns are focusing on turnout operations, with President Barack Obama and his challenger, Mitt Romney, presenting themselves as agents of change.

In his speeches, Romney emphasized the need for change, criticizing Obama's record and promising to deliver a new era of economic hope. Obama, on the other hand, highlighted his accomplishments and emphasized the importance of trust, saying that voters know what he means and says what he means.

Both campaigns are using celebrity endorsements to draw crowds, with Obama being endorsed by Pitbull and Romney being supported by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey. The candidates are also using social media to reach voters, with Obama's campaign releasing a video featuring celebrities and Romney's campaign releasing a video featuring everyday Americans.

The campaigns are also engaging in a war of words over voting, with Republicans accusing Democrats of encouraging older voters to illegally fill out absentee ballots for their family members. The Republican National Committee sent a letter to the Iowa secretary of state expressing concern over the alleged conduct.

As the election draws near, both candidates are confident in their chances, with Obama holding a slender lead in several battleground states. The campaigns are racing against the clock, with Romney planning events in Florida, Virginia, Ohio, and New Hampshire on Monday.

Title: Israeli Troops Fire on Gazans Near Border Fence, Killing One and Wounding 19

Israeli troops fired on Palestinians approaching the border fence in Gaza on Friday, killing one person and wounding 19 others. The incident occurred as a fragile two-day-old cease-fire between Israel and Hamas remained in place, following eight days of cross-border fighting that was the bloodiest between the two sides in four years.

According to Gaza health official Ashraf al-Kidra, the 20-year-old man killed was identified as Anwar Abdulhadi Qudaih, and at least 19 others were injured by Israeli fire near the border. Palestinian U.N. observer Riyad Mansour accused Israel of violating the cease-fire and using excessive and lethal force against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

Hundreds of Palestinians approached the border fence in several locations in southern Gaza, testing expectations that Israel would no longer enforce a 300-meter-wide no-go zone on the Palestinian side of the fence. In one incident captured by Associated Press video, several dozen Palestinians, most of them young men, approached the fence, coming close to a group of Israeli soldiers standing on the other side. Some Palestinians briefly talked to the soldiers, while others appeared to be taunting them with chants of "God is Great" and "Morsi, Morsi," in praise of Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi, whose mediation led to the truce.

Israel's military said roughly 300 Palestinians approached the security fence at different points, tried to damage it, and cross into Israel. Soldiers fired warning shots in the air, but after the Palestinians refused to move back, troops fired at their legs, the military said. A Palestinian infiltrated into Israel during the unrest, but was returned to Gaza, it said.

The truce, which calls for an end to Gaza rocket fire on Israel and Israeli airstrikes on Gaza, was brokered by Egypt and came after eight days of fighting that killed 166 Palestinians, including scores of civilians, and six Israelis. Over 1,230 Palestinians were injured, predominantly women and children, according to Mansour.

The fighting has also led to increased tensions between Israel and the international community, with the Palestinian U.N. observer calling on the Security Council and the international community to remain vigilant in their demands for a complete cessation of hostilities and for compliance by Israel.

Title: Debt Ceiling Fight Looms as Ryan and White House Take Opposing Stances

The recent passage of a budget agreement by the House of Representatives has brought a sense of relief to Washington, but it has also raised concerns about another potential debt ceiling fight. Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan, the House Budget Committee chairman, has stated that the GOP will not agree to a clean debt ceiling bill, instead seeking to negotiate spending cuts as part of the debt ceiling debate.

Ryan's stance is consistent with his previous views, as he has argued that the debt ceiling is the appropriate place to address spending cuts. He has also cited precedents set by previous presidents, including Barack Obama, who have negotiated over the debt ceiling in the past.

However, the White House has reiterated its position that it will not negotiate over the debt ceiling, with Press Secretary Jay Carney stating that the administration will not "play chicken with the full faith and credit of the United States." Carney also emphasized that the president's position has not and will not change.

The disagreement between Ryan and the White House sets the stage for another potential debt ceiling showdown, which could occur as early as March, coinciding with the start of the 2014 primary season. This could put pressure on Republicans to vote against a clean debt ceiling bill, potentially leading to another government shutdown or default.

The outcome of this standoff remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the debt ceiling debate is likely to continue to be a contentious issue in Washington, with both sides dug in and unwilling to budge.

Title: Protesters Interrupt Democratic Debate with Chants Over Immigration and Policing Issues

The second night of the Democratic presidential primary debate in Detroit was disrupted twice by protesters in the audience, who drew attention to issues surrounding immigration and policing. The first interruption occurred during New Jersey Senator Cory Booker's opening statement, with a few audience members shouting "Fire Pantaleo" in reference to Staten Island police officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the 2014 death of Eric Garner. The chant was aimed at New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has been criticized for not pushing for Pantaleo's dismissal.

The protesters' goal was to draw attention to the ongoing tensions between the African American community and law enforcement, particularly in the wake of the Justice Department's decision not to bring criminal charges against Pantaleo in July. While de Blasio does not have the legal authority to fire Pantaleo, his handling of the issue has contributed to his low approval ratings among his constituents.

Later in the debate, a separate group of protesters interrupted the discussion to protest former Vice President Joe Biden and the Obama administration's record on immigration. The Cosecha Movement, which advocates for a halt to all immigrant detention and deportation, unfurled a banner reading "Stop all deportations on day one" and chanted "3 million deportations." The group is also pushing for the reunification of families separated by deportation under the Trump administration and the immediate legalization of the estimated 11 million people living in the country illegally.

The debate was broadcast live on CNN, and the interruptions did not disrupt the overall flow of the discussion. The protesters' actions aimed to bring attention to the issues and spark a national conversation about policing and immigration reform.

Title: Upset in New York: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Defeats Incumbent Joe Crowley in Democratic Primary

Article:

In a stunning upset, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a 28-year-old progressive candidate, defeated 10-term incumbent Joe Crowley, 56, in the Democratic primary election in New York City's 14th congressional district. Ocasio-Cortez won with 57.5% of the vote, sending shockwaves throughout the political establishment.

Crowley, a prominent Democrat and potential future party leader, had not faced a challenger from within his own party in 14 years. The district, which covers parts of the Bronx and Queens, is predominantly ethnic minority. Ocasio-Cortez, a former Bernie Sanders volunteer from a Puerto Rican family, ran a grassroots campaign focused on issues such as universal healthcare, tuition-free college, and criminal justice reform.

The political newcomer, who describes herself as a socialist Democrat, raised more small-dollar donations than any other New York City congressional candidate. Her campaign gained significant momentum, with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, a top Democrat, endorsing Crowley. However, Ocasio-Cortez posted on Twitter that Gillibrand "didn't even bother to talk to nor consider me before endorsing" Crowley.

The upset marks a significant shift in the political landscape, as Crowley was seen as a potential future Speaker of the House of Representatives. His defeat sends a message that the Democratic Party is moving to the left, with growing support for progressive policies such as universal healthcare and free college education.

Ocasio-Cortez will now face Republican candidate Anthony Pappas in the November mid-terms. If she wins, she will become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. The political novice has gained widespread attention for her campaign, which emphasized her working-class background and commitment to progressive values.

The outcome of the election has significant implications for the Democratic Party, as it signals a shift towards a more diverse and progressive leadership. The party is moving to the left, with growing support for issues that were at the heart of Senator Bernie Sanders' 2016 presidential campaign.

Title: House Passes Continuing Resolution to Fund Government, Excluding Obamacare

The House of Representatives has passed a continuing resolution to fund all parts of the government at sequestration levels through December 15, excluding funding for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The move comes as the temporary budget is set to expire, and the government faces the possibility of a shutdown.

The Republican position is that the government should not fund Obamacare if it is not ready to be implemented in full. They argue that the law has been plagued by procedural failures and unintended consequences, with over 20 delays, exemptions, and revisions since its implementation. The law has also been criticized for disproportionately burdening the most vulnerable members of society, such as young Americans who will pay higher costs to subsidize the older and wealthier.

A recent poll by FreedomWorks found that 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor a continuing resolution that does not include funding for Obamacare. Only 17% of all voters believe Obamacare will have a positive personal impact, a new low since the law was passed in 2010.

The article also highlights the growing public discontent with the law, citing a recent poll that found 62% of all voters prefer a "patient-centered" healthcare system that allows for competition and choice.

The author, Matt Kibbe, argues that Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Senate Democrats are refusing to compromise and instead are holding the government hostage by stripping the defunding language from the continuing resolution. Kibbe also criticizes President Obama for his handling of the law, citing his own words from the 2004 Democratic National Convention, where he promised to unite the country.

The article concludes by advising House and Senate Republicans to stick to their guns and pass the continuing resolution without funding Obamacare, and to go home and watch the "Chicken Littles on the left" tell the country that the sky is falling.

Title: Congressional Republicans Seek Inspiration from Elvis to Pass ObamaCare Replacement Bill

Article:

Congressional Republicans are working to pass a replacement bill for ObamaCare, and they may be drawing inspiration from the King of Rock and Roll, Elvis Presley. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, one of the authors of the health care blueprint, said, "We have a choice. We can act now or we can keep fiddling around and squander this opportunity to repeal ObamaCare."

The Republican-led effort to repeal and replace ObamaCare is a complex and challenging process. The GOP can only lose 21 votes before the measure fails on a party-line vote. The Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative lawmakers, has a bylaw that requires its members to vote as a bloc if 80 percent of its members feel the same on a given issue, which could be enough to kill the bill.

The Trump administration has deployed Budget Director and Freedom Caucus founder Mick Mulvaney to liaise with congressional Republicans, and Vice President Pence has also paid a visit to the Freedom Caucus. Pence told the group that the bill was still open for negotiation, but some lawmakers are skeptical.

The Freedom Caucus is a key player in the Republican effort to repeal and replace ObamaCare. The group has a reputation for being fiercely independent and has been known to buck the party line. Some conservative lawmakers and interest groups are criticizing the GOP legislation, calling it "ObamaCare-lite."

The passage of the Republican health care bill comes down to the numbers. The GOP can only lose 21 votes before the measure fails on a party-line vote. The Freedom Caucus has a bylaw that requires its members to vote as a bloc if 80 percent of its members feel the same on a given issue, which could be enough to kill the bill.

The margin to pass this bill could be tight. Consider the narrow vote engineered by Pelosi to pass ObamaCare. Ryan and other Republican leaders must earn the support of skeptics in their own party, not antagonize them.

Title: Republican Presidential Candidates Debate Nuclear Agreement with Iran

The debate over the nuclear agreement with Iran, signed in Vienna a month ago, has sparked a discussion among Republican presidential candidates about the best approach to ensure the country's national security. The agreement, which lifted sanctions on Iran in exchange for limitations on its nuclear program, has been opposed by all Republican candidates. Some, like Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin, have vowed to "tear up" the accord on their first day in office, while others, like Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, have taken a more cautious approach.

However, few candidates have outlined what they would replace the agreement with or how they would prevent Iran from resuming its nuclear program if the deal is abandoned. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has proposed reimposing sanctions waived by the Obama administration and working with Congress to impose new sanctions, but has not specified what would happen if other countries refuse to cooperate.

The debate has also drawn attention to the importance of ensuring "sustainable outcomes" after American troops leave, a lesson learned from the Iraq and Afghan wars, according to General Ray Odierno, the retiring Army chief of staff. The debate highlights the tension between short-term and long-term results, as well as the balance between American strength and weakness.

Title: Decline of Local Newspapers Linked to Political Polarization

The decline of local newspapers has had a significant impact on the way people consume news and, subsequently, their political views. A recent study has found that the loss of local newspapers leads to political polarization, making governing more difficult both locally and nationally.

In the past decade, local newspapers have struggled to stay afloat, with ad revenues plummeting by 66% and the workforce shrinking by 47%. This decline has resulted in a significant decrease in the availability of local news, leaving many Americans without a reliable source of information about their communities.

The study, which examined the effects of local newspaper closures on political polarization, found that voters are 1.9% more likely to vote for the same party for president and senator after a newspaper closes in their community. This may seem like a small margin, but it can be enough to swing an election.

The researchers also found that the decline of local newspapers is not just a matter of people switching to national news, but rather a shift towards partisan voting. The study's findings suggest that when people lose their local newspaper, they turn to their political partisanship to inform their political choices.

The study's authors argue that local newspapers provide a valuable service to democracy by keeping readers' focus on their communities. When they lose local newspapers, readers turn to their political partisanship to inform their political choices. If Americans can support local news with their dollars and attention, it could help to push back against the partisan polarization that has taken over American politics today.

The study's findings have significant implications for the future of American democracy. As local newspapers continue to decline, it is essential to find ways to support and preserve this vital source of community news and information.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Report Confirms Al Qaeda Involvement in Benghazi Attack

The Senate Intelligence Committee has released a comprehensive report on the 2012 Benghazi attack, which definitively concludes that individuals tied to Al Qaeda groups were involved in the incident. The report challenges recent claims that the terror network was not a factor in the attack.

The report, released on Monday, states that individuals affiliated with terrorist groups, including Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), participated in the September 11, 2012, attacks. The militant Ansar al-Sharia, which was labeled as a terror group by the State Department last week, was also involved.

The report does not implicate Al Qaeda's core leadership, believed to be in the Pakistan region, but does blame some of its influential branches. The report suggests that the attack was not highly coordinated but rather opportunistic, possibly put in place in short order after protests over an anti-Islam film elsewhere in the region.

The report also delves into what went wrong at the U.S. mission in Benghazi before the attack. The committee determined that the attack was preventable and that the administration failed to respond to ample warnings that security was deteriorating before September 11, 2012. The report faults the State and Defense departments for their handling of the situation.

The report highlights multiple "tripwires" that were crossed, signaling security problems, including an August 16, 2012, cable from Ambassador Chris Stevens raising security concerns and prior attacks on westerners in Benghazi. The report also details a possible failed ambush where attackers tried to lure the CIA into the hospital where Stevens' body was being held.

The report's findings aim to put conspiracy theories to rest, according to Senate Intelligence Committee Chairwoman Dianne Feinstein. Sen. Saxby Chambliss, the top Republican on the panel, said the report provides "needed and deserved answers."

Title: Iowa Democratic Caucuses Results Show Tight Race Between Buttigieg and Sanders

The Iowa Democratic caucuses have concluded, with former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) in a virtual tie, according to the latest results. With 97% of precincts reporting, Buttigieg has 26.2% of state delegate equivalents, while Sanders has 26.1%, a difference of just three votes out of 1,097.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) trails with 18.2%, followed by former Vice President Joe Biden with 15.8%, and Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) with 12.2%. No other Democratic presidential candidates broke the double-digit level in state delegate equivalents.

In the popular vote, Sanders leads with 26.5%, compared to Buttigieg's 25%, a difference of about 2,500 votes. Warren is in third place in the popular vote, with over 18,000 votes.

The Iowa Democratic Party chairman, Troy Price, stated that full results should be released by Thursday morning, and an independent review will be conducted. The caucuses were marred by technical problems, but the results are expected to be finalized in the coming days.

Title: Trump Gains Ground in Polls, Narrowing Gap with Democratic Contenders

A recent CNN/SSRS poll has found that former Vice President Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump 49% to 44% in a potential general election matchup. This marks a significant shift, as the Democratic margin in head-to-head matchups has narrowed by at least 5 points since October. Trump's approval rating has remained relatively stable throughout his presidency, consistently trailing his most likely Democratic opponent by high single to low double digits.

The poll also shows that Trump has gained ground against other leading Democratic contenders, including South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. In the 15 closest states of the 2016 election, where the presidential contest was decided by 8 or fewer points, Trump's in a stronger position, with none of the Democrats leading in CNN's December poll.

The shift in Trump's favor coincides with an upward movement in his personal popularity, with his net favorable rating standing at -6 points among voters in CNN's latest poll. This is an improvement from his previous net favorability ratings of -12 points in the two prior CNN polls.

The economy appears to be a key factor in Trump's upward trajectory, with 76% of voters saying it is good in the CNN poll, the highest percentage since 2001. The impeachment inquiry does not seem to be having a significant impact on the polls, as fewer voters consider it an extremely or very important issue to their vote.

Additionally, Trump's opponents are not as popular among their own party's voters as he is among Republicans. This could change once the primary ends, but for now, Trump is in a stronger position than he was in October. While he still trails Biden and Sanders in the average poll, he has narrowed the gap and is in a better position than he was just a few months ago.

Title: Trump's Approval Rating Remains Unchanged After Putin Press Conference

The approval rating of President Donald Trump has remained largely unchanged in the first polls to emerge after his widely criticized performance at a joint press conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll showed Trump's approval rating rising to 45%, his highest level since taking office, while the Economist/YouGov survey showed no significant deviation from his previous week's numbers.

The polls included responses before and after Trump's July 16 news conference with Putin, meaning it's possible that a more pronounced negative impact could show up in the next wave of polls. However, there is currently no evidence of such an effect.

Democratic strategists attribute Trump's resilience to several factors, including the strength of the economy, his voters' tendency to discount negative press coverage as "fake news," and his visceral connection with his base, partly due to his willingness to press cultural hot buttons relating to race, immigration, and related issues.

However, Democrats also argue that Trump's base is not big enough to bring sustained electoral success, either in November's midterm elections or in his 2020 reelection race. Robert Shrum, a Democratic strategist, noted that Trump's approval ratings have been low by historical standards and that his base is in deep trouble for the 2018 election.

The polls also showed that the share of Americans who strongly approve of Trump, 29%, was far outweighed by the 44% who strongly disapprove. This could mean that Democrats can expect greater intensity among their base, which could be vital since Democratic-leaning voting blocs tend to turn out less reliably in midterm elections.

On the other hand, the same poll showed that the Democrats' lead in the so-called generic ballot, where voters nationwide are asked which party they would prefer to control Congress, had shrunk to 6 percentage points, a notable slippage from the 10-point advantage the party enjoyed just a month before. This raises questions about the idea of a "blue wave" that might sweep Democrats into power in the House or Senate after November.

Despite the mixed signals, many Democrats remain confident that things will go their way in November. Tad Devine, a senior adviser to Sen. Bernie Sanders, believes a takeover of both the House and Senate is a real possibility for Democrats. He noted that the party does not need to adopt a one-size-fits-all approach to framing the election and that candidates can run unique campaigns tailored to their districts.

The article concludes that opinions diverge as to why Trump commands such strong loyalty from his base of support, with some attributing it to economic factors and others to his ability to tap into voters' emotions and anxieties. For now, the idea of a Trump collapse looks increasingly unrealistic, at least in the short term, giving his opponents and supporters plenty of food for thought.

Title: Former IRS Commissioner's Ties to Left-Leaning Group Raise Questions Amid IRS Scandal

The former commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), Douglas Shulman, has faced scrutiny over his role in the agency's targeting of conservative groups during his tenure. However, new information has emerged about his personal connections to a left-leaning organization, which may raise questions about his impartiality.

Shulman's wife, Susan L. Anderson, is a senior program adviser for Public Campaign, a Washington-based group that claims to be nonpartisan and works with a broad range of organizations to reform campaign finance rules. However, the group receives significant funding from liberal organizations, including the Ford Foundation, Barbra Streisand's The Streisand Foundation, and Health Care for America NOW, a coalition of labor unions supporting ObamaCare.

Public Campaign has been vocal about its views on campaign finance, stating that the wealthiest Americans, specifically the top 1 percent, are trying to buy or influence elections by secretly donating to political groups. The group produced a "holiday card" video in which one person criticized the Koch brothers, successful businessmen aligned with conservative and libertarian causes, for their philanthropic efforts.

When the scandal over the IRS's targeting of conservative groups broke, Public Campaign defended the tax agency, suggesting that the misdeeds of a "few bad apples" within the agency would make it harder to ask questions about bias. Anderson has also been involved in the Occupy Wall Street movement and participated in Occupy DC events.

Shulman was appointed commissioner by former President George W. Bush and logged over 100 visits to the White House during the Obama administration, although he denied any knowledge of the IRS's targeting of Tea Party groups during congressional testimony last month. The exact nature of his relationship with his wife's employer and his own visits to the White House remain under scrutiny.

**US Prepares to Issue Guidance on Reducing Unnecessary COVID-19 Testing**

The United States is working to reduce the number of COVID-19 tests conducted on individuals who have already completed home quarantine, with the goal of cutting turnaround times for tests. According to Brett Giroir, assistant secretary for health at the US Department of Health and Human Services, such tests are "clogging up the system" and are not necessary for most individuals.

Giroir explained that people who have completed home quarantine do not need to be retested unless they are critically ill or have a weakened immune system, which could cause them to shed the virus for longer than seven or eight days. The goal is to streamline the testing process and reduce the burden on the healthcare system.

Currently, only 26 states are able to produce test results within three days, with one state taking more than five days. The US government is working to transition away from lab-based tests, which can have longer turnaround times, to point-of-care tests, which can provide results in minutes and can be conducted in a wider variety of locations.

The US government expects to have 20 million point-of-care tests available per month by September, with Becton Dickinson announcing on Wednesday that the US government has agreed to purchase 750,000 of its point-of-care tests. The new guidance on testing is not a result of shortages, but rather a recognition that many tests are unnecessary and can be eliminated without compromising public health.

Title: Biden Expresses Regret to Anita Hill Over Handling of 1991 Testimony, But She Remains Unsatisfied

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, who launched his third presidential campaign on Thursday, reached out to Anita Hill earlier this month to express his regret over the way he handled her testimony during the 1991 Supreme Court confirmation hearings. Hill, a law professor, accused Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during the hearing, which was chaired by Biden as the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

According to Hill, Biden's apology was not sufficient, as she believes real change and accountability are needed. "I can't be satisfied by simply saying I'm sorry for what happened to you," she told The New York Times. "I will be satisfied when I know there is real change and real accountability and real purpose."

Biden has previously apologized for allowing an all-male and all-white panel of lawmakers to aggressively question Hill during the hearing. His role in the hearing has come under renewed scrutiny in light of the #MeToo movement and the 2018 Supreme Court hearing of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, who denied accusations of sexual assault.

Hill emphasized that Biden needs to take responsibility for his actions and give an apology not only to her but also to other women and the American public. "The focus on apology to me is one thing," she said. "But he needs to give an apology to the other women and to the American public because we know now how deeply disappointed Americans around the country were about what they saw. And not just women. There are women and men now who have just really lost confidence in our government to respond to the problem of gender violence."

A spokesperson for Biden's 2020 campaign confirmed the private discussion between Biden and Hill, stating that Biden shared his regret for what Hill endured and his admiration for her work in changing the culture around sexual harassment. Biden publicly addressed his treatment of Hill last month at an event in New York City, saying, "She faced a committee that didn't fully understand what the hell this was all about. To this day, I regret I couldn't give her the kind of hearing she deserved. I wish I could have done something."

Hill's comments come as Biden faces allegations from several women who have accused him of unwanted, inappropriate behavior. In response, Biden said, "Social norms are changing. I understand that, and I've heard what these women are saying. Politics to me has always been about making connections, but I will be more mindful of personal space in the future. That's my responsibility, and I will meet it."

Title: Facebook Study Examines Partisan News Consumption on Social Network

Facebook, the world's most widely used social network with over 1.3 billion users, has been scrutinized for its role in shaping public discourse. According to the Pew Research Center, about 30% of American adults get their news from Facebook. A recent study published in Science, conducted by Facebook's researchers, aimed to shed light on the social network's impact on national discourse.

The study analyzed how users engage with news on Facebook, focusing on the point of view of articles and the frequency of clicks on conflicting stories. Researchers found that users tend to share articles that align with their political ideologies, with Fox News stories being shared mainly by conservatives and Huffington Post articles by liberals. The study also measured how often users' feeds displayed stories that conflicted with their professed ideologies and how often they clicked on those stories.

The study's findings suggest that Facebook's algorithm does not create a significant echo chamber, but rather, users tend to self-select the news they consume. However, some academics have raised concerns that Facebook's constant tweaking of the News Feed could lead to a more isolated and polarized online environment.

The study's results were reviewed by an anonymous panel of scholars unaffiliated with Facebook, and the journal Science warned reviewers to disclose any financial ties that could be perceived as a conflict of interest. The study's methodology was substantively different from a previous study that sparked controversy, in which Facebook altered the number of positive and negative posts users saw to examine the effects on mood.

While the study's findings may be seen as convenient for Facebook, they do not necessarily absolve the social network of its responsibility in shaping public discourse. As David Lazer, a political scientist at Northeastern University, noted in a commentary published alongside the study, "A small effect today might become a large effect tomorrow. The deliberative sky is not yet falling, but the skies are not completely clear either."

Title: Rep. Matt Gaetz Introduces Resolution Calling for Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Recusal

Article:

Representative Matt Gaetz (R-FL) has introduced a resolution calling for Special Counsel Robert Mueller to recuse himself from the investigation into the Trump campaign's potential collusion with Russia. Gaetz, along with Representatives Louie Gohmert (R-TX) and Andy Biggs (R-AZ), cite Mueller's involvement in the "Uranium One" controversy, which occurred during his tenure as FBI director.

The Uranium One scandal refers to a deal approved by the Obama administration that allowed a Russian company to purchase a controlling interest in Uranium One, a Canadian mining company. The deal has been frequently used by Republicans to shift the focus away from Mueller's investigation towards the story. However, it is important to note that there is little evidence to support the claim that Hillary Clinton, as Secretary of State, approved the sale in exchange for donations to the Clinton Foundation.

According to the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS), Clinton did not have the authority to approve or veto the sale, as it was a decision made by the president. None of the other eight members of the CFIUS or President Obama voted against or blocked the sale, as it posed no national security risk.

Despite the lack of evidence, some Republicans continue to argue that Russia obtained 20% of the American uranium supply, which is not accurate. The Russians were only interested in Uranium One to create productive uranium mines in Kazakhstan.

A recent report found that roughly 20 Republican Senators have expressed support for Mueller and his investigation. However, there is still a faction on the right that believes Mueller should resign. A resolution introduced by Gaetz and his colleagues is expected to gain more support from the House Freedom Caucus.

The White House has stated that President Trump has "no intention" of firing Mueller, but Trump himself has left the possibility open. His personal lawyer, Jay Sekulow, stated that Trump could only terminate a special counsel for cause, and there is no basis for cause at the moment. However, Trump has hinted at one issue he has with the Mueller investigation that could give him cause.

In a recent interview with The New York Times, Trump responded to a question about Mueller's focus on the Trump family finances, saying "I would say yeah. I would say yes." This resolution shows that if Trump were to fire Mueller, he would have the support of some members in Congress.

Title: The Decline of Community Organizations and the Impact on Society

The article discusses the decline of community organizations and its impact on society. French historian Alexis de Tocqueville visited the United States in the 1830s and was fascinated by the non-political community organizations Americans had created. These groups, clubs, and organizations played a unique role in society, bringing people together and creating a sense of community. Over the years, Americans created organizations such as Kiwanis, supper clubs, Shriners, churches, bowling leagues, and countless others. These groups raised thousands of dollars for local charities and volunteered countless hours, meeting needs and working for change.

However, since the height of social clubs and civic organizations in the 1960s, membership has more than halved. Political scientist Robert Putnam raised the alarm about this trend in his 2000 book "Bowling Alone." He found that participation in league bowling had dropped 40 percent in just over a decade. Putnam's research showed that Americans are isolating themselves, with a decline in community activities such as attending club meetings, having family dinners, and having friends over.

The decline of community organizations has led to an increase in political polarization. In the past, neighbors with competing political views could come together at community events, but today, most Americans have few or no friends with opposing political views. People are reading and watching their own side's news almost exclusively, and communities are coming apart at the seams.

The article concludes by encouraging readers to recommit to their communities and find ways to build relationships with people who disagree with them. The author argues that sharing freedom and changing hearts and minds depends on forming real relationships with people who disagree with us, and that this is almost impossible in a climate like today's.

Title: Republican Leadership Signals Shift Away from Infighting and Gridlock

The Republican congressional leadership is sending a clear message that they will not tolerate infighting and gridlock in the new session, according to reports from Politico. Just days after their midterm victories, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner are vowing to work together to pass legislation and avoid repeating the mistakes of the past.

McConnell has reportedly indicated that he will not use the debt ceiling as leverage for spending cuts, a move that triggered the government shutdown last year. Instead, he is focusing on finding common ground with President Barack Obama and working on issues that both parties can agree on. In his victory speech, McConnell emphasized the importance of cooperation, stating that the GOP has a "duty" to work with the White House on issues they agree on.

Boehner, too, is taking a more conciliatory approach, saying he plans to be a "responsible leader" and emphasizing the need for the party to be unified to take advantage of its political dominance. The leadership may feel more justified in demanding loyalty from the conservative wing of the party, given that the victories from this election cycle were mainly the result of the party's early backing of establishment candidates, some of whom are from moderate districts.

The legislative agenda set by Boehner and McConnell prioritizes helping the struggling middle class, with a first step being the passage of many bills the House has already approved. By enacting these measures early in the new session, the leadership hopes to signal that the logjam in Washington has been broken and establish a foundation of certainty and stability that both parties can build upon.

The leadership will also be aware that unity could be paramount to maintaining the Senate majority in 2016, when a number of senators from blue and purple states are up for re-election.

Title: Republicans Soften Stance on Marijuana, Embracing Decriminalization and Legalization

The Republican Party is shifting its stance on marijuana, with several prominent figures advocating for a softening of federal laws and even legalization. This marks a significant departure from the party's previous stance, which was characterized by opposition to marijuana use and legalization.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been a vocal advocate for leaving the issue of marijuana to the states, while Texas Governor Rick Perry has pointed to drug courts in his state as a step towards decriminalization. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has gone further, vowing to scrap the "failed war on drugs" altogether.

The shift in the Republican Party's stance on marijuana is a response to changing public opinion and the growing acceptance of marijuana use. In 2012, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney promised to fight against marijuana legalization, even for medical use. However, in recent months, some prominent Republicans have recalibrated their stance, embracing the idea of being "smart on crime" rather than "hard on crime."

Public opinion is also shifting, with voters in two states, Colorado and Washington, approving referendums allowing adults to possess limited amounts of marijuana for personal use. More than 12 states have decriminalized possession of small amounts of marijuana, and some are poised to follow Colorado and Washington by allowing recreational use.

The Obama administration has taken a more lenient approach to marijuana, giving states leeway as long as they do not see evidence of criminal gangs trafficking the drug or children gaining access to it. This has made marijuana an issue in states that will be important in the 2016 elections, including New Hampshire, which hosts the first-in-the-nation presidential primaries.

While some Republicans remain opposed to marijuana use, others are embracing the idea of decriminalization and legalization. Representative Steve Vaillancourt, the Republican sponsor of a bill legalizing marijuana for recreational use in New Hampshire, hopes that his party will not be on the wrong side of history on this issue.

The shift in the Republican Party's stance on marijuana is a significant development, as it marks a departure from the party's previous opposition to the drug. While some Republicans still oppose marijuana use, others are embracing the idea of decriminalization and legalization, reflecting changing public opinion and the growing acceptance of marijuana use.

Title: North and South Korea Leaders Meet Amid Efforts to Revive US-North Korea Summit

Article:

Leaders of North and South Korea met in the demilitarized border area between the two countries, marking the second meeting between South Korea's President Moon Jae-in and North Korea's Kim Jong-un. The meeting comes as both sides continue efforts to revive the historic US-North Korea summit, which was previously cancelled by US President Donald Trump.

The latest talks were held on the northern side of the Panmunjom truce village, with Mr. Moon's office stating that the leaders exchanged opinions on the successful holding of the North Korea-US summit. The outcome of the talks will be announced by Mr. Moon on Sunday morning.

In Washington, the Trump administration confirmed that an advance team of White House and Department of State officials will travel to Singapore this weekend to prepare for a possible summit between Trump and Kim. The talks, if they proceed, will focus on ways to denuclearize the Korean peninsula and reduce tensions.

The meeting between the two leaders comes after Trump cancelled the scheduled summit last Thursday, citing "tremendous anger and open hostility" from North Korea. However, Trump later tweeted that "very productive talks" had taken place with North Korea on reinstating the summit with Kim.

The goals of both sides appear to differ on what denuclearization means. The US wants to see the complete and irreversible dismantling of North Korea's nuclear program and weapons, allowing international inspectors to verify every step of the process. North Korea, on the other hand, wants a more reciprocal agreement, where it would give up its nuclear assets in exchange for comparable gestures from the US.

The US has a large military presence in South Korea and Japan, which North Korea would like to see scaled down. It also wants assurances that its survival as a state would never be in question.

The meeting between the two leaders is a significant step towards improving relations between the two countries, which have been strained in the past. In April, the leaders of both Koreas held a historic meeting at the border, promising to end hostilities and work towards the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

Title: Senator Cory Booker's Confrontation with Nielsen Raises Questions about Civility in Politics

Article:

In a recent hearing, Senator Cory Booker (D-NJ) confronted Kirstjen Nielsen, the Secretary of Homeland Security, over her role in the Trump administration's immigration policies. The exchange sparked controversy, with some critics accusing Booker of mansplaining and manterrupting Harris, a female senator. While some have defended Booker's actions, others have condemned them as a display of sexism and disrespect.

The incident highlights the ongoing debate about civility in politics, with some arguing that identity politics and "respect for women" are often used as a double standard. The article notes that if a conservative male senator had treated a progressive female cabinet secretary with similar disrespect, liberals would be quick to condemn it as proof of sexism.

The author, David French, argues that incidents like this one demonstrate the hypocrisy of the Left's claims about "norms," "values," and "civility." He notes that many conservatives have been critical of Trump's behavior, but that the Left has been slow to condemn similar behavior from their own members.

French also references the Iran-Iraq War phase of conflicts over civility, suggesting that the only norm left is hypocrisy. He concludes that the only way to restore civility and dignity to public debate is to treat people with respect, even when angry, and to speak with regret rather than outrage.

The article does not take a stance on the political affiliations of the individuals involved or the policies at stake, instead focusing on the broader implications of the incident and the state of civility in politics.

Title: Trump Orders Tariffs on Remaining Chinese Imports, Escalating Trade War

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has ordered his trade chief to begin the process of imposing tariffs on all remaining imports from China, a move that underscores the lack of progress in talks aimed at ending the escalating trade war. The tariffs would subject around $300 billion worth of Chinese imports to punitive duties, according to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.

Lighthizer stated that a final decision on the new duties has not been made, which would come on top of an earlier tariff rate increase to 25% from 10% on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports. Despite the escalation in tariffs, Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said they would continue talks, avoiding the worst-case scenario of a complete breakdown in negotiations between the world's two largest economies.

The U.S. and China have held "candid and constructive conversations" on the status of their trade relationship, Trump said on Twitter. Liu later told Chinese state media that China and the U.S. had agreed to hold more talks in Beijing, with differences remaining over "principal issues" but the talks being constructive and not broken down.

China had dealt the talks a major setback last week by proposing extensive revisions to a draft trade agreement, which included deleting prior commitments that Chinese laws would be changed to enact new policies on issues from intellectual property protection to forced technology transfers. The issue dominated the talks between Liu, Lighthizer, and U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Thursday and Friday, with no progress made as Liu sought to defend the changes.

Major U.S. stock indexes reversed course to close higher after Mnuchin called the talks "constructive," while yields on U.S. government debt also drifted higher. The new 25% U.S. duty is being imposed on over 5,700 categories of products, applied to products leaving China after 12:01 a.m. EDT on Friday. The biggest sector affected is a $20 billion-plus category of internet modems, routers, and similar devices.

The higher tariffs could reduce U.S. gross domestic product by 0.3% and China's by 0.8% in 2020, according to consultancy Oxford Economics. Some in the manufacturing sector are concerned that the policies could backfire if the dispute with China is not resolved soon.

Title: Romney's VP Pick: A Safe Choice or a Game-Changer?

Article:

Mitt Romney is reportedly close to announcing his vice presidential running mate, and conventional wisdom suggests he will choose a "safe" candidate with conservative credentials and a presence in a swing state. However, some argue that Romney's pick should be someone who can attract undecided voters, rather than simply appealing to his base.

One potential candidate who could fit the bill is Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City. Bloomberg has a reputation for being a compassionate leader with traditional Republican views, who has successfully governed in a diverse region and has a track record of reducing deficits through a combination of revenue increases and spending cuts.

Bloomberg's views on taxation are also noteworthy. He has written in the Wall Street Journal that Republicans who emphasize economic freedom should stop promising a "free lunch" and instead focus on making tough decisions on spending cuts and revenue increases. This kind of honest assessment is exactly what voters on the fence are looking for.

While Bloomberg has not endorsed Romney, he has stated that he believes Romney would do a better job of running the country than President Barack Obama. However, he has not endorsed him due to their differences on social issues. Romney's social politics have shifted towards the right, which Bloomberg used to align with before he started pandering to the religious right.

Picking a safe, conservative running mate may not be the best strategy for Romney, as it may alienate independents who are wary of a social policy agenda hijacking the attention away from the economy. Instead, Romney should consider a candidate who can bring a fresh perspective and a track record of success, like Bloomberg.

Title: Migrants at US-Mexico Border Wait for Asylum Processing

A group of migrants, including a pregnant woman and her two young sons, have been waiting at the US-Mexico border for weeks, seeking asylum in the United States. Gabriela Hernandez, a 27-year-old mother of two, was chosen by her fellow migrants to be one of the first eight people to begin the process of seeking asylum.

Hernandez and her sons, ages 6 and 2, had fled a threat of violence in Honduras and had been traveling for a month before reaching the US-Mexico border. However, officials at the San Ysidro port of entry told them that they had reached capacity and were unable to process any additional migrants without proper documentation.

The migrants, including Hernandez, have vowed to camp outside the center until every last one is admitted into the United States. When customs officials began processing the cases of "undocumented arrivals," the migrants looked among themselves for who should step forward. Hernandez, who had traveled 3,000 miles with her sons, was chosen to be one of the first eight people to begin the process.

As Hernandez and her sons waited, they shared a pizza and some fries and wings with another migrant, Tesla Rich, who had left her 9-month-old daughter with someone at the crossing. Rich had left her daughter with someone at the crossing, worried about her daughter's safety.

The migrants have been waiting for hours, sometimes days, for their chance to seek asylum in the United States. Hernandez and her sons have been living in a processing center, where they have been given limited resources and have had to rely on volunteers for food and blankets. The migrants have been facing harsh conditions, including rain and cold weather, and have had to rely on each other for support.

Hernandez's journey has been documented by CNN, and she has spoken about her fears and hopes for her future. She has said that she is worried about her children's well-being and is unsure of what the future holds. Despite the challenges, Hernandez remains hopeful that she will be able to find safety and a new home in the United States.

Title: State Attorneys General Join Forces to Investigate Big Tech, Adding Pressure to Federal Regulators

A bipartisan group of attorneys general from 48 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico has announced plans to investigate Google's advertising business, while a smaller group led by New York's Letitia James is probing Facebook's business practices. This development adds pressure to federal regulators, who are already investigating the tech giants. The state-led probes are seen as a way to supplement the federal investigations and potentially hold the companies accountable for any anticompetitive practices.
