The group of state attorneys general, led by D.C. Attorney General Karl Racine, emphasized their independence from federal regulators and vowed to conduct their own investigation. "The state attorneys general, they are an independent bunch," Racine said. "And they can be quite tenacious. So I'm very confident that this bipartisan group is going to be led by the facts and not be swayed by any conclusion that may fall short, if you will, if it's inconsistent with our facts."

The mobilization of this large group of attorneys general could indicate a level of dissatisfaction among top state legal officials with federal action against Big Tech. Federal regulatory action against Facebook and Google has had little impact on their core businesses or stock prices. The Federal Trade Commission recently slapped Google with a $170 million fine for allegedly violating a law protecting children online, while the FTC's record $5 billion settlement with Facebook over its use of user data resolved all claims against Facebook and its executives.

State attorneys general have played a significant role in past cases, gaining concessions from tobacco companies and pressing Microsoft in a landmark antitrust case. However, experts note that state investigations can add heat to federal probes but ultimately pale in comparison to the resources of the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice. "The big picture here is that states can serve as a backstop if the federal government decides not to go after these companies," said Rutgers Law professor Michael Carrier. "You're putting 30 generally small offices together and then they have to coordinate. It's good, but it's not quite the same as the extent of the staffs on the federal level."

Title: Facebook to Allow Remote Work, but Salary Adjustments to Follow

Facebook Inc. CEO Mark Zuckerberg has outlined the company's future remote-working plans, which will allow about half of its employees to work from home five to 10 years from now. However, there is a catch for those expecting to take their Silicon Valley salaries and live in a rural area. According to Zuckerberg, employees who choose to work remotely must notify the company if they move to a new area before January 1, 2021, and their salaries will be adjusted based on the location.

Facebook already pays its employees based on location, but Zuckerberg emphasized that salaries will be adjusted to reflect the cost of living in the area. This means that employees working remotely in areas with a lower cost of living will receive lower salaries. The company will also take taxes into account when making these adjustments.

The move is part of Facebook's effort to become more diverse in its workforce and recruit talent from a broader range of locations. Currently, about 95% of Facebook's employees are working from home due to coronavirus stay-at-home orders. The company has said that workers will be able to work from home at least through the end of the year.

Zuckerberg noted that about 45% of employees who said they would want to work remotely full-time are "pretty confident" that they would move to another place if given the opportunity, while an additional 30% said they "might" move. About 60% of those surveyed said they would prefer to move to a smaller city or town.

The median employee compensation at Facebook was over $240,000 in 2018, while the median home price in Menlo Park, California, where the company is headquartered, is $2.4 million. The median home price in the wider Bay Area was $928,000 last year.

Title: The Russia Email Leak: A Calmer Perspective on "Election Hacking"

The recent sanctions imposed by President Obama against Russia for allegedly interfering with the U.S. election process have sparked heated debates about the nature of the email leaks and their impact on democracy. Hillary Clinton has described the leaks as an "attack against our country" and "our electoral system," while others argue that the information revealed was simply a form of voter education, helping citizens make more informed decisions.

The term "election hacking" has been used to describe the leaking of emails stolen from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and John Podesta, Clinton's campaign chairman. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals that the hacking was likely a case of phishing, where hackers tricked employees into revealing their passwords. The leaked emails contained information about the DNC and Podesta's personal and professional lives, including their opinions on various political issues.

The New York Times reports that the emails were obtained through standard phishing techniques, and that every major publication, including The Times, published multiple stories citing the D.N.C. and Podesta emails posted by WikiLeaks. The information in the emails concerned matters of legitimate public interest, such as the DNC's disdain for Clinton rival Bernie Sanders, excerpts from her secret Wall Street speeches, and observations about her weaknesses as a candidate.

Valuable journalism often involves obtaining or divulging information that was obtained illegally by individuals with axes to grind. It is difficult to see how this case is different in principle. The nationality of the informants may be a factor, but it is not the only consideration. If the emails had been swiped by Americans, would Hillary Clinton still be talking about a democracy-threatening attack on the electoral process?

The article concludes that cybersecurity is a serious concern, especially when it comes to systems that control important functions such as vote counting, banking, and the distribution of electricity. However, helping politicians conceal facts that might alienate voters probably does not belong in the same category.

**China Expresses Confidence in Reaching Trade Deal with US Despite Fresh Warnings**

China has expressed confidence in reaching a trade deal with the United States, despite fresh warnings from President Donald Trump that he would revert to more tariffs if the two sides fail to resolve their differences. The Chinese Commerce Ministry made the statement on Wednesday, following a period of relative quiet from Beijing after Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping reached a temporary truce in their trade war at a meeting over dinner in Argentina on Saturday.

According to the ministry, China will try to work quickly to implement specific issues already agreed upon, as both sides "actively promote the work of negotiations within 90 days in accordance with a clear timetable and road map." The ministry called the latest bilateral talks "very successful" and expressed confidence in implementation.

Trump, via Twitter, held out the possibility of an extension of the ceasefire but warned tariffs would be back on the table if the talks failed to bear fruit. He said he would place "major tariffs" on Chinese goods imported into the United States if his administration is unable to reach an effective trade deal with Beijing.

The threat of further escalation in the trade war between the world's two largest economies has loomed large over financial markets and the global economy for much of the year. Investors initially greeted the ceasefire with relief, but the mood has quickly soured on skepticism that the two sides will be able to reach a substantive deal on a host of highly divisive issues within the short negotiating period agreed.

The White House says China had committed to start buying more American products and lifting tariff and non-tariff barriers immediately, while beginning talks on structural changes with respect to forced technology transfers and intellectual property protection. Sources told Reuters that Chinese oil trader Unipec plans to resume buying U.S. crude by March after the Xi-Trump deal reduced the risk of tariffs on those imports.

Global financial markets tumbled on Tuesday as doubts over what could realistically be accomplished in the tight negotiating window added to concerns about fading global growth. The benchmark Shanghai stock index closed down 0.6 percent on Wednesday.

Despite the challenges ahead, China's Foreign Ministry referred specific questions to the Commerce Ministry, which is due to hold its weekly news briefing on Thursday in Beijing. The ministry expressed hope that the two working teams from both sides can strengthen consultations and reach a mutually beneficial agreement soon.

Title: Harvard University Honors Eight African Americans for Contributions to Black History and Culture

Harvard University's Hutchins Center for African & African American Studies has announced the names of the eight recipients of this year's W.E.B. Du Bois Medal, an award that honors individuals from around the world for their contributions to African American culture and the life of the mind. The medal is named after William Edward Burghardt "W.E.B." Du Bois, a scholar, pan-Africanist, NAACP founder, and the first African American to earn a doctorate from Harvard.

The Du Bois Medal has been awarded since 2000 and is Harvard's highest honor in the field of African and African American Studies. Past recipients include notable figures such as Chinua Achebe, Ava DuVernay, Eric Holder, Muhammad Ali, and LL Cool J.

This year's recipients include Colin Kaepernick, a former NFL quarterback who has been a vocal advocate for racial justice and equality; Dave Chappelle, a renowned comedian known for his sharp commentary on racial issues; Bryan Stevenson, founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative; Kenneth Chenault, former CEO of American Express and a champion of diversity in corporate boardrooms; Shirley Ann Jackson, a physicist and the first black woman to earn a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Pamela Joyner, a philanthropist and art collector; Florence Ladd, a novelist and poet; and Kehinde Wiley, an artist known for his portraits of prominent figures, including Barack Obama.

The ceremony honoring the W.E.B. Du Bois Medal recipients will take place on October 11 at Harvard's Memorial Hall, with tickets available for free.

Title: The Distinction Between Upward Mobility and Actual Progress

The concept of upward mobility has been a topic of discussion in recent times, with many studies claiming that America has lost its ability to provide opportunities for those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds to rise. However, a closer examination of the definition of upward mobility reveals a crucial distinction between the opportunity to rise and the actual achievement of rising. This distinction is often overlooked in most studies, which can lead to misinterpretation and misattribution of the results.

The notion that everyone should have an equal chance to achieve a particular goal is a common misconception. In reality, people have different aspirations, values, and interests, which can influence their choices and outcomes. For instance, not everyone may have the desire to become a doctor or scientist, just as not everyone may have the aptitude or interest in ballet. This does not necessarily mean that there are "barriers" created by society preventing them from achieving their goals.

Furthermore, the idea that every demographic group should be equally represented in all areas is an unrealistic expectation. Different groups have different agendas, values, and priorities, which can lead to varying outcomes. For example, women may not be as interested in computer engineering as men, and that is not necessarily a result of societal barriers. Instead, it may be a reflection of their own choices and priorities.

Recent studies have shown that certain groups, such as Asian Americans and American-born Mormons, have achieved significant upward mobility, debunking the notion that it is impossible for people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds to rise. These findings suggest that the concept of upward mobility is more complex and multifaceted than previously thought.

In conclusion, the discussion around upward mobility should focus on the distinction between opportunity and actual progress, as well as the diverse aspirations and values of different groups. Rather than blaming societal barriers for the lack of representation, we should recognize the complexity of human choices and outcomes.

Title: Conservative Commentator Criticizes Rubio's Immigration Reform Proposals

Conservative commentator Ann Coulter has joined other Republicans in criticizing Senator Marco Rubio's immigration reform proposals, stating that his efforts are aimed at creating more Democratic voters. In a column for Human Events, Coulter argued that Rubio's plan is nothing but amnesty, making illegal aliens legal and failing to provide adequate border security and enforcement mechanisms.

Rubio's proposal, which is being worked on with a group of four Democrats and four Republicans, aims to provide a comprehensive overhaul of the current immigration system. However, Coulter believes that the plan's first step is to grant illegal aliens the right to live and work in America legally, which she views as a "wolf in wolf's clothing."

Rubio has defended his efforts, stating that Republicans are not anti-immigration and that his bipartisan plan is designed to avoid the problems that plagued the 1986 immigration bill, which granted amnesty to three million illegal immigrants but failed to provide adequate border security and enforcement mechanisms. He emphasized the need for beefed-up border security, workplace enforcement, and a visa tracking system.

Other Republicans, such as Louisiana Senator David Vitter and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, have also criticized Rubio's proposals, with Vitter calling them "naive" and Bush stating that some in Congress are looking for "quick fixes" to the problem.

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Address: A Mixed Bag of Familiar and Contradictory Ideas

The recent foreign policy address delivered by Donald Trump, touted as a challenge to Washington's accepted wisdom, has sparked fierce political debate. While some have praised Trump's speech as a bold and refreshing departure from the status quo, others have criticized it for its simplistic slogans, contradictions, and misstatements. This article will examine 10 passages that suggest Trump may be having his cake and eating it too.

One of the most striking aspects of Trump's speech was his call to challenge radical Islam through "philosophical struggle" as well as military force. This idea could have come from the lips of Barack Obama, and it is a notion that has been widely accepted by both Republicans and Democrats. However, Trump's supporters argue that he was at his strongest, skewering the inconsistencies of the Democratic establishment's approach under Obama and Clinton.

Despite the familiar tone, Trump's speech was also filled with contradictions. He stated that some groups "will never be anything but our enemies," but later claimed that the world must know that the US does not go abroad in search of enemies. He promised to make America a reliable friend and ally again, but then delivered warnings about paying for NATO membership that could be seen as blackmail.

Trump's speech also raised questions about his approach to promoting democracy in the world. He claimed that the US is getting out of the nation-building business, but then added that he will work with allies to reinvigorate Western values and institutions. He also argued that promoting Western civilization and its accomplishments will do more to inspire positive reforms around the world.

The speech also contained some questionable claims. Trump stated that there are scores of recent migrants inside the US charged with terrorism, an assertion that is already disputed. He also claimed that the US will no longer surrender to the "false song of globalism," but this phrase has been used by anti-globalization groups in the past.

One of the most notable aspects of Trump's speech was its lack of transparency. He claimed that Obama was snubbed during recent state visits to Cuba and Saudi Arabia because he was not greeted at the airport by a senior leader. However, this claim does not stand up to scrutiny, as the Queen's decision to send the Lord-Lieutenant of Essex to meet Obama at London's Stansted airport was a standard practice.

In conclusion, Trump's foreign policy address was a mixed bag of familiar and contradictory ideas. While some of his supporters may see it as a bold and refreshing departure from the status quo, others will view it as a simplistic and inconsistent approach to international relations. As the world waits to see how Trump's policies will unfold, it is clear that his speech has sparked a lively debate about the role of the US in the world.

Title: Hillary Clinton Takes a Strong Stance on Immigration, Distinguishing Herself from Republican Rivals

Article:

Hillary Rodham Clinton, a presidential candidate, took a significant step forward in her stance on immigration during a speech in Las Vegas on Tuesday. She emphasized her support for a path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the United States. Clinton also promised to take executive action to defer the deportations of those with strong ties to the community through family and work, going beyond the actions taken by President Obama.

Clinton's stance sets her apart from her Republican rivals, who have been hesitant to support a path to citizenship. Senator Marco Rubio, a former advocate of sensible reform, has since been swayed by the Tea Party and now proposes a provisional status for undocumented immigrants, which would require a long and difficult path to a temporary work permit. Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, has been moderate in the past but is unclear about his support for citizenship, leaving many in his party uncertain about his stance.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky speaks compassionately about immigrants at times, but his agenda focuses on sealing the border and ending the 14th Amendment guarantee of citizenship by birth. Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin wants all unauthorized immigrants to leave the country and limits legal immigration. While it's early in the campaign, Clinton's full-throated commitment to expansive immigration action is a welcome surprise.

Clinton's stance is a departure from her previous reluctance to address the issue. Last fall, she dodged questions from young advocates known as Dreamers with a discouraging non-answer, "Elect more Democrats." However, her recent speech suggests she may prove herself a strong defender of immigrants' rights.

Title: Trump Sues Banks to Block Release of Financial Records to Congress

The US President, Donald Trump, has filed a lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One, two banks involved in his real estate projects, to prevent them from complying with subpoenas issued by Democrat-led congressional committees. The subpoenas seek information on his financial dealings, which the Trump Organization claims are without legitimate or lawful purpose.

The lawsuit, filed in New York on Monday, argues that the subpoenas are an attempt to harass the President and his family, and that no grounds exist to establish any purpose other than a political one. The filing also suggests that Democrats are hoping to stumble upon something they can use as a political tool against the President.

The House Intelligence and Financial Services Committees issued the subpoenas earlier this month, seeking documents and materials related to the bank's relationship with Trump and his family. The committees are investigating allegations of potential foreign influence on the US political process.

Representatives Adam Schiff and Maxine Waters, the Democratic chairmen of the House Intelligence and Financial Services Committees, described the lawsuit as "meritless" and said it shows the depths to which President Trump will go to obstruct Congress's constitutional oversight authority. They emphasized that Congress will not be deterred from carrying out its constitutional responsibilities.

In 2017, Deutsche Bank rejected requests by Democrats in the House of Representatives to provide details of the President's finances, citing privacy laws. It was also reported that special counsel Robert Mueller had ordered Deutsche Bank to provide records of Trump's accounts during his investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia.

Title: Summer Lunch Program Provides Meals for Millions of Children, but Raises Questions About Eligibility

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) funds a summer lunch program that provides meals for over 3 million children across the country, with over 30,000 sites available. The program is designed to provide a valuable resource for families who struggle to afford meals, but critics argue that it may be a convenient freebie for those who are not in need.

The "Summer Fun Cafe" in northern California, and similar programs like it, offer meals to anyone 18 and under, with no income requirement, enrollment, or paperwork required. The San Juan Unified School District's nutrition director, Monique Stovall, stated that all children in the community in that age range can come and eat for free.

While the program aims to provide a healthy meal to children, critics argue that it may be open to abuse, with some questioning whether taxpayers are footing the bill for children from wealthy families. Jon Coupal, with the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, asked, "If someone is coming from a family that makes a quarter-of-a-million dollars a year, and they're not checking eligibility when they're coming in the door, I think most people would wonder, 'Am I paying for this?'"

For many low-income families, the free lunch means more money can go toward other meals or necessities. For those who can afford to feed their children, it's an easy way to get fed and go. One mom, Julie Marks, said, "Normally we wouldn't qualify for a free lunch, but we're close and it's convenient, and my kids like it – that's important."

Charity and nonprofit groups help sponsor free meal sites in their community, and organizers contend that the summer lunch program is easier to administer when the location qualifies, as opposed to the user. Monitors are on hand to ensure that the lunch is eaten on site and that adults do not mooch off the kids. The program's goal is to provide a healthy meal to children, and supporters believe that after a summer of nourishing meals, these kids will do better when school resumes in the fall.

Title: Republican Senators Introduce Amendment to Replace Columbus Day with Juneteenth as Federal Holiday

Article:

In the aftermath of George Floyd's death, protests against racial inequality have led to the removal of a Christopher Columbus statue in Boston, Massachusetts. Amidst this backdrop, Republican Senators Ron Johnson and James Lankford introduced an amendment to replace Columbus Day with Juneteenth as a federal holiday. This proposal follows a bipartisan Senate bill introduced by Senator John Cornyn, which would establish Juneteenth as a federal holiday.

The amendment aims to offset the costs associated with Cornyn's plan, which estimates that each new federal holiday would cost around $600 million in paid time off for government employees. Senator Lankford stated that the goal is to celebrate the progress made towards becoming a more perfect union, while being mindful of the impact on federal services and local businesses.

Senator Johnson emphasized that they support celebrating emancipation with a federal holiday, but believe it should be achieved by eliminating an existing holiday, such as Columbus Day. They chose Columbus Day as a holiday that is lightly celebrated and least disruptive to Americans' schedules.

Juneteenth, commemorating the day in 1865 when slavery definitively ended in the U.S., is currently celebrated in 47 states. The holiday has gained increased attention amid nationwide protests following George Floyd's death in police custody. Protestors have removed and vandalized statues of Christopher Columbus, with some calling for Columbus Day to be eliminated or renamed Indigenous Peoples' Day, citing his mistreatment of the New World's native population.

Senator Cornyn expressed concerns about eliminating Columbus Day in favor of Juneteenth, stating that it would "dilute the message we're trying to send, which is one of being respectful and honoring and remembering our history."

Title: Trump Tweets Support for CoronaVirus Relief Bill After Chaotic Negotiations

The House of Representatives passed the CoronaVirus Relief Bill on Saturday morning, with President Trump expressing his approval in a tweet. The bill, which aims to provide relief to those affected by the outbreak, was the result of intense and constant negotiations between Democrats and Republicans. The process was marked by confusion and contradictions, with key officials on both sides providing conflicting information about the status of the deal.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced a deal had been reached shortly after 6 p.m. on Friday, but House Republicans and even the No. 2 House Democrat, Steny Hoyer, said talks were still ongoing and a deal had not yet been reached. The bill still had some outstanding issues, including a tax credit for paid family sick leave, with Republicans seeking more flexibility for small business owners.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin surprised even his own party by announcing an agreement with Pelosi on Fox Business, but the deal was later confirmed by House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy. The bill will now be voted on in the House, with Trump tweeting his support and urging both parties to come together and vote yes.

One of the major obstacles was Trump's personal demand for a payroll tax cut, which has little support on Capitol Hill and will be debated as part of future coronavirus crisis-related legislation. McCarthy confirmed that Republicans will push for the payroll tax cut in the next tranche of economic relief, which could come later this month or in April.

Title: Republicans Offer Competing Ideas on Healthcare After ObamaCare Replacement Effort Fails

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell acknowledged on Monday that the current approach to repeal and replace ObamaCare would not garner the necessary votes, citing the opposition of two more senators. As a result, the Senate will consider a repeal-only bill passed in 2015. This move is backed by conservatives, who argue that Congress should pass a bill that repeals the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and start from a clean slate.

President Trump also expressed support for the repeal-only approach, tweeting that Republicans should "REPEAL failing ObamaCare now & work on a new Healthcare Plan that will start from a clean slate. Dems will join in!" However, this bill does not appear to have the votes to pass, and other GOP lawmakers are calling for working with Democrats or passing an alternative GOP bill.

Some Republicans, like Senator John McCain, are advocating for a bipartisan approach to stabilize ObamaCare markets, which could include funding for cost-sharing reductions and reinsurance. However, conservative members, including Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn, have objected to this idea, arguing that it would simply throw more money at the healthcare law.

Senator Lindsey Graham proposed an alternative approach, which would give states a chunk of money and allow them to decide whether to keep much of ObamaCare or try something new. This approach has been criticized from both the left and right.

The Congressional Budget Office previously found that the 2015 repeal-only bill would lead to 32 million more uninsured people over a decade, with premiums nearly doubling. Despite these concerns, conservatives are pushing for a clean repeal vote.

Title: President Trump Surprises Troops in Afghanistan with Thanksgiving Visit

President Donald Trump surprised troops and news outlets on Thanksgiving morning by visiting Afghanistan to thank them for their service and help serve a turkey dinner. The visit required extreme security measures to ensure both safety and secrecy. Trump's journey began on Wednesday evening, when he snuck out of Mar-a-Lago and flew out of an undisclosed airport in Florida on a small, undisclosed plane. The plane was bare-bones, with only four blue leather chairs and a port-a-potty, and phones were taken from all onboard, including senior White House officials.

As part of the security measures, Trump greeted the crew but remained in the cockpit for takeoff. The plane landed at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland, where Trump switched to Air Force One, which was not lit up on the tarmac but was instead hidden in a hangar. The plane took off from JBA with all interior lights off and the windows drawn.

The plane landed in Afghanistan on a pitch-black runway, and the pool was only allowed to take pictures of Trump's arrival from a nearby van. Accompanying Trump were White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham, Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien, Deputy Press Secretary Judd Deere, and Senator John Barrasso.

Grisham stated that only a tight circle of White House officials knew about the trip, and the White House even scheduled tweets to be sent out from the president's account during the internet blackout. "It's a dangerous area and he wants to support the troops," Grisham said. "He and Mrs. Trump recognize that there are a lot of people who are away from their families during the holidays and we thought it would be a nice surprise."

After serving and sitting down for a Thanksgiving dinner, Trump took as many pictures as time would allow with troops. He then met with Afghan President Ashraf Ghani, who was notified only a few hours prior due to security concerns. Trump finished his trip by addressing a few hundred cheering troops in the hangar on the airfield, bringing Ghani on stage to also express his appreciation to the American troops. Trump told them that everyone was working hard to bring them back home. "We will continue to work tirelessly for the day when all of you can go home to your families... and that day is coming very soon," he said.

Title: Multiple Casualties Reported in Westminster Attack, Investigation Underway

A terrorist incident occurred in Westminster, London, on Wednesday, leaving multiple people injured and several fatalities. The attack occurred when a car swerved onto Westminster Bridge and crashed into a fence around Parliament, causing chaos and panic.

Eyewitnesses described the scene as "daunting" and "terrifying," with one witness, Kirsten Hurrell, stating that she saw a body lying on the ground and called emergency services. Another witness, Robert Vaudry, said he was told the car had already mowed down a number of people on Westminster Bridge before the incident.

Radoslaw Sikorski, a former foreign minister of Poland, was in a taxi on Westminster Bridge when the pedestrians were hit by the other vehicle. He described the scene as "chaotic" and said he saw several people lying on the ground, including one person who was unconscious and bleeding heavily.

Andrew Bone, executive director of the Responsible Jewellery Council, was on a bus heading towards Victoria Station when it was stopped at the edge of Parliament Square. He initially thought an action movie was being shot, but quickly realized the gravity of the situation as the bus was evacuated and he saw the vehicle that had crashed into a railing.

The incident is the latest in a string of attacks in which vehicles have been used to kill people, with similar incidents reported in France, Germany, and Israel. Jeremy Shapiro, a former State Department official, said that the London attack is consistent with the recent pattern of attacks, citing the use of improvised weapons and a desire to target softer targets.

The incident is under investigation, with police cordoning off the area and urging everyone to move back past Downing Street. The attack is a stark reminder of the threat of terrorism and the importance of vigilance and cooperation between law enforcement agencies.

Title: Trump Drops Choice for US Spy Chief Amid Questions Over Experience and Resume

Article:

Washington (D.C.) - President Donald Trump has withdrawn his nomination for John Ratcliffe to become the Director of National Intelligence, a move that comes after questions arose about the congressman's lack of experience and possible exaggerations in his resume. The decision marks the latest upheaval over a top national security post.

Trump announced the move five days after he surprised many in Washington by selecting Ratcliffe, a conservative Republican lawmaker from Texas, to replace Daniel Coats as director of national intelligence. The position oversees the 17 U.S. civilian and military intelligence agencies, including the CIA.

According to a source familiar with the situation, Trump is considering Republican Representatives Michael McCaul and Devin Nunes for the job. McCaul is a former chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, and Nunes is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee.

Trump told reporters at the White House that he has a list of three people he will consider for the job this weekend. The Republican president blamed unflattering news coverage for Ratcliffe's decision to withdraw and instead remain in the House. Ratcliffe, 53, faced a potentially difficult Senate confirmation process.

The vacancy comes as the U.S. intelligence community grapples with an array of challenges, including the threat of foreign interference in next year's U.S. elections, the impact of a rising China, escalating tensions with Iran, North Korea's nuclear program, and the desire to end years of conflict in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria.

Trump announced last Sunday that Coats, who had clashed with him over assessments involving Russia, Iran, and North Korea, will step down on August 15. Ratcliffe, a Trump loyalist and the most junior member of the House Intelligence Committee, had been tapped but not formally nominated to replace Coats.

The change in leadership at the top of the U.S. intelligence community comes after a half-year of turmoil atop the Pentagon. The Senate on July 23 confirmed Army Secretary Mark Esper as defense secretary, ending the longest period that the Pentagon had been without a permanent top official, a stint that began after James Mattis resigned in December over policy differences with Trump.

Trump's previous pick for defense secretary, Patrick Shanahan, withdrew in June after reports of domestic violence in his family. The post of director of national intelligence was created after the September 11, 2001, attacks on the United States.

Ratcliffe confirmed he had withdrawn from consideration, saying he did not want a national security and intelligence debate surrounding his confirmation to become a purely political and partisan issue. Ratcliffe gained attention by defending Trump and criticizing former Special Counsel Robert Mueller during a July hearing on Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election.

Although Ratcliffe had touted his counter-terrorism experience as a federal prosecutor in Texas, media outlets reported on concerns that he may have exaggerated his achievements in the post. Democratic lawmakers and some former senior U.S. intelligence officers had said Ratcliffe lacked the expertise and experience to replace Coats. Some voiced concern that he would warp U.S. intelligence to support Trump's views. Ratcliffe served for six months on the intelligence panel.

Trump said he might name the No. 2 intelligence official, Sue Gordon, as acting director of national intelligence. That is required when there is a vacancy in the top job. Such a move would likely be reassuring to many U.S. intelligence experts because of her deep experience. However, some Trump allies, according to a source familiar with the matter, were floating the possibility of instead naming CIA Director Gina Haspel as acting director until a permanent director is confirmed by the Senate.

Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr said while he was "heartened" that the office of the director of national intelligence has an experienced team in place during the transition, "there is no substitute for having a Senate-confirmed director in place" leading it. Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, a critic of Ratcliffe for the job, said in a statement, "The next Director of National Intelligence must be someone who is nonpartisan, sees the world objectively and speaks truth to power."

Title: US Retailers Impose New Gun Restrictions Following Florida School Shooting

In the aftermath of the recent shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida, where 17 people lost their lives, two major US retailers, Dick's Sporting Goods and Walmart, have announced new restrictions on gun sales. Dick's Sporting Goods, with over 600 stores, has stopped selling assault-style rifles and has backed "common sense gun reform." Walmart, the largest seller of guns in the US, has raised the minimum age for buying guns and ammunition to 21 years old.

The move comes as students and teachers returned to classes at the affected school, with grief counselors on hand to support those affected by the tragedy. The shooting, which occurred on February 14, has sparked widespread outrage and calls for action on gun control. Several companies, including Hertz car rental, United Airlines, and Delta Airlines, have ended discounts to the National Rifle Association (NRA).

Walmart has removed items from its website that resemble assault-style rifles and stopped selling high-powered rifles in its stores in 2015, citing low demand. In a statement, Walmart said, "We take seriously our obligation to be a responsible seller of firearms."

In Washington, President Donald Trump urged lawmakers with diverse views to come up with a comprehensive bipartisan solution to address gun violence. While some Republican leaders have rejected raising the minimum legal age to buy rifles from 18 to 21, Trump expressed willingness to consider the idea.

Meanwhile, a teacher in Georgia was arrested after barricading himself in a classroom and firing a handgun, although no one was injured. Dick's Sporting Goods has announced a new policy that includes not selling assault-style rifles, banning high-capacity magazines, and not selling firearms to anyone under the age of 21.

The company's CEO, Edward Stack, acknowledged that the decision may spark a backlash from some customers, but emphasized the need to address gun violence. The Parkland shooting suspect, Nikolas Cruz, bought a gun at Dick's, but not the weapon he allegedly used in the attack, Stack said.

As students returned to school, many were visibly shaken and expressed concerns about the possibility of another attack. Lyliah Skinner, a 16-year-old student, said, "We're not going to really be learning much today - it's all about healing." David Hogg, a senior student and activist, expressed trepidation about the possibility of another attack, saying it was "really hard to think about" what occurred two weeks ago.

The handling of the shooting by authorities has sparked criticism, with the FBI and local police facing criticism for failing to follow up on multiple tips about the suspect, Nikolas Cruz. The school's Building 12, the site of the shootings, will remain closed and cordoned off indefinitely. Florida's State House and Senate will soon begin reviewing proposed bills related to firearms, which need their approval and that of Governor Rick Scott.

Title: Power Cuts Plague Middle East, Disrupting Daily Life

Power outages have become a common occurrence in the Middle East, causing frustration and disruption to daily life for millions of people. In Egypt, a recent power cut during a hysterectomy operation highlights the severity of the issue. The patient, who was awake but numb under spinal anesthesia, was forced to endure the ordeal for over an hour and a half, with doctors using cellphones as makeshift light sources.

Egypt is not alone in its struggles. Neighboring Libya has seen frequent power cuts, with residents in Tripoli reporting outages lasting up to 14 hours a day. In Benghazi, city resident Ahmed Amir Neihoum described the experience as "like the end of the world."

The Gaza Strip has also struggled with power outages, with the territory's only power plant damaged in the recent conflict with Israel. The result is a severe shortage of electricity, with only 36% of the population's needs being met.

In Iraq, Baghdad has suffered from frequent power cuts, with many residents unable to afford generators. The situation has been exacerbated by the country's ongoing conflict and lack of investment in its electrical infrastructure.

Lebanon is also experiencing power cuts, with an ongoing strike by electrical company workers threatening to make matters worse. The country's power rationing has been exacerbated by the influx of over 1 million Syrian refugees.

In Syria, power cuts have contributed to worsening health conditions, with damaged water infrastructure, hot weather, and overcrowded shelters all contributing to water shortages and outbreaks of waterborne diseases.

The power outages are not limited to these countries, with many other nations in the region experiencing similar issues. The root causes of the problem vary, but common factors include a lack of investment in electrical infrastructure, conflicts, and economic instability.

In a televised address, Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi acknowledged the severity of the issue, urging the public to be patient and understanding. However, many residents are growing frustrated with the situation, with some considering leaving the country due to the instability.

**New Zealand Bans Assault Rifles Following Christchurch Mosque Attacks**

New Zealand has banned all assault rifles, high-capacity magazines, and military-style semi-automatic rifles in response to the country's deadliest massacre in history. The ban, announced by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, takes effect immediately and will be followed by legislation next month.

Ardern stated that the ban is necessary to prevent similar attacks in the future and to ensure the safety of the nation. She emphasized that gun ownership is a privilege, not a right, in New Zealand. The country's citizens are being asked to turn in their banned weapons, and an amnesty will be put in place for those who do so.

The ban comes after the Christchurch mosque attacks, which left 50 people dead and many more injured. The alleged shooter, who was arrested and charged with murder, used two legally purchased semi-automatic rifles modified with 30-plus round magazines to carry out the attacks.

New Zealand's gun laws are being tightened in response to the tragedy. The country's cabinet will implement a buyback plan for banned weapons, and there will be tightly regulated exemptions for some owners, such as hunters and farmers.

Ardern has also emphasized the importance of denying the alleged shooter the notoriety he sought. "He is a terrorist, he is a criminal, he is an extremist, but he will, when I speak, be nameless, and to others I implore you: Speak the names of those who were lost rather than the name of the man who took them," she said.

The ban is part of a broader effort to address gun violence in New Zealand. The country has fewer restrictions on rifles or shotguns than many countries, and the rate of gun ownership is relatively high. However, the ban is seen as a significant step towards reducing gun violence and ensuring the safety of the nation.

Title: UK Anti-Racism Campaigners Call for Neo-Nazi Satanist Group to be Outlawed as Terrorist Organization

The anti-racism campaign group Hope Not Hate has released its annual State of Hate report, urging the British government to outlaw the Order of Nine Angles (ONA), a neo-Nazi Satanist group, as a terrorist organization. The report highlights the group's increasing online presence and its influence on young extremists in the UK and beyond.

According to the report, the ONA's ideology, which combines Nazi and Satanist beliefs, encourages violence, criminality, and sexual offending. In the past year, four teenagers linked to the ideology have been jailed in the UK for terror offenses, with one individual convicted of preparing for a terror attack by attempting to alter himself in line with instructions from ONA texts.

The report notes that the ONA's terminology and trappings have become increasingly popular among the wider far-right, and its "sick ideas" have drawn in young extremists, nourishing a culture of unprecedented depravity. Yvette Cooper, chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee, has called on the Home Secretary to immediately refer the ONA to the government's proscription review group.

A Home Office spokesperson stated that the government is taking action to "root out and dismantle the groups that promote extreme right-wing views" and is providing police with the tools and resources they need to tackle the threat. The spokesperson also noted that the list of proscribed terrorist organizations is kept under review.

Counter-terrorism police have previously spoken about the increasing amount of work relating to "niche ideologies" such as violent Satanism. The ONA's influence has been linked to the Sonnenkrieg Division, an extreme right-wing organization that was added to the UK's list of proscribed terrorist groups last week.

Title: Former Vice President Joe Biden's Political Leanings Spark Debate Among Democrats

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, the most recent candidate to file for the Democratic presidential nomination, is being considered a moderate by many. This assessment is a testament to the significant shift the Democratic Party has taken to the left. According to some, a Democratic politician is considered moderate if they do not support the removal of 180 million Americans from private health insurance and into a government system, restrict third-trimester abortions, and prioritize deportation as part of the immigration regime. These positions were once considered compatible with the Democratic creed, but are now being rejected by left-wing activists who dominate the party's primaries.

In the progressive media, Biden is being criticized for not expanding his indictment of President Donald Trump to include an indictment of America for electing him. The effort to win the primaries may prompt Biden to move further left, as he has already denounced the legal system as "white man's law," possibly due to its emphasis on the presumption of innocence. Reporters may seek clarification on this point.

It is essential to note that Biden has consistently supported left-wing causes throughout his career, including higher taxes, hate-crimes laws, and liberal judicial activism. Conservatives should not be misled into believing he is a moderate, and neither should actual moderates.

Title: Parents of ISIS Victims Urge Trump Administration to Prioritize Bringing Home Remaining American Hostages

The parents of victims of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi are calling on the Trump administration to work with them to bring home remaining American hostages and detainees from around the world. The Trump administration has prioritized the return of American hostages during its presidency, with President Trump naming some of the innocent Americans killed by ISIS during his announcement of al-Baghdadi's death.

The parents of some of Baghdadi's victims, including Dianne Foley, the mother of American journalist James Foley, and Carl and Marsha Mueller, the parents of aid worker Kayla Mueller, appeared on Fox & Friends to express their gratitude for the president's actions so far. However, they emphasized that more needs to be done to bring home the hundreds of innocent Americans still detained or taken hostage.

Dianne Foley, whose son James was beheaded by ISIS in 2014, commended the administration for prioritizing the return of American hostages, but urged the intelligence community to find Americans before tragic events occur. Carl and Marsha Mueller, whose daughter Kayla was kidnapped in 2013 and reportedly forced to have sex with Baghdadi before being crushed by debris in an airstrike, have conducted their own private investigation outside of the government and are seeking the U.S. government's help to bring their daughter home.

The Muellers have been working to bring Kayla home since August 2013 and are asking President Trump to work with them to bring home the remaining American hostages.

Title: Congressman's Alleged Request to Abort Pregnancy Raises Questions About Consistency on Abortion Stance

Article: A recent report by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette has shed light on an alleged incident involving Rep. Tim Murphy, a Pennsylvania congressman known for his anti-abortion stance. According to documents obtained by the newspaper, Murphy asked his girlfriend, Shannon Edwards, to terminate a pregnancy in January. The pregnancy was later determined to be a false alarm.

The revelation has sparked questions about Murphy's consistency on the issue of abortion. Murphy has been a vocal advocate for anti-abortion legislation, including the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, which would ban abortion care after 20 weeks' gestation. He has also sponsored the bill, which is set to be voted on in the House on Tuesday.

In a statement, Murphy acknowledged that he had asked Edwards to consider abortion, but claimed that he had not written the anti-abortion posts on his professional Facebook account. He also stated that he had told his staff to stop writing the posts, which he described as "discouraging."

The incident raises questions about Murphy's stance on abortion and whether he applies a different set of ethics to his own life than to the lives of the millions of U.S. women his votes affect. This is not the first time an anti-abortion legislator has faced similar allegations. Rep. Scott DesJarlais of Tennessee, who is still in office, has been accused of supporting his wife's two abortions and telling a 24-year-old woman with whom he was having an affair that she needed to have an abortion to "get on with their lives." DesJarlais is also sponsoring the 20-week abortion ban.

The controversy surrounding Murphy's actions highlights the importance of consistency in one's beliefs and actions. While individuals have the right to their personal opinions and beliefs, public figures like Murphy have a responsibility to uphold their values and principles, especially when it comes to issues that affect the lives of millions of people.

Title: Senator Ted Cruz Apologizes to New Yorkers for "New York Values" Remark

Article:

Senator Ted Cruz of Texas delivered a stump speech at North Greenville University in TIGERVILLE, S.C., where he addressed the topic of "New York values." Cruz, known for his conservative views, used the term to describe his rival, Donald J. Trump, who is from New York. The remark sparked backlash from New York residents and elected officials, who felt it was an attack on the state and its values.

In response, Cruz issued a faux apology, stating he was "happy to apologize to millions of New Yorkers" on social media and in remarks to reporters. During his speech, he elaborated on his apology, saying he was apologizing to "millions of New Yorkers who've been abandoned for years by liberal politicians," as well as those who want jobs, but are affected by fracking bans, and those who support pro-life and pro-marriage causes. He also mentioned small businesses fleeing the state due to high taxes and regulations.

Cruz's speech was met with a mix of reactions from the audience, with some grumbling at his theatrical tone. However, he seemed pleased with the delivery, saying he hoped his apology was what those seeking it were looking for. The senator's speech demonstrated his knowledge of New York politics and its various issues, including conflicts between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the NYPD, as well as debates around charter schools.

Title: Trump Administration Prepares to Provide Aid to Farmers Affected by Tariffs

The Trump administration is planning to provide $12 billion in emergency aid to farmers affected by the ongoing trade war, according to reports. This move comes as the agricultural industry faces significant financial turmoil due to tariffs imposed by the administration.

Tariffs have been a contentious issue, with President Donald Trump declaring them "the greatest" on Twitter. The administration has imposed tariffs on imported steel, aluminum, and electronics, leading foreign countries to retaliate with tariffs on American agricultural products such as soybeans, dairy, pork, apples, and potatoes.

The impact of tariffs on US agriculture is significant, with prices for agricultural products like soybeans dropping to a 10-year low. Farmers across different markets are growing increasingly nervous about the future of their businesses if the trade war continues.

The administration's plan, which has yet to be formally released, aims to stabilize the agricultural industry through three programs: direct financial assistance for farmers, a purchase and distribution program, and a trade promotion program. The plan will reportedly use a Depression-era program that allows the government to borrow up to $30 billion from the Treasury without congressional approval.

Some lawmakers, such as Rep. Mike Conaway (R-TX), have expressed confidence that the administration will act to help farmers "persevere" through this period. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue has also been working on tools to mitigate the impact of tariffs on the agricultural industry.

However, farmers are still uncertain about the administration's endgame and the potential long-term effects of the tariffs. Republican lawmakers from agriculture-heavy states, such as Sens. Ben Sasse (R-NE) and Chuck Grassley (R-IA), have warned the administration about the potential consequences of blanket protectionism.

The administration's plan to provide aid to farmers is a step towards mitigating the financial disaster, but farmers are still waiting for a clear plan to address the ongoing trade war.

Title: Russia Says One Crew Member Survives Downing of Warplane by Turkey, Rescued by Syrian Commandos

Russia has confirmed that one of the two crew members who ejected from a Russian warplane shot down by Turkish F-16s on Tuesday has been rescued by a Syrian commando unit in an operation that concluded early Wednesday. The news comes as international tensions continue to escalate over the incident.

According to Russian officials, the Su-24 fighter jet was flying over Syria at the time of the incident, while Turkey claims it was in Turkish airspace. The Russian crew members ejected from the plane and parachuted to the ground, but one was reportedly found dead by a Syrian rebel group. The rescued crew member was part of a 12-hour operation led by Russia's defense minister, which ended in the early hours of the morning.

Meanwhile, Russia and Turkey continue to exchange heated rhetoric, with Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu stating that Russia cannot justify its attacks on ethnic Turks in Syria under the pretext of fighting the Islamic State. However, Davutoglu emphasized that targeting Russia is "out of the question." Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov called the shooting of the plane a "planned provocation" and said Moscow is considering "reconsidering relations with Ankara." However, Lavrov emphasized that Russia has "no intention to go to war with Turkey."

In response to the incident, Russia is deploying an advanced anti-aircraft system to its base in Syria, which appears to be guarding against Turkish planes or planes from other coalition members, such as the U.S. or France. Moscow may also consider non-military forms of retaliation against Turkey, with Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev stating that "important joint projects could be canceled and Turkish firms could lose Russian market share." The two countries' economies are closely linked by energy purchases, tourism, and other business activity.

Title: Senate Close to Deal to Raise Debt Ceiling and End Government Shutdown

The Senate is reportedly 70-80% close to a deal to raise the debt ceiling and end the government shutdown, according to Senator Joe Manchin (D-West Virginia). Manchin, along with Senator Susan Collins (R-Maine), led a bipartisan group of 10 senators to draft a plan that would end the ongoing stalemate in Washington. The plan would extend the debt limit and government funding, as well as delay the 2.3% tax on medical devices and give federal agencies greater flexibility to deal with sequestration.

Senator Collins stated that the group is making progress and hopes to have an agreement soon, but declined to release any details until an agreement is reached. However, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada) rejected the plan on Saturday, citing that it "won't go anywhere at this stage."

The Senate voted on a separate procedural measure to extend the debt limit with no strings attached on Saturday, but it fell short of the 60 votes needed to proceed. Senator Collins expressed surprise at Reid's decision and believes that the plan has sparked a dialogue that did not exist before.

The framework of the deal includes verification measures to prevent people from "scamming or frauding" the health care insurance system and would require the Senate and House to go to conference to reconcile their differences and work out a long-term budget deal. The deadline for the budget conference is one of the details that has not been worked out.

The Treasury Department has stated that it will be unable to pay the government's bills unless the debt limit is increased by Thursday. The partial shutdown of government services has been in effect since October 1.

While the deal is close, a key sticking point for Democrats is sequestration, as they do not want to agree to anything that allows another round of spending limits to kick in as they are supposed to in mid-January. Republican Senator Bob Corker (R-Tennessee) believes that the Senate will come to an agreement on Monday.

The Senate reconvened briefly on Sunday afternoon but adjourned with no signs of progress on a deal. The Senate meets again on Monday at 2 p.m. ET, while the House meets at noon.

Title: Clinton Meets with FBI in Investigation into Private Email Server Use

Article:

Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump called for charges to be filed against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton after she met with the FBI regarding the agency's investigation into her use of a private email server for official correspondence. Trump tweeted that it is "impossible for the FBI not to recommend criminal charges against Hillary Clinton" and that what she did was "wrong" and what her husband Bill did was "stupid."

The Clinton campaign stated that the voluntary meeting lasted around three-and-a-half hours and took place at FBI headquarters in Washington. Clinton's campaign spokesman, Nick Merrill, said that Clinton is pleased to have had the opportunity to assist the Department of Justice in bringing this review to a conclusion and would have no further comment about the interview.

The FBI investigation is reportedly coming to a close, and the Clinton interview is considered one of the final steps in the case. Clinton's use of a private server and email address, and whether classified information was mishandled as a result, has cast a shadow over her campaign from the start.

The FBI investigation was launched last July after the discovery of emails containing classified information. The State Department's inspector general said in a blistering audit in May that Clinton and her team ignored clear warnings from State Department officials that her email setup violated federal standards and could leave sensitive material vulnerable to hackers. Clinton has said relying on a private server was a mistake but that other secretaries of state had also used a personal email address.

The FBI has already interviewed top Clinton aides, including her former State Department chief of staff Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin, a longtime aide who is currently the vice chairwoman of Clinton's campaign. The staffer who set up the server, Bryan Pagliano, was granted limited immunity from prosecution by the Justice Department last fall in exchange for his cooperation.

The emails were routed through a server located in the basement of Clinton's New York home during her tenure as the nation's top diplomat from 2009 to 2013. Dozens of the emails sent or received by Clinton through her private server were later determined to contain classified material.

Title: Satellite Images Confirm Destruction of Oldest Christian Monastery in Iraq

The oldest Christian monastery in Iraq, St. Elijah's, has been destroyed by the Islamic State (IS) group, according to satellite images obtained by the Associated Press. The monastery, located near the city of Mosul, stood for 1,400 years and was a significant historical and spiritual site for Christians.

The images, published on Wednesday, suggest that the monastery was demolished in late 2014, shortly after IS seized the city. The destruction is the latest in a series of attacks on Christian sites and communities in Iraq and neighboring Syria, where IS has targeted Christians, forcing them to convert to Islam, pay a special tax, or flee.

St. Elijah's Monastery, also known as Deir Mar Elia, was believed to have been constructed by Assyrian monks in the late 6th century. It was later claimed by a Chaldean Catholic order. In 1743, its monks were given an ultimatum by Persian forces to convert to Islam, and as many as 150 were massacred.

The destruction of the monastery is a significant loss for the Christian community in Iraq, which has been targeted by IS since the group seized control of the city of Mosul in 2014. More than 100 churches and monasteries have been destroyed or damaged in the area since then, and many Christians have been forced to flee or live in hiding.

Father Paul Thabit Habib, a Catholic priest from Mosul, warned that the destruction of the monastery is part of a broader effort to erase Christian history and culture from the region. "We see it as an attempt to expel us from Iraq, eliminating and finishing our existence in this land," he said.

The destruction of St. Elijah's Monastery is a stark reminder of the devastating impact of IS's campaign against religious minorities in Iraq and Syria. The group has also destroyed numerous pre-Islamic sites, including the ancient cities of Nimrud, Hatra, and Nineveh, as well as the historic city of Palmyra in Syria.

The destruction of the monastery was confirmed by a security source in Nineveh province, who told the BBC that IS militants had blown up the monastery, completely destroying it.

Title: Trump's Love-Hate Relationship with Mainstream Media Continues

The relationship between President Donald Trump and the mainstream media has been a topic of discussion and debate since his first press conference. The president has frequently referred to the media as the "enemy of the American people," while the media has pushed back against his claims, calling them "fake news." A recent study by the Media Research Center found that 89% of Trump's coverage by major media networks is negative.

Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski believes this negative coverage is intentional, stating that the media wants to highlight perceived failures and create a narrative that the president is not successful. Lewandowski also emphasized that Trump wants a fair shake and for the whole story to be told, without editing or chopping up interviews.

On the other hand, media reporter Paul Farhi from The Washington Post believes that Trump's public disdain for the media is a show, and that he secretly enjoys the attention and has courted the media to get his message out. Farhi noted that Trump is a "sophisticated media animal" who knows how to work the room and utilize the media to his advantage.

The question remains whether this daily drama will continue to play out over the next four years. Politico's Jake Sherman believes that Trump's behavior is unlikely to change, and that he will continue to be who he is.

Additionally, there is a potential new development in the fight between Trump and the media. The president has expressed interest in changing the country's libel and slander laws to make it easier to sue reporters and media outlets over their stories. This could be the next level in an escalating fight with no end in sight.

Title: NSA Reports Reveal Thousands of Privacy Rule Breaks Since 2008

The National Security Agency (NSA) has broken privacy rules and overstepped its authority thousands of times since 2008, according to a report released by The Washington Post on Thursday. The report, based on an audit and secret documents provided by NSA leaker Edward Snowden, challenges claims made by President Obama that the agency is not abusing its authority.

The report revealed that the NSA broke privacy rules and overstepped its authority thousands of times, including unauthorized surveillance of Americans and foreign intelligence targets in the United States. The audit counted 2,776 incidents in the preceding 12 months of unauthorized collection, storage, access to, or distribution of legally protected communications.

The incidents ranged from significant violations of law to typographical errors that resulted in unintended interceptions of U.S. emails and telephone calls. The most serious incidents included a violation of a court order and unauthorized use of data about more than 3,000 Americans and green-card holders.

Congressional Democrats have expressed concern and outrage over the revelations, with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi calling the reports "extremely disturbing." Rep. Mike Thompson, a member of the House Intelligence Committee, said the reports are "outrageous, inappropriate, and must be addressed."

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said he plans to hold another hearing in the wake of the report, stating, "The American people rely on the intelligence community to provide forthright and complete information so that Congress and the courts can properly conduct oversight. I remain concerned that we are still not getting straightforward answers from the NSA."

The Obama administration has repeatedly said that Congress was thoroughly briefed on the programs revealed by Snowden in June. However, the latest report challenges those claims, and the administration's efforts to reassure Americans and Congress that the surveillance programs are nothing to be worried about.

The report's findings have sparked renewed calls for reform and oversight of the NSA's activities. At least 19 pending bills are aimed at restraining the NSA's powers or changing how the agency is regulated, according to a count kept by the ACLU.

Title: President Obama Urges Congress to Revive Economic Stimulus Measures Amid Economic Headwinds

President Obama has asked Congress to revive a set of legislative proposals designed to stimulate the economy, citing economic headwinds from Europe and concerns about the labor market. The initiatives, first proposed in September, include investments in infrastructure, tax breaks for small businesses, and funding for teachers, firefighters, and other public sector workers. However, Congressional Republicans declined to pass the measures last year, and the Obama administration had previously moved on to other debates.

Recent economic reports have sparked concern that the economy is slowing, and further fiscal stimulus may be needed to maintain growth rates. The debt crisis in Europe and its resulting economic malaise are adding to worries, with President Obama voicing concern that American exports may slow as a result. The President emphasized the need for Congress to act, stating, "Right now, people in this town should be focused on doing everything we can to keep our recovery going and keeping our country strong – and that requires some action on the part of Congress."

However, it is unlikely that Congress will heed Obama's call, as lawmakers will recess in July and face deadlines on student loan and highway funding bills. They will return from recess to face the so-called fiscal cliff, which includes the expiration of the Bush tax cuts, middle-class protection from the Alternative Minimum Tax, and more than 50 "temporary" tax breaks for individuals and businesses. The fiscal cliff also includes nearly $1 trillion in blunt spending cuts across many areas of the federal budget.

Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has also urged Congress to move quickly to resolve the issue, stating that going over the cliff would "pose a significant threat to the recovery." He added that uncertainty over the issue's resolution could "undermine business and household confidence." Despite these pleas, lawmakers are unlikely to move quickly on legislation that would provide further stimulus or certainty to markets. Republicans find the prospect of further spending to be anathema, and election year politics is unlikely to allow for compromise.

Title: Shift in Gun Rights Movement: Nine States Implement "Red Flag" Laws, NRA's Influence Wanes

The gun rights movement in the United States has undergone a significant shift in the past year, with nine states implementing "red flag" laws that allow authorities to temporarily seize weapons from individuals deemed a risk to themselves or others. This change comes after a series of mass shootings, including those in Las Vegas, Orlando, and Sutherland Springs, which have led to a growing public demand for stricter gun control measures.

According to estimates by author Adam Winkler, the number of Americans living in states trending towards more gun control has increased to 140 million, up from around 112 million. This shift is attributed to the powerful appeals from Florida shooting survivors, which have led to a "tectonic shift" in gun policy in the US.

The National Rifle Association (NRA), once a powerful advocate for gun rights, has faced financial struggles and become embroiled in the investigation of Russian meddling in US political affairs. The organization's influence has waned, and its rhetoric has become less effective in opposing gun control measures.

The Supreme Court has also seen a shift, with President Trump installing two gun-rights-friendly justices. However, their views will be tested in a gun rights case out of New York City this spring.

Experts, such as author Robert Spitzer, note that the "rhetoric gets dulling and not very effective after a while" and that the public is less patient with the NRA's warnings of gun bans and average people having their rights endangered. The "red flag" laws, which allow authorities to seize weapons for a range of reasons, including domestic battery and social media threats, have been carried out at least 1,700 times last year.

The shift in the gun rights movement is a significant development in the ongoing debate over gun control and public safety in the United States.

Title: Republicans Revamp Immigration Policy, Offering Legal Status to Undocumented Immigrants

The Republican Party has released a new statement outlining its principles on immigration, marking a significant shift in its stance on the issue. The document acknowledges the need to provide an opportunity for legal residence and citizenship for individuals brought to the United States as children through no fault of their own. This change is a departure from the party's previous stance, which opposed the Dream Act and emphasized "self-deportation."

The new statement does not offer a "special path to citizenship" for undocumented immigrants, but it does propose a pathway to legal residence and eventual citizenship for those who meet certain requirements, such as paying back taxes, passing background checks, and learning English. This approach is at odds with President Barack Obama's proposal for a new avenue for undocumented immigrants to be naturalized.

The Republican Party's new stance is a major change, but it also raises concerns among some party members who see unauthorized migrants as an affront to the rule of law and a cultural threat. The House GOP leadership faces the challenge of balancing the needs of its conservative base with the need to appeal to Latino voters.

The new statement includes some tough but ill-considered demands, such as securing the borders and verifying their security, which some critics argue is an unrealistic goal. The document also endorses the E-Verify system, which would require the federal government to confirm the employment eligibility of every new hire in America. However, this system has been criticized for making mistakes and causing delays in hiring.

The Republican Party's new stance on immigration is a step in the right direction, but it still perpetuates the fantasy of wiping out illegal immigration by empowering government. However, the fact that the party is willing to consider a compromise and offer legal status to millions of people is a significant progress.

Title: European Union Imposes Tough New Sanctions on Russia Amid Ukraine Conflict

The European Union has adopted new economic sanctions against Russia, aimed at increasing pressure on Russian leader Vladimir Putin. The measures, coordinated with the United States, include an arms embargo and a ban on the sale of dual-use and sensitive technologies, such as advanced energy technology equipment relevant for deep sea and Arctic drilling. The sanctions also prohibit Russian state-owned banks from selling bonds or equities with a maturity of over 90 days in European capital markets.

The EU has added eight names to the list of individuals subject to EU-wide asset freezes and travel bans, including four people close to Putin. Three more entities have been added to the list of companies and organizations subject to EU sanctions due to their alleged actions against Ukraine's sovereignty or territorial integrity.

The new sanctions come amid reports of significant gains made by Ukrainian forces near the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed in July. Ukrainian forces are reportedly attempting to split the territory held by the rebels into two parts between the major cities of Donetsk and Luhansk, while the Russian-backed separatists are trying to cut off supply lines from Russia.

Igor Girkin, the top defense official in the separatist Donetsk People's Republic, stated that over 100 wounded separatist fighters had been evacuated to Russia, citing concerns about the potential "total siege of Donetsk from all sides." The self-proclaimed Prime Minister of the separatist republic, Alexander Borodai, left the rebel-held territory for Moscow, sparking speculation that the rebels are fleeing the city.

The EU's decision to impose new sanctions was made during a videoconference call between the leaders of Britain, Germany, Italy, and France, who expressed their willingness to adopt new sanctions against Russia in coordination with the US. The EU's measures will be codified in legal language and take effect on Thursday.

The Western nations are demanding that Russia halt the alleged supply of arms to Ukrainian separatists and other actions that destabilize the situation in eastern Ukraine. The EU's sanctions are part of a broader effort to pressure Russia to take concrete steps to address the crisis.

Title: Trump to Visit Seven States in Marathon Rally Sprint Ahead of Election

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump will embark on a busy Sunday, staging five rallies across seven states in a final push to the finish of the 2016 election. The rallies will take him to Denver, Colorado, Sioux City, Iowa, Minnesota, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Virginia.

Trump's day will begin in Denver, where he addressed a packed rally on Saturday evening. He will then fly to Sioux City, Iowa, where he will hold a rally at the Sioux City Convention Center at 12:00 p.m. Central Standard Time (CST). From there, he will travel to Minnesota, a state where the race is closer than expected, with Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton tied in a late September poll. Trump will address supporters at the Sun Country Airlines Hangar at 2:00 p.m. CST.

The candidate will then head to Michigan, where he will hold a rally at the Freedom Hill Amphitheater in Sterling Heights, north of Detroit, at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST). Next, he will travel to Moon Township, Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh, where he will hold a rally at the Atlantic Aviation hangar at 8:00 p.m. EST. Finally, he will hold his last rally of the day at the Loudoun Fairgrounds in Virginia at 9:30 p.m. EST.

Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton will address two events on Sunday: a get-out-the-vote event with LeBron James in Cleveland, Ohio, and a rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, at the Whittemore Center Arena with President Barack Obama at 3:00 p.m.

Title: Obamacare's Future Uncertain as Repeal Efforts Collapse

The Senate's attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has failed, leaving the healthcare law's future uncertain. President Trump has stated he is willing to "let Obamacare implode" and then reopen negotiations. Without legislation, the Affordable Care Act's fate remains unclear.

The law's health insurance marketplaces, created for individuals who don't receive coverage through employers or government programs, will likely remain stable in most parts of the country, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. Insurers are on track to have their best year in the marketplaces since 2014, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.

Some major insurance companies, such as Anthem, plan to no longer offer coverage in many areas next year due to uncertainty about federal policy. However, Centene, another insurer, is expanding its coverage areas. The Kaiser Family Foundation's Larry Levitt noted that the individual insurance market has been stabilizing but needs continued support and can be undermined by Congress.

Premiums continue to be out of reach for some people, particularly those who don't qualify for federal subsidies. The cheapest plans come with high deductibles, making it difficult to access coverage. The pool of people using the exchanges has been sicker and older than anticipated, leading to higher premiums and fewer insurance companies willing to participate.

The Obama administration's decision to allow people to keep their pre-ACA plans longer than originally anticipated kept some healthier people from moving to the marketplace. Insurers also argue that the ACA's penalties for not having coverage are too lenient and that it's too easy for people to enroll only when they anticipate needing care.

Republicans have been criticized for limiting funding in one part of the ACA that helped offset extreme losses by insurers as the marketplaces were being started. They also took the Obama administration to court to block payments to insurance companies for subsidies that reduce deductibles and co-payments for lower-income customers.
