To improve the marketplaces, lawmakers could end the dispute over cost-sharing subsidies, continue the industry support program that subsidizes the cost of the sickest customers, and expand premium subsidies. Some experts propose giving insurers incentives to sell plans in counties that would otherwise lack coverage and making families eligible for premium subsidies if plans offered by an employer aren't affordable.

The majority of gains in insurance coverage since the ACA was passed have come through the law's expansion of Medicaid eligibility, with 19 states choosing not to expand the program. However, more states are expected to do so. If the law isn't changed, 80% of the population could live in states that expanded Medicaid by 2026, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

Title: Trump's Unpopularity May Cost Republicans in Next Year's Congressional Races

The recent Democratic election victories in Virginia and New Jersey have raised concerns for Republicans, as they lost ground in suburban areas where President Donald Trump's unpopularity may have played a significant role. The results suggest that Trump's strategy of playing to a loyal but limited base has not helped broaden support for his presidency or his party.

In Virginia, Democratic candidate Ralph Northam won the governor's race by a larger margin than expected, while in New Jersey, Democrat Phil Murphy won the governor's race as expected due to the unpopularity of outgoing Republican Governor Chris Christie. The results have Democrats believing that control of the U.S. House of Representatives and the Senate, currently controlled by Republicans, may be up for grabs in next year's elections.

Some Republicans share this view, acknowledging that their party's candidates did poorly among independent, college-educated, women, and minority voters in suburban areas. Republican Senator John McCain warned that unless the party gets its act together, they will lose heavily.

Democrats would need to pick up 24 seats next year to retake control of the House. If that happens, Trump's policy agenda would be effectively dead, and the administration would come under greater scrutiny.

Trump quickly distanced himself from Republican candidate Ed Gillespie's poor showing, saying on Twitter that Gillespie "worked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for." However, Trump's leadership record appeared to motivate Democrats to vote in record numbers in Virginia, with exit polls showing many came out simply to express their displeasure with the president.

Trump's base is strong, but it's not growing, said Rodell Mollineau, a Democratic strategist. His base is made up of passionate supporters, many of whom are older white men who live in rural areas declining in population, and has shown little inclination to reach out to the majority of voters who disapprove of him.

Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster, warned that the party is on a risky track, trading fast-growing upscale suburban counties for slow-growing or declining rural areas. This is not a formula for long-term success.

There are also signs of slippage in Trump's political base. In Virginia, Gillespie campaigned hard on immigration and crime, two hot issues with the president's supporters, but did worse than expected in some rural and suburban areas that Trump easily won last year. In rural Dickenson County, considered the heart of Trump country in Virginia, Gillespie's margin over Northam was almost 7 percentage points less than Trump's margin of victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton last year.

In northern Virginia's populous suburbs, Gillespie was blown out by Northam, a sign that Trump's struggles in the presidential race may be continuing. "The suburbs came out in full force," said Matt Mackowiak, a Republican strategist. "They appear to be very motivated to try and deliver a message to Trump."

In growing Loudoun County, outside of Washington, Democrat Barack Obama barely edged out Republican Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential race. On Tuesday, Northam buried Gillespie there by almost 20 points. "I'm worried," said Ari Fleischer, a former White House spokesman for Republican President George W. Bush. "Democrats came out in huge numbers yesterday in the races and if they have that kind of enthusiasm going into 2018, it's going to be very tough sailing for Republicans."

Gillespie, a longtime Washington insider and lobbyist, tried to keep his distance from Trump personally even as he adopted some of his more combative campaign rhetoric. It was a strategy that failed, and Mackowiak said the result reflected Trump's historically low approval rating. "I don't think the White House was worried about that before, but now I think they have to be."

The five-day Ipsos tracking poll has Trump hovering around 35 percent approval nationally, with close to 60 percent of respondents disapproving of his performance in office.

Title: Michigan's Vote-by-Mail Applications Spark Legal Debate

The Michigan Secretary of State's decision to send unsolicited absentee ballot applications to all 7.7 million registered voters in the state has sparked a legal debate, with President Donald Trump claiming it is "illegally and without authorization." The Trump campaign cites a 2008 Michigan case, Fleming v. Macomb, which ruled that private entities, such as political parties, can send unsolicited absentee ballot applications to their members, but the state itself cannot.

The New York Times fact-checking article notes that the 2008 case involved sending applications to a "limited universe of voters," but this is not the basis for the court's decision. The court's ruling was based on Michigan's election statute, which does not provide express authority for state or local officials to mail ballot applications to voters who have not requested them first.

The 2018 ballot initiative, Proposition 3, amended the state's constitution to allow absentee voting for any reason, but it does not authorize state authorities to send unsolicited applications. The initiative states that voters can apply to vote by mail for any reason and that state election authorities shall have the authority to make absent voter ballots available for voting in person at additional times and places. However, it does not provide authority for state authorities to send unsolicited applications.

The fact that voters can already print ballot applications at home suggests that the state did not contemplate a need to authorize officials to mail unsolicited applications. Therefore, President Trump's claim that Michigan's effort was "done illegally and without authorization" is supported by precedent and the text of the Michigan election statute.

It is unclear whether a court would ultimately agree with the Trump campaign's argument, but they have a good legal case. The issue of funding is separate, and it is possible that the Trump campaign could withhold future funding to the state, although this could prove more politically damaging than the risk of voter fraud itself.

Title: Obama Administration's Deportation Policy Criticized for Lack of Effectiveness

The Obama administration's policy aimed at reducing the deportation of otherwise law-abiding illegal immigrants has been met with criticism from immigrant advocates, who claim it has had almost no effect. According to a recent government review, fewer than 2% of the over 400,000 pending deportation cases have been halted. The government has announced plans to close thousands more cases, but critics argue that the paltry results expose an unwillingness among immigration agents to enforce the new policy.

The policy, announced a year ago, aimed to focus on deporting convicted criminals, those who pose a clear risk to national security, and those who defraud the visa system. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) granted its agents "prosecutorial discretion" to extend leniency to DREAM Act-eligible individuals and those with clean records. This leniency took several forms, including deferred deportation and authorization to work in the U.S. legally.

Immigrant advocates and Latino leaders have criticized the Obama administration's immigration policies, citing an increase in deportations beyond those of the Bush administration. The administration's tougher enforcement has led to the deportation of a record 1.1 million people in the last three years. Critics argue that ICE is not effectively applying its newfound discretion, declining to offer the full range of options called for in the new policy, even though people in a majority of cases meet the standards.

Crystal Williams, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, stated that most people are being offered administrative closure without the option to obtain work, saying, "It's putting your file on a shelf. That's it. No other possibilities are being offered, like the settlement of cases, adjustment of status." As a result, critics predict that the new policy will clear no more than 5% of the cases.

Title: House Democrats Vow to Investigate Allegations of Trump's Possible Obstruction

Article:

House Democratic committee chairmen, Jerrold Nadler and Adam Schiff, have vowed to investigate allegations that President Donald Trump directed his former attorney, Michael Cohen, to lie to Congress about a potential real-estate development in Moscow. The allegations were published in a report by BuzzFeed News, which claims Trump instructed Cohen to mislead Congress about the extent of his involvement in the deal and when negotiations to launch the project ended.

Nadler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, tweeted that the allegations are part of a "long pattern of obstruction" and that the committee will "get to the bottom of it." Schiff, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, called the allegations "among the most serious to date" and vowed to "do what's necessary to find out if it's true."

The report claims that Trump directed Cohen to lie about the project's timeline and extent of his involvement, which Cohen later admitted to in his testimony to Congress. Cohen pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about the project's timeline, stating that it ended in January 2016, when in reality it continued until June 2016.

Trump did not directly comment on the allegations, but retweeted a Fox News story highlighting Cohen's conviction for perjury and fraud. Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, called Cohen a "convicted criminal and liar" and denied the allegations, stating that any suggestion that Trump counseled Cohen to lie is "categorically false."

The BuzzFeed report also claims that the office of Special Counsel Robert Mueller has additional evidence about the alleged deception, backed up by interviews with multiple witnesses from the Trump Organization and internal company emails, text messages, and documents.

Democratic leaders have reacted with concern and anger, pledging to investigate and establish the accuracy of the report. At least one lawmaker, Rep. Joaquin Castro, called for Trump's impeachment if the report's accuracy is proved.

**Global Virus Outbreak Continues to Spread**

A recent update on the global virus outbreak, which began in China, has reported over 31,400 cases worldwide. According to health authorities, as of Friday in Beijing, China has recorded 636 deaths and 31,161 confirmed cases on the mainland. Hong Kong has reported 22 cases, including one death, while Macao has had 10 cases.

In related news, health officials in Japan have reported 10 more people infected with the virus aboard one of two quarantined cruise ships, which has a total of 5,400 passengers and crew on board. Meanwhile, China has announced that the first group of patients are expected to start taking a new antiviral drug.

The virus, which was first detected in central Hubei province in December, has spread globally, with cases reported in multiple countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) continues to monitor the situation and provide guidance to affected countries.

Title: Speaker of the House Paul Ryan Offers Uncertain Endorsement to Donald Trump

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican, has announced his intention to vote for the Republican Party's presumptive nominee, Donald Trump, in the November election. Ryan's statement, published in an op-ed in the Walworth County Gazette Xtra, lacked the theatrical flair often associated with Trump's campaign. Instead, it presented a more measured approach, acknowledging the speaker's reservations about Trump's ideas and tone.

Ryan's endorsement, which did not use the word "endorse," was met with a statement from Trump, who expressed his "pleasure" with the speaker's decision. The two have reportedly had discussions about Trump's policy ideas and tone, with Ryan expressing concerns about specific issues, such as the proposed Muslim ban.

In his op-ed, Ryan emphasized the importance of the election, stating that it is not just a choice between two individuals, but between two visions for America. He highlighted the Republican Party's policy agenda and its potential to shape the country's future. Ryan also acknowledged the need for party unity and the importance of having a Republican president who can sign bills into law.

Ryan's statement did not provide a full-throated endorsement of Trump, but rather a reluctant acknowledgment of the need to move forward. The speaker has faced pressure from journalists to clarify his stance on Trump, and he expressed his hope that he will not have to speak out on a case-by-case basis in the future.

Title: Undersecretary of Defense for Policy John Rood to Leave Position at End of the Month

The Pentagon announced on Wednesday that Undersecretary of Defense for Policy John Rood will step down from his position at the end of the month. Rood, who joined the administration in 2018, was involved in approving $250 million in security assistance for Ukraine, which was temporarily withheld by the White House last summer.

According to CNN, Rood was asked to resign after losing the support of senior national-security leadership. Administration officials told Bloomberg that senior national-security officials had lost confidence in Rood's ability to execute President Donald Trump's agenda. Sources told Foreign Policy that Rood was asked to resign after Trump lost confidence in him following a string of departures of senior Pentagon policymakers.

In a tweet, Trump wished Rood well and thanked him for his service. Rood's resignation letter, obtained by NBC, reveals that Trump requested his resignation. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper thanked Rood in a separate statement.

The specific reason for Rood's resignation is still unclear, but multiple reports have noted his connection to the security aid to Ukraine that became the focus of impeachment proceedings. In his role at the Pentagon, Rood certified to Congress that Ukraine was eligible to receive $250 million in security assistance. That aid was temporarily withheld at the White House's direction last summer.

Rood expressed concern about withholding aid to Ukraine in an email to Esper following Trump's July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that set in motion Trump's impeachment. In the email, Rood wrote that "placing a hold on security assistance at this time would jeopardize this unique window of opportunity and undermine our defense priorities with a key partner in the strategic competition with Russia."

Title: Rubio's Strong Showing in New Hampshire Ignites Marco-Momentum

Article:

Florida Senator Marco Rubio's strong third-place finish in the Iowa caucuses has generated significant momentum for his presidential campaign. On Tuesday night, Rubio delivered his signature stump speech to a crowd of over 700 enthusiastic supporters in Exeter, New Hampshire. The speech focused on his family's immigrant and working-class roots, emphasizing his ability to unite Republican voters and appeal to lower-income and minority communities.

Rubio's message is resonating with voters, who are drawn to his personal narrative and the promise of a better life. He is framing himself as a candidate uniquely qualified to bridge the gap between the Republican Party and these traditionally Democratic-leaning communities.

In a crowded field of candidates, Rubio is standing out for his ability to deliver a consistent message and connect with voters. His campaign is banking on his strong showing in New Hampshire to propel him to the top of the pack and make him the establishment's preferred candidate.

Rubio's opponents, including Governors John Kasich, Jeb Bush, and Chris Christie, are taking aim at his inexperience and lack of a proven track record. Bush, in particular, has drawn parallels between Rubio and Barack Obama, citing their shared ability to deliver a compelling personal narrative. Christie has mocked Rubio's youth and tendency to deliver the same speech at every event.

Rubio's campaign is pushing back against these criticisms, emphasizing his ability to connect with voters and deliver a message of hope and opportunity. As the primary season heats up, Rubio's strong showing in New Hampshire has set the stage for a fierce battle for the Republican nomination.

Title: Investors Offer Alternative to Traditional Student Loans: Income-Share Agreements

Article:

A growing number of investors are offering income-share agreements (ISAs) as an alternative to traditional student loans. In an ISA, investors provide money to a college, which then offers a free or partially free education to some students. In return, the students agree to pay the college a certain percentage of their future income.

Proponents of ISAs argue that this model incentivizes students to succeed, as they only pay back the loan if they find a job. Purdue University alumnus Andrew Hoyler, who received an ISA loan, believes that this approach provides a sense of security, knowing that he'll never have to pay back more than he can afford.

ISAs also provide students with valuable information about the job market and the potential earning potential of different majors. For example, English majors may pay 4.58% of their income for 116 months, while math majors pay 3.96% for 96 months. This information can help students make informed decisions about their academic choices.

Critics of ISAs argue that they are "predatory" and make students "indentured servants." However, Purdue ISA recipient Paul Larora counters that if a student doesn't have a job, they don't have to pay anything. He believes that ISAs provide a more transparent and responsible approach to student lending.

In contrast, politicians have proposed solutions that stick taxpayers or lenders with the bill. President Barack Obama signed a student debt relief bill that aimed to "cut out private middlemen," but costs to taxpayers increased. Some politicians still blame banks for the student loan crisis, despite the government taking over student lending in 2010.

Experts argue that private lenders, with skin in the game, would be more likely to care about being paid back and provide students with valuable information about their future earning potential. This approach would also incentivize students to make informed decisions about their academic choices.

The Brookings Institution found that 28% of students don't even know they have a loan. ISAs could provide a more transparent and responsible approach to student lending, allowing students to make informed decisions about their education and future.

Title: Tea Party Divided: Rand Paul and Marco Rubio Offer Different Responses to President's State of the Union Address

The Tea Party movement is not uniformly backing either Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul or Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, who are both responding to President Obama's State of the Union address. While both senators are seen as champions of fiscal responsibility and constitutionally limited government, their approaches to the response differ.

Rand Paul, who is delivering a response sponsored by the Tea Party Express, views his speech as an "extra response" and not a direct challenge to Rubio's official GOP response. Paul's speech will focus on the debt crisis and the need for spending cuts, while Rubio's response will highlight the importance of immigration reform and the need for a more inclusive Republican Party.

The choice of Rubio as the official GOP response has led some to view him as the establishment's chosen candidate for the 2016 presidential nomination. However, others see Paul as the true champion of the Tea Party movement, which is concerned about the debt and government spending.

Jenny Beth Martin, co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, stated that both Paul and Rubio are elected officials who are fighting for Tea Party values, but some Tea Party groups are skeptical of Rubio's distance from the movement and his inaccessibility to Tea Party groups.

The differing responses from Paul and Rubio highlight the divisions within the Tea Party movement and the Republican Party, with some seeing Paul as the true representative of the movement's values and others viewing Rubio as the more inclusive and moderate candidate.

Title: Ukraine Repels Rebel Attack at Donetsk Airport as Russia Sends Second Convoy of Aid

Ukraine's military successfully repelled an attack by pro-Russian separatists at Donetsk airport on Saturday, marking a significant escalation in the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine. The incident occurred just a week after a cease-fire agreement was reached between Ukraine and Russia, highlighting the fragility of the truce.

According to a statement posted on the City Council website, a volley of rockets struck residential buildings near the airport, but no casualties were reported. The Ukrainian military responded with force, pushing back the separatists and securing the area.

Meanwhile, Russia sent a second convoy of trucks into Ukraine, carrying humanitarian aid, despite Ukraine's objections. The convoy, which consisted of around 245 trucks, delivered goods such as cereals, sugar, medicines, and warm clothes to the eastern Ukrainian city of Lugansk. The aid was welcomed by residents, who had been without water for over a month.

Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk emphasized that, despite the cease-fire agreement, his country remains in a state of war, with Russia as the key aggressor. He stated that the ongoing conflict has hindered the implementation of important government-proposed reforms and has made it difficult to attract international investors.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has consistently denied that Russian troops have entered eastern Ukraine, but has defended the right of the Russian-speaking minority to defend themselves. The second convoy of aid was delivered without the oversight of the International Red Cross, contrary to an agreement signed between Ukraine and Russia.

Title: CBS News Correspondent Sharyl Attkisson Faces Criticism from Own Bosses Over Aggressive Coverage of Benghazi Story

Article:

CBS News correspondent Sharyl Attkisson, known for her relentless pursuit of the Fast and Furious scandal, is now facing criticism from her own bosses over her aggressive coverage of the Benghazi story. According to a Politico article, CBS News executives see Attkisson's coverage of the Benghazi scandal as "dangerously close to advocacy," leading to her being marginalized and underutilized. This criticism has led Attkisson to consider leaving the network ahead of her contract renewal.

Attkisson's reporting on Benghazi has been met with skepticism by some, who view it as a partisan issue. However, her reporting has also been praised for shedding light on the controversy surrounding the 2012 attack on the US diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, which killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

The article highlights the tension between Attkisson's reporting and the network's editorial stance on the issue. While CBS News has celebrated Attkisson's commitment to the story, some critics view her reporting as advocacy rather than objective journalism. The article notes that Attkisson's Twitter feed went silent during the House Oversight Committee's hearing on the topic, sparking speculation about her involvement.

The article also touches on the broader media landscape, noting that the media establishment and liberals view conservative media outlets like Fox News as illegitimate and "partisan." The article suggests that this bias may be contributing to the criticism Attkisson faces for her reporting on Benghazi.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced view of the controversy surrounding Attkisson's reporting on Benghazi, highlighting the tension between her aggressive pursuit of the story and the network's editorial stance.

Title: D.C. Gun Owners Face Mandatory Registration Renewal Process

The Metropolitan Police Department in Washington, D.C. has proposed new rules requiring legal gun owners to renew their registration certificates, which will involve fingerprinting, photographing, and a criminal-background check. This process will apply to gun owners who registered their firearms before 2011. The new regulations aim to ensure that gun owners remain eligible to possess their firearms.

The proposed rules require gun owners to visit police headquarters in person to renew their registration certificates. The process will involve fingerprinting, photographing, providing proof of address, paying a fee, and confirming the owner's eligibility to possess the firearm. The Firearms Registration Section will then issue a new registration certificate, now in the form of an ID card.

The Metropolitan Police Department plans to schedule the renewal process in three-month windows based on the owner's birthday, starting from January 1 and going through 2015. The department is also working on setting up an online system to make appointments and accept credit card payments for the $13-per-gun fee.

Critics argue that the renewal process is unnecessary and will cause inconvenience for law-abiding gun owners. George Lyon, a plaintiff in the original Heller case, pointed out that the process will cost him $104 to re-register his eight guns. He believes the process should be done online and automated, without adding extra fees.

The renewal process was initially supposed to be done online and by mail, starting in 2012. However, the police did not retain any fingerprints or photos taken until March 2013. The city council chairman, Phil Mendelson, explained that the renewal process is intended to ensure gun owners remain eligible to own firearms.

The registration-renewal requirement is currently being challenged in court as part of the Heller v. District of Columbia case, also known as "Heller II." The case challenges the entire registration law enacted in 2009, which was upheld by the Supreme Court in the original Heller decision.

The lead plaintiff, Dick Heller, questioned the purpose of the renewal process, stating that it will not deter criminals from obtaining firearms. The attorney for Heller II, Stephen P. Halbrook, argued that the re-registration process is onerous, unnecessary, and a trap for the unwary, as failing to re-register can result in criminal charges.

The estimated 30,000 registered firearms in D.C. are a small percentage of the city's 600,000 residents, as many law-abiding citizens choose not to go through the 11-step registration process. The critics argue that gun registration is a violation of the Second Amendment's intent to prevent government tyranny, as it allows the government to track and monitor gun ownership.

Title: Alabama Republican Senate Candidate Roy Moore Threatens to Sue The Washington Post Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Alabama Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore has announced plans to sue The Washington Post over a report alleging he pursued sexual relationships with teenagers, including a 14-year-old, when he was in his 30s. Moore has denied the allegations, calling them "completely false" and "fake news."

The Washington Post published a report on Thursday, citing interviews with over 30 people, including three women who claimed Moore pursued them when they were between the ages of 16 and 18. One woman alleged that Moore took her to his house, undressed down to his underwear, and touched her and moved her hand to touch his underwear, which could have been sexual offenses due to her age. However, the statutes of limitations in effect during that time have passed.

Moore has denied the allegations, stating that they are "very hurtful to me personally" and that he has "the highest regard for the protection of young children." He also claimed that there are ongoing investigations into the motivations behind the Post article and promised "revelations" about the story to come in the next few days.

The allegations have led to several Republicans withdrawing their endorsements of Moore, including the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which severed a joint fundraising agreement with Moore's campaign.

Title: NBC's "Meet the Press" Declares Climate Change a Fact, No Debate Allowed

Article:

NBC's "Meet the Press" hosted a panel discussion on climate change, featuring lawmakers and scientists, on Sunday. The show's host, Chuck Todd, made it clear from the start that the program would not provide a platform for climate deniers. Todd stated, "The earth is getting hotter, and human activity is a major cause. Period." He also emphasized that the show would not give time to those who question the existence of climate change.

The panel discussion included non-scientists offering their opinions, such as California Governor Jerry Brown, Representative Carlos Curbelo, and potential Democratic presidential contender Michael Bloomberg. Curbelo emphasized the need to move beyond debating the issue and focus on finding solutions.

The show's decision to not provide a platform for climate deniers has sparked controversy among some who argue that the term "denier" implies a comparison to those who deny historical events like the Holocaust or 9/11. They point out that while everyone agrees that burning fossil fuels increases carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, there is still a range of scientific opinion on the extent of human impact on climate change and the likelihood of various consequences.

Climatologists also emphasize the distinction between weather and climate, with Todd himself making this distinction last month. Scientists typically refrain from attributing specific weather events to human-induced climate change.

The show's decision to focus on the issue and not provide a platform for those who question its existence has been met with applause from some politicians, including Senator Bernie Sanders, who tweeted congratulations to Todd and the show for holding a serious discussion about climate change.

Title: NRA Executive Vice President Warns of Imminent Threat to Second Amendment Rights

The National Rifle Association (NRA) Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre sent an email to supporters on Tuesday evening, expressing concerns about President Obama's plans to sign executive orders on gun control measures. LaPierre claims that the proposed measures are not about protecting children or stopping crime, but rather about banning guns.

According to LaPierre, the NRA was invited to a White House meeting last week, which was marketed as an "open discussion" on improving school safety. However, LaPierre alleges that the meeting was not a genuine discussion, as the administration did not consider any real solutions to keep children safe and instead focused on blaming and vilifying gun owners.

The email urges supporters to renew or upgrade their NRA membership, citing the importance of standing up for Second Amendment freedoms. LaPierre emphasizes that the media has been attacking and intimidating NRA members, labeling them as terrorists and blaming them for violent crimes. The email concludes by expressing gratitude for the support and encouragement received from members.

It is essential to note that the email does not provide specific details about the proposed executive orders or the NRA's stance on gun control measures.

Title: Clinton Reaffirms Commitment to Gun Control and Criminal Justice Reform

The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton reiterated her stance on gun control and criminal justice reform during an event on Saturday, emphasizing the importance of protecting communities and addressing systemic issues. Clinton's remarks come as she shifts her focus to the general election against her Republican opponent, Donald Trump.

Clinton has made gun control a central issue in her primary campaign against Bernie Sanders, highlighting the stories of mothers who have lost children to gun violence. Her campaign has featured television ads featuring mothers who have been affected by gun violence, including Erica Smegielski, daughter of a school principal killed in the Sandy Hook massacre.

A recent New York Times/CBS News poll found that 57% of respondents support stricter gun laws and 88% favor background checks for all gun purchases. Clinton reaffirmed her commitment to both gun control and criminal justice reform, which have been key issues in her primary campaign and have garnered broad support among African-Americans.

Clinton also emphasized the need to address the "schools to prison pipeline" that disproportionately affects black men. She stated, "Something is wrong when so many Americans have reason to believe that our country doesn't consider their children as precious and worthy of protection as other children because of the color of their skin."

Clinton also reiterated her promise to "end the era of mass incarceration" and "rebuild the bonds of trust between law enforcement and communities," issues that could resonate with voters in Los Angeles, Oakland, and other California cities ahead of the state's June 7 primary.

Title: The Emergence of a Religious Left: Buttigieg and the Growing Movement

The 2020 presidential election is witnessing a significant shift in the political landscape, with Pete Buttigieg, a gay man, running for the highest office in the land. This development has sparked a renewed interest in the intersection of politics and faith, particularly among progressive Christians. The emergence of Buttigieg and other Democratic candidates who are open about their religious beliefs is seen as a significant departure from the traditional notion that politics and faith are mutually exclusive.

Buttigieg's candidacy has resonated with many who feel that the current political climate has been dominated by a narrow, conservative Christian perspective. His campaign has been praised for its emphasis on inclusivity, diversity, and social justice, which has attracted a diverse range of supporters. His opponents, including Senators Cory Booker and Elizabeth Warren, have also spoken about the importance of faith in their political beliefs.

The article highlights the significance of Buttigieg's candidacy, noting that it is a powerful symbol of the growing Christian left movement. This movement is characterized by its focus on issues such as immigrant rights, universal healthcare, LGBTQ rights, and racial justice. The article also notes that Buttigieg's opponents are not necessarily opposed to his faith-based politics, but rather see them as a way to challenge the dominant conservative Christian narrative.

The article also touches on the idea that Buttigieg's candidacy has sparked a renewed interest in the role of faith in politics. The author notes that while some may see Buttigieg's faith as a liability, others see it as a strength, as it allows him to connect with voters on a deeper level. The article concludes by noting that while Buttigieg's candidacy is not without its challenges, it has the potential to bring about a more inclusive and compassionate politics.

**Guam Residents Go About Daily Lives Despite North Korea Threats**

Guam, a US territory in the Pacific, has been in the international spotlight recently due to threats from North Korea. Despite the heightened tensions, residents of the island have not been rushing to stock up on supplies or flee the area. Instead, they have been going about their daily lives, with many attending to their daily routines and enjoying the weekend.

The Home Depot in Guam saw a steady stream of customers, but not necessarily for emergency supplies. General Manager Bobby Salcido reported that customers were buying typical items, such as batteries, flashlights, and bottled water, which are commonly purchased in preparation for typhoons. Loss prevention manager Andrew Guilliot noted that there was no significant increase in sales of emergency supplies, such as generators, tarps, and plastic sheeting.

Some residents have expressed concerns about the situation, with some stocking up on canned goods and bottled water as a precaution. However, many others are taking a wait-and-see approach, with some even going about their daily activities as usual.

The island's leaders have received assurances from US President Donald Trump and White House Chief of Staff General John Kelly, which has provided some comfort to the residents. Guam Governor Eddie Calvo has also emphasized that the island is well-prepared to handle any potential emergency.

Despite the concerns, Guam residents are not panicking, and many are taking a pragmatic view of the situation. Some have even been going about their daily routines, such as fishing, attending football practice, and visiting beaches and malls. The University of Guam's Kid's Fishing Derby, which culminated its two-week program over the weekend, saw a strong turnout of registered children and their families.

For many Guam residents, the threats from North Korea are just another chapter in the island's history of being threatened. Some have lived through previous threats and have learned to take them with a grain of salt. As one resident, Vicente Bautista, put it, "They always had a missile aiming to Guam ever since. I don't believe that he's going to fight the whole world. I doubt they're going to start something to fire the missile here to Guam."

Title: Senator Rand Paul's Principles and Expediency: A Study in Contrasts

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a self-proclaimed champion of libertarian principles, has emerged as a key figure in the Republican Party's health-care reform efforts. Paul has consistently voted against any compromise that does not fully repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. He has argued that this is a matter of principle, citing his party's campaign promises to repeal the ACA.

However, some have questioned whether Paul's stance is driven by principle or expediency. His home state of Kentucky has a high percentage of Medicaid recipients, which could be a factor in his opposition to the bill. Additionally, Paul's father, Ron Paul, was known for his opposition to most legislation, often citing constitutional or libertarian concerns.

Rand Paul has also been criticized for his stance on trade agreements. While he has expressed support for free trade, he has opposed several agreements, including the Central American Free Trade Agreement, citing concerns about managed trade. This stance has been seen as protectionist, which is at odds with his libertarian views.

In terms of health-care reform, Paul has been inconsistent in his stance. He has opposed efforts to slow the growth of entitlements, citing concerns that the reform did not go far enough. However, he has also expressed support for allowing people to join associations to buy insurance, which is already a provision in the Senate bill.

Paul has also been accused of playing politics, as his opposition to the bill has been seen as a way to avoid accountability for his own role in the failure of the Republican health-care reform efforts. His father, Ron Paul, was known for his opposition to earmarks, but he would often vote against spending bills that included them.

In conclusion, Senator Rand Paul's stance on health-care reform and trade agreements has been marked by inconsistencies and contradictions. While he has expressed support for libertarian principles, his actions have been driven by expediency and a desire to avoid accountability.

Title: US Defense Secretary Defends Funding Shift for Border Wall, Citing National Security

Article:

U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper defended his decision to divert billions of dollars in funding for Navy and Air Force aircraft and other military programs to help pay for President Donald Trump's promised wall on the U.S.-Mexico border. Esper made the comments during a press conference on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference in Germany.

The Pentagon announced on Thursday that Esper approved shifting $3.8 billion in funds that Congress had previously authorized for F-35 fighter aircraft and other military programs to help the Department of Homeland Security build portions of the border wall. The Pentagon indicated that more such actions could be coming to provide additional funding for Trump's signature campaign promise.

Esper stated that "border security is national security" and that the action taken is "legal under the law." He declined to elaborate further.

The decision drew sharp rebukes from both Democrats and Republicans. Representative Adam Smith, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, called the move "bad policy" and said it would undermine national security. Representative Mac Thornberry, a Republican from Texas, expressed concerns that the administration was overstepping its constitutional authority by diverting funds without congressional approval.

Thornberry stated that while the administration has the authority to recommend how tax dollars are spent, the final decisions are made by Congress. He emphasized that the re-programming announced by the Pentagon is contrary to Congress's constitutional authority and requires congressional action.

The controversy surrounding the border wall has been ongoing since Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, when he promised that Mexico would pay for the wall. Mexico has refused to do so, and the issue has become a contentious topic in U.S. politics.

Title: Democrats' "Better Deal" Agenda: A New Package of Familiar Ideas

The Democratic Party's latest attempt to revamp its policy vision, dubbed the "Better Deal," has been met with skepticism by some, who argue that it is simply a rehashing of the same old ideas. The "Better Deal" is an attempt to distance the party from its anti-Trump rhetoric and provide a fresh approach to policy-making. However, critics argue that the new agenda is still rooted in the same principles that have defined the Democratic Party for decades, namely the New Deal.

The New Deal, implemented by President Franklin D. Roosevelt during the Great Depression, was a series of programs aimed at stimulating economic recovery and providing relief to those affected by the crisis. While it was a groundbreaking initiative at the time, it has since become a relic of the past, with many arguing that it is no longer relevant in today's political landscape.

The "Better Deal" agenda, which was rolled out by House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi and other party leaders, is an attempt to update the New Deal for the 21st century. However, some critics argue that it is simply a rebranding of the same old ideas, rather than a genuine attempt to break with the past.

The "Better Deal" includes a range of policy proposals, including a new infrastructure plan, which would see the federal government take on a greater share of the costs. However, some have questioned the originality of the plan, pointing out that it is simply a rehashing of previous proposals.

The article concludes that while the "Better Deal" may be enough to win the 2018 midterm elections, it is unlikely to be enough to sustain the party's momentum in the long term. The Democrats need to come up with new ideas and a fresh approach to policy-making if they are to remain relevant in the future.

Title: Congress Nears Budget Deal, Trump Demands Immigration Reforms

Article:

The United States Congress is reportedly close to reaching a budget deal that would keep the government functioning without using hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children as bargaining chips. However, President Trump is pushing for significant changes to legal immigration policies, including deep cuts to the diversity visa program and family-based immigration.

The President's demands are based on a zero-sum view that what is good for immigrants is bad for America. This perspective runs counter to American tradition and principles, as well as evidence of what is best for the country. The programs targeted by Trump are designed to make legal immigration more diverse and humane. The diversity visa program, also known as the lottery system, offers visas to people from underrepresented countries, while family-based immigration provides visas to close relatives of citizens and legal residents.

Trump has been focusing on the diversity visa program, which he has claimed is a threat to national security. Last month, his Department of Homeland Security released a report claiming that those who entered the country through the lottery were more likely to be tied to terrorist attacks. However, the Cato Institute found that lottery visa holders actually killed only eight of 3,037 Americans murdered by foreign-born terrorists since 1975. Additionally, lottery winners must undergo criminal, national security, and medical checks, and are not guaranteed permanent residence, only a chance to continue through the immigration process.

It is worth noting that the 50,000 recipients of the visas are not chosen "without any regard for skill, merit, or the safety of our people," as Trump stated in his State of the Union address. They must have at least a high school education or two years of experience in skilled work.

Title: House Democrats Debate Participation in Benghazi Investigation Committee

House Democrats met behind closed doors on Wednesday to discuss the proposed structure of a special investigative committee on the Benghazi attacks, with some lawmakers arguing they should boycott the investigation altogether. Democratic leaders refused to confirm their plans, stating "one day at a time" when asked about their intentions.

The proposed committee, outlined by GOP leaders on Tuesday, would consist of seven Republicans and five Democrats. House Speaker John Boehner emphasized that the committee would not be a "sideshow" or "circus," but rather a comprehensive probe into the U.S. response efforts and internal communications following the attack.

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi and her deputy, Rep. Steny Hoyer, objected to the committee's structure, calling for an evenly split panel and a "real and equal voice" for Democrats in issuing subpoenas, questioning witnesses, and other areas. They expressed concerns that the current proposal does not meet these criteria.

Rank-and-file Democrats have also expressed reservations about participating in the committee, fearing it would legitimize what they view as a political effort. However, others argue that not participating would mean they would not be able to shape the direction and narrative of the probe.

The committee will investigate the events surrounding the September 11, 2012 attack on the U.S. consulate in Libya, including efforts to rescue U.S. personnel. Four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens, died in the assault. The committee will have subpoena power and may order depositions to be given under oath. A final report is required, although some information may be classified.

The next step will be for the House to vote on the committee and for members to be chosen. Rep. Trey Gowdy has already been selected to chair the committee.

Title: Trump Administration to Set Terms for Title X Funding, Raising Concerns Over Abortion Restrictions

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is set to issue new terms for the Title X family planning program, which has long been a point of contention between the administration and reproductive health advocates. The program, which provides funding for family planning services, has been criticized by conservatives who view it as promoting abortion.

Teresa Manning, the deputy assistant secretary of the office of population affairs at HHS, is a prominent anti-abortion advocate and former lobbyist for the National Right to Life Committee. Her involvement has raised concerns among supporters of the program that the administration may use this opportunity to reshape the program to fit its anti-abortion views.

The National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA) and other supporters of the program worry that the administration may freeze out clinics that provide abortions, restrict the types of services performed at clinics, limit access to certain types of birth control, or reduce funding for the program.

Anti-abortion advocates, on the other hand, hope the administration will resurrect Reagan-era regulations that banned Title X providers from offering abortion referrals and counseling, as well as encouraging, promoting, or advocating for abortion as a method of family planning. This would require a rulemaking process that could take months.

The Trump administration's intent will be clear when HHS issues a funding opportunity announcement for the Title X grants. The conditions are expected to differ from those set by the Obama administration, potentially significantly.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated that Planned Parenthood and its affiliates receive about $60 million a year through the Title X program. In 2017, Congress appropriated $286 million total for the grants.

The Guttmacher Institute, which supports abortion rights, believes it would be naive to think the Trump administration won't take the opportunity to "put a flag in the ground" on Title X. The administration has shown its opposition to abortion and providers who offer or are affiliated with abortion.

The Trump administration's fiscal 2018 budget request would have excluded Planned Parenthood affiliates from all forms of federal funding, but that provision has yet to pass Congress. Title X remains the most plausible route for the administration to crack down on abortion providers.

While federal dollars cannot be used to pay for abortions, critics argue that the money is fungible and could still indirectly support the procedure if it goes to groups that perform abortions like Planned Parenthood. This is the argument for resurrecting Reagan-era restrictions requiring a physical and financial separation between Title X projects and abortion services.

The Reagan-era regulations were upheld by the Supreme Court but were never fully implemented due to time-consuming legal challenges. Former President Clinton officially lifted the restrictions in one of his first executive orders. Restoring these regulations could take months, but groups that support them say it would ensure that no federal funds go toward abortion.

The possible changes to Title X would have a big impact on women, especially those living in underserved communities. Any attempt to undermine the program or providers or women's access to affordable care would be a huge setback and would definitely impact these women and represent an unacceptable disruption of the program.

Title: FBI Director Comey Discusses Investigation into Trump-Russia Ties and Criticizes WikiLeaks

Article:

FBI Director James Comey testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the agency's investigation into alleged ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. During his testimony, Comey made some notable comments about WikiLeaks, describing it as an "important focus" of investigations and stating that it "crosses a line" when it "moves from being about educating a public to just pushing out information...just to damage the United States." He also emphasized that the focus of investigations would almost always fall on leakers during legitimate investigations.

Comey's comments on WikiLeaks echo those made by CIA Director Mike Pompeo, who recently criticized the organization, saying it "ends now" and that it is a "perversion of what our great Constitution stands for." However, some critics argue that it is not the role of government officials to define what constitutes journalism and that Comey's comments are hypocritical given the FBI's own history of illegal and ineffective activities.

In a four-year period, the FBI authorized criminal activity by confidential informants over 22,000 times, raising questions about the agency's accountability. Additionally, President Donald Trump has publicly criticized Comey's refusal to recommend charges against Hillary Clinton and has called for the "loosening" of libel laws regarding public figures and elected officials. The controversy surrounding Comey's comments on WikiLeaks has sparked debate about the role of transparency and the importance of whistleblowers in holding government accountable.

It is worth noting that WikiLeaks has forced transparency in ways that have greatly benefited the public, and some argue that it is too much to ask U.S. officials to embrace the organization and its methods.

**Ross Perot, Billionaire and Two-Time Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89**

Ross Perot, the billionaire businessman and two-time presidential candidate, has died at the age of 89, according to his family spokesman James Fuller. Perot passed away after a five-month battle with leukemia.

Perot, who made his fortune by selling his data processing business to General Motors for $2.5 billion, entered the political arena in the 1990s, running as an independent candidate in the 1992 and 1996 presidential elections. His populist platform and colorful personality made him a household name, and his 1992 campaign remains one of the most successful third-party bids in American history.

Perot's 1992 campaign garnered nearly 19% of the vote, finishing third behind Bill Clinton and incumbent President George H.W. Bush. Election experts and scholarly research have since challenged the notion that Perot's candidacy cost Bush the election, with The New York Times concluding that Perot's effect on the outcome was "appears to have been minimal."

In 1995, Perot founded the Reform Party, and in 1996, he received 8% of the vote as the party's candidate. After his second and final presidential bid, Perot served as president and CEO of Perot Systems Corporation, which he founded in 1988. He was the head of the company until 2000, when he passed the title to his son, Ross Perot Jr.

Aside from his business and political careers, Perot was also recognized for his efforts during the Vietnam War to improve conditions for US prisoners of war. He was awarded the Medal for Distinguished Public Service by the Department of Defense in 1974 for his efforts. In 1979, he organized and funded a successful private mission to rescue two EDS employees taken hostage during a revolution in Iran.

Perot's life was marked by his entrepreneurial spirit, his love of horses, and his commitment to his country. He was born Henry Ray Perot on June 27, 1930, in Texarkana, Texas, where his father ran a cotton mill. He graduated from the Naval Academy in 1953 and spent four years at sea before working as a salesman at IBM and eventually founding Electronic Data Systems in 1962.

Perot's legacy is one of integrity, action, and compassion. His family and friends will deeply miss him, and his contributions to American business and politics will be remembered for years to come.

**Senate Republicans Poised to Use "Nuclear Option" to Confirm Gorsuch to Supreme Court**

The United States Senate is on the verge of a significant rule change, with Republicans planning to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations. This move comes as a response to Democratic opposition to the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch. Senators from both parties have expressed concerns about the implications of this change, which could have long-term consequences for the minority party and the legislative process.

Historians and political scientists have weighed in on the significance of this development, with some viewing it as an extreme but not unprecedented move in American history. Brian Balogh, a professor of history at the University of Virginia, notes that while the use of the nuclear option is not unprecedented, it is part of a decades-long polarization process in Congress.

Sarah Binder, a professor of political science at George Washington University, sees the move as part of a "parliamentary arms race" between the two parties, but notes that it is not as earth-shattering a change as some make it out to be. She believes that the gradual ratcheting up of partisanship has been underway since the 1980s and is a natural response to previous episodes where the minority has exploited the rules and the majority has fought back.

The elimination of the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations is likely to make bipartisan cooperation even harder, as neither party has an incentive to compromise on anything. This could lead to a more scorched-earth policy, with both parties pursuing their agendas without regard for the other side.

Experts agree that there are two solutions to the partisanship problem: either the voters stop rewarding extremism or lawmakers discover mutually beneficial compromises. Balogh believes that the American public will have to decide that they care more about effective governance than their party allegiances. Binder notes that lawmakers can still find ways to work together and achieve legislative gains, even in polarized times.

The elimination of the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations is a significant development that could have long-term consequences for the legislative process and the minority party. As the Senate moves forward, it remains to be seen whether lawmakers will find ways to work together or continue down a path of partisanship.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Off in Second Debate

The second night of the 2020 Democratic presidential debates saw 10 candidates take the stage, with Senator Kamala Harris and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg emerging as the winners, and Senators Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden struggling to make an impact.

Senator Bernie Sanders, who had a strong performance last night, was expected to bring new ideas to the table, but instead, he was criticized for being "yelling, stern, and short on details." His Medicare-for-all plan was pummeled by Buttigieg, who argued that it would not benefit everyone equally. Sanders struggled to explain how his plan would work on a national level and admitted that taxes would increase under his plan.

Former Vice President Joe Biden started strong, defending Obamacare and sharing his plans on education, but struggled as the debate went on, particularly when faced with questions about his record on race and criminal justice. Senator Kamala Harris was the clear standout on the stage, using her prosecutorial experience to effectively challenge Biden and demonstrate her toughness.

Two younger candidates, Harris and Buttigieg, impressed with their leadership skills, policy acumen, and authenticity. Harris demonstrated her ability to take on the front-runners and bring attention to her own experiences and policies. Buttigieg showed his ability to take responsibility for his city's shortcomings and demonstrate his commitment to addressing the issues.

The debate highlighted the challenges faced by Biden and Sanders, who were seen as tired, rehearsed, and out of touch. While neither candidate offered new solutions to today's problems or a creative path forward, Harris and Buttigieg demonstrated the qualities that voters are attracted to, regardless of gender, color, or sexual orientation.

Title: Boeing Ends Year with Negative Commercial Airplane Orders for First Time in Decades

Boeing ended the year with a rare occurrence: negative commercial airplane orders. According to CNBC, the aerospace giant lost orders for 87 airplanes, resulting in more cancellations than new orders. This marks a significant decline in demand for the company's aircraft.

The high rate of cancellations is largely attributed to the ongoing crisis surrounding the 737 Max, which has been involved in two fatal crashes that took the lives of 346 people. The grounding of the 737 Max by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in mid-March has led to a significant drop in orders for the model. In fact, there was a 90% drop in orders for 737 models during the year, with American Airlines extending its cancellations until June 4th.

The 737 Max's troubled history is well-documented, with the crashes linked to a piece of software known as the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS). The latest controversy surrounding the company involves internal messages from Boeing employees discussing the problems with the 737 Max in an "unacceptable" manner. The messages, released by congressional investigators, show employees mocking regulators, expressing concerns about flying on the 737 Max themselves, and describing interactions with FAA officials as "cover-ups."

The messages also reveal Boeing's efforts to reduce the amount of simulator training required by the FAA to certify pilots for the 737 Max. Last week, the company announced it would recommend simulator training for pilots of its 737 Max jets, a change from its previous stance that such training was unnecessary. Boeing had originally sold the 737 Max to carriers on the promise that pilots would not need to pay for simulator training, instead opting for a short course on an iPad.

The decline in orders and cancellations is a significant blow to Boeing's bottom line, with its order book for the troubled jet shrinking by 183 planes. The company's struggles to get the 737 Max certified are ongoing, with regulators yet to approve the aircraft for flight.

Title: Job Market Data Suggests Economic Recovery May Be Slowing Down

The latest data on job postings and small business activity suggests that the economic recovery may be losing momentum. According to ZipRecruiter, job postings on their platform decreased in June after a sharp increase in May. Data from Homebase, a scheduling and time tracking software provider, shows that small business employment and openings worsened over the past week, following a nearly 40% improvement in May. This decline is particularly concerning, as it indicates a potential reversal of the progress made in May.

Some states experiencing surges in infections, such as Texas, have already seen layoffs and business closures, even before officials reimposed restrictions on economic activity. Foot traffic to retailers and other businesses declined in large cities across the southern states, according to an analysis of Safegraph.com data by the American Enterprise Institute. Data from 40 million households compiled by Commerce Signals shows that credit and debit card spending declined at the end of May across most states, marking a departure from the "rocket ship" recovery promised by President Trump.

Federal Reserve officials have warned that the recovery appears perilous and highly dependent on public health. Fed Chair Jerome H. Powell stated that a full recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to re-engage in a broad range of activities. The next few months of recovery could be rocky, even if the current infection surge abates. Job losses have slowed but remain at levels higher than in any previous recession, and a growing share of workers now report being laid off permanently, rather than temporarily furloughed. A significant share of small businesses have still not reopened, even as states lift restrictions on their operations, suggesting some may be shuttered for good. By many measures, business activity and employment remain down by a quarter or more from pre-crisis levels.

Title: Trump Targets Clinton as "Real Enemy" in Exclusive Interview

In an exclusive interview with a news outlet, presumptive Republican nominee for President Donald Trump stated that the "real enemy" lies ahead in likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. The interview took place on Tuesday evening, just as Trump was wrapping up winning the GOP nomination for the presidency. Trump emphasized the need to unify the Republican Party and set his sights squarely on Clinton, calling her the "real enemy."

Trump criticized Clinton's positions on trade deals, such as NAFTA and the Trans-Pacific Partnership, saying they will weaken her in the general election. He also expressed concerns about her stance on securing the U.S. border with Mexico and her opposition to a strong American military.

When asked about his running mate selection process, Trump stated that he will choose a political figure, not a businessperson. He emphasized the need for someone who can deal with Congress and get things done.

Trump also expressed confidence in his ability to win the general election, citing the high Republican primary turnout and low Democratic turnout. He believes this trend will continue, stating that he will beat Clinton in popular votes if he had only one, non-serious competitor.

In the interview, Trump highlighted his views on the economy, stating that NAFTA, signed by Clinton's husband, is the worst economic development deal in the history of the country. He believes his own policies will bring jobs back to America, while Clinton's will not.

Trump's comments came as he was expected to win big in Indiana, but before his last remaining serious rival, Senator Ted Cruz, dropped out, handing the nomination to Trump.

Title: Senator Bob Corker Criticizes President Trump's Border Wall Proposal

Senator Bob Corker, a Tennessee Republican, has criticized President Trump's determination to secure funding for a border wall, calling it a "made-up fight." During an appearance on CNN's "State of the Union," Corker stated that the White House is proposing the wrong solution, arguing that the focus should be on more sophisticated technology.

Corker compared the idea of building a wall to using outdated technology, such as the Wright brothers' aircraft, instead of advanced stealth fighters. He emphasized that it's not just about the money being spent, but what it's being spent on. "This is a made-up fight so the president can look like he's fighting, but even if he wins, our borders are going to be insecure," Corker said.

The senator's comments come as President Trump and Democratic leaders remain locked in a stalemate over his demand to fund a border wall, leading to a partial shutdown of the federal government. Trump has tweeted that technology is fine, but a wall is essential, stating that "it is only a good old-fashioned Wall that works!" He believes that a wall or barrier is the only way to stop drugs, gangs, human trafficking, and criminal elements from entering the country.

The debate over border security and the proposed wall continues, with Senator Corker's comments adding to the ongoing discussion.

Title: House Oversight Committee to Vote on Holding Attorney General Eric Holder in Contempt

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has scheduled a vote for June 20 to consider holding Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress over the controversial Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation. The committee's chairman, Darrell Issa, released a 64-page memo in early May outlining the case for holding the attorney general in contempt, citing Holder's failure to respond to an October 2011 subpoena for internal Justice Department documents on the operation.

The Justice Department maintains that it has cooperated with the investigation and provided thousands of documents, with Attorney General Holder testifying before the committee at least eight times about Fast and Furious. However, the committee's chairman, Issa, argues that the department has "obstructed the investigation" and that Holder has "failed to meet his legal obligations."

The committee's vote is scheduled for June 20, with the Justice Department stating that it has provided 7,600 pages of documents to date and provided testimony during "hours and hours" of congressional hearings. The White House Press Secretary, Jay Carney, has also noted that the vote is "unwarranted" and "politicized."

The Fast and Furious program oversaw the sale of nearly 2,000 firearms to suspected Mexican drug cartels in an attempt to trace gun trafficking. However, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) recovered only 567 of the guns, with many of the remaining guns found at violent crime scenes, including at the shooting of Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

The Republican leadership has initially been hesitant to fully support Issa's case, citing concerns that charging the attorney general in contempt in an election year could backfire. However, six House Republican freshmen wrote to the leadership in May to push for a contempt of Congress resolution against Holder, and Majority Leader Eric Cantor, Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy, and Speaker John Boehner have also issued a letter to Holder demanding full cooperation with the Oversight Committee investigation.

The Senate Judiciary Committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Charles Grassley, has called the latest announcement "straightforward and necessary," while the House Oversight Committee's ranking Democrat, Rep. Elijah Cummings, has called the committee's action "unfortunate."

Title: Americans' Attention to COVID-19 News Varies by Age Group

A recent survey conducted by the Election News Pathways project found that an overwhelming majority of U.S. adults (92%) were following news about the COVID-19 pandemic in late March. However, the level of attention varied significantly across different age groups. The survey, which was conducted twice in March, found that younger adults (ages 18-29) were the least likely to follow COVID-19 news very closely, while older adults (ages 65 and older) were the most likely.

The survey, which included 8,914 U.S. adults in the first wave and 11,537 in the second wave, found that the portion of adults following COVID-19 news very closely grew from 51% to 57% over the two-week period. However, this growth was not uniform across all age groups. The portion of adults ages 30-49 and 50-64 following the news very closely grew by 10 percentage points, while the portion of adults ages 18-29 remained largely unchanged.

The survey also found that the oldest adults (ages 65 and older) were the most engaged with COVID-19 news, with 69% saying they were following it very closely. This level of engagement remained consistent from mid to late March.

The data suggests that younger adults, particularly those in the 18-29 age group, are less engaged with COVID-19 news, with only 42% saying they were following it very closely. This group's level of engagement remained relatively unchanged over the two-week period.

The survey's findings are based on data from the Election News Pathways project, which is a collaborative effort between the Pew Research Center and The Pew Charitable Trusts. The project aims to understand how Americans consume and engage with news about the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title: House Budget Committee Approves GOP's ObamaCare Repeal and Replacement Plan

The House Budget Committee has approved the Republican's ObamaCare repeal and replacement plan, with a vote of 19-17. Three Republican representatives, Dave Brat, Mark Sanford, and Gary Palmer, voted against advancing the bill. The three representatives are members of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, which opposes the bill due to its perceived similarities to ObamaCare and the retention of some of its provisions and insurance mandates.

The bill will now move to the House Rules Committee, where leadership may make amendments to appease conservatives and moderates unhappy with the current legislation. The Rules Committee will be the final stop before the bill reaches the floor.

House Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows has announced plans to offer an amendment to leadership, although the specifics of the amendment have not been disclosed. Budget Chairwoman Diane Black urged conservatives to stay in the discussions and work towards building a better product.

The committee also approved four non-binding recommendations from Republicans, including a work requirement for able-bodied adults enrolled in Medicaid and a proposal to gear the plan's refundable tax credits towards low-income individuals. The tax credits are currently based on age, not income, for individuals making up to $75,000. Some Republicans have expressed concerns that the credits are too generous for those with higher incomes and would not do enough for older, low-income individuals.

The work requirement is generally supported by both conservatives and moderates, with Rep. Gary Palmer stating that it would help states focus their resources on the truly needy. Another motion approved by the committee would recommend giving states the option to accept their Medicaid funding through block grants.

The White House has announced that it is working with leadership on a manager's amendment to the bill, although details have not been disclosed. The Republican Study Committee wants the bill to include a quicker Medicaid freeze and work requirements for Medicaid recipients. Rep. Mark Walker, the chairman of the RSC, expressed hope that these changes would be included in the manager's amendment.

The bill faces significant challenges on the floor, with at least 15 Republicans indicating they will vote against it or are leaning against it. In the Senate, some Republicans are privately rooting for the House bill to fail, citing the challenges they may face in passing the measure.

Title: Sanders' Fundraising Efforts Show Promise, but Challenges Remain

The 2020 Democratic presidential primary has seen a surge in fundraising efforts from Senator Bernie Sanders, with the candidate pulling in approximately $34.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2019, bringing his total to nearly $100 million. This significant amount of funding has led some to believe that Sanders' chances of winning the nomination have improved. Historically, candidates who lead in fundraising at this point in the primary have gone on to win the nomination, with 9 out of 14 leaders at this stage going on to win.

However, Sanders faces stiff competition from other candidates, including former Vice President Joe Biden, who has secured 33 endorsements from members of Congress and governors. Biden's strong showing in endorsements has a strong track record of predicting success, with 10 out of 14 endorsement leaders going on to win the nomination.

Sanders appears to be focusing on drawing contrasts with his fellow Democratic candidates to peel away votes. He has been highlighting his differences with Biden on issues such as the Iraq War, NAFTA, and bankruptcy reform. Sanders' familiarity with Biden's voting record, having served in the Senate alongside him, allows him to point to specific moments where they disagreed.

Despite his efforts, some caution that Sanders may struggle to take down Biden, citing his inability to do so in the 2016 primary against Hillary Clinton. Additionally, the issue of the Iraq War may not be as potent this time around, with some arguing that the greater challenge to Biden may come from former Navy intelligence officer and former South Bend, Ind., mayor Pete Buttigieg, who has a strong record on national security and can scold Trump for using a "bone spur" deferment to avoid the Vietnam War.

Others believe that Sanders is well-positioned to use the ramping up of hostilities in the Middle East as an opportunity to highlight his alternative policy, which includes ending the forever wars, using aid money as leverage to push Israel to negotiate with the Palestinians, and making climate change a cornerstone of American foreign policy. However, the difficulty for Sanders lies in making an argument against not only Trump but also Barack Obama, who has been critical of Sanders' foreign policy.

Former President Barack Obama's top lieutenants have been hesitant to publicly oppose Sanders' bid for the nomination, with some even declining to offer a preferred candidate to take on President Trump in 2020. The lack of a coordinated effort to stop Sanders' campaign has allowed him to gain momentum, making it unclear what will happen next.

In related news, President Trump's decision to draw a "red line" against Iran has raised concerns about the potential for violent conflict in the region. Some influential Republican senators, such as Lindsey Graham, Marco Rubio, and Mitch McConnell, have been urging Trump to reconsider his stance and avoid getting drawn into a war with Iran.

Title: U.S. Senators Spar Over Impeachment Trial Rules, Witnesses

U.S. senators are at odds over the rules and procedures for the upcoming impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, with Republican leader Mitch McConnell stopping short of agreeing to a Democratic request for the Senate to agree ahead of time to take testimony during the trial. McConnell, speaking on Fox News, cited the 1999 impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton as a model, stating that the Senate should follow a similar approach.

In the 1999 trial, senators went through opening arguments, had a written question period, and then decided which witnesses to call, with limited testimony by video. Allowing witness testimony, particularly from current and former administration officials, could prolong the trial and bring up new evidence potentially damaging to Trump, who was impeached by the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives last week.

Chuck Schumer, the top Democrat in the Senate, urged his colleagues to call for the release of relevant Trump administration documents and to subpoena witnesses, stating that a trial without documents and witnesses would seem like a "sham trial" to most Americans. The House voted along party lines to impeach Trump on two charges over his alleged pressuring of Ukraine to announce an investigation of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden.

Trump has accused Democrats of delaying tactics and urged for a quick conclusion to the impeachment process. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has not yet transmitted the articles of impeachment to the Senate, a move aimed at pressuring Senate Republicans to reach an accord with Schumer on trial rules. McConnell stated that the Senate cannot take any action until it receives the articles.

The White House blocked four witnesses, including Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney and former National Security Adviser John Bolton, from testifying during impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives in December. Schumer has requested that these witnesses be subpoenaed for the trial. The Senate is expected to begin the trial in early 2020.

Title: Rep. Ayanna Pressley Introduces Resolution Seeking Impeachment Inquiry into Justice Brett Kavanaugh

Article:
