Representative Ayanna Pressley, one of the four freshman congresswomen known as the "Squad," is planning to introduce a resolution seeking an impeachment inquiry into Supreme Court Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh. This move comes after a New York Times report published a new allegation of sexual misconduct from when Kavanaugh was in college. However, an editor's note later revealed that the alleged victim did not recall the incident.

Pressley's resolution calls for the House of Representatives to inquire whether impeachment is warranted and for the House Judiciary Committee to conduct depositions and take affidavits, serving subpoenas if necessary. The resolution specifically focuses on the women who came forward during Kavanaugh's confirmation process, citing Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez.

While Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the head of the House Judiciary Committee, has not explicitly ruled out impeaching Kavanaugh, he has stated that it is not a top priority for his committee. Nadler emphasized that the committee has its hands full with impeaching President Trump.

GOP lawmakers, including Senator Lindsey Graham, have rallied around Kavanaugh, calling the attacks "beyond the pale." Graham expressed sympathy for Kavanaugh's family, saying they are being forced to endure "ridiculous treatment once again."

Several Democratic presidential candidates, including Senators Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren, Cory Booker, Pete Buttigieg, Beto O'Rourke, and Julian Castro, have called for Kavanaugh's impeachment. Harris has continued to push for an investigation, circulating an impeachment petition on her Twitter account.

It is worth noting that the original Times piece included an allegation of sexual misconduct from a Kavanaugh classmate, but the paper later revised the story to include the fact that several friends of the alleged victim said she did not recall the reported sexual assault.

Title: NSA Allegedly Taps into Google and Yahoo Communications Links to Gather User Data

The National Security Agency (NSA) has allegedly tapped into the communications links used by Google and Yahoo to gather huge amounts of email and other user information, according to a report by the Washington Post. The report, based on secret NSA documents leaked by former contractor Edward Snowden, suggests that the agency has used weak restrictions on its overseas activities to exploit major U.S. companies' data to a far greater extent than realized.

The newly disclosed program, code-named MUSCULAR, appears to show that the NSA has gained access to a cable or switch that relays traffic through an unnamed telecommunications provider. The operation, operated jointly with the United Kingdom's Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ), amassed 181 million records in one recent 30-day span, according to one document reported by the Post.

Google and Yahoo, like other companies, constantly send data over leased and shared or exclusive international fiber-optic telecommunication lines as they synchronize information. The companies have strict controls in place to protect the security of their data centers, and they have not given access to their data centers to the NSA or any other government agency.

The NSA has denied the allegations, stating that the suggestion that the agency relies on a presidential order on foreign intelligence gathering to skirt domestic restrictions imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and other laws is not true. The agency also denied that it collects vast quantities of U.S. persons' data from this type of collection.

The report is likely to add to growing tensions between the U.S. intelligence establishment and the tech companies, which have been struggling to assure customers overseas that they need not fear U.S. spying. The Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Patrick Leahy, has requested an administration briefing on the program, citing concerns about the privacy rights of law-abiding Americans.

The NSA's Director General, Keith Alexander, has stated that the agency does not have unfettered access to the U.S. companies' servers and that it goes through court orders to access data. However, he did not directly address whether the agency intercepts traffic in transit.

Title: Tea Party Advocates and Conservatives Unite Against Healthcare Law

The Tea Party movement and conservative groups have joined forces to push for the defunding of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. This effort has led to a potential government shutdown, with Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota stating that this is what the public wants. However, not all groups are on board with the defunding campaign, with some, like Americans for Prosperity, focusing on sowing public doubts about the law.

The goal of the defunding effort is to cripple the ACA, which Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican, has likened to a horror movie. Americans for Prosperity, a group funded by the Koch brothers, plans to spend tens of millions of dollars on a multifront effort to prevent states from expanding Medicaid under the law. Their ultimate goal is to repeal the law.

The Heritage Action group, a Tea Party organization, held a "Defund Obamacare Town Hall Tour" in Dallas, with nearly 1,000 attendees. Senator Ted Cruz and Jim DeMint, a former South Carolina senator, addressed the crowd, emphasizing the importance of defunding the law. Cruz has been vocal about his opposition to the ACA, delivering a 21-hour monologue on the Senate floor in September.

The tactic of defunding is not new in Washington, with the Hyde Amendment being attached to spending bills to ban the use of federal funds for abortions, except in cases of incest and rape. The idea of defunding the ACA has been around since its passage in 2010, with Representative Todd Tiahrt proposing to defund parts of the law.

Title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Ex-British Spy Christopher Steele Over Dossier Allegations

A Washington DC judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Christopher Steele, a former British spy who compiled a dossier alleging links between Donald Trump and the Kremlin. The lawsuit was filed by three Russian oligarchs who claimed Steele defamed them by stating they tried to influence the 2016 US election.

Steele's lawyers argued that the legal action was frivolous and an attempt to silence him. The judge agreed, citing Washington DC's anti-SLAPP law, which prevents parties from filing lawsuits to tamp down on opposing political views. The judge also ruled that Steele has a right to his opinion, citing the First Amendment to the US Constitution.

The Russian billionaires, Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven, and German Khan, had argued that Steele was not entitled to free speech protections under the First Amendment because he is not a US citizen. However, the judge disagreed, stating that advocacy on issues of public interest has the capacity to inform public debate and furthers the purposes of the First Amendment, regardless of the citizenship or residency of the speakers.

Steele's lawyer, Christy Hull Eikhoff, welcomed the decision, saying it showed support for the First Amendment and the "profound national principle" that debate should be "uninhibited, robust, and wide open." The court's decision is a significant victory for Steele, who had argued that the owners of Alfa Bank were trying to intimidate him into silence.

The court's judgment states that Steele's opinion, as expressed in the dossier, represents his opinion based on what his sources were telling him about the Alfa oligarchs' long relationship with Vladimir Putin, including the claim that they sent him "large amounts of illicit cash" when he was deputy mayor of St Petersburg. The court noted that the dossier "does not present any direct evidence that Alfa interfered in the election."

The FBI has been investigating whether a computer server in Trump Tower was communicating with one belonging to Alfa Bank during the campaign, but it is unclear what, if anything, the FBI found. The Russian billionaires have previously brought a defamation case against Fusion GPS, the Washington DC-based research company that hired Mr. Steele.

Title: Sanders Denies Accusation of Saying a Woman Can't Win Presidency, CNN's Debate Exchange Raises Questions

Article: During the recent Democratic debate, Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) denied an accusation that he told Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) that a woman could not win the presidency. The accusation surfaced over the weekend, with unnamed sources from the Warren campaign claiming that Sanders made the comment during a 2018 meeting. Sanders vehemently denied the claim, and the exchange was revisited on the debate stage.

CNN's Abby Phillip asked Sanders if he had told Warren that a woman could not win the election, to which Sanders responded, "Correct." Phillip then turned to Warren and asked what she thought when Sanders allegedly made the comment. However, it is worth noting that Phillip did not ask Warren if she had actually heard Sanders make the statement, instead presuming that he had said it.

The exchange was framed by CNN as Sanders denying that he said a woman could not be president, which some critics argue implies that Sanders is denying an objective reality. However, there is no evidence to support the initial accusation, and Warren's recollection of the statement was not specifically probed by the moderator.

The debate exchange has sparked controversy among Sanders' supporters, who believe the media is biased against their candidate. The incident highlights the importance of fact-checking and providing accurate information, as well as the need for moderators to ask more probing questions to clarify the truth.

Title: Intelligence Community's Alleged "Intransigence" Leads to Cancellation of House Intelligence Committee Briefing

The House Intelligence Committee's plans to hold a briefing on Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election were cancelled on Wednesday night, sparking anger and frustration among committee members. The alleged "intransigence" of the intelligence community, specifically the CIA, FBI, Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and National Security Agency, was cited as the reason for the cancellation.

Representative Peter King, a member of the committee, expressed his disappointment and frustration with the intelligence community's lack of cooperation. "Somebody has the time to leak it to The Washington Post and The New York Times, but they don't have the time to come to Congress," King said. "It's their job to come. They don't have any choice. They have to come in, especially when they have created this."

The briefing was originally requested by Chairman Devin Nunes, who wanted to discuss the alleged Russian interference and its impact on the election. However, the CIA Director, John Brennan, declined to provide a briefing, citing the agency's focus on the full review requested by President Obama. The other agencies did not respond to the committee's request, which is unusual given the panel's jurisdiction over intelligence matters.

The intelligence community defended its position, stating that senior administration officials regularly provide extensive, detailed classified and unclassified briefings to members and staff on Capitol Hill. However, the agencies are focusing on the review ordered by President Obama on foreign efforts to influence US elections. The review is expected to be completed in the coming weeks, and the intelligence community will make its findings available to Congress and the public once it is complete.

Representative King expressed his concerns about the lack of cooperation and the potential for manipulation of intelligence for political purposes. "The consensus was that there was an attempt by the Russians to put a cloud over the election, to create disunity. Well, that's what's happening right now, but it's the intelligence community that's doing it," he said.

The controversy surrounding the intelligence community's alleged "intransigence" has sparked concerns about the potential for political manipulation and the need for transparency and cooperation between the intelligence agencies and Congress.

Title: White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus Discusses Evelyn Farkas' Comments on Trump-Russia Ties

Article:

In a Thursday morning interview with Hugh Hewitt, White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus discussed the recent comments made by Evelyn Farkas, a former Defense Department official under President Obama, regarding the Trump administration's ties to Russia. Farkas had appeared on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" on March 2, 2017, and stated that she had concerns about the Trump team's dealings with Russia and had tried to get information to the Hill.

Priebus expressed skepticism about Farkas' comments, saying that it's "almost unbelievable" and that he wonders if she knows what she's talking about. He also stated that the White House wants to get to the bottom of the matter and that the intelligence committees and agencies should be interested in investigating the issue.

Farkas' comments have been highlighted by conservative media outlets, including Fox News, which ran a story titled "Former Obama official discloses rush to get intelligence on Trump team." The article notes that Farkas' statement suggests that the Obama administration may have pushed for the collection of intelligence on the Trump transition team's dealings with Russia.

Priebus' comments come as the Trump administration continues to face scrutiny over its ties to Russia, with some critics accusing the president of having colluded with the Russian government during the 2016 election. The White House has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, with Priebus stating that there is "nothing to hide" and that the allegations are "total garbage."

Title: The End of Race in America: A Call to Move Beyond Skin Color

The article discusses the author's perspective on the state of race relations in America, 50 years after Dr. Martin Luther King's famous "I Have a Dream" speech. The author argues that it is time to stop caring about skin color and focus on individual character. They share their personal experiences, including their parents' immigration to the United States and their own political career, to illustrate the progress made in overcoming racial barriers.

The author notes that while racism still exists, significant progress has been made in the past 50 years. They highlight the importance of judging people based on their character, not their skin color, and express disappointment in the current trend of emphasizing individual identities over a shared American identity.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need to move beyond skin color and focus on individuality. The author suggests that it is time to "get over it" and recognize that people are created in the image of God, regardless of their physical characteristics.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Endorses Hillary Clinton, Puts Herself in Frame as Possible VP Candidate

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has publicly endorsed Hillary Clinton as the Democratic Party's presidential nominee, stating she is "ready to jump in this fight" to ensure Clinton becomes the next President of the United States. Warren, a popular figure among the progressive wing of the Democratic party, praised Clinton as a "fighter with guts" who would keep Donald Trump out of the White House.

In an interview with MSNBC, Warren expressed her willingness to be Clinton's running mate, saying she believes she could do the job. She also commended Bernie Sanders' primary campaign, calling it "powerfully important" and acknowledging his ability to bring millions of people into the democratic process.

Warren's endorsement came shortly after President Barack Obama formally endorsed Clinton's candidacy, stating she is "the most qualified person to hold this office." Vice President Joe Biden also gave his endorsement, expressing support for "whoever the next president is – and God willing, it will be Hillary Clinton."

Warren, a Harvard-trained constitutional law professor, is seen as a possible running mate who could help entice back a disaffected left that has been excited by Sanders but ambivalent about Clinton. She has been vocal in her criticism of Donald Trump, attacking him in a series of speeches and setting herself up for a prominent role in the presidential election.

In a speech to the American Constitution Society in Washington D.C., Warren described Trump as "a loud, nasty, thin-skinned fraud who serves no one but himself" and criticized his attacks on Judge Gonzalo Curiel as "exactly what you would expect from somebody who is a thin-skinned racist bully."

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Arizona Immigration Law Seen as Opportunity for Romney to Highlight Obama's Handling

The recent Supreme Court decision striking down most of Arizona's immigration law has sparked a debate among political strategists about its potential impact on the presidential race. While some see the ruling as a blow to Republicans who had touted the law as a model for state enforcement efforts, others believe it could actually benefit Mitt Romney's campaign.

According to several GOP strategists, the ruling provides Romney with a critical opportunity to highlight the Obama administration's "poor handling" of illegal immigration. Analysts suggest that Arizona's ongoing struggle to enforce its own immigration law could help feed the narrative that the federal government needs to step in with a better approach, which Romney claims to be offering.

Romney's opponents, however, argue that the ruling will not have a significant impact on the election. "I don't think it's going to get him any net advantage," said Don Fowler, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "The electoral impact of this is going to be relatively minor."

The ruling upheld one provision of Arizona's law, requiring law enforcement to check immigration status during routine stops for those they suspect may be in the country illegally. However, it struck down three other provisions, including one that allowed Arizona's law enforcement to arrest those they think might be guilty of a deportable offense.

Romney's campaign has already taken a stance on the issue, with a statement saying that President Obama has failed to provide any leadership on immigration and that the country needs a comprehensive plan to address the issue. Obama, on the other hand, has argued that Republicans have persistently blocked reforms to the immigration system and that a patchwork of state laws is not a solution to the problem.

The ruling has also sparked debate among analysts about the best approach to addressing illegal immigration. Some, like former South Carolina GOP chairman Van Hipp, Jr., believe Romney should focus on the national security aspects of securing the border, while others argue that the issue is too complex and divisive to be a key factor in the election.

Title: Republicans Face Shift in Public Opinion on Gay Marriage

The US Supreme Court is set to hear arguments in two gay marriage cases this week, and the political landscape on this hot social issue is rapidly shifting. Recent headlines reflect the growing support for gay marriage, with 58% of Americans now saying gay and lesbian couples should be allowed to get married, according to the latest Washington Post/ABC poll.

The shift in public opinion is most challenging for Republicans, who are struggling to adapt to the changing attitudes. When Senator Rob Portman of Ohio came out in support of same-sex marriage, fellow Republicans professed their personal support while gently disagreeing with his stance. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, a potential presidential candidate in 2016, wrestled with the issue, stating that he is "of two minds" on the topic.

Other Republican leaders, such as Senator Saxby Chambliss of Georgia, have taken a more dismissive approach, joking that he is not gay and therefore does not plan to marry one. Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, a potential presidential candidate, took a more libertarian stance, stating that he does not want the government promoting something he does not believe in, but also does not mind if the government remains neutral on the issue.

In a significant development, Ken Mehlman, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, gathered signatures from 131 prominent Republicans to file a friend-of-the-court brief in support of same-sex marriage. Margaret Hoover, a former George W. Bush White House aide and a leading Republican Party operative, believes it is not out of the question for the next Republican nominee for the White House to support gay marriage.

The polls suggest that the issue is changing more rapidly with the public than it is with the GOP. According to the Pew Research Center, 70% of millennials (those born after 1980) support same-sex marriage, up from 51% when President Obama took office in 2009. The Post/ABC poll finds that 81% of adults under 30 support same-sex marriage.

The Republican Party is attempting to rebrand itself as more inclusive, with former Florida Governor Jeb Bush chiding his party for appearing "anti-everything," including "anti-gay." Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus also emphasized the importance of dignity and respect for all individuals, stating that nobody deserves to have their dignity diminished or be disrespected.

Title: Trump's Claim About Fauci's Disagreement on China Travel Restrictions Contradicts Previous Statements

Article: President Trump recently claimed on Fox News Business that he restricted travel with China, and Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, disagreed with the decision, but later agreed that it saved hundreds of thousands of lives. However, this claim contradicts previous statements from both Trump and Fauci.

During the April 13 coronavirus task force press briefing, Trump was asked if he and Fauci were "on the same page." Trump responded, "Yeah, we have been from the beginning." At the same briefing, Fauci discussed how responsive Trump was to the recommendations made by the task force, including the recommendation to restrict travel with China.

Fauci has consistently supported the travel restrictions with China, publicly stating that "because there are so many unknowns here, we're going to take the action that the secretary will describe [restricting travel from China], in a temporary way, to make sure we mitigate, as best as we possibly can, this risk." He also stated that the travel restrictions would "dampen down" the spread of the virus and protect Americans from travel-related cases.

Fauci's statements contradict Trump's claim that Fauci disagreed with the decision. In fact, Fauci was an early advocate for restricting travel with China, and his public statements and internal government discussions confirm that he supported the decision.

The article also notes that while Trump initially was skeptical of the travel restrictions, he was convinced by Fauci, CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar to implement the restrictions. The restrictions were implemented based on the uniform recommendations of career public health officials at the Department of Health and Human Services.

In conclusion, Trump's claim about Fauci's disagreement on China travel restrictions is inaccurate, and the available information suggests that Fauci consistently supported the decision.

Title: Mueller's Grand Jury Move Sparks Media Frenzy, But Is It Really a Big Deal?

The Wall Street Journal's report that special counsel Robert Mueller has impaneled a grand jury in Washington has sent shockwaves through the media and the public. The move is being seen as a sign that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election is intensifying. However, as an old Justice Department reporter notes, convening a grand jury is a routine step in the investigative process and not necessarily a sign of anything extraordinary.

In fact, there was already a grand jury in place in Alexandria, Virginia, which the FBI was using in this case before Mueller was appointed. The association of grand juries with indictments has led to speculation that the move could be a sign that Mueller is building a case against President Trump or his inner circle. However, it's important to note that grand juries are often used to gather evidence and question witnesses, and it's impossible to know for certain what Mueller's intentions are.

The Washington Post and USA Today have reported that the grand jury will give Mueller the power to subpoena documents and compel witnesses to testify under oath, which could potentially accelerate the resolution of the investigation. Trump's lawyer, Ty Cobb, has welcomed the move, saying it could help bring the investigation to a close.

While the grand jury's existence has sparked a media frenzy, it's worth noting that grand jury proceedings are typically secret, except when leaks occur, which has been a hallmark of this administration. The grand jury's existence could eventually pose a serious threat to the White House, but for now, it's mainly fueled speculation and media attention.

Title: Facebook's Fact-Checking Conundrum: A Nuanced Look at a Misleading Headline

The recent controversy surrounding The Weekly Standard's labeling of an article by Ian Millhiser, justice editor at ThinkProgress, as "false" has sparked a heated debate about the role of fact-checking in the digital age. The article in question, which claimed that Brett Kavanaugh said he would "kill" Roe v. Wade, has been criticized for being misleading, with some arguing that the headline's strong language is an exaggeration.

The stakes are high, as Facebook's fact-checking program, which has granted The Weekly Standard the power to formally fact-check articles, can have a significant impact on a publication's traffic and credibility. According to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, articles tagged as false will lose 80% of their future traffic, making the accuracy of fact-checking a crucial issue.

Millhiser, a vocal critic of Facebook's decision to grant fact-checking powers to The Weekly Standard, argues that the outlet's editors have acted with reckless disregard for the truth. However, a closer examination of the article reveals that the headline's claim is, at the very least, nuanced.

The article in question does not quote Kavanaugh as saying he would "kill" Roe v. Wade, but rather cites his comments on the "Glucksberg test," a Supreme Court decision that established the Constitution does not protect a right to physician-assisted suicide. Kavanaugh's statements suggest that he may be inclined to overturn Roe v. Wade, but the language used in the headline is misleading.

In his follow-up article, Millhiser argues that the definition of the verb "said" is crucial in understanding the headline's claim. While the dictionary does list "indicate," "show," and "communicate" as possible definitions for the word, "said" is generally used as a synonym for these actions when the subject is a person who uses words. In this case, the headline's claim that Kavanaugh "said" he would "kill" Roe v. Wade is an exaggeration.

Ultimately, the controversy highlights the importance of nuanced language and the need for fact-checking to be accurate and transparent. While The Weekly Standard's fact-checking powers may have been granted, it is crucial that the outlet's editors exercise their responsibility with care and attention to detail.

Title: NRA Leaders Warn of Ongoing Battle for Gun Rights

The National Rifle Association (NRA) held its annual meeting in Houston, where leaders warned members that President Barack Obama and gun control advocates will stop at nothing to curtail their rights. The NRA leaders used dire language to predict that liberals will use the next shooting tragedy to rally support for stricter gun control measures.

According to NRA Chief Wayne LaPierre, the Senate's recent vote to block background check legislation is just one skirmish in a long war against Constitutional rights. LaPierre emphasized that the NRA is in the midst of a once-in-a-generation fight for everything they care about, stating that the group has a chance to secure their freedom for a generation or lose it forever.

The NRA has grown to a record 5 million members in the wake of the post-Newtown battle, according to LaPierre. He vowed that the organization will "go the distance" and "never give up or sacrifice our constitutional freedom." LaPierre also emphasized that the NRA will "never surrender our guns."

Chris Cox, the group's chief lobbyist, quoted an old Margaret Thatcher line that victories in politics are never final. Cox stated that the NRA is stronger than ever, but freedom is under attack like never before, and the group must be stronger.

The NRA leaders' warnings come as the debate over gun control continues to unfold in the United States.

Title: Lawmakers Push for Federal Standards to Protect Electric Grid from Attack

Article:

Lawmakers are pushing for federal standards to protect the country's electric grid from attack, following a recent report about a sniper assault on a California electrical substation last year. The incident, which occurred on April 16, 2013, involved snipping AT&T fiber-optic lines and firing shots into a Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) substation, causing outages.

According to The Wall Street Journal, Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) and fellow senators plan to ask the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), which has jurisdiction over the electric grid's reliability, to set minimum security standards for critical substations. The FBI is leading the investigation into the incident, but an agency spokesman told the newspaper that it does not believe the incident was a terror attack.

The attack, which was not widely publicized until The Wall Street Journal reported new details, involved intruders lifting heavy manhole covers, cutting AT&T fiber-optic cables, and firing over 100 rounds into substation equipment, disabling 17 of 20 big transformers and causing about $16 million in damage. No arrests have been made in the case.

During an oversight hearing in December, Representative Henry Waxman (D-Calif.) described the incident as an "unprecedented and sophisticated attack on an electric grid substation with military-style weapons." He said he had been in touch with the FBI about the incident but withheld details to avoid harming the investigation.

One proposal being discussed in Congress would give the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission the power to write and impose interim rules on grid defenses. The utility industry would still be able to influence any permanent requirements, according to the Journal. Representative Trent Franks (R-Ariz.) said, "The last thing I want to do is regulate any industry," but added that utilities must do more to protect the grid for the sake of national security.

Under current law, the commission has to accept or reject proposals written by an industry-dominated group, but cannot alter them. Some utility industry executives told the Journal that it would be difficult to come up with rules for improving security that would work in both urban and rural areas. "One size fits all may not get you true resiliency," said Lisa Barton, executive vice president of transmission for American Electric Power, adding that increasing protections could be costly. "I'm not saying it isn't worth it," she said.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Meets with President Trump Amid Russia Investigation

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who serves as the second-in-command at the Department of Justice, met with President Donald Trump at the White House on Thursday. The meeting was arranged quickly, with Rosenstein being called away from an event at the Justice Department to attend the meeting. According to a White House official, the meeting was focused on "routine department business."

Rosenstein was accompanied by FBI officials and discussed document production to Congress during the meeting, which lasted about an hour. He also met with White House Counsel Don McGahn. The meeting comes at a sensitive time for Rosenstein, as Trump has been publicly venting his frustration with the deputy attorney general and Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Trump has been critical of Rosenstein's role in the investigation, specifically his decision to sign a FISA surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The president has repeatedly decried the Department of Justice and FBI's efforts to obtain the warrant. Trump has also expressed frustration with Attorney General Jeff Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, which led to Rosenstein's appointment as special counsel.

Some Trump supporters have called for Rosenstein's ouster, citing his role in the investigation and his decision to appoint Mueller as special counsel. However, Trump himself has not publicly called for Rosenstein's removal, and has instead agreed to cooperate with the investigation. In a tweet, Trump stated that he has agreed with his legal team's approach of cooperating with Mueller's probe.

The meeting between Trump and Rosenstein comes amid a renewed push from some Trump supporters to shut down the Russia investigation. Former Trump adviser Stephen Bannon has publicly encouraged Trump to stop cooperating with Mueller's requests, citing concerns over executive privilege. However, Trump has denied seeking to shut down the investigation, stating that he would have fired Mueller if he had wanted to.

Title: Experts Debate Risks and Responsibilities Amidst COVID-19 Surges and Protests

The recent surge in COVID-19 cases in several US states has sparked concerns about the risks of reopening the economy and the potential consequences of protests against systemic racism and police violence. Experts are divided on the issue, with some arguing that the protests may lead to a significant spike in coronavirus infections and deaths, while others believe that the risks are manageable and that public health officials should focus on harm reduction strategies.

According to data, new hotspots are emerging in Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, and Utah, with the positive test rate increasing from less than 8% at the end of May to nearly 14% now. Some experts attribute the surge to increased testing, while others point to the reopening of businesses and public spaces as a contributing factor.

The nationwide protests over George Floyd's death, police violence, and structural racism have also raised concerns about the potential for superspreading events. However, experts note that it is too early to determine whether the protests will lead to a significant increase in COVID-19 cases. Additionally, the difference between outdoor and indoor exposure is significant, with indoor exposure being much more dangerous.

Some experts argue that public health officials should not tolerate the abuse and manipulation of health expertise for political ends. They suggest that either the protests will lead to a significant spike in coronavirus infections and deaths, or they will not, and that public health experts should be held accountable for their actions.

Others note that protesters are aware of the risks of COVID-19 transmission and are taking precautions. They argue that public health experts should focus on harm reduction strategies, such as providing masks and protective gear, rather than trying to stop the protests altogether.

Many experts have adopted a harm-reduction approach to the protests, acknowledging that they will happen and offering recommendations to help people protest safely. Others have gone further, providing masks and protective gear on-site. The decision reflects the goal of public health experts to maximize the health of the population across all aspects of life.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding the risks and responsibilities of reopening the economy and protesting against systemic racism and police violence highlights the complexity of the issue. While some experts are concerned about the potential consequences of the protests, others believe that the risks are manageable and that public health officials should focus on harm reduction strategies. Ultimately, the decision on how to proceed will depend on a careful consideration of the facts and the best available evidence.

Title: House Immigration Reform Efforts Gain Momentum as Speaker Meets with Hispanic Caucus

The House of Representatives is set to take a significant step forward in addressing immigration reform this week, with the Judiciary Committee holding its first markup on an enforcement-centered bill and a meeting between Speaker John Boehner and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. The bipartisan group, which has been working on a bill for four years, is finally on the verge of producing a comprehensive immigration reform package.

The House Judiciary Committee will hold its first markup on Tuesday, focusing on an enforcement-centered bill that Democrats have criticized. Meanwhile, the all-Democratic Congressional Hispanic Caucus will meet with Speaker Boehner on Wednesday, a meeting seen as a significant step towards finding common ground. Rep. Luis Gutierrez, head of the CHC immigration task force, emphasized the importance of cooperation, stating, "He wants to get comprehensive immigration reform; we want to get comprehensive immigration reform passed. We should form a pact. Let's cement it this Wednesday."

The dual-track approach could signal actual momentum on House immigration reform, which has lagged behind efforts in the Senate. The Senate is currently considering the bipartisan Gang of Eight bill on the floor and may vote on it before the July 4th recess. The House group, composed of three Republicans and four Democrats, appears poised to unveil its bill, which could come as early as Wednesday or later in the week.

Negotiators still need to meet again to finalize the language and review the bill's language, which has come back from the House legislative counsel. The four Democratic negotiators will update all House Democrats at a caucus meeting on Tuesday. The group's Democratic members are also having smaller briefings with different members throughout the week.

While the meeting between Boehner and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus is seen as a significant step towards finding common ground, it remains to be seen whether the House will be able to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill.

Title: White House Warns of Potential $200 Billion Drop in Consumer Spending if Tax Cuts Aren't Extended

The White House released a report on Monday, coinciding with the biggest online shopping day of the year, Cyber Monday, warning that consumer spending could drop by nearly $200 billion in 2013 if Congress fails to approve an extension of tax cuts for the middle class by the end of next month. The report, from the National Economic Council and the Council of Economic Advisers, analyzed the impact on retailers if taxes go up on January 1 for families earning less than $250,000 per year.

According to the report, allowing middle-class tax rates to rise and failing to pay for a short-term "patch" of the Alternative Minimum Tax could cut the growth of consumer spending by 1.7 percentage points in 2013. The administration estimates that consumers could spend nearly $200 billion less next year just because of higher taxes, about four times the amount that shoppers spent during the "Black Friday" weekend in 2011.

The White House is urging lawmakers to come together to renew middle-class tax cuts, providing families and businesses with more certainty at a critical time for the economy. The administration's release of the report seemed a calculated effort to build support for President Obama's position in negotiations with Congress to avert the so-called "fiscal cliff," a mix of tax increases and automatic spending cuts due to take effect in January.

Lawmakers in both parties have expressed optimism that they will reach at least a stopgap deal with the White House before the end of the year. Senator Jon Kyl, an Arizona Republican, said in an interview on CNN that a compromise will be necessary to get through the end of the year and into next year.

Title: Uncertainty Surrounds Treatment of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev as Enemy Combatant

The legal status of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving Boston Marathon bombing suspect, remains unclear, with some lawmakers debating whether he can be held as an enemy combatant. Senator Lindsey Graham, a leading Republican voice on national security, believes it would be lawful to hold Tsarnaev as an enemy combatant, citing the Supreme Court's Hamdi v. Rumsfeld decision. However, other lawmakers disagree, and the question remains unresolved.

In the Hamdi case, the Supreme Court upheld the indefinite military detention of an American citizen, Yaser Esam Hamdi, who was captured carrying a weapon on the Afghanistan battlefield. The court did not resolve the case of Jose Padilla, an American citizen held as an enemy combatant for several years after his arrest in Chicago, as two federal appeals courts disagreed about the legality of holding him in indefinite detention without trial.

In the Hamdi ruling, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote that there is no bar to the nation holding one of its own citizens as an enemy combatant, but noted that the decision was limited to the "narrow circumstances" of the case. She also emphasized that the purpose of wartime detention is to keep captured enemies from returning to fight, and that indefinite detention for the purpose of interrogation is not authorized.

Senator Graham believes that holding Tsarnaev as a military detainee would allow for lengthy questioning without a lawyer, citing the Obama administration's plan to use a public-safety exception to the Miranda rule to question him for a period without warning him of his rights. However, Graham acknowledged that ultimately, Tsarnaev must be transferred back to the civilian criminal justice system for prosecution, as the statute authorizing military commissions does not apply to United States citizens.

Graham emphasized that interrogation as an enemy combatant would not involve inflicting suffering on Tsarnaev to make him talk, and that anything he said in military detention would not be used as courtroom evidence. He rejected the view that the Federal Bureau of Investigation might be equally or more effective than intelligence officials at persuading Tsarnaev to provide information, even with a defense lawyer present. Graham believes that interrogators need to build a rapport with a prisoner, suggesting that the presence of a lawyer would disrupt this dynamic.

In conclusion, the legal status of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev remains unclear, with lawmakers debating whether he can be held as an enemy combatant. While Senator Graham believes it would be lawful, others disagree, and the question remains unresolved.

Title: Biden Campaigns in Michigan Ahead of Presidential Primary

The former Vice President Joe Biden visited Detroit on Monday, seeking votes, volunteers, and campaign cash in the crucial state of Michigan. Speaking to a crowd of about 1,000 people at Renaissance High School, Biden emphasized the importance of winning Michigan in the November election. He highlighted his experience working with Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan during the city's bankruptcy and his commitment to the state.

Biden was joined by two of his former Democratic presidential rivals, U.S. Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker, who praised Biden's ability to unite the country and beat Donald Trump. However, not everyone in the crowd was a Biden supporter, with about a dozen protesters carrying Green New Deal signs disrupting the rally.

The event was part of a busy day for Biden, who also attended a $1,000-per-person fundraiser at the Detroit Athletic Club and met with health officials and the media in Grand Rapids. Despite some small crowds at his events, Biden's numbers have surged in recent polls, with a 24-point lead over Bernie Sanders in a poll of 400 Michigan voters.

Biden's rally in Detroit featured a raucous crowd, a marching band, and signs emblazoned with "Joementum" and "Michiganders love Biden!" He emphasized the importance of the election, saying it's a battle for the soul of America and a choice between decency and the chaos of the Trump administration.

Title: The Media's Missed Opportunity: A Chance to Re-Gain Trust

The election of Donald Trump has presented the media with a unique opportunity to re-gain the trust of a significant portion of the American public. A Gallup poll in September 2016 showed that only 14% of Americans have "a great deal" of trust in the news media to report the news fully, accurately, and fairly. This lack of trust is particularly evident among Trump's 63 million voters, who may have felt that the media was biased against them during the campaign.

The media has a chance to change this narrative by treating Trump's presidency with the same respect and professionalism they showed during Barack Obama's presidency in 2008. Instead of celebrating Trump's election as a historic occasion, many news organizations have continued to be mean and petty, focusing on perceived chaos in the transition team and Trump's alleged lack of preparedness.

For example, The New York Times reported that Trump's transition team was in disarray, citing firings, infighting, and difficulties in reaching the president-elect. However, this narrative was later proven to be inaccurate, as Trump's transition went smoothly and he appointed a competent Cabinet.

The media's failure to adapt to the changing political landscape has led to declining audiences and revenue losses. The New York Times itself is facing layoffs and is planning to rent out office space to offset declining ad revenue.

The media's liberal bias and lack of representation from the nation's interior have contributed to this decline. Many news organizations are based in liberal strongholds like Washington, New York, and Los Angeles, and are staffed by people who may not have a deep understanding of the nation's interior.

The Columbia Journalism Review has urged reporters to abandon objectivity and stop Trump, citing the declining audience for traditional news. However, this approach has only led to further division and mistrust. Instead, the media should focus on providing balanced coverage and giving readers and viewers a reason to trust them again.

In conclusion, the media has a chance to re-gain the trust of the American public by treating Trump's presidency with respect and professionalism. By doing so, they can increase their audience and revenue, and provide a vital service to the public.

Title: Trump Welcomes Conservative Social Media Provocateurs to White House, Criticizes Big Tech

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump hosted a meeting with prominent conservative social media personalities at the White House on Thursday, where he expressed concerns about alleged censorship and suppression of conservative voices by big tech firms. Trump stated that his administration is exploring regulations and legislation to protect free speech, although he did not provide specific details on the measures being considered.

The meeting brought together dozens of pro-Trump online personalities, including social media influencers, activists, and lawyers, who shared their concerns about alleged censorship on social media platforms. Trump himself has been a vocal critic of social media, using it as a key part of his 2016 and 2020 presidential campaigns.

Freedom of speech is enshrined in the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and Trump emphasized that "we're not going to be silenced." He also acknowledged that some conservative users of social media may engage in online behavior that is deemed unacceptable, but argued that they should still have a voice.

The meeting was attended by several members of Trump's cabinet and White House team, as well as his son Donald Trump Jr. The event was marked by freewheeling remarks from Trump, who discussed the power of social media and railed against the traditional media.

The meeting has been met with criticism from some quarters, with Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, saying that instead of focusing on combating Russian social media misinformation, punishing anti-competitive practices, or protecting Americans' data and privacy, the president has invited "trolls, conspiracy theorists, anti-Semites, and the whole comments section to the White House."

Facebook, Twitter, and Google declined to comment on Trump's announcement that he would bring them to the White House for a meeting. The Internet Association, a trade group representing major tech firms, stated that "internet companies are not biased against any political ideology, and conservative voices in particular have used social media to great effect."

The meeting is the latest development in a long-standing debate about alleged conservative bias on social media platforms. Republicans in Congress have held numerous hearings on the issue, and Senator Josh Hawley, who is working on proposed legislation, took the stage briefly to air his complaints.

Title: Pope Francis' Unconventional Approach Sparks Mixed Reactions in the United States

Pope Francis, the head of the Roman Catholic Church, is currently visiting the United States for the first time. His approval ratings in the country have taken a tumble, from 76% in 2014 to 59% today, according to Gallup. The Pope's unconventional approach to his role has sparked a mix of emotions among Americans, with some viewing him as a champion of social justice and others seeing him as a threat to traditional values.

The Pope's emphasis on caring for the poor, his rejection of opulent living arrangements, and his focus on environmental issues have earned him admiration from some. However, his criticism of unfettered capitalism and his views on issues like same-sex marriage, women's ordination, and abortion have led to scorn and fear among others.

Conservative figures like R. Albert Mohler Jr., president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, have expressed concerns about the Pope's views on wealth distribution and his perceived criticism of American capitalism. Mohler believes the Pope's words are "dangerous" and have "split Roman Catholicism on that issue."

Progressives, on the other hand, see the Pope as a champion of social justice, citing his criticism of greedy Wall Street types, his views on climate change, and his support for undocumented immigrants. However, they are also disappointed by the Church's stance on certain moral issues.

The Pope's approach has been described as "difficult to read" and "not always a people-pleaser" by Rev. Thomas Bohlin, vicar of Opus Dei. The Pope's goal is not to be popular, but to challenge people to think and take responsibility for their actions.

New York Mayor Bill de Blasio noted that the Pope is not concerned with his approval ratings, but rather with "telling the truth" and promoting a new path forward. The Pope's encyclical has been seen as a call to action, urging people to take responsibility for their role in addressing environmental and social issues.

Overall, Pope Francis' visit to the United States has sparked a complex and multifaceted reaction, with some viewing him as a champion of social justice and others seeing him as a threat to traditional values.

**Suspected Cop Killer Eric Frein Captured After 48-Day Manhunt in Pennsylvania**

Eric Frein, a 31-year-old self-styled survivalist and fantasy soldier, was captured on Thursday after a 48-day manhunt in northeast Pennsylvania. He was found at an abandoned airplane hangar in the Pocono Mountains, where he had apparently taken refuge.

Frein was suspected of killing a state trooper and injuring another in a brazen sniper ambush attack on September 12. He was taken into custody by a team of US marshals assisting in the manhunt, and was transported to the Pike County Correctional Facility.

According to police, Frein was clean-shaven and "healthier than expected" at the time of his arrest, with a minor cut on his nose that was not caused by police. There were conflicting reports about whether Frein was armed at the moment of his arrest.

Frein's capture came after a massive manhunt that involved state police, FBI, and ATF agents, as well as civilian tracking experts. The search was hampered by the dense and rugged terrain of the Pocono Mountains, as well as concerns about another sniper attack on searchers.

Prosecutors have announced that they will seek the death penalty for Frein, who faces charges of murder and bomb-making. However, his motives for the attack remain unclear, and may only be revealed at his upcoming trial.

Frein's past has been marked by a history of fascination with war games and survival skills, and he had been jailed for 109 days in the mid-2000s for larceny related to a war-reenactment festival in New York. His work history is patchy, and he had been known to play organized war games using rifles that shoot rubber bullets.

The capture of Frein has sparked questions about the effectiveness of the manhunt and the tactics used by law enforcement. Some civilian tracking experts have noted that police methods may have fallen short, and that the combination of thick geography and concerns about another sniper attack on searchers had slowed the manhunt down.

The shooting and manhunt also came in a year marked by anti-police protests in New York City and Ferguson, Missouri, over cases where unarmed black men were killed by white police officers.

Title: Trump Refuses to Address Police Violence Against Black People, Instead Highlights White Victims

Article:

In an interview with CBS, President Donald Trump refused to answer a question about police violence against Black people, instead pointing out that white people are also sometimes victims of police violence. Trump stated, "And so are white people, so are white people," when asked why Black Americans are still dying at the hands of law enforcement.

According to a Washington Post database, white people make up roughly half of the people shot and killed annually by police, while Black people make up only 13% of the population. The database also shows that the rate at which Black people are shot and killed by law enforcement is twice as high as that of white people.

Trump also defended the Confederate flag, stating that it is a matter of freedom of speech. When asked if he would be comfortable with his supporters displaying the Confederate flag at political events, Trump replied that he is "comfortable with freedom of speech." He also mentioned NASCAR, which banned the Confederate flag from its events after Darrell "Bubba" Wallace Jr. called for change in the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd.

Trump has been criticized for his insistence on protecting monuments that honor Confederate leaders who fought to protect slavery and uphold white supremacy. He threatened to veto Congress' annual defense authorization bill if it contained language to rename U.S. military bases honoring Confederate commanders. Trump signed an executive order at the end of June to protect federal monuments after statues memorializing the Confederacy and some of the nation's Founding Fathers were vandalized.

Title: Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin Raises Concerns Over Voter Fraud in Gubernatorial Election

Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin expressed concerns over potential voter fraud in the state's gubernatorial election, citing "irregularities" and a "history of vote fraud" in the state. The governor's remarks came as he requested a recanvass of the results, which showed him trailing his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Andy Beshear, by about 5,000 votes.

Bevin pointed to "thousands of absentee ballots that were illegally counted," voters being "incorrectly turned away," and voting machines "not working properly" as potential issues. He also stated that his team is collecting affidavits and other information to better understand what happened during the election.

The Kentucky Secretary of State, Alison Lundergan Grimes, has scheduled a recanvass for next Thursday to ensure the vote count was accurate. However, Bevin would need a court's approval to pursue a recount.

While some prominent Kentucky Republicans have acknowledged Beshear's apparent victory, Bevin has refused to concede, citing the need for a thorough investigation. The election saw a significant increase in voter turnout, with over 1.4 million voters participating, a nearly 50% increase from the 2015 governor's race.

President Trump, who held a rally in Kentucky on Monday, claimed that his event had a "massive impact" on the election, stating that the increase in votes for the governor's race was at least 15 points, and possibly 20.

Title: North Carolina Passes Voter ID Law, Joining Other States in Requiring Identification at Polls

The North Carolina House has approved a measure requiring voters to present photo identification at the polls, joining a growing list of states that have implemented similar laws. The Republican-dominated House passed the bill late Thursday night, citing its intention to prevent voter fraud and ensure the integrity of the election process.

The bill, which was approved by the state Senate a day earlier, will require voters to present a valid government-issued photo ID at the polls. Proponents of the bill argue that this measure will help prevent voter fraud and ensure that voters are who they claim to be. Senate President Pro Tempore Phil Berger stated that the bill will "bring North Carolina in line with the majority of other states that already require voter ID."

However, critics of the bill argue that it will disproportionately affect certain groups, including the poor, minority, and disabled voters. The American Civil Liberties Union of North Carolina described the bill as an "attack on democracy at its core" and listed several provisions that it believes will make it harder for eligible voters to participate in elections. These provisions include eliminating same-day voter registration, shortening early voting, and eliminating state-mandated voter registration drives.

In the past two years, at least 11 states have approved laws requiring voters to show identification at the polls. The Supreme Court's decision to strike down Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act last month has allowed states to implement these laws without federal approval. Attorney General Eric Holder expressed displeasure with the decision, stating that it will make it easier for states to implement voting laws that may discriminate against certain groups.

The Justice Department has already taken steps to challenge some of these laws, and civil rights groups are also expected to file lawsuits to block the laws under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. The debate over voter ID laws is likely to continue, with proponents arguing that they are necessary to prevent fraud and critics arguing that they will disproportionately affect certain groups.

Title: Court Rules Officials' Actions Not Criminal, Despite Corruption Allegations

The United States Court of Appeals has ruled that government officials' actions in realigning toll lanes were not criminal under federal law, as they did not obtain any money or property. The court concluded that the officials' actions were motivated by partisan aims, aiming to make life harder for constituents of their political opponents, but this was not a federal crime.

This decision is not an isolated incident. The court has previously vacated the conviction of a former Virginia governor who gave out access to meetings in exchange for political donations. The court accepted that this behavior is a common practice in government, even if it is "distasteful."

The court's willingness to permit public officials to engage in corrupt behavior is not new. In previous cases, the court has invalidated statutes designed to combat public corruption, citing concerns that money in politics is a normal part of government operations. The court has also struck down limits on campaign expenditures and contributions, arguing that these limits are unnecessary and unconstitutional.

The recent decision in the Bridgegate scandal comes at a time of heightened public concern about government corruption, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. The scandal involves allegations of government officials using their power for partisan gain, including claims that the president and other officials have prioritized political considerations over public health and safety. The Department of Justice has refused to prosecute the president's national security adviser for lying to the government and secretly working for a foreign government.

The court's decision highlights the ongoing debate about the role of money in politics and the limits of federal criminal law in addressing corruption. While the court has ruled that the officials' actions were not criminal, the decision has sparked concerns about the potential for corruption and the need for stronger laws to prevent it.

Title: Unlikely Alliance Forms as Democrats and Tea Party Activists Consider Challenging McConnell in Kentucky Primary

Article:

In an unusual move, Democratic donors, local liberal activists, and a left-leaning super PAC in Kentucky are considering throwing their support behind a right-wing candidate to challenge Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell in a 2014 primary election. The goal is to weaken McConnell and make him more vulnerable in the general election, where Democrats still maintain a voter registration advantage. Alternatively, they hope to see a weak candidate emerge, similar to Todd Akin or Richard Mourdock, who may actually lose.

The liberal group MoveOn and the Democratic super PAC, Progress Kentucky, have begun circulating petitions urging Republicans to jump into the race. Democratic donors active in Bluegrass State and national politics are privately making it clear they are willing to help bankroll a tea party candidate. However, neither the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee nor the Kentucky Democratic Party is involved in these efforts at this point.

Sarah Durand, president of the Louisville Tea Party, said Democratic donors and activists have told her they would be willing to spend seven figures in a GOP primary to help a candidate willing to challenge McConnell. Durand noted that tea party groups are not satisfied with McConnell's three-decade tenure in Washington, but the challenge lies in recruiting a candidate who wouldn't hand the seat to the Democrats.

Meanwhile, McConnell and his veteran campaign staff are working swiftly to snuff out any primary challenge. McConnell has attended over 100 tea party meetings in the state over the past two years and has stumped at three tea party rallies, including one with Senator Rand Paul. He has also held face-to-face meetings with several tea party types, including Durand and her fellow activists. McConnell has also brought under his wing the two biggest forces in tea party politics in the state: Paul and freshman Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), who initially was seen as a possible primary threat to the GOP leader.

Title: World Leaders Gather to Discuss Climate Extremes, but Some Question the Urgency

Article:

World leaders gathered in Manhattan on Tuesday to discuss climate extremes and hear President Obama's concerns about the issue. However, some experts and leaders are questioning the urgency of the matter, citing the need for a balanced approach to energy and development.

The President urged world leaders to abandon the pursuit of prosperity and focus on addressing climate change, but many recognize that giving up affordable energy sources that emit carbon dioxide would hinder economic growth. Several European nations have already rejected the idea of a binding worldwide treaty, which collapsed in Copenhagen five years ago.

Even Hollywood seems to be losing interest in the topic, with a recent study showing a decline in mentions of climate change in movies and TV shows. The phenomenon peaked after Al Gore's documentary "An Inconvenient Truth" debuted in 2006, but has since become a supporting role in some films.

Some experts argue that the Earth is resilient and can withstand the effects of climate change, citing examples such as Antarctica's growing sea ice and the fact that island nations like Fiji and Vanuatu are still intact. New Scientist magazine recently reported that the Antarctic sea ice is expanding due to warming winds in the Southern Hemisphere.

The article concludes that while the world's diplomats should give President Obama polite applause, they should not prioritize climate change over economic development.

Title: Congress Must Act to Limit Damage of Cuba Deal

The recent deal between the United States and Cuba, which saw the release of American hostage Alan Gross in exchange for three Cuban spies, has been widely criticized for its lack of progress towards freedom in Cuba. The deal has been seen as a lifeline to Cuba's dictators, rather than a step towards democracy and human rights.

The deal has also been criticized for its failure to secure any significant concessions from the Cuban government. In fact, the deal has been seen as a surrender to the demands of the Castro regime, which has been making demands for normalization for decades.

Congress has the power to limit the damage of this deal and ensure that the United States does not become complicit in Cuba's human rights abuses. The Helms-Burton Act of 1996 gives Congress the authority to override any action taken by the executive to lift the embargo on Cuba, and Congress can use this power to block any further normalization efforts.

Additionally, Congress can make it clear to the President that there are statutory criteria that must be met before Cuba can be taken off the State Department's list of terrorism sponsors. These criteria include a change of leadership and policies, as well as assurances that Cuba will no longer support terrorist acts.

Senators can also put a hold on any ambassador nominated to serve in Cuba unless the Cuban government can demonstrate significant progress towards democracy and human rights. Senator Marco Rubio has already announced his intention to do so.

Furthermore, Congress can use policy riders in the upcoming DHS appropriations debate and the Fiscal Year 2016 appropriations process to deny the President funds for setting up relations with Cuba.

The deal has been widely criticized for its lack of progress towards freedom in Cuba, and Congress must act to limit the damage. The President's approach has been seen as feckless, and Congress must take a stronger stance to ensure that the United States does not become complicit in Cuba's human rights abuses.

Title: Trump Urges Muslim Leaders to Combat Extremism and Isolate Iran

Article:

In a historic speech in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, President Trump emphasized the importance of Muslim nations taking the lead in combating extremism and isolating Iran. The speech marked a significant departure from the previous administration's approach, as Trump vowed that the U.S. would be a strong partner in the fight against terrorism, but emphasized that Muslim nations must take the initiative in preaching religious tolerance and ferreting out extremists.

Trump stressed that there can be no coexistence with terrorism, and that it is up to Muslim leaders to take action. He called for a unified front to combat and isolate Iran, a common enemy of many in the room. The president also emphasized the need for a message of religious tolerance and anti-violence to come from political and religious leaders in the Muslim world.

The speech was well-received, with Saudi King Salman introducing Trump with a plea for unity in the fight against extremism. Trump's message was blunt and at times grim about the struggle against evil, but he delivered it with a tone of respect for the assembled leaders and optimism that they would prevail.

The strategy outlined by Trump included denying territory or safe havens for extremists and cutting off financial streams to groups associated with terrorism. He stressed that more than military action, a message of religious tolerance and anti-violence had to come from political and religious leaders in the Muslim world.

The speech also marked a significant shift in Trump's rhetoric, as he did not use the phrase "radical Islamic terrorism," a phrase he had previously criticized President Obama for not using. Instead, Trump referred to "Islamists" and "Islamic terror," making clear the source of the extremism. However, he stressed that the U.S. was not at war with Islam.

The speech was seen as a significant moment in Trump's first trip abroad as president, which aimed to unite three major world religions and lay the foundation for Middle East peace talks. The speech was also seen as a political win for Trump at home, as the news media focus shifted briefly from accusations and investigations of collusion with Russia.

Title: Cities Across Europe and the United States Heighten Security Measures Amidst Terror Threats

Cities across Europe and the United States are taking extra precautions to ensure public safety, following a series of terror threats and attacks in recent weeks. In New York City, authorities conducted an extensive active-shooter drill, involving federal and local responders, to prepare for potential threats. Mayor Bill de Blasio praised the city's first responders, stating, "They're ready to protect us."

In Brussels, the city was placed under a high alert level, with Prime Minister Charles Michel citing an "imminent threat" to the capital. The city was effectively locked down, with commuter rails, schools, and cultural and sports venues closed. A suspicious package was evacuated from a major railway station, but no explosives were found.

In Paris, authorities are still searching for Salah Abdeslam, a suspected terrorist linked to the November 13 attacks that left 130 people dead and hundreds wounded. Abdeslam's brother, Mohamed, made a public appeal for his brother to surrender, stating he prefers to see him in jail rather than in a graveyard.

In Rome and Milan, authorities were placed on alert after the foreign ministry warned that St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City and some sites in Milan might be potential terror targets. In Los Angeles, a Southwest Airlines flight made an unscheduled landing in Kansas City after passengers reported suspicious behavior, but no explosives were found.

In Washington, D.C., Police Chief Cathy Lanier advised residents to consider taking action, including shooting, if they find themselves in the midst of a terror attack. "Your options are run, hide, or fight," she said. "If you're in a position to try and take the gunman down, to take the gunman out, it's the best option for saving lives before police can get there."

While no imminent, credible threats were reported for Washington or New York, security measures were tightened across both cities. U.S. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes noted that intelligence gathering can be challenging, stating, "We don't know what we don't know. They've gotten very good at hiding from intelligence services across the world."

Title: Senate Republicans Pledge to Acquit President Trump on Impeachment Charges

Article:

In a move that dashes hopes of Democrats, Senator Lisa Murkowski announced she will vote to acquit President Trump on both articles of impeachment this week. The Alaska senator scolded Mr. Trump for his behavior but argued that the House bungled the case against him, making it impossible to get a fair trial in the Senate. She expressed a desire for the House to have pursued censure instead.

Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, considered the most likely Democrat to side with Mr. Trump, has not yet decided how he will vote. However, he also expressed disappointment that Congress did not pursue censure, stating that Mr. Trump's dealings with Ukraine were not "perfect." Manchin believes a bipartisan majority would support censure, but impeachment will likely fail.

House Democrats made a last-ditch appeal to senators, urging them to vote to convict Mr. Trump on both articles of impeachment. Representative Adam B. Schiff, the top impeachment prosecutor, delivered a stern rebuke, stating that the president lacks character and has "betrayed" the country by subverting national security to his political whims.

The president's lawyers argue that the impeachment process has been tainted from the start and that a fair outcome is acquittal. The president's team presented a video montage of Democrats vowing impeachment in January 2017, even before the president was inaugurated, and claimed that Democrats' targeting of Mr. Trump began well before last summer's phone call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky.

Senators have two days to ponder their votes before the final action on Wednesday afternoon. House Democrats voted to impeach Mr. Trump on December 18 on two articles, accusing him of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The president's allies argue that he had the authority to request a probe into possible corruption, citing Hunter Biden's involvement with a Ukrainian energy company. Democrats, however, say Mr. Trump abused his position and that there is no basis to question the Bidens' behavior.

The impeachment trial has been marked by controversy, with Democrats accusing the president of conditioning aid on Ukraine investigating the Bidens, while the president's team denies any wrongdoing. Senators will have all day Tuesday to make remarks on the chamber floor about the impeachment proceedings, and will cast their final vote on whether to acquit Mr. Trump the following afternoon.

Title: Midterm Elections Shift Focus to National Security and Terrorism Amidst Islamic State Threat

The 2014 midterm election has taken a dramatic turn, with the rise of the Islamic State (ISIS) threat dominating the national conversation and shifting the focus away from domestic issues like ObamaCare and administration scandals. With just nine weeks until the election, candidates from both parties are scrambling to demonstrate their hawkish stance on national security and terrorism.

The sudden shift in focus has posed a challenge for both Republicans and Democrats. Republicans, who have been pulled in an isolationist direction by Senator Rand Paul, are adjusting their tone, with some, like Senator Mark Warner, urging the Obama administration to present a clear strategy for eliminating the ISIS threat. Even Senator Rand Paul, who has been critical of military intervention, acknowledged that the terror group has declared war on America.

Democrats, on the other hand, are using the focus on the Middle East to distance themselves from the Obama administration's perceived weaknesses on foreign policy. Senator Jeanne Shaheen, for example, rebuked the president on Twitter, saying that ISIS is not manageable and must be chased to the "gates of hell."

A recent poll by George Washington University found that 58% of likely voters disapprove of President Obama's handling of foreign affairs, a significant shift from his 2012 campaign, when he ran on the successful mission to take out Osama bin Laden. The same poll showed that 54% of Americans believe Obama is not tough enough on security issues.

The Pew Research Center and USA Today survey also revealed a significant change in attitudes toward America's role in the world, with 31% of Americans now saying the U.S. does too little to address world problems, a significant increase from 2013. The share who say the opposite has decreased sharply.

As the election approaches, both parties are adjusting their tone on national security and terrorism. Republicans are criticizing the Obama administration's strategy, while Democrats are trying to distance themselves from the president's perceived weaknesses on foreign policy. The outcome of the election will likely depend on how voters respond to these shifting priorities.

Title: Senate Polls Indicate Republicans May Gain Seats, Despite Democratic Predictions of "Blue Wave"

Article:

As the election season heats up, political analyst John Waage has analyzed the latest poll numbers to assess the key Senate races up for grabs. Despite predictions of a "blue wave" from Democrats and their allies in the liberal media, the polls suggest that Republicans may gain seats in the Senate.

To take control of the Senate, Democrats need to win two seats, but they face an uphill battle as they need to hold onto six states where they are facing tough challenges from Republicans. Some polls suggest that the controversy surrounding Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation may have had an impact on voter sentiment, with voters expressing concerns about due process and the "innocent until proven guilty" principle.

In North Dakota, incumbent Senator Heidi Heitkamp (D) is trailing challenger Kevin Cramer (R) by double digits, while in Missouri, Republican challenger Josh Hawley is giving incumbent Senator Claire McCaskill (D) a tough fight. In Montana, the race between incumbent Senator Jon Tester (D) and challenger Matt Rosendale (R) is nearly a dead heat.

On the other hand, Republicans are defending seats in Arizona and Tennessee, where Senators Jeff Flake and Bob Corker are retiring. In Tennessee, Republican Marsha Blackburn has a 14-point edge over Democrat Phil Bredesen, even after pop singer Taylor Swift came out against Blackburn. In Arizona, Republican Martha McSally is tied or slightly ahead of Democrat Kyrsten Sinema.

In Texas, Senator Ted Cruz (R) has increased his margin over Democrat Beto O'Rourke, but Democrats have pumped millions of dollars into the race, and O'Rourke has more campaign funding. Democrats are also hoping to take away the Republican-held seat in Nevada, where Jacky Rosen (D) is facing incumbent Senator Dean Heller (R), but Heller has a slight lead in recent polls.

According to Waage, based on the current polls, Republicans would gain two Senate seats if the election were held today. While the possibility of a House takeover is more likely for Democrats, it will ultimately come down to voter turnout. Waage believes that even if Democrats win control of the House, it will be by a very slim margin, as both bases are mobilized and Republicans were not before the Kavanaugh hearings, but are now.

**Senate Clears Path to Citizenship for Undocumented Immigrants**

The US Senate has voted to open debate on a bipartisan immigration bill, which would provide a 13-year path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants living in the country. The 82-15 vote, with most Republicans joining the Democratic majority, launched what is expected to be an arduous legislative journey for the 1,076-page measure.

The bill addresses an emotionally charged issue with huge political stakes for both parties.
