President Barack Obama and Democrats want to fulfill a promise to Hispanic Americans, the nation's fastest-growing demographic and a key voting bloc, to address the limbo of the 11 million immigrants living illegally in the country.

The legislation would increase spending on border security and require undocumented immigrants to pursue a 13-year path to eventual citizenship. President Obama emphasized that this path would involve background checks, learning English, paying taxes, and a penalty, as well as going to the back of the line behind those who have done things the right way and have tried to come here legally.

The bill is expected to pass the Senate, but its fate in the Republican-controlled House is uncertain. Senator Ted Cruz, a key opponent, said the bill will "crash and burn" in the House in its current form due to the pathway to citizenship. However, Senator Marco Rubio, a member of the bipartisan "Gang of Eight" and a possible GOP presidential contender in 2016, argued that doing nothing amounts to a "de facto amnesty" for immigrants currently living illegally in America.

The bill's supporters, including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, union leaders, and other interest groups, are pushing for its passage, while opponents, including some congressional conservatives, argue that it would grant permanent legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants without ensuring border security. The bill's fate will be decided in the coming weeks as lawmakers consider various amendments and debate the legislation.

Title: Trump Picks Ryan Zinke as Interior Secretary

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has chosen Representative Ryan Zinke, a former Navy SEAL commander, as his interior secretary. Zinke, a 55-year-old Republican from Montana, will head the Interior Department, which employs over 70,000 people across the United States and oversees more than 20% of federal land, including national parks like Yellowstone and Yosemite.

Zinke's choice was a surprise, as some Republican officials had wanted him to challenge Democratic Senator Jon Tester of Montana in the 2018 elections. He emerged as a top contender after Trump considered nominating Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington state for the position. Zinke is a proponent of keeping public lands under federal ownership, which puts him at odds with some in his Republican Party who are more favorable to privatization or placing them under state control.

It remains unclear where Zinke would stand on opening up more federal lands to increased drilling and mining, something Trump promised he would do as president. Trump's official energy platform calls for opening "onshore and offshore leasing on federal lands, eliminate moratorium on coal leasing, and open shale energy deposits."

Zinke had been an early Trump supporter, backing the New York businessman for president in May. His nomination must now be confirmed by the Republican-controlled Senate. Zinke, a member of the House of Representatives subcommittee on natural resources, has voted for legislation that would weaken environmental safeguards on public land. However, unlike other candidates who were on the short list for the interior secretary job, Zinke opposes the transfer of public lands to the states, a position that echoes Trump's.

The Interior Department also oversees the Bureau of Indian Affairs and handles tribal policy. Under Obama, the department played a big role in efforts to curb the effects of climate change by limiting fossil fuel development in some areas.

Title: Harvey Weinstein Indicted on Rape and Sex Act Charges, Faces Possible Trial

Harvey Weinstein, the former Hollywood producer, has been indicted on charges of first- and third-degree rape and a first-degree sex act. The Manhattan grand jury handed down the indictment on May 30, following an investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct. Weinstein is accused of raping one woman and forcing another to perform oral sex on him.

Weinstein surrendered to authorities in New York and was arraigned shortly after. He was released on $10 million or $1 million cash bond, with conditions including the surrender of his passport and the use of a GPS monitoring system. He is only permitted to travel between New York and Connecticut.

Weinstein's lawyer, Ben Brafman, reiterated his client's contention that he did not engage in non-consensual sexual activities and that he will enter a plea of not guilty. The arrest came two days after reports that federal prosecutors had begun a sex crimes investigation into Weinstein and that a state grand jury had convened to hear evidence in sexual assault allegations against the former Hollywood mogul.

The NYPD does not release the names of sex crime victims, but Lucia Evans, a marketing consultant, has confirmed that she is pressing charges against Weinstein. Evans alleges that in 2004, when she was an aspiring actress, Weinstein forced her to perform oral sex on him at the Miramax office in Tribeca.

Actress Paz de la Huerta has also accused Weinstein of raping her in 2010 at a Manhattan hotel, although her allegations are not part of the charges expected to be filed against him. She has said she will testify if asked.

The Manhattan District Attorney, Cyrus Vance, will now decide whether to prosecute Weinstein, who has been accused of sexual harassment and assault by over 80 women. Vance has faced criticism for declining to prosecute Weinstein in a 2015 sexual assault case, and has received a campaign donation from Weinstein's lawyer. Vance has denied any connection between the donation and the decision not to prosecute.

Weinstein's connection to Vance could play a role in the future of this case, as he has hired another lawyer who was a donor to Vance's campaign and represented two high-profile rape defendants whom Vance declined to prosecute. Whether Weinstein will get a fair trial or a trial at all remains to be seen.

The case against Weinstein is a significant moment in the #MeToo movement, as the first high-profile figure accused of sexual misconduct faces the possibility of criminal charges. The outcome of the case will be closely watched, as will the role of the Manhattan DA's office in the investigation and prosecution.

Title: Federal Reserve Chairman Warns of Economic Downturn if Congress Fails to Reach Budget Agreement

The Federal Reserve Chairman, Ben Bernanke, painted a bleak picture of the US economy on Tuesday, warning that a recession would occur if Congress fails to reach an agreement to avert a budget crisis. Bernanke emphasized that the Fed is prepared to take further action to help the economy if unemployment stays high, but did not signal any immediate steps.

Bernanke's warning comes as the economy is growing modestly, but has weakened, with manufacturing slowing and consumers spending less. Job growth has slumped to an average of 75,000 per month in the April-June quarter, and the unemployment rate remains stuck at 8.2%. The Fed chairman noted that the economy is likely to weaken further in the coming months.

Bernanke urged Congress to resolve its impasse before the year ends, stating that doing so would help reduce uncertainty and boost household and business confidence. He also warned that the cuts that would kick in next year could cost as many as 1.25 million jobs, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

The Fed chairman also highlighted the need for a long-term plan to shrink federal budget deficits, warning that failure to do so could lead to a financial crisis marked by rising interest rates. He noted that the economy's challenges go beyond the budget impasse, and that lawmakers must produce a plan to address the country's long-term fiscal issues.

Despite Bernanke's grim assessment, stocks rose sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing more than 90 points. The Fed chairman's testimony also touched on the European debt crisis, which he said poses a serious threat to the US economy. He noted that the Fed has been working with US banks to ensure they are prepared for a crisis.

While some senators urged Bernanke to take action now, others questioned the effectiveness of further monetary policy measures, noting that mortgage rates and other key borrowing rates are already at record lows. The Fed's next policy meeting is scheduled for July 31-August 1, and some economists predict that policymakers may unveil another round of bond purchases if growth and job creation continue to weaken.

Title: New Allegations Against Brett Kavanaugh Spark Controversy and Questions

The recent publication of a New York Times essay by authors Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly has sparked controversy and raised questions about the accuracy and credibility of the allegations against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh. The essay details a new sexual assault allegation against Kavanaugh, which claims that a classmate, Max Stier, witnessed the justice engaging in inappropriate behavior during a drunken dorm party in his freshman year.

The allegation states that Stier saw Kavanaugh's friends pushing his penis into the hand of a female student. However, the article does not provide any additional details about the incident, such as who the friends were, who the female student was, or whether there were any witnesses besides Stier. The article also does not mention whether the alleged victim has any recollection of the incident.

The authors of the essay, Pogrebin and Kelly, have written a book that will be released on Tuesday, which provides more information about the allegations. However, the book has been criticized for omitting the fact that the alleged victim has no memory of the alleged incident. The authors have also been accused of downplaying the doubts expressed by Deborah Ramirez, a Yale classmate of Kavanaugh's who made a similar allegation in 2018.

Ramirez's allegation claims that Kavanaugh exposed himself to her during a party, but she has expressed doubts about whether he was the one who did it. The article does not provide any additional details about the incident, such as who was present or whether there were any witnesses.

The controversy surrounding the allegations has sparked a debate about the accuracy and credibility of the claims against Kavanaugh. The New York Times has updated its article to include the information that the alleged victim did not recall the alleged assault.

Title: Government Shutdown Disrupts Budget Information, Making It Difficult to Assess Economic Impact

The ongoing government shutdown has resulted in the cancellation of several key reports on deficits, spending, and the economy, making it challenging for Congress to make informed decisions on these issues. The shutdown has also delayed the release of the September jobs report and the monthly budget reviews, leaving policymakers without crucial data to guide their decisions.

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) and the Treasury Department have suspended their monthly budget reviews, which means the government does not have a final deficit figure for fiscal year 2013, which ended last week. The CBO has also delayed the release of a report on tax and spending options for reducing the deficit, which was supposed to be published this month.

The shutdown has left analysts scrambling to fill the gap with their own calculations and data. The Alliance for American Manufacturing has asked for anecdotal stories from workers about their job searches, while the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank, has issued a report estimating that the government's continued spending without regard to the deficit could have added 260,000 jobs.

Some analysts believe that the shutdown could end up saving money because programs are being halted and there are fewer employees to pay. However, others argue that it takes money to shut down and start up operations. Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former CBO director and now president of the conservative American Action Forum, said that while it is costing money to mothball and open things, the cost of a shutdown is "not a lot of money."

The longer the shutdown continues, the more reports are likely to be delayed. The problem for federal agencies is that the number crunchers have been furloughed as part of the 800,000 federal employees whose jobs were not deemed essential to protecting life or property. At the CBO, only about 10% of agency employees are on the job, dealing with bills that are actively under consideration in Congress.

Senator John Cornyn, a Texas Republican, said the lack of information works to the White House's advantage because it hides bad numbers about the state of the budget. "Discovered another reason why WH likes the'shutdown' other than it thinks it is 'winning. The Congressional Budget Office won't publish reports due to lapse of funds. Guess the WH thinks no news on fiscal matters is good news," Cornyn said in a Twitter message.

The shutdown has also raised concerns about the potential impact on the economy. Douglas Holtz-Eakin said that while the shutdown is not catastrophic, it does hurt and makes it difficult for policymakers to have a clear understanding of the economy in real-time. He also noted that the calculations of damage to the economy are probably overblown.

The Treasury Department is still producing the Daily Treasury Statement, which shows the status of the federal debt. The department has also released a report arguing that bumping up against the debt limit could cause the worst recession since the Great Depression.

Title: Trump Nominates Heather Nauert as Next U.N. Ambassador

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to nominate Heather Nauert, the current State Department spokeswoman and former Fox News anchor, as the next United States Ambassador to the United Nations. If confirmed by the Senate, Nauert will replace Nikki Haley, who is set to leave the post at the end of the year.

Nauert, 48, has been a prominent figure in the Trump administration, serving as the State Department's chief spokesperson since April 2017. Prior to her role at the State Department, she worked as a journalist at ABC and Fox News. During her time at the State Department, Nauert has been known for her camera-ready presence and her ability to defend the administration's policies at the podium.

Nauert's nomination has not been without controversy, however. She has faced criticism for a perceived lack of government and foreign policy experience, as well as some high-profile missteps, including a tourist-like Instagram post from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and a comment comparing the D-Day invasion to America's strong relationship with Germany.

Despite these criticisms, Trump has praised Nauert, stating that she is "excellent" and a "supporter" of his administration. Nauert's nomination is subject to Senate confirmation, and if approved, she will take over as U.N. Ambassador at the end of the year.

Title: Strategies to Address the Issue of Illegal Immigration

The article discusses the issue of illegal immigration and proposes several strategies to address it. The author argues that the current situation, where thousands of people from Central and South America march towards the US-Mexico border, must be stopped and prevented from happening again in the future. The author suggests that building a wall and streamlining the deportation process are obvious solutions, but also proposes less obvious ways to address the issue.

One strategy is to tax remittances sent by Mexican nationals working in the US to their families back home, which could help Mexico take a more active role in addressing the issue. The author also suggests imposing serious fines on employers who hire illegal aliens and implementing work requirements for welfare recipients.

The article also touches on the need for the US to take a more active role in Latin America, including cutting off foreign aid to corrupt governments and supporting leaders who are willing to fight corruption. The author highlights Brazil as an example of a country that is at a crossroads, with the upcoming election serving as an opportunity to either continue down a path of corruption or elect a reformer who will stand up to corruption.

The author concludes that the US should embrace leaders like Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro, who is promising to fight corruption and end violence in his country. By making it unappealing for people to come to the US and providing incentives for them to stay in their home countries, the author believes that the "invading horde" can be stopped and prevented from happening again in the future.

Title: Senate to Vote on Procedural Motion to Limit Debate on 1,200-Page Immigration Bill

Article:

The United States Senate is set to vote on a procedural motion at 5:30 pm, which will effectively shut down debate on a 1,200-page substitute bill. The bill, a product of the "Gang of Eight," has been merged with the Corker-Hoeven amendment, and Senator Jeff Sessions stated that it is now a single, 1,200-page proposal. The procedural motion, led by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, aims to accelerate the vote on final passage before members have had a chance to thoroughly review the legislation.

Senator Marco Rubio has expressed concerns about the process, stating that he will not support a vote that is rushed and not transparent. He has challenged the sponsors of the bill to commit to extensive, open debate and has questioned whose interests are being served by pushing the bill through without proper consideration.

The bill has been criticized for lacking provisions on border security, with Senator Sessions stating that it is "toothless" on the issue. Senator Rubio has also emphasized the importance of securing the border, saying that any discussion about immigration must center on this issue.

The vote is expected to be contentious, with some critics likening the process to the passage of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The bill's proponents, however, argue that it is a necessary step towards comprehensive immigration reform.

Title: President Trump Backs Sen. Grassley's Immigration Legislation, Urges Senate Support

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his support for Senator Chuck Grassley's immigration legislation, urging the Senate to back the bill and reject any proposals that fail to meet the White House's four pillars for immigration reform. In a statement, Trump praised Grassley's bill, which aligns with the White House's Immigration Reform and Border Security Framework, and emphasized the importance of securing the border and addressing the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

The Grassley bill, introduced with Senator Tom Cotton, aims to provide a path to citizenship for 1.8 million DACA recipients, allocate $25 billion for border security and wall funding, limit family-based migration, and eliminate the diversity visa lottery. While it is unclear if Trump has suggested any changes to the original bill, the legislation has not received support from any Democrats, requiring nine Democratic votes to pass.

The bill's backers argue that it is the only viable option on the table, offering a workable compromise that protects nearly two million immigrants while providing security funding for immigration hawks. Trump also expressed optimism about developments in the House, citing House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte and House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul's legislation, which he believes also enshrines the four pillars.

Goodlatte's bill, unveiled last month, takes a tougher stance on illegal immigration enforcement and addresses the future of DACA recipients, allowing beneficiaries to be eligible for 3-year renewable permits to stay in the U.S. While the bill does not include all 70 security points from the Trump administration's immigration wish list, it does contain key elements, such as funding the border wall and ending chain migration and the visa lottery program. The bill also outlines a long-term plan for DACA recipients, providing a potential path to citizenship without favoring them over other immigrants seeking citizenship.

Trump hailed Goodlatte's bill as a "good starting point" for his administration to achieve its immigration goals, emphasizing the need for responsible and commonsense immigration reform that delivers for the American people.

Title: Royal Couple's Decision to Step Down Raises Questions About Legacy of British Empire's Troubled Past

The decision by Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, to step down from their roles as senior royals has sparked a mix of reactions, with some seeing it as a bold move to break away from the traditional royal mold, while others view it as a retreat from the pressures of royal life. However, for many black British people, the couple's decision is also a reflection of the troubled legacy of the British Empire's history of colonialism, racism, and discrimination.

The British Empire's history of exploiting and oppressing people from the Caribbean and Africa is well-documented, with the slave trade and racist ideologies being a significant part of its past. The legacy of this history is still felt today, with many black British people continuing to face discrimination in areas such as education and housing. The wrongful deportation of black British people in recent years has also been a source of concern.

Meghan's decision to join the British royal family, which is seen as the symbolic heart of the establishment responsible for this troubled history, was met with skepticism by many black British people. The couple's decision to step down from their roles as senior royals is seen as a response to the challenges they have faced, including the constant media scrutiny and the pressure to conform to traditional royal norms.

The couple's decision to bypass official royal channels and communicate directly with the press has been seen as a sign that they are willing to challenge the traditional royal protocol. The decision to announce their decision to step down from their roles as senior royals was also seen as a surprise to Buckingham Palace, suggesting that the couple is willing to take a non-traditional approach.

While the reasons behind the couple's decision are still unclear, it is clear that they are seeking a more private and peaceful life. The decision is also seen as a reflection of the challenges faced by the couple, including the constant media scrutiny and the pressure to conform to traditional royal norms.

**UN Imposes Sanctions on North Korea, Pyongyang Vows "Thousands-Fold" Revenge**

The United Nations Security Council has imposed new sanctions on North Korea in response to its recent tests of intercontinental ballistic missiles. The measures, which were approved unanimously, aim to slash the country's annual export revenue by a third. The sanctions target key revenue earners such as coal, iron, lead, and seafood, but not oil.

In a statement carried by the official KCNA news agency, the North Korean government described the sanctions as a "violent violation of our sovereignty" and part of a "heinous plot to isolate and stifle" the country. Pyongyang vowed to take "righteous action" and threatened the US would pay "thousands of times" for the sanctions.

The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, said that North Korea should halt its missile launches if it wants to negotiate. The UN measures prohibit China, Russia, and other countries from hiring North Korean laborers, whose remittances help fund the regime, and prohibit new investment in existing business partnerships.

The US Ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, described the measures as "the single largest economic sanctions package ever leveled" against North Korea. The sanctions are part of an effort to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

The US and South Korea have agreed to apply maximum pressure on the regime, while China has expressed concerns that the sanctions could have a negative impact on the North Korean people and the economy. The North Korean government has vowed to continue its nuclear and missile development, citing its right to self-defense and the need to counter the perceived threat from the US and its allies.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Legacy: A Consequential Six-Year Tenure

Attorney General Eric Holder's resignation, announced on Thursday, marks the end of a nearly six-year tenure that has been marked by significant legal milestones and controversy. Holder, the first African-American to hold the position, has been a vocal advocate for strong legal positions on various issues, despite facing a frequently hostile Congress.

One of the most notable decisions during his tenure was his announcement in 2011 that the Justice Department would no longer defend the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defined marriage under federal law as between a man and a woman. Holder deemed the law unconstitutional, a move that foreshadowed President Obama's own "evolution" on same-sex marriage the following year and the Supreme Court's 2013 ruling invalidating a key part of the law. Since then, nearly two dozen federal courts have struck down state bans on same-sex marriage, and the Supreme Court has been asked again to rule on whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

Holder also played a key role in fighting discriminatory voting restrictions around the 2012 elections. After the Supreme Court gutted the core of the Voting Rights Act in 2013, Holder was quick to find new ways to challenge discriminatory laws. The Justice Department joined lawsuits challenging new restrictions like strict voter-ID requirements and cutbacks to voting hours in North Carolina and Texas. In both states, Republican-controlled legislatures imposed rules that most heavily burdened poorer and minority voters, who tend to vote Democratic.

Throughout his tenure, Holder has been a strong advocate for civil rights and social justice, taking bold and laudable legal positions on many of the most contested issues of our time. While his record is not without controversy, his legacy is likely to be remembered as one of the most consequential in United States history.

Title: Trump Emphasizes Anti-Terrorism Efforts in Ohio Rally Speech

Article:

In a measured and scripted speech, Donald Trump addressed a rally in Youngstown, Ohio, focusing on the threat posed by radical Islamic terrorism. The speech was a departure from Trump's previous, more unpredictable approach, and it expanded upon his most controversial foreign policy statements. Despite being restrained, Trump did not back down from his stance on the subject.

Trump emphasized the need for the US to work with Russia in "coalition operations" to fight ISIS, stating that Russia has had its own battles with Islamic terror. This proposal would be a significant change from current Obama administration policy, which has not included cooperation with Russia in the fight against ISIS.

The speech also touched on the topic of "extreme vetting," a method that could help Trump get around his previous suggestion of a temporary ban on the entry of non-citizen Muslims into the US. The new vetting procedure would involve asking immigrants or refugees from areas affected by terrorism to answer questions about their beliefs in a "tolerant" way of life and their agreement with US values.

Critics on social media quickly noted that such a test might be easy to game, and that it would require significant resources to implement. The whole approach seemed more like a rebranding of the previous Muslim ban proposal, rather than a new policy.

Trump also used the speech to back away from his previous statement that the US should pull out of NATO unless other members paid more for the common defense. He noted that NATO has a new anti-terrorism initiative, which he attributed to his own criticism of the organization. NATO officials have denied this claim.

Trump's allies praised the speech, saying it showed that he has the ability to be presidential and handle the responsibilities of commander-in-chief. However, critics were quick to point out that the speech was more of the same from Trump, with no real changes or new ideas.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Ends Democratic Sit-In on Gun Control Measures

The House of Representatives adjourned early Thursday morning after a 25-hour sit-in by congressional Democrats failed to force a vote on gun control measures. The protest, which began on Wednesday afternoon, saw 168 House Democrats and 34 Senate Democrats join the effort to dramatize the need for action to stem gun violence.

Despite the failure to secure a vote, Democrats declared the protest a success in drawing attention to the issue and changing the dynamic on gun control. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said the party would not stop until the job is done, and House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer criticized the Republican majority for shutting down the House and ignoring the unfinished business of the American people.

The protest, which included loud chants and live-streaming, was met with criticism from Republicans, who called it a publicity stunt. House Speaker Paul Ryan described the bill pushed by Democrats as taking away people's constitutional rights and depriving them of due process.

The sit-in was sparked by the recent shooting rampage at a Florida gay nightclub that killed 49 people and injured 53 others. The event was part of a growing movement to address gun violence, which has seen a series of tragic incidents in recent years, including the school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut.

The protest was marked by a burst of activity in the middle of the night, including recorded votes on other issues such as the Zika virus. The spectacle captured the attention of a Washington gridlocked on guns, despite the slaughter in Orlando. Senate Democrats had undertaken a nearly 15-hour filibuster last week in fighting for the same cause.

The protest began with little advance warning from Democrats and unfolded on the House floor with lawmakers speaking of the need for gun control and sharing personal stories of constituents who had been killed. Visitors watched from the galleries, and a crowd of several hundred gun control advocates gathered outside the Capitol to show their support.

The sit-in, led by Georgia Rep. John Lewis, who had participated in the civil rights sit-ins in the South in the 1960s, had the look of a 1960s-style protest, with lawmakers sitting on the floor, others in their seats, and some taking breaks on pillows and blankets.

Title: Trump Delivers Optimistic Address to Congress, But Democrats Warn of Unacceptable Agenda

Article:

In his debut speech to Congress, President Donald Trump awarded himself high marks as president, except on communication. Trump told Fox News that he would give himself a "C or C+" in terms of messaging. The speech was seen as a polished and optimistic address by many, with Trump supporters hoping he has finally found his footing as president.

The speech touched on many of the typical themes of a State of the Union address, including healing and hope, and called for bipartisanship in the name of common national purpose. Trump began by condemning recent vandalism and threats against Jewish targets and the shooting of two Indian men in Kansas, following criticism that he was slow to speak out against such attacks.

The speech also contained policies that serve his "America first" campaign theme, including a major increase in defense spending, a pull-back from multilateral trade agreements, the border wall, and tax cuts for corporations and the middle class. Trump expressed support for NATO, but also signaled a retrenchment of America's role on the global stage.

Despite the optimistic tone, Democrats warned that Trump's agenda is unacceptable, citing the threat of mass deportations, the gutting of environmental protections, and the loss of health coverage for millions of newly insured low-income Americans. Some Democrats were unimpressed by Trump's message, with Senator Jeff Merkley (D-Oregon) dismissing his talk of clean air and water as "empty" words.

The speech won early high marks from the American public, with 7 in 10 Americans who tuned in saying it made them feel more optimistic about the country, according to a CNN poll. However, it remains to be seen whether Trump can maintain this more presidential posture and deliver on his promises.

Title: US Job Growth Slows Sharply in May, Unemployment Rate Edges Up

The US unemployment rate rose to 8.2% in May, as businesses across various sectors, including factories and office parks, pulled back on hiring. The Labor Department reported that job growth fell sharply to 69,000, the weakest growth in a year, and revisions showed that only 77,000 jobs were created in April, far below the 115,000 previously reported.

The slowdown was seen in many industries, including construction, which had seen unusual job gains in the winter due to mild weather. The vital business services sector, which is the heart of the US economy, lost 1,000 jobs in May. However, some industries, such as healthcare, transportation, and wholesaling, saw healthy job gains.

Economists are divided on the reasons behind the slowdown. Some attribute it to payback after stronger-than-usual hiring earlier in the year due to warmer-than-normal weather in the winter months. Others believe it reflects a fundamental slowdown in the economy that will lead to further rises in the unemployment rate.

The report has sparked a heated debate about the health of the US economy, with Republicans pointing to it as evidence that President Obama's economic program is not working. The White House, however, attributes the slowdown to "headwinds" hitting the economy from the European economic crisis and the spike in gasoline prices this spring.

The report also showed that the average workweek declined 0.1 hour to 34.4 hours in May, and average hourly wages slumped to a 1.7% yearly rate, close to a record low. The rise in unemployment reflected not only the slowdown in job growth but also a surge in people looking for work but unable to find jobs.

Title: Trump Denies Russian Connection, Accuses Intelligence Community of Leaking Classified Information

President Donald Trump has denied reports that his associates had contact with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign, calling the allegations "non-sense." In a series of tweets, Trump accused the U.S. intelligence community of illegally leaking information to news outlets and claimed that the real scandal is the intelligence community's alleged practice of giving out classified information "like candy."

Trump's tweets come as multiple news outlets, including CNN and The New York Times, reported that Russian officials were in touch with members of his team during the campaign. According to CNN, advisers close to Trump were in "constant communication" with Russians known to U.S. intelligence during the campaign. Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort denied any knowledge of contacts with Russian officials or intelligence officials regarding the ongoing investigation.

Trump's denial of any contacts between his campaign and Russian officials is consistent with his previous statements on the matter. The reports come on the heels of the resignation of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who was accused of misleading Vice President Mike Pence and others about the nature of his conversations with Russia's ambassador to the U.S. after the November election.

In his tweets, Trump also criticized the media, calling them "fake news" and accusing them of spreading conspiracy theories and blind hatred. He specifically mentioned CNN and MSNBC as being "unwatchable," while praising Fox News' morning show.

Title: California Primary Election Looms as Democratic Candidates Vie for Delegates

The California primary election is just around the corner, with the Democratic candidates still vying for the 475 delegates up for grabs. Hillary Clinton claims she is on the verge of beating Bernie Sanders in the Golden State and beyond, but the Vermont senator believes he is gaining ground and has a strong chance of securing the primaries.

In the past few days, Clinton has traveled the state in an effort to win over the delegates she needs to exceed the 2,383 threshold and secure the nomination. "I'm very proud of the campaign we're running here, and I believe, on Tuesday, I will have decisively won the popular vote and I will have decisively won the pledged delegate majority," she said on CNN's "State of the Union."

However, Sanders' campaign disputes the delegate math and argues that money doesn't tell the whole story. He is not ready to concede, especially with the strong coalition of supporters he has in California. "It is extremely unlikely that Secretary Clinton will have the requisite number of pledged delegates to claim victory on Tuesday night," Sanders told reporters in Los Angeles on Saturday, according to CNN. "At the end of the nominating process, no candidate will have enough pledged delegates to call the campaign a victory. That will be dependent upon superdelegates. In other words, the Democratic National Convention will be a contested convention."

Some Clinton supporters fear the continued intra-party fight will risk Democrats' unity ahead of the general election, leaving them vulnerable against presumed Republican nominee Donald Trump. Even if Clinton wins the nomination, part of her energy will need to go towards wooing "Bernie or Bust" supporters, instead of focusing on existing Trump voters alone.

Twenty-five percent of Sanders supporters said they would not vote for Clinton in the general election if she were the nominee against Trump, according to a Quinnipiac University poll. The "Bernie or Bust" movement may be even stronger in California, where the USC Dornsife/LA Times poll indicated that Clinton lagged behind Sanders 43 percent to 44 percent among registered voters. Only 65 percent of those who are voting Sanders in the California primary said they would definitely support Clinton in the case of a Clinton-Trump face-off.

After Puerto Rico's primary on Sunday, Clinton holds 1,809 delegates and 548 superdelegates, for a total of 2,357. Winning the nomination requires at least 2,382 delegates. During the Democratic primaries on Tuesday, 694 delegates, including 475 delegates in California, will be at stake.

Title: Obama Faces Pressure to Clarify US Response to Egypt Crisis

The United States is grappling with a complex and fluid situation in Egypt, where the military has ousted President Mohamed Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood government. President Barack Obama has so far declined to describe the event as a coup d'état, instead expressing concern about a military takeover and staying vague about the US response. As the crisis unfolds, a debate is emerging among politicians and experts, scrambling familiar partisan and ideological lines.

A coalition that formed over Iraq has begun to fray, with Israel supporters welcoming the ousting of Morsi and democracy advocates noting that his government, despite its flaws, was legitimately elected and has now been illegitimately overthrown. The Washington Post editorial page has criticized Obama's response as "feckless," while The New York Times has praised his "appropriate caution."

Under US law, the $1.3 billion in American military aid to Egypt must be suspended if Morsi's ouster and the arrest of his allies are formally declared a coup. As the situation continues to evolve, Obama will be forced to make a clear choice.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Express Frustration with Debate Format

Article:

In the aftermath of the second round of Democratic presidential debates, candidates Joe Biden and Kamala Harris expressed frustration with the format, stating that it left them little time to explain their views and led to combative exchanges. The debate, which featured 10 candidates, had a time constraint of 60 seconds to answer a question and 30 seconds to rebut an attack.

Harris, a U.S. senator from California, said the format was conducive to "sound bites" and did not allow for a real exploration of policy. Biden, the former U.S. vice president and the Democratic front-runner, agreed, stating that it was difficult to explain complicated topics in less than one minute.

The crowded field of over two dozen candidates vying for the Democratic nomination has forced the party to set up back-to-back nights of debates, leading to rapid-fire exchanges that frustrated not only candidates but some viewers. The Democratic National Committee has doubled the fundraising and polling requirements to qualify for participation in an effort to reduce the crowd on stage.

Biden and Harris said they were not surprised they were the target of attacks from all directions during the debate, as they are considered front-runners. However, Biden expressed disappointment that the immigration and healthcare policies of former President Barack Obama, still the most popular figure in the Democratic Party, came under sharp criticism during the debate.

The debate format has been criticized by some, including former presidential candidate Mike Huckabee, who called it "game show rules." The party's next debate is not until September, and the Democratic National Committee has doubled the fundraising and polling requirements to qualify for participation in an effort to reduce the crowd on stage.

In the aftermath of the debate, Cory Booker, a U.S. senator from New Jersey, told a rally in Detroit that the strife would eventually be forgotten, and the candidates would close ranks behind the eventual nominee.

Title: Alabama Senate Nominee Roy Moore Denies Allegations of Romantic Relationships with Teenage Females

Alabama Republican Senate nominee Roy Moore has denied allegations that he pursued romantic relationships with teenage women dating back to the 1970s, when he was in his early thirties and single. The allegations were reported by The Washington Post, which Moore has accused of having a "political agenda" and making "false and untrue" claims.

According to the report, Moore, a former chief justice of Alabama's Supreme Court and a social conservative, pursued relationships with four teenage women, with one woman claiming she was 14 when the 32-year-old Moore asked her out and made sexual advances. Moore has denied the allegations, stating that he has not been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone.

Moore has also accused The Washington Post of launching a "desperate attempt to stop my political campaign for United States Senate" and having a "left-leaning" bias, as the paper has endorsed his Democratic opponent, Doug Jones. The allegations have caused significant damage to Moore's campaign ahead of the special election for the seat once held by Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Top Republicans, including President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have called on Moore to drop out of the race if the allegations are true. However, Moore has shown no signs of doing so and has instead continued to campaign for the Senate seat.

Title: Senators Cruz and Rubio Unite Against Washington Post Cartoon

Article: Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, both Republican presidential candidates, have found common ground in their criticism of a recent cartoon published by The Washington Post. The cartoon, created by editorial cartoonist Ann Telnaes, depicted Cruz dressed as Santa Claus with his two daughters, Caroline and Catherine, attached to strings and wearing red outfits, likening them to "trained monkeys." Cruz responded swiftly on Twitter, calling the cartoon "classy" and stating that the children are "out of your league." Rubio also expressed disgust and support for Cruz, saying the cartoon is "disgusting" and that the Post's claim that children are "fair game" is "even worse."

The Cruz campaign quickly turned the cartoon into a fundraising appeal, characterizing it as an attack on Cruz and his family from the "liberal media." The email, which included a screenshot of the cartoon, read, "I'm sickened...I knew I'd be facing attacks from day one of my campaign but I never expected anything like this."

The Washington Post has since removed the cartoon, acknowledging that it was a mistake to publish it. Editor Fred Hiatt issued an editor's note, stating that it is the paper's policy to leave children out of its editorial section, and that he failed to review the cartoon before its publication.

Title: Experts Weigh In on the Pros and Cons of a Coronavirus Vaccine

The development of a coronavirus vaccine is a crucial step towards ending the pandemic, with over 100 potential vaccines in various stages of development. The Trump administration's "Operation Warp Speed" aims to have millions of doses available by the end of the year, with Dr. Anthony Fauci expressing cautious optimism about a vaccine being ready by early 2021. Experts agree that a vaccine is the quickest and safest way to establish herd immunity, which is necessary to stop the virus from spreading.

However, some experts are skeptical about the idea of a game-changing vaccine being just a few months away. Developing a vaccine by the end of the year or even by next summer would shatter the record for the fastest vaccine ever developed, which currently stands at four years. Even if that extraordinary feat is accomplished, drug companies will still need to produce hundreds of millions of doses and distribute them to those who need them.

Some experts warn that investing too much in a best-case scenario may lead to complacency and a lack of preparation for the long-term fight against the virus. Others argue that rushing development may backfire by increasing the risk that an unsafe vaccine might be the first to market, which could undermine herd immunity.

A vaccine won't be a magic solution, but it's still the best path out of the pandemic. Experts emphasize the importance of developing effective systems of testing, tracing, and therapeutic medicines that can last as long as they're needed. The possibility of a vaccine not being entirely effective or providing immunity only for a short period of time is also a concern.

The article concludes that a vaccine won't be a silver bullet, but it's still the best way to begin the end of the pandemic. Experts stress the need for continued vigilance and preparation, as well as the importance of addressing the challenges that lie ahead.

Title: Unlikely Friendship and Self-Discovery: A Journey of Empowerment

The article features an account of an unlikely friendship between Lindsey and Annie, who met while interning in Washington D.C. during their college summer. Lindsey, who was initially a Republican, had a different understanding of feminism, which Annie helped her to understand and challenge. Annie, who had her own experiences with the Democratic Party, shared her own journey of self-discovery and empowerment through her friendship with Lindsey.

Lindsey's initial understanding of feminism was that it was about giving women opportunities they didn't deserve just because they were women. She believed that the playing field was already level and that she didn't need feminism. However, Annie's guidance and support helped Lindsey to understand the importance of feminism and how it can help women achieve their goals. Annie taught Lindsey that certain behaviors, such as getting her ass slapped in an office, were not acceptable and that she deserved to be treated with respect.

Annie, on the other hand, had her own journey of self-discovery, which was influenced by Lindsey's confidence and comfort in her own body. Lindsey's confidence and self-acceptance inspired Annie to be more comfortable with her own body and sexuality. Annie learned that it's okay to show off or cover up her body as she sees fit, and that she is powerful and amazing just the way she is.

The article highlights the importance of friendship and the impact it can have on personal growth and self-discovery. Lindsey and Annie's unlikely friendship shows that people from different backgrounds and with different beliefs can come together and learn from each other. Their stories serve as a reminder that everyone has their own journey of self-discovery and that it's okay to take the time to figure out what works best for them.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Discusses Partisanship and Leadership at Stanford University

Article:

U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg recently spoke at Stanford University, sharing her thoughts on partisanship in Congress and her personal approach to leadership. During her talk, she expressed her hope that Congress would return to a time when it worked for the good of the country, rather than solely along party lines. Ginsburg did not address specific issues like the nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court or President Donald Trump's travel ban, which may eventually come before the high court.

Ginsburg did share her thoughts on the Electoral College, stating that she would like to see it changed. This comment drew applause from the packed audience. She did not elaborate on her stance.

During the presidential campaign, Ginsburg had expressed her expectation that Democrat Hillary Clinton would win and have the opportunity to make a few appointments to the court. She had also stated that she did not want to consider the possibility of a Trump victory, calling him a "faker" who "really has an ego." However, she did acknowledge the bipartisan support she received during her own nomination to the Supreme Court, citing Republican Senator Orrin Hatch as her most ardent supporter.

Ginsburg, 83, spoke about her personal reflections on leading a meaningful life during the discussion. She also joked about the importance of eating kale, suggesting that Justice Anthony Kennedy, the second oldest justice on the Supreme Court, could benefit from doing so. Ginsburg has shown no signs of slowing down, crediting her personal trainer and family for her continued energy and determination. She emphasized her attitude of perseverance, stating, "I'm going to surmount this whatever it is."

Title: Supreme Court Rules in Indecency Case, FCC Free to Modify Policy

The Supreme Court has ruled in the FCC vs. Fox Television Stations case, avoiding the central question of whether the Federal Communications Commission's indecency rules violate the First Amendment. Instead, the court ruled 8-0 that the FCC failed to give networks fair notice that they had broken the rules, allowing them to avoid paying steep fines.

The ruling leaves the FCC free to modify its current indecency policy, taking into account the public interest and applicable legal requirements. FCC Chairman Julius Genachowski stated that the commission is reviewing the decision, which appears to be narrowly limited to procedural issues related to actions taken several years ago. However, he assured lawmakers that the FCC will continue to protect young TV viewers, consistent with First Amendment principles.

Lawmakers from both parties welcomed the continuation of broadcast regulations, with Sen. Jay Rockefeller (D-W.Va.) stating that the decision leaves in place the FCC's authority to protect children from indecent programming. The ruling means Fox and ABC will no longer face FCC fines and sanctions in their cases, and it signals that the FCC should revisit its policy.

The case was sparked by the FCC's decision to change its indecency rules following rock star Bono's impromptu utterance during his acceptance speech at the 2003 Golden Globe Awards on NBC. The commission decided not to fine NBC at the time, but later changed its rules to allow for fines for fleeting expletives. The Supreme Court's ruling leaves the issue of whether the FCC's indecency policy is constitutional for another day.

Title: Global Markets Reach New Highs as Trade Tensions Ease and Yields Remain High

Global stock markets reached new highs on Thursday, with the S&P 500 Index and the Dow Jones Industrial Average both setting records, as investors responded positively to news from China about tariff and currency moves that could ease trade tensions. The S&P 500 Index gained 0.8% to its highest level ever, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1% to a record high. The MSCI Emerging Market Index also jumped 0.9% to its highest level in over two weeks.

The dollar weakened against major currencies, with the U.S. Dollar Spot Index decreasing 0.4% to its lowest level in eight weeks. The Japanese yen fell 0.1% to 112.41 per dollar. The yield on 10-year Treasuries remained near its highest level this year, at 3.07%, while the yield on German and British 10-year bonds fell slightly.

The rally in global markets was led by the technology, health-care, and financial sectors, with 28 of the 30 constituents of the Dow Jones Industrial Average flashing green. Most European and Asian shares also gained, as investors became more optimistic about the outlook for corporate earnings and global growth.

The news from China, which included plans to cut the average tariff rate it charges on imports from most of its trading partners as soon as next month, helped to ease trade tensions. The country's Premier Li Keqiang also stated that his government would not devalue the currency to boost exports amid the trade war.

The rally in global markets was also supported by the resilience of equity markets in the face of rising bond yields, which had been a concern for investors in recent weeks. The yield on 10-year Treasuries had risen to its highest level in over four months, but investors seemed to be comfortable with the outlook for corporate earnings and global growth.

In other market news, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies will meet in Algiers this weekend to discuss oil production levels. The meeting comes as U.S. President Donald Trump resumed his criticism of OPEC on Twitter, causing West Texas crude to drop 0.4% to $70.80 a barrel.

Title: Israeli Government Blocks U.S. Representatives Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar from Entering the Country

The Israeli government has blocked U.S. Representatives Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar from entering the country, citing concerns over their support for boycotts of Israel. The decision was made by Interior Minister Arye Deri and announced by Deputy Foreign Minister Tzipi Hotovely earlier this week.

The move has sparked a massive outcry from Democratic lawmakers in Washington, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling it a "sign of weakness" and Omar accusing Israel of implementing "Trump's Muslim ban." Omar stated that it is an affront that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, under pressure from President Trump, would deny entry to representatives of the U.S. government.

However, the Israeli government has staunchly defended the decision, suggesting that the lawmakers had ulterior motives with the planned trip. Netanyahu explained that Tlaib and Omar's itinerary "revealed that they planned a visit whose sole objective is to strengthen the boycott against us and deny Israel's legitimacy."

The decision was made despite prior assurances that the congresswomen would be allowed in. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu confirmed that Deri would consider permitting Tlaib to visit her Palestinian family members if she filed a humanitarian request and promised not to promote boycotts of Israel while she visits.

The U.S. ambassador to Israel put out a statement of support for the decision, while Democratic lawmakers and some Israel advocacy groups expressed strong opposition. The Jerusalem Post reported that Netanyahu met with officials to discuss the matter, and Israeli Channel 13's Barak Ravid reported that Netanyahu had been considering allowing Tlaib and Omar to enter Israel, but only to travel within the territories controlled by the Palestinian Authority.

The controversy has sparked a heated debate, with some arguing that the Israeli government is undermining the principles of democracy and others saying that the congresswomen's support for boycotts of Israel is unacceptable.

Title: FDA Launches Criminal Probe into Vaping-Related Illnesses, Death Toll Rises to 530

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has launched a criminal investigation into the recent surge in vaping-related illnesses, which has jumped to 530 cases, with seven confirmed deaths in six states. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that the confirmed cases have increased from 380 last week, with 38 states and one territory affected as of September 17.

The FDA's investigation will focus on the products, where they were purchased, and how they are being used, rather than personal use of vaping-related products. The agency has collected over 150 vaping product samples for forensic analysis and is testing them for various substances, including nicotine, THC, and other cannabinoids, opioids, cutting agents, additives, pesticides, poisons, and toxins.

The cause of the outbreak remains a mystery, with no consistent product, substance, or brand identified in all cases. Most patients reported a history of using e-cigarette products containing THC, a psychoactive chemical found in cannabis. Vitamin E acetate has been detected in some lab samples, but no singular compound has been found in all samples.

Health authorities are urging consumers to avoid buying vapes off the street or modifying vape products. "People are dying," said Dr. Anne Schuchat, principal deputy director at the CDC. "We ask you to take these recommendations seriously."

The majority of those affected are male, with about three-fourths of those diagnosed with an illness being male, which is slightly over-represented in the general vaping population. Young people have been particularly affected, with more than half of those who have gotten sick being younger than 25, and 2 out of 3 cases being people between 18 and 34 years old.

Illinois has seen 69 reported cases and one death, with health officials turning to the public for help in cracking the case. The state is asking residents who have recently vaped to fill out an online, anonymous survey regarding their vaping habits.

As the vaping industry faces scrutiny, politicians, businesses, and individuals are taking action. The formation of a new congressional caucus aimed at curbing the nation's teen-vaping epidemic was announced, with lawmakers vowing to work tirelessly to keep e-cigarettes out of the hands of young people. President Donald Trump has also announced plans to ban the sale of flavored vaping products, and several states have taken similar measures.

Title: European Military Observers Detained in Ukraine, Possible Exchange for Jailed Activists

A team of eight European military observers, part of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), has been detained in eastern Ukraine, with the possibility of being released in exchange for jailed pro-Russian activists. The detained team, led by Germany, was traveling under the auspices of the OSCE when they were taken into custody.

According to Vyacheslav Ponomarev, the self-proclaimed people's mayor of Slovyansk, the detained observers were found with maps containing information about the location of Ukrainian checkpoints, leading to suspicions of espionage. Ukraine's state security service, however, claims that the OSCE representatives are being held in inhuman conditions and that one of them requires immediate medical attention.

The German Defense Ministry has confirmed that it lost contact with the team, which included five Ukrainians. Tim Guldimann, OSCE's special envoy for Ukraine, stated that efforts are being made to resolve the situation, but declined to provide further details.

Meanwhile, Ukraine's acting Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk met with Pope Francis at the Vatican, but was forced to return home due to escalating tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The Pope gifted Yatsenyuk a fountain pen, saying "I hope that you write 'peace' with this pen."

The Group of Seven (G-7) nations, including the United States, have agreed to impose additional economic sanctions on Russia in response to its actions in Ukraine. The G-7 nations plan to act urgently to intensify targeted sanctions and prepare broader sanctions on key Russian economic sectors if Moscow takes further aggressive action. The White House has stated that US sanctions could be levied as early as Monday.

Title: FBI Calls Bullets Fired at ICE Offices in Texas a "Targeted Attack"

The FBI has described the recent shooting at the US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) offices in San Antonio, Texas, as a "targeted attack" against federal employees. The incident occurred on Tuesday at around 03:00 local time, with multiple shots fired at the offices, but no injuries reported.

The FBI is reviewing surveillance footage and investigating the incident, with no arrests made and suspects still at large. ICE officials have blamed the shooting on "political rhetoric" and "misinformation" about the Trump administration's detention policies.

The shooting occurred at two neighboring buildings, with bullet holes visible in several windows. The building targeted is mainly used for executive and administrative purposes, according to ICE.

The FBI's San Antonio operations head, Christopher Combs, described the incident as "cowardly, brazen, violent acts" and stated that the perpetrators "did some research" and "knew what floors ICE was on, and they hit those." Combs emphasized that the attack was "very targeted" and that the bullets could have easily hit federal officials, had they been just a few inches off target.

This incident is the latest in a series of four recent attacks on ICE facilities across the country, with previous incidents occurring in Washington D.C., Tacoma, Washington, and Aurora, Colorado, within days of each other in July. The FBI is concerned that the current political climate may lead to more attacks, with Combs stating, "We can't allow political discourse to lead us to the point of violence, where federal employees, innocent people doing their jobs, are put in harm's way."

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders to Concede Democratic Primary if Joe Biden Gains Plurality of Delegates

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has stated that he will drop out of the Democratic primary if, by the time of the Democratic National Convention, former Vice President Joe Biden has a plurality of delegates. Sanders made this announcement during an interview with MSNBC's Rachel Maddow on Wednesday.

According to Democratic primary rules, candidates need a majority (1,991 delegates) to secure the nomination. Projections suggest that no candidate may reach this threshold, leading to a second ballot where superdelegates can vote. Superdelegates make up about 15% of all delegates and include major elected officials, former presidents or vice presidents, and prominent members of the Democratic National Committee.

Sanders has stated that he will concede the nomination to Biden, even if Biden only has a plurality of delegates, rather than a majority. This decision would mean forfeiting a chance to win the nomination through a contested convention. Sanders expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a contested convention, saying it would be a "real, real disaster" for the Democratic Party.

Some may view Sanders' decision as a demonstration of his commitment to the will of the people and his dislike of superdelegates. However, it is more likely that Sanders is setting a standard for the convention that he hopes Biden will follow if Sanders enters the convention with a plurality.

Currently, Biden holds 596 delegates, while Sanders has 531. Biden has gained momentum in recent days, winning 581 of his 596 delegates in the past seven days with significant victories in South Carolina and on Super Tuesday.

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders Defines Democratic Socialism as Human Rights and Economic Rights

Sen. Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, discussed his ideology of democratic socialism during a CNN town hall speech on Monday night. According to Sanders, democratic socialism is about human rights and economic rights, which include a living wage and free college tuition for every American.

When asked to respond to President Trump's repeated attacks on socialism, Sanders emphasized that the country is heading in the direction of democratic socialism, regardless of the president's opinions. He stated that if elected, he would prioritize making healthcare a right, making public colleges and universities tuition-free, and raising the minimum wage to at least $15 an hour.

Sanders also highlighted the importance of environmental rights, stating that it is a human right for children and grandchildren to grow up in a healthy and habitable planet. He criticized President Trump for rejecting science and denying the reality of climate change.

During the Q&A session, a woman in the audience asked Sanders to explain why democratic socialism is preferable to capitalism. Sanders responded that while constitutional rights like freedom of speech and freedom of religion are crucial, economic rights are lacking. He emphasized that everyone needs a decent-paying job, healthcare, and education, and that democratic socialism aims to ensure that all people live in security and dignity.

In summary, Sen. Bernie Sanders defines democratic socialism as a system that prioritizes human rights and economic rights, including a living wage and free college tuition, and aims to ensure that all people live in security and dignity.

Title: Republican Presidential Candidates Cruz and Kasich Announce Partnership to Block Trump's Path to Nomination

In a surprise move, Republican presidential candidates Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Ohio Governor John Kasich announced their plan to divvy up some remaining primary states and avoid competing with each other in three states. This partnership aims to block Donald Trump's path to the Republican nomination.

Cruz and Kasich have been fighting for the #NeverTrump vote since the field shrunk to three candidates last month. However, until recently, Cruz was fighting for a conventional nomination, while Kasich has long banked on a contested convention. Now, after the probability of a Cruz pre-convention was shrunk to nearly nil by the New York primary, the two candidates share the same #NeverTrump goal: block Trump from reaching 1,237 delegates before the Republican National Convention in July.

The partnership involves Cruz focusing his campaign resources in Indiana, while Kasich will compete in Oregon and New Mexico. This allocation of states cannot be defended by primary dates, as the Northeastern states hold primaries on Tuesday, followed by Indiana's primary on May 3, and Oregon's primary on May 17. New Mexico's primary occurs on June 7.

The choice of these three states may seem perplexing, but it highlights the importance of Indiana. With Trump close to reaching 1,237 delegates, Indiana's 57 delegates could be a game-changer. A Cruz win in Indiana is the best prospect for a contested convention.

Despite a polling blackout in Indiana due to a state law prohibiting automated polling, it appears to be a good state for Cruz. The Upshot's demographic-based model has Cruz leading Trump 43 to 40 percent, with Kasich trailing at 16 percent. Giving Oregon to Kasich also makes sense for the #NeverTrump duo, as early polls predict Kasich winning that primary over Cruz and Trump.

This partnership may sound strange, but when gaming out the rest of the primary contest, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that Trump's quest to reach a majority of delegates before the convention could all turn on Indiana. If Trump wins big in the East and West Virginia, loses the winner-take-all rural Western states, and earns his expected share of proportional delegates in Washington, Oregon, and New Mexico, he would still be 175 delegates short of the nomination.

Title: President Obama Meets with Labor Leaders to Discuss Fiscal Cliff and Tax Increases

President Barack Obama met with labor leaders at the White House on Tuesday to discuss ways to avoid automatic tax increases and spending cuts at the beginning of the new year. The meeting is part of a series aimed at finding a solution to the so-called fiscal cliff.

The president's meeting with labor leaders comes after his re-election, in which he won the support of 62 million Americans. Obama's campaign focused on his plan to raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans, which was a key issue in his debate with Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney. Exit polls showed that 60% of voters believe income taxes should increase, either for the wealthy or for everyone.

Former White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel, now the mayor of Chicago, believes that the election results could set the stage for a compromise between Obama and congressional Republicans. Emanuel noted that President Clinton achieved a balanced budget agreement with a Republican Congress after his re-election in 1996.

Obama has expressed encouragement towards Republican House Speaker John Boehner's willingness to consider increasing tax revenue from the wealthy, but is not waiting passively for congressional Republicans to come around. The president believes that public pressure from outside Washington can be an important tool in moving a reluctant Congress.

In his second term, Obama plans to focus on being in a constant conversation with the American people to put pressure on Congress to move forward on issues like tax policy. He has acknowledged that it is easier said than done, as he discovered in his first term when he gave up on his pledge to hold health care talks on national television.

The president's meetings with labor leaders and CEOs are aimed at garnering support as he heads into negotiations with Congress. Obama believes that the American people are essential to the success of his second term, and that their involvement and engagement are crucial to the functioning of democracy.

Title: Obama Administration Issues Guidance on Access to Facilities for Transgender Students

The Obama administration has issued a decree to all US public schools, requiring them to allow transgender students to access restrooms and facilities that align with their gender identity, even if others object. The guidance, sent by the Justice Department and Department of Education, provides extensive guidelines on how to protect transgender students from discrimination and ensure they have access to appropriate facilities.

The letter, obtained by a news organization, does not add new legal requirements but provides guidance on how to ensure transgender students are treated fairly and have access to facilities consistent with their gender identity. The letter states that schools may provide separate facilities based on sex, but must allow transgender students access to such facilities consistent with their gender identity.

The guidance also emphasizes that transgender students must have access to facilities even in circumstances where others raise objections or concerns. The letter notes that accommodating others' discomfort cannot justify a policy that singles out and disadvantages a particular class of students.

A supporting document provides examples of policies and practices for supporting transgender students, as well as guidelines on privacy, confidentiality, anti-bullying, and other issues affecting LGBT students. The guidance aims to give administrators, teachers, and parents the tools they need to protect transgender students from peer harassment and identify and address unjust school policies.

The announcement comes amid a national debate over LGBT rights, particularly in response to North Carolina's "bathroom bill." The Justice Department and North Carolina are engaged in a high-profile legal battle over the state's law, which critics argue is discriminatory and unenforceable. The law requires transgender individuals to use restrooms that correspond to the sex assigned to them at birth, rather than their gender identity. The Obama administration has deemed the law a "state-sponsored discrimination" and has threatened to withhold federal funding from the state if it does not repeal the law.

The fight over transgender rights extends beyond North Carolina, with a federal appeals court in Virginia recently ruling that banning a transgender boy from using the boys' bathroom was a civil rights violation. School officials in Chicago and Oregon have also outlined protections for transgender students.

Title: House Republicans Urge Senate to Act, While Senate Leader Calls for House Action

The House of Representatives has called on the Senate to take action on any last-minute legislation, while the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, has urged House Republicans to pass an existing Senate measure that would prevent tax increases on household income up to $250,000. The Senate is set to reconvene on Thursday evening, with no clear agenda or legislation to consider.

The House will likely be givenled back into session at 2 p.m. on Thursday, but it is unclear what, if any, legislation will be considered. The Senate has already rejected House Republicans' "Tea Party" bills, and Democrats are calling on House Republicans to drop their "knee-jerk obstruction" and pass the existing Senate bill.

The focus has shifted to Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, who is being asked to provide assurances that he will not use procedural tactics to delay any potential bill. However, a spokesman for McConnell said that no one from the White House or Reid's office has reached out to begin negotiations.

Democrats are pushing for an extension of expiring unemployment benefits and a delay in across-the-board spending cuts, while Republicans are resisting any changes to the tax code. The Senate may be running out of time, as without unanimous agreement, Reid would have to take procedural steps to begin considering a bill.

Lawmakers from both parties believe that McConnell could be the key to a resolution, as he has played the role of adjudicator for Congressional Republicans in the past. With days to spare, McConnell must decide whether to allow the Senate to consider the Democrats' bill to extend expiring tax cuts, which could force House Speaker John Boehner's hand and quiet his raucous Republican conference.

Title: Democratic House Campaigns See Surge in Online Donations, Blunting Republican Advertising Efforts

The 2020 US House elections are heating up, with Democratic campaigns receiving a significant influx of online donations, totaling over $35.8 million in August alone. This surge in fundraising has allowed Democratic candidates to air TV ads earlier than ever before, countering the Republican Party's plan to attack them with negative ads.

The Congressional Leadership Fund (CLF), a Republican super PAC, had pledged to spend $100 million in 2018 to attack Democratic candidates. They launched a salvo of TV attack ads in 15 districts before Labor Day, seeking to disqualify Democrats before the fall campaign heated up. However, the gush of online money to Democratic candidates has allowed them to hit the airwaves themselves, defining themselves before facing GOP attacks.

According to a review of TV spending totals, Democrats in nearly 20 districts aired TV ads first to define themselves, while CLF went on offense first in seven districts. This sustained cash flow has extended Democrats' already formidable edge in the fight for control of the House.

Fourteen Democratic challengers raised at least $500,000 via ActBlue, the Democratic online fundraising platform, in August, while another 38 brought in at least $250,000 online. Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer running in Virginia, raised $790,000 online in August, and saw a fundraising spike after disclosing that CLF had obtained her confidential security clearance application.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has been instrumental in this fundraising surge, placing digital staffers in each of its regional political teams for the first time this election. This groundwork has allowed campaigns to grow online and be prepared to capitalize on viral moments and other opportunities.

The resulting well-funded campaigns have put House Democrats in an unusual position: they and their allied outside groups are currently out-advertising the GOP in some battlegrounds. According to Charlie Kelly, executive director of House Majority PAC, "Candidates and Democratic groups have been running even or we have an advantage in paid communications on the air in many of the top 25 to 30 districts across the country."

While the money is no guarantee of success, the surge in online donations has given Democratic candidates a significant advantage in the 2020 House elections.

Title: West Hollywood City Council Votes to Urge Removal of Donald Trump's Star from Hollywood Walk of Fame

The West Hollywood City Council has voted unanimously to urge the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce to remove the star honoring U.S. President Donald Trump from the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The council's decision is largely symbolic, as it has no jurisdiction over the Walk of Fame, which is located in neighboring Hollywood. The council's resolution cites allegations of sexual harassment against Trump and his policy of separating migrant families at the U.S.-Mexico border, which he has denied.

The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce has never removed a star from the Walk of Fame, and has rejected calls to strip the honor from any of the recent spate of powerful men accused of sexual misconduct. The chamber's president, Leron Gubler, stated that there are no plans to remove any stars from the Walk of Fame, and the council's request will be considered at the chamber's next meeting.

Trump's star was added to the Walk of Fame in 2007 in recognition of his television work prior to his entry into politics, including his hosting of the NBC show "The Apprentice" and his producing of the Miss Universe beauty pageants. The star has become a focal point for anti-Trump protests since his presidential run in 2015, and has been vandalized twice by individuals with heavy tools, only to be swiftly repaired.

Title: "Politically Correct Moments of the Decade: A Look Back at the Most Absurd and Controversial Issues"

Article:

The past decade has seen a significant increase in discussions around political correctness, with many individuals and institutions striving to be more inclusive and respectful. However, this effort has sometimes led to some absurd and controversial issues. Here are 24 examples of the most notable ones:

From a Clemson University diversity-training course teaching that it's culturally insensitive to expect people to be on time, to a professor being accused of sexual harassment for stating that effort is 10% of the grade, these examples highlight the challenges of navigating the complexities of political correctness.
