Other notable examples include a campus survey including a trigger warning for anatomical names of body parts, a professor being forced to change his syllabus after being accused of sexual harassment for stating that effort is 10% of the grade, and a Seattle-area councilman being concerned about the city hosing poop off its sidewalks because he thought it might seem too racially insensitive.

Additionally, there were instances of a bathing-suit advertisement being criticized for being "sexist" because it depicted a woman in a bathing suit, a professor claiming that small chairs in preschools are sexist, and a group of Berkeley students insisting that they couldn't take their in-class exam due to their lack of privilege.

The decade also saw controversies surrounding language, with phrases like "long time, no see" being declared "derogatory" towards Asians, and lecturers being warned that capital letters might scare students and that they should avoid using them.

Furthermore, there were instances of cultural appropriation, such as a campus-wide email telling white students to stop wearing hooped earrings because it was offensive to "black and brown bodies who typically wear hooped earrings." A campus Christian club was also found guilty of discrimination for requiring its leaders to be Christians.

The decade also saw a focus on emotional well-being, with Oxford University law students being told they didn't have to learn about rape or violence law if they found it too triggering, and Evergreen State University telling professors to take student protesters' feelings into account when grading them.

Finally, there were controversies surrounding art and literature, such as a liberal author demanding that "normal people" avoid wearing any kind of red hat because all red hats can be too scary, and a lot of college kids being upset about The Vagina Monologues.

These examples highlight the complexities and challenges of navigating the complexities of political correctness, and the need for continued dialogue and understanding.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Response to Execution of Coptic Christians

Egyptian President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi has vowed revenge for the execution of 21 Coptic Christian citizens by ISIS, and the country's military has swiftly followed through with airstrikes against ISIS's weapons caches, training grounds, and camps in Libya. The airstrikes were announced on state radio on Monday, with the military stating that the attacks aimed to "avenge the bloodshed and seek retribution from the killers."

The airstrikes were a response to a five-minute propaganda video released by ISIS on Sunday, which showed the execution of the Egyptian Coptic Christians. In the video, the men were paraded onto a beach, forced to kneel, and then beheaded. The video also included threats against Western powers and a promise to conquer Rome.

The Egyptian men were not in Libya to fight ISIS, but rather were kidnapped in two separate incidents in December and January from the city of Sirte. They were taken captive while trying to make a living in the country.

Libya's air force also carried out airstrikes in the eastern city of Darna, which an ISIS affiliate took over last year. According to Libyan air force commander Saqer al-Joroushi, the airstrikes resulted in casualties among individuals, ammunition, and communication centers, with around 40 to 50 militants killed. The Libyan air force has promised to continue the airstrikes in coordination with Egypt.

This is not the first time Egypt has taken military action against ISIS. In 2015, Egypt launched airstrikes against ISIS targets in Libya in response to the execution of the 21 Coptic Christians.

Title: Covington Catholic Student Defends Actions in Confrontation with Native American Activist

The Covington Catholic High School student, Nick Sandmann, has defended his actions in the controversial confrontation with Native American activist Nathan Phillips on Friday. In an interview with NBC's "Today," Sandmann maintained that both he and Phillips were exercising their First Amendment rights during the incident.

According to Sandmann, the students had permission from their chaperones to shout school chants to drown out the insults from another protest group, the Black Hebrew Israelites. He stated that he felt threatened despite being part of a larger group because the protesters were adults and he was unsure of what might happen.

In hindsight, Sandmann wished they had found another spot to wait for their buses, but at the time, he believed being positive seemed better than letting the protesters slander them. He acknowledged that his group should have walked away once the Native American activists approached, but he didn't want to be disrespectful to Phillips if he was trying to have a conversation.

Sandmann also clarified that he wasn't intending to be disrespectful, but rather trying to show that he wouldn't be moved to further aggression. "As far as standing there, I had every right to do so," he said. "I can't say that I'm sorry for listening to him and standing there."

Phillips, on the other hand, disputes Sandmann's version of events, claiming that Sandmann locked eyes with him and approached him. "I have read the statement from Nick Sandmann, the student who stared at me for a long time. He did not apologize, and I believe there are intentional falsehoods in his testimony," Phillips said.

Covington Catholic High School, an all-boys school, closed on Tuesday for safety reasons and reopened on Wednesday, although parents do not have to send their sons to school for the time being.

Title: Nepal's Muslims Face Growing Islamophobia Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Nepal, a country with a history of religious tolerance, has seen a surge in Islamophobia in recent weeks, fueled by Indian media and social media. The country's Muslim minority, which makes up around 4% of the population, has been targeted with false and sensationalized reports, spreading fear and hatred.

The latest incident involved two Muslim women who were accused of deliberately spreading the coronavirus by spitting on currency notes. The claim was based on a CCTV video showing the women dropping the notes, but subsequent testing revealed that one of the women had a false positive result, and further testing showed that both women had not contracted the virus. The incident was later deemed to be an accident, with the women having simply dropped the notes after visiting a bank.

However, the damage had already been done, with the incident spreading quickly on social media and fueling further Islamophobic posts. This is not an isolated incident, as India's Hindu nationalist media and social media have been spreading false and sensationalized reports about Muslims and the coronavirus.

In April, Indian media outlets reported that Pakistan might have sent coronavirus-infected Muslim men to India via Nepal, using the term "corona-jihad." The claim was based on an unverified report from the state of Bihar and was later denied by the Nepalese government. This is not the first time such allegations have been made, with earlier reports claiming that Muslims traveling between India and Nepal were "superspreaders" of the virus.

The rise of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his link to the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh organization have strengthened the Indian establishment's push for a Hindu nationalist agenda, which has led to a growing sense of Islamophobia in Nepal. The country's Muslims are worried about the rise in hate speech and attacks on social media, but many Nepalis are rejecting the attempts to whip up hatred and are choosing to stand against it.

The incident highlights the importance of fact-checking and responsible journalism, as well as the need for social media platforms to take action against hate speech. Nepal's Muslims are hoping that their friends and neighbors will stop the spread of hate and choose to reject it, just as they have done in the past.

**Kashmir's Forgotten Casualty: The Tragic Story of Osaib Altaf Marazi**

In the aftermath of India's decision to revoke Article 370, granting special status to the Muslim-majority region of Kashmir, a 17-year-old boy named Osaib Altaf Marazi made a fatal decision. On August 5, 2019, Osaib left his home to play cricket with his neighborhood friends, unaware of the chaos that would unfold. His body was later found in the Jhelum River, sparking a traumatic quest for his family to prove his death and secure a death certificate.

Osaib's mother, Saleema Bano, has struggled to come to terms with her youngest son's death, breaking down almost every day for five months. She remembers the day vividly, telling her son to have lunch first and not to go out, but he insisted he would be back soon. That was the last time she saw Osaib.

The events that followed forced the Marazi family to embark on a difficult journey to prove Osaib's death and seek a death certificate. After four months of denial, Kashmiri police finally admitted that Osaib's death was the first in the wake of the abrogation of Article 370.

The crackdown on Kashmir, which included blocking roads, setting up checkpoints, and shutting down phone networks, internet services, and TV channels, seemed designed to prevent Kashmiris from protesting against New Delhi's decision. The Marazi family mourned Osaib's death as Kashmir endured the longest internet shutdown imposed by a democracy.

Suhail Ahmad Marazi, Osaib's older brother, gathered witness accounts of what happened to his brother in the moments before his death. According to witnesses, Osaib was with his friends when they were surrounded by paramilitary forces. The boys jumped into the river to escape, and Osaib held onto the edge of the bridge before being hit with a stick on his head and hands and slipping into the waters. The family believes it was a murder.

The Marazi family's struggle to prove Osaib's death was met with denial and obstruction from the authorities. The hospital refused to issue a death certificate, citing the need for a First Information Report (FIR) from the police. The police, in turn, refused to register the FIR, citing jurisdictional issues. It was only after child rights activists filed a petition in the Supreme Court that the police finally admitted Osaib's death.

The family's ordeal highlights the difficulties faced by Kashmiris in seeking justice and accountability in the aftermath of the August 5 decision. The Indian authorities have denied any killings took place, but local human rights groups have reported six civilian deaths, including 17-year-old Asrar Firdous Khan, who was killed by Indian armed forces while playing cricket with his friends.

Osaib's family continues to struggle for acknowledgement of his death, while Saleema struggles with her pain and longing. "I want to tear my heart open to find my son," she said. "It seems the light of my eyes has gone away."

Title: Clinton Campaign Denies Access to Print Pool Reporter, Raising Concerns About Transparency

The Hillary Clinton campaign has denied access to a print pool reporter, sparking concerns about the campaign's commitment to transparency and openness. David Martosko, the U.S. political editor for London's Daily Mail, was scheduled to be the designated print pool reporter in New Hampshire on Monday, but was told by the campaign's press secretary, Harrell Kirstein, that he would not be allowed to pool the day's events.

According to Martosko, Kirstein told him that he was not on the list and that he should contact Nick Merrill, the campaign's traveling press secretary, with questions. Martosko reported that Merrill explained that the campaign's position is that the Daily Mail does not qualify because it has not been added to the White House's regular print pool, a claim Martosko disputed, citing the fact that the Daily Mail's White House correspondent, Francesca Chambers, has been vetted and has a hard pass.

The campaign's decision to deny access to the print pool reporter has raised concerns about the campaign's commitment to transparency and openness. The Daily Mail is seeking an explanation from the Clinton campaign as to why Martosko was denied access.

In a statement, Merrill said that the campaign is trying to follow the same process and system as the White House, and that the decision had "nothing to do" with the Daily Mail being considered foreign press. However, Martosko reported that Merrill did not provide a clear explanation for the decision.

The incident has also raised questions about the Secret Service's role in the incident. Martosko reported that Secret Service agents refused to let him into the event, citing a decision made by the head of Mrs. Clinton's Secret Service detail, who was not named. The agents told Martosko that he could not enter the event and advised him to use a nearby restroom.

The incident has sparked concerns about the campaign's commitment to transparency and openness, and has raised questions about the role of the Secret Service in the incident.

Title: Investigation into Russian Election Interference Expands to Include Hillary Clinton's Campaign

The investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election has taken a new turn, with reports emerging that the probe now includes elements of Hillary Clinton's campaign. This development has sparked a significant shift in the narrative, with some suggesting that the investigation may implicate long-time Washington, D.C. Democrats.

Fox News senior political analyst Brit Hume joined Tucker Carlson Tonight to discuss the implications of this new information. Hume noted that the revelation that Paul Manafort, a key figure in the Trump campaign, worked with the Podesta group on behalf of Russian interests changes the entire character and focus of the investigation. He also questioned why other journalists had not uncovered this information earlier.

The discussion highlighted the potential consequences for the Democratic Party, with Hume suggesting that Democrats may be disappointed in the outcome of the investigation. The conversation also touched on the Uranium One matter, which has been the subject of Congressional investigations.

The investigation's expansion to include Hillary Clinton's campaign has raised questions about the nature of Russian interference and the extent of their efforts to influence American policy. The revelation that the infamous Steele dossier was paid for by the DNC and Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign has also sparked controversy.

Hume noted that the brazenness of the allegations against the Trump campaign, which have been largely without evidence, may be matched by the actions of the Podesta group. The investigation's shift in focus may ultimately reveal a more complex and nuanced picture of Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Sanders Wins New Hampshire Primary, Biden and Warren Face Challenges

The New Hampshire primary has concluded, with Bernie Sanders emerging as the winner. Sanders led his closest rivals in Manchester, Concord, and Nashua by significant margins. Pete Buttigieg performed well in communities south of Manchester, Boston suburbs, and college towns like Hanover, home to Dartmouth College.

Joe Biden, once considered a national front-runner, finished fourth in Iowa and fifth in New Hampshire. Elizabeth Warren, the neighboring state's senator, edged out Biden by a narrow margin for fourth place.

The two candidates now face a challenging 11-day sprint to the next contest in Nevada and an 18-day wait for the South Carolina primary. They will need to convince donors and supporters that they can regroup and rebuild their campaigns to score a win.

There were concerning signs for both Biden and Warren in Tuesday's outcome. Warren, known for her comprehensive plans, struggled among voters who prioritize electability. Among those who value a candidate who agrees with them on major issues, more than a third chose Sanders, while only a small fraction chose Warren. Among voters who support replacing America's healthcare system with a single-payer plan, three times as many chose Sanders over Warren.

Both Biden and Warren took steps to distance themselves from the New Hampshire results, even before the polls closed. Warren stayed in New Hampshire to concede, offering kind words to Klobuchar and pledging to fight on. Her campaign manager, Roger Lau, emphasized that Warren remains the consensus choice of a wide coalition of Democrats across the country.

Each campaign will now need to convince its chief supporters that it still has a path to the 1,990 delegates necessary to win the convention. Without the support necessary to sustain a national field organization and seven-figure television budgets, any candidate's campaign will wither and die. When a candidate loses or falls short of expectations, money problems mount even more rapidly.

Warren faces the challenge of breaking through for the first time. She does not lead in polls in Nevada, South Carolina, or most Super Tuesday states, and it is unclear where she will score her first win. "The road to the Democratic nomination is not paved with statewide winner-take-all victories," Lau wrote in a memo. "This is a district-by-district contest for pledged delegates awarded proportionally."

Title: The Evolution of Census-Taking: From Ancient Times to Modern Era

The United States is currently undertaking its population census, a once-a-decade effort to count every person living in the country. This process is not unique to the United States, as more than 150 other countries are also participating in the global census round centered on 2020. In fact, around 90% of the world's population has already been or will be counted.

While the modern census may seem technologically unspectacular, collecting data on every individual and household requires a significant amount of information. The American questionnaire asks just seven questions of each person, with a few more for each household, resulting in around 45 GB of data for the entire US population. However, the challenges of this year's census are social, political, logistical, and now public-health related, rather than strictly technological or scientific.

The concept of counting one's population is not new, with evidence of census-taking dating back to ancient times. Herodotus recounts a story of the Scythians, nomadic warriors who lived in Central Asia in the first millennium BCE, who counted their population by collecting arrowheads. Similarly, the Inca Empire, which dominated Andean America at the time of the Spanish conquest in the 15th century CE, recorded elaborate census statistics using knots tied in complex bundles of colored strings called khipu.

The most significant ancient census, from a modern perspective, was that of Rome. The Romans adopted the census late in the city's regal period, shortly before the more familiar republic was declared in 509 BCE. They gave the procedure the name "census," which is still used today, and made it fundamental to their social order. The censors, who conducted the census, determined each Roman citizen's position in an elaborate class hierarchy, which dictated how they lived, including their dress, legal treatment, and political power.

Title: White House Security Breaches: Recent Incident Highlights Concerns Over Agency's Effectiveness

The recent incident involving a fence-jumper on the White House lawn has raised concerns over the effectiveness of the Secret Service's security measures. According to reports, the individual was not stopped immediately, despite 16 previous instances of fence-jumping over the past five years. The Post revealed that a plainclothes surveillance team failed to notice the intruder, the front door was left unlocked, and an alarm box was muted due to staff annoyance.

The incident is not an isolated case. In 2011, a man fired a semiautomatic weapon into the White House residence area, but the Secret Service initially dismissed it as backfire from a vehicle. It took four days for the agency to understand the gravity of the situation, and the public and Congress were not properly informed.

The president and first lady were reportedly furious when they learned of the incident, and lawmakers have expressed concerns about the potential consequences if the attackers had been organized terrorists. The Secret Service's budget and size have decreased in recent years, with staff positions falling from 6,900 to 6,600 and the budget decreasing from $1.9 billion to $1.8 billion. This has led to staff burnout, low morale, and unmonitored posts.

The incident has sparked calls for an independent, top-to-bottom review of the Secret Service, rather than an internal investigation. The president will have to decide whether the current director, Julia Pierson, is the right person to lead the agency and protect the nation's reputation.

Title: California Bill to Limit Vaccine Exemptions Advances, Sparking Debate on Individual Rights and Responsibilities

A bill in the California Senate aimed at limiting vaccine exemptions, allowing students to opt out only if they have a medical condition that justifies an exemption, has passed the health committee with a 6-2 vote. The proposal was introduced in response to a measles outbreak linked to almost 150 infections in late December.

The bill sparked a heated debate among hundreds of supporters and protesters outside the Capitol building in Sacramento, with opponents wearing American flags and holding signs, such as "Force my veggies, not vaccines." They argue that eliminating the personal belief exemption would threaten their ability to make choices about their children's health.

Lisa Cadrein, a Los Angeles resident, expressed concerns about the potential risks of vaccines for her daughter. "I am afraid that her big beautiful blue eyes will not focus on me anymore, and she won't be the kid that she is," she said.

However, scientific studies have found no link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorder. During the hearing, parents also discussed the importance of protecting their children from those who are not vaccinated. Democratic Sen. Lois Wolk, a member of the Senate Health Committee, emphasized that individual rights are not without limits and that the insistence on personal choice could harm others.

The bill still has many more hearings before it could become law, and similar legislation has stalled in Washington, Oregon, and North Carolina.

Title: White House Press Secretary Advocates for School Reopenings, Citing Study on Low Risk to Children

The White House press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, emphasized the importance of reopening schools, stating that "science is on our side" in a press briefing on Thursday. McEnany cited a study published by JAMA Pediatrics, which found that the risk of critical illness due to the novel coronavirus in children is "far less" than the seasonal flu.

According to McEnany, the study demonstrates that severe illness in children is significant but less frequent than in adults, and that preexisting medical conditions seem to be an important factor in children who contract the disease. She encouraged localities and states to follow the science and reopen schools, citing concerns about the negative impact of prolonged school closures on children's mental health and well-being.

President Trump has also been vocal about reopening schools, stating that the risk to children remains low and threatening to put pressure on governors to reopen schools in their states. Trump has praised Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for directing schools to reopen in the fall, despite the state experiencing a surge in coronavirus cases.

However, health experts have expressed concerns about the potential risks of reopening schools, citing the risk of children spreading the virus and potentially worsening the spread of the disease. Some school districts have opted for virtual learning in the fall to reduce the risk of transmission.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has provided guidelines for reopening schools, which Trump has criticized as "very tough" and "expensive." Maryland Governor Larry Hogan, a Republican, penned a scathing op-ed criticizing the president's response to the coronavirus, stating that Trump has eschewed the advice of public health experts.

Title: The New York Times Corrects Its 2016 Story on FBI Investigation of Trump Campaign

The New York Times has issued a correction to its 2016 article about the FBI's investigation into the Trump campaign's potential ties to Russia. The correction comes after the paper revisited its story to provide more information about the investigation's early stages. The article initially played down the case, stating that law enforcement officials had found no conclusive link between Trump and the Russian government.

The original article, published on October 31, 2016, reported that FBI agents had scrutinized some of Trump's advisers but found no evidence of involvement with Russian hacking. The article's tone and headline, "Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia," gave the impression that the investigation had concluded, when in fact it was just beginning.

The Times has since disclosed that during the 2016 probe, dubbed "Crossfire Hurricane," at least one government informant met with two Trump campaign aides, Carter Page and George Papadopoulos, according to current and former officials. This information has become a contentious point, with Trump's allies questioning whether the FBI was spying on the Trump campaign or trying to entrap campaign officials.

The article presents the FBI's judgments and misjudgments in a sympathetic light, noting that the bureau was cautious in its investigation of Trump due to concerns about being criticized for going easy on him. The article also highlights the FBI's aggressive approach in the Hillary Clinton investigation, which was driven by concerns about her likely victory and the potential for criticism.

The article has sparked debate, with Trump tweeting that the revelation is "bigger than Watergate." Trump's allies have criticized the FBI's actions, while others have defended the agency's handling of the investigation. The article's correction and the ongoing controversy surrounding the investigation's origins are likely to continue to be a topic of discussion in the coming weeks.

Title: Hillary Clinton Makes History as First Female Presidential Nominee from a Major U.S. Political Party

Article:

Hillary Clinton made history on Thursday night as the first woman to accept the presidential nomination of a major U.S. political party. The theme of her speech was "Stronger Together," which she emphasized throughout her nearly one-hour address. Clinton's main focus was on differentiating herself from her rival, Donald Trump, and highlighting her experience and steady leadership on foreign policy and the economy.

Clinton did not mention faith, religious liberty, or abortion in her speech. She did, however, reference her Methodist faith, quoting her mother's advice to "do all the good you can, for all the people you can, in all the ways you can, as long as ever you can." Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, also made an appearance, praising her mother's accomplishments and expressing her own pride in being her daughter.

Clinton's speech touched on several key issues, including her plan to support local forces in the fight against ISIS, creating more good jobs with rising wages in the United States, and working with Senator Bernie Sanders to make college tuition free for the middle class and debt-free for all. She also emphasized the importance of providing necessary leadership in foreign policy and criticized Trump's ability to handle complicated foreign affairs.

Clinton ended her speech on a note of promise for the future, telling Americans, "We are stronger together." The speech was seen as an attempt to unite the Democratic party and appeal to voters who may have supported Bernie Sanders during the primary election.

Title: Theresa May's Third Brexit Defeat Leaves Britain in Precarious Situation

Article: British Prime Minister Theresa May suffered her third successive defeat on Friday, with a majority of 58 MPs voting against her Brexit deal. While the margin of defeat was smaller than the previous two, the outcome is clear: May's deal is dead. The prime minister's decision to put her agreement to a third vote, despite the likelihood of defeat, has been widely criticized. This article will examine the reasons behind May's decision and the implications of her defeat.

May's decision to put her deal to a third vote was likely motivated by a desire to keep some kind of Brexit process moving, despite the fact that her deal was unlikely to pass. She may have also been trying to shift the blame for the delay to the opposition Labour Party and hardline Brexiteers. However, this strategy backfired, with only five Labour MPs backing her deal and 34 Conservative MPs voting against it.

The attorney general had argued that the purpose of the third vote was procedural, aimed at moving the Brexit deadline from April 12 to May 22. However, this is no longer a viable option, as the UK is now likely to face a choice between a no-deal exit in two weeks or a longer delay to Brexit. Given the dangers of a no-deal exit, a longer delay is the more likely outcome.

May's decision to put her deal to a third vote also had more partisan motivations. The revolt by MPs last Monday, which took control of parliament from the government, opened up the possibility of opposition MPs and pro-European Tories softening the deal, revoking Article 50, or demanding a second referendum. Many Conservative MPs panicked at this prospect, and over 40 of them switched to support the deal. However, this was too little, too late, and the deal was still defeated.

The defeat clears the way for a different approach, with the indicative votes on Monday offering a chance for MPs to rally behind alternative proposals, such as a customs union and a second referendum on the final deal. If the Commons can unite behind these proposals, the EU summit on April 10 could grant the UK a longer extension of Article 50 to cement a different form of deal, with a public vote at the end. It is ironic that May's third defeat may have finally created space for a very different approach from the one she has followed for three wasted years.

Title: Labor Secretary Nominee Thomas Perez Accused of "Secret Deal" with Minnesota City

Article:

A congressional Republican report has accused Labor Secretary nominee Thomas Perez of making a "secret deal" with leaders of a Minnesota city, persuading them to drop a contentious lawsuit in exchange for the Justice Department staying out of whistleblower cases brought against the city. The report claims that this "quid pro quo" potentially cost taxpayers as much as $200 million.

According to the report, Perez, as assistant attorney general, "manipulated" federal law and "pushed the limits of justice" to make the deal happen. The report states that the Justice Department's decision to opt out of the whistleblower cases potentially cost taxpayers $200 million, the amount the government could have won had it pursued damages in the case.

The report alleges that Perez was concerned that the Supreme Court, in reviewing the case, would strike down a major element of civil rights enforcement. Perez allegedly sought leverage to stop the city from pressing its appeal, which involved a case where property owners claimed the city made extraordinary efforts to condemn their properties, violating the federal Fair Housing Act.

The report concludes that Perez appeared to think the Supreme Court overturning the case would have been a severe blow to civil rights enforcement. The "disparate impact" provision, which the report describes as legally questionable, prohibits housing policies that end up discriminating against certain groups even if those policies are not blatantly discriminatory.

The report also alleges that Perez facilitated and consummated the deal because he feared the Court would find disparate impact unsupported by the text of the Fair Housing Act. The other end of the alleged deal was for the Justice Department not to get involved in cases against the city of St. Paul that alleged the city received millions in Department of Housing and Urban Development funds but failed to file the requisite paperwork regarding the hiring of low-income workers.

The Obama administration has acknowledged that senior Justice Department attorneys recommended intervening in the case and characterized the False Claims Act infractions reported by Newell as "particularly egregious." However, they thought the case would be "quite weak and never should have been a serious candidate for intervention."

The Justice Department claims everything was above board, stating that the department held three staff briefings, heard 24 hours of additional testimony, and reviewed 1,400 pages of documents before deciding not to intervene.

The report was a joint effort by minority leaders of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Republican-led House's Judiciary and Oversight and Government Reform committees. Congressional Democrats have refuted the details, stating that the "overwhelming evidence" indicates Perez and others "acted professionally to advance the interests of civil rights and effectively combat the scourge of discrimination in housing."

Title: The Politics of Intelligence: A Historical Perspective on the Debate Surrounding the Russia Probe

The debate surrounding the origins of the Russia probe has sparked intense discussions about the role of federal law-enforcement agencies, particularly the CIA and FBI. The recent decision by Attorney General William Barr to launch an investigation into the matter has caused discomfort among Democrats and Trump-administration critics, who view it as an attempt to flip the narrative from Trump's alleged collusion with Russia to a dubious decision by the FBI to begin spying on the political opponents of Hillary Clinton and the Obama administration.

The article highlights that the notion that the intelligence community is above politics has been an outdated concept since the upheaval of the late 1960s and early 1970s. The CIA and FBI have always been involved in politics, and their activities have been scrutinized and criticized by both parties.

The article notes that Democrats are now treating criticism of federal law enforcement as beyond the pale, while Republicans are suddenly skeptical. However, a closer examination of the past reveals that both parties have historically defended or criticized the intelligence community based on their political agendas.

The article also mentions that the failure of the investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller to prove the collusion allegations makes it reasonable to determine whether the unprecedented probe of a presidential campaign was an abuse of power. The decision by Barr to investigate the matter has sparked anger among Democrats, who are hoping to pursue the impeachment of Trump by picking up the case that Mueller failed to make after two years of effort.

The article concludes that sensible people of either party will always seek to mix deference to the intelligence community's mission with an understanding that all government officials and agencies must be kept on a tight leash lest they abuse the awesome power vested in them.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Refuses to Abandon Immigration Reform Efforts

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has refused to give up on his efforts to pass immigration reform legislation, despite opposition from some Republican lawmakers and conservative pundits. In a press conference on Tuesday, Boehner stated that his focus is on getting immigration reform done as early as possible and that it is part of the Republican conference agenda.

Boehner's office has released several documents outlining the GOP principles on immigration, which include eliminating the ability for any administration to arbitrarily decide which laws to enforce. While some top amnesty proponents outside Congress have expressed support for the principles, others have raised concerns about the timing and President Obama's trustworthiness.

Despite the pushback from conservatives, Boehner remains committed to moving forward on the issue. "I think leadership's focus and my focus is to get [immigration] done as early as possible," he said.

However, the road ahead remains challenging. The pushback from conservatives has caused significant tremors of doubt within Boehner's leadership team, and some lawmakers are already expressing skepticism about the prospects of passing immigration reform this year.

In a recent meeting with top Democrat Senator Chuck Schumer, House Majority Leader Eric Cantor expressed support for a GOP version of the DREAM Act, which grants amnesty to the children of illegal immigrants. However, Cantor is also keeping an eye on his right flank in the event Boehner retires at the end of this Congress, leaving the seat open for Cantor to claim.

Meanwhile, House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan has confirmed meeting with Schumer on immigration but dismissed the importance of the session, which occurred last year. Ryan expressed concerns about the lawlessness of the White House and the lack of confidence in the President's ability to enforce the laws.

The issue remains complicated, with some lawmakers expressing support for the substance of the principles but opposing moving forward on legislation. Conservative heavyweights like Reps. Tom Price and Jeb Hensarling have come out strongly against moving forward, and the result of the meeting seemed to change Ryan's tone in the days afterward.

Despite the challenges, some lawmakers remain optimistic about the prospects of passing immigration reform. "I wouldn't be surprised" if immigration legislation came to the House floor as early as this spring, said a well-connected GOP member.

Title: Jeb Bush Weighs in on Immigration Reform and Presidential Speculation

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has been making headlines recently, sparking speculation about a potential presidential run in 2016. Bush appeared on NBC's "Today" show, where he shared his opinions on current issues, including immigration reform and the 2013 sequester. His comments have led many to wonder if he might be gearing up for a White House bid.

Bush has been relatively quiet since his brother, former President George W. Bush, left office. However, his new book "Immigration Wars" outlines his stance on giving illegal immigrants legal status, but not a pathway to citizenship. He is also a featured speaker at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) 2013, which takes place in Washington from March 14 to 16.

During his "Today" appearance, Bush expressed optimism that a consensus will be found on immigration reform, but emphasized the need for the budget to be addressed first. He neither confirmed nor denied speculation about a presidential run, stating that it's "way off into the future."

Bush's comments have added fuel to the rumor mill, as he is now being seen as raising his public profile. Another potential contender for the 2016 presidential race is Chris Christie, the popular New Jersey governor. However, CPAC organizers did not invite Christie to give a keynote address this year, a decision Bush described as surprising.

Bush attributed Christie's snub to the governor's handling of budget issues related to Hurricane Sandy, which he believes led to disappointment among CPAC organizers. Bush emphasized that Christie's absence from the conference does not diminish his importance in the Republican Party's future.

Title: Romney and Trump Engage in Twitter War Over Tax Returns

Article:

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, and Donald Trump, a 2016 presidential candidate, have engaged in a Twitter war over tax returns. The exchange began when Romney suggested on Fox News that Trump's tax returns might be "a bombshell" and that voters have a right to see them before deciding on a nominee. Trump responded by calling Romney a "lightweight" and "dope" and questioning his ability to win an election.

Trump also took aim at Marco Rubio, another Republican presidential candidate, saying he should have done better in the New Hampshire and Nevada primaries. Trump's Twitter followers have joined in, posting insults and criticisms of Romney, with Trump re-tweeting many of them.

Romney's tweet, which sparked the exchange, read: "Methinks the Donald doth protest too much. Show voters your back taxes, @realDonaldTrump. #WhatIsHeHiding" Romney's comment was in response to Trump's refusal to release his tax returns, with Trump saying his campaign will "make that determination over the next couple of months."

The Twitter war is likely to continue on the Republican debate stage Thursday night, where the remaining five GOP candidates will gather for their last bout before the Super Tuesday nominating contests.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder Defends Himself Against Congressional Scrutiny Over Recent Administration Scandals

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder faced intense questioning from lawmakers on Wednesday during a House Judiciary Committee hearing, where he was grilled on recent administration scandals, including the Justice Department's decision to secretly obtain two months' worth of phone records from the Associated Press. Holder's comments sparked a heated exchange with Republican Rep. Darrell Issa, who accused him of repeatedly keeping information from Congress.

During the hearing, Holder was questioned about the Justice Department's decision to obtain the phone records, which the AP and several lawmakers claim infringe on the constitutional rights of the press. Holder claimed he had recused himself from the case and was unable to answer questions on why the department failed to negotiate with the AP prior to obtaining the subpoenas, a standard practice in such cases.

Wisconsin Rep. James Sensenbrenner pressed Holder on why the department did not negotiate with the AP, suggesting that Deputy Attorney General James Cole testify before the committee. Holder testified that all decisions made in the case fell on Cole's shoulders, but Sensenbrenner expressed frustration that the administration seemed unwilling to accept responsibility for the mistakes made.

The controversy surrounding the Justice Department's actions has sparked bipartisan outrage, with Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus calling for Holder's resignation. New York Sen. Charles Schumer plans to reintroduce legislation to protect journalists from revealing their sources, which has stalled in Congress since 2009.

The Obama administration has been aggressive in pursuing government workers accused of leaking classified information, with five workers facing indictments and a sixth case ongoing against a U.S. Army soldier accused of sending classified documents to WikiLeaks. Under Holder's command, the Justice Department has prosecuted more government officials for alleged leaks under the World War I-era Espionage Act than all of his predecessors combined.

Title: Texas Sen. Ted Cruz Enters 2016 Presidential Race, Citing Strong Conservative Credentials

Texas Senator Ted Cruz has officially announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, becoming the first major candidate to do so. With his announcement, Cruz is expected to start his campaign immediately, skipping the traditional exploratory committee phase. This move is seen as a strategic decision to gain an early advantage over potential opponents.

Cruz's decision to run is backed by strong Tea Party support, with Amy Kremer, former head of the Tea Party Express, stating that his announcement will "excite the base in a way we haven't seen in years." Cruz's stance on key issues, such as his opposition to Obamacare and his strong stance on immigration, has earned him a reputation as a conservative champion.

Cruz's campaign is expected to focus on his conservative credentials, which include his 21-hour speech on the Senate floor in September 2013, attempting to defund the Affordable Care Act. He has also taken a strong stance on immigration, defying GOP leaders to force a vote on opposing President Barack Obama's executive action on immigration.

Cruz is seen as more independent than other potential GOP candidates, having defied party leaders on immigration and taking a strong stance on issues that resonate with Republican voters. He is also firmly in the mainstream of Republican voters on nearly every issue, unlike some fellow candidates.

Cruz's campaign has been praised for its strong grassroots support, with his 2012 Senate campaign against David Dewhurst being one of the biggest upsets in the election. He has also been praised for his strong campaign skills, having won the election despite being outspent by his opponent.

Cruz's appeal to Hispanic voters is also seen as a major asset, with his father being born in Cuba and Cruz being the first Hispanic U.S. Senator from Texas. His campaign has been praised for its ability to reach across party lines and appeal to disillusioned voters, with Saul Anuzis, former chairman of the Michigan Republican Party, stating that "people are looking for something new and something different."

Cruz's strong legal background, having earned his law degree at Harvard University and clerked for Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist, is also seen as an asset. His wife, Heidi Cruz, has taken an unpaid leave from her job at Goldman Sachs to help her husband's campaign, bringing valuable experience from her work on George W. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign and her time at the National Security Council and Treasury Department.

Title: Corporate Entities Explain Payments to Michael Cohen's Shell Company, Essential Consultants LLC

A recent report by Stormy Daniels' attorney Michael Avenatti has shed light on the financial dealings of Essential Consultants LLC, a shell company owned by Michael Cohen, a former personal-injury lawyer and longtime associate of Donald Trump. The company received large sums from various corporate entities, which are now attempting to explain the purpose of these payments.

According to Avenatti's report, Essential Consultants LLC received payments from Korean Aerospace Industries, AT&T, Novartis, and Columbus Nova. The companies claim that they paid Cohen's company for various consulting services, including legal advice on accounting standards, telecom reform, tax policy, antitrust law, and healthcare policy.

Korean Aerospace Industries paid $150,000 for "legal consulting concerning accounting standards on production costs." AT&T paid $600,000 for Cohen's help in understanding the Trump administration's approach to policy issues, including regulatory reform at the FCC, corporate tax reform, and antitrust enforcement. Novartis paid $1.2 million for Cohen's advice on how the Trump administration might approach certain U.S. healthcare policy matters, including the Affordable Care Act. Columbus Nova paid $500,000 for Cohen's work as a business consultant on potential sources of capital and potential investments in real estate and other ventures.

The companies' explanations for the payments have been met with skepticism, with some critics questioning the nature of the services provided and the lack of transparency surrounding the transactions. Novartis has acknowledged that it made a "mistake" in hiring Cohen, while Columbus Nova's CEO has denied any connection to Russian billionaire Viktor Vekselberg, who has been affected by the economic sanctions imposed by the Trump administration.

The payments to Essential Consultants LLC have raised questions about the potential for influence peddling and the use of shell companies to facilitate backdoor deals. The controversy surrounding these payments serves as a reminder of the importance of transparency and accountability in corporate dealings, particularly when it comes to government officials and their associates.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Refers Michael Avenatti and Julie Swetnick to Justice Department for Criminal Investigation

The Senate Judiciary Committee has referred attorney Michael Avenatti and his client, Julie Swetnick, to the Justice Department for criminal investigation. The referral comes after Swetnick's unsubstantiated allegation that Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh participated in a gang-rape ring while in high school. Avenatti publicized Swetnick's claim, which was presented to the Committee in a sworn statement on September 26. However, Swetnick later backed off her claims during an October 1 interview with NBC News, stating she never witnessed Kavanaugh spike anyone's drink or participate in gang rape.

In a statement, Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley explained his decision to refer Avenatti and Swetnick to the Justice Department, citing concerns about the potential for false statements and obstruction of congressional investigations. Grassley emphasized the importance of taking allegations of sexual misconduct seriously, but also the need to ensure that false claims are not made.

Avenatti responded to the referral on Twitter, calling it an opportunity to expose Kavanaugh's high-school conduct. He also criticized Grassley for not taking action earlier in the confirmation process. The referral is the latest development in the ongoing controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court.

Title: Trump Discusses Various Topics in "60 Minutes" Interview

In a recent interview with "60 Minutes" anchor Lesley Stahl, President Donald Trump addressed a range of topics, including North Korea, the Supreme Court nomination process, and climate change. Trump defended his knowledge of world politics and events, stating he wasn't "a baby" and that he knows what's happening, but he doesn't know if it's man-made. He also expressed trust in North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, saying he trusts him, but acknowledged that he could be proven wrong.

On the topic of climate change, Trump said he thinks something is happening, but it could very well go back. He also questioned the scientific consensus, stating that scientists have a "very big political agenda." When asked about his views on the 2016 election, Trump said that Russia meddled, but he also believes China meddled.

Trump also discussed his views on the Supreme Court nomination process, stating that he thinks Democrats don't want to heal and that he wants to unify the country. He also expressed his own feelings about being president, saying it took him a little time to adjust, but now he feels like POTUS.

The interview covered a range of topics, with Trump engaging in verbal sparring with Stahl at times. The president also made some notable comments, including stating that Defense Secretary James Mattis is "sort of a Democrat" and that he doesn't trust everyone in the White House.

Title: Trump's Failure to Understand GOP Concerns Led to AHCA's Demise

The recent cancellation of the American Health Care Act (AHCA) by President Trump and Speaker Paul Ryan has sparked questions about the president's approach to persuading House Republicans to pass the bill. While Trump did engage in intense efforts to persuade lawmakers, including inviting them to the White House and dispatching key aides to Capitol Hill, he failed to understand the concerns that drove their reluctance to vote for the bill.

According to reports, Trump focused more on the political consequences of not passing the bill, threatening primary challenges to those who didn't sign on, rather than understanding the actual issues at stake. This lack of focus on the details of the legislation led to a significant number of House Republicans refusing to vote for the bill.

Some Republicans had concerns about the bill's ability to lower premiums, while others felt it didn't go far enough in repealing Obamacare's requirements for insurance coverage. Conservative health-policy wonks also raised concerns about the bill's potential impact on lower-income individuals and those in their 50s and 60s.

The article highlights the complexity of the issues involved, noting that any attempt to repeal Obamacare would require significant changes to the healthcare system, including trade-offs between cost control and benefit limitations. The article also quotes House Freedom Caucus chair Mark Meadows, who stated that almost no one in his caucus wanted to vote no, but simply didn't see enough good in the bill to make voting for it worthwhile.

The article concludes that President Trump's lack of focus on the details of the legislation and his failure to understand the concerns of House Republicans ultimately led to the bill's demise.

Title: Obama's Limited Strike in Syria: A Middle Ground Approach

The United States is on the verge of taking military action in Syria, with President Barack Obama leaning towards a limited strike as a middle ground approach. This decision comes after the reported use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government, which has led to widespread condemnation and outrage. The strike is seen as a response to the use of chemical weapons, with the aim of deterring future attacks and degrading the Syrian military's capacity.

The article highlights that the president has only three options: doing nothing, doing everything, or finding a middle ground. The limited strike is seen as the least bad option, as it avoids the risks associated with doing nothing or trying to change the regime. The article notes that the president has wisely avoided a more robust approach, citing the lack of correlation between the use of U.S. military power and its relation to the end state.

The article also mentions that the opposition to the Syrian government is composed of over 1,000 disparate rebel groups, with some allied with al-Qaeda and other Sunni extremists. Ousting the current regime would be a complex and challenging task, with no guarantee of success.

The limited strike is seen as a way to deter the use of chemical weapons and degrade the Syrian military's capacity, but it is not expected to change the arc of the battlefield balance. The article notes that there are downsides to this approach, including the risk of a response by Hezbollah or Syria against Israel, and the danger of undermining American credibility.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual account of the situation, highlighting the complexities and challenges involved in addressing the crisis in Syria.

Title: Sanders' Electability: A Closer Look at the Polls and Social Media Presence

The notion that Bernie Sanders is unelectable and will bring down the Democratic Party if nominated has been a topic of concern among some Democrats. However, recent polling data and social media metrics suggest that this may not be the case. In fact, Sanders' strong online presence and loyal base of supporters could be a significant advantage in the general election.

According to recent polls, Sanders is tied with or beating President Trump in various national and swing state polls. A Quinnipiac poll showed him beating Trump in Michigan and Pennsylvania, while a CBS News/YouGov poll found him doing the same nationally. A Texas Lyceum poll even showed Sanders performing better against Trump in Texas than any other Democrat, losing by just three points.

Sanders' social media presence is also a significant factor. He has a larger following on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and other platforms than his rivals, and has consistently demonstrated new media sophistication that others lack. His supporters are also known for their loyalty, with many writing checks and showing up to rallies and elections.

Some argue that Sanders' socialist views will be a major turn-off for voters, but it's worth noting that he has been open about his beliefs for years and has not been punished at the polls for it. In fact, his supporters are passionate and dedicated, and he has a strong fundraising ability, making him the best-funded non-billionaire in the Democratic game.

Peter Hamby, a writer for Vanity Fair, suggests that Democrats may be underestimating Sanders' electability. He argues that instead of asking if Sanders is unelectable, we should ask if he is actually the most electable Democrat. In the age of Trump, hyper-partisanship, institutional distrust, and social media, Sanders' candidacy could be seen as a perfect match for the 2020 election.

Ultimately, it's impossible to know for certain what voters will accept or want, but the evidence suggests that Sanders' strong online presence, loyal base, and fundraising abilities make him a formidable candidate.

Title: Texas Legislature Passes Restrictive Abortion Bill, Democrats Vow to Challenge in Courts and at the Ballot Box

The Texas Legislature has passed an omnibus abortion bill, one of the most restrictive in the nation, with a Republican majority voting in favor of the measure and all but one Democrat voting against it. The bill, which will ban abortions after 20 weeks, require abortion doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, and require all abortions to take place in surgical centers, is expected to be signed into law by Governor Rick Perry in the coming days.

The bill was passed after a long and contentious debate, with Democrats offering 20 amendments to the bill, including exceptions for rape and incest, and allowing doctors more leeway in prescribing abortion-inducing drugs. However, Republicans rejected all of these amendments.

The bill is part of a broader effort by anti-abortion groups to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade, which guarantees a woman's right to decide on an abortion before the fetus is viable outside the womb. Texas falls under the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, which has shown a willingness to accept more stringent limits on abortions.

The bill has sparked widespread protests in Texas, with thousands of abortion rights supporters flooding the Capitol to draw out normally boring committee hearings and disrupting key votes. The protests were sparked by a filibuster started by Democratic Sen. Wendy Davis of Fort Worth, which effectively killed the bill during the first special session.

Title: Environmental Groups' Influence on EPA Regulations Raises Concerns

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has been accused of colluding with radical environmental groups to write regulations that harm industries and consumers. A recent study by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce found that the EPA has given green groups a seat at the table when drafting environmental regulations, while excluding those most affected. The Sierra Club, WildEarth Guardians, and other groups have participated in "closed-door deals" with the EPA, resulting in regulations that have a significant impact on the economy.

The "sue and settle" legal technique allows environmental groups to file lawsuits against federal agencies, which are then settled in closed-door meetings. This process has led to the creation of regulations that penalize industries and consumers, but benefit radical greens. For example, a settlement between the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Center for Biological Diversity could lead to federal control over private lands in several states, affecting the oil and gas industry.

The "sue and settle" litigation has resulted in significant economic losses, with industries and consumers footing the bill. A 2011 Government Accountability Office report showed that environmental groups received millions of dollars in legal fees from the EPA. The American Lung Association, which supports the EPA's actions, received nearly $20.5 million in funding from the agency.

The EPA's apparent complicity in the "sue and settle" method raises concerns about the agency's accountability and direction. Its primary mission is to protect human health and the environment based on the best available scientific information, but it appears that politics and ideology have taken precedence. The agency's stonewalling and lack of transparency have led to accusations of collusion and a lack of trust in its decision-making process.

The consequences of the "sue and settle" litigation are far-reaching, with industries and consumers facing significant economic losses. The EPA's actions have the potential to destroy jobs, increase costs, and limit economic growth. The agency's apparent complicity in this process raises serious questions about its accountability and direction, and highlights the need for greater transparency and oversight.

Title: Senate Poised to Pass Budget Agreement, But House Fate Uncertain

The Senate is on the verge of passing a massive two-year budget agreement, which would pave the way for over $400 billion in increased defense and domestic spending. However, Sen. Rand Paul's decision to block the bill from passing before the midnight deadline has forced a partial government shutdown. The deal, negotiated by congressional leaders, eliminates the 2011 budget caps, allowing for increased spending on defense and domestic programs.

The agreement includes a major disaster relief package for regions affected by last year's devastating storms and a one-year suspension of the debt limit. President Trump has endorsed the deal, stating that Republicans and Democrats must support the troops and support the bill.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Democratic Leader Charles Schumer have championed the agreement as a bipartisan breakthrough, which would end the cycle of short-term spending bills. The bill is expected to win bipartisan support in the Senate, but its fate in the House remains uncertain.

Defense hawks and moderate Republicans view the deal as a strong compromise that will provide a much-needed boost to the military. However, conservatives have called it a budget-busting proposal that would further sink the country in debt. Democrats are also conflicted, as the deal increases spending for domestic programs but does not address the issue of DREAMers, undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi delivered a record-breaking 8-hour speech on the House floor, telling the stories of DREAMers and objecting to the budget plan's failure to protect them. If conservative Republicans in the House oppose the agreement, House Speaker Paul Ryan will need a significant number of Democratic votes to get it passed.

Title: FBI's Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Server: A Turning Point in Her Career of Skirting the Law

The FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server has been a topic of much debate and scrutiny. As the investigation unfolds, it has become clear that Clinton's handling of classified information was "extremely careless," according to FBI Director James Comey. This revelation has raised questions about Clinton's judgment and her ability to handle sensitive information.

Clinton's husband, Bill Clinton, has been involved in several scandals throughout his political career, including the Monica Lewinsky scandal and the Whitewater scandal. Despite these controversies, Hillary Clinton has remained a prominent figure in American politics. However, her association with her husband's scandals has led some to question her judgment and her ability to make sound decisions.

The FBI's investigation into Clinton's email server has also raised concerns about her handling of classified information. According to Comey, Clinton's use of a private email server was "extremely careless" and put sensitive information at risk. This revelation has led some to question Clinton's ability to handle classified information and her judgment in general.

In conclusion, the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server has raised concerns about her handling of classified information and her judgment. While Clinton has been a prominent figure in American politics, her association with her husband's scandals and her own handling of classified information have led some to question her ability to make sound decisions.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Indiana Law on Fetal Remains, Sparking Abortion Debate

The Supreme Court has upheld an Indiana law requiring the burial or cremation of fetal remains following an abortion, reigniting the contentious debate surrounding reproductive rights in the United States. The decision has sparked a renewed discussion about the legal and moral implications of abortion, with proponents on both sides of the issue weighing in.

The debate has become increasingly polarized, with some advocating for greater access to abortion and others pushing for stricter regulations and even bans. The Supreme Court's decision has added fuel to the fire, with some seeing it as a victory for pro-life advocates and others viewing it as an attack on women's reproductive autonomy.

The debate is not limited to the legal and moral aspects of abortion, but also extends to the scientific and medical aspects of fetal development. Advances in neonatal research and technology have raised questions about the viability and dignity of the fetus, particularly in the later stages of pregnancy.

The debate has also highlighted the need for greater understanding and empathy on both sides of the issue. While some argue that abortion is a necessary medical procedure, others see it as a morally reprehensible act. The Supreme Court's decision has brought attention to the importance of respecting the dignity and autonomy of both the unborn and the woman carrying the pregnancy.

In conclusion, the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Indiana law on fetal remains has sparked a renewed debate about the legal, moral, and scientific aspects of abortion. As the debate continues, it is essential to approach the issue with empathy, understanding, and a commitment to respecting the dignity and autonomy of all individuals involved.

Title: Lawmakers Seek Broader Strategy in Syria Following US Missile Strikes

The US missile strikes in Syria, authorized by President Trump in response to the apparent chemical weapons attack by Syrian President Bashar Assad, have sparked debate on Capitol Hill about the constitutionality of the action and the need for a broader strategy in the region. Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain, R-Ariz., cautioned that the strikes are only the beginning, stating, "It's the end of the beginning, not the beginning of the end." He emphasized the complexity of the situation, citing the challenges posed by both the Assad regime and the Islamic State (ISIS).

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., urged the administration to collaborate with Congress on a strategy, stating, "In the days ahead, I am committed to working with the administration to continue developing a counter-ISIL strategy that hastens the defeat of ISIL and establishes objectives for dealing with the Assad regime." Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., also emphasized the need for a strategy, saying, "Making sure Assad knows that when he commits such despicable atrocities he will pay a price is the right thing to do. It is incumbent on the Trump administration to come up with a strategy and consult with Congress before implementing it."

Some lawmakers, including Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., and Rep. Justin Amash, R-Mich., are questioning the constitutionality of the strikes, citing the need for congressional authorization. Rep. Barbara Lee, D-Calif., also expressed concerns, stating, "I was the lone vote against the 2001 AUMF. Syria strikes are far beyond the scope of this war authorization. Speaker Ryan needs to bring a vote."

House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., characterized the strike as "appropriate and just" and signaled that he wants the Trump administration to consult with Congress on the matter. The Senate is scheduled to hold a classified briefing with military and intelligence officials on Friday afternoon, while the House has already adjourned for the two-week Spring recess.

Title: Trump Signs Legislation to Roll Back Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's Auto Lending Guidelines

The President Donald Trump signed a bill on Monday that revokes guidelines issued by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) in 2013 aimed at discouraging discrimination in auto lending. The guidelines, issued by the CFPB, outlined steps lenders should take to address discrimination by auto dealers, who often determine the terms of car loans for their customers. The rollback was backed by auto dealers and lenders, who argued that the CFPB should have followed formal rule-making procedures and sought more public feedback before issuing the guidelines.

The 2010 Dodd-Frank law prohibits the CFPB from regulating auto dealers, and the CFPB guidance was addressed to lenders under its jurisdiction. CFPB Acting Director Mick Mulvaney praised the move, calling it a "misguided" initiative by his predecessor, appointed by President Barack Obama. "I am heartened that the people, through their elected representatives, have corrected this instance of Bureau overreach," Mulvaney said in a statement.

Democrats and consumer watchdogs, however, warned that the rollback could encourage unfair lending practices and open a new front in the Republicans' deregulation drive under Trump, which would be felt beyond the CFPB. This marks the first time lawmakers have used their authority under the Congressional Review Act to kill a regulatory action taken by an agency several years in the past, rather than within a brief window outlined by the 1996 law.

The congressional move was also novel because the law was used to take down regulatory guidance instead of a formal rule under the Administrative Procedure Act. Agencies issue informal guidance to advise businesses about how laws and rules are being implemented. "This controversial abuse of the CRA should never have been allowed to happen in the first place," said Amit Narang, regulatory policy advocate at Public Citizen. "By signing it, President Trump is turning his back on consumers by giving auto dealers license to discriminate against minorities."

Mulvaney, who also serves as the White House budget director, said the bureau will "continue to fight unlawful discrimination at every turn." The CFPB stated that the process clarified that a number of its other guidance documents may be considered rules subject to the Congressional Review Act and that it will "confer with congressional staff and federal agency partners" to identify additional documents to submit to Congress.

Title: Strong November Jobs Report Gives President Trump a Path to Win Second Term

The latest economic numbers, which show 266,000 jobs created in November and an unemployment rate at a 50-year low, have made one thing clear: President Donald Trump has a path to win a second term next year. While some may debate whether the strong November report or the upward revisions in job gains for the last two months or the broader upswing in the economy is due to Trump's policies, the data suggests that presidents tend to get credit when the economy is strong and blame when it is weak.

A recent CNN poll found that Trump's overall job approval was 42%, with 54% disapproving. However, when asked about his handling of the economy, 52% approved, while 40% disapproved. This is the only area where a majority of respondents approved of Trump's job performance.

The economy is strong, and many people give Trump credit for that fact. In a series of tweets, Trump championed his economic successes, citing the strong stock market and the country's economic growth.

The famous phrase "It's the economy, stupid" has been proven right over and over again. Incumbent presidents rarely lose re-election unless the economy is perceived to be weak or faltering. Jimmy Carter, George H.W. Bush, and Gerald Ford are examples of presidents who lost re-election due to economic issues.

The data suggests that it's very hard to beat an incumbent president unless the economy is seen by a majority of the public to be weakening badly. In election after election, voters cite the economy as the most important issue affecting their vote.

Given that voters care most about the economy, it makes sense that if they believe a president is doing a good job on the economy, they are inclined to reelect that person to keep it going. However, Trump's approval numbers on the economy have been strong for much of the past few years, but his overall job approval numbers have not come close to showing that a majority approve of the job he is doing overall.

Trump's inability to stay on message and focus on the economy could be a major factor in his re-election bid. If he was relentless in his focus on the state of the economy between now and next November, he would undoubtedly make it more likely he wins a second term. However, Trump has demonstrated throughout his presidency and life that he lacks the attention span and/or discipline to stay on any message at all.

Title: Republicans Shift Stance on Roy Moore, Embracing Winning Over Morality

The Republican Party is facing a stark reality: Roy Moore may win the Alabama special election next Tuesday. In response, President Donald Trump endorsed Moore in a tweet and phone call, urging him to "go get 'em." Meanwhile, senators who initially condemned Moore's alleged pursuit of teenage girls when he was in his 30s are now finding ways to walk back their comments.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky stated that the Senate will address the matter after the election, allowing the people of Alabama to decide who they want to send to the Senate. Utah Sen. Orrin Hatch rationalized Trump's endorsement, saying the President needs every Republican to pass his agenda.

Hatch also downplayed the allegations against Moore, stating that many of the incidents occurred decades ago and are a decision for the people of Alabama to make. This shift in stance is attributed to Moore's denial of the allegations and his pledge to remain in the race, as well as polling suggesting his numbers have bounced back.

The logic behind this shift is transparently obvious, as winning is prioritized over morality. Hatch's comments imply that any Republican, including one accused of inappropriate behavior, is better than a Democrat. This stance raises questions about the Republican Party's values and whether they are willing to sacrifice their moral high ground for short-term political gains.

Some Republicans, like Mitt Romney and Matthew Dowd, have expressed concerns about the implications of Moore's potential win. Romney tweeted that Moore's election would be a stain on the GOP and the nation, while Dowd emphasized that the President, the White House, and the GOP have lost moral authority to discuss the allegations against others.

The issue at hand is whether the Republican Party's focus on winning is compromising its moral values. If winning is the sole goal, the party risks sacrificing its principles and integrity. The cost of holding a Senate majority may be too high a price to pay for moral compromise.

Title: Congress Prepares to Deliver Rebuke to Trump Over Trade Talks with China

Congress is gearing up to deliver a stinging rebuke to President Donald Trump over his efforts to normalize trade with China. The move comes as the administration has defended its deal with ZTE, a Chinese telecom company, as tougher than the original penalties imposed in 2017.

The Senate is expected to pass an amendment to the annual defense policy bill that would essentially reverse the administration's softening of penalties on ZTE. The amendment, co-sponsored by Senators Tom Cotton, Marco Rubio, Chuck Schumer, and Chris Van Hollen, prohibits the entire U.S. government from purchasing or leasing equipment from ZTE and a similar telecom company, Huawei, which has also been cited for national security risks.

The amendment would also restore penalties on ZTE imposed in 2017, including a fine and a seven-year ban on the company's ability to purchase U.S. parts. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross announced last week that the administration had reached a "definitive agreement" with ZTE, which included a $1 billion fine and the company's agreement to install a new compliance board. However, critics argue that the deal is not tough enough and would allow ZTE to continue posing a national security risk.

Senator Marco Rubio stated that the administration's deal with ZTE is much weaker than what was originally imposed, and that Congress should remain "clear-eyed and unified on the threat China poses to U.S. interests and national security." The White House has yet to weigh in on the latest development.

Meanwhile, Senate Republicans are also upset over the administration's bellicose language towards Canada over the weekend, which they see as unnecessary and unhelpful. The administration's refusal to endorse a joint statement and accusations of bad faith diplomacy with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau have been met with criticism from some Republicans.

While some Senate Republicans are working on a bill to check the president's ability to impose tariffs on national security grounds, it appears unlikely to pass in the near term. The bill would require congressional approval, which is unlikely to happen given the current political climate.

Title: Lawmakers and Activists Plan to Pressure Banks to Take Stance on Controversial Issues

Article:

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) gained attention recently for her intense questioning of Wells Fargo CEO Timothy Sloan during a House Financial Services Committee hearing. The freshman lawmaker pressed Sloan on the bank's involvement in issues such as child detention and environmental concerns. Ocasio-Cortez and other progressive lawmakers plan to use similar tactics to advance their agenda on issues like climate change, gun violence, and immigration.

According to Politico, Ocasio-Cortez and her allies are leveraging their seats on the powerful House Financial Services Committee and social media following to confront finance industry executives and discourage them from funding projects that contradict their values. They aim to "shame" major financial institutions into taking a stance on these divisive issues.

The lawmakers are using their influence to pressure banks to cut ties with companies that operate oil pipelines, firearms manufacturers, and private prison companies that run immigration detention centers. Activist groups are amplifying the message, and Ocasio-Cortez has acknowledged that part of their strategy involves circumventing Congress.

"We can also use the tools that we have here to pressure change in other ways as well," she said. "There's more than one way to skin a cat, and not everything has to be done through legislation explicitly."

The plan appears to be working. JPMorgan and Wells Fargo recently announced they would cut ties with prisons after being pressured by Ocasio-Cortez and progressive activists. The strategy also led to the National Rifle Association (NRA) losing its credit card partnership with First National Bank after millions of Americans boycotted the NRA following the Parkland, Florida, massacre.
