Karen Shaw Petrou, a managing partner at Federal Financial Analytics, noted that banks are highly sensitive to public pressure due to their reputation-driven business and the potential for sudden customer attrition. As a highly regulated industry, banks are also aware of how their reputations can impact their political-risk profile and Congressional scrutiny.

Title: Researchers Explore Civic Engagement through Letter Delivery Experiment

Researchers in Perth, Australia, conducted an experiment to understand civic engagement by leaving 300 letters on the streets, half of which were stamped and half not. The results showed that 92 of the stamped letters were delivered, compared to 42 of the unstamped ones. The study aimed to identify factors that contribute to trust and neighborly connections within communities.

The experiment is part of a broader effort to understand civic engagement, which encompasses various activities such as community service, voting, and volunteering. According to a 2016 Gallup survey of 140 countries, civic engagement is a crucial aspect of social peace and economic prosperity. The survey ranked countries based on their population's inclination to give back to their communities, with Myanmar, Sri Lanka, and Indonesia topping the list.

The survey also found that the most common forms of giving back to a community are helping a stranger in need (44%), donating money (27%), and volunteering (20%). The experiment in Perth aimed to explore why more letters were delivered in certain communities than others, with the hope of identifying factors that can build trust and neighborly connections.

Other cities and towns are also experimenting with ways to boost civic engagement. For example, a project in Birmingham, Alabama, provided small grants to local volunteer groups for neighborhood-improvement projects, resulting in a decrease in crime rates. The project was part of the national Love Your Block initiative.

In his address to the United Nations in September, former President Barack Obama emphasized the importance of civic engagement, stating that democracy needs to be driven by civic engagement from the bottom up, rather than governance by experts from the top down. The experiment in Perth and similar initiatives around the world aim to understand and promote civic engagement, ultimately contributing to a more cohesive and prosperous society.

Title: Trump Freezes Funding to World Health Organization Over Handling of Coronavirus Pandemic

The United States has placed a hold on funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) for 60 to 90 days, pending a review, announced President Trump on Tuesday. The decision comes after Trump accused the WHO of "severely mismanaging and covering up" the coronavirus crisis. The President stated that the U.S. has a duty to insist on full accountability and that the country will be forced to find other ways to work with other nations to achieve public health goals if the WHO does not improve.

The WHO's 2018-2019 budget was approximately $6 billion, with the U.S. being the biggest donor, contributing more than $400 million last year. Trump emphasized that American taxpayers provided between $400 million and $500 million per year to the WHO, while China contributes roughly $40 million a year.

The President cited several specific complaints that led to his decision to freeze funding, including the WHO's failure to adequately obtain, vet, and share information in a timely and transparent fashion, as well as its failure to investigate credible reports from sources in Wuhan that conflicted with the Chinese government's official accounts.

The decision gives Trump someone else to blame and a way to deflect from his own handling of the virus. The White House's Office of Management and Budget has been working on a menu of options for how to snub the WHO, with the most likely route being to reprogram U.S. funding allocated to the organization.

The United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres expressed concern about the decision, stating that "now is a time for unity in the global battle to push the COVID-19 pandemic into reverse, not a time to cut the resources of the WHO, which is spearheading and coordinating the global body's efforts."

Title: EPA's Former Administrator Used Fake Email Alias, Completed Training Certificates

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has disclosed documents showing that former Administrator Lisa Jackson used a fake email alias, "Richard Windsor," to complete agency training courses and receive certificates. The documents, obtained through open-records requests, reveal that Jackson used the alias to complete online training modules, including cybersecurity awareness and ethical behavior courses.

According to the records, Jackson's "Richard Windsor" account was awarded certificates for completing online training, including the "No FEAR Act Training Module" in 2010 and a "Cybersecurity awareness training" course in 2011, where she scored 83%. The account was also awarded the "scholar of ethical behavior" designation each year from 2010 to 2012.

EPA officials explained that Jackson used the alternate email address regularly to conduct agency business, as her main email address was published on the agency's website and received a high volume of public emails. However, critics argue that the use of the fake email alias raises concerns about transparency and compliance with open-records laws.

The revelation comes as the EPA faces criticism for its handling of open-records requests. In April, acting Administrator Bob Perciasepe wrote a letter to agency employees, acknowledging that the agency had fallen short in many transparency areas and requiring employees to retake training classes to improve compliance.

The use of the fake email alias was first revealed by researcher Christopher Horner, who made open-records requests to obtain the documents. Horner has been pushing for more transparency and accountability from the EPA, and the latest revelations have sparked further scrutiny of the agency's practices.

Title: Conservative Legal Scholars and Attorneys General Helped Put Health Care Mandate on the Map

The upcoming Supreme Court decision on the future of President Barack Obama's health care reform law will undoubtedly define the court under Chief Justice John Roberts. However, it also has the potential to define the careers of several legal minds who helped the case get there. The individual mandate, which requires nearly all Americans to buy health insurance, was not initially a major concern when Congress debated health care reform in 2009. However, a handful of conservative legal scholars, including David Rivkin and Lee Casey, started questioning its constitutionality.

Rivkin and Casey, constitutional lawyers at the law firm Baker Hostetler, were the first to publicly express their skepticism about the mandate's constitutionality in a September 2009 op-ed in The Wall Street Journal. Their article served as the catalyst for further scrutiny and debate. In an interview, Rivkin stated, "We concluded pretty quickly that this kind of mandate was beyond the constitutional power of the federal government."

When the 2010 health law was passed with the mandate, several states hired Rivkin and Casey to represent them in a lawsuit against the federal government. The lawsuit, which now includes 26 plaintiff states and the National Federation of Independent Business, was filed the day Obama signed the bill into law. Rivkin represented some states in the district court and won, with Judge Roger Vinson ruling that the mandate was unconstitutional and the entire law should fall.

Bill McCollum, the former Florida attorney general, hired Rivkin and Casey and filed the states' lawsuit against the health law. McCollum credits the Rivkin-Casey op-ed with sparking his interest in the issue and assigning lawyers in the Florida attorney general's office to do their own research. By early 2010, McCollum, working with then-South Carolina Attorney General Henry McMaster, asked fellow attorneys general if they wanted to join the lawsuit. The politics of the issue were intense, with McCollum stating that even sympathetic Democratic attorneys general were hesitant to join due to potential political repercussions.

The Supreme Court's decision on the health care mandate will likely define the careers of Rivkin, Casey, and McCollum, as well as the court itself.

**Trump Disagrees with Fauci on Reopening Schools, Blames Political Opponents for Slow Economy**

In an interview with Fox Business Network's Maria Bartiromo, President Trump expressed his disagreement with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), on the measures needed to reopen schools. Trump believes that his political opponents want to keep the economy closed going into the November election, citing it as a "political thing."

When asked if he thinks his opponents want him to keep the economy closed, Trump replied, "Yeah, I do. I think it's a political thing." He also stated that people who want to see the right thing happen agree with him, emphasizing the need to get the country open.

Trump also criticized Fauci's testimony on reopening schools during a Senate Health Committee hearing, saying he disagrees with Fauci's stance. "We have to get the schools open, we have to get our country open, we have to open our country. Now we want to do it safely, but we also want to do it as quickly as possible," Trump said.

The president also highlighted the progress made in the United States on coronavirus testing, a major benchmark many experts and governors have said is necessary to hit before moving to lift stay-at-home orders and business closures. Trump noted that young people tend not to get as sick due to the coronavirus and have lower death rates.

Fauci, on the other hand, expressed concerns about the potential risks of reopening schools, stating that "we should be humble about what we don't know" and that the virus can have severe consequences for children. He also warned that prematurely lifting coronavirus restrictions could lead to "suffering and death" and "turn the clock back instead of going forward."

The president also touched on his earlier move to restrict travel from China, which he credited with saving hundreds of thousands of lives. He also criticized the Chinese government for knowing about the coronavirus outbreak when it signed a trade deal with Trump in January.

The disagreement between Trump and Fauci highlights the ongoing debate over the best approach to reopening the economy and mitigating the spread of the coronavirus.

Title: Republicans Struggle to Find Consensus on Immigration Policy Ahead of 2016 Election

The Republican presidential candidates are grappling with the complex issue of immigration, with some candidates shifting their positions and others remaining unclear on how to handle the millions of people in the United States illegally. The debate comes as the party seeks to win back the White House in the 2016 election.

Many Republicans are divided on the issue, with some advocating for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants and others opposing it. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, for example, once backed a pathway to citizenship but now favors granting legal status instead. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who was an architect of a broad immigration bill that included a citizenship path, now favors a piecemeal approach.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has reversed his stance, opposing a pathway to citizenship, while Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is one of the toughest critics of offering citizenship to illegal immigrants. However, he has left unanswered the question of whether they should eventually be allowed to earn legal status.

A recent Associated Press-GfK survey found that 53% of respondents support a path to citizenship, while 50% support a path to legal status. Among Republicans, only 4 in 10 support allowing immigrants who arrived as children, along with parents of citizens or permanent residents, to legally remain.

The current stances of GOP candidates tee up a campaign issue for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, who has forcefully backed creating a pathway to citizenship for many illegal immigrants. Clinton has argued that Republicans' refusal to embrace a pathway to citizenship would relegate millions of people to underclass status.

The issue is particularly important for Hispanic voters, who are a key demographic in the 2016 election. Overhauling immigration law in a way that offers a chance at citizenship is an issue that matters to Hispanic voters across the board, said Javier Palomarez, president and CEO of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.

The dynamic is far different within the Republican primary electorate than it is sure to be among general-election voters. For Jeb Bush, past support for a pathway to citizenship looms as a potential obstacle to winning the GOP nomination. Now he talks mostly about granting legal status short of citizenship and about overturning President Barack Obama's executive actions.

The other Republican candidates, including Senator Rand Paul and former Governors Rick Perry and Mike Huckabee, have also taken varying stances on the issue. While some have expressed support for a pathway to citizenship, others have opposed it or left the question unanswered.

The debate highlights the challenges Republicans face in navigating the conflicting pressures of a primary contest and the general election. As the party seeks to win back the White House, it must balance the demands of its conservative base with the need to appeal to Hispanic voters and other key demographics.

Title: Media's "Inevitable" Narrative Surrounding Hillary Clinton's 2016 Presidential Bid

The media has been building a narrative around Hillary Clinton's potential 2016 presidential bid, labeling her as the "inevitable" candidate. This narrative gained momentum after a joint interview with Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton on "60 Minutes" and her appearance on various magazine covers. Polls showed her with a significant lead over potential Democratic challengers, and many wondered which Republican could possibly challenge her.

However, some Obama aides and strategists have expressed concerns that Hillary's campaign is building a machine without a clear message, similar to her 2008 campaign. They argue that she should make it clear that she is not the "inevitable" candidate. White House pollster Joel Benenson and Obama campaign spokesman Ben LaBolt emphasized that positioning her as inevitable does not provide strategic value and may not help her in the long run.

It is true that Hillary's top-heavy operation in 2008 did not yield the desired results, as she lost the nomination to Barack Obama. Additionally, she does not have a clear message, which may be due to her not being a declared candidate yet. If she were to start acting like a candidate, she would be subject to Republican attacks and a long campaign.

Despite her potential advantages, including being the first female president and wife of a former president, Hillary's campaign has been criticized for not being more active. She has not taken questions from reporters and has not made a clear announcement about her candidacy. A CNN poll showed her with a 16-point lead over Chris Christie, but this may be due to the governor's bridge troubles rather than her own campaign.

The article concludes that Hillary's biggest problem may be that people will be tired of her by the time the 2016 election rolls around, as she will seem like a status quo incumbent running for a third Obama term. The media will likely continue to label her as the "inevitable" candidate, making it difficult for her to change the narrative.

Title: White House Warns of Dire Consequences of Spending Cuts, But Are They Exaggerated?

The White House has warned of severe consequences if automatic spending cuts, set to take effect on March 1, are not reversed. Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood warned of potential air travel delays, reduced airport hours, and even temporary airport closures. However, experts argue that the cuts are not as drastic as claimed.

The Department of Transportation's budget for 2013 is $74.2 billion, with the proposed cuts slicing $1 billion, or less than 1.4 percent, from its budget. Despite this, the administration claims that the cuts will have a significant impact, with air traffic controllers being forced off the job and essential services being reduced.

However, critics argue that the cuts are relatively modest and that the Department of Transportation will actually spend more money this year than it did last year. The administration's warnings of dire consequences, including forest fires, chicken shortages, and long air travel delays, have been met with skepticism.

In an interview, Secretary LaHood explained that the cuts will have a significant impact on the Department of Transportation's employees, with 55,000 employees, including 30,000 air traffic controllers, being affected. However, critics point out that the cuts are less than 2 percent of the department's budget.

Another fact lost in the debate is that the impact of the cuts will not be felt immediately. The federal government will give employees 30 days' notice before they may have to take unpaid leave, meaning the first furloughs will not occur until March 31 at the earliest. For Department of Transportation employees, the most they will be asked to take is one unpaid day off every two weeks.

The White House has defended its warnings, citing the potential impact on essential services, but critics argue that the administration is exaggerating the consequences of the cuts. As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the proposed spending cuts will have a significant impact on the economy and essential services.

Title: Trump Jr. Met with Envoy Representing Saudi Arabia and UAE in 2016, Report Says

Article: Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of the 45th President of the United States, met with an envoy representing the crown princes of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Saudi Arabia in August 2016, according to a report by The New York Times. The meeting was confirmed by an attorney representing Trump Jr.

The meeting, which took place on August 3, 2016, was arranged by Erik Prince, the founder and former head of private military contractor Blackwater, and Joel Zamel, a co-founder of an Israeli consulting firm. The envoy, Lebanese-American businessman George Nader, told Trump Jr. that the crown princes of Saudi Arabia and the UAE were eager to help his father win the 2016 presidential election.

According to The New York Times, the meeting was a chance for the envoy to offer help to the Trump presidential campaign. A company connected to Zamel also worked on a proposal for a "covert multimillion-dollar online manipulation campaign" to help Trump, utilizing thousands of fake social media accounts.

The meeting is an indication that other countries besides Russia may have offered help to Trump's presidential campaign. Mueller's investigators have questioned witnesses in Washington, New York, Atlanta, Tel Aviv, and elsewhere regarding possible foreign help to the campaign.

Alan Futerfas, Trump Jr.'s attorney, said that nothing came of the meeting and that Trump Jr. was not interested in the proposal. "Prior to the 2016 election, Donald Trump Jr. recalls a meeting with Erik Prince, George Nader, and another individual who may be Joel Zamel," Futerfas said in an emailed statement. "They pitched Mr. Trump Jr. on a social media platform or marketing strategy. He was not interested and that was the end of it."

The Saudi and UAE embassies in Washington did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The Wall Street Journal last month reported that investigators working for U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller had met with Zamel, and that Mueller's team was looking into his firm's work and his relationship with Nader.

Mueller is investigating whether Russia meddled in the presidential election and if Moscow colluded with the Trump campaign, as well as whether Trump committed obstruction of justice by trying to thwart the U.S. Department of Justice probe. Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and has called the Mueller investigation a "witch hunt."

**US-China Trade Talks Resume Amid Tensions**

The United States and China resumed trade negotiations in Shanghai on Tuesday, following a three-month hiatus. The talks come as tensions between the two nations remain high, with US President Donald Trump criticizing China for its unwillingness to purchase American agricultural products.

Trump took to Twitter to express his frustration, stating that China is "doing very badly" and "just don't come through" on their commitments. He also warned that the US has "all the cards" and that China faces a tougher deal if he is re-elected in 2020.

China's state media responded to Trump's comments, refuting his claims and stating that the US has forgotten its commitment to restart negotiations on a basis of equality and mutual respect. The US, on the other hand, has accused China of not following through on its commitments.

The negotiations are expected to be challenging, with the two sides still far apart on key issues. China is pushing for compromise, while the US is seeking concessions. The outcome of the talks will determine whether China will resume negotiations from a draft text agreed upon before the impasse in May or wait for the 2020 election or propose something else.

The US-China trade war has had a significant impact on global markets, with the S&P 500 Index closing lower for a second day. The US-China trade talks are expected to continue on Wednesday, with the outcome still uncertain.

Title: Trump Rally in Texas Focuses on Nationalism and Anti-Abortion Efforts

The President's rally in Texas, held on October 22, 2018, focused on themes of nationalism and anti-abortion efforts. Trump, who had previously referred to himself as a nationalist, promised tax cuts and emphasized the alleged threat posed by ISIS, "illegals," MS13 gang members, liberal mobs, Congressional Democrats, and the media. The crowd, which was largely made up of supporters of the President, was receptive to his message.

The rally was also attended by Alex Jones, a prominent figure in the conspiracy theory community, who was seen shouting at a pile of horse manure, which he referred to as Beto O'Rourke, the Democratic challenger to Senator Ted Cruz. Cruz was not a major focus of the rally, with speakers mentioning him only in general terms.

Trump spent a significant amount of time discussing his accomplishments, including the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and the number of judges he has appointed. He also touched on the topic of the FDA's efforts to crack down on a website that sells abortion-inducing drugs, Aid Access, which has been shipping the drugs from India to women in the US. The FDA has deemed the process illegal, but the website's founder claims it is legal under current regulations.

The rally was notable for its lack of focus on Senator Cruz, who is expected to win his re-election bid. Instead, Trump's speech was more focused on his own accomplishments and the perceived threats to the country.

Title: President Obama Proclaims "Captive Nations Week", Amid Criticism Over Response to Syrian Crisis

Article:

President Barack Obama has signed an executive order proclaiming "Captive Nations Week", a tradition started by President Dwight Eisenhower in 1959. The proclamation does not specifically mention the ongoing crisis in Syria, where forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad have killed nearly 15,000 civilians in 16 months of open revolt against the regime. The order instead focuses on the United States' commitment to supporting individuals and nations seeking freedom, equality, and human rights.

Critics, including former Undersecretary of Defense Douglas Feith, have accused the Obama administration of being too timid in its response to the Syrian crisis. Feith argues that the administration has not taken sufficient action to support the rebels or establish a no-fly zone, and has not provided adequate support to establish a humanitarian "safe zone" on the Turkish border.

Meanwhile, Russia has accused the West of attempting to use blackmail to secure a new U.N. Security Council resolution that could allow the use of force in Syria. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov stated that the Kremlin has no intention of supporting the British proposal to enact U.N. sanctions to resolve the crisis. The U.S. has consistently supported sanctions, which the Obama administration has stepped up as the crisis has deepened.

The U.N. Security Council's mandate for a monitoring mission in Syria expires on July 20, and Lavrov accused the West of using the deadline as a bargaining chip. The U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has worked with the U.N. Security Council and U.N. envoy Kofi Annan on a June 30 accord calling on Syrians to come up with a political transition.

In his proclamation, President Obama emphasized the importance of supporting those who struggle for their rights, stating that "as long as there are people who live in the darkness of oppression, America will remain their steadfast friend, linked by a common dream and our common ideals."

Title: Bipartisan Resolution Calls for International Investigation into China's Handling of COVID-19 Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic, which originated in Wuhan, China, has become a contentious issue on Capitol Hill, with Democrats and Republicans taking differing stances on the role of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in the global health crisis. While Democrats have been reluctant to criticize the CCP, two rising stars in the Republican Party, Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-NY) and Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO), have proposed a resolution calling for an international investigation into the CCP's handling and cover-up of the virus.

The resolution aims to investigate the CCP's knowledge and decision-making regarding the virus, as well as the harm caused by its intentional negligence. Rep. Stefanik is introducing the resolution in the House of Representatives, stating that the CCP's "unconscionable decision to orchestrate an elaborate cover-up of the wide-ranging and deadly implications of coronavirus led to the death of thousands of people, including hundreds of Americans and climbing." Sen. Hawley echoed this sentiment, saying that the CCP "intentionally lied to the world about the origin of this pandemic" and that it is "time for an international investigation into the role their cover-up played in the spread of this devastating pandemic."

The proposed resolution does not aim to assign blame or make accusations, but rather seeks to hold the CCP accountable for its actions and provide compensation for the harm caused by its negligence. The CCP has been accused of destroying samples and forcing doctors to remain silent about the virus, which has led to widespread criticism and outrage. While Democrats have refused to condemn the CCP's actions, the proposed resolution aims to bring transparency and accountability to the situation.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Condemns Rep. Don Young's Use of Term "Wetbacks"

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, has condemned the use of the term "wetbacks" by Representative Don Young, a senior member of Congress from Alaska. Young used the term in an interview with an Alaska radio station to describe Hispanic migrant workers who used to work on his family's ranch. The term is considered a slur for Mexicans crossing illegally into the United States.

Young, 79, has spent four decades in Alaska's only U.S. House seat and apologized for his use of the term, stating that he meant no disrespect. In a later statement, he explained that the term was commonly used during his childhood on a farm in Central California and that he understands the importance of migrant workers in America's workforce.

The controversy comes at a sensitive time for the Republican Party, which is attempting to navigate calls for changes in immigration law and is considering a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. Many conservatives oppose such a path, while others, including some party leaders, support it.

Boehner's statement condemning Young's use of the term "wetbacks" was brief, stating that it was "beneath the dignity of the office he holds." The incident highlights the ongoing challenges the Republican Party faces in addressing the complex issue of immigration reform and its impact on Hispanic voters.

Title: Justice Department Declines to File Charges Against NYPD Officer in Eric Garner's Death

The United States Department of Justice has declined to file federal civil rights charges against NYPD Officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the chokehold death of Eric Garner on July 17, 2014. The decision comes one day before the fifth anniversary of Garner's death and the expiration of the statute of limitations. According to a source familiar with the matter, the Justice Department's decision was made by Attorney General William Barr, who took the Eastern District of New York's recommendation not to prosecute over the department's civil rights division's recommendation to move forward with a prosecution.

The decision was met with disappointment from Eric Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, who stated that the Justice Department "has failed us." A Staten Island grand jury had previously declined to indict Officer Pantaleo on any state criminal charges four months after Garner's death.

A senior official from the Justice Department explained that the decision was made after a rigorous legal examination of the facts, stating that "you can't watch the video and not feel great sympathy towards Eric Garner, but then I think you have to impose a rigorous legal examination of the facts." The official noted that the department determined it could not establish the willful intent requirement, and therefore did not seek to analyze elements like whether Pantaleo's actions were permissible or reasonable under NYPD or other law enforcement policies.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (PBA) President, Patrick J. Lynch, stated that it is "no coincidence" that both the grand jury and the Justice Department found no criminality in Officer Pantaleo's actions, and that the NYPD will continue to investigate the incident as a disciplinary matter. The PBA believes that if the disciplinary case is handled on the facts, free of political influence, Officer Pantaleo will be fully exonerated of any wrongdoing.

Title: Twin Explosions Near Iranian Embassy in Beirut Kill at Least 20, Wound Hundreds

Article:

A devastating explosion rocked the southern Jnah district of Beirut, Lebanon, on [date], killing at least 20 people, including an Iranian official, and injuring over 100. The blasts, which occurred near the Iranian embassy, have left a trail of destruction and chaos in their wake. The area is known as a stronghold of the Hezbollah group, which has been a major backer of the Syrian government.

The explosions were caused by two suicide bombers, one on foot and one in a car, detonating their explosives. The Iranian ambassador to Beirut confirmed the death of Iranian cultural attaché Ebrahim Ansari, who had been in his post for only a month.

The identity of the perpetrators is still unclear, but the Lebanese Sunni jihadi group Abdullah Azzam Brigades has claimed responsibility. The group stated that the attack was meant to send a "clear message."

The area has been targeted by several attacks in recent months, and Lebanon has seen a surge in violence and sectarian clashes in recent years. The country has been caught in the middle of the Syrian civil war, with Iran and Hezbollah supporting the Syrian government and Sunni groups backing the rebels.

Lebanon's Prime Minister Najib Mikati stated that the aim of the blast is to stir up the situation in Lebanon and use the country as a means to convey messages. The attack has raised concerns about the potential for further violence and instability in the region.

The Syrian government has been pushing back against rebel fighters on multiple fronts, including the Qalamoun region along the Lebanese border. This has led to fears that the conflict could spill over into Lebanon, exacerbating the country's fragile security situation.

Lebanon has a history of being a battleground for regional conflicts, and the country is currently hosting over 1 million Syrian refugees. The ongoing violence in Syria has the potential to destabilize Lebanon's fragile democracy, which is still recovering from a 15-year civil war that ended in 1990.

The stakes are high for Lebanon, with some experts warning that if one side or the other emerges victorious in the Syrian conflict, it could have far-reaching consequences for the country's stability. A negotiated solution in Syria, which would require rival actors to make compromises, may be the best outcome for Lebanon.

Title: Rep. Ocasio-Cortez Discusses Potential Vice Presidency and Importance of Language Preservation

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a 30-year-old freshman congresswoman from New York, recently expressed her interest in being considered as a potential vice presidential candidate in a Spanish-language interview with Noticias Telemundo. However, she quickly pointed out that she falls five years short of the constitutional age limit to hold the office, which requires candidates to be at least 35 years old.

During the interview, Ocasio-Cortez discussed her experience as a community organizer in the Bronx, where she worked with Sen. Bernie Sanders during the last presidential campaign. She also highlighted the importance of preserving her Spanish language skills, stating that it is crucial for her to continue practicing and improving her language skills to maintain a connection with her family and community.

Ocasio-Cortez also reflected on her journey from working in a taqueria as a waitress and bartender to becoming a congresswoman, emphasizing that her values remain the same. She emphasized the need to fight for working families, health insurance, education for all children, and fair salaries.

The interview took place before Ocasio-Cortez headlined a campaign event for Sen. Bernie Sanders in Las Vegas, where she endorsed him for the White House in October. Her involvement could play a key role in helping Sanders differentiate himself from fellow progressive Sen. Elizabeth Warren in seeking the Latino vote in Nevada.

Title: US Warns Russia of "Grave" Consequences Over Ukraine Crisis

Article:

In a stern warning, US Secretary of State John Kerry urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to reverse his "provocative" actions in Ukraine, threatening "grave" and "costly" consequences from the international community if he fails to do so. Kerry's statement, delivered at a State Department briefing room, echoed comments from President Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, who have also expressed concern over Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine.

Kerry accused Russia of engaging in covert and destabilizing activities, including the deployment of disciplined paramilitary groups in unmarked uniforms, the arrest of undercover Russian intelligence agents, and the kidnapping and murder of local Ukrainian officials and journalists. He cited these actions as evidence that Russia is stoking instability in Ukraine, rather than working to quell it.

The US has accused Russia of violating the agreement reached in Geneva last week, which aimed to stabilize the situation in Ukraine. Kerry stated that while the Ukrainian government is doing everything it agreed to under the plan, Russia is taking steps to undermine and provoke the Kiev government.

The US has already imposed sanctions on Russia over its annexation of Crimea, and Kerry cited statistics suggesting that the Russian economy is already feeling the impact. However, some analysts are skeptical that the international community will be united in imposing new sanctions on Russia, as Western Europe remains reliant on Russian energy and may struggle to replace it in time for next winter.

The European Union is also not united on imposing broad sector sanctions, and some Europeans may be sympathetic to Russia's claim that it is acting to restore order in Ukraine. This could create a challenge for the US and its allies in maintaining a united front against Russia.

Title: International Community Urges Caution in Venezuela Crisis

The situation in Venezuela has reached a critical point, with millions fleeing the country and the United Nations estimating over 5 million refugees by the end of the year. The crisis is not just about politics, but about survival, as the Maduro regime has devastated the economy and social order. While the international community recognizes Juan Guaidó as the legitimate president of Venezuela, many urge caution against US military intervention.

The US should refrain from intervening militarily, but continue providing diplomatic and logistical support. The public around the world should hope that the powerful in Venezuela will see the light and either persuade Maduro to leave or escort him out of office. The key to the situation lies in whether the military will abandon the regime, and the odds are against it.

The US posturing may taint the opposition and lead to unwise risks being taken by Guaidó and his supporters. It is crucial to keep quiet and stay out of the situation, as it is not in the US' best interest to get involved. The Venezuelan people have international moral support and the promise of aid to rebuild, but they are on their own against a regime backed by Cuba, Russia, China, and Iran.

The situation is a David vs. Goliah contest, but it may be a good thing for Venezuelans in the long run. It will be their fight to win or lose, and they have already proven their country is worth fighting for.

Title: US Senate Passes Sweeping Tax Cuts Bill, Marking Trump's First Major Legislative Victory

The US Senate has passed a sweeping tax cuts bill, marking a significant legislative achievement for President Donald Trump. The bill, which passed with a slim majority of 51-49, would reduce corporate tax rates and provide modest tax breaks for most Americans. The legislation is expected to add $1 trillion to the budget deficit over the next decade, according to a Senate committee finding.

The bill's passage comes after a marathon session of negotiations and amendments, with Democrats criticizing the plan for primarily benefiting the wealthy and big business. The plan would lower the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20%, while future foreign profits of US-based firms would be mainly exempt from tax.

The bill now needs to be merged with the version passed by the House of Representatives before it can be signed into law by the President. Trump has expressed his enthusiasm for the bill, stating that it will "grow the country, grow jobs, and grow everything."

The bill's passage marks a significant victory for Trump, who has struggled to get major legislative movement in Congress since taking office. The bill's passage also comes as the Trump administration faces ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 election and possible collusion with his campaign team.

The bill's opponents, including Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, have criticized the plan for endangering social security and medical provision, while Independent Senator Bernie Sanders called the treasury "being looted." Republican Senator Mitch McConnell, however, praised the bill, stating that it will "prove to be just what the country needs to get growing again."

The bill's passage is not the end of the process, as the House and Senate must now smooth out differences in their bills and vote on the compromise. The bill's passage is seen as a major victory for the Republican party, which has struggled to pass major legislation this year.

Title: Democratic Lawmakers Tour Remote Texas Tent City Holding 2,700 Immigrant Teens, Urge Facility to Close

A group of five Democratic lawmakers, including Rep. Beto O'Rourke, toured a remote tent city in West Texas on Saturday, where they found 2,700 immigrant teens being held at a cost of approximately $1 million per day. The lawmakers urged the nonprofit running the facility, BCFS Health and Human Services, not to renew its federal contract, which expires on December 31. This long-shot request could effectively shut down the camp, which was initially intended to be temporary but has taken on a permanent feel with soccer fields, a dining facility, and separate sleeping quarters for boys and girls.

The lawmakers, who included Sens. Mazie Hirono of Hawaii, Jeff Merkley of Oregon, and Tina Smith of Minnesota, as well as Rep. Judy Chu of California, expressed concerns about the conditions at the facility and the treatment of the children. O'Rourke noted that they were not allowed to speak to the children in any meaningful way, and that the teens seemed disengaged during recreational activities.

"We need to shut it down," Chu said. "It is inhumane. It is a child prison. It has no right to exist."

The lawmakers also highlighted the high cost of the facility, which has cost taxpayers $144 million since opening in June. They urged BCFS Health and Human Services to refuse to renew its contract with the U.S. government, but acknowledged that it is unclear where the children would be transferred if the facility were to close.

The lawmakers also expressed concerns about the treatment of the children, including the fact that many have family already in the United States who would like to take them. However, federal authorities have begun fingerprinting and conducting background checks on would-be "sponsors," resulting in 170 apprehensions on possible immigration violations. Despite this, the contractor reported that 1,300 children have relatives ready to take them, but have remained at Tornillo due to unexplained federal delays.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Strategy Pays Off in Government Shutdown Negotiations

The recent three-day government shutdown has come to an end, with President Trump and Senate Republicans emerging victorious. The shutdown, which was sparked by a dispute over immigration and border security, saw Trump adopt an uncharacteristic approach, laying low and making no public appearances. This strategy allowed him to put pressure on Senate leaders to reach an agreement and open the government, ultimately delivering a much-needed victory for the president.

According to Politico, Trump's "stand-back-and-watch" approach paid off, forcing Senate leaders to negotiate on their own and delivering a win for the White House. This tactic was a departure from Trump's usual impulsive behavior and inability to step out of the spotlight, as described in Howard Kurtz's book "Media Madness: Donald Trump, The Press, And The War Over the Truth."

The shutdown also saw a rift emerge within the Democratic Party, with some lawmakers criticizing their Senate colleagues for not standing firm on their demands. House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland called out Senate Democrats, saying, "How do we know the Senate isn't screwing us?" Rep. Luis Gutiérrez of Illinois expressed disappointment, saying, "They blink, they just do, and it's unfortunate."

The shutdown has left Democrats reeling, and some are already looking ahead to the midterm elections. Trump's aides believe that the president has learned new tricks and may surprise them again in the future. As one White House aide noted, "No one is saying Trump won't be Trump, and he knows how to pivot and attack better than anyone. But he is also figuring out that timing is everything and you sometimes have to wait and let your adversaries trip over themselves."

Title: Romney Shifts Focus to Economy and Military Strength After Libya Remarks Controversy

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney appeared in Virginia on Thursday, attempting to refocus his campaign on the economy and military strength. The move comes a day after his criticism of President Obama's handling of events in Libya and Egypt sparked a heated debate. Romney largely avoided discussing the unrest in Egypt and the attack on the American consulate in Benghazi, Libya, which left four Americans dead.

At a rally in Fairfax, Virginia, Romney began his speech by paying tribute to the victims of the attack, including Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other embassy staffers. He expressed condolences to their families and acknowledged the tragedy of their loss.

Romney's speech did not directly address the controversy surrounding his claims that the Obama administration's statements on the Egyptian embassy's Facebook page were "akin to an apology." His comments had faced strong backlash, including criticism from some fellow Republicans.

During the speech, a heckler interrupted Romney, shouting "Why are you politicizing Libya?" The crowd attempted to drown out the heckler with chants of "Mitt" and "U-S-A!" Romney responded by saying he would offer a moment of silence, but the heckler refused, so he continued with his speech.

Meanwhile, President Obama traveled to Golden, Colorado, where he spoke about improving the economy and vowed to find those responsible for the attack on the American consulate in Libya. He emphasized that the United States will not be intimidated by acts of terror and will not let them shake its resolve.

Libyan officials informed the U.S. on Thursday that four people are in custody in connection with the attack. Romney's speech in Virginia focused on his vision for a strong and leading United States, emphasizing the importance of American strength in shaping global events.

Title: Catholic Church in New Haven Reports Vandalism, Latest in String of Attacks on Churches Across the US

The St. Mary's Parish in New Haven, Connecticut, has reported an incident of vandalism at St. Joseph's Church, with anarchist and satanic symbols painted on the doors. The Archdiocese of Hartford confirmed the incident, stating that the vandalism occurred between 9 p.m. on Wednesday and 6 a.m. on Thursday.

This latest incident follows a pattern of similar attacks on Catholic churches and statues across the United States, including incidents in Chattanooga, Queens, Boston, Sacramento, and Ocala. The pastor of St. Mary's Parish, John Paul Walker, stated that the motive behind these attacks is to intimidate and instill fear in those who worship Christ.

Despite the recent incidents, the pastor expressed confidence in the resilience of the Catholic faith, which has endured for over 2,000 years. He emphasized that the faith will not be intimidated and will continue to pray for the conversion of the hearts of those responsible for the vandalism.

The New Haven police have not commented on the incident, and the investigation is ongoing. The incident is the latest in a string of similar attacks on Catholic churches and statues across the country, including a recent incident in Calgary, Alberta, where a statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus was defaced.

Title: Americans' Economic Concerns Weigh on Trump's Job Approval Rating

A recent poll conducted by the Washington Post and ABC News has revealed that six out of 10 Americans believe a recession is likely in the next year, with many attributing this concern to the ongoing trade war with China. This sentiment has had a significant impact on President Donald Trump's job approval rating, which has fallen by six points to 38% since July. Trump's average rating since taking office remains the lowest on record for any modern president at a comparable point in their term.

The poll found that 56% of Americans are concerned that the trade dispute with China will raise the price of things they buy, and 60% believe a recession is very or somewhat likely in the next year. This is a concerning sign for Trump, as his approval rating among those who see a recession as likely or are concerned about the trade dispute is significantly lower than among those who are less pessimistic.

The poll also revealed that economic attitudes are closely tied to Trump's overall job performance rating. Among those who see a recession as likely, Trump's approval rating is just 20%, while among those who are concerned about the trade dispute, it is 19%. In contrast, his ratings among those who are less pessimistic about the economy and the trade dispute are 50 and 51 points higher, respectively.

The poll also showed that economic attitudes are highly partisan, with 90% of Republicans rating the economy positively, compared to 52% of independents and 33% of Democrats. One in three Republicans sees a recession as very or somewhat likely in the next year, rising to 60% among independents and 83% among Democrats.

The survey was conducted by landline and cellular telephone from September 2-5, 2019, among a random national sample of 1,003 adults, with a margin of sampling error of 3.5 points. The survey was produced for the Washington Post by Langer Research Associates of New York, with sampling and data collection by Abt Associates of Rockville, Md.

Title: Senate to Consider Additional Sanctions to Pressure Iran on Nuclear Program

Article:

The United States Senate is set to consider further sanctions on Iran, aimed at pressuring the country to abandon its nuclear program. This move comes as the international community continues to monitor Iran's progress on its nuclear ambitions. The sanctions, if passed, would give President Obama the authority to take swift and decisive action to pressure Iran into an agreement acceptable to the West.

The Senate has a long history of playing a significant role in shaping American foreign policy, dating back to the Alaska Purchase in 1867 and the United Nations in 1945. Many notable Senators, including J. William Fulbright, Chuck Percy, and John Kerry, have played crucial roles in crafting American foreign policy.

The additional sanctions are seen as crucial because Iran has strong incentives to maintain its nuclear program. Iran is now within striking distance of developing an atomic bomb, which would make it a major player in the Middle East and pose a threat to countries it views as hostile, such as Israel, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE. Domestically, the nuclear program is popular among Iranians, with 80% in favor of it.

A nuclear Iran would likely lead to an arms race in the Middle East, with several countries acquiring nuclear weapons. Radical Islamist forces in the region would be strengthened, while moderate, pro-American states would be discouraged and feel threatened to their very survival.

According to a report, Iran may have intercontinental ballistic missiles capable of hitting the East Coast of the United States by 2020. Even before then, Iran may be able to hit Western and Central Europe with nuclear weapons. Therefore, the diplomatic effort to dismantle the Iranian nuclear program is vital to American national security.

Tough sanctions have already brought Iran to the bargaining table, and the country remains highly vulnerable to economic sanctions due to its poor economic state. A United Nations study ranked Iranian GDP per capita 82nd in the world, below that of Botswana. A World Bank study showed the ease of doing business in Iran is 152nd in the world, below that of Liberia. Another World Bank study ranked Iran 166th in the world in getting electricity, below Swaziland.

The sanctions would give President Obama the leverage to ensure that Iran has no choice but to dismantle its nuclear weapons program. Iran has given up its nuclear ambitions before, but only under extreme duress. In 1987, Grand Ayatollah Khomeini ended the war against Iraq when he realized that more massive casualties would not bring victory. In 2003, Grand Ayatollah Khamenei slowed down the nuclear program when the American army took Baghdad.

Title: Trump's Tough Stance on Trade: A New Era of Protectionism or a Necessary Measure?

Article:

President Donald Trump has made getting fair trade deals a central part of his platform, and he has followed through with the imposition of additional tariffs on selected goods coming into the United States. This move has been met with skepticism from supporters of free trade, who argue that tariffs are taxes in disguise and lead to higher prices for U.S. consumers. The stock market dropped 500 points after the new China tariffs were announced, and critics argue that tariffs provide a safe harbor for inefficiencies and protect markets and manufacturers from the need to innovate and increase productivity.

However, some see the tariff strategy as a necessary measure to get China to the negotiating table to address issues such as intellectual property protection. The strategy has worked with other countries, including the Europeans, Japan, Mexico, and Canada, leading to new trade deals that were previously considered unlikely.

However, the article highlights a recent example of a country exploiting a trade agreement. Qatar, a nominal U.S. ally and host to the largest American military base in the Gulf, has been accused of cheating on a trade agreement with the United States. Under the Open Skies agreement, Qatar agreed not to use government subsidies to establish lower fares in competition with U.S. carriers. However, Qatar has found a loophole by purchasing a 49% share in an Italian carrier, Air Italy, and using it to offer bargain-rate flights to the United States.

Qatar Airways is using Air Italy to get access to gates at U.S. airports, despite agreeing not to pursue this route under its own name. The airline's financial statements show that Qatar Airways covers Air Italy's operating losses, and the airline's executives are former Qatar Airways senior executives. The U.S. carriers are rightly angry about this development, and American advocates on Capitol Hill are urging the Trump administration to take action.

The article concludes that Qatar must be held accountable for its actions, not just for its own mischief but also for the message it sends to other major U.S. trading partners. If Qatar gets away with this, it could embolden other countries to cheat on trade agreements, undermining the integrity of the global trading system.

Title: Correction Officers Fail to Check on Inmates, Including Epstein, on Night of His Death

A recent indictment has revealed that two correction officers, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, failed to perform their duties on the night before Jeffrey Epstein's death. According to the indictment, Epstein's cellmate was transferred out of the cell on August 9, and Epstein was escorted into his cell by Noel and another guard shortly before 8 p.m. By 10 p.m., inmates were locked in their cells for the night.

Surveillance footage showed Noel walking up to the door to the cluster of cells where Epstein was housed around 10:30 p.m., but nobody approached the wing, including Noel and Thomas, over the next few hours. The two were supposed to check on the inmates every half-hour, but instead, they "sat at their desk, browsed the internet, and moved around the common area." They then signed "count sheets" saying they had checked on the inmates multiple times overnight when they had not.

The next morning, when Noel and Thomas entered Epstein's cell, they found him unresponsive with a noose around his neck. When a supervisor arrived, the guards admitted they had not properly performed their duties. Noel stated, "We did not complete the 3 a.m. nor 5 a.m. rounds," while Thomas said, "She's not to blame, we didn't do any rounds."

The director of the Bureau of Prisons, Kathleen Hawk Sawyer, has stated that the agency is taking the allegations of misconduct "very seriously" and will respond to them appropriately.

Title: White House Adviser Discusses President Obama's Upcoming Executive Orders and State of the Union Address

The White House senior adviser, John Podesta, spoke with NPR's Steve Inskeep on Morning Edition, discussing President Obama's plans to use executive orders to advance his agenda. According to Podesta, the President will sign an executive order raising the minimum wage in new federal contracts from $7.25 to $10.10 per hour. This change will only apply to new contracts and not to renewals of existing agreements.

Podesta also mentioned that the President will renew his push for an increase in the federal minimum wage for all workers during the State of the Union address. Additionally, Obama will make the case for a bilateral security agreement with Afghanistan and discuss signs of a recovering economy.

The White House adviser emphasized that the President has the authority to take executive actions on a wide range of topics, including retirement security and climate change, and that the administration will continue to explore this option in the coming year. However, there may be arguments about whether some of these actions usurp congressional powers and are therefore unconstitutional.

The State of the Union address is scheduled to begin shortly after 9 p.m. ET, and NPR will be live blogging and streaming the speech and its coverage.

Title: Putin Says He Convinced Trump Russia Did Not Interfere in US Election

Article: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on Saturday that he believes he convinced President Donald Trump that Russia did not interfere in the 2016 United States presidential election. The topic of election interference was the first item on the agenda when the two leaders met on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany. According to Putin, Trump asked many questions about the subject and Putin answered them to the best of his ability. Putin claimed that Trump took his denials into consideration, but it is unclear whether Trump agrees with him.

The meeting between Trump and Putin was overshadowed by Russian interference in the election and allegations of Trump campaign collusion. Trump has been criticized for expressing doubt about Russian interference, although several U.S. intelligence agencies believe Russia was responsible. Trump stated that he believes Russia was involved, but that other countries or individuals could also have been involved.

The interference included the spread of disinformation during the campaign, with the most prominent example being the hacking into email accounts at the Democratic National Committee and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign officials, exposing embarrassing information. While there is no evidence that the efforts impacted the outcome of the election, Democrats have pointed to Russian interference to delegitimize the Trump presidency.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who attended the meeting, said Trump opened the discussion by pressing Putin about election interference and a "very robust and lengthy exchange" ensued. Tillerson stated that Trump pressed Putin on the topic multiple times, with Putin denying any involvement.

The meeting also touched on other topics, including a Syrian cease-fire agreement, Russia's disputed annexation of Crimea, and the fight against ISIS and radical Islamic terrorism. Putin expressed optimism about the potential for cooperation between the two leaders, stating that he believes their personal relations are established and that they can work together on various issues.

Title: Governors' Decline in Presidential Race Raises Questions About Political Experience

The Iowa caucuses may have left the presidential race in disarray, but one thing is clear: the next president will not be a governor. This is a surprising turn of events, given that just a year ago, many believed that a Republican governor would be the likely nominee. The governors were seen as the GOP's talent pool, with notable candidates like Jeb Bush, Scott Walker, Bobby Jindal, John Kasich, Rick Perry, and Chris Christie. However, they have all but disappeared from the race.

The decline of the governors can be attributed to voters' growing distrust of politicians and their experience. Even the successes of governors like John Kasich, who balanced budgets in the 1990s and for five years as governor, were dismissed. The more Kasich boasted about his accomplishments, the more conservatives concluded that he had been around too long.

The article's author, Stephen Moore, notes that many governors have actually walked the walk, cutting taxes, balancing budgets, and taking on unions and reforming welfare. However, their campaigns were marred by tone-deafness to voter rage and a failure to reintroduce themselves to voters.

The article concludes that the next president will likely be one of the three remaining candidates: Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio. While none of them have governed, the author hopes that the winner will choose a governor as their running mate, citing the talent pool of experienced governors in state capitals.

Title: House Ways and Means Committee Sets April 23 Deadline for IRS to Turn Over Trump's Tax Returns

The House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Rep. Richard Neal, has set a final deadline of April 23 for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to turn over President Trump's tax returns. The deadline was set after the Treasury Department missed an earlier deadline of April 10, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stating that the administration is still studying the legal questions involved.

Mnuchin described the new deadline as "arbitrary" without indicating whether the administration will meet it. If the deadline passes without the documents or a resolution to the dispute, House Democrats and the Trump administration could be headed for a clash in federal court.

The administration had previously missed the April 10 deadline, with Mnuchin stating that he was consulting with the Justice Department about the law and exploring whether Neal had a legitimate legislative purpose for the request. Under the tax code, Neal can request any taxpayer's returns, and the Treasury Department "shall furnish" them.

Neal wrote a letter to IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig, stating that the law clearly entitles him to receive the six years of business and personal returns of Trump that he requested. Neal set a deadline of 5 p.m. on April 23 and said he would interpret a failure to hand over the records by then as a denial of his request. After that, he could issue a subpoena or go straight to a federal court to seek to enforce the law.

The legal question would reach beyond the language of the statute and consider the extent of constitutional constraints on legislative inquiries. Matthew Leas, an IRS spokesman, declined to comment on Neal's letter.

Mnuchin stated that Treasury officials are working "diligently" on working through the legal issues. "This is a decision that has enormous precedence in potentially weaponizing the IRS," he said. "The implications of this is way beyond, in my mind, a congressional oversight issue and a president issue. The issue is, I feel a responsibility that we get this right and the IRS does not become weaponized like it was under the Nixon administration."

Trump broke with four decades of precedent by refusing to release his tax returns. He has said he would release his returns after an audit is complete. Although a public release might complicate his audit, no law prevents Trump from revealing his returns at any time. Under an IRS procedure, presidents are subject to mandatory audits. Neal has taken Trump's argument against a voluntary release and turned it into his rationale for a mandatory handover of the returns, arguing that the committee needs to determine if the IRS is doing those audits properly.

Using the 1924 law that gives the tax-writing committees full access to taxpayers' information, Neal has also requested administrative files relating to any audits of the president or some of his business entities. It would take a subsequent committee vote to publicly release all or part of the returns. The administration has not formally denied Neal's request, though Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, said that Democrats would "never" get the returns.

Title: Stock Market Suffers Worst Slide in Nearly Two Months, Technology Stocks Lead the Way Down

The stock market experienced its worst decline in nearly two months on Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 264.26 points, or 1.5%, to close below 17,000 at 16,945.80. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 32.31 points, or 1.6%, to finish at 1965.99, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 88.47 points, or 1.9%, to 4466.75.

The decline was led by technology stocks, with Apple shares declining 3.8% and finishing the trading session just below $98. The Nasdaq composite, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, suffered the worst losses of the day.

The decline was attributed to growing concerns about the global economy and a backlash against problems consumers are reporting with Apple's latest software updates and product launches, including the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus. The rising volatility on Wall Street is causing concern after the market enjoyed a relatively uneventful period earlier in September. A measure of volatility known as the "fear gauge" jumped 25% on Thursday.

Analysts are worried that the buildup of complacency among investors and the approach of what could be a disappointing third-quarter earnings season could mean more trouble in the weeks ahead. However, the damage is relatively minor, given that the Dow and S&P are both down roughly 2% from their record highs set last week.

Fixed-income investments appeared to benefit from the flight out of stocks, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note falling to 2.51% from 2.57% on Wednesday. In economic news, durable goods orders plunged 18.2% in August, while applications for unemployment benefits rose 12,000 to a seasonally adjusted 293,000. Asian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei index jumping 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index falling 0.6%. European markets were trading lower, with Britain's FTSE 100 dropping 1% and Germany's DAX falling 1.6%.

Title: Republican Strategists and Media Figures Present Contrasting Views on Presidential Election Polls

Article:

A recent article highlights the disparity between Republican political operatives and conservative media figures regarding the current state of the presidential election polls. While private surveys show Mitt Romney trailing behind President Obama, some conservative pundits and media personalities claim that the polls are inaccurate and part of a larger conspiracy to suppress Republican voter turnout.

According to Republican strategists, Romney is trailing in most national polls released in September, with the only question being by how much. However, conservative media figures like Dick Morris and Rush Limbaugh argue that the polls are intentionally biased and designed to depress Republican voters. Morris, a former Clinton advisor turned conservative pundit, claims that if the election were held today, Romney would win by 4-5 points in key swing states like Florida, Ohio, Virginia, Nevada, and Pennsylvania.

Limbaugh, a prominent conservative talk radio host, believes that the media and university polls are designed to suppress Republican voter turnout. He cites specific polls from The Washington Post, CBS News, and Quinnipiac University as examples of this supposed bias.

The divide between Republican consultants and conservative media figures is not new, as the former must focus on winning and losing, while the latter aim to build their audience and email lists. However, the rise of the internet has allowed this alternate reality to flourish, with some websites even reweighting polls to show Romney leading in nearly every national poll released in September. While this approach is unscientific, it has gained traction among some Republicans, including Texas Governor Rick Perry, who tweeted about the website unskewedpolls.com.

The article highlights the stark contrast between the views of Republican strategists and conservative media figures on the current state of the presidential election polls. While some see a clear picture of Romney trailing behind Obama, others believe that the polls are inaccurate and part of a larger conspiracy to suppress Republican voters.

Title: Trump's Attorney Rudy Giuliani Discusses Potential Interview with Special Counsel Mueller

The ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller has been a subject of much debate, with critics arguing that it is a distraction for the White House and detractors saying it has gone on long enough without producing any concrete charges related to the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Russia. The investigation has also led to questions about whether President Trump could pardon himself if necessary, a topic that has divided legal experts.

One of the key figures in the investigation is former FBI Director James Comey, who is expected to come under scrutiny in an upcoming report by the Justice Department inspector general. The draft report reportedly calls Comey's behavior during the Hillary Clinton email probe "insubordinate."

Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, recently sat down for an exclusive interview with Pat Robertson of The 700 Club, where he discussed the possibility of the president sitting down for an interview with the special counsel's team. Giuliani stated that the legal team is leaning against agreeing to testimony, but would consider it if the points to be clarified are limited to five or six.

"If they can convince us that it would be brief, it would be the point, there are five or six points they have to clarify. And with that, we can get this over, this long nightmare for the American public over," Giuliani said.

However, if Mueller subpoenas Trump to testify, Giuliani's team will likely fight it, which could lead to a long legal battle potentially going all the way to the Supreme Court. The outcome of this standoff remains uncertain, as the investigation continues to unfold.

Title: Watergate: A Complex and Well-Documented Scandal that Left a Lasting Impact on American Politics

The Watergate scandal, which unfolded over 900 days, is widely regarded as the mother of all modern political scandals. As former counsel to President Richard Nixon, John Dean was at the center of the scandal, and his latest book, "The Nixon Defense: What He Knew and When He Knew It," provides a unique perspective on the events that led to the scandal.

Dean's article begins by highlighting the complexity of the story, which was difficult to cover for journalists and historians. He notes that the scandal is well-documented, with a wealth of information available, including testimony, autobiographies, diaries, and secret tape recordings.

Dean recounts the events of June 17, 1972, when five burglars were arrested for breaking into the Democratic National Committee headquarters. The investigation led to a cover-up by the Nixon White House, which Dean was a part of. He notes that the break-in was not the only incident, as the same group had previously broken into the office of a psychiatrist treating Daniel Ellsberg, who had leaked the Pentagon Papers.

Dean emphasizes that while he has never found evidence that Nixon knew about or ordered the Watergate break-in, he did know that Nixon had ordered an earlier break-in at the Brookings Institution, which was believed to have a copy of the Pentagon Papers. The secret recordings of Nixon's conversations during those early days after the arrests show his concern that he might have ordered the Watergate break-in.

The article also highlights the fact that the Watergate burglars were not just ordinary burglars, but were part of a larger operation to bug the campaign headquarters of Nixon's Democratic opponent, Senator George McGovern. This mission was traceable directly to the Oval Office, as Nixon wanted a "plant" placed in McGovern's campaign.

Dean notes that Watergate did not end with Nixon's resignation and departure from the White House in August 1974. The scandal continued to play out in headline-grabbing events during the cover-up trial of Nixon's top aides, including H.R. "Bob" Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman, and John N. Mitchell. While these men claimed innocence, the record now shows that each of them quietly admitted to Judge John J. Sirica that they had committed the offenses for which they were found guilty.

Dean concludes by emphasizing the importance of learning from the truth and not trying to recast the story of Watergate. He notes that he has always believed that the truth is the only solution and that he was unwilling to write a bogus report about Watergate that the President wanted him to write.

Title: Russia-Ukraine Tensions Escalate as Russian Military Aircraft Enter Ukrainian Airspace

The United States has condemned Russia's military aircraft entering Ukrainian airspace on several occasions, amid rising tensions in eastern Ukraine. A Pentagon spokesman, Col. Steven Warren, called on Russia to "de-escalate the situation" and take "immediate steps" to do so. The statement came as the G7 group of industrialized countries agreed to impose fresh sanctions on Russia over Ukraine.

Russia has tens of thousands of troops deployed along its border with Ukraine, with pro-Moscow separatists occupying official buildings in a dozen eastern towns, defying the government in Kiev. Russia has accused the West of wanting to "seize" Ukraine, while the US Secretary of Defense, Chuck Hagel, described Russian activity along the Ukrainian border as "dangerously destabilizing" and "very provocative".

Last week, Ukraine and Russia struck an agreement in Geneva calling for separatists to leave official premises and give up their arms, but so far, pro-Russian activists have refused to comply. A joint statement from the G7 said Russia had taken "no concrete actions in support of the Geneva accord".

The G7 has agreed to impose additional sanctions on Russia, with White House sources indicating that they could be in place as early as Monday. It is unclear what form the sanctions will take, but under current US and EU measures, assets freezes and travel bans have targeted several Russian officials.

Meanwhile, armed separatists have seized seven representatives from the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), as well as five Ukrainian army personnel and a bus driver. Pro-Russian leaders in Sloviansk confirmed the bus had been stopped near the town of Sloviansk and said they were checking the identities of those on board.

Title: Trump's Trade Policy: A Delicate Balance Between Protectionism and Global Cooperation

The Trump administration's trade policy has been a topic of much debate, with some warning of a potential trade war with China that could have devastating consequences for the global economy. However, experts argue that the global trade system has deep flaws that are related to China, not Trump. The issue is not just about tariffs and trade wars, but about China's failure to play by the rules and its unfair practices.

China has been welcomed into the global trade system with the expectation that it would play by the rules, but experts say that has not happened. The country has been accused of violating both the letter and spirit of global trade rules, including the World Trade Organization's (WTO) agreements. This has led to concerns about the impact of China's industrial, agricultural, technology, and cyber policies on US jobs and exports.

Some experts argue that a tougher stance towards China is needed, but not necessarily a trade war. Robert Atkinson, an economist who studies the ties between global trade and national economic performance, believes that the US has been too soft on China for too long. He argues that China's sheer size and determination to acquire a leadership role in advanced industries make it a unique challenge.

The US Trade Representative's annual report covering 2016 lists an array of settlements reached with China, including settlements on subsidies, taxes, and other policies in industries such as aircraft, autos, financial information, wind power, and green technologies. This suggests that progress can come when pressure is applied.

However, critics argue that much more needs to change, particularly in areas such as the way foreign companies doing business in China are pressured to transfer knowledge to Chinese partner firms in industries such as aerospace. The World Trade Organization prohibits countries from making such demands, yet the Chinese arrangements are hard to prosecute.

As Trump and Xi met at the Trump-branded Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, there were few early signs of either progress or breakdown. The White House statement said the US president "noted the challenges caused by Chinese government intervention in its economy and raised serious concerns about the impact of China's industrial, agricultural, technology, and cyber policies on United States jobs and exports."

The outcome of Trump's trade policy remains uncertain, with some experts warning of a potential trade war and others urging a tougher stance on China. The key will be how much the Trump administration seeks to build an international coalition to press China, and whether it will prioritize bilateral dealing or seek a broader, rule-of-law system under which all parties can benefit.

Title: Clinton's Narrow Victory in Iowa May Prove Costly for the Democratic Party

The Democratic Party is facing a potentially long and grueling primary season after Hillary Clinton's narrow victory in Iowa, which has left many questioning the legitimacy of her win. The result was a statistical tie, with Clinton and Bernie Sanders each receiving 49.9% of the vote, with Clinton winning by a margin of just six coin tosses. While a crushing defeat would have been worse for Clinton, her narrow victory may ultimately prove costly for the party.

Clinton's supporters are already celebrating her win, but her campaign is facing criticism for its perceived disconnect from the party's young base. The Clinton camp is said to be disappointed with the result and is considering a staff shakeup to improve its organization, messaging, and communications strategy. However, any attempts to tout her victory as a win may come across as ungracious and grasping, further antagonizing Sanders' supporters.

The real loser in this situation is the Democratic Party, which is now stuck with a flawed candidate who may struggle to connect with the party's young base. The party's hopes of avoiding a socialist nominee or a fatally flawed Clinton candidacy have been dashed, and it is unclear how she will be able to win over the activists who are crucial to her success in November.

The window for a Democratic savior, who could have potentially challenged Clinton and Sanders, has slammed shut. The party is now left to navigate a long and potentially grueling primary season with a candidate who may struggle to connect with the party's young base.

Title: US Deploys Additional 2,000 Troops to Mexican Border, Bringing Total to 4,300

The United States is deploying an additional 2,000 troops to its border with Mexico, the Pentagon announced. This move will bring the total number of troops stationed on the southern border to approximately 4,300.
