The soldiers will assist border-patrol agents in carrying out surveillance work and installing miles of razor wire.

The deployment comes as President Donald Trump continues to push for funding to build a wall along the border, which he claims is necessary to stop illegal immigration. The President's insistence on including funds for the wall in the US budget led to the longest government shutdown in US history last year. The current agreement expires on February 15.

The US Defense Department stated that 3,750 extra soldiers will be sent to the border, with many replacing troops already stationed there. The deployment is expected to last 90 days, during which time the troops will provide a mobile surveillance capability and install approximately 150 miles of concertina wire between ports of entry.

President Trump has repeatedly described the situation on the Mexican border as a "crisis," although critics have dismissed the use of troops as a political stunt. The deployment is not the first time US presidents have sent troops to the border with Mexico; Presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush also deployed troops to the area.

In related news, officials in Texas have revealed that nine migrants on hunger strike at an immigration detention center are being force-fed. The detainees have refused food in protest against conditions at the El Paso Processing Center, and relatives have reported severe nosebleeds and vomiting as a result of the use of plastic nasal tubes to feed them. A federal judge authorized the force-feeding last month.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Practices Under Scrutiny: A Review of the State Department's Inspector General Report

The controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State has sparked widespread debate and scrutiny. According to the State Department's Inspector General (IG) report, Clinton disregarded cybersecurity guidelines and failed to preserve federal records, deleting approximately 30,000 emails before an investigation began. The report also found that Clinton did not comply with the Department's policies and the Federal Records Act.

The IG's report highlights Clinton's failure to print and file records with the Office of the Secretary, as required, and her refusal to surrender emails dealing with Department business before leaving office. This lack of compliance has raised concerns about the potential compromise of U.S. secrets and the potential for tampering with sensitive information.

The report also notes that Clinton stonewalled requests by the government for access to her server, which was located in her Chappaqua, N.Y., home, and another discovered in an unsecured location in a Denver bathroom closet. The report does not specify whether any foreign hackers, such as those from China or Russia, may have accessed Clinton's emails.

Clinton has denied any wrongdoing, claiming she only used her private email for personal matters, such as her daughter's wedding and yoga classes. However, the IG's report contradicts this claim, stating that Clinton did not comply with notification requirements when her personal device containing personally identifiable information was compromised.

The report's findings have sparked concerns about the potential consequences of Clinton's actions. While it is unclear whether her actions will lead to an indictment, the FBI is investigating the matter. The report's findings also raise questions about the accountability of high-ranking government officials and their responsibilities for handling records once they leave office.

In conclusion, the controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's email practices highlights the importance of transparency and accountability in government. While Clinton's actions may not be unprecedented, her failure to comply with cybersecurity guidelines and federal regulations has raised concerns about the potential compromise of U.S. secrets and the potential for tampering with sensitive information.

Title: President Obama to Deliver Major Speech on Economic Revival in the Midwest

President Barack Obama will travel to the Midwest this week to deliver a major speech on economic revival, focusing on his domestic agenda and promoting his vision for rebuilding the economy. The speech will take place at Knox College in Illinois, where the President will outline economic steps he will take on his own, steps Congress should take, and actions private industry can accomplish to bolster the economy.

According to White House senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer, the President's speech will "lay out his vision for rebuilding an economy that puts the middle class and those fighting to join it front and center." The speech is also seen as an attempt by the President to regain control of his second term, which has been sidetracked by scandals and controversies.

The President will visit Galesburg, Illinois, and Warrensburg, Missouri, to promote his domestic agenda, which includes spending on infrastructure and universal preschool programs, as well as highlighting the economic benefits of comprehensive immigration reform.

The speech comes as Detroit, Michigan, faces financial struggles, with the city filing for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection last week. The city's financial woes have been a topic of discussion, with some calling for a federal bailout. However, the White House has stated that it is not planning to provide financial aid to the city, instead leaving it up to local leaders and creditors to resolve the issue.

The President's speech is expected to set the terms of the debate for looming battles with Congress over the budget and debt limit, and to outline his vision for rebuilding the economy.

Title: Moderate House Republicans Begin to Budge on Government Shutdown

Article:

A growing number of moderate House Republicans, representing districts that are likely to be vulnerable in the 2014 elections, are starting to distance themselves from the government shutdown and calling for the party to compromise and move on from its fight over defunding Obamacare. Virginia Representative Scott Rigell, Pennsylvania Representative Pat Meehan, and New Jersey Representative Jon Runyan are among those who have expressed their desire to pass a clean continuing resolution (CR) to reopen the government.

Rigell, Meehan, and Runyan's districts were narrowly won by President Barack Obama in the 2012 elections, making them more susceptible to public opinion and potentially more open to compromise. The lawmakers are concerned that the government shutdown is damaging the economy and harming the military, and are urging their colleagues to put aside their differences and find a solution.

Other endangered Republicans, such as New York Representative Peter King and Pennsylvania Representative Charlie Dent, have also been vocal in their criticism of the House GOP's stance. New Jersey Representative Frank LoBiondo, who represents an Atlantic City-area seat that Obama won by eight percentage points, has expressed his discontent with the House GOP's approach, stating that he wants to see a result and is not willing to continue with a strategy that is not yielding progress.

Illinois Representative Rodney Davis, a freshman incumbent who represents a district nearly evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans, has stopped short of calling for his party to abandon its fight, but has emphasized the need for an agreement. Davis, who previously voted in favor of budget resolutions that would defund the health care law, is facing criticism from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) for his role in the shutdown.

The DCCC has launched an automated call campaign targeting Davis and 60 other Republicans, accusing them of shutting down the government and prioritizing insurance company profits over constituents' benefits. The committee has also labeled Davis as a member of the "Too Little, Too Late Caucus."

Title: The American Health Care Act: A Step Towards Affordable Healthcare

The American Health Care Act, the first iteration of the Republican plan to replace and repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), has been met with criticism from conservatives and libertarians. Investor's Business Daily editors argue that the bill supports all the key elements of Obamacare, citing its repeal of the individual mandate, employer mandate, and hidden taxes, as well as its expansion of Health Savings Accounts (HSAs). However, this viewpoint is unrealistic about what the Republicans can accomplish, given their narrow margin in the Senate.

In reality, the public does not want a free market healthcare system, but rather affordable and accessible care. Free market purists believe that unfettered competition and open markets are the best way to achieve this goal, but this would require the government to stay completely out of healthcare. Medicare, Medicaid, and other government healthcare programs would need to be repealed, which is unlikely.

The American Health Care Act addresses several issues that the public dislikes about Obamacare. It repeals the unconstitutional individual mandate, effective after December 31, 2015, eliminating penalties, fines, and taxes for those who failed to buy coverage. The bill also repeals the job-killing employer mandate, allowing employers to hire new workers without being forced to provide health insurance coverage.

The plan eliminates the vast majority of stealth taxes imposed by Obamacare, including the tax on over-the-counter medications, the cap on contributions to Flexible Spending Accounts (FSAs), and the high medical bill tax. It also reduces the tax on early withdrawals from Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) and eliminates the medical device tax.

Conservatives and libertarians are critical of the bill's 30% premium surcharge for patients who wait until they are ill to buy coverage, but this is an incentive based on individual choices, not a mandate. The bill also defunds Planned Parenthood and reforms Medicaid, which are benefits that conservatives have long been clamoring for.

While the American Health Care Act is not perfect, it is a step towards affordable healthcare. If conservatives hold out for full repeal and cling to the fantasy of a free market replacement plan, there is a real danger that Obamacare will never be repealed.

**French Authorities Investigate Charlie Hebdo Attack, AQAP Claims Responsibility**

French authorities are working to piece together the events surrounding the January 7th attack on the Charlie Hebdo satirical magazine, which left 12 people dead. Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) has claimed responsibility for the attack, citing U.S.-born cleric Anwar al-Awlaki as the mastermind behind it.

In a video released on Wednesday, AQAP leader Nasr Ibn Ali al-Ansi praised the attack, saying it was revenge for Charlie Hebdo's depictions of the Prophet Mohammed. Al-Ansi also blamed France and the United States for their perceived crimes against Muslims.

The video shows pictures of the Kouachi brothers, who authorities say were behind the Charlie Hebdo attack, in the background. Al-Ansi claimed that Cherif Kouachi received $20,000 from AQAP to carry out the attack.

French security services have identified a suspected accomplice in the kosher grocery store attack, which occurred on the same day as the Charlie Hebdo attack. The suspected accomplice, a man from a Paris suburb, may have driven gunman Amedy Coulibaly to the kosher supermarket, where he shot and killed four people.

The new edition of Charlie Hebdo, featuring a cartoon of the Prophet Mohammed crying, has sold out quickly, with more copies expected to be released soon. The magazine's editor, Charb, said the attack was a "cowardly act" and that the magazine will continue to publish despite the threats.

French authorities have deployed 10,000 troops across the country and are investigating dozens of cases against people accused of expressing support for terrorism since the attacks. The Justice Ministry has opened 54 cases, including investigations into phone threats, cyberattacks, and Facebook posts.

The attacks have also led to increased security measures, with thousands of police officers on patrol and hundreds assigned to protect Jewish schools.

Title: Political Campaigns Resort to More Personalized Emails to Connect with Voters

In an effort to connect with potential donors and voters, political campaigns are adopting a more personalized approach to fundraising emails. Gone are the days of generic subject lines and bland messages. Instead, campaigns are using emails that resemble pleas from a friend or family member to make a personal connection with recipients.

The Arizona Democratic gubernatorial campaign, led by Fred DuVal, is one example of this trend. Their emails aim to be as personal as possible, according to Bill Scheel, a member of the campaign team. "We want to be as personal as possible," Scheel told FoxNews.com. "It's all part of a tremendous science that is now very important to campaigns."

However, not all campaigns are taking a similar approach. The Conservative Campaign Committee, for instance, sent an email with the subject line "Would You Like Us to Leave You Alone?" which began with a compelling story of a long-time conservative woman who is tired of receiving emails. The message eventually tacked on a standard fundraising pitch, asking recipients to contribute any amount.

Scheel acknowledges that some emails may be seen as desperate or manipulative, but the DuVal campaign draws the line at sending "doom and gloom" emails, which can be seen as negative and off-putting. "We're sending positive, upbeat messages," Scheel said. "That's what our campaign is all about."

Former Bush campaign and White House aide Taylor Griffin, a strategist-turned-first-time candidate, believes that technology has been a game-changer in voter contact. "The more you can personalize and segment different voters, the more you can communicate with them about specific issues," Griffin said.

Campaigns often hire firms that specialize in voter contact, which includes phone canvassing, culling voter rolls, and acquiring membership lists. They can also use social media platforms like Facebook to craft narrowly focused messages to potential voters. Candidates can place specific ads on the Facebook homepage of specific voters based on their internet profiles, essentially an online history that includes where they shop and which websites they have visited.

While some may see these tactics as invasive or manipulative, campaigns argue that they are effective ways to connect with voters on issues. As Scheel pointed out, allowing recipients to unsubscribe from emails is an important consideration, as too many unopened or rejected emails can create problems for campaigns with internet watchdogs.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Admit GOP Health Care Bill is Likely "Dead"

Article:

Two Republican lawmakers, Senators John McCain and Bill Cassidy, have acknowledged that the initial GOP bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is likely "dead". Senator McCain stated in a televised interview on CBS that the bill may be "probably going to be dead" and that it may be time for Republicans to come up with a new proposal with support from Democrats. Senator Cassidy expressed similar sentiments, saying that the draft plan is "clearly dead" and that it is unclear what the new plan will be.

Senator Chuck Grassley, another Republican senator, expressed pessimism about the bill's chances, stating that Republicans will lose their Senate majority if they don't pass health care legislation. He also tweeted that the party should be "ashamed" that it has not been able to repeal and replace the ACA.

President Trump used Twitter to urge Republicans to follow through on their pledge to get rid of the health care law pushed by his predecessor. At least 10 GOP senators have expressed opposition to the initial bill drafted by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and Republicans hold a 52-48 majority, meaning that just three GOP defections will doom the bill.

The weeklong July 4 recess only raised more doubts among senators as many heard from constituents angry about the GOP bill and the prospect of rising premiums. McConnell has said he will introduce a fresh bill in about a week, but acknowledged that if the broader effort fails, he may turn to a smaller bill with quick help for insurers and consumers and negotiate with Democrats.

Senator Ted Cruz's plan, which aims to lower premiums for healthy people, has drawn support from the White House and some conservatives in the House, but has limited appeal to Republican moderates like Grassley, who criticized the plan as "subterfuge to get around pre-existing conditions". Cruz dismissed Grassley's criticism as a "hoax" being pushed by Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, insisting that people will be able to get the coverage they need at an affordable price.

Title: "Random House to Publish Controversial Book on Fox News and Roger Ailes"

Article:

Random House and author Gabriel Sherman are preparing for the release of "The Loudest Voice in the Room" on January 21, a book that promises to offer a new perspective on Fox News. The publisher and Sherman are already anticipating a backlash, as a new website has been launched to promote the book and provide a platform for pushback against misinformation.

The book is based on over 600 interviews with people who have known Roger Ailes, including hundreds of Fox News insiders. The website features caricatures of key figures in Ailes' world, including Rupert Murdoch and Ailes' "guard dog," Champ.

The release of the book coincides with a piece by USA Today's Michael Wolff, which examines Fox News' 2013 ratings triumphs. Fox News' audience outpaced both MSNBC and CNN combined last year.

The book has been in the works for over two years, with Sherman not interviewing Ailes himself. Ailes gave unprecedented access to Zev Chafets for a biography. In August, Sherman speculated that Ailes was "more isolated than ever before" after Brian Lewis, a senior adviser to Ailes, was fired, an assertion Fox News executives quickly disputed.

Title: Iowa's Democratic Electorate May Not Be Ready to Back Hillary Clinton Again

Article:

Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential ambitions were derailed in Iowa, where voters opted for Barack Obama and John Edwards over the former first lady. This time around, Clinton faces a similar predicament. Iowa's Democratic electorate is currently behind non-establishment candidates, and the caucus system rewards enthusiasm and organization over raw support. While an upset is unlikely, the ingredients for a political surprise are present.

According to a report in the Wall Street Journal, more than half of Iowa's 99 county Democratic chairs are reluctant to back Clinton, citing concerns about her ability to win a general election and her fundraising ties to Wall Street firms and corporations. County officials also expressed admiration for senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who they believe could be more effective candidates.

Iowa's Democratic electorate mirrors its Republican counterpart, with a sizable number of voters willing to back non-establishment candidates. In 2012, Mitt Romney came close to winning the Iowa caucuses, but ultimately lost to Rick Santorum. This trend could repeat itself in the Democratic primary, with Clinton facing a narrow loss or even defeat.

While a loss in Iowa would be a significant blow to Clinton's campaign, it's unlikely to happen. The Clinton machine has been able to fend off top-tier challengers so far. However, the discontent with Clinton is palpable, and her support in the polls could be an artificial result of standing alone on the presidential stage.

Democrats who want to see Clinton challenged in a primary are laying the groundwork to blame her for a 2016 defeat if a challenge does not materialize. Local Democrats note that the energy, donations, and political infrastructure acquired during a contested primary become critical tools to use in the general election. Without those, the Democratic nominee may be at a disadvantage.

The question remains whether Clinton will be willing to consider a challenge, given the memories of her 2008 defeat in Iowa. Anti-Clinton forces seem resigned, while those who are prepared to accept her coronation are preparing to consign the name Clinton to history's dishonorable scrap piles should she lose. It would be a bitter irony that the name Clinton, once associated with reviving the Democratic brand, might soon become synonymous with its destruction.

Title: Churches Face Financial Crisis as Donations Dry Up Amid Pandemic

The traditional Holy Week is set to begin tomorrow, with many churches across the country either voluntarily or by government decree closing their doors. While this debate will be had once the crisis passes, churches are currently facing a financial crisis due to the disappearance of Sunday gift collection plates, which are a crucial source of income for many. The Archdiocese of Newark has set up an online GoFundMe donation page, where individuals can contribute to specific parishes or the "Parishes in Need Fund."

The Archdiocese of Newark stated that parishes are facing increased financial shortfalls due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its effects on daily life. Priests and clergy rely on donations to fund important charity work, including providing food to hungry families, paying monthly rent for others, and other essential services.

Bishop Robert Casey of the Archdiocese of Chicago emphasized that Holy Week is a critical fundraising period for churches, as it brings together a large number of people and allows them to continue their mission and ministries. Father Paul Vigil of St. Timothy's Catholic Church in Los Angeles echoed this concern, stating that the last thing they want to do is lay off employees or furlough them, especially during this time.

The Archdiocese of Los Angeles is encouraging parishes and schools to avoid layoffs and is calling on parishioners to support extending unemployment benefits to church workers, who in many states do not have access to state unemployment insurance. With money tight all around, asking parishioners to dig deep in tough economic times has always been challenging. However, churches have survived depressions, wars, and now, a pandemic, and the historic goodness and generosity of the American people will see them through.

Title: The United States' Targeted Killing Policy: A Long-Running Pattern of State-Sponsored Violence

The recent assassination of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani by the United States has sparked controversy and debate about the morality and legality of targeted killings. The incident has also shed light on the long-standing practice of the US government using targeted killings as a tool of state-sponsored violence.

The US has an assassination ban in place, established in the 1970s following revelations of CIA attempts to kill foreign leaders. However, over the past two decades, both Republican and Democratic presidents have worked to skirt the ban by issuing secret legal opinions that justify targeted killings.

The practice began under the Clinton administration, which launched cruise missile strikes against Al Qaeda targets in Afghanistan in 1998. The primary target was Osama bin Laden, but the White House claimed the strikes were aimed at the "command and control infrastructure" of Al Qaeda, rather than the leader himself. This euphemism-laden language provided legal cover for the president and his advisors.

After 9/11, the Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) was passed, providing legal authorization for counterterrorism strikes. The AUMF has been used by both the Bush and Obama administrations to justify targeted killings, which have claimed countless innocent lives and destabilized nations.

The US has targeted suspected terrorists, but the recent assassination of Qassim Suleimani marks a clear departure from this practice. Suleimani was the head of the Quds Force, the elite external operations arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, and was responsible for Iran's ground campaign against ISIS in Iraq. He was not a "non-state actor," but rather a high-ranking official of a foreign government.

The US has taken credit for the defeat of ISIS in Iraq, but has not acknowledged the role of Suleimani's paramilitary actions and strategic acumen in achieving this victory. The incident highlights the need for a re-examination of the US' targeted killing policy and its implications for international relations and global security.

Title: Trump's Policy Positions Blur Party Lines, Leaving Republicans and Democrats Alike Perplexed

Article:

Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, is facing a challenge as he tries to charm Republicans still skeptical of his candidacy. His policy positions on several key issues have raised eyebrows, as he sounds an awful lot like a Democrat. In some cases, he even finds himself running to the left of his likely Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton.

Trump's stance on trade is one area where he diverges from traditional Republican orthodoxy. While the party's 2012 platform emphasized the importance of free trade, Trump has criticized existing deals, saying they are bad for American workers. He has also opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Asia-Pacific pact, positions shared by Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders.

On Social Security, Trump has taken a stance that puts him in line with Clinton. He has said he has no plans to scale back benefits or raise the retirement age, a position that differs from that of House Speaker Paul Ryan, a top-ranked elected Republican. Trump has argued that his stance aligns with the wishes of most voters.

Trump's tax plan, released last fall, called for lowering the rate paid by the wealthiest individuals and slashing the corporate tax rate. However, outside experts concluded that the plan would disproportionately benefit the rich and balloon the federal deficit. Trump has since said his plan was just a starting point and is open to negotiating a deal that benefits the middle class more.

On the minimum wage, Trump has said wages are too high and does not support a federal minimum wage. However, he has also acknowledged the difficulty of surviving on the current minimum wage of $7.25 an hour and is open to doing something about it.

In foreign policy, Trump has taken a stance that leans more towards isolationism, which is at odds with Clinton's approach of using "smart power" to expand American influence. Trump has criticized the military alliance NATO, questioning the structure that sees the U.S. pay for most of its costs.

Trump's policy positions have left both Republicans and Democrats perplexed, making it difficult to define him as a traditional Republican or Democrat. His willingness to adapt and negotiate his plans has also raised questions about his commitment to his own proposals.

Title: St. Louis Couple Who Confronted Protesters with Firearms Turns Over Rifle to Police

The St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department executed a search warrant at the home of Mark and Patricia McCloskey on Friday, as part of an ongoing investigation into an incident where the couple was seen brandishing firearms at protesters outside their Central West End home. The couple, who went viral after the June 28 incident, turned over a Colt, semi-automatic,.223 caliber rifle to authorities, while a handgun was turned over to their previous lawyer.

According to the police statement, detectives executed the search warrant at the McCloskey's home, seizing the rifle as evidence. The couple's attorney, Joel Schwartz, stated that the home was not searched by police and that the rifle was voluntarily given up. The handgun was turned over to the previous lawyer, Albert Watkins.

Schwartz maintained that the McCloskeys are "law-abiding citizens" who were "well within their rights" to defend themselves. He also stated that the couple regrets their actions but did not break any laws. The St. Louis Circuit Attorney's Office said the matter remains under investigation.

The incident occurred during a protest against police brutality and recent actions by the city's mayor, Lyda Krewson. Demonstrators were in the neighborhood to protest against police brutality and the mayor's decision to release the names and addresses of activists who want to defund the police. Krewson has since apologized.

Witness Daniel Shular, a freelance photojournalist, recalled seeing people walk through an open gate and not seeing anyone break the gate leading to the neighborhood. He stated that he saw at least one armed protester, but it's "not super out of the ordinary for the protests here."

Title: Univision's Coverage of Trump's Mount Rushmore Speech Raises Questions about Biased Reporting

Article:

Univision, a Spanish-language television network, has been accused of presenting a biased and incomplete report on President Donald Trump's Independence Day speech at Mount Rushmore. The network's coverage has been criticized for its selective editing and omission of key points from the president's address.

According to the report, Univision's coverage of the event framed the event as a "campaign rally" and only included a brief clip of Trump's statement "This monument will never be desecrated." The network failed to include the rest of the speech, which mentioned Washington, Lincoln, Roosevelt, and Jefferson, as well as Trump's denunciations of the radical left's attempts to erase history.

The report also highlighted Senator Tammy Duckworth's (D-IL) reaction to the speech, dismissing Trump as spending all his time "talking about dead traitors." However, it is unclear if Duckworth was aware of the full context of Trump's speech, as Univision's report only presented a limited view.

Furthermore, Univision's reaction to Tucker Carlson's criticism of Duckworth's willingness to have a "conversation" on the erasure of George Washington was also criticized for its lack of context. The report failed to mention the broader movement to erase American history and the violent mobs that have attempted to vandalize statues of George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and Frederick Douglass.

The article raises questions about Univision's reporting practices and its potential bias in presenting a one-sided view of the event.

Title: Investors Flock to Companies with Strong Environmental, Social, and Governance Practices Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about a significant shift in the way people behave, with many adopting codes of conduct that prioritize the well-being of others. Similarly, the business world is witnessing a trend towards companies adopting environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, which prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profits. This shift is not only driven by a sense of social responsibility but also by the financial benefits that come with it.

Research by Bloomberg Intelligence and RBC Capital Markets has shown that investors who invested in companies with strong ESG practices are faring better than other broad indexes so far this year. The trend is also reflected in the growing popularity of ESG mutual funds, according to Bank of America.

The pandemic has accelerated the adoption of ESG practices, with companies taking steps to prioritize their employees, customers, and communities. Many are choosing to furlough workers instead of laying them off, donating equipment or resources to their communities, and suspending dividends or executive bonuses. This shift towards corporate social responsibility is not only a moral imperative but also a sound business strategy.

As the global economy recovers from the pandemic, investors are looking to corporations to help build collective resilience. According to Barclays, the use of ESG by investors may accelerate in the post-COVID-19 world, as investors recognize the importance of preparing for potential future economic shocks, such as climate change. The crisis has highlighted the importance of ethical values in companies, and many investors are now prioritizing companies that prioritize their social and environmental impact over bottom-line profits.

In conclusion, the COVID-19 pandemic has brought about a significant shift in the way people and businesses behave, with a growing emphasis on social responsibility and long-term sustainability. As the global economy recovers, investors are recognizing the financial benefits of prioritizing ESG practices, and the trend is likely to continue in the post-pandemic world.

Title: White House Deputy Director Highlights Economic Gains for Non-College Graduates and Blue-Collar Workers under Trump Administration

The White House Deputy Director of Communications, Adam Kennedy, recently discussed the Trump administration's economic policies and their impact on various segments of the population. In an interview on SiriusXM's "Sunday with Matt Boyle," Kennedy emphasized that Americans without college degrees and those with blue-collar backgrounds have seen significant gains under the current administration.

According to Kennedy, the president has prioritized the economy and American families since taking office. The passage of the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement (USMCA) is seen as a key factor in this growth, as it puts in place tougher labor standards for manufacturing, encouraging factories to stay in the United States rather than moving to Mexico.

Kennedy noted that blue-collar workers have received the largest economic benefits across Trump's presidential tenure, with non-supervisory positions in manufacturing experiencing the highest wage gains. The deputy director attributed this growth to the administration's focus on putting the economy and American people first.

The White House official also touched on the ongoing impeachment inquiry, stating that Republicans are unified in their opposition to the Democrats' push against the president. Kennedy believes that a bipartisan vote against convicting the president is more likely than a partisan vote, citing the Republicans' unity and the Democrats' division on the issue.

The interview on "Sunday with Matt Boyle" aired on SiriusXM Patriot 125 from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Eastern (4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Pacific).

Title: Tacoma, Washington, May Levy High Taxes on Gun Sales to Fund Violence Prevention Programs

Tacoma, Washington, could become one of a handful of U.S. cities to impose high taxes on gun sales, opening a new front in the ongoing debate over local governments' authority to regulate firearms. The proposed tax, which would collect $25 per gun sale to fund violence prevention programs, is modeled on a law in neighboring Seattle that has already been deemed constitutional by the state supreme court.

The proposed tax would also collect taxes on ammunition, a move that has sparked opposition from gun shop owners and advocates. Dan Davies, who owns Mary's Pistols in Tacoma, claims the tax would force his business out of the city, saying, "It'll put us out of business; there's no ifs, ands, or buts about it."

The National Shooting Sports Foundation, the firearms-industry trade association, is also fighting against the tax, citing concerns that other cities could follow Tacoma's lead. Lawrence Keane, senior vice president of government relations and public affairs, stated, "Are we concerned that politicians will try to seek their antigun agenda through taxation? Yes, that's what this is about."

Aero Precision, a gun parts maker that employs around 400 people in Tacoma, has also expressed opposition to the tax, stating it would be forced to explore its options if the city council votes the tax into place. Sergey Solyanik, who owns Precise Shooter, a gun store in neighboring Lynnwood, moved his business from Seattle due to the tax, saying, "It's not really possible to run a store with this tax."

Proponents of the tax, including Tacoma City Councilman Ryan Mello, argue that it would bring in between $30,000 and $40,000 each year to fund violence prevention programs, making buying a gun less appealing. Mello stated, "I can't ban assault rifles in the city of Tacoma. I can't ban certain types of ammo in the city of Tacoma. I can't require safe storage. There's a lot I can't do, but the one thing I am not pre-empted from doing is reasonable taxation on firearms and ammunition."

Many states have passed so-called gun pre-emption laws, limiting local governments' authority to regulate guns. Cities across the country have tried to buck these prohibitions with limited success. Pittsburgh earlier this year passed restrictions on semiautomatic rifles, but the law was immediately met with a lawsuit filed with the backing of the NRA and has since been put on hold.

Title: Republicans Mostly Silent on Trump's Ukraine Revelations

Article:

In the wake of the release of a rough transcript of a call between President Trump and Ukraine's president, in which Trump urged the latter to investigate the Bidens, Republican lawmakers have been largely silent on the matter. According to a report, not a single Republican senator has appeared on MSNBC since the transcript's release, and only four Republican House members have appeared on the network. On CNN, seven Republican House members have appeared, but no senators have done so.

CNN anchor Jim Sciutto noted that more than 60 Republican members of the House and Senate did not respond when asked whether Trump's actions were appropriate. One Republican senator, Ron Johnson, appeared on NBC's "Meet the Press" and was met with criticism from host Chuck Todd for deflecting questions about Ukraine to discuss emails from former FBI agent Peter Strzok.

Todd's aggressive handling of the interview drew praise from media critics, with New York University journalism professor Jay Rosen tweeting that Todd's tone was "different" and his patience with denial had "run out." Washington Post media columnist Margaret Sullivan wrote that the tense exchange was "the right thing for Todd to do."

Other Republican lawmakers have also dodged questions about Trump's conduct, with some suggesting that his actions were joking or that the news cycle moves on quickly. However, impeachment is not going away, and Republicans' silence has become a story in itself. The news cycle has been dominated by revelations, including explosive text messages among diplomats and Trump's call on the White House lawn for China to investigate the Bidens.

Some Republicans may fear speaking out against Trump, as he has targeted those who do so, such as Utah Sen. Mitt Romney. Texas Rep. Will Hurd, who has announced he is not running for reelection, has been one of the few Republicans to speak out, calling exchanges between U.S. diplomats over efforts for Ukraine to investigate the Bidens "damning."

A few Republican senators have appeared on Fox News, including Ted Cruz, Rick Scott, Rob Portman, and Lindsey Graham, who expressed criticism of Trump's decision to pull troops out of Syria. Some lawmakers have criticized the Syria decision while also blasting the NBA for apologizing to China after the general manager of the Houston Rockets expressed support for pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

Title: President Obama Participates in Reddit's "Ask Me Anything" Session

President Barack Obama took to Reddit, a popular social media and forum site, to participate in an "Ask Me Anything" (AMA) session on August 15. The event, which started at around 4:00 p.m. ET, allowed users to ask questions and receive answers from the President. The session was confirmed by the Obama campaign with a photo of the President at his computer and a tweet.

During the hour-long session, Obama fielded questions on various topics, including internet freedom, the space program, the most difficult decision of his first term, and even the White House beer, which he described as "tasty." The President's answers were posted on Reddit, and the site experienced a surge in activity, with hundreds of comments and questions being posted within a short period.

Reddit's founder, Alexis Ohanian, noted that the President's participation in the AMA was a significant milestone for the site, which was started by Ohanian and Steve Huffman in Charlottesville, Virginia, seven years ago. The event was also part of Reddit's "Internet 2012" bus tour, which aims to engage Americans in discussions about internet usage and legislation.

The President's closing comment on the Reddit experience was "NOT BAD!" The event marked a unique moment in the intersection of politics and social media, allowing the President to connect directly with the public and share his thoughts on various topics.

Title: FOX Business Network to Host GOP Debate on January 14, Featuring Seven Presidential Hopefuls

Article:

The FOX Business Network will host the sixth GOP debate on January 14, starting at 6 P.M. ET, featuring seven presidential hopefuls. The debate will take place at the North Charleston Coliseum and Performing Arts Center, less than 10 miles from the Emanuel AME church, the site of the June 2015 mass shooting. Gun control is expected to be a topic of discussion, following President Obama's mention of it in his State of the Union Address and South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley's reference to the incident in her Republican response.

The debate will provide an opportunity for the candidates to address the global economy, given Charleston's maritime commerce and the presence of BMW and Volvo's auto manufacturing facilities. The city's history and cultural significance will also be highlighted, with references to the Civil War and the city's role in the global economy.

The article highlights six potential storylines to watch during the debate:

1. The candidates' reactions to President Obama's State of the Union Address, including his omission of the situation on Farsi island, his emphasis on guns and domestic terrorism, and his use of the term "Muslim" in conjunction with hate crimes.
2. The controversy surrounding Ted Cruz's Canadian birth and the potential for other candidates to intervene or let Trump and Cruz "slug it out."
3. The candidates' approaches to the local electorate in South Carolina, which is considered the most conservative of the four February primary stops.
4. John Ellis "Jeb" Bush's struggles in South Carolina, which has historically been a crucial state for his family's presidential campaigns.
5. Donald Trump's potential to be the "wild card" in the debate, with his ability to attack Ted Cruz or go easy on him and focus on his favorite target, the Clintons.
6. Marco Rubio's potential to be the "old-fashioned" candidate, with his sudden shift towards more traditional Republican views and his ability to market and sell his message.

The article concludes by noting that the debate will be broadcast live at 9 P.M. ET and will provide an opportunity for the candidates to showcase their views and policies to the American public.

Title: Cuts in Military Spending Pose Problem for Lawmakers on the Campaign Trail

The looming $1.2 trillion automatic spending cuts, set to take effect early next year, are not only a pressing policy issue but also a potential political liability for lawmakers from defense-heavy districts. The cuts, which include reductions to the Pentagon's budget, could trigger an election loss for some lawmakers.

The sequester, as it is known, has already been warned to have the potential to trigger another recession. However, it may also have a significant impact on jobs, with one study suggesting that deep defense cuts could cost 1 million jobs nationwide, with heavy hits in California, Virginia, and Florida.

Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle are taking different approaches to address the issue. Republicans are pushing to spare the Pentagon from the cuts, while Democrats are insisting that new tax revenues must be part of any deal to roll back military cuts. This has led to some lawmakers being targeted by their opponents for their stance.

In the toss-up race between Democratic Rep. Mark Critz and Republican Keith Rothfus in Pennsylvania's 12th Congressional District, Rothfus has criticized Critz for rejecting GOP proposals to shield the Pentagon cuts. However, the Democrats also have a major problem with the package of cuts, which hits domestic safety net programs.

The looming sequester has left Democrats stuck between honoring last year's debt limit deal, which put the defense cuts trigger into law, and protecting jobs in their home district. The projected military cuts have made for easy targeting by Republican operatives, who are trying to paint some Democrats as being ready to kill stable defense-oriented jobs.

The National Republican Congressional Committee has slammed Democratic lawmakers like Reps. Larry Kissell of North Carolina, Bill Owens of New York, and John Barrow of Georgia for rejecting plans to save cuts from hitting Forts Bragg, Drum, and Gordon. "These Democrats are already on record opposing common-sense reforms that would avoid these devastating cuts to local jobs and America's military," said Paul Lindsay, an NRCC spokesman.

Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.) agrees with Republicans on at least this point: that these cuts would be cataclysmic.

Title: FDA Approves New Ebola Diagnostic Kit as Survival Rate in Hard-Hit Area Climbs to 70%

The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency approval for a new diagnostic kit to test blood for the Ebola virus, even as doctors report a significant increase in survival rates in one hard-hit area. The FDA's decision marks the seventh emergency authorization since October, following the federal government's declaration that the ongoing health crisis warrants the use of unapproved diagnostic methods.

The new diagnostic kit is part of an effort to be more proactive in the handling of the disease, rather than simply responding to outbreaks. The FDA's decision was based on a 2006 determination by then-Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff that the Ebola virus presents a material threat against the United States population sufficient to affect national security.

The United States has seen four confirmed cases of Ebola so far, with three health care workers and one man, Thomas Eric Duncan, who died in Texas after contracting the virus in Liberia. Liberia's U.N. peacekeeping mission has reported its fourth Ebola case, with the infected worker being transferred to an Ebola treatment unit.

In a positive development, doctors are reporting signs of improvement in the fight against Ebola, with a survival rate of about 70% in Sierra Leone. According to a letter published in the New England Journal of Medicine, about 70% of Ebola patients are surviving the virus, despite the absence of a vaccine. The letter describes 581 cases treated at an Ebola treatment center in Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, in late September, with a mortality rate of less than 24% among patients admitted since November 5.

The spread of the outbreak has slowed significantly, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), which had predicted a worst-case scenario of as many as 1.4 million cases by mid-January. However, the agency has since revised its estimate, citing real momentum and progress in the fight against the disease.

Title: House Conservatives Express Dissatisfaction with Boehner's Government Funding Plan

Article:

A group of House conservatives, led by Representative Steve King, will meet on Wednesday to discuss the lame duck legislation and express their dissatisfaction with the plan outlined by Speaker John Boehner. The plan, which would keep the government funded through September with a review of the Department of Homeland Security's funding in March, has been met with criticism from hard-line Republicans.

Representatives John Fleming and Mark Meadows have expressed concerns about the plan, with Fleming stating that it may not pass and Meadows leaning towards voting "no" due to the lack of limitation language. Senator Jeff Sessions, Senator David Vitter, and Senator Mike Lee have also criticized the plan, arguing that the House should block funding for the implementation of President Obama's immigration action.

Senator Lee has outlined a detailed roadmap to taking on the executive action, advocating for a short-term continuing resolution that blocks funding for the executive action. Senator Sessions has expressed concerns that the plan is not effective and that Congress has an institutional duty to reject the executive action.

The House conservatives are converging around the idea of a shorter-term CR that strictly limits funds to the Department of Homeland Security, which is tasked with implementing Obama's immigration executive actions. Representative Jim Jordan has stated that the "cavalry is coming" and that he prefers to deal with the larger funding issues next year.

The article does not provide information on the exact number of Republican "no" votes needed to derail the vote, but estimates suggest it could be near 30 to 40. The article also notes that Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has given a tepid endorsement of the House leadership's plan, calling it "unfortunate" that DHS money will not be included in the omnibus.

Title: Election 2018: Expectations Remain Stable, but Turnout Shifts Could Determine Outcome

The upcoming Election Day is approaching, and expectations remain largely unchanged from the past six months. In the Senate, Republicans are favored to gain seats, while in the House, Democrats are expected to win control, but with a potentially modest "blue wave." These general expectations are shaped by geography and history, with Republicans expected to perform well in traditionally GOP-leaning states and Democrats expected to do well in midterm elections.

Despite this stability, there is a wide range of possible outcomes due to the closeness of many races. Six highly competitive Senate races are currently considered toss-ups, with five of them leaning towards the Republicans and Montana tilting towards the Democrats. Scott Rasmussen.com has conducted research for the Auto Alliance and the National Retail Federation, examining three different turnout models for each of these races. The results show that small shifts in turnout could have significant implications.

If Republican turnout is higher than expected, the GOP could win all six competitive Senate races, resulting in a 56-44 majority. Conversely, if Democratic turnout is higher than expected, the outcome could be a 50-50 Senate. The practical implications of these small shifts are enormous.

The same dynamic applies to the House of Representatives, where Democrats need to pick up 23 seats to win control. Scott Rasmussen.com currently projects that Democrats are poised to pick up 12 seats, with 33 seats too close to call. The odds favor a Democratic majority, but it's not a sure thing.

The Generic Congressional Ballot polling shows Democrats with a 7-point advantage, which would likely result in them winning most of the 33 competitive races. However, a shift of just a couple of points could have a significant impact. If Republicans can boost turnout and pull within 5 points in the nationwide popular vote, they might be able to win enough close races to keep their majority. Conversely, if things shift in the opposite direction, Democrats might enjoy a big night and gain around 45 seats.

Ultimately, the outcome of Election 2018 will be determined by very modest changes in who decides to show up and vote.

Title: Twitter Allows Chinese Officials to Spread Disinformation and Conspiracy Theories on COVID-19

Twitter has allowed Chinese officials to spread disinformation and conspiracy theories about the COVID-19 pandemic on its platform, according to a company representative who spoke to the Daily Beast on condition of anonymity. The representative cited Twitter's terms of service, which state that direct interactions with fellow public figures, comments on political issues of the day, or foreign policy saber-rattling on economic or military issues are generally not in violation of the Twitter Rules.

A recent example of this is Chinese senior official Lijian Zhao, who tweeted on March 12 that the United States may have brought the epidemic to Wuhan, China. Zhao also falsely stated that Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director Robert Redfield was "arrested" before sharing the conspiracy theory with his 317,000 followers. Health officials have said the virus began in China's Wuhan region and expanded geometrically from there.

Twitter has also allowed other examples of misinformation to go unchecked. For instance, Tesla CEO Elon Musk tweeted on March 20 that children are "essentially immune" to COVID-19, which Twitter previously stated was impermissible. However, Twitter appeared to backtrack after Musk made the comment, stating that the tweets did not violate its rules.

Twitter's policy allowing world officials to "clobber each other" appears to allow them to distribute disinformation wantonly. The company's language on its website states that direct interactions with fellow public figures, comments on political issues of the day, or foreign policy saber-rattling on economic or military issues are generally not in violation of the Twitter Rules.

Title: GOP Delegates May Have More Flexibility Than Expected in Choosing Nominee

Article:

A delegate to the Republican National Convention in Cleveland has sparked debate about the extent to which delegates are bound to support a particular candidate. Curly Haugland, a GOP national committeeman from North Dakota, believes that party rules do not bind delegates to vote for a specific candidate, even if they are "pledged" to a particular contender due to state primary results. According to Haugland, primary votes are "absolutely irrelevant" come convention time.

Haugland cites Rules 37 and 38 of the GOP's convention rules, which he interprets to mean that delegates may "vote their conscience." While Rule 37 explains the procedure for roll call votes, Rule 38 states that no delegate may be "bound" by the "unit rule," meaning that delegates from a state cannot be forced to vote the same way.

Not all experts agree with Haugland's interpretation, with many believing that delegates currently pledged to Trump, Cruz, Kasich, or others must support them at least on the first ballot. However, if no candidate receives a majority, delegates would necessarily vote in different ways on later ballots to resolve the impasse.

Another point Haugland makes is that when the convention convenes, delegates adopt their own rules, which have not been adopted yet. While there is a standard template for conventions, delegates could tweak the template, changing the game in any way they want. The only real constraint is that their actions would be publicly known and open to criticism.

The latitude afforded delegates explains why it is considered significant that Senator Ted Cruz has outmaneuvered Trump in several states, ensuring that as many delegates as possible are Cruz supporters. Haugland's personal goal is to adopt a rule that assures delegates the chance to choose from a wide range of alternatives, including candidates such as Jeb Bush or Marco Rubio who have suspended their campaigns.

Title: CDC Outlines Ebola Guidelines, Governors Differ on Quarantine Policies

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has outlined updated guidelines for monitoring individuals entering the United States from Ebola-stricken nations in West Africa. The guidelines aim to identify and track those at risk of contracting the virus, with the highest-risk individuals being asked to voluntarily quarantine themselves at home for 21 days.

The CDC's new guidelines categorize individuals into four groups, based on their level of risk. Those at the highest risk, such as healthcare workers who had a needle stick while treating Ebola patients, will be asked to remain under voluntary home quarantine and have daily, in-person checks by a health official.

The guidelines also cover individuals who may have had contact with the virus domestically, including healthcare workers returning from Africa. These individuals will be included in the "some risk" category, which allows for more freedom of movement, with daily direct monitoring on a case-by-case basis.

The CDC's guidelines come after several states, including New York and New Jersey, announced their own policies, including mandatory quarantines for returning healthcare workers. However, many public health officials have criticized these policies, citing concerns that they may cause more harm than good.

New Jersey, in particular, faced scrutiny after quarantining a nurse who had returned from working with Ebola patients in Sierra Leone. The nurse, Kaci Hickox, had tested negative for Ebola and was allowed to return to her home in Maine on a private flight, avoiding contact with the public.

CDC Director Tom Frieden emphasized the importance of balancing public health concerns with the need to avoid stigmatizing healthcare workers who are working to combat the Ebola outbreak. "If we turn them into pariahs instead of recognizing the heroic nature of the work they're doing, then they may be less likely to identify themselves as health workers – and thus go unmonitored – and less likely to go help [Africa] in the first place," Frieden said.

The quarantined nurse, Kaci Hickox, had retained a civil rights attorney and threatened to sue New Jersey for detaining her, despite having no symptoms and testing negative for Ebola. Her case has become a symbol of the controversy surrounding mandatory quarantines.

Virginia has also announced stepped-up plans to monitor individuals coming into the country from the affected part of West Africa, with some individuals considered at high risk facing a quarantine at home, with daily check-ins by health officials. The CDC's guidelines are based on science and aim to strike a balance between public health concerns and the need to support healthcare workers in their efforts to combat the Ebola outbreak.

Title: Covington Catholic High School Students Report Threats and Doxxing After Viral Video

Covington Catholic High School students Sam Schroder and Grant Hillmann have released a video statement describing the alleged threats and doxxing they have faced since a viral video showed a classmate, Nicholas Sandmann, interacting with a Native American leader, Nathan Phillips, at a D.C. protest. The video, which has sparked widespread debate and controversy, shows Sandmann wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat and seemingly smirking at Phillips, who was beating a drum in front of him.

According to Schroder and Hillmann, the threats against them and the school have escalated significantly, with some students receiving death threats and others having their identities and contact information made public online. The students claim that police have been posted at the school and that some students are too scared to attend classes.

Schroder and Hillmann also described how they have been doxxed, with Schroder stating that he was not even present during the incident but was targeted for his vocal support of his school and peers. Hillmann claimed to have been doxxed on three separate occasions, resulting in a "tsunami of hateful messages and threats."

The students placed blame on the media for the situation, with Hillmann stating that several outlets "blatantly lied" about the encounter and that the coverage has affected their community "greatly." Sandmann, on the other hand, released a statement claiming he was attempting to "diffuse" the situation by smiling and that Phillips had "singled him out for a confrontation."

The incident has sparked a heated debate about the context and implications of the video, with some viewing it as a symbol of racism and others seeing it as a misunderstanding. The full story remains unclear, and the consequences of the incident are still unfolding.

Title: AI Systems Adapt to Pandemic-Induced Changes in Consumer Behavior

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has brought about unprecedented changes in consumer behavior, forcing AI systems to adapt and evolve to keep pace. As people's spending habits and preferences shift, AI-powered companies are making adjustments to their algorithms and models to better understand and respond to the new reality.

Sharma, an expert in AI, believes that the pandemic is a "perfect trigger" to build better machine-learning models, incorporating data from past crises like the Great Depression and the 2007-2008 financial crisis. However, even with these efforts, AI systems can't prepare for every eventuality, as David Excell, founder of Featurespace, notes. His company's AI has not been severely impacted, as people are still engaging in familiar behaviors like buying essentials on Amazon and subscribing to Netflix, but with reduced spending on big-ticket items.

Featurespace's engineers have had to adjust for a surge in purchases of garden equipment and power tools, which are typically flagged as suspicious by fraud-detection algorithms. Excell emphasizes the need for more oversight and flexibility in AI systems, acknowledging that the world and data have changed.

London-based Phrasee, which uses natural-language processing and machine learning to generate email marketing copy and Facebook ads, has also had to adapt. Its AI generates phrases and runs them through a neural network to select the best ones, but humans review the output to ensure it doesn't go awry. When COVID-19 hit, Phrasee filtered out language that might be too happy or alarming, and culled emojis that could be misinterpreted.

Amazon, a microcosm for the retail industry, is also making subtle adjustments to its algorithms to help spread the load. The company is promoting sellers that handle their own deliveries, rather than those that rely on Amazon's logistics. This change has a ripple effect on the algorithms used by sellers to decide on online advertising.

The pandemic has exposed the importance of human oversight and manual intervention in AI systems. As Cline, an expert at Amazon, notes, "The situation is so volatile... You're trying to optimize for toilet paper last week, and this week everyone wants to buy puzzles or gym equipment." The tweaks Amazon makes to its algorithms have knock-on effects on the algorithms used by sellers, highlighting the need for a dedicated team to monitor and adjust AI systems in real-time.

The pandemic has brought to light the importance of designing AI systems that can adapt to changing circumstances and the need for human oversight to ensure they remain effective and responsible.

Title: Migrant Group Reaches U.S.-Mexico Border, Seeks Asylum

A group of approximately 150 migrants, carrying white flags bearing the message "La paz y Dios" or "Peace and God are With Us," has separated from a larger caravan near Southern California and approached within 500 feet of the U.S. border, according to a report. The migrants are attempting to present themselves as asylum seekers near Baja, California.

The group, led by Honduran Carlos Lopez, claims to be peaceful and is seeking to enter the United States. Lopez stated that conditions in Mexico are "horrible," with sick children and women, and children forced to remain outside in the elements. Those already in the city have camped out in tents, slept on dirt fields, or stayed in overcrowded shelters, waiting to determine their next steps.

The larger group, comprising around 6,219 Central Americans, is expected to grow to 10,000 in the coming weeks or months, according to federal government estimates. U.S. President Donald Trump has warned that the caravan poses a national security threat and will not be allowed to enter the country.

On Monday, a judge blocked the president's ban on asylum for those who cross the U.S. border illegally, a decision the administration claims will lead to "countless illegal aliens pouring into our country."

The migrants, who have traveled for over a month, can now see the bridge that separates them from the U.S. Trump, speaking in Florida, threatened to close the U.S. border with Mexico for an undisclosed period if his administration determines that Mexico has lost control of the situation. He also stated that he has given active-duty troops the "OK" to use lethal force against migrants "if they have to" and praised Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen for her efforts to address the issue.

Title: From Slavery to Salvation: The Redemptive Story of John Newton

The story of John Newton, an English slaver born 300 years ago, serves as a powerful illustration of the transformative power of the Christmas message. Newton's life was marked by a life of sin and rebellion against God, but it was also a journey of redemption and salvation.

Born into a seafaring family in Liverpool, Newton's early life was marked by a lack of spiritual guidance. His mother's faith had a lasting impact on him, but he soon adopted the rough and tumble lifestyle of a sailor. He was eventually captured and forced to work on a slave ship, where he was subjected to harsh treatment and flogging. Newton's life continued to spiral downward, and he became embroiled in the slave trade, treating human beings as mere commodities.

Despite his involvement in the slave trade, Newton's life was marked by a series of misfortunes, including being captured, beaten, and left for dead. He was eventually rescued and returned to London, where he was exposed to the preaching of George Whitefield and the influence of John Wesley. It was during this time that Newton experienced a profound spiritual transformation, and he was born again into the new life in Christ.

Newton's testimony of redemption is a testament to the power of God's mercy and forgiveness. He died on December 31, 1807, at the age of 82, leaving behind a legacy of faith and a beloved hymn that would become a staple of Christendom.

Title: Anthony Scaramucci Deletes Old Tweets Amid Appointment as White House Communications Director

Anthony Scaramucci, the newly appointed White House communications director, has begun purging his Twitter account of old tweets that do not align with the administration's agenda. In a tweet on Saturday, Scaramucci stated, "Full transparency: I'm deleting old tweets. Past views evolved & shouldn't be a distraction. I serve @POTUS agenda & that's all that matters."

Scaramucci did not specify which tweets would be deleted, but within hours of his announcement, several tweets from 2012 and 2016 were no longer available. These included a tweet advocating for "common sense" gun laws and complimenting Hillary Clinton, Trump's former campaign rival. In another tweet, Scaramucci expressed support for combating climate change without crippling the economy.

Scaramucci's appointment as White House communications director came after Sean Spicer's resignation on Friday. The former press secretary resigned to give the President and the new team a "clean slate." Scaramucci acknowledged that he had previously spoken critically of Trump and acknowledged that the President hired him despite being aware of his earlier remarks.

In a statement, Scaramucci said, "One of the biggest mistakes I made, because I was an inexperienced person in the world of politics. I was supporting another candidate. I should have never said that about him." He also expressed his loyalty to the President and the mission of the administration.

The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Scaramucci's tweet deletions.

Title: Economist Stephen Moore Advocates for Reopening Economy, Compares Protesters to Rosa Parks

Article:

Economist Stephen Moore, a member of President Donald Trump's economic advisory council, has been involved in planning a protest against Wisconsin's stay-at-home order. In a YouTube video, Moore stated that he is working on a "drive-in" protest in Wisconsin to challenge the order issued by Governor Tony Evers (D). The order was extended until May 26.

Moore compared those protesting the order to Rosa Parks, the civil rights icon who fought for racial equality. He believes that the protesters are fighting against government injustices and a loss of liberties. However, his comments drew criticism from some on social media, with Democratic congressional candidate Scott Huffman calling his remarks "strikingly stupid and deeply offensive."

Moore also expressed his opinion that the Trump administration has waited too long to reopen the economy. He believes that the country should have started reopening a week or two ago and that the current measures to save lives are causing huge hardship for citizens and businesses.

Protesters against stay-at-home orders took to the streets in several states this week, including Wisconsin, where plans for a "Freedom Rally" were announced for April 24. Moore stated that he is in talks with the protest organizers and that an unnamed donor has pledged to pay bail and legal fees for anyone who gets arrested during the rally.

Many health experts and state leaders, such as New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, have emphasized the need for more widespread testing before the country can reopen safely. Trump's plan to reopen parts of the country, rolled out on Thursday, includes a three-phase strategy. However, Trump took to Twitter on Friday, calling to "LIBERATE" Minnesota, Michigan, and Virginia, all states under stay-at-home orders with Democratic governors.

Title: Cindy Hensley McCain Calls on Americans to Join the Arena and Fight for a Greater Cause

Article:

Cindy Hensley McCain, wife of the late Senator John McCain, has called on Americans to join the arena and fight for a greater cause, echoing her husband's message of service and leadership. In a recent statement, she emphasized that her husband's legacy is not just about his own accomplishments, but about the values he embodied and the impact he had on others.

According to Cindy Hensley McCain, John McCain's message was that Americans must join together, shaped by their deepest values of liberty, equal justice, and respect for the dignity of all people, and step into the arena to fight for a greater cause. He demonstrated this commitment throughout his life, whether it was advocating for the best possible leadership and support for the armed forces, empowering freedom fighters against dictators, or demanding accountability for human rights abuses.

The McCain Institute for International Leadership, now Cindy Hensley McCain's home and mission, will continue to fight for the values that animated her husband's life. The institute aims to pay his legacy forward, and Cindy Hensley McCain is urging Americans to support the organization and join her in the arena.

In her statement, Cindy Hensley McCain encouraged individuals to take action and contribute to a greater cause, whether through leadership, support, or donations. She emphasized that every individual has the power to make a difference and that it is now up to Americans to carry on her husband's legacy.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Won't Defend State's Same-Sex Marriage Ban in Court

The attorney general of Virginia, Mark Herring, has surprised the state's political circles by announcing he will not defend the state's ban on same-sex marriage when it goes before a federal judge next week. Herring, a Democrat, stated that he wants the state to be "on the right side of history" and believes the anti-gay marriage law violates the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

The decision comes as a lawsuit challenging the ban is set to be heard in a federal court in Norfolk. Herring pointed to another Virginia law that once limited marriage, specifically multi-racial marriage, which the U.S. Supreme Court struck down. He believes that everyone, including same-sex couples, have the right to marry.

However, backers of the prohibition on gay marriage see it differently. Kirk Cox, the Republican majority leader of the Virginia House of Delegates, stated that the attorney general has a constitutional and statutory obligation to enforce and defend the duly adopted laws and constitution of Virginia.

Virginians had varying reactions to Herring's decision. Some, like Mary Linn, were unhappy with the decision, citing their Christian beliefs. Others, like Stan Gray, were ambivalent, stating that it doesn't bother them one way or the other.

The decision is part of a larger trend in the United States, with several federal judges having overturned similar bans in Utah and Oklahoma. Pennsylvania's attorney general also refused to defend that state's ban, and more than a dozen states have lawsuits challenging laws forbidding same-sex marriage. It is likely that the issue will ultimately be decided by the U.S. Supreme Court.

Title: Cyber Attacks on Federal Agencies on the Rise, Experts Warn

The number of cyber attacks on federal agencies has increased by 35% over the past three years, according to a CNN review of cyber attacks against federal agencies. This surge in cyber incidents has left experts warning that the problem is not just a matter of malware, but an adversary problem, with individuals being paid to try to breach government systems 24/7.

The review found that there were almost 61,000 cyber attacks and security breaches across the entire federal government last year, with the number of incidents involving government agencies jumping 35% between 2010 and 2013. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) reported that there were roughly 34,000 cyber incidents in 2010, compared to about 46,000 in 2013.

The attacks have affected various government agencies, including the White House and the Department of Energy. In one instance, the Energy Department was hacked, resulting in the theft of personally identifiable information from over 100,000 people. The data included names, dates and places of birth, social security and bank account numbers, and information about education and disabilities.

Experts point to human error as one of the main culprits behind the surge in cyber attacks. "This is a global problem. We don't have a malware problem. We have an adversary problem. There are people being paid to try to get inside our systems 24/7," said Tony Cole, vice president of the cyber security firm FireEye.

The attacks have also affected personal information accessible through government computer systems, similar to the recent breaches at Target and Home Depot. The IRS, for example, mistakenly posted tens of thousands of social security numbers on government websites, according to the nonprofit Public.Resource.org.

The Obama administration report showed that federal government agencies spent $10 billion on information security, but experts say that billions of dollars in security spending cannot stop an employee from clicking a malicious link. "There is no patch for a stupid user," said Denise Zheng, a deputy director at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

The attacks have also affected sensitive information about the nation's 85,000 dams, which was stolen from the Army Corps of Engineers. The data included location, condition, and potential for fatalities if the dams were to be breached, according to a report by Sen. Tom Coburn, the ranking Republican on the Senate Homeland Security Committee.

Experts warn that the uptick in security breaches is not just a matter of a lack of spending, but a patchwork of different systems and human error. "We need to have a response, whether it's an industry or a government response, so that folks understand there is a penalty here," said Zheng. "If they go unpunished, the message that sends is detrimental."

Title: Justice Department Drops Campaign Finance Case Against John Edwards

The United States Department of Justice has announced that it will not retry former Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards on campaign finance charges. The decision comes after a federal jury in Greensboro, North Carolina, failed to reach a verdict on five counts related to payments Edwards received from friends to support his pregnant mistress.

In August, the jury found Edwards not guilty on one count, and the government's central witness, Andrew Young, was criticized by several jurors who did not believe his testimony. The Justice Department's Criminal Division had asked Judge Catherine Eagles to dismiss the case with prejudice, meaning it will not pursue the case further.

Assistant Attorney General Lanny A. Breuer stated, "We knew that this case – like all campaign finance cases – would be challenging. But it is our duty to bring hard cases when we believe that the facts and the law support charging a candidate for high office with a crime. Last month, the government put forward its best case against Mr. Edwards, and I am proud of the skilled and professional way in which our prosecutors from the Criminal Division's Public Integrity Section and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of North Carolina conducted this trial. The jurors could not reach a unanimous verdict on five of the six counts of the indictment, however, and we respect their judgment. In the interest of justice, we have decided not to retry Mr. Edwards on those counts."

Edwards' lawyers released a statement saying, "While John has repeatedly admitted to his sins, he has also consistently asserted, as we demonstrated at the trial, that he did not violate any campaign law nor even imagined that any campaign laws could apply. We are confident that the outcome of any new trial would have been the same. We are very glad that, after living under this cloud for over three years, John and his family can have their lives back and enjoy the peace they deserve."

Title: The Elusive Quest for Civility in Politics

The recent passing of George Herbert Walker Bush, a renowned figure known for his kind and polite demeanor, has sparked a renewed interest in the concept of civility in politics. Many are optimistic that his passing will lead to a revival of a bygone era of respectful and gentle politics. However, the reality is that politics has always been a game of strategy and tactics, where "bashing" is an inevitable part of the game.

A recent discussion hosted by the National Institute for Civil Discourse and the American Psychological Association explored the decline in civility and mutual respect in public discourse. The panelists noted that negativity and extreme views often make it difficult for people with different opinions to engage in constructive dialogue. This can lead to a reinforcement of extreme views and a lack of understanding between opposing sides.

The idea that politicians of the past can serve as a model for civility is not without its flaws. The 1800 presidential election between John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, for instance, was marked by personal attacks and mudslinging. The Jefferson campaign accused Adams of having a "hideous hermaphroditical character," while the Adams campaign called Jefferson a "mean-spirited, low-lived fellow." These kinds of personal attacks are not unique to the past and continue to be a part of modern politics.

The National Institute for Civil Discourse and the American Psychological Association have identified the decline in civility and mutual respect in public discourse as a major concern.
