The institute's Arthur Evans noted that negativity makes it difficult for people with different opinions to engage in constructive dialogue, often leaving only extreme views to dominate the conversation.

While civility in politics is an admirable goal, it is not always a practical reality. Politicians, including presidents, understand that "bashing" is an inevitable part of the game. The stakes are too high for it to be otherwise. As Leo Durocher, the famous baseball manager-philosopher, once said, "nice guys finish last."

Title: Hillary Clinton Expresses Regret Over "Deplorables" Comment, Stands by Criticism of Trump's Actions

Article:

Hillary Clinton expressed regret over her comment that half of Donald Trump's supporters are "deplorables," but she stood by her criticism of Trump's actions and rhetoric. At a fundraiser in New York, Clinton characterized many Trump supporters as racist, sexist, and homophobic, saying it was "never a good idea" to generalize. She later clarified that she was referring to Trump's actions, not his supporters, and that she would not stop calling out bigotry and racist rhetoric in the campaign.

Clinton's initial remark sparked criticism from the Trump campaign, which accused her of revealing "her true contempt for everyday Americans." Trump's campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, urged Clinton to apologize and tweeted that she should "come to an event; talk to real people who aren't donors." Clinton's spokesman, Nick Merrill, responded that not all Trump voters are part of the alt-right, but alt-right leaders back the Republican nominee, and that their supporters appear to make up half his crowd when observing the tone of his events.

Clinton later clarified that the other "basket" of Trump supporters are "people who feel that the government has let them down, the economy has let them down, nobody cares about them, nobody worries about what happens to their lives and their futures, and they're just desperate for change." She also stated that she would not stop calling out bigotry and racist rhetoric in the campaign.

The Trump campaign responded to Clinton's comments, with Trump saying she "should be ashamed of herself" and asking how she could be president when she has such contempt and disdain for so many great Americans. Trump also accused Clinton of trying to turn her mistake around with a "pathetic rehash of the words and insults used in her failing campaign."

Title: Washington's Elites Play Contemptible Game with Nation's Fate

The article by Alex Castellanos highlights the perceived threat of mandatory budget cuts and the alleged inability of Washington elites to make hard spending choices. Castellanos argues that Americans have learned to live with less since the recession, and it is time for the government to do the same. He criticizes both parties for playing a contemptible game, with President Obama being accused of threatening to hold the country hostage unless his demands for increased spending are met.

The article also touches on the growing wealth of Washington's elites, with the city having the third-largest concentration of high-income households in the country. It mentions the example of Treasury Secretary Jack Lew, who received a nearly $1 million bonus from Citigroup before the company received a taxpayer-funded bailout.

Castellanos concludes by urging President Obama to lead by example and have the government tighten its belt 2%, as Americans have had to do since the recession. He argues that the sequester deal agreed upon in 2011 was a mistake and that both parties are to blame for the current situation.

Title: US Secretary of State Declares ISIS Responsible for Genocide Against Christians, Yazidis, and Shia Muslims

Article:

United States Secretary of State John Kerry announced on [date] that the terrorist group ISIS is guilty of committing genocide against Christians, Yazidis, and Shia Muslims. This declaration comes as a congressional deadline urging the Obama administration to make its own judgment was set to expire. The House had earlier approved a resolution, 393-0, stating that ISIS's actions against Christians and other religious and ethnic minorities in Iraq and Syria constitute genocide.

In a statement from the State Department briefing room, Kerry emphasized that ISIS is "genocidal by self-proclamation, by ideology, and by actions in what it says, what it believes, and what it does." He noted that the group's ideology is based on eliminating those who do not subscribe to its beliefs, and that its actions are intended to destroy entire ethnic or religious groups.

Kerry highlighted the specific targeting of Christians, Yazidis, and Shia Muslims, stating, "The fact is that Da'esh kills Christians because they are Christians, the Yazidis because they are Yazidis, [and] Shia because they are Shia." The US military intervened in Iraq in August 2014 to halt the ISIS massacre of the Yazidis, an ancient ethnic minority living in the Sinjar area.

It is unclear what impact this declaration will have, as there are no legal obligations to enforce a response. The last time a US administration declared genocide during an ongoing conflict was in 2004, when Colin Powell determined it applied to the actions of the Sudanese government in Darfur. However, that declaration did not compel the US to take action.

Kerry did not indicate any policy shift in the ongoing US-led effort to degrade and defeat ISIS.

Title: Senator John McCain Calls on Donald Trump to Make Amends to Veterans

Article:

Senator John McCain of Arizona has expressed deep dismay at the tone of the Republican presidential race, specifically criticizing Donald J. Trump's comments about prisoners of war. In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, McCain stated that Trump should make amends to "a body of American heroes" he had offended. Trump had previously mocked McCain for being captured and imprisoned during the Vietnam War, saying he prefers "people who weren't captured."

McCain emphasized that he is personally indifferent to Trump's ridicule, but cannot abide the affront to veterans in general. When asked if he would appear on the campaign trail with Trump, McCain said "a lot of things would have to happen" first. He stressed that Trump should express his appreciation for veterans who were imprisoned as prisoners of war, not just himself.

This statement adds to the pressure on Trump to mend his relationships across the Republican Party and win over party leaders he has alienated in the 2016 campaign. Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has already announced he will not vote for Trump under any circumstances.

McCain also noted that the "personalization" of the 2016 race is unprecedented, where people's integrity and character are questioned. He believes the Republican Party's leaders have lost touch with many voters, particularly older, white, blue-collar workers who see no job prospects. "There is some distance, if not a disconnect, between party leadership and members of Congress, and many of the voters who have selected Donald Trump to be the nominee of the party," McCain said.

Title: Decline in Importance of Presidential Candidate's Religious Beliefs

The Pew Research Center has released a study revealing a significant decline in the importance of a presidential candidate's religious beliefs among American voters. The study found that two-thirds of Evangelicals plan to vote for Donald Trump, while two-thirds of religiously unaffiliated "nones" plan to support Hillary Clinton. However, the percentage of Americans who want a president with strong religious beliefs has decreased by 10 percentage points since 2008, with a steeper decline among Democrats.

The reasons for this decline differ between Republicans and Democrats. Republicans are willing to support less-religious candidates to maintain political clout, while Democrats are shifting their focus to secular morality over traditional religion. Evangelicals, in particular, are willing to compromise on their candidate choices, as seen in their support for Donald Trump.

Experts suggest that the growing "nones" among the Democratic Party are driving this shift. The number of Americans claiming no religious preference has increased from 7% in the late 1980s to 25% in 2012. This could be a reaction to the intense fusion of theological doctrine and politics among religious conservatives.

On the other hand, Democrats are increasingly viewing morality outside of religiousness. "Nones" were among Bernie Sanders' strongest supporters in the primary, drawn to his vision of a society that takes better care of all. They saw him as a plain speaker whom they could trust, and are slow to warm to Clinton's campaign due to her alleged email misuse and connections to Wall Street.

The result is a curious situation in which Democrats appear to be more worried about the morality of their candidate than Republicans are. While Republicans are less concerned with the personal morality of their leader, Democrats are holding Clinton to a higher moral standard, making her alleged misdeeds stick.

Title: California Public School Students Sue State Over Teacher Tenure and Protections

A group of nine California public school students is suing the state over its laws on teacher tenure, seniority, and other protections that the plaintiffs claim keep bad educators in classrooms. The non-jury trial is set to begin on Monday in Los Angeles Superior Court and is expected to conclude in March.

The lawsuit, sponsored by an educational reform group, argues that the current system is "dysfunctional and arbitrary" due to outdated laws that restrict school administrators' ability to fire underperforming teachers. The plaintiffs claim that this leads to a situation where students are forced to learn from substandard teachers, hindering their educational progress.

The lawsuit seeks to have five statutes within the state education code deemed unconstitutional, including the one on tenure, which was created in the early 20th century to prevent arbitrary or discriminatory firings. The other four statutes outline the steps to dismiss a teacher and the "last-hired, first-fired" rule, which the lawsuit's attorneys say hurts young but talented teachers.

The California Teachers Association and the California Federation of Teachers have intervened in the lawsuit, arguing that the changes would lower morale, deny teachers due process, and unfairly target older teachers. They also claim that the evaluations are too dependent on standardized tests and that eliminating such protections would erase a vital support system for the teaching profession.

The lawsuit's attorneys argue that teachers too often receive tenure simply by showing up to work after 18 months, making it almost impossible or too expensive to fire them. They claim that this leads to a situation where schools are forced to send substandard teachers to disadvantaged schools, which are seen as less desirable places to work by experienced teachers.

The California teacher unions support improving teacher evaluations and streamlining the dismissal process, but argue that these changes should be the work of the Legislature, not the courts. The lawsuit's attorneys, however, believe that declaring the laws unconstitutional will allow the Legislature to craft legislation that actually works.

The outcome of the lawsuit is expected to have significant implications for the education system in California and beyond, as states across the nation are weakening teaching job protections to give administrators more flexibility to fire underperforming teachers.

Title: Trump's Praise for Robert E. Lee: A Complex and Controversial Legacy

Article:

President Donald Trump has once again drawn attention to his admiration for Confederate General Robert E. Lee, stating that he is a "true great fighter and a great general." This sentiment is not new, as Trump has consistently included Lee in his pantheon of military leaders alongside George S. Patton, Douglas MacArthur, and Ulysses S. Grant. As president, Trump has also exploited Lee's contested legacy to stoke divisions, using his praise for Lee to justify the preservation of Confederate monuments and statues.

However, Trump's understanding of the Civil War and its causes is questionable. He tends to downplay the role of slavery, instead reflecting the views prevalent in the textbooks of his youth. This limited understanding is reflected in his praise for Lee, who fought for a cause that was "one of the worst for which a people ever fought, and one for which there was the least excuse," as Grant put it.

The article highlights the complex and controversial nature of Lee's legacy, which has been used to advance the cause of sectional reconciliation and white supremacy. Presidents such as Woodrow Wilson, who was a great admirer of Lee, have lionized him as a national hero and embodiment of Southern honor, duty, and sacrifice. However, this narrative has often omitted Lee's personal cruelty as a slave owner and the fact that the reconciliation was built on a shared commitment to white supremacy and the tacit approval of Jim Crow.

The article concludes that Trump's praise for Lee is significant, as it underscores the ongoing debate about the legacy of the Civil War and the Confederacy. Corey Stewart, Trump's former Virginia campaign chair and now a GOP nominee for Senate, has also praised Lee as a "hero and an honorable man" and made defending his statues a centerpiece of his campaign. Until Sunday, there was no reason to think Trump might distance himself from praise for Lee.

**Climate Change: A Looming Threat to the Planet**

World leaders are gathering in Paris to discuss the urgent need to address climate change, a pressing issue that has far-reaching consequences for the planet. According to climatologists, even the best-case scenario, which involves immediate and drastic emissions cuts, would still result in a 2-degree Celsius increase in planetary surface temperatures over the coming decades. This may seem like a small increase, but it would have profound implications, including the destruction of plant and animal habitats, reduced crop yields, and increased exposure to flooding and drought.

If the current emissions trend continues, temperatures could rise by almost 6 degrees Celsius this century, according to the Committee on Climate Change. The consequences of a heating globe are already being felt, with Alaska warming twice as fast as the rest of the US. Rising temperatures have thawed frozen soil in some areas, leaving coastlines vulnerable to storms and tidal activity.

The loss of habitats is a significant concern, with an increase of 4 degrees Celsius resulting in severe habitat loss for almost two-thirds of plant species and one-third of mammal species. Even if nations curtail carbon emissions, a growing number of communities will be exposed to threats caused by climate change, including flooding and drought.

The world's biggest emitters, including the US, China, and India, have made commitments to curb their greenhouse gas production. China has promised to peak its carbon emissions by 2030, while the US aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 26-28% by 2025. The European Union has set a target to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030.

The consequences of inaction are dire, with an estimated 2-13 million people exposed to flooding each year, equivalent to the population of New Orleans and southern Louisiana. Additionally, 1.5-2 billion people will live in areas without enough usable water, almost five times the US population.

The world's biggest emitters, responsible for two-thirds of global emissions, must take immediate action to reduce their carbon footprint. The Paris talks are a crucial step towards mitigating the effects of climate change, but more needs to be done to ensure a sustainable future for our planet.

Title: IRS Acknowledges Targeting of Conservative Groups, Apologizes for "Inappropriate" Behavior

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has acknowledged that it inappropriately flagged conservative groups for additional review during the 2012 election, singling them out because they included the words "tea party" or "patriot" in their applications for tax-exempt status. The agency's acknowledgment came after Lois Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups, confirmed that organizations were targeted due to their political beliefs.

According to Lerner, the practice was initiated by low-level workers in Cincinnati and was not motivated by political bias. She stated that the IRS would like to apologize for the "inappropriate" behavior, which included asking some groups for their list of donors. Lerner emphasized that the practice was not widespread and that no high-level IRS officials knew about it.

The IRS has since changed its protocol in response to the rising number of applications for 501(c)(4) groups, which grant tax-exempt status to social welfare organizations. The agency claims that mistakes were made, but they were not due to any political or partisan rationale.

Conservative groups, including the Tea Party Patriots, have condemned the IRS's actions, calling them "disturbing," "illegal," and "outrageous." Republican lawmakers have also seized on the issue, with Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell calling for a "government-wide review" to ensure that similar practices are not in use elsewhere. House Republican Leader Eric Cantor has announced that the House will investigate the matter.

The IRS's acknowledgment and apology have been met with skepticism by some, with Senator Orrin Hatch stating that "we need to have ironclad guarantees from the IRS that it will adopt significant protocols to ensure this kind of harassment of groups that have a constitutional right to express their own views never happens again." Representative Darrell Issa called the targeting of conservative groups "unconscionable."

Title: House Majority Leader McCarthy Advocates for Treaty Route in North Korea Deal

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, a California Republican, has suggested that any eventual deal with North Korea should be submitted to the Senate for approval as a treaty. McCarthy made this statement on Saturday during an interview with MSNBC's Hugh Hewitt. He emphasized that this approach would not only make the deal more lasting but also counter criticism that President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal has made other countries uncertain about negotiating with the US.

McCarthy drew a comparison between the Iran deal and the potential North Korea deal, stating that the former was treated as an executive agreement rather than a treaty, which made it easier for Trump to revoke US participation. He believes that treating the North Korea deal as a treaty would make it more durable and less susceptible to changes in administration.

The House Majority Leader also disputed the notion that ripping up the Iran deal has made negotiating with North Korea more difficult. He argued that the US cannot negotiate with North Korea to end its nuclear program if it is allowing Iran to develop weapons in the future. McCarthy believes that Trump's approach of saying "no" to Iran and negotiating with North Korea to stop its nuclear program is the right one.

In his comparison to President Reagan's approach with the Soviet Union, McCarthy noted that Reagan was willing to talk when negotiations were going in his favor but willing to walk away when they went off track.

Title: IRS Acting Commissioner Steven Miller Testifies Before Congressional Panel Amid Controversy

Article:

Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller faced intense questioning from Republicans on Friday, who accused the agency of "systemic abuse" and targeting conservative groups seeking tax exemptions. Miller apologized for "foolish mistakes" made by employees trying to be more efficient in their workload selection, but pushed back against Republican assertions that the agency is politicized.

Miller maintained that the practice of flagging key terms in applications for tax exemptions is legal and praised a civil servant who worked in the agency's scandal-ridden tax-exempt division before helping implement the health care overhaul. He also denied lying to Congress, stating that he answered questions as they were asked.

The hearing, which lasted nearly four hours, left Republicans frustrated and seeking more information. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dave Camp (R-Mich.) expressed disappointment, saying Miller's answers were "not very complete" and that the committee will continue to examine the issue.

Miller's testimony did not ease the outrage among Republicans, who are determined to expand the scope of their investigation. They are looking into other IRS actions that have been criticized by conservatives, including a March 2012 Huffington Post story that disclosed confidential donor information for the National Organization for Marriage and a ProPublica article that said the IRS leaked applications from conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status.

Miller's testimony also revealed that agency officials discussed how to talk about the controversial targeting program before Lois Lerner, the director of the agency's tax-exempt division, was scheduled to appear at an American Bar Association conference on May 10. Lerner's comments that the agency was wrong to flag nonprofit applications with certain terms sparked a firestorm that has held Washington's attention for a week.

President Barack Obama announced on Thursday that Daniel Werfel, the current controller of the Office of Management and Budget, will succeed Miller as acting IRS commissioner next week.

Title: Obama Heads to the Middle East for Talks on Peace and Security

Article:

President Barack Obama is set to visit the Middle East this week, including his first trip to Israel since becoming commander-in-chief. The White House is downplaying expectations, stating that the president's goal is to help leaders come together to bring peace and democracy to the region.

During his visit, Obama will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who was re-elected in January and has formed a new government. The president will also meet with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and Prime Minister Salam Fayyad in the West Bank.

The White House has emphasized the need for frank peace talks between Israeli and Palestinian leaders, but has also expressed concerns about unilateral actions, such as Israel building settlements in east Jerusalem and the West Bank. The administration is willing to continue playing a facilitating role in the peace process, but has warned that face-to-face talks will be difficult if the leaders continue with one-sided actions.

The visit comes as the region faces several pressing issues, including ongoing efforts to reach a peace agreement between Israel and Palestine, and Israel's efforts to stop Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. The White House has established a "red line" against Iran obtaining nuclear weapons, but Netanyahu has questioned Obama's commitment to containing Iran's nuclear ambitions.

Obama will also make cultural stops in the region, including the Holocaust memorial Yad Vashem, the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, and an Iron Dome battery, part of the missile defense system for which the U.S. has helped pay. He will also visit a Palestinian youth center in the West Bank, as part of his effort to appeal to the Israeli public, particularly young people.

In addition to his meetings with Netanyahu and Abbas, Obama will also meet with Jordan's King Abdullah, where he will discuss the violence in neighboring Syria and the country's efforts to liberalize its government. The president's final stop will be at Petra, Jordan's ancient city.

The visit is seen as an attempt to quiet critics in the U.S. who interpreted Obama's failure to travel to Israel during his first term as a sign that he was less supportive of the Jewish state than his predecessors.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Delays Impeachment Vote, Scheduling Dispute Erupts

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee will vote on Friday on whether to move forward with impeaching President Donald Trump, after a marathon hearing that lasted over 14 hours. The committee had been expected to approve two articles of impeachment late on Thursday, setting up a vote by the Democratic-controlled House next week. However, Chairman Jerry Nadler sent lawmakers home for the night, citing the need for members to review the evidence and allowing the American people to see the vote.

The sudden change in plans incensed Republican leaders, who had been planning to travel home on Friday and will now have to reset their schedules. Top Republican Doug Collins expressed frustration, calling the decision "the most bush league thing I have seen, forever." Collins also criticized Chairman Nadler for not consulting with him before rescheduling the vote.

The hearing had been expected to wrap up early in the evening, but Republicans, led by Collins, proposed a series of amendments that had no hope of passage. The amendments focused on various topics, including natural gas drilling and the state of the economy, and were repeatedly presented by Republicans.

If the House impeaches Trump, who is charged with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, he would then go on trial in the Senate. The Republican-led chamber is unlikely to vote to find the president guilty and remove him from office. The House Judiciary Committee will reconvene on Friday at 10 a.m. ET to continue the impeachment proceedings.

Title: Alabama Senate Election: Rural White Voters and Write-in Candidates May Play Crucial Role

The upcoming Alabama Senate election between Republican candidate Roy Moore and Democratic candidate Doug Jones is expected to be closely contested. While energizing African-American voters is crucial for Mr. Jones, Mr. Moore's campaign also relies heavily on a strong turnout from his longtime base of rural white voters. If these voters decide to stay home due to the sexual misconduct allegations against Mr. Moore, it could significantly complicate the Republican's electoral math.

The election is expected to be decided by the early reporting counties in the state's northern tier and along the Gulf Coast, which are likely to report their results first. Mr. Moore's performance in these rural areas will be crucial in determining whether he can withstand Mr. Jones's expected success in Alabama's cities.

If Mr. Moore can replicate his performance in the Republican runoff victory in September, where he received over 60% of the vote in several rural counties, he is likely to claim victory. Additionally, if write-in candidates do well, it may not require Mr. Moore to reach 50% of the vote to win.

It is challenging for an Alabama Democrat to capture over 50% of the vote, but Mr. Jones may not need to reach this threshold to win. Senator Richard C. Shelby, a Republican and the state's longest-serving lawmaker, recently reminded Alabamians that he wrote in the name of another Republican rather than supporting Mr. Moore, which could inspire others in the party to do the same.

Two write-in candidates have already announced their bids: Lee Busby, a Republican and retired Marine colonel from Tuscaloosa, and University of Alabama football coach Nick Saban, who is widely considered the most important man in the state. The more Republicans or independents who write in the name of a third candidate, the lower the threshold Mr. Jones needs to reach to win. Depending on the number of write-ins, he could potentially win even if he only captures 48% of the vote.

Title: Trump Pushes Back Against GOP Establishment, Accuses Opponents of "Taking Advantage of Our Country"

Article:

Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump has pushed back against the growing movement among the party establishment to slow his march to the convention, accusing his opponents of "taking advantage of our country." In a special town hall with Sean Hannity, Trump called his campaign a "movement of competence and common sense and low taxes and secure borders," and warned against giving it away.

The billionaire businessman was referring to a recent conference held by the American Enterprise Institute, where Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and other key Republican congressmen reportedly discussed stopping Trump from securing the Republican nomination.

Trump accused his opponents of wanting to "take advantage of our country" and "stuff flowing across the borders" without strong borders. He also claimed that politicians prioritize the interests of those who gave them money over what's right for the country.

Meanwhile, Florida Senator Marco Rubio has denied reports that he is planning to drop out of the race, saying he will "fight this thing through Tuesday" and "go on." Rubio trails Trump by 23 percentage points among likely Republican voters in Florida, according to a recent poll.

Rubio also dismissed the possibility of forming a "unity" ticket with Texas Senator Ted Cruz, calling it "the kind of drama that makes it interesting in TV to speculate about." Cruz, who is Trump's closest challenger in the delegate race, said Rubio and Ohio Governor John Kasich are "good, honorable people" but lack a path to the nomination.

Cruz also walked back his earlier opposition to a possible convention fight between himself and Trump, saying that contested conventions are a part of the process. However, he reiterated his opposition to a brokered convention, warning of an "open revolt" among Republican voters.

The article also mentions that Kasich has staked his campaign's future on victory in next Tuesday's Ohio primary, where he is currently leading Trump by five percentage points among likely Republican voters.

Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect Pleads Not Guilty to 30 Counts of Using a Weapon of Mass Destruction

Boston, Massachusetts - Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the 19-year-old suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, pleaded not guilty to 30 counts of using a weapon of mass destruction in a federal court hearing on Wednesday. Tsarnaev, who was arrested on April 19, appeared disheveled and fidgety, wearing a partially unbuttoned orange jumpsuit and a black t-shirt. He spoke in a Russian accent and repeatedly looked into the crowded courtroom.

Tsarnaev's arraignment was his first public appearance since his arrest, and he was flanked by his two attorneys. The prosecution read aloud the 30 charges against him, each of which could bring a life-in-prison sentence, with 17 also eligible for the death penalty if the government decides to seek capital punishment.

Tsarnaev's defense attorney, Judy Clarke, attempted to enter a single "not guilty" plea on his behalf, but Judge Marianne Bowler asked that Tsarnaev speak for himself and that all the charges be read aloud. Tsarnaev responded with a simple "not guilty" repeated seven times.

The charges against Tsarnaev stem from the April 15 bombings that killed three people and wounded over 200, as well as the killing of an MIT police officer. His brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, was killed in a shootout with police three days after the bombings.

According to authorities, the brothers were inspired by al-Qaeda publications and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev left a confession in his boat justifying the bombings as payback for U.S. military action in Muslim countries. He wrote that the U.S. government was "killing our innocent civilians" and that "I don't like killing innocent people, but I can't stand to see such evil go unpunished."

Tsarnaev's arrest stunned those who knew him as a likable high school athlete in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he lived with his older brother after his parents left for Russia. The indictment also stated that Tsarnaev downloaded Internet material from Islamic extremists that advocated violence against the perceived enemies of Islam.

The victims of the bombings were Martin Richard, 8, Krystle Marie Campbell, 29, and Lingzi Lu, 23. Authorities say the Tsarnaevs also killed Massachusetts Institute of Technology officer Sean Collier days later while they were on the run.

Title: House Democrats Prepare to Investigate Trump Administration, Potential Targets Include 85+ Investigations and Subpoenas

Article:

House Democrats are gearing up to investigate the Trump administration, with incoming House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff and House Appropriations Chair Nita Lowey outlining their plans to explore potential grounds for impeachment and scrutinize various aspects of the president's actions. According to Schiff, the committee has assembled a list of at least 85 potential Trump-related investigation and subpoena targets.

Schiff expects Trump to resist the committees' requests, demands, and subpoenas, potentially pushing the fight over documents and testimony as far as the Supreme Court. The incoming chairs are planning to release transcripts of dozens of interviews conducted during the committee's Russia probe, which contain possible contradictions with other testimony and facts that have come to light, potentially putting witnesses in legal jeopardy.

Incoming House Appropriations Chair Nita Lowey, a close ally of House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, has given her stamp of approval to a long list of potential investigative targets, including the Space Force, hurricane relief in Puerto Rico, White House security clearances, and more. Lowey stated, "We have our boxing gloves on. I'm ready. And so is Nancy."

The Democratic leaders are planning to explore possible grounds for impeachment, with a public report by Special Counsel Robert Mueller likely to ignite the kindling. Tom Steyer, a liberal activist who spent over $100 million during the campaign to build support for impeachment, believes that establishment leaders who are trying to postpone talk of impeachment are "the outliers," as 80% of registered Democrats think they are right.

The potential targets include investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 elections, as well as other issues such as James Comey's firing, Attorney General Jeff Sessions' ouster, the Muslim travel ban, family separation policy at the border, discussions of classified information at Mar-a-Lago, and administration dealings with North Korea and Saudi Arabia.

Trump has already signaled confrontation, stating that if Democrats investigate him, the result will be "a warlike posture." When asked if he'll investigate the Democrats back, he replied, "Oh, yeah. Better than them."

The House Democrats' move to investigate the Trump administration comes as a response to the president's actions, with the goal of providing checks and balances on the executive branch. For over 225 years, federal courts have upheld the Constitution's mandate of Congress as an equal branch of government, providing a strong foundation for the House Democrats' actions.

Title: Republican Candidates Echo Rhetoric of Victimhood and Oppression Among Social Conservatives

Article:

Many Republican presidential candidates are adopting a narrative of victimhood and oppression to appeal to social conservatives, who feel besieged and marginalized in today's society. This narrative posits that the forces of secularism are consolidating their gains and preparing to make it illegal to be a Christian. Jeb Bush, Bobby Jindal, Marco Rubio, and Mike Huckabee are among those echoing this sentiment, warning that opposing same-sex marriage will lead to the criminalization of Christianity.

The candidates' rhetoric is partly a response to the rapid change in public opinion and laws on gay rights, as well as the decline of Christianity as a proportion of the population. According to Pew Research Center data, Christians made up 70.6% of the American population in 2014, down 8 points from seven years prior. The "unaffiliated" – atheists, agnostics, and those without a religion – now make up 23% of the public.

This perceived marginalization has led social conservatives to feel like they are living in a society that no longer shares their values. However, many have constructed an uplifting narrative around their supposed persecution, portraying themselves as courageous revolutionaries fighting for their principles and God's desires. When opposing gay marriage, they see themselves as standing up against the forces of secularism, rather than perpetuating discrimination.

While liberals may dismiss this rhetoric as exaggerated or even ridiculous, it is sincere and likely to become louder as social progress continues. The upcoming Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage may be a turning point, with candidates likely to emphasize their opposition to any potential ruling in favor of gay marriage.

Title: Bipartisan Index Reveals Rising Political Polarization in Congress

The Lugar Center, a think tank founded by former Indiana Republican Sen. Richard Lugar and Georgetown University's McCourt School of Public Policy, has released its inaugural Bipartisan Index, ranking members of Congress based on their willingness to work across the aisle. The index measures lawmakers' sponsorship and co-sponsorship of bills, as well as their ability to attract co-sponsors from the opposing party and co-sponsor others' bills.

According to the index, the 112th and 113th Congresses were the most partisan since 1993. Only a little more than one-third of lawmakers serving from 2013-2014 were ranked "bipartisan." The top scorers in the Senate included Republican Susan Collins of Maine and Democrat Joe Manchin of West Virginia, while those ranked as least bipartisan included Republicans Ted Cruz of Texas and Tim Scott of South Carolina.

In the House, GOP Reps. Christopher Gibson and Peter King of New York ranked most bipartisan, while Reps. Tim Huelskamp, R-Kan., and Donna Edwards, D-Md., were least bipartisan. The scores of presidential candidates in the Senate were all in the bottom half of the index, including Florida Republican Sen. Marco Rubio, Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul, and independent Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.

The trend of increasing polarization has been noted before. Tracking voting patterns since the early 1950s, CQ Roll Call has found that partisanship and polarization are driving legislative behavior more than in any other period since the start of the Eisenhower administration. A diagram by The Washington Post shows that starting in the 1990s, "the parties began pulling apart from each other, like a single cell dividing into two," and that "in the 2000s, there are hardly any links between the parties at all."

The Lugar Center hopes that the Bipartisan Index will incentivize lawmakers to be more bipartisan when writing legislation and making co-sponsorship decisions, as well as keeping an open mind about legislation introduced by the other party.

Title: Alabama Senate Race: Roy Moore's Support Remains Strong Among Loyal Base, but Some Republicans Waver

Alabama's Senate Republican nominee, Roy Moore, has been facing allegations of past sexual misconduct, which have led to a decline in support from some conservatives. However, his loyal supporters, who have backed him in previous statewide races, remain committed to his candidacy.

Johnny Williams, a 77-year-old retired bus charter company owner, is one such supporter. He has seen Moore "fighting at them fires" and believes in him. Williams is not alone in his loyalty, with many others citing Moore's stance on issues such as the direction of the country and the need to support President Trump's legislative agenda.

Ann Eubanks, a 68-year-old tea party group leader, said she is a "policy voter" and refuses to send a "far-left liberal Democrat" to Congress. She believes the election is about more than just Moore, but about the direction of the country and the balance of the Senate.

However, not all Republicans are on board with Moore's candidacy. Richard Barnett, a 66-year-old general manager of a metals and welding company, said he was not a fan of Moore before the allegations surfaced and will not vote for him. He believes Moore lacks the ability to represent the majority of people and may write-in Sen. Luther Strange instead.

The election has also brought out some unusual voters, with some Republicans expressing disappointment with Moore's candidacy. Sandra, a mother from Alabaster, said she is "100 percent behind Donald Trump" but is unsure how she will vote Tuesday. She wishes Luther Strange had been the candidate.

The path to victory for Moore may lie in motivating Trump's supporters in Alabama to vote in the special election Tuesday. His campaign was jubilant that President Trump held a rally in Pensacola, Florida, to encourage people to vote for Moore. However, not all voters are convinced, with one Waffle House employee, Nona, saying she cannot bring herself to vote for any of the candidates due to Moore's alleged behavior being "not Christian."

Title: Thousands March to Commemorate 50th Anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s Famous Speech

The 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s famous "I Have a Dream" speech was commemorated on Saturday with a march from the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial to the National Mall. The event drew tens of thousands of people, who pledged to continue working towards equality for all, including African Americans, LGBTQ+ individuals, Latinos, the poor, and the disabled.

The march was an homage to the generation of activists who faced fire hoses, police brutality, and indignities to demand equality for African Americans. However, it was also a call to action, with many speakers emphasizing that the work is not yet complete.

Martin Luther King III, the oldest son of the slain civil rights leader, emphasized that the task is not done and that more work is needed. Eric Holder, the nation's first black attorney general, highlighted the struggles faced by marginalized communities, including LGBTQ+ individuals, women, and the disabled.

Other speakers, including Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., and Al Sharpton, a longtime activist and MSNBC host, emphasized the importance of continued activism and advocacy. Lewis, who was a leader in the 1963 March on Washington, railed against the recent Supreme Court decision that effectively erased a key anti-discrimination provision of the Voting Rights Act.

The march was also attended by people from all walks of life, including Lynda Chambers, who gave up a day's pay to attend and felt compelled to make the trip after feeling alienated and deprived of her rights as a black person. Longtime activist Al Sharpton implored young black men to respect women and reminded them that two of the leading figures in the civil rights movement of the 1960s were women.

Speakers also touched on persistent high unemployment among blacks, which is about twice that of white Americans, and the acquittal of George Zimmerman for the shooting death of unarmed black teenager Trayvon Martin in Florida. The event was attended by people from all over the country, including Nancy Norman, who was disappointed that more people who look like her had not attended, but was glad to hear climate change discussed alongside voting rights.

The march was a reminder that the work of the civil rights movement is not yet complete and that continued activism and advocacy are necessary to achieve true equality and justice for all.

Title: Senate Committee Approves Gun Trafficking Bill, Debates Other Measures

The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill making gun trafficking a federal crime, marking the first key votes on gun laws since the December shootings at a Connecticut elementary school. The committee also debated bills banning assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, requiring background checks for nearly all gun purchases, and providing more money for schools to buy video cameras and other safety equipment.

The trafficking bill was approved by an 11-7 vote, with only Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa voting in favor of the measure. The committee is considering four pieces of legislation, all of which face uncertain fates on the floor of the Senate and in the House.

The bills being debated include the "assault weapons ban of 2013," sponsored by Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., the "stop illegal trafficking in firearms" act put forward by Committee Chairman Pat Leahy, D-Vt., the "protecting responsible gun sellers act of 2013" from Sen. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and the "school safety enhancements act of 2013" from Sen. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif.

The Democratic-controlled committee is expected to vote in favor of all four bills, which would then be considered by the full Senate. However, the bills' prospects after that are uncertain, as they would face an uphill battle in the Republican-controlled House.

Title: Polls Indicate Obama Holds Slight Lead Over Romney Ahead of First Debate

A new poll released by ABC News and the Washington Post suggests that President Barack Obama holds a slight lead over Republican nominee Mitt Romney in the upcoming presidential election. According to the survey, 55% of likely voters believe Obama will win the first debate, while 31% think Romney will emerge victorious. This finding is consistent with a previous CNN/ORC International poll conducted after the Democratic National Convention, which showed Obama with a 59%-34% advantage over Romney.

The ABC News/Washington Post poll also found that 49% of likely voters would vote for Obama if the election were held today, while 47% would choose Romney. The president's two-point margin is within the survey's sampling error. A separate Politico/George Washington University Battleground poll released Monday also showed Obama and Romney tied at 49% among likely voters nationwide.

The polls come ahead of the first debate between Obama and Romney on Wednesday night in Denver, Colorado. The debate will be the first of three between the two candidates, with Vice President Joe Biden and Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, Romney's running mate, also facing off.

The ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted from September 26-29, with 1,001 adults nationwide, including 929 registered voters and 813 likely voters, questioned by telephone. The survey's sampling error for likely voters is plus or minus four percentage points. The Politico/George Washington University Battleground poll was conducted from September 24-27, with 1,000 adults nationwide questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: Historic Shift in Public Opinion on Gay Rights Reflects Bipartisan Support for Marriage Equality

The gay rights movement has reached a milestone, with the Supreme Court set to decide on the constitutionality of Proposition 8 and the Defense of Marriage Act. While the outcome is uncertain, it is clear that the movement has achieved a significant shift in public opinion, with a clear majority of Americans now supporting same-sex marriage.

According to John Avlon, the success of the gay rights movement is a model for reaching consensus on other issues. The movement has skillfully positioned itself as bipartisan and centrist, with politicians from both sides of the aisle declaring their support for marriage equality. In recent weeks, politicians like Hillary Clinton, Jon Huntsman, and Rob Portman have publicly endorsed same-sex marriage.

The shift in public opinion is attributed to the efforts of activists like Evan Wolfson and Andrew Sullivan, who took early stands in favor of the freedom to marry. The movement has also been driven by the mainstreaming of marriage equality, with a focus on building bridges beyond the base and making conservative arguments for same-sex marriage.

Ted Olson, the former Bush administration solicitor general, and David Boies, his opponent in the Bush v. Gore Supreme Court case, have been vocal supporters of same-sex marriage. They argue that it is a civil-rights issue and a human-rights issue, and that it is not exclusive to either party or political spectrum.

The Respect for Marriage coalition has run ads highlighting public testimonies in favor of marriage equality by Colin Powell, Dick Cheney, and President Obama, showcasing unexpected common ground. The ads feature images of apple pie Americana, emphasizing the idea that marriage is an essentially conservative institution that leads to societal stability and reduced dependence on the government.

The shift in public opinion has also been driven by language, with terms like "freedom to marry" and "marriage equality" being used to depolarize the issue. The emphasis on individual freedom and civil rights helps humanize the issue and creates new coalitions.

The movement's success is a reflection of the durability and flexibility of American democracy, which can adapt to changing public opinion and cultural norms. The centrist model used by the movement can be replicated as the country tries to solve problems through the process of addition rather than division.

Title: Trump's Lawyers Prepare Answers to Special Counsel's Questions on Russian Interference in 2016 Election

The lawyers of President Donald Trump are preparing answers to questions from the U.S. special counsel, Robert Mueller, regarding Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, according to a source familiar with the matter. This development comes after several months of talks between Mueller and Trump's legal team regarding the president's potential interview.

Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, stated last month that Mueller wanted the president to commit to a follow-up interview after answering written questions, a position Trump's legal team has been resisting. The question of a potential interview has not yet been settled, but the source indicated that Mueller is willing to accept written answers to questions without a commitment from Trump's lawyers on what comes next.

Giuliani reiterated that Trump would be willing to answer questions about whether his campaign had colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election, but not whether he had acted to obstruct the Russia probe. Mueller is investigating both allegations.

In an NBC News interview last year, Trump tied his decision to fire FBI Director James Comey to the investigation into Russian election meddling. At the time of his firing, Comey was leading the probe. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the election to try to tip it toward Trump and away from his Democratic challenger, Hillary Clinton. Moscow has denied any interference, while Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and any obstruction of justice.

Title: White House Remains Hopeful for Assault Weapons Ban Despite Senate Setbacks

The White House has not given up on the assault weapons ban, despite the lack of Democratic support in the Senate, according to Vice President Joe Biden. Biden stated that he is still pushing for the ban to pass, citing the majority of Americans and gun owners who agree that military-style assault weapons do not belong on the streets.

In an interview, Biden mentioned that the 1994 assault weapons ban, which was attached to the Biden Crime bill, was also declared dead several times before it was passed. He believes that attitudes are changing and that the president and he will continue to push for the ban.

Biden emphasized that he does not think it makes sense to support something and declare that there is no possibility of it passing. He pointed out that the 1994 ban only had seven Republican votes, and he is willing to continue pushing for logical gun safety regulations.

The Vice President also mentioned that the Department of Justice, ATF, and other regulatory agencies will be crucial in the fight for gun control. He expressed confidence that the will of the people will eventually prevail, and the ban will be passed.

It is unclear whether the assault weapons ban will be passed in the near future, but the White House remains committed to the cause.

Title: Presidential Campaigns Halt Political Activities in Wake of Aurora Shooting

The mass shooting in Aurora, Colorado, has had a significant impact on the US political scene, with both major party presidential campaigns suspending their activities and re-evaluating their messaging. The incident, in which at least 12 people were killed and many more injured, has brought the issue of gun control to the forefront of the national conversation.

President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney both revised their campaign schedules, with Obama canceling a planned rally in Orlando and turning a scheduled event in Fort Myers into a somber and reflective occasion. Obama emphasized the importance of prayer and reflection, saying, "There are going to be other days for politics. This is a day for prayer and reflection."

Romney also adjusted his schedule, canceling a planned event in Bow, New Hampshire, and issuing a statement with his wife, Ann, expressing condolences to the victims and their families. The statement read, "Today is a moment to grieve and remember, and to reach out and to help, to appreciate our blessings in life."

Both the Obama and Romney campaigns also suspended their political ads in Colorado, a key battleground state, out of respect for the victims and to avoid the appearance of crassness. The Obama campaign initially stopped airing "contrast" ads, which are known as negative ads, and later asked Colorado station affiliates to pull all campaign ads. Romney's campaign also suspended all TV ads in the state.

The issue of gun control has emerged as a key topic in the wake of the shooting, with New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg calling on both Obama and Romney to provide specific details on how they plan to combat gun violence in the nation.

Title: Ebola Crisis: A Test of Trust and Transparency in the US Government

The recent Ebola crisis in the United States has raised concerns about the government's handling of the situation and its transparency with the public. On September 16, President Obama held a news conference at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta, where he assured the public that the chances of Ebola coming to America were "extremely low." However, just four days later, a Liberian Ebola carrier, Thomas Eric Duncan, arrived in the United States.

The president's initial reassurances and the CDC's guidelines, which stated that Ebola could only be transmitted through direct contact with blood or bodily fluids of an infected person, were later found to be incomplete and misleading. The CDC's Director, Tom Frieden, was forced to admit that simply standing within a three-foot radius of someone with Ebola poses a risk of infection, contradicting his previous statements.

The incident highlights the importance of transparency and accuracy in government communication during times of crisis. The public expects officials to provide clear and honest information to help them make informed decisions. Instead, the government's initial responses were criticized for being misleading and downplaying the risks.

The Ebola crisis also raises questions about the role of the media in holding the government accountable. In the past, the media has been accused of being too soft on politicians and failing to challenge their statements. However, in this case, CNN's Sanjay Gupta and other reporters forced Dr. Frieden to correct his previous statements, providing a rare example of the media doing its job.

The incident serves as a reminder that the public expects transparency and accuracy from government officials, and that the media has a crucial role to play in ensuring that officials are held accountable.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar's Comments on Israel Spark Backlash from Both Parties

Rep. Ilhan Omar, a freshman Democrat from Minnesota, has sparked a heated debate after accusing a prominent lobbying group of paying members of Congress to support Israel. The comments have drawn criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some lawmakers calling for her to be removed from the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Omar's comments were in response to a tweet by journalist Glenn Greenwald, who criticized House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy for threatening to take action against Omar and another freshman lawmaker, Rashida Tlaib, over allegedly anti-Semitic remarks. McCarthy made the comments during a press conference, stating that there are "situations in our conference where a member does something that is wrong" and that he believes silence is just as guilty.

Omar responded to Greenwald's tweet, saying "It's all about the Benjamins, baby," quoting a 1997 rap song by Puff Daddy. She doubled down when challenged by Batya Ungar-Sargon, the opinion editor of The Forward newspaper, saying "AIPAC!" referring to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.

AIPAC responded, stating that they are "proud to be engaged in the democratic process to strengthen the US-Israel relationship" and that their efforts are "reflective of American values and interests." Another freshman Democrat, Max Rose of New York, tweeted that Omar's statements are "deeply hurtful to Jews, including myself."

House GOP conference chair Liz Cheney slammed Omar's remarks, calling for House Democrat leaders to remove her from the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Zudhi Jasser, a physician and President of the American Islamic Forum for Democracy, went further, arguing that removing Omar from the committee would be a "good first step, followed by a swift sanction against @IlhanMN for bigotry unfit for the US Congress with removal from all committees."

The Republican Jewish Coalition called on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to take action against Omar and asked rhetorically if other House Democrats would "care to comment on the outrageous anti-Semitism being spewed by one of your fêted members?" Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley tweeted that Omar's statements "CAN NOT be tolerated in our own Congress by anyone of either party."

Chelsea Clinton, daughter of former President Bill Clinton, tweeted that "we should expect all elected officials, regardless of party, and all public figures to not traffic in anti-Semitism." Meghan McCain, daughter of late Arizona Senator John McCain, lauded Clinton for calling out anti-Semitism "on all sides, in all spaces, no matter how uncomfortable."

Left-wing historian and Politico Magazine contributing editor Joshua Zeitz tweeted that he knew exactly what Omar meant and that she might as well call people "hook-nosed." Omar responded to Clinton, saying she would "reach out" to her Monday and that they can build an inclusive movement for justice together.

This is not the first time Omar has faced criticism for her comments on Israel. In 2012, she tweeted that "Israel has hypnotized the world, may Allah awaken the people and help them see the evil doings of Israel." She did not apologize for the tweet until last month. In January, Omar argued in a Yahoo! News interview that Israel could not be considered a democracy and compared it to the Islamic theocracy in Iran.

Title: Jeb Bush Denies Shift in Views on Immigration Reform

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has vigorously denied allegations that he has shifted his stance on immigration reform, stating that he still favors a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants. In his new book, "Immigration Wars: Forging an American Solution," Bush writes that he supports a path to residency, rather than citizenship, for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country. However, he emphasized that his views on the issue have been consistent, despite earlier backing a pathway to citizenship.

Bush made his comments on Sunday talk shows, including "Fox News Sunday" and "Face the Nation," where he reiterated his support for a path to citizenship, as long as it is easier and less costly than coming legally. He also praised the bipartisan group of senators, including Senator Lindsey Graham, who are working to craft a consensus on the issue.

Senator Graham had previously criticized Bush's stance, saying it "undercuts" the senators' efforts. However, Bush maintained that he and Graham are on the same page and that his views have not changed. He also dismissed the notion that his book was a political maneuver to position himself for a potential 2016 presidential bid.

The issue of immigration reform has been a contentious one, with Republicans working to distance themselves from President Obama's push for comprehensive reform. Senator Marco Rubio, a potential 2016 nominee, has been a vocal supporter of a pathway to citizenship for those currently in the country illegally. Bush's views on the issue align with Rubio's, and he praised the senator's efforts to craft a bipartisan solution.

The debate surrounding immigration reform is ongoing, with both sides of the aisle weighing in on the issue. While Bush's views may have sparked controversy, he maintains that his stance has been consistent and is driven by a desire to find a solution to the complex issue.

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Consider Gun Control Measures Amid Intensifying Debate

Article:

Colorado has become a focal point in the national debate over gun control measures, as lawmakers consider a package of proposals aimed at preventing gun violence. The measures, which include limiting ammunition magazines to 15 rounds and expanding background checks to include private sales and online purchases, cleared Democratic-controlled committees on party-line votes but still require approval from the full Senate.

The debate has been intense, with hundreds of gun rights supporters gathering outside the state Capitol and circling the building with car horns blaring. Inside, the husband of former U.S. Rep. Gabrielle Giffords urged lawmakers to pass universal background checks and victims of mass shootings in Connecticut and a suburban Denver movie theater pleaded for more gun controls.

Retired astronaut and Navy captain Mark Kelly testified that he and his wife support the Second Amendment, but believe the right to bear arms should not extend to criminals and the mentally ill. He compared the different background check requirements for private and retail sales to having two different lines at the airport, one with security and one without.

Gun control opponents argue that the proposals will not reduce violence and instead suggest strengthening access to mental health services for individuals who could be dangerous to communities. The bill hearings were at times testy, with some outbursts from the audience and complaints from gun rights advocates that lawmakers limited testimony time.

Several bills have already cleared the House, and because Democrats control both chambers of the state Legislature, some of the proposals have a strong chance of passing. The state's Democratic governor, John Hickenlooper, supports magazine limits and expanded background checks, but has not indicated where he stands on other measures.

The debate has garnered national attention from gun rights groups, victims' families, and White House officials. Gun rights supporters wore stickers reading "I Vote Pro-Gun" and waved American flags outside the Capitol, while a small plane flew overhead carrying a banner with a message for the governor, "HICK: DO NOT TAKE OUR GUNS!"

One of the nation's largest producers of ammunition magazines, Colorado-based Magpul, has threatened to leave the state if lawmakers restrict the size of its products. Its founder said smaller magazines can be easily connected to each other and the company fears it would be legally liable if people were to do that.

About 20 Colorado sheriffs opposed the expanded background checks and magazine limits, saying the bills are unenforceable. Victims who have lost relatives to gun violence, such as Tom Sullivan, whose son was killed in the Aurora, Colo., theater shooting, urged lawmakers to pass magazine restrictions.

The debate highlights the complex and emotional issue of gun control, with proponents arguing that stricter laws can save lives and opponents believing they infringe on Second Amendment rights.

Title: Joe Biden Reverses Stance on Abortion Funding Amid Criticism from Fellow Democrats

Article:

Former US Vice-President Joe Biden has reversed his stance on abortion funding, stating that he believes all healthcare is a right. This change comes amid mounting criticism from his fellow 2020 Democratic rivals, who have attacked his previous support for the Hyde Amendment. The amendment, passed in 1976, restricts federal abortion funding and has been a source of controversy among Democrats.

Biden's campaign had previously stated that he still supported the amendment, which has led to backlash from liberal Democrats. However, at a Democratic gala in Atlanta, Biden said that the amendment is now incompatible with his views on universal health coverage. He stated that he believes healthcare is a right and that the amendment makes that right dependent on someone's ZIP code.

Biden also cited the recent push by conservative state legislatures to enact restrictions on abortion or an outright ban as one of the reasons for his policy change. He did not mention the attacks on his stance from his party members.

The former vice-president's original opposition to taxpayer-funded abortion was not necessarily out of step with the American public, but rather in conflict with the active and vocal base of the Democratic Party. The base passionately feels that abortion rights in the US are under the strongest attack in decades and wants to know that Democratic presidential candidates won't waiver in support of the procedure's continued legality.

Many among the field of 2020 Democratic presidential candidates, including Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Jay Inslee, have expressed support for repealing the Hyde Amendment. On Wednesday, both Elizabeth Warren and Beto O'Rourke directly criticized Biden's now-changed viewpoint, with Warren calling it "discrimination" against poorer women and O'Rourke saying it's "absolutely wrong." The four female senators running for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination have also co-sponsored a measure to revoke the Hyde Amendment and tweeted criticisms of the law this week, although they did not name Biden.

Title: Iran Confronts Widespread Protests and International Criticism After Downing of Airliner

Iran is facing widespread protests and international criticism following the downing of a Ukrainian airliner last week, which killed 176 people, including 57 Canadians. The incident occurred hours after Iran fired missiles at Iraqi military bases housing US troops, in retaliation for a drone strike that killed Iranian commander Qasem Soleimani.

The protests, which have spread to several cities across the country, are calling for Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to step down and for those responsible for the downing of the plane to be prosecuted. Demonstrators have chanted slogans such as "Khamenei has shame, leave the country" and "Justice for the victims."

Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has apologized for the "disastrous mistake" and expressed condolences to the families of the victims. However, the apology has done little to quell the anger and frustration of the protesters.

The incident has also led to international criticism, with US President Donald Trump tweeting his support for the demonstrators and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu calling on European powers to increase pressure on the Iranian regime.

The protests have also been marked by the temporary arrest of British Ambassador Rob Macaire, who was accused of instigating and directing radical and destructive demonstrations. Macaire was later released after his identity was confirmed.

The incident has also led to an investigation by the Ukrainian general prosecutor's office, which is now investigating the incident as a possible case of "willful killing and aircraft destruction."

Title: Trump Warns Protesters Ahead of Tulsa Rally, Vows Tougher Response

Article:

President Donald Trump warned protesters and "anarchists" on Friday that they will face a different scene in Oklahoma compared to cities like New York, Seattle, and Minneapolis, ahead of his comeback rally on Saturday night. In a tweet, Trump stated, "Any protesters, anarchists, agitators, looters or lowlifes who are going to Oklahoma please understand, you will not be treated like you have been in New York, Seattle, or Minneapolis. It will be a much different scene!"

White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany later clarified that the president's tweet referred to violent protesters, "anarchists," and looters. The rally is expected to draw tens of thousands of people to the Bank of Oklahoma (BOK) Center, with the Trump campaign implementing measures to check attendees' temperatures and distribute hand sanitizer and masks, although wearing masks is optional.

The Oklahoma Supreme Court denied an attempt by local plaintiffs to block the rally from going forward, ruling that the petitioners did not establish a "clear legal right" to have the rally canceled. The court stated that it is not its duty to fashion rules or regulations to achieve a desired outcome.

The Trump campaign is touting the rally as a "transition to greatness" and an opportunity for the president to rev up the economy after societal lockdowns designed to control the virus. Trump is also expected to discuss efforts to overhaul policing in the wake of George Floyd's death. However, he is positioning himself as a "law and order" candidate who will not let protests spill into violence.

Community organizers plan to observe the Juneteenth holiday over the weekend in the historic Greenwood district, which was known as Black Wall Street before white mobs destroyed it in a 1921 massacre. Political professor Ross Baker noted that Trump's decision to hold the rally in Tulsa is likely an attempt to boost his morale, which has been flagging since the Lafayette Square episode.

**Tacoma Man Dies in Shooting Incident at Immigration Detention Center**

A 69-year-old man, identified as Willem Van Spronsen, was killed in a shooting incident at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center in Washington state early Saturday morning. The privately run facility, operated by GEO Group, holds migrants pending deportation proceedings.

According to the Tacoma Police Department, officers responded to the scene at around 4 a.m. after receiving reports of a man armed with a rifle throwing incendiary devices. The officers arrived and opened fire, and Van Spronsen was found dead at the scene. The Pierce County Medical Examiner's Office later identified the deceased as Van Spronsen, a resident of Vashon Island.

Police said Van Spronsen caused a vehicle to catch fire and attempted to ignite a large propane tank and set buildings on fire. He was armed with a rifle, a satchel, and flares. The officers who fired their weapons have been placed on paid administrative leave, as is standard procedure in officer-involved shootings.

A friend of Van Spronsen, Deb Bartley, described him as an anarchist and anti-fascist, and believes his attack on the detention center was intended to provoke a fatal conflict. Bartley said Van Spronsen had written a manifesto and sent goodbye letters to friends before the incident.

Van Spronsen had a history of activism, including an incident in 2018 where he was accused of assaulting a police officer during a protest outside the detention center. He pleaded guilty to obstructing police and received a deferred sentence.

GEO Group, the company that operates the detention center, released a statement condemning the violence and expressing gratitude for the quick response of the Tacoma Police Department. The company emphasized the importance of employee safety and the provision of modern amenities at the detention center.

The incident is under investigation, and authorities are processing the scene. No law enforcement officers were injured during the incident.

Title: Intelligence Official Praises Analysts for Warning on ISIS Gains, Amidst White House Dispute

The Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, sent a memo to staff praising analysts for their work in highlighting the Islamic State's (ISIS) gains over the past two years. This comes as Republican lawmakers and intelligence officials dispute President Obama's claim that his administration underestimated the threat posed by ISIS.

In the memo, Clapper acknowledged that the intelligence community has been monitoring and assessing the expansion of ISIS, and that the president has found this work to be critical to developing his strategy against the terrorist group. Clapper also noted that he and Obama agree that it was difficult to predict the will of Iraqi security forces to fight against ISIS.

However, Clapper's memo may fuel concerns that the White House was not taking seriously enough the intelligence community's warnings about ISIS. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers faulted "policy makers" for not confronting the threat, and intelligence officials have told Fox News that they were drawing attention to the ISIS threat for months, but were ignored by the White House.

The White House has disputed accusations that Obama ignored intelligence warnings, with Press Secretary Josh Earnest pointing to Clapper's memo as evidence that the president was not aware of the threat. However, Clapper's memo does not acknowledge underestimating ISIS, as Obama claimed on "60 Minutes."

Title: Obama to Warn Iran on Nuclear Weapons, Emphasize Global Cooperation

Article:

President Barack Obama will address the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, warning Iran that the United States will "do what we must" to prevent it from acquiring a nuclear weapon. The president will also appeal to world leaders to unite against further attacks on U.S. diplomatic missions in Muslim countries.

According to excerpts released by the White House, Obama will emphasize the importance of resolving the issue through diplomacy, stating that "America wants to resolve this issue through diplomacy, and we believe that there is still time and space to do so. But that time is not unlimited." He will also highlight the potential risks of a nuclear-armed Iran, including the elimination of Israel, the security of Gulf nations, and the stability of the global economy.

The president will also pay tribute to Ambassador Chris Stevens, who died in the September 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya.

Obama's address comes as the U.S. presidential campaign heads to its finish, with Republican rival Mitt Romney criticizing the president's foreign affairs leadership. Romney has assailed Obama's handling of the Middle East, focusing on the killing of the U.S. ambassador in Libya and mass bloodshed in Syria.

The United Nations General Assembly is scheduled to begin on Tuesday, with Obama set to speak just after 10 a.m. ET. The U.N. webcasts its proceedings, and updates will be posted as world leaders address the assembly.

**Nigerian Security Chiefs Urge Public to Come Forward with Information on Abducted Girls**

Nigerian security chiefs are calling on the public to provide any information that could lead to the rescue of the over 200 schoolgirls abducted by Boko Haram in mid-April. The girls, who were taken from their beds at a school in northeastern Nigeria, are believed to have been split up and taken out of the country.

The search for the girls has expanded to neighboring countries, including Niger, Cameroon, and Chad, according to a UN official. France, the United States, Britain, and China have all offered assistance in the search and rescue efforts.

Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan has vowed that the abduction of the girls will be the "beginning of the end" for the terrorist group Boko Haram. However, the task of recovering the girls appears to be growing more complicated, with US intelligence suggesting they have been broken up into smaller groups.

The Nigerian government has been under fire for its slow response to the abduction, with some critics saying officials failed to take action in the hours and days after the girls were taken. The government has defended its response, saying efforts were underway but could not be disclosed publicly.

The US has sent a team of law enforcement experts and military advisers to assist in the search, while France and Britain have also offered to send specialized teams. China has promised to provide any intelligence gathered by its satellite network.

Nigerian security officials have appealed to the public for help, calling on members of the immediate community to provide security agencies with useful information that will lead to the rescue of the girls.

Title: Congressional Leaders and President Trump Fail to Reach Agreement on Government Shutdown

Article:

Washington, D.C. - A meeting between U.S. congressional leaders and President Donald Trump on Wednesday failed to produce an agreement to end the partial government shutdown, now in its 12th day. The impasse stems from Trump's insistence on securing $5 billion in funding for a border wall, which is fiercely opposed by Democrats.

The White House convened the meeting to present Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen's briefing on the need for a wall on the southern border with Mexico. However, Democratic leaders cut off the presentation and instead pressed Trump to accept their offer to fund most of the government through September, with a partial funding for the Department of Homeland Security, which is responsible for the wall.

Senator Dick Durbin described the briefing as "not credible," while Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi emphasized the need to focus on ending the shutdown. Pelosi stated that the House will proceed with plans to hold votes on Thursday on legislation that would end the shutdown without providing the wall funding sought by Trump.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell refused to consider the legislation, calling it a "political sideshow" and "total nonstarter." Democrats argue that funding most of the government through September would allow for further negotiations on wall funding.

The meeting was the first since the sharp exchange between Pelosi, Schumer, and Trump in the Oval Office on December 11, during which Trump said he would be "proud to shut down the government for border security." The $5 billion Trump is seeking would cover only a portion of the estimated $23 billion needed for the border wall, which Trump had claimed Mexico would pay for, but Mexico has refused.

The government shutdown, which has affected about a quarter of the federal government and 800,000 federal workers, is expected to continue into the weekend, with congressional leaders set to return to the White House on Friday to resume talks.

Title: West Point Graduation Ceremony Brings Cadets Back to Campus Amid COVID-19 Outbreak

The United States Military Academy at West Point held its graduation ceremony on June 13, with President Donald Trump delivering an in-person speech to the 1,000-person graduating class. The event was a logistical challenge, as cadets were summoned back to campus despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
