The Army reported that 1.5% of the returning graduates, approximately 15-16 students, tested positive for COVID-19, but none were symptomatic and no cases were linked to person-to-person contact while under the Army's care.

The decision to hold an in-person ceremony was not without controversy. The Army had initially planned to hold a virtual graduation, but Trump's sudden announcement to attend the ceremony forced a last-minute scramble. The event was criticized for putting cadets and staff at risk, with some arguing that it was unnecessary and could have been spaced out to ensure greater safety.

The Army's top civilian leader, Ryan McCarthy, justified the decision by stating that cadets needed to return to campus for physicals and clearance procedures, but critics argue that this could have been done in a way that prioritized safety. The decision has sparked an uproar on the West Point Parents Facebook group, with some parents expressing concerns about the risks involved.

The event was also seen as a departure from the usual protocol, as other military academies, such as the Naval Academy and Air Force Academy, have held virtual graduation ceremonies. The Army's superintendent, Lt. Gen. Darryl Williams, emphasized that returning cadets will be "segregated the entire time" into five cohorts, with no intermingling for 14 days, and will eat and live separately.

The decision to hold an in-person graduation ceremony has raised questions about the priorities of the Trump administration and the Army, with some critics arguing that it prioritizes pageantry over safety. The event has sparked a heated debate, with some seeing it as a necessary tradition and others viewing it as a reckless decision.

Title: Reddit Quarantines 'European' Subreddit, Citing Violation of Content Policy

Reddit, a popular online forum, has quarantined a subreddit titled 'European' on May 12, 2016, citing a violation of its content policy. The subreddit, which was set to private, now requires users to be moderators or approved submitters to access the content. Visitors were encouraged to continue discussions on Voat, another online forum.

Reddit's decision to quarantine the subreddit was met with mixed reactions from users, with some arguing that the community hosted a range of opinions and others claiming that it expressed racist views. The move was also compared to recent allegations of bias in social media, including claims that Facebook contractors deliberately suppressed conservative news on its Trending Topics section.

Reddit's statement explained that quarantines are rare and are only implemented when content is deemed offensive to the broader Reddit community. The quarantine process does not end the conversation, but rather adds an opt-in measure, allowing users to choose whether to join the discussion.

Restrictions on quarantined subreddits include requiring an explicit opt-in, verified email addresses, no custom images, and the removal of revenue generation. The 'European' subreddit's quarantining has sparked debate among users, with some arguing that it stifles free speech and others believing it is necessary to prevent offensive content from being viewed.

Reddit's content policy prohibits illegal content, spam, the publication of private and confidential information, sexually suggestive content featuring minors, and anything that incites harm or violence against an individual or group. The policy also bans content that harasses, bullies, or abuses individuals or groups.

In a related development, a blogger analyzed a Reddit dataset of 4.6 million comments and found that 78 percent of Reddit threads with over 1,000 comments mention Nazis or Hitler. The blogger noted that around 2.6 percent of comments in the 'European' subreddit mentioned Nazis or Hitler, slightly higher than the 'AskHistorians' and 'History' subreddits.

Title: Justice Department Investigates 27 Leaks of Classified Information with Political Motive

The United States Justice Department is currently conducting 27 active investigations into leaks of classified information with a political motive, according to Attorney General Jeff Sessions' testimony before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday. This is a significant increase from the three years prior, when the agency had nine such investigations.

Sessions emphasized that leaks have reached "epidemic proportions" and that the agency is working to ensure that those responsible are held accountable. He specifically mentioned the case of Reality Winner, a former National Security Agency contractor who was charged with leaking classified information.

The stepped-up investigations come amid pressure from the White House, with President Trump criticizing Sessions for being "weak" on issues related to leaks. In response, Sessions held a press conference with Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats, calling for an end to the leaks.

A recent report by the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee found that the Trump administration is facing an "alarming" and "unprecedented" cascade of media leaks that pose a potential danger to national security. The report estimated that the administration has dealt with roughly one leak per day, with leaks flowing about seven times faster under the Trump administration than during the first 126 days of both Obama's and George W. Bush's presidencies.

Title: US Designates North Korea as a State Sponsor of Terrorism, Imposes New Sanctions

The United States has designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism, a move aimed at punishing and isolating the country for its continued development of missiles that could potentially hit the US mainland. The decision was announced by President Donald Trump during a Cabinet meeting on Monday, with the administration set to reveal new sanctions on Tuesday.

North Korea will join Iran, Sudan, and Syria as the only countries on the state sponsors of terrorism list, which bars them from receiving US development assistance, bans defense sales, restricts exports of items that could potentially be used for military purposes, and imposes tougher financial restrictions.

The designation is based on North Korea's alleged support for terrorism, with the administration citing the February assassination of Kim Jong Un's estranged half-brother in Malaysia as an act of terrorism. However, the exact extent of North Korea's support for terrorism is debatable, with some questioning whether the brutal death of Otto Warmbier, a 23-year-old US citizen who was released by North Korea this summer and returned home in a coma, constitutes an act of terrorism.

North Korea was previously designated as a state sponsor of terrorism by President George W. Bush in 2002, but was removed from the list as part of talks aimed at getting the country to stop its nuclear program. However, the country has since continued to develop its nuclear program, testing a missile capable of hitting most of the US on July 28.

The move is unlikely to stop North Korea's nuclear program, as the country has no interest in giving up its nuclear arsenal and is already heavily sanctioned by the US, China, and Europe. The designation may inflict more financial pain on the country, but it is unlikely to achieve the Trump administration's ultimate goal of stopping North Korea's nuclear program.

Title: Green Party Candidate Jill Stein Raises Funds for Recount in Three Key States, Amid Election Integrity Concerns

The Green Party candidate, Jill Stein, has raised over $4 million in just three days to fund a recount in three critical Rust Belt states that narrowly handed Donald Trump the presidency. Stein claims that the election was "hack-riddled" and is seeking to challenge the results. Meanwhile, Republican Governor Pat McCrory in North Carolina is refusing to concede defeat, citing fraudulent votes that gave his opponent, Attorney General Roy Cooper, the win on Election Day.

Election experts have expressed skepticism about the likelihood of the recount changing the outcome, citing a lack of evidence to support the fraud claims. The fact that candidates on both sides are unwilling to accept the results highlights the deep divisions and mistrust surrounding the 2016 election.

Some experts suggest that regularly auditing voting machines could provide safeguards against hacking and improve voter confidence. J. Alex Halderman, director of the University of Michigan Center for Computer Security and Society, emphasized the importance of examining physical evidence in these states, even if it finds nothing amiss, to give voters justified confidence that the results are accurate.

The hacking of the Democratic National Committee and state voter registration systems has raised concerns about the vulnerability of the US voting system. Some experts suggest that the recent hacks of the Democratic Party and state voter registration systems suggest that those keen to disrupt the US system are probing its defenses.

The willingness to invoke the potential of fraud has dovetailed with emerging cyberthreats to ring fresh alarm bells about the US voting system. Suggested reforms include bolder safeguards against insider wrongdoing, more federal funding to upgrade aging voting machines, and automatic paper-trail audits.

Title: Trump Seeks to Rebound in Second Presidential Debate

The second presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton is just around the corner, and Trump's campaign is under pressure to build on the momentum created by his running mate, Mike Pence, who impressed many with his performance in the vice presidential debate. Trump's campaign is reportedly taking a more focused approach to debate preparations, with New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, an early Trump supporter and skilled debater, involved in the process.

However, some Republicans are skeptical about how much ground Trump can make up at this stage. "Now it's up to him," said GOP strategist Matt Mackowiak. "It's like coaching versus playing. Coaches can prepare you and they can have the right play calls. But at the end of the day, the player on the field has to go do it. So far, Trump has fallen short. He really needs to win decisively on Sunday."

Numerous recent polls have shown the scale of the challenge Trump faces. On Wednesday, a new poll from Monmouth University showed him trailing Clinton by 2 percentage points in Ohio, which has been one of the most favorable battleground states for the GOP nominee. Another new survey, from WRAL-TV and Survey USA, showed Trump trailing in North Carolina, also by 2 points. A national poll from Reuters/IPSOS gave Clinton a 6-point edge.

Despite the challenges, some Clinton critics maintain that she could yet be pushed off track by an external event, such as an unforced error or damaging disclosures from an organization like WikiLeaks. However, a WikiLeaks news conference earlier this week failed to live up to the hype that surrounded it, casting doubt on whether the organization can follow through on its threats.

Republicans warn that Trump and his supporters can't depend on a lucky break. The nominee himself needs to wrest back the initiative from Clinton. "Hope is not a strategy," said Mackowiak. "More of the same is not going to change the trajectory of the race. He needs to demonstrate at this next debate that he is prepared to be president — and that he can force Hillary Clinton back on defense."

The second debate will be in a town-hall format, but there is no consensus among insiders as to whether that helps or hinders Trump. Some backers suggest it will make it easier for Trump to feed off the energy of the crowd, while skeptics counter that televised town halls are technically challenging, in terms of tone and body language, and that a small, mostly quiet audience creates a very different atmosphere from the rambunctious rallies where Trump thrives.

What if Trump surpasses expectations and reels in Clinton's lead one more time? "He would be the turnaround master of the decade if he pulls that off," said Boston University professor Tobe Berkovitz.

Title: Trump Grants Clemency to Military Figures Embroiled in War Crimes, Sparking Criticism and Concerns

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has granted clemency to three military figures accused of war crimes, citing the need to give troops "the confidence to fight" without worrying about potential legal overreach. The decision has sparked widespread criticism and concerns about the impact on military discipline and the rule of law.

The President's actions have been met with criticism from both sides, with some arguing that the pardons will undermine military discipline and others saying that the individuals involved were unfairly targeted. The Navy's top official, Richard Spencer, was fired by Defense Secretary Mark Esper, who alleged that Spencer had proposed a deal with the White House behind his back to resolve one of the cases.

The controversy surrounds the cases of Eddie Gallagher, a Navy SEAL accused of war crimes, and two other service members. Gallagher was accused of killing three civilians, including a prisoner, and was found guilty of posing for photos with the corpse of a dead ISIS fighter. The President's decision to grant clemency to Gallagher and the other two service members has been criticized by many, who argue that it sends a message that war crimes will be tolerated.

The President's actions have also been criticized for undermining the military's own system of justice and discipline. The Navy's SEAL team has been shaken by a series of scandals in recent years, prompting Navy officials to take a tougher stance on ethical issues. The President's decision to restore Gallagher to service sends a message that the military will not hold its members accountable for their actions.

The President's actions have also been criticized for undermining the rule of law and the principles that guide the military. The President's decision to pardon the individuals involved has been seen as a betrayal of the values that the military holds dear, and has raised concerns about the impact on the morale of the troops.

In conclusion, the President's decision to grant clemency to the three military figures accused of war crimes has sparked widespread criticism and concerns about the impact on military discipline and the rule of law. The decision has been met with criticism from both sides, with some arguing that it will undermine military discipline and others saying that the individuals involved were unfairly targeted. The controversy highlights the importance of the President's role in upholding the values and principles that guide the military, and the need for accountability and transparency in military decision-making.

Title: Republican Senators Oppose Dismissing Impeachment Charges Against Trump Without Trial

The Republican-led United States Senate is poised to begin an impeachment trial against President Donald Trump in the coming days, with some Republican senators voicing opposition to dismissing the charges against him without a trial. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has vowed to help acquit his fellow Republican, but other Republican senators are taking a different stance.

Senator Roy Blunt stated that there is little interest among Republican senators for a motion to dismiss the House charges, while Senator Mitt Romney said he will not be supporting such a motion. Senator Susan Collins, among a handful of Republicans whom Democrats hope to persuade to back their call for witness testimony, is discussing a trial format that would allow lawmakers to vote on whether to include witnesses after hearing from each side and having the opportunity to pose questions.

The House of Representatives is expected to formally send the charges to the Senate this week, where McConnell has vowed to help acquit Trump. However, some moderate Republicans have expressed discomfort with McConnell's support for the president. The Senate is expected to vote to acquit Trump, requiring a two-thirds majority of those present in the 100-member chamber.

The impeachment charges against Trump, which were passed by the House on December 18, stem from his request that Ukraine investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to face Trump in the November 3 presidential election. The House charged Trump with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

Title: Hillary Clinton Takes Responsibility for Campaign Mistakes, Blames External Factors for Election Loss

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton spoke at the Code Conference in California, acknowledging that she takes responsibility for her campaign's missteps. However, she also argued that external factors, such as media coverage and "weaponized information" from fake news sites, contributed significantly to her unsuccessful election bid.

Clinton emphasized that she takes responsibility for every decision she made during her campaign, but believes that these decisions were not the primary reason for her loss. She specifically criticized media coverage of her private email scandal, which she felt was blown out of proportion and overshadowed other important issues.

"I take responsibility for every decision I made, but that's not why I lost," Clinton said. "Over the summer, we went and told anyone we could find that the Russians were messing with the election, and we were basically shooed away. We couldn't get the press to cover it."

Clinton also pointed to social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter, which she believes have been "victimized by deliberate efforts to shape the conversation and push it towards conspiracies, lies, and false information."

While acknowledging that she was not a "perfect candidate," Clinton expressed her commitment to continuing to be involved in politics, having founded the political action organization "Onward Together" this month. "I'm not going anywhere," she said. "I have a big stake in what's happening to this country."

Title: Google's Algorithm and the Distribution of Relevance and Quality in Media

The debate surrounding Google's algorithm and its impact on the media landscape has sparked a discussion about the relevance and quality of online content. While Google claims to prioritize relevance and high-quality content, critics argue that these metrics may not be equally distributed across the media landscape. This article examines the concept of relevance and quality in the context of mainstream and conservative media outlets.

To evaluate the ranking algorithm, markers of relevance such as timeliness, impact, and keyword density were applied to the work of mainstream media outlets, including The New York Times and Washington Post. These organizations, with their larger staffs and deeper roots in the field, would naturally rank higher. In contrast, conservative publications, such as The Daily Signal and HotAir, have smaller staffs and limited resources, making it challenging for them to compete.

The article also highlights the differences between mainstream and conservative media outlets in terms of their journalistic standards and practices. While mainstream outlets adhere to traditional journalistic values, some conservative outlets may prioritize advocacy over fact-based reporting, peddling conspiracy theories, or engaging in ethically questionable practices.

The power of opaque platforms like Google's algorithm is also discussed, with the company's concept of "relevance" caught in a loop between what people want and what people think it provides. The article concludes that quality is hard to define among journalism experts, and while some indicators of credibility exist, none are airtight. The algorithm can be gamed, and it is far from perfect.

Title: Educating Yourself on Local Police Practices and Advocating for Change

As protests against racism and police violence continue to spread across the United States, it's essential to recognize that change can start at the local level. Every community has a local police department, and residents can take the first step towards creating change by educating themselves about the department's practices. This involves gathering information and support, which can be achieved by shining a light on what the police are doing in the community.

Before starting, it's crucial to acknowledge that others have likely already begun this process. Local black-led activist groups are often at the forefront of this effort, and residents can find out what they're doing and what help they need. It's essential to avoid duplicating efforts and instead, work collaboratively.

To gather information, residents can start by finding out the laws and policies governing police operations in their area. This can be done by searching online or digging deeper. Investigative reporter Andrew Ford suggests asking the department for its policies on specific practices, such as restraining suspects or using pepper spray or Tasers. Residents may also need to request rules set by county or state authorities. Written copies of these policies can be obtained, and if none exist, this may be a topic worth investigating.

Another crucial aspect is understanding the records retention policies, including what records must be kept and for how long. This may include police reports, use-of-force reports, 911 call recordings, and body camera footage. The Reporters' Committee for Freedom of the Press provides a clickable map with body camera policies for many cities and a list of state laws on 911 call recordings to help residents get started.

Residents can also check with their local government to learn how they spend their budget and how much goes towards policing. Then, they can work together with other residents to make their town safer.

For those looking to advocate for Black lives, a list of resources is available. By taking these steps, residents can begin to educate themselves on local police practices and work towards creating positive change in their community.

Title: US Deploys F-22 Stealth Fighters to South Korea Amid Heightened Tensions with North Korea

The United States has deployed two F-22 stealth fighter jets to South Korea to participate in ongoing military exercises with Seoul, following North Korea's warning that the Korean Peninsula has entered a "state of war." The Pentagon confirmed the deployment of the F-22 Raptors to Osan Air Base in South Korea from Japan on Sunday, as part of the air component of the Foal Eagle exercise.

The exercise has been planned for some time and is part of the ongoing military drills between the US and South Korea. Meanwhile, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un gathered legislators for an annual spring parliamentary session, which followed a ruling party declaration that nuclear bomb building and a stronger economy were the nation's top priorities.

The meeting of the Supreme People's Assembly comes amid near-daily threats from Pyongyang, including vows of nuclear strikes on South Korea and the US. The US military in South Korea urged North Korea to restrain itself, stating that "North Korea will achieve nothing by threats or provocations, which will only further isolate North Korea and undermine international efforts to ensure peace and stability in Northeast Asia."

North Korea has threatened to shut down a border factory complex that is the last major symbol of inter-Korean cooperation, according to the Associated Press. The threats are seen as part of an effort to provoke the new government in Seoul to change its policies toward Pyongyang and to win diplomatic talks with Washington in order to gain more aid.

The White House has stated that the US is taking North Korea's threats seriously, but has also noted Pyongyang's history of "bellicose rhetoric." The US military has also revealed that two B-2 stealth bombers dropped dummy munitions on an uninhabited South Korean island as part of annual defense drills, which Pyongyang sees as rehearsals for invasion. Hours later, Kim ordered his generals to put rockets on standby and threatened to strike American targets if provoked.

Military analysts have said a full-scale conflict between North and South Korea is extremely unlikely, noting that the Korean Peninsula has remained in a technical state of war for 60 years. However, the North's continued threats toward South Korea and the US have raised worries that a misjudgment between the sides could lead to a clash. In addition to the military exercise, the US will fortify its defenses against a potential North Korean missile attack by adding more than a dozen missile interceptors to the 26 already in place at Fort Greely, Alaska, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has announced.

Title: Apple Unveils New Wearable Products, Raises Questions on Privacy and Security

Apple has launched new products focused on mobile payments and health and fitness, emphasizing the importance of trust and security. The company's CEO, Tim Cook, introduced Apple Pay, a mobile payment system that could revolutionize the decades-old credit card system. The system uses Near Field Communications and Touch ID technology to complete transactions, ensuring that credit card numbers and other sensitive information are not stored or shared.

The Apple Watch, which comes in three styles and various colors, allows users to track their fitness and health, including their heartbeat and mileage. The device's sensors can detect flat and elevated surfaces, set goals, and reward fitness milestones. Apple's lead designer, Jony Ive, emphasized the personal nature of the device, stating, "You can share something as personal as your own heartbeat."

The Apple Watch is part of the company's efforts to redefine the market for "wearables," devices that track fitness and health. Apple sees the potential for wearables to become an integral part of the U.S. healthcare system, with the company estimating that the payment business could generate $12 billion daily and over $4 trillion annually.

However, concerns about privacy and security have been raised, particularly in light of the recent celebrity hacking scandal. Apple claims that its iCloud was not hacked, but rather thieves individually hacked victims' personal ID passwords. The company emphasizes that it does not store credit card numbers, collect retail transaction information, or share data with anyone.

The Apple Watch, when combined with the HealthKit app, raises unique privacy concerns. The HealthKit app allows consumers to track their health and fitness information, which could be shared with healthcare providers and researchers. Apple has banned developers from storing HealthKit data in iCloud, and the company has strict guidelines for data sharing.

Apple's entry into the health and fitness market is significant, with the company partnering with organizations like the Mayo Clinic, Cleveland Clinic, and Epic Systems. The company aims to make a significant impact in the $2.7 trillion American healthcare industry, which spends hundreds of billions on health IT.

According to Morgan Reed, executive director of the Association for Competitive Technology, "eHealth is going to be huge, and Apple wants a piece of that." While Apple's new products have raised concerns about privacy and security, the company's emphasis on trust and security may help alleviate some concerns.

Title: Ferguson Unrest: Officials Criticize Response to Violence, Questions Raised Over Police Tactics

Ferguson, Missouri, witnessed violent clashes on Monday, with reports of 21 fires, at least 150 gunshots, and damage to 10 police cruisers. The unrest followed a news conference held by James Knowles III, the mayor of Ferguson, who criticized the state's response to the situation. Rob Chabot, the owner of Mobile Eye Care Solutions, expressed frustration, stating, "They abandoned us completely. For what cause? I don't know."

The police reported that over 60 people were arrested, with most being Missouri residents. The arrests were made on various charges, including second-degree burglary and arson. The police response was criticized by some, who felt it was too tame, while others defended the approach taken by Chief Jon Belmar of the St. Louis County Police.

Chief Belmar explained that the initial, hands-off tactics were intended to allow protesters to demonstrate peacefully, but the situation ultimately grew so unstable that a more forceful approach was required. He acknowledged that the magnitude of the violence was beyond their control and that they had not foreseen the chaos that unfolded. Despite months of preparation and training, and a buildup of manpower, equipment, and technology, the police were unable to prevent the destruction of property and the arrest of individuals.

The situation in Ferguson has been marked by controversy and unrest since the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in August. The police response to the latest violence has raised questions about the effectiveness of their tactics and whether they were adequately prepared to handle the situation.

Title: FTC Issues Orders to Five Tech Giants to Disclose Small Mergers

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has issued special orders to five major technology companies - Alphabet Inc's Google unit, Amazon.com Inc, Apple Inc, Facebook Inc, and Microsoft Corp - to provide information on mergers that were too small to report to antitrust regulators. The FTC's queries come at a time when the Justice Department, state attorneys general, and the House Judiciary Committee are investigating the big tech platforms for potential anti-competitive behavior.

The FTC has asked the companies to identify transactions that were done between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2019, and to provide information about deals that were not subject to antitrust notification. The agency plans to use the information obtained in this study to examine trends in acquisitions and the structure of deals, including whether acquisitions not subject to antitrust notification might have raised competitive concerns.

The tech giants have come under scrutiny from both sides of the political spectrum, with Republicans and Democrats expressing concerns about the impact of their mergers and acquisitions on the market. Senator Elizabeth Warren, a presidential candidate, has called for federal regulators to undo "anti-competitive mergers," including Amazon's purchases of Whole Foods and Zappos, Facebook's purchase of WhatsApp and Instagram, and Google's acquisitions of Waze, Nest, and DoubleClick.

The companies have made various acquisitions over the years, with Alphabet spending $1 billion on an unspecified number of small acquisitions in 2019, mostly in the areas of artificial intelligence research and cloud computing services. Apple has made small deals valued at less than $500 million over the past decade, snapping up companies working on key technologies such as augmented reality displays, camera sensors, and artificial intelligence software. Microsoft made 19 small acquisitions for a total of $1.6 billion in fiscal 2019, mostly in cash, and has sought to consolidate its position in the business software market with major acquisitions such as LinkedIn and GitHub.

FTC Chairman Joe Simons declined to rule out an enforcement action based on the results of the study, stating that "all options are on the table." The companies have not commented on the matter.

Title: US Vice-President Reaffirms Commitment to Baltic States' Security Amid Rising Tensions with Russia

The US Vice-President, Mike Pence, has reiterated Washington's commitment to the security of the Baltic states, emphasizing that an attack on any of the three countries would be considered an attack on all NATO allies. Pence made the statement during a visit to Estonia, where he met with the presidents of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.

The remarks come amid growing tensions between the US and Russia, which has ordered a significant reduction in the number of US diplomatic staff in Russia in response to new US sanctions imposed over Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election.

Pence emphasized that the US stands firmly behind its Article 5 pledge of mutual defense, which guarantees that an attack on one NATO member is considered an attack on all. He also warned that Russia continues to pose a significant threat to international security, seeking to redraw borders by force, undermine democracies, and divide European nations.

The US Vice-President's visit to the region comes as Russia prepares to hold large-scale military exercises with its ally Belarus in the coming month. The exercises have raised concerns among NATO allies, particularly the Baltic states, which have grown increasingly wary of Russian aggression since the annexation of Crimea.

Pence's visit to the region is seen as a show of support for the Baltic states, which achieved independence from the Soviet Union in 1991. The US Vice-President is scheduled to attend joint military exercises with Georgia, a country that fought a war with Russia in 2008 and seeks to join NATO. He will also visit Montenegro, NATO's newest member.

The US and Russia have been engaged in a diplomatic standoff over the past few months, with both sides imposing sanctions on each other. The US has imposed sanctions on Russia over its annexation of Crimea and alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election, while Russia has ordered a significant reduction in the number of US diplomatic staff in Russia in response.

Title: Jussie Smollett Arrested and Charged with Filing False Police Report

Jussie Smollett, a 36-year-old actor known for his role in the TV show "Empire," was arrested and charged with filing a false police report in Chicago. The actor had previously claimed that he was the victim of a homophobic and racist physical attack in January, but police now suspect that he paid two Nigerian brothers, Ola and Abel Osundairo, to stage the incident.

According to reports, the brothers, who are also extras on "Empire," had been held for nearly 48 hours after returning to the US and providing information that "shifted the trajectory of the investigation." They were released without charges, but their testimony has led to the charges against Smollett.

The investigation began to raise suspicions after police were unable to find any video footage of the alleged incident from surveillance cameras, and there were no witnesses. However, investigators were able to track down the Osundairo brothers, who had left the US after the alleged attack and returned last week.

The brothers, who are Smollett's personal trainer and extra on "Empire," chose to cooperate with the investigation and provide information that led to the charges against Smollett. Their lawyer, Gloria Schmidt, said they decided to come forward because "there was a point where this story needed to be told" and "they manned up and said, 'You know what? We're going to correct this.'"

Smollett turned himself in early on Thursday and is currently being held at the Cook County Jail. He faces felony charges for disorderly conduct and filing a false police report, which carries a maximum sentence of three years in prison and may also require him to reimburse the police for the cost of their three-week-long investigation.

Smollett's legal team has released a statement saying that the actor is innocent and that the investigation has been marred by leaks of false information. The actor had previously claimed that he was attacked by two white men who hurled racial and homophobic insults at him, punched him, poured a chemical substance over him, and put a rope around his neck. He also claimed that the attackers told him "this is Maga country," apparently referring to President Donald Trump's "Make America Great Again" slogan.

Title: Newspapers Unite Against Trump's Criticism, Promote Freedom of the Press

The Boston Globe coordinated an effort among over 300 newspapers across the United States to publish editorials promoting freedom of the press, in response to President Trump's repeated criticism of the media. The initiative, which included large newspapers like the New York Times and small local publications, encouraged editorial boards to participate regardless of their political point of view.

The principle of a free press has protected journalists and served as a model for free nations abroad, according to the Globe's editorial board. The board noted that 48% of Republicans and 29% of Americans overall agree with Trump that the news media is the enemy of the people. However, 43% of Republicans and 26% of Americans believe the president should be able to close news outlets for bad behavior.

Editorial boards around the country added their own words on Thursday, emphasizing the importance of a free press in building democracy. The Tampa Bay Times wrote that a free press builds the foundation for democracy, providing citizens with honest and independent media for accurate information about their government, elected leaders, and institutions.

The Sun-Times emphasized the importance of a free press in holding authority accountable and promoting fairness and equality. The newspaper encouraged readers to subscribe to their local papers and to praise or criticize them when necessary.

In response to the editorials, President Trump took to Twitter, calling the media "the opposition party" and claiming that they are "very bad for our Great Country." He also referenced the sale of the Boston Globe to the New York Times, stating that the Globe is now in "collusion" with other papers on free press.

The initiative highlights the ongoing debate over the role of the media in American society and the importance of protecting a free press.

Title: Americans Divided on Political Discourse: Trump's Impact and What's Acceptable

A recent survey has shed light on Americans' attitudes towards the tone and nature of political debate in the United States. The survey, which examined the impact of President Donald Trump's rhetoric, found that large majorities of Americans believe the political discourse has become more negative, less respectful, and less focused on issues.

According to the survey, 85% of U.S. adults believe the political debate has become more negative, while 76% say it has become less fact-based and 60% say it has become less focused on issues. The survey also found that 55% of Americans believe Trump has changed the tone and nature of political debate for the worse, while 24% say he has changed it for the better.

The survey also explored what Americans consider acceptable language for elected officials to use in political debates. The results showed that majorities of Americans agree that it is fine for an elected official to say their opponent is uninformed on the issues, but 41% say it is never acceptable to say their opponent is anti-American. The partisan divide was evident, with 25% of Republicans saying it is never acceptable to accuse an opponent of being anti-American, compared to 53% of Democrats.

The survey also found that Americans broadly agree that elected officials should avoid using heated language, with 73% saying it could encourage violence. While majorities in both parties agree on this, the view is more widely held among Democrats (83%) than Republicans (61%).

The survey also touched on the national climate for political discourse, with Republicans believing that Democrats are more comfortable expressing their political views than Republicans. The sense of an unequal environment for political expression was most pronounced among conservative Republicans and Republican leaners.

Finally, the survey explored Americans' views on what constitutes racist or sexist language, with 61% saying people generally do not agree on what is considered racist language. The survey found that Black people are more likely to say people agree on what is considered racist language, while whites and Hispanics are more likely to say people do not agree.

Overall, the survey highlights the complexities and divisions surrounding political discourse in the United States, with Americans holding different views on what is acceptable language for elected officials and the national climate for political expression.

**Trump Escalates Trade War with China, Threatens Tariffs on $200 Billion Worth of Goods**

Washington (AP) - In a move that sent financial markets reeling, US President Donald Trump escalated the trade war with China, threatening to impose tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods. The announcement came as a Chinese delegation was set to resume talks in Washington on Wednesday aimed at resolving the trade dispute.

According to Trump's tweet, the tariffs would be a "pure win" for the US and a "loss" for China. However, experts dispute this claim, stating that the costs of tariffs are borne by American consumers and businesses, not China.

A study by economists from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Columbia University, and Princeton University found that by the end of last year, the public and US companies were paying $3 billion a month in higher taxes and absorbing $1.4 billion a month in lost efficiency. The study concluded that the burden of Trump's tariffs on imports from China and other countries falls entirely on US consumers and businesses.

A coalition of US trade organizations representing retail businesses, tech, manufacturing, and agriculture also disputed Trump's statement, saying that Americans have been paying the full cost of the trade war, not China. "To be clear, tariffs are taxes that Americans pay, and this sudden increase with little notice will only punish US farmers, businesses, and consumers," the coalition said.

Trump has also made false claims about the US trade deficit and hurricane aid to Puerto Rico. He tweeted that the US has been paying tariffs to China, which is not true, and that Puerto Rico has received $91 billion in hurricane aid, which is also incorrect. According to the White House, actual aid to Puerto Rico has been around $11 billion, with an additional $50 billion in expected future disaster disbursements that could span decades.

The stock market dropped in response to Trump's tweet, as investors reacted to the potential economic implications of the tariffs. The trade war between the US and China has already had a significant impact on the global economy, and the latest escalation has raised concerns about the potential consequences for businesses and consumers.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Pledges Cooperation in Ongoing Scandal Investigation

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie delivered his annual State of the State address, which took on national interest due to ongoing investigations into the use of Superstorm Sandy relief funds and allegations of political retribution. Christie emphasized bipartisan efforts and cooperation, acknowledging mistakes made by his administration and promising to work with federal auditors to ensure similar breaches of trust do not happen again.

The governor's speech focused on the successes of his first term, including job creation and economic growth, and outlined new proposals for education reforms and programs to help drug offenders rejoin society. However, the controversy surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closures and allegations of political retribution remained a prominent topic.

Christie accepted responsibility for the mistakes made by his administration, stating that "mistakes were clearly made, and as a result, we let down the people we are entrusted to serve." He pledged cooperation with all appropriate inquiries and emphasized that the scandal does not define the state or its people.

The controversy surrounds allegations that Christie's staff orchestrated traffic gridlock near the George Washington Bridge to punish a Democratic mayor for not endorsing his re-election. The New Jersey State Assembly committee investigating the matter has released over 2,000 pages of documents suggesting politics was behind the lane closures, and Christie has repeatedly apologized for being "blindsided" by what his aides and appointees were doing.

Federal officials are also investigating whether Christie improperly used Superstorm Sandy relief funds to produce tourism ads promoting the Jersey shore's recovery, which starred him and his family. The investigation has the potential to be more damaging to Christie's national image since it was his signature achievement following the storm.

Despite the controversy, Christie's speech received applause from the audience, with some lawmakers standing and applauding during his address. The governor's office has denied any wrongdoing and has cooperated with the ongoing investigations.

Title: North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un Reappears, Ending Rumors of Illness or Deposition

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has reemerged after a six-week absence, putting to rest rumors of his grave illness, deposition, or worse. The leader was seen smiling broadly and using a walking stick while touring the newly built Wisong Scientists Residential District and another new institute in Pyongyang, as part of his regular "field guidance" tours. The exact date of the visit was not disclosed, nor did the North address Kim's health.

Kim's reappearance has allowed the country's massive propaganda apparatus to continue glorifying the third generation of Kim family rule. The event will also likely tamp down, at least for the moment, rampant rumors of a coup and serious health problems.

Before Tuesday, Kim missed several high-profile events he normally attends and was described in an official documentary as experiencing "discomfort." Archive footage from August showed him overweight and limping, prompting speculation that he had undergone surgery on his ankles or was suffering from gout or diabetes.

According to a South Korean analyst, Kim likely broke his media silence to dispel outside speculation that he was not in control and to win sympathy from a domestic audience by creating the image of a leader who works through pain. The appearance may be a form of "emotional politics" meant to appeal to the North Korean people's sympathy.

It was the first time a North Korean leader has been seen relying on a cane or crutch, with Kim's father, Kim Jong Il, reportedly suffering a stroke in 2008 before dying of a heart attack in late 2011. Kim's grandfather, Kim Il Sung, was never seen with a walking stick.

Kim appears to have lost around 22 pounds compared to pictures from May, with some speculating that he may have had surgery on his left ankle. The South Korean government has seen no signals of any major problems, and the recent absence was likely an attention-getting device to quell rumors and keep him in the public eye.

The reappearance has put North Korea back on the front page, with the country on a diplomatic offensive in Europe and elsewhere, and feeling isolated from Washington.

Title: Romney Outlines Tax Reform Plan, Proposes "Choose-Your-Own-Deduction" Approach

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, has begun to provide more details about his tax reform plan, which aims to cut taxes by 20% while keeping the plan deficit-neutral. In an interview with a Fox affiliate, Romney described a "choose-your-own-deduction" approach, where taxpayers can fill up a $17,000 "bucket" with the deductions they want. Higher-income individuals might have a lower number, he said.

Romney's campaign aide later clarified that the $17,000 cap could change and that the tax rate cut could be offset by putting a dollar cap on personal exemptions and reducing health care tax preferences. The campaign has not provided a specific estimate of the 20% rate cut's cost, but a separate source suggested it could cost up to $1.7 trillion over 10 years.

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney for not providing enough details about his plan, saying he has not explained how he would pay for his massive new tax cut for the wealthiest Americans. Romney's proposal may provide some clarity on this issue, but it remains to be seen how his plan will be received by voters.

The debate between Romney and President Obama is set to take place on Wednesday night, with both campaigns managing expectations and trying to gain an edge. Romney's campaign has been aggressive in the hours leading up to the debate, seizing on a comment by Vice President Biden that the middle class has been "buried" over the last four years. The Obama campaign has called this a "desperate and out-of-context attack."

The debate is a high-stakes event, with both candidates having a lot to gain or lose. Romney has been slipping in key battleground states, and the debate is a chance for him to close the gap. The Obama campaign has laid out real and achievable goals for the next four years, and Romney will need to provide more details on his proposals to move forward.

Title: Facebook Overhauls Privacy Tools to Make it Easier for Users to Find and Edit Personal Information

Facebook has announced a revamp of its privacy tools, aimed at making it easier for users to find and edit the personal information the company holds. The move comes after intense criticism following the revelation that data about 50 million users was harvested and passed on to a political consultancy.

The overhaul was already planned ahead of the scandal to comply with new EU rules, specifically the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into effect on May 25. The new law toughens the requirements on how organizations handle public data and imposes harsher penalties for breaches.

The updated privacy settings menu will regroup controls and add descriptions to make it clearer what each involves. A new "simplified" settings menu will bring together the most critical controls into a single place, making it faster for users to review posts they have shared or reacted to and limit the information used to target ads at them.

Additionally, a revised data download and edit tool will allow users to review past interactions with the site, including "liked" posts and comments, with the option to make deletions. Users will also be able to download specific categories of data, such as photos, from a selected time range.

Facebook's chief privacy officer, Erin Egan, acknowledged the damage caused by the Cambridge Analytica scandal and emphasized the need for the company to do more to help people understand how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data.

The move is seen as a step in the right direction, but some critics argue that Facebook should be more proactive in warning users about the data they are sharing. The company has lost significant market value since the Cambridge Analytica scandal, with around $80 billion wiped off its market value since March.

Facebook has also faced criticism from New Zealand's privacy watchdog, which accused the company of breaking the law by refusing to provide data about a dispute involving one of its citizens. The company responded by saying it was protecting the privacy of several individuals and did not have to comply with the commissioner's request.

Title: Supreme Court Denies Request to Block Texas Abortion Restrictions

The United States Supreme Court has declined to block Texas' controversial abortion restrictions, which have been deemed some of the strictest in the country. The court's 5-4 vote denied a request by Planned Parenthood to block a ruling by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, allowing key parts of the Texas abortion law to remain in effect while the lawsuit challenging the restrictions moves forward.

The law, which was signed into effect in October 2013, requires doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital. The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals acknowledged that this provision may increase the cost of accessing an abortion provider and decrease the number of physicians available to perform abortions. However, the panel concluded that the U.S. Supreme Court has held that having an "incidental effect" on the availability of abortion services is not enough to invalidate a law that serves a valid purpose.

As a result, at least 12 clinics in Texas have stopped performing abortions since the ruling. A spokeswoman for the Texas Attorney General's Office expressed satisfaction with the Supreme Court's decision, stating that the regulations are "commonsense and perfectly constitutional" and further the state's interest in protecting the health and safety of Texas women.

Texas Governor Rick Perry also welcomed the decision, saying it is "good news both for the unborn and for the women of Texas, who are now better protected from shoddy abortion providers operating in dangerous conditions."

The appeals court's decision is temporary and will be reviewed in a complete hearing, likely in January. The restrictions have been the subject of controversy since their passage, with Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis launching a nearly 13-hour filibuster against them in June. The law also bans abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy and requires doctors to perform all abortions in surgical facilities.

During the trial, officials for one chain of abortion clinics testified that they have tried to obtain admitting privileges for their doctors at 32 hospitals, but so far, only 15 have accepted applications and none have announced a decision. Many hospitals with religious affiliations will not allow abortion doctors to work there, while others fear protests if they provide privileges.

Title: China's Official COVID-19 Numbers Raise Questions Amid Global Pandemic

The number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the United States and other countries continues to rise, while China, the source of the pandemic, has reported a significant decline in new cases. However, the accuracy of China's official figures has been questioned due to the country's history of secrecy and cover-ups. Despite this, Western media organizations, the World Health Organization, and the United Nations have referred to China's numbers as "confirmed cases," giving the impression that the country has largely contained the virus.

The National Health Commission of China, responsible for tracking statistics during the crisis, has been publishing daily updates since late January. According to the commission, the number of cases skyrocketed from 1,287 to 17,205 in just over a week. The commission also reported that over 5 million people had left Wuhan due to the Spring Festival and the epidemic, which raised concerns about the virus spreading rapidly across the country.

However, against all odds, the National Health Commission reported no new domestically acquired cases, attributing every new case to those returning to China. Over the last half of March, despite the massive dispersion of Chinese citizens from Wuhan, the commission reported barely one new domestically acquired case per day. As of mid-March, 683,281 people had been identified as having had close contact with infected patients, with 9,144 under medical observation.

The United Nations published an article titled "China shows COVID-19 coronavirus can be'stopped in its tracks,'" based on an interview with a WHO representative in China, Dr. Gauden Galea. Dr. Galea stated that the data and observations suggest that the epidemic has been nipped in the bud and stopped in its tracks. However, critics have questioned the accuracy of China's numbers, citing the country's history of secrecy and cover-ups.

Various media organizations have relied on China's numbers for dramatic headlines, including the New York Times, Axios, and NPR. However, the accuracy of these reports has been called into question, as China's numbers have been incomplete and may not reflect the true extent of the outbreak.

Recently, the Wall Street Journal reported that China's numbers have indeed been incomplete, stating that over 1,500 people who were infected with the virus but hadn't shown symptoms were not included in the national tally of confirmed cases. This raises further questions about China's transparency, especially in light of the drastic measures the Communist government took early on to hush up the extent and seriousness of the epidemic.

In conclusion, while China's official COVID-19 numbers have raised concerns about the accuracy of the data, the media and international health authorities should approach any information coming from China with a more skeptical eye.

Title: Governors Weigh in on Marijuana Legalization

Four governors from the United States, two Republicans and two Democrats, have shared their stance on legalizing recreational marijuana. During an appearance on CNN's "State of the Union," Texas Governor Rick Perry, a Republican, was the first to express his opposition to legalization. Perry, who is considering a 2016 presidential bid, believes that current policies have helped decrease the prison population in Texas and favors lowering penalties for marijuana use.

Indiana Governor Mike Pence, also a Republican, echoed Perry's sentiments, stating that he does not support legalization. "That's been my position for a long time and will continue to be," Pence said.

Connecticut Governor Dan Malloy, a Democrat, has taken a more nuanced approach. While his state has decriminalized small amounts of marijuana and has moved forward with medical marijuana, Malloy believes that legalization is not the next step. "I think that's about as far as we go," he said. Malloy emphasized that taxes should not be used as an incentive to legalize marijuana.

Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, also a Democrat, indicated that his state is not heading towards pot legalization, but some in his state are starting to open up about medical marijuana. "I think our legislature might consider that, but I think to move beyond that at this point is a bridge too far," Nixon said.

The governors' comments come as Colorado and Washington have legalized recreational marijuana, with Colorado seeing a surge in tax revenues from marijuana sales. However, the governors' opinions on the matter remain divided, with some seeing the potential benefits of legalization and others expressing concerns about the potential consequences.

Title: Obama Predicts Republican Alienation of Latino Community as Reason for Potential Victory

The Romney campaign has accused President Obama of taking the Hispanic community "for granted" after a previously off-record interview was published, showing the president predicting that if he wins a second term, it will be because Republicans "alienated" Latinos. The president made the comment during a 30-minute conversation with the Des Moines Register's editorial board, which was initially kept off the record. The Obama campaign released the transcript after the editor complained that the president's team had "handcuffed" the newspaper by insisting it be kept off record.

In the interview, Obama made two pledges for a second term, stating his confidence that Washington can strike a "grand bargain" deal on deficit reduction and immigration reform next year. He also took a swing at Republicans on the latter issue, saying that if he wins a second term, it will be because the Republican nominee and the Republican Party have "alienated" the fastest-growing demographic group in the country, the Latino community.

The Romney campaign responded by casting doubt on the president's editorial board comments, pointing to Obama's failure to pass comprehensive immigration reform despite pledges in 2008 to do so. "It's a fascinating glimpse into how President Obama has taken the Hispanic community for granted for the past four years," said spokesman Alberto Martinez. "He's caught making secret promises to an editorial board in Iowa, which also happens to be a promise he made in 2008, a promise he failed to keep, and a promise he doesn't repeat publicly. The whole episode underscores why millions of Hispanics are deeply disappointed with President Obama."

The rest of the Des Moines Register interview was focused on policy issues, with Obama discussing his plans for the economy, education, and energy development while vigorously defending his term to date. At one point, Obama also told the editors he has "absolutely" no regrets that he didn't more forcefully pursue measures focused on the economy at the time he was pushing for the health care overhaul.

Title: US Job Growth Slows in May, Unemployment Rate Hits 16-Year Low

The US labor market showed signs of slowing down in May, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 138,000 jobs, lower than the 185,000 jobs economists had forecast. The unemployment rate fell to 4.3%, its lowest level since May 2001, but this was largely due to 429,000 people dropping out of the labor force.

The manufacturing, government, and retail sectors lost jobs, while construction payrolls rose 11,000. Average hourly earnings rose 4 cents or 0.2% in May, leaving the year-on-year increase in wages at 2.5%.

The job market has been slowing down in recent months, with job growth averaging 181,000 per month over the past 12 months. This has led some economists to believe that the labor market is nearing full employment. However, the jobless rate has declined five-tenths of a percentage point this year, and the labor force participation rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point to 62.7%.

The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates at its June 13-14 policy meeting, despite the modest job growth. The economy needs to create 75,000 to 100,000 jobs per month to keep up with growth in the working-age population.

The job market has been affected by political uncertainty, with companies struggling to find qualified workers and holding off on hiring amid worries about the impact of political scandals on the economy. The labor market is also facing challenges from the widening trade deficit and declining retail sales.

Title: Republican Ted Cruz Faces High-Stakes Test in Indiana Primary

The Indiana primary on Tuesday presents a crucial test for Republican Ted Cruz's slumping presidential campaign, one of the last opportunities for the Texas senator to halt Donald Trump's march toward the GOP nomination. Cruz has spent the past week campaigning in Indiana, securing the support of the state's governor and announcing Carly Fiorina as his running mate. However, his aides were pessimistic heading into Tuesday's voting and were prepared for Cruz to fall short, although the senator vowed to stay in the race regardless of the results.

Trump has devoted more time to campaigning in Indiana than he has to most other states, underscoring his eagerness to put his Republican rival away and shift his attention toward Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton. While Trump cannot clinch the nomination with a big win in Indiana, his path would become easier and he would have more room for error in the campaign's final contests.

Republican leaders had initially dismissed Trump as an entertainer who would fade once voting started, but Republican primary voters have stuck with the billionaire businessman, handing him victories in every region of the country, including a string of six straight wins on the East Coast.

In the Democratic primary, Hillary Clinton and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders will face off in Indiana, although the stakes are lower than in the Republican race. Clinton holds a commanding lead over Sanders, securing 91% of the delegates needed to win the nomination. This means she can still win the nomination even if she loses every remaining contest.

Sanders has conceded that he faces a difficult path to overtake Clinton, which hinges on convincing superdelegates to back him over the former secretary of state. Superdelegates are Democratic Party insiders who can support the candidate of their choice, regardless of how their states vote. And they favor Clinton by a nearly 18-1 margin.

Neither Clinton nor Sanders planned to spend Tuesday in Indiana, with Sanders making stops in Kentucky, which holds a primary in mid-May, and Clinton moving on to Ohio, a key general election battleground. Clinton's team has started deploying staff to states crucial in November and is also raising money for the fall campaign. Even as Trump hires more staff to round out his slim team, he already lags far behind Clinton in general election preparations.

A showdown between Clinton and Trump would pit one of Democrats' most popular and highly-regarded figures against a first-time political candidate who is deeply divisive within his own party. Cruz and other Republicans have argued that Trump would be roundly defeated in the general election, denying their party the White House for a third straight term. However, Trump is the only Republican left in the race who can secure the 1,237 delegates needed for the nomination through regular primary voting.

Title: Dueling Reports on Benghazi Attacks Fail to Provide Clear Answers

The investigation into the 2012 attacks on a diplomatic outpost and CIA annex in Benghazi, Libya, remains shrouded in controversy as Democrats and Republicans release competing and contradictory reports. The assault, which claimed the lives of four Americans, including US Ambassador Chris Stevens, has been the subject of a two-year investigation by a House panel staffed by members of both parties.

The primary objective of the investigation has been to examine the actions of senior US military and civilian officials, including former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, to determine whether they could have done more to prevent the loss of life. The Democratic report, released on Monday, absolves the US military and Clinton of any wrongdoing, stating that the US military could not have done anything differently on the night of the attacks to save the lives of the four Americans who perished.

The report also notes that the State Department's security measures were "woefully inadequate," but that Clinton never personally turned down a request for additional security. In contrast, the Republican report, released on Tuesday, accuses the Obama administration of being slow to send help to the Americans in Benghazi due to an "obsession with hurting the Libyans' feelings."

The Republican report also criticizes Clinton for her role in the incident, labeling Benghazi as the "wild east." The report states that eyewitnesses remained in constant contact with officials in Washington during the attack, but none mentioned a protest. A redacted portion of the report claims that a witness to the attack updated officials in Washington every 15 to 30 minutes throughout the night.

The White House and the investigating panel are at odds over whether President Obama should answer questions already submitted by the panel for his consideration. The White House has refused to comment on the reports, while the investigating panel has accused the administration of misleading the public over the incident and failing to protect US personnel.

The dueling reports have already had political repercussions for presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Clinton, with the Benghazi investigation uncovering her use of a private email server to conduct government business, now the subject of an FBI investigation. The Democratic report states that the cause of the attacks "remains unclear to this day," quoting testimony by former CIA Director David Petraeus, who said, "To be candid with you, I am not sure that the amount of scrutiny spent on this has been in the least bit worth it."

Title: Obama Administration Issues Directive on Transgender Students' Access to Bathrooms and Locker Rooms

The Obama administration has issued a directive to public schools, obliging them to allow transgender students to use bathrooms and locker rooms that match their chosen gender identity, even if their education records or identity documents indicate a different sex. The directive, formulated by the Education and Justice Departments, is intended to clarify how school districts receiving federal funding can comply with Title IX, which protects individuals from discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities that receive federal financial assistance.

According to the directive, schools are obligated to treat students according to their chosen gender identity, and there is no obligation for students to present a medical diagnosis for the change. The Human Rights Campaign, a civil rights organization for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals, commended the move, stating that it sends a message that every student deserves to be treated fairly and supported by their teachers and schools.

The directive comes at a time when transgender individuals are gaining visibility across the social and cultural landscape, prompting a societal debate over the definition of gender identity. The debate has come to a head in North Carolina, where the state is locked in a legal battle with the federal government over its bathroom bill, HB2. The Justice Department sued North Carolina over HB2, saying it is discriminatory, and advised the state to confirm it would not be moving ahead with the legislation. North Carolina responded with a countersuit, saying the state was given an unrealistic amount of time to comply with the federally-imposed compliance deadline.

Attorney General Loretta Lynch stated that the directive is about "dignity and respect for our fellow citizens." The Obama administration's stance on transgender students' access to bathrooms and locker rooms is a significant step towards ensuring that all students are treated with respect and dignity, regardless of their gender identity.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli Challenges Court Ruling on Anti-Sodomy Law

Article:

Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli has filed a petition to challenge a recent court ruling that declared Virginia's anti-sodomy law unconstitutional. The law, which bans oral and anal sex, was deemed a violation of the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit. The case in question involved a 47-year-old man, William Scott MacDonald, who was convicted of soliciting a minor to commit a felony.

Cuccinelli's office is seeking a full 15-judge court review of the panel's decision, citing concerns about the protection of a 17-year-old girl from a 47-year-old sexual predator. Cuccinelli's spokeswoman, Caroline Gibson, stated that the case is not about sexual orientation but about using current law to protect children from predators.

The case has sparked controversy, with LGBT advocates expressing disappointment and accusing Cuccinelli of trying to re-criminalize sexual behavior between consenting adults. However, Cuccinelli's position is focused on upholding the conviction of a man who solicited a sexual act from a minor, not on targeting gay rights.

The Attorney General's office is siding with the dissenting judge, Albert Diaz, who argued for deference to the Virginia Court of Appeals. The case has also drawn attention from gubernatorial candidate Terry McAuliffe, who has criticized Cuccinelli's decision as "divisive" and "ideological."

The article notes that Cuccinelli's position has nothing to do with consenting adults or gay rights, but rather about protecting a minor from a sexual predator. The article also highlights the economic achievements of Virginia under Governor Bob McDonnell, who inherited a 7.2% unemployment rate and budget deficits from his Democratic predecessor and has transformed the state into one of the nation's most business-friendly climates.

The article concludes by noting that Cuccinelli's campaign will need to be careful in explaining his position to voters, as the optics of fighting to uphold a sodomy law in the midst of a national debate over gay rights could be damaging.

Title: Obama Urges Optimism Amidst Tensions, Calls for Action on Gun Violence

President Barack Obama has urged Americans to remain optimistic about race relations in the United States, despite the recent tragic events in Dallas, where five police officers were killed by a gunman. Speaking in Warsaw, Poland, Obama emphasized that the actions of a few individuals should not define the entire nation.

The President also announced the revival of a task force formed after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, which resulted in weeks of violent protests. The task force will include police officers, community and civil rights activists, and others to discuss next steps.

Obama acknowledged that violent crime in the United States has decreased over the past five, 10, and 15 years, but emphasized that there is still work to be done. He renewed his commitment to stopping gun violence, stating that it is essential to make it harder for people to carry out their anger with weapons.

The President also addressed the recent sniper attack in Dallas, calling the perpetrator, Micah Johnson, a "demented individual." He emphasized that Johnson's actions do not represent the views of all Americans, saying, "They don't speak for all of us. That's not who we are."

Obama declined to label the Dallas sniper attack as a hate crime, citing the difficulty in interpreting the shooter's motives. He expressed sympathy for police officers in gun-filled communities, who have "very little margin of error" when deciding how to engage with people on the street.

The President also touched on the topic of personal safety, stating that violent crime is actually down in the United States. He emphasized the importance of addressing the gun issue, saying, "If you care about the safety of our police officers, then you can't set aside the gun issue and pretend it's irrelevant."

In other topics, Obama discussed the recent Brexit vote in the United Kingdom, the threat posed by the Islamic State group, and the importance of the United States' partnership with European countries to eliminate terrorist threats. He also expressed his commitment to ensuring a smooth transition for the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union.

Title: Romney's Presidential Campaign Surpasses Obama's in May Fund-Raising

The Mitt Romney presidential campaign raised more than $76.8 million in May, surpassing President Barack Obama's campaign by nearly $17 million. This marks the first full month that Romney and the Republican National Committee were in partnership, resulting in a significant increase in fund-raising compared to the previous month. The Romney campaign and the Republican National Committee ended May with $107 million in cash.

According to Romney's national finance chairman, Spencer Zwick, the surge in fund-raising is a sign that voters are making an investment in the campaign because they believe it will benefit the country. The campaign's statement emphasized that the average donation was over $50.

In comparison, Obama's campaign announced that it raised $60 million in May, with the average donation being over $50. The $60 million includes money raised directly by the campaign and the Democratic National Committee. The campaign and committee raised $43.6 million in April, about the same amount as Romney raised that month.

Aides to Obama said they were not particularly concerned about the fund-raising numbers, citing the fact that some Republican donors may have given the maximum they could in May and will not be able to give again in the coming months. However, the financial comparisons underscore the concern that Obama's campaign has expressed about the need for stepped-up financial contributions.

The article also notes that Obama's campaign held a fund-raiser with Hollywood celebrities, including George Clooney, in early May, which reportedly raised $15 million for the campaign. The event was seen as a success, as it boosted fund-raising among wealthy members of the gay community, who had been concerned about Obama's public support for same-sex marriage.

Title: Falling Gas Prices: A Mixed Bag for the Economy

The recent decline in gasoline prices has brought relief to many consumers, with the average cost per gallon dipping to around $3. However, some economists are sounding the alarm, warning that this downward trend could be a sign of deflation, a phenomenon last seen during the Great Depression of the 1930s.

Deflation occurs when prices fall across the board, causing a vicious cycle of reduced spending, lower production, and a broader economic downturn. Economists consider deflation to be a nightmare scenario, as it can lead to a plunge in the value of businesses, homes, and investments.

The current downward pressure on prices is largely attributed to weak growth in Europe and China, which has led to a decrease in global demand for energy and goods. Central bankers and policymakers are working to stimulate growth and keep prices from falling further.

For most Americans, the benefits of low inflation are evident. Wages and prices are not moving much, and interest rates remain low. The drop in energy prices has boosted consumer purchasing power, making it easier to buy a car and fill it up with cheap gas. Many are applauding the pleasures of low inflation, as it can stimulate the economy by increasing travel and consumer spending.

However, some experts warn that the deflationary winds blowing from Europe could lead to a broader economic downturn. The Federal Reserve, which sets interest rates, wants to see the inflation rate hold steady at 2 percent. If prices continue to fall, the Fed may be hesitant to raise interest rates, potentially slowing economic growth.

For individuals like Macy Gould, a recent college graduate from Lexington, Kentucky, the benefits of low inflation are clear. She was thrilled to refuel for $2.83 a gallon and is now hoping to revive a driving trip to St. Louis that was previously unaffordable. While the current economic landscape is a mixed bag, many are enjoying the benefits of low inflation, at least for now.

Title: Obama Warns Congress: No Negotiations on Debt Ceiling, Says Washington Must Pay Its Bills

Article:

President Barack Obama reiterated his stance on Monday, stating that he will not negotiate over the debt ceiling, calling it "absurd" and "irresponsible" to do so. The president emphasized that the debt ceiling is a necessary measure to ensure the government pays its bills, and that the country is not a "deadbeat nation."

During his press conference, Obama also discussed his plans to address gun violence in the wake of the recent mass shooting in Newtown, Connecticut. He reiterated his promise to take action to prevent such tragedies, stating, "If there is a step we can take that will save even one child from what happened in Newtown, we should take that step."

The president also touched on the National Rifle Association's (NRA) stance on gun control, suggesting that the organization is using fear tactics to mobilize gun owners against federal gun control measures. In response, an NRA spokesperson, Andrew Arulanandam, stated that the president should speak with gun buyers to understand their motivations.

Regarding the debt ceiling, Obama emphasized that raising the limit does not authorize new spending, but rather pays for bills that have already been incurred. He urged Congress to pass a clean bill to increase the debt ceiling, without tying it to spending cuts.
