The agency has recognized that an undue proliferation of bargaining units can cause unnecessary work stoppages and is inconsistent with the long-term goals of collective bargaining. In the past, the NLRB has proposed rules to make a single facility unit presumptively appropriate and has cautioned against an undue proliferation of bargaining units.

Congress has also expressed concerns over the potential impact of micro-unions on job creation and industry stability. During debates over expanding the NLRB's jurisdiction to include non-profit health care institutions, Congress cautioned the agency against an undue proliferation of bargaining units that could cause unnecessary work stoppages and threaten patient care.

Labor boards in other countries, such as Canada, also recognize the dangers of micro-unions and seek to avoid them. The Ontario Labor Relations Board, for example, has stated that the proliferation of bargaining units is not normally conducive to collective bargaining stability.

The NLRB's decision has been criticized for its potential impact on job creation and industry stability. The agency's political leadership has been accused of prioritizing union interests over those of workers and businesses, leading to uncertainty and a chill on job creation.

Title: President Obama Discusses Challenges and Future of Obamacare

President Barack Obama recently spoke with The New York Times, sharing his thoughts on the current state of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. Despite acknowledging that public opinion remains divided, Obama expressed confidence that the law will eventually gain popularity once it is implemented and its benefits become apparent.

According to Obama, the key to winning over public opinion lies not in public relations efforts, but in the law's effectiveness. He believes that as people sign up for insurance and experience the benefits firsthand, they will come to appreciate the ACA. The President cited the increased security and access to preventive care as reasons why people with existing insurance will not be negatively impacted.

In the interview, Obama acknowledged the challenges the ACA faces, including being "outspent four to one" and the uncertainty surrounding its implications. He emphasized that the test of the law's success will be its ability to work and provide benefits to those who need them.

The President's comments come as the ACA continues to face criticism and controversy. While some argue that the law's penalties and requirements will not be worth the benefits, Obama remains optimistic about its potential to improve healthcare outcomes and increase access to care.

The article does not provide further information on the specific details of the ACA or its implementation, as the focus is on the President's views and opinions on the matter.

Title: Early Data Suggests ObamaCare Sign-Ups Mostly Comprise Already Insured Individuals

The majority of the over 2 million Americans who signed up for health insurance under ObamaCare through the end of December were already enrolled in employer-sponsored plans or had previously purchased their own coverage, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. Early data from insurers, brokers, and consultants suggests that the marketplaces are popular among consumers who were previously covered elsewhere, raising questions about the law's intent to expand coverage to millions of healthy, uninsured Americans.

A survey by McKinsey & Co. found that only 11% of consumers who purchased new coverage under ObamaCare were previously uninsured. The survey, based on a sampling of 4,563 consumers between November and January, suggests that the majority of sign-ups are comprised of individuals who were already insured.

HealthMarkets Inc., an insurance agency that signed up about 7,500 people in exchange plans, reported that 65% of its enrollees had prior coverage. Fifteen percent of enrollees had their individual plans canceled, and 40% switched over from previous individual plans.

Some insurers, such as Cigna, had expected a higher number of newly insured consumers. David M. Cordani, Cigna's chief executive, stated, "One of the intents of the law was to address the uninsured problem in our country." However, early data on newly insured consumers is falling short of expectations.

Insurers in Michigan, for example, expected 400,000 of the state's 1.2 million uninsured people to join private plans this year. As of the end of December, only 76,000 people had signed up, many of whom were previously covered.

Federal health officials have not yet released the number of people who have signed up for coverage through the exchanges who had insurance when they enrolled. Consumers have until the end of March 31 to purchase plans under ObamaCare.

According to Aaron Albright, a spokesman for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, "We are in the middle of a sustained six-month open-enrollment period, and we have seen a strong interest in the product overall across the range of demographics so far. We are ramping up outreach activities so that more Americans learn how they can now benefit from affordable health insurance."

The data also shows that adults aged 55-64 were the most heavily represented in the sign-ups, accounting for 33% of the total. Nationwide, premiums paid by people in this demographic do not fully cover their medical expenses. Some are in the waiting room for Medicare, which starts at age 65. Young adults from 18 to 34 are only 24% of total enrollment, according to the Obama administration's first signup figures broken down by age, gender, and other details. Enrolling young and healthy people is important because they generally pay more into the system than they take out, subsidizing older adults.

Title: Democrats Push for Gun Control and Mental Health Reform After Connecticut School Shooting

Article:

Following the devastating school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut, which left 20 children and six adults dead, Democratic lawmakers and Independent Senator Joe Lieberman are calling for a ban on military-style assault weapons and a review of the nation's approach to mental health. The discussion on gun control has been a hot topic in the past, with a 10-year ban on assault weapons enacted in the early 1990s. However, since the ban expired in 2004, few Americans have pushed for stricter laws, and politicians have been hesitant to take on the powerful gun lobby.

Senator Joe Manchin, a lifelong member of the National Rifle Association, has broken ranks with his fellow gun rights advocates, stating that it is time to discuss gun policy and move towards action on gun regulation. Manchin agrees with New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who has advocated for banning the sale of assault weapons.

President Barack Obama has vowed to use his executive powers to engage citizens, law enforcement, mental health professionals, parents, and educators in an effort to prevent future tragedies. He has also emphasized the need to address the issue of mental illness, asking whether the nation is prepared to say that it is powerless in the face of such violence.

Senator Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., believes the nation may be at a tipping point, where it can finally get something done on gun control. He and other Democrats, including Lieberman, want to ban the sale of new assault weapons and make it harder for mentally ill individuals to obtain weapons. Lieberman suggests creating a new commission to examine gun laws, the mental health system, and violence in movies and video games.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., plans to introduce legislation next year to ban new assault weapons, as well as large clips, drums, and strips of more than 10 bullets. Bloomberg believes Obama can use executive powers to enforce existing gun laws and support legislation like Feinstein's.

Gun rights activists have been largely silent on the issue since the shooting, with only one representative, Rep. Louie Gohmert, R-Texas, appearing on Sunday talk shows. Gohmert defended the sale of assault weapons and suggested that the principal at Sandy Hook Elementary School should have been armed.

A study by the California-based Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence found that seven of the 10 states with the strongest gun laws are also among the 10 states with the lowest gun death rates. Gun-control advocates argue that this proves that stricter gun laws do not lead to increased crime rates.

The debate on gun control and mental health reform is ongoing, with both sides presenting their arguments. As the nation mourns the loss of innocent lives, it remains to be seen what actions will be taken to prevent future tragedies.

Title: Deadly Shooting at San Diego Synagogue: Rabbi Credits Congregation's Heroism and "Miracle" for Stopping Attack

A devastating shooting occurred at the Chabad of Poway synagogue in San Diego, California, over the weekend, leaving one fatality and injuring three others. The youngest victim was eight-year-old Noya Duhan, who had recently moved from southern Israel with her family. The deceased victim was 60-year-old Laurie Kaye, who reportedly stepped in front of the rabbi to stop the accused gunman, identified as 19-year-old John T. Earnest.

Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein, who was present during the attack, described the incident as "unfathomable" and credited the heroism of his congregation members for risking their lives to stop the shooter. He also attributed the attack's limited damage to a "miracle" – the shooter's gun jamming.

According to authorities, Earnest was arrested about a mile from the synagogue after being chased by an off-duty border patrol agent, Oscar Stewart, who opened fire as Earnest drove away. The agent's actions are believed to have prevented further harm.

In an online letter, Earnest expressed his desire to kill Jews and praised the gunmen responsible for the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting and recent mosque attacks in New Zealand. He was also being investigated in connection to an arson attack at a California mosque.

President Trump condemned the attack and offered his condolences to Rabbi Goldstein. The World Jewish Congress criticized the New York Times for publishing a cartoon in its international edition showing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu leading a blind President Trump, which they deemed to contain anti-Semitic tropes. The New York Times subsequently retracted the cartoon and issued an apology.

Experts, such as Michael Rydelnik, an expert on anti-Semitism at the Moody Bible Institute, described anti-Semitism as a "contagious disease" that can resurface and spread quickly. Earnest has been charged with murder and will likely face federal hate crime charges.

Title: Democrats Seek to Clarify Their Position on Border Security Amid Shutdown Debate

The Democratic Party is facing pressure to articulate its stance on border security, as the ongoing government shutdown has allowed President Trump to dominate the debate. Representative Ro Khanna, a Democrat from California, emphasized the need for Democrats to show that they support border security, but not the president's vision for a wall. The issue was discussed during a Democratic caucus meeting, where lawmakers were briefed on Speaker Nancy Pelosi's latest criticism of Trump's shutdown tactics.

Pelosi had requested that Trump delay or cancel his State of the Union address due to the security measures required for federal workers working without pay. Trump responded by preventing Pelosi from taking a military plane, revealing her itinerary, which was previously kept secret for security reasons. Pelosi accused Trump of not understanding the importance of keeping such information confidential, citing his inexperience.

After Pelosi made alternative travel arrangements to fly commercially, people close to Trump revealed her plans to reporters, prompting Pelosi to cancel the trip due to concerns about safety. A White House official denied any wrongdoing, claiming that it was impossible for Pelosi to keep her trip a secret and that any suggestion of a leak is a lie.

The controversy highlights the ongoing struggle for Democrats to articulate their position on border security, as they face criticism for not being clear about their stance. Representative Khanna emphasized the need for Democrats to show that they support border security, but not the president's vision for a wall. The debate is expected to continue as the government shutdown persists.

Title: Obama to Meet with Mexican President to Discuss Border Security and Immigration

Article:

United States President Barack Obama will meet with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto at the White House on Tuesday to discuss ways to prevent more migrants from crossing the U.S.-Mexico border in search of a free pass. The meeting will focus on Mr. Obama's immigration action and border security, with a senior administration official stating that the agenda will include finding ways to "avoid a renewed surge of migrants this year and to minimize the number of people who undertake this dangerous trip."

The official also noted that illegal immigrants already in the U.S. who try to aid their relatives in sneaking across the border will not be eligible for Mr. Obama's new deportation amnesty. Mexican consulates will play a key role in informing Mexican immigrants about who qualifies and who does not qualify for executive actions.

Homeland Security and State Department officials are teaming up on a campaign to dissuade would-be illegal immigrants. Even before Mr. Obama announced his action on November 20, tens of thousands of illegal child immigrants had surged into the U.S. last year, many motivated by the belief that they would be allowed to stay.

Mexican officials say Mr. Pena will thank Mr. Obama for taking the executive action, as illegal immigrants from Mexico account for two-thirds of those who are eligible for deportation relief under Mr. Obama's action. The administration official stated that the U.S. has made "tremendous progress" in strengthening the border with Mexico, and that Mr. Pena has been an "important partner" in helping to stem the flow of illegal child immigrants last year.

The administration official also noted that the number of illegal immigrants entering the country is at a historic low, with the last time the number was this low being in the 1970s. Moreover, this is the first time in 40 years that the size of the unauthorized population living in the United States has stopped growing. President Obama is committed to continuing this progress.

The two leaders are also likely to discuss other security issues, including the embattled Mexican president facing street protests over his handling of the massacre of 43 students who were abducted in September by a drug gang working with corrupt police in the city of Iguala. Drug wars could also be on the agenda.

Human Rights Watch urged Mr. Obama in a letter to press his Mexican counterpart to investigate and prosecute abuses by Mexican security forces. The U.S. has provided Mexico more than $2 billion since 2007 through the Merida Initiative to fight organized crime.

The White House said that the two leaders will highlight the importance of expanding dialogue and cooperation between the United States and Mexico on economic, security, and social issues, as well as underscoring the deep cultural ties and friendship that exist between the two countries.

Title: Obama's Deft Hand with Speech, But Not with Congress?

The article discusses President Obama's State of the Union speech, which was delivered in a context of low expectations and a challenging political environment. Despite the president's approval ratings being underwater, he managed to deliver a confident and brisk address, focusing on issues such as income inequality and immigration reform. The speech was seen as a success, with the president avoiding some of the more contentious issues, such as the National Security Agency scandal and deportations.

The article notes that the president's speech was not a "powerhouse" hand, but rather a "gamer" who played the cards he was dealt well. The author suggests that the president's ability to adapt and be nimble in his presentation was a key factor in his success. However, the article also notes that the president's ability to deal with Congress, the federal bureaucracy, and other power centers has been a challenge throughout his presidency.

The article concludes that the president's new staff appointments, including senior adviser John Podesta, may help him extend his talent for presentation to produce more successes in policymaking.

Title: Amber Guyger Found Guilty of Murder in Death of Botham Jean

Amber Guyger, a former Dallas police officer, was found guilty of murder on October 1, 2019, in the death of 26-year-old Botham Jean. The verdict was delivered by a jury after a trial that began on September 23, 2019. Guyger was accused of shooting Jean on September 6, 2018, in his own apartment, which was directly above hers.

The case centered around the "Castle Doctrine," which allows for the use of deadly force when someone feels threatened in their own home. Guyger claimed she mistakenly entered Jean's apartment, thinking it was her own, and shot him because she believed he was an intruder. The defense argued that Guyger made a tragic but honest mistake, while prosecutors contended that she acted rashly and failed to follow proper protocol.

The jury deliberated for several hours before delivering the guilty verdict. Guyger was initially charged with manslaughter, but the charge was upgraded to murder after a review by the district attorney's office. The trial was marked by emotional testimony from both sides, with Guyger breaking down in tears as she took the stand.

The verdict was met with relief and joy from Jean's family, who had been advocating for justice in the case. Attorney Ben Crump, who represented the Jean family, praised the decision, saying it was a victory for unarmed black and brown people in America. Jean's mother was overcome with emotion, exclaiming "God is good. Trust him" as cheers erupted outside the courtroom.

Guyger remained standing until the jury left the courtroom, then fell into her chair, reportedly shaken by the verdict. The case has sparked widespread attention and debate, with many calling for police accountability and an end to systemic racism.

Title: Dallas Jury Convicts Former Police Officer of Murder in Wrongful Shooting Death of Botham Jean

A Dallas jury has convicted former police officer Amber Guyger of murder for shooting and killing 26-year-old Botham Jean in his own apartment in 2019. The verdict comes after Guyger, who was off-duty at the time, entered the wrong apartment and shot Jean, who was eating ice cream on his couch. The jury's decision is significant, as it rejects the "Castle Doctrine" defense, which allows officers to use force to protect themselves and their property, even if they are the ones who are trespassing.

The Castle Doctrine, which is not a formal legal doctrine but rather a colloquial term, has been used to justify police shootings in many cases. However, in this instance, the jury recognized that Guyger had no right to shoot Jean, who was in his own home and posed no threat to her. The verdict is a rare example of a jury holding a police officer accountable for their actions, and it sends a message that officers are not above the law.

The case highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the risks involved in lawful encounters between police and civilians. While it is essential to recognize the dangers faced by police officers, it is equally important to ensure that they are held to the same standards as the general public. The verdict in this case is a step in the right direction, as it acknowledges that officers are not entitled to a special exemption from accountability simply because they are in uniform.

The case has sparked a wider conversation about the need for police reform and the importance of holding officers accountable for their actions. It is a reminder that even those in positions of authority must be held to the highest standards of behavior and that justice must be served, regardless of the perpetrator's profession.

Title: Democratic Operative Arrested for Alleged Assault on Nevada GOP Gubernatorial Campaign Manager

A Democratic operative, Wilfred Michael Stark III, was arrested by the Las Vegas City Marshals on Tuesday evening and remains in custody in the Las Vegas city jail. The arrest stems from an altercation involving Stark, who allegedly grabbed and yanked the arm of Kristin Davison, the female campaign manager for Nevada GOP gubernatorial nominee Adam Laxalt, and refused to let go.

According to the Laxalt campaign and local law enforcement, the incident occurred after a campaign event in East Las Vegas on Tuesday evening. Davison, 31, claimed that Stark, 50, burst into the room where she and Laxalt were talking with a camera, and became physical, pushing her and other staff members, and screaming.

Davison stated that Stark grabbed her right arm, bruising her neck and arms, and held her for several minutes, saying "I was scared and screaming'stop—you're hurting me'." The Laxalt campaign described the incident as "assaulting the female campaign manager of the opposing campaign, which is disgusting and has no place in our system."

This is not Stark's first arrest; he was previously arrested for allegedly assaulting the female press secretary for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke earlier this year. Stark also has a record of arrests while working for American Bridge, a group founded by David Brock and funded by liberal billionaire George Soros.

The incident has sparked concerns about the level of aggression and violence in politics, with the Laxalt campaign stating that "assaulting the female campaign manager of the opposing campaign is disgusting and has no place in our system." The incident has also raised questions about the role of American Bridge and its operatives in the political process.

It is unclear whether Stark was on the job for American Bridge during the confrontation, but he works for the group, listing himself as a reporter for them on his LinkedIn page. The group's largest donor is liberal billionaire George Soros, who donated more than $2 million between 2015 and 2016.

Title: Judge Kavanaugh and Dr. Blasey Prepare to Testify in Senate Hearing

Article:

Judge Brett Kavanaugh and Dr. Christine Blasey Ford are set to testify in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee, with both sides preparing to make their cases about the allegations of sexual assault. In his prepared remarks, Judge Kavanaugh plans to acknowledge that he drank excessively in high school and made mistakes, but maintain his innocence. He will tell the committee that his past mistakes are not comparable to the serious allegations made against him.

Dr. Blasey, on the other hand, has expressed her reluctance to come forward, stating that she is "terrified" and only doing so because she believes it is her civic duty to share her story. She will tell senators that she knew Judge Kavanaugh and his friend group during her freshman and sophomore years of high school, and that their friend groups intersected, making it possible for her to identify him as her assailant.

The release of handwritten calendar notations from Judge Kavanaugh's high school days and affidavits from Dr. Blasey's friends and husband have added to the growing pile of evidence and testimony in the case. A polygraph test administered in August indicated no deception on Dr. Blasey's part. As the hearing approaches, allies of both Judge Kavanaugh and Dr. Blasey have assembled letters attesting to their integrity, while protesters are preparing for rallies and threats have flooded the phone lines and inboxes of key players in the drama.

Title: Fox News Anchor Debunks Uranium Scandal, Sparks Outrage Among Conservative Viewers

Article:

Fox News anchor Shepard Smith has sparked controversy by debunking the so-called "Hillary Clinton uranium scandal" on Tuesday evening. The segment, which aired on the network, presented a detailed analysis of the allegations made by a journalist for the right-wing news website Breitbart and repeated by President Donald Trump during the 2016 election campaign.

Smith's report highlighted the inaccuracies in the original accusations, which claimed that Hillary Clinton, as Secretary of State, approved the sale of a Canadian company with uranium mining interests in Wyoming to the Russian nuclear agency, Rosatom, in exchange for $140 million in donations to the Clinton Foundation. The allegations were used by Trump to attack Clinton during the campaign, with chants of "Lock her up" becoming a rallying cry for his supporters.

Smith's segment presented a detailed timeline of the events, pointing out that the deal required approval from a committee formed by the heads of nine federal government agencies, including the State Department, and that Barack Obama was involved in the process due to the national security implications of Russia holding US uranium interests. The report also noted that the State Department stated that Clinton did not intervene to approve the deal and did not have the power to approve or block it.

The anchor also highlighted that none of the uranium mined in Wyoming was exported to Russia and that the majority of the donations to the Clinton Foundation were made by a man who had already sold his stake in the uranium company in 2007, years before the Russian deal went through and about 18 months before Clinton became Secretary of State.

The segment sparked outrage among some Fox News viewers, with one Twitter user posting, "Get Shepard Smith off of Fox. He's arrogant and doing his own spin. Nobody knows how deep the left's conspiracy goes and Shepherd Smith has ZERO inside info because nobody trusts him. OUT!" Another user tweeted, "Fox News reports on Uranium One. Shepard Smith uses detailed facts & graphs to explain why there is no reason to investigate. It is a false controversy meant to draw our attention from real issues within the Trump administration."

The segment was met with criticism from some viewers who felt that Smith was going against the grain of other stories reported by Fox News and against the political bent of many viewers. However, the report presented a comprehensive analysis of the allegations and provided detailed information to support its claims.

Title: Virginia Seeks Funding for Health Insurance Navigators, Filling Gaps in Federal Support

The Virginia Department of Insurance has requested $495,000 in funding to support the state's health insurance navigators, which would cover the equivalent of seven and a half full-time navigators, computers, equipment, informational materials, marketing, and outreach events in five counties. This funding would help individuals understand and enroll in health plans through the new insurance markets.

The federal government has allocated $54 million for navigators in 34 states, which is significantly less than the initial plan, as it was assumed that most states would build their own health insurance markets. To fill the gaps, other organizations will also be working to educate the uninsured and help them sign up for health plans. Community health centers, which provide medical care for the uninsured, have received $150 million in federal funding to support outreach and enrollment efforts. Virginia's health centers received $2.5 million.

In addition to navigators, insurance agents, brokers, and insurance companies selling plans through the markets will also play a role in helping people sign up for coverage. Local organizations, such as Northern Virginia Family Service, plan to enlist partner organizations to help with outreach and enrollment or provide resources.

Christine Barber, a senior policy analyst at Community Catalyst, notes that many local groups may have funding or volunteers to help with outreach and enrollment efforts. "Everyone is anxious to know who the navigators are so that other groups can partner with them, know who to refer people to, know how to flesh out their coalitions and their outreach," she said.

Navigators will receive at least 20 hours of training and take a certification test. They will not recommend any particular health plan or receive compensation from an insurance company.

Title: Candidates Focus on Energizing Base Voters, Ignoring Undecideds

The 2012 presidential election has taken a sharp turn, with both candidates shifting their focus from persuading undecided voters to energizing their respective bases. President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are now engaging in a series of harsh exchanges, with the president mocking his rival's character and Romney accusing Obama of waging a "campaign of division and anger and hate."

The shift in strategy is a response to the dwindling number of undecided voters. According to recent polls, only 5% of voters in six swing states are still undecided, and only about 1 in 10 likely voters who have chosen a candidate say they are open to switching. This has led strategists in both parties to conclude that the traditional balance between motivating core supporters and persuading independents is no longer relevant.

The Romney campaign is attempting to expand its support among Republicans who are eager to see Obama defeated, while the Obama campaign is trying to capture moderate voters who are dissatisfied with the direction of the country. The election has become a referendum on the choice of approaches to the economy, Medicare, and the role of government, rather than a simple referendum on Obama's economic record.

The Romney campaign has selected Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, as its running mate, which has drawn praise from conservatives and helped Romney become a stronger and more confident campaigner. However, some Republicans are worried that the focus on the economy has overshadowed other important issues, and that the debate over Medicare could be a risk for other candidates in the party.

The outcome of the election remains uncertain, with some voters like Iowa resident John Brooks saying his mind was made up before Obama's surprise visit to his table at a local restaurant. The question remains: will a surge of conservative enthusiasm for the Republican ticket outweigh any potential falloff among voters who supported Obama in 2008 and are open to changing their minds this year?

Title: Rep. Michael Grimm Indicted on Over 20 Charges, Including Tax Fraud and Hiring Illegal Immigrants

Article:

U.S. prosecutors have indicted Rep. Michael Grimm, a former FBI agent and current congressman, on over 20 charges related to his ownership of a health food restaurant, Healthalicious, which he operated from 2007 to 2010. The indictment alleges that Grimm hid over $1 million in revenue from the IRS by paying employees, including illegal immigrant workers, in cash.

The indictment accuses Grimm of wire fraud, perjury, and obstruction of justice, among other charges. According to the indictment, Grimm paid some employees exclusively in cash and others partly in cash and partly through checks. The payroll processing companies working with Grimm would only see the payments given by check, and these were the only payments reported to various entities, including his accountant, the IRS, the State of New York, and health insurance companies.

Grimm allegedly hid $1.3 million in profits by not reporting them to the IRS and other entities. This allowed him to avoid paying federal and state taxes, as well as workers' compensation insurance and health insurance coverage for employees. The indictment also alleges that Grimm hired illegal immigrants, who were paid exclusively in cash.

The indictment further accuses Grimm of committing wire fraud by sending a manager the true profits of the restaurant and salaries of employees through an AOL account, and lying under oath during a deposition for a lawsuit brought by former employees of Healthalicious.

Grimm's attorney, William McGinley, has denied the allegations, calling the government's actions a "politically driven vendetta against Congressman Grimm and not an independent search for the truth."

The indictment has raised concerns about Grimm's political career, with watchdog groups like Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington calling for his immediate resignation.

**Senate Fails to Repeal Obamacare, Trump's Healthcare Agenda in Jeopardy**

The Republican-led Senate failed to pass a bill to repeal key elements of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, on Friday, dealing a significant blow to President Donald Trump's healthcare agenda. The bill, which aimed to dismantle the healthcare law, was defeated 51-49, with Senator John McCain casting the deciding vote.

The failure of the bill has raised questions about the Republican Party's ability to govern, as they control the White House, Senate, and House of Representatives. The bill's defeat also marks a major setback for Trump, who had promised to repeal and replace Obamacare during his presidential campaign.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell acknowledged the failure, saying it was time to move on to other legislative priorities. House Speaker Paul Ryan, however, urged fellow Republicans not to give up on healthcare, citing other pressing issues like tax-cut legislation.

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law by former President Barack Obama in 2010, has provided health insurance to 20 million people and driven the percentage of uninsured individuals to historic lows. The law's failure to repeal has left health insurers uncertain about the future of the program, with the administration's hostility towards it.

The Blue Cross Blue Shield Association has pledged to work towards a smooth open enrollment period and stabilize the individual insurance market under Obamacare. Shares of health insurers and hospitals were up on the news, as the prospects for big cuts in the Medicaid insurance program for the poor and disabled dwindled.

The failure of the bill has also raised concerns about the Republican Party's ability to deliver on their campaign promises, particularly among their conservative base. The 2018 congressional elections are now seen as a key test of the party's ability to govern.

Title: States Take Cautious Approach on Immigration Amid Changing Political Currents and Court Decisions

The immigration debate may be intensifying in Washington, but the fervor of the crackdown on illegal immigration that swept the country two years ago has given way to a more cautious approach in the states. Gone are the days of broad "omnibus" bills, such as Arizona's 2011 law that imposed state criminal penalties for illegal immigration. Instead, it's immigrant-rights groups that are now on the offensive, passing laws granting in-state college tuition rates to illegal immigrants in Colorado and driver's licenses to illegal immigrants in Illinois.

According to Arturo Vargas, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials, the shift is partly due to the impact of the Latino vote in the 2012 elections. "Most of these pieces of legislation had been supported by Republican legislators, and I think people are thinking twice about whether this is a strategy the party wants to pursue," Vargas said.

Just two years ago, the momentum was on the other side. Congress was stalemated, leaving conservative states to push ahead with their own laws intended to get a handle on illegal immigration. Arizona pioneered a law requiring all businesses to use the government's voluntary electronic worker verification system, followed by similar laws in South Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, and Indiana. The Supreme Court upheld the worker verification law in 2011 and last year issued a major ruling allowing police checks to continue, though it struck down the state criminal penalties for illegal immigration.

Now, many states are waiting to see what the courts and Congress will do next. Ann Morse, who runs the National Conference of State Legislatures' immigrant policy project, said interest in immigration is still high at the state level, but there are no longer the big omnibus bills. Some states are debating new verification requirements for state services or for voting.

However, where there is clear momentum, it appears to be on the immigrant-advocacy side. Colorado's General Assembly passed a bill earlier this month granting illegal immigrants in-state tuition rates to state colleges, and lawmakers there introduced another bill to repeal a 2006 law requiring police to cooperate with federal immigration agents. Other states have moved to grant driver's licenses to the young adult illegal immigrants granted tentative legal status by President Obama last year.

Some Republican attorneys general, such as Colorado's John W. Suthers, are calling for Washington to take the lead on immigration reform. "We have to look to the federal government to take the charge on immigration reform," Suthers said. "The Arizona case and others are kind of mapping out what the states can do and what the federal government has to do."

However, Kris Kobach, the secretary of state in Kansas and a leading architect of Arizona's crackdown law, said he still sees an appetite to act. "I don't think the atmosphere in the state legislatures has changed at all," he said. "I think what we saw in 2011 and 2012 was the states that were the low-hanging fruit were already primed and ready to do something active. They've already taken steps, and are happy with those steps, and other states are moving to follow them."

Kobach said the president's move to grant legal status to illegal immigrant young adults last year was confusing for states, creating chaos about what other benefits they should be entitled to. "The Obama administration, through its illegal executive amnesty, is trying to have it both ways," Kobach said. "They recognize that they have no power to grant lawful immigration status to illegal aliens, yet at the same time they are trying to tell the states to go ahead and give these illegal aliens driver's licenses."

Given the president's moves and the debate in Congress, state lawmakers who want to see a crackdown realize that the states are their only avenues for action. "The events since the start of the year have made it clear to state leaders that the only serious efforts to enforce the law are going to be at the state level," Kobach said.

Title: Senate Democrats End Filibuster, Agree to Hold Votes on Gun Control Measures

The US Senate ended a marathon Democratic filibuster on Thursday morning, with Senator Chris Murphy yielding the floor after more than 14 hours. The filibuster, led by Murphy and several colleagues, was aimed at pushing for tighter gun control measures in the wake of the Orlando nightclub massacre. According to Murphy, a deal was struck with Republican leaders to hold votes on amendments to expand background checks and ban gun sales to suspected terrorists.

The filibuster, which began on Wednesday afternoon, saw senators from both parties take to the floor to argue for legislation. Murphy, a Connecticut Democrat, led the effort, citing the devastating impact of gun violence on his state, particularly the 2012 Newtown school shooting. He called for the Senate to take action, stating that "there are 30,000 people dying" annually in the country.

The filibuster was supported by several Democratic senators, including Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and Cory Booker of New Jersey, who stayed with Murphy on the floor for most of the debate. The effort was also backed by gun control activists and advocacy groups, such as Everytown for Gun Safety.

The election-year fight over gun control pits strong proponents of the second amendment right to bear arms against those arguing for greater restrictions on the ability to obtain weapons. The National Rifle Association (NRA) has endorsed Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who has stated he will meet with the organization to discuss the terror watchlist and gun purchases.

The Senate is expected to hold votes on the proposed amendments, which would expand background checks and ban gun sales to suspected terrorists. The legislation is a response to the Orlando shooting, which killed 49 people and injured 53 others. The shooter, Omar Mateen, was added to a government watchlist of individuals known or suspected of being involved in terrorist activities in 2013, but was removed from the list 10 months later.

The NRA has expressed support for a bill from Texas Senator John Cornyn that would let the government delay firearms sales to suspected terrorists for up to 72 hours, while Democrats argue that this would deny due process to individuals who may be on the list erroneously.

Title: Trump Administration Exempts Keystone XL Pipeline from "Buy American" Executive Order

The Trump administration has decided to exempt the Keystone XL pipeline from its executive order requiring new pipelines to use American steel "to the maximum extent possible." The decision was made due to the pipeline already being under construction, with White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders stating that it does not count as a new, retrofitted, repaired, or expanded pipeline.

The Keystone XL pipeline, which was first proposed in 2008, has been a contentious issue, with the Obama administration rejecting the project in 2015 due to environmental concerns. However, the Trump administration revived the project in January, and its decision to exempt it from the "Buy American" executive order is seen as a win for business-friendly ideas and a pragmatic approach.

Some see the decision as a triumph of open economies over populist calls to "buy American and hire American." Forbes contributor Tim Worstall, a senior fellow at the Adam Smith Institute, wrote that the value of a pipeline is that it can be used, and if American steel is the best option, then use it, but if not, use another option. He emphasized that what matters is the overall cost of the project, not the nationality of the steel.

The Keystone XL pipeline is expected to add $5.7 billion to the economies of Oklahoma and Texas while the southern leg of the pipeline was under construction, according to the Institute for Energy Research. The project's construction was initially threatened by Trump's populist program, but the administration's decision to exempt it from the executive order has cleared the way for its completion.

The decision may also be seen as a temporary demonstration of pragmatism rather than a shift in course, as the administration emphasized that American steel will be a feature of future pipelines. The Canadian government welcomed the decision, calling it a "recognition that the integrated Canadian and US steel industries are mutually beneficial."

Title: Layoffs and Job Cuts Continue Amid Economic Uncertainty

The private sector has responded to President Obama's statement that the economy is "doing fine" with a wave of layoffs and job cuts. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, employers issued 1,316 "mass layoff actions" in September, affecting over 122,000 workers. Many of these layoffs are attributed to the slowest period of earnings growth since the third quarter of 2009.

Some companies, such as Dana Holding Corp., are citing the burden of increasing taxes on small businesses and regulatory schemes as a reason for their layoffs. The company's CEO, Roger Wood, specifically mentioned the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as a major factor in their decision. The ACA will cost Dana Holding Corp. approximately $24 million over the next six years in additional healthcare expenses.

Other companies, such as Consol Energy, are facing layoffs due to regulatory delays and permit issues. The company's CEO, Robert E. Murray, has blamed the Obama administration's anti-coal agenda for the layoffs and closure of his company's mine.

The medical device industry is also feeling the impact of Obamacare. Companies such as Stryker, Covidien, and Zoll Medical Corp. are slashing jobs and reducing costs due to the impending 2.3% medical device excise tax. This tax is expected to cost these companies millions of dollars annually.

Several executives, including those from Koch Industries, Westgate Resorts, and ASG Software Solutions, have spoken out about the negative impact of Obama's economic policies on their businesses. However, left-wing groups have criticized these executives for exercising their political free speech.

The article also mentions the administration's attempt to silence companies that disclosed the impact of Obamacare on their bottom lines and the administration's promise to cover the legal fees of defense contractors who delayed layoffs before the election.

Title: Common Core Supporters Vow to Revamp Campaign Amidst Waning Public Support

Article:

Common Core, a set of academic standards aimed at elevating math, reading, and writing instruction across the nation, has faced a challenging week. Two recent national polls have found the public growing increasingly skeptical of the standards, with a significant decline in support among public school teachers. The polls, conducted by Education Next and Phi Delta Kappa International, suggest that the term "Common Core" has become increasingly polarizing, with many Americans expressing concerns about federal intrusion and local control.

Despite this setback, Common Core supporters are vowing to revamp their campaign. On Friday, Latino evangelical pastors from across the country will gather to rally their congregations behind the standards. The event will feature former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee as the guest speaker, who has previously expressed concerns about the standards' perceived federal overreach.

The new polls highlight the challenges facing Common Core supporters. The 46th annual PDK/Gallup poll found that 80% of Americans have heard about the Common Core, with nearly half saying they know at least "a fair amount" about the standards. However, 60% of respondents expressed opposition to using the standards to guide instruction in their community, citing concerns about local teachers' support and flexibility in the classroom.

The Education Next poll also found that the term "Common Core" has become toxic, with only 53% of respondents backing the standards. Opposition was particularly high among Republican voters. When asked about standards for reading and math that are the same across the states, without the term "Common Core," support soared to 68%, with Republicans and Democrats alike expressing enthusiasm.

The polls suggest that Common Core supporters face an uphill battle in changing public perception. However, the revamping of their campaign and the involvement of influential figures like Huckabee may help to shift the narrative and increase support for the standards.

Title: Trump's Meeting with Putin: A Win-Win for Russia, a Loss for the US

Article:

President Donald Trump's meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin has raised concerns about the US leader's willingness to accept Russia's denials of election interference, despite the entire US intelligence community believing the Kremlin mounted a sophisticated campaign to help Trump win the White House. According to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, Trump told Putin that some in the US were "exaggerating" the impact of Russia's election interference, effectively dragging Moscow into Trump's partisan wars at home.

The meeting's outcome is seen as a win-win for Putin, as it allows him to deny any involvement in election meddling and gain an appearance of legitimacy. Trump's lack of preparation and notes, as well as his focus on other issues, may have contributed to the outcome. The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, noted that Trump "took note of the actions that have been discussed by the Congress, but I think the two presidents - I think rightly - focused on how do we move forward?"

The meeting also saw Trump and Putin agree on a ceasefire in Syria's southwest, but it is unclear what this will achieve, as most of the fighting is in Syria's east and north. The meeting's outcome has sparked concerns about Trump's willingness to accept Russia's denials of election interference and his ability to negotiate effectively with world leaders.

Title: Lawyers for Intelligence Official Express Concerns for Whistleblower's Safety Amid Trump's Calls for Disclosure

The lawyers for the intelligence official who filed a whistleblower complaint against President Trump have expressed "serious concerns" for their client's safety, citing Trump's recent calls for the whistleblower's identity to be publicly disclosed. In a letter to Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, the lawyers, led by Andrew Bakaj, pointed to Trump's statement that he wants to know who provided the whistleblower with the information, which they believe puts their client in harm's way.

The letter, dated Saturday and made public on Sunday, stated that events from the past week have heightened concerns that the whistleblower's identity will be disclosed publicly and that their client will be put in harm's way. Bakaj acknowledged that Trump's comment targeted the whistleblower's source of information, but claimed that the distinction "does nothing to assuage our concerns for our client's safety."

The lawyers also expressed concern about reports of a $50,000 bounty being offered for information about the whistleblower's identity, which they believe is an attempt to intimidate and silence the official. The Washington Examiner reported that two right-wing activists had offered the sum for "credible information corroborating" the person's identity.

Trump tweeted on Sunday that he wants the whistleblower to be outed, stating, "Like every American, I deserve to meet my accuser, especially when this accuser, the so-called 'Whistleblower,' represented a perfect conversation with a foreign leader in a totally inaccurate and fraudulent way."

The lawyers called on lawmakers to speak out for whistleblower protections and insisted that retaliation against the official, whether direct or implied, would not be tolerated. They also expressed concern that the situation will worsen and become even more dangerous for their client and any other whistleblowers as Congress investigates the matter.

The whistleblower, identified by the New York Times as a CIA officer, is already under federal protection, according to CBS News. However, Mark Zaid, a lawyer from Compass Rose Legal, tweeted that CBS "completely misinterpreted" the contents of the letter, stating that the legal team had not yet reached an agreement with Congress regarding contact with their client.

Representative Adam Schiff, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday that he expected the whistleblower to testify "very soon" once security measures were implemented to protect the person's identity.

Title: Democratic Party's Identity Crisis: Kamala Harris Falls Victim to Party's Ideological Divide

The Democratic Party is facing an identity crisis, with Senator Kamala Harris being the latest casualty. Harris, once considered a top-tier candidate, struggled to convince voters that she was a reliable voice for their issues, failing to unite the party's two wings. The primary has crystallized into a contest between the party's two wings, with Harris falling by the wayside.

The party's leaders have divided along both ideological and attitudinal lines over the past three years, with some candidates choosing to align on one side of the line or the other. Harris attempted to bridge the gap, but was dismissed as an impostor by both camps. The party's leaders have divided into two groups: the "Adjusters," who believe that the world was a pretty good place in October 2016 and that removing President Donald Trump from office represents a necessary course correction, and the "Revolutionaries," who see removing Trump as only the first step towards sweeping, even radical change.

The Adjusters are led by former Vice President Joe Biden, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, and other moderate candidates who believe that the country should return to the path outlined by former President Barack Obama's presidency. The Revolutionaries are led by Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who advocate for a much more dramatic overhaul of the country's priorities.

Harris was the only Democratic candidate who made a serious effort to talk to voters in both groups, but lacked the skills and experience to convince either faction that she was one of them. Her failure serves as a warning sign to the remaining Democratic candidates that the party's unity is crucial to defeating Trump in the general election.

The eventual Democratic nominee will not defeat Trump unless the Adjusters and Revolutionaries are able to put aside their differences. Harris's greatest contribution to her party this year may be to serve as a reminder of what could happen if that unity is not achieved.

Title: US Officials Prepare Options for Potential Response to Chemical Weapons Use in Syria

The United States is considering a range of options in response to the possible use of chemical weapons in Syria, according to officials. The possible shift in policy comes after the US disclosed its preliminary intelligence assessment that chemical munitions, which the Syrian government has been known to stockpile, had been used on a small scale in the country.

President Barack Obama has emphasized the need for conclusive proof of chemical weapons use before taking action, stating that he wants to ensure he has the facts before making decisions about America's national security and potential responses. "What we now have is evidence that chemical weapons have been used inside of Syria, but we don't know how they were used, when they were used, who used them; we don't have chain of custody that establishes what exactly happened," Obama said.

Despite the lack of conclusive proof, the Pentagon has prepared a menu of options for Obama, including airstrikes, commando raids, and enforcing a no-fly zone over Syria. The administration is also exploring ways to increase aid to the rebels.

The US had previously resisted calls to arm the rebels, including from former CIA Director David H. Petraeus and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. A proposal by Petraeus to provide arms to carefully vetted members of the opposition was shelved last fall, but officials expect it to be revisited.

Title: Iranian Hackers Expand Cyber Capabilities, Targeting Critical Infrastructure and Industries

Iranian hackers have significantly advanced their cyber capabilities over the past five years, expanding their targets beyond data wiping to sophisticated attacks on financial networks, internet infrastructure, energy companies, and even critical infrastructure sites. According to cybersecurity expert James A. Lewis, the hackers have developed the ability to disrupt critical infrastructure and wipe data, and it is unclear what specific targets they may target next.

Iran has been embracing cyberattacks as part of its strategy of "asymmetrical warfare" since 2010, when a joint American-Israeli cyberattack targeted an Iranian nuclear facility. Since then, the country's specialized teams have learned how to cause significant destruction to vulnerable systems, according to American intelligence assessments and private security researchers.

American officials and cybersecurity experts have tracked Iranian hackers as they have advanced their capabilities, targeting over 200 oil, gas, and heavy machinery companies around the world, as well as telecom companies and infrastructure systems. The hackers have also targeted critical infrastructure sites, such as the Bowman Dam in Westchester County and the Energy Department's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Falls.

As the conflict between Iran and the U.S. continues, experts warn that the hackers will likely test the limits of their capabilities, targeting company networks, universities, federal networks, and smaller government networks in towns and cities. Iranian leaders have issued strident calls for revenge against the U.S. after the killing of Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani in an overnight airstrike at the Baghdad airport.

Title: Hunter Biden's Business Deals with Foreign Entities Raise Questions

Hunter Biden, the son of former US Vice President Joe Biden, has been under scrutiny for his business dealings with various foreign entities, including those tied to the governments of Russia, China, and Kazakhstan. A new book by author Peter Schweizer, "Profiles in Corruption: Abuse of Power by America's Progressive Elite," reveals that Hunter Biden and his business partners, including Devon Archer, were involved in numerous foreign deals, including those with Burnham Financial Group.

According to the book, Hunter Biden and Archer used Burnham to make deals with governments and oligarchs, including Nurlan Abduov, an associate of Kazakh oligarch Kenges Rakishev. Rakishev is the son-in-law of the former vice prime minister of Kazakhstan, Imangali Tasmagambetov, who is now the Kazakh ambassador to Russia.

The book also reveals that Hunter Biden received funds from a firm run by Rakishev in 2014, and that Archer acted as a backchannel between Kazakhstan and then-Secretary of State John Kerry. Additionally, the book states that Hunter Biden had business deals with two Chinese companies, Kirin Global Enterprises Limited and Harvest Global Investors, as well as a financial relationship with Russian oligarch Yelena Baturina.

Furthermore, the book alleges that Hunter Biden was involved in a $60 million fraudulent bond scheme to rip off union pension funds and the poorest Indian tribe in America, the Oglala Sioux. Although Hunter Biden was not charged, the book states that his fingerprints were all over the scheme, and that his political status as the vice president's son lent legitimacy to the Burnham Financial Group.

The book also highlights the pattern of the Biden family's business dealings, which often involved foreign entities seeking to benefit from his father's political influence. The book notes that Hunter Biden's business dealings have long been a source of controversy, with some critics accusing him of using his father's name and influence to secure lucrative deals.

It is worth noting that the book's author, Peter Schweizer, is a conservative journalist known for his critical reporting on the Biden family's business dealings. However, the book's revelations are based on publicly available information and do not contain any new or unverified information.

Title: Benghazi Committee to Investigate American Presence in Libya, Not Political Scandals

The Benghazi Committee has been criticized for its handling of the investigation into the 2012 attack that resulted in the deaths of four Americans. The committee's primary goal was to determine why the Americans were in Benghazi in the first place, rather than focusing on political scandals. The article highlights the importance of understanding the context and circumstances surrounding the attack, including the role of the American contractors and the Libyan militia groups they were working with.

The article questions the purpose of the American presence in Benghazi, citing the fact that consulates and embassy annexes are typically used for issuing visas and finding lost luggage, which does not seem to be the case in this instance. It also asks who was responsible for the security of Ambassador Stevens and why his repeated calls for more security were ignored.

The article also touches on the possibility that the Benghazi attack may have been a gun-running operation to take Qaddafi's abandoned weapons and turn them over to Syrian rebels, and whether the American contractors were working with and arming Libyan rebels who turned out to be Al Qaeda-type terrorists. It notes that this would not only be foolish but also illegal.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the committee focusing on the events leading up to the attack and asking questions about the lack of a rescue mission during the attack and the subsequent cover-up. It also notes that the committee has new evidence, including Ambassador Stevens' own emails, and that it will be difficult for witnesses to dodge questions this time around.

Title: Oslo Mosque Shooting: Suspect Identified as Philip Manshaus, 21, with Far-Right Views

A shooting occurred at the Al-Noor Islamic Center near Oslo, Norway, on Saturday, leaving one worshipper injured and the suspect overpowered. According to local police, the alleged gunman, identified as Philip Manshaus, 21, had expressed far-right views and admiration for Vidkun Quisling, Norway's leader who collaborated with the Nazis during World War II.

Manshaus, reportedly wearing body armor and heavily armed, shot through a glass door to gain entry to the mosque. He was confronted by a 65-year-old worshipper, who was injured in the process. Authorities believe the shooting could have been more deadly if the suspect had arrived a few minutes earlier, as there were over a dozen people inside the mosque at the time.

The investigation is ongoing, and police have charged Manshaus with the murder of his 17-year-old stepsister, whose body was found at his home in Baerum, west of Oslo. He is also facing an attempted murder charge for the mosque shooting.

Police are investigating the shooting as terrorism due to the suspect's apparent intent to inspire fear, but emphasized that there is no evidence he was part of a larger network. Authorities have found a social media post made by a user with the same name as the alleged gunman, expressing admiration for the Christchurch mosque shooter and the El Paso, Texas, shooter.

In response to the incident, authorities have ordered police to guard mosques in the city, and many non-Muslims stood outside mosques in Oslo to stand guard during Eid al-Adha celebrations. Prime Minister Erna Solberg condemned the attack, stating, "Norway should be safe. All places of worship should be safe."

Title: FBI's National Instant Criminal Background Check System Sees Decline in June

The FBI's National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has seen a decline in checks run through the system in June, marking the first year-over-year drop since October 2011. According to the FBI, 1.3 million checks were run through the system in June, a significant decrease from the 2.7 million checks in December and about 20,000 fewer than the same month last year.

Experts attribute the decline to the fact that those motivated by fear to purchase a firearm over the past several months have acquired all the guns they desire or can afford. David Chipman, a former agent for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, said, "It seems that those motivated by fear to purchase a firearm over the past several months have acquired all of the guns they desire or can afford."

John Hudak, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who studies gun issues, noted that the desire for a gun fit into the psyche of the moment, with people feeling a threat and the need to acquire a firearm as a result. "The shock and horror has died down in pretty dramatic fashion over the past few months," he said.

The National Sports Shooting Foundation, the trade group for the guns and ammunition industry, keeps its own adjusted tally every month to account for checks that don't translate directly into sales. According to Mike Bazinet, a spokesman for the group, low numbers in the middle of the year are not uncommon. "In a typical year, mid-year sales historically dip, but we haven't had a typical year in three years," he wrote in an email.

Josh Horwitz, executive director of the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, cautioned against reading too much into any comparisons with figures from December, saying that's always the biggest month. "Months always vary in a pattern, they vary in the same way," he said.

The decline in NICS checks may signal to some that the issue is fading from the public eye, but President Obama and groups like the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence have vowed not to let that happen. The president has rolled out an ambitious gun control package that included bans on semi-automatic rifles and high-capacity magazines and near-universal background checks, although the package ultimately devolved into a compromise measure that would expand background checks to sales online and at gun shows.

Title: Two Top Staffers Leave Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Office Amid Controversy

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's two top staffers, Chief of Staff Saikat Chakrabarti and Communications Director Corbin Trent, are leaving her Congressional office. Chakrabarti's departure is effective immediately, while Trent will remain until the end of the month before transitioning to Ocasio-Cortez's 2020 campaign.

Chakrabarti will join New Consensus, a nonprofit climate change group that promotes the Green New Deal. The news was first reported by The Intercept and confirmed by The Post.

During their time in Ocasio-Cortez's office, Chakrabarti and Trent were known for their aggressive tactics, which sometimes made life difficult for the congresswoman in Washington. Chakrabarti's tweets sparked controversy, including a remark that likened moderate Democrats to "new southern Democrats," which was widely criticized. He also regularly tweeted criticism of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

Trent's tweets have also generated negative press, including an incident where he used profanity to call out a potential Republican challenger. Both aides worked with Ocasio-Cortez during her successful primary campaign, which saw her defeat Rep. Joe Crowley.

The finances surrounding Justice Democrats, the group Chakrabarti and Trent co-founded, have also been scrutinized. The group attracted three Federal Election Commission complaints due to an unusual setup involving money flowing into two limited liability companies controlled by Chakrabarti. Ocasio-Cortez did not require Chakrabarti or Trent to disclose their personal finances.

In a statement, Ocasio-Cortez's office said the departures were planned before the recent dustup between her and other members of the "Squad" and House leadership. Chakrabarti's departure was described as a planned move to work with New Consensus, while Trent will transition to the congresswoman's 2020 campaign.

Title: Honduras Signs Deal with US to Send Migrants Back to Central America

The government of Honduras has signed a "safe third country" agreement with the United States, aimed at curbing migration. This deal, similar to those signed with El Salvador and Guatemala, will allow migrants who cross Honduras on their way to the United States to seek asylum in the country instead.

According to a senior U.S. Department of Homeland Security official, the agreement will enable migrants to seek protection closer to their home. However, few details have been released on how the agreement will be implemented.

The Trump administration has been pushing for a rule that would bar most migrants from gaining U.S. asylum if they did not seek safe haven in a country they transited through first. This rule, which has faced legal challenges, would accomplish the same goal as the agreements with Central American countries.

The majority of migrants arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border are from the three northern triangle countries, and many turn themselves in to border officials to ask for asylum in the United States. President Donald Trump has made reducing the number of asylum claims a top priority, implementing measures to discourage migrants from applying.

Immigrant advocates, however, argue that sending people seeking refuge back to the region where they fled, even if not to their home country, violates international commitments meant to prevent vulnerable migrants from being returned to danger. The three countries have tiny asylum offices that could struggle to process a large number of claims.

Honduras President Juan Orlando Hernandez has faced scrutiny over a court filing document related to the upcoming drug trafficking trial in New York of his brother, Juan Antonio "Tony" Hernandez. The president has denied any wrongdoing.

Title: Justice Department Investigation of AP Phone Records Sparks Speculation About Attorney General Eric Holder's Future

The recent revelation that the Justice Department secretly obtained two months of phone records from the Associated Press (AP) has sparked widespread criticism and speculation about the future of Attorney General Eric Holder. The investigation, which targeted over 100 phone lines used by more than 20 AP reporters and editors, has been deemed a "massive and unprecedented intrusion" by the news cooperative.

The controversy has led to calls for Holder's resignation, with some arguing that his actions are "constitutionally abhorrent" and "politically moronic." While only President Obama knows for certain whether Holder will be forced to step down, the political stakes are high for the White House. The administration is already facing multiple controversies, including its handling of the Benghazi attack and the IRS's investigation of conservative political organizations.

Holder has been a controversial figure, particularly among Republicans, who voted to hold him in contempt of Congress in 2012 over his refusal to turn over certain documents related to the "Fast and Furious" gun sting operation. He has also faced criticism for his stance on the use of military tribunals to try terrorists and his comments about the difficulty of prosecuting large banks.

The bipartisan outcry over the AP phone records seizure has been unprecedented, with even some Democrats expressing concern. Senator Patrick Leahy, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has called for the government to explain its actions, while White House Press Secretary Jay Carney has distanced himself from the investigation.

In a statement, Holder recused himself from the decision to subpoena the AP's phone records, citing his own involvement in the investigation into the leak of classified information. The Justice Department has defended its actions, stating that it takes seriously its obligations to follow applicable laws and regulations when issuing subpoenas for media organizations.

The controversy has left many wondering about Holder's future as Attorney General. While he has expressed his desire to stay in the position, his comments on a recent radio show suggested he may not be sure if he will remain in the role for the full four years of Obama's second term.

Title: Ted Cruz Announces Carly Fiorina as Running Mate in Unconventional Move

Ted Cruz, a Republican presidential candidate, has announced former GOP primary rival Carly Fiorina as his choice for running mate if he wins the party's nomination. The move was met with skepticism by the Trump campaign, who dismissed it as an act of "desperation." Cruz defended the decision, stating that "nobody is getting to 1,237 delegates" and that voters should "know what they will get."

Cruz made the announcement in Indiana, which votes next Tuesday, touting Fiorina's credentials and life story. The theoretical pairing represents a diverse ticket, offering the possibility of electing the first Hispanic president and first female vice president.

Fiorina, a former HP CEO, accepted the offer, saying she's ready to "fight." She has had a varied career, including being the first woman to lead a Fortune 20 company, but also faced criticism for her time at HP, including allegations of deals with Iran and layoffs of 30,000 employees.

Trump dismissed the move, saying Fiorina didn't do well in the primary and that Cruz is trying to stay relevant. Fiorina's past as a political candidate includes an unsuccessful bid to unseat California Sen. Barbara Boxer in 2010 and a presidential campaign in 2015, which she suspended after single-digit finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire.

The move is seen as an unconventional one, as most presidential candidates wait until they have the nomination sewn up to announce a running mate. However, Cruz believes the battle will proceed to a contested convention, where he hopes to triumph once some pledged delegates become unbound and are free to switch their votes.

Title: Education Secretary Calls for Collaboration to Reduce Gun Violence in America

Article:

Education Secretary Arne Duncan has urged school leaders, politicians, Second Amendment advocates, and others to come together to find solutions to reduce gun violence in the United States. In a speech at Washington, D.C.'s Neval Thomas Elementary School, Mr. Duncan emphasized the need for "real and rapid progress" on this issue. He acknowledged that the factors leading to the tragic shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, are complex, but believes limiting access to high-powered firearms is a simple and easy solution that everyone should agree on.

Mr. Duncan, a member of President Obama's task force on gun violence and mental health, expressed his personal perspective on the issue, stating that he wonders what might have happened if the shooter, Adam Lanza, did not have access to those guns. He noted that if Lanza had not had access to firearms, he might have simply been punching his pillow, and his mother would still be alive, and 26 families in Newtown would be celebrating the holidays instead of attending funerals.

The speech comes as the National Rifle Association is set to hold its first press conference since the Newtown massacre, which will provide insight into the potential challenges faced by gun-control advocates seeking stricter laws. Those advocating for gun control are pushing for the reinstatement of the assault weapons ban, closing the "gun show loophole," and limiting high-capacity ammunition clips, such as those used by Lanza at Sandy Hook.

Mr. Duncan emphasized that "reasonable people should be able to agree on these restrictions."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing Highlights Contradictions and Hypocrisy

The recent Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Brett Kavanaugh's nomination to the Supreme Court was a striking display of contradictions and hypocrisy. On one hand, Republican senators appeared to be respectful and courteous to Christine Blasey Ford, the woman accusing Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct. They hired a female prosecutor to question her and refrained from using derogatory language, unlike the treatment of Anita Hill 27 years ago.

On the other hand, the hearing also felt "strikingly retrograde," with Ford's emotional testimony largely ignored as Republican senators deferred to the righteous indignation of a white man. The hearing demonstrated how much has changed for American women, yet how little has changed in terms of institutional power dynamics.

The day's events were marked by stark contrasts. Ford came across as deferential, nervous, and deeply concerned with accuracy, while Kavanaugh appeared as an angry bully bent on intimidation. The latter's performance was marked by yelling, weeping, and sniffing, conveying a sense of self-pity and indignation.

The Republican senators' self-presentation was also notable, with some describing Ford as "credible" and "attractive," while others failed to engage with her testimony. The hearing was portrayed as a "he-said/she-said" standoff, with a lack of corroborating evidence seen as sufficient to dismiss Ford's allegations.

The hollowness of the proceedings highlighted the Republican party's ability to pay lip service to the #MeToo movement while still indulging in old-fashioned hypocrisy. The party's approach was marked by a failure to acknowledge the real power of women's voices and a refusal to take allegations of sexual misconduct seriously.

The cracks in the right's approach are showing, however, as evidenced by the emotional confrontation between two sexual assault survivors and Senator Jeff Flake, which led to his call for a further FBI investigation. The Kavanaugh affair is a referendum on the political power of women, and the right knows it has a woman problem that it may not want to acknowledge but can no longer ignore.

Title: Trump Administration Alters Visa Policy, Allowing Deportation of Immigrants Cooperating with Investigations

The Trump administration has made a significant change to its handling of visas granted to immigrants who cooperate with criminal investigations. The new policy allows Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to deport individuals pending U visa applications, which can take up to four years to process. The U visa is a special type of visa given to individuals who are cooperating with criminal investigations.

Immigration attorneys argue that this change will make immigrants less likely to report serious crimes, as they will be at risk of being deported even while waiting for their visas. Eileen Blessinger, an immigration attorney, stated that the change will have a "chilling effect" because individuals will be reporting themselves to ICE, but there is now a risk that ICE might pick them up.

The revised ICE directive, released on August 2, allows ICE to grant permission for individuals to stay in the country while awaiting their U visas, but also reserves the right to deport pending applicants at their discretion. The directive states that ICE will "exercise its discretion" in determining whether to grant stay of removal requests, but notes that the agency "no longer exempts classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement."

ICE defended the change, citing the volume of U visa applications and the need to streamline the process. However, immigration attorneys argue that the change is part of a broader effort by the Trump administration to deport as many immigrants as possible from the United States.

The change has already had an impact on some individuals, including a Salvadoran immigrant who was detained after failing to appear in court due to a lack of information about the hearing date and time. The individual was granted a U visa certification, but would have been deported under the new ICE directive.

Advocates for immigrants argue that the change contravenes the purpose of the U visa program, which was created in 2000 to provide protection for immigrant survivors of crime and to assist law enforcement in investigating and prosecuting criminal activity. The change has also left many individuals in the dark about what they are supposed to do, as ICE has yet to publicly issue full guidance on the new policy.

The change is seen as part of a broader trend of the Trump administration's efforts to restrict immigration and limit access to protection for immigrants.

Title: California Judge Rules State's Teacher Tenure System Unconstitutional, Spurring Nationwide Debate

Article:

A Los Angeles County Superior Court judge, Rolfe Treu, has delivered a significant ruling in the case of Vergara v California, declaring the state's teacher tenure rules unconstitutional. The decision has sparked a heated debate about the role of teacher job security and the impact on education in California and beyond.
