The ruling holds that California's teacher tenure system, which provides employment protections for teachers, violates the state's students' constitutional right to an equal education. Judge Treu cited empirical evidence showing that ineffective teachers have long-term negative consequences for students and that these teachers are more likely to be found in heavily minority schools. He also noted that the current system disproportionately affects minority students, who are more likely to be taught by ineffective teachers.

The decision is likely to be appealed to the California Supreme Court, and even if the ruling is reversed, the fact that the plaintiff prevailed at any level is expected to spur litigation in additional states. The case has significant implications for the education system in California and beyond, as it challenges the current system of teacher job security and compensation.

The debate surrounding teacher tenure is complex, with proponents arguing that it provides job security and stability for teachers, while opponents argue that it hinders the ability to remove ineffective teachers and promote merit-based employment decisions. The ruling has sparked a mix of reactions, with some viewing it as a victory for education reform and others seeing it as an attack on teacher unions.

The case has also raised questions about the use of value-added models, which track student test scores and measure teacher performance based on student progress. Critics argue that these models are unstable and unreliable, while proponents note that they correlate with adult life outcomes, such as college attendance and socioeconomic status.

The ruling has no immediate consequences, as Judge Treu issued a "tentative decision" in anticipation of appeal. However, the case is expected to have a significant impact on education policy in California and beyond, and the debate is likely to continue as the case is appealed and other states consider similar litigation.

Title: Mitt Romney Reflects on His Campaign and the State of America

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, has been experiencing a surge in popularity, with recent polls showing an increase in his support. He has been on a two-day swing through Connecticut and New York, where he has secured big donors and hard money. Additionally, he has won the GOP primaries in Kentucky and Arkansas.

Romney attributes his upward momentum to an increased sense among voters that the country is on the wrong path and a growing sense that he has proved himself. In a telephone interview, he reflected on his campaign, stating that he and his team have worked hard to convince voters that he is the right candidate for the job.

When asked about the difference between the America he saw in 2008 and the one he sees now, Romney noted that there is a higher degree of anxiety among voters. He believes that people are less confident in their job security and the prospects for their children. The economic downturn has had a significant impact on the country, and Romney believes that it is now the central issue in his campaign.

Romney also discussed his campaign journal, which he keeps on his iPad. He writes every two or three days, reflecting on his experiences and the people he meets. He believes that this journal will help him remember the details of his campaign 10 years from now.

In terms of his personal feelings about politics, Romney stated that he enjoys the rallies and town meetings, as well as the interchange with individuals who are probing and pushing. However, he does not feel agony in loss, as he believes that victory is still a thrill.

Romney also addressed the myth surrounding his father, George Romney, and the idea that one word – "brainwashed" – did in his presidential candidacy in 1968. He stated that this myth does not influence his thinking and that he is more concerned with his own mistakes and the impact they may have on his campaign.

When asked about historic parallelism and the idea that this election is similar to previous ones, Romney believes that it is 2012 and that history does not repeat itself identically. He believes that America is at an inflection point, where the course of the nation will change, and he hopes to usher in a period of economic vitality if elected.

Title: FBI's Andrew McCabe Accused of Improperly Leaking Information and Lying to Investigators

The Justice Department's inspector general has released a report accusing former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe of improperly leaking information to a reporter and lying to both his boss, then-Director James Comey, and FBI agents investigating his behavior. The report, which had been circulating within the government for weeks, was used to justify McCabe's firing earlier this year.

According to the report, McCabe authorized leaks to a Wall Street Journal reporter in 2016 to shape the narrative surrounding his role in the investigation into Hillary Clinton's secret emails. The leak confirmed the existence of an investigation into the Clinton Foundation, which the FBI had previously avoided confirming. The inspector general concluded that McCabe's actions were inappropriate and violated FBI policies.

The report also found that McCabe lied to Comey, FBI agents, and the inspector general on multiple occasions, including during a follow-up interview last year. The inspector general concluded that McCabe lacked candor, including under oath, and that his actions violated FBI Offense Codes 2.5 and 2.6.

The report also delves into several other issues related to the 2016 presidential election, including an August 2016 call between McCabe and a high-ranking Justice Department official who expressed concerns about the FBI's investigation into the Clinton Foundation. McCabe described the call as "very dramatic" and said he had never had a confrontation like that with the Justice Department before.

The report is likely to fuel President Trump's complaints about the FBI and special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into his own behavior and that of his 2016 campaign. However, Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, said the report has nothing to do with Mueller's investigation and that Trump will likely misuse the findings in his "ongoing disinformation campaign."

The report's release has sparked reactions from both sides of the political aisle. Rep. Trey Gowdy, Republican from South Carolina and chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, said the report justifies McCabe's firing, while Sen. Dianne Feinstein, ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said McCabe's actions needed to be viewed in the context of him trying to defend himself and his wife against false press reports.

Title: Bloomberg News Restricts Coverage of Mike Bloomberg's Presidential Campaign

Bloomberg News, a leading global news organization, has issued an edict to its staff, prohibiting the investigation of its founder, Mike Bloomberg, and his family and foundation. This decision comes after Bloomberg announced his candidacy for the 2020 Democratic presidential primary. The news service's editor-in-chief, John Micklethwait, stated that the policy will extend to Bloomberg's rivals in the party, citing the need to treat all candidates equally.

The decision has sparked controversy among some journalists, who argue that it compromises the organization's independence and ability to report on the presidential campaign. Bloomberg News has a long history of avoiding coverage of its founder, even when he was mayor of New York City. However, this policy has been criticized as a conflict of interest and a potential violation of journalistic ethics.

The news service will continue to investigate the Trump administration, but will not cover Bloomberg's campaign or his rivals. The decision has raised questions about the potential for bias and the impact on the organization's reputation. Bloomberg News has a large team of journalists and a global reach, making it one of the most influential news organizations in the world.

The decision has also sparked debate about the role of corporate ownership in journalism. Bloomberg News is owned by its founder, Mike Bloomberg, who made his fortune in the financial industry. The organization's decision to restrict coverage of his campaign has raised concerns about the potential for bias and the impact on the organization's independence.

In conclusion, the decision by Bloomberg News to restrict coverage of its founder's presidential campaign has sparked controversy and raised questions about the role of corporate ownership in journalism. The organization's decision to treat all candidates equally has been criticized as a compromise, and the impact on the organization's reputation remains to be seen.

Title: Analysis of Tribal Loyalty and Political Polarization

The article explores the concept of tribal loyalty and its implications on political polarization. It discusses the examples of Congresswoman Maxine Waters and President Trump, highlighting the hypocrisy of some individuals who claim to resist Trump on constitutional and ethical grounds but fail to apply the same standards to others. The article also touches on the idea of obligatory post-election anti-Trumpism, which can lead to a lack of critical thinking and a failure to consider the actual issues.

The author argues that some individuals, such as Senator Chuck Schumer, use the Paris Agreement as an example of Trump's supposed disregard for the environment, but fail to acknowledge the potential for executive overreach when a liberal president takes office. The article also references Harvard Law professor Laurence Tribe's warning about the corrosion of process and executive abuse.

The author concludes that Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Agreement can be seen as strengthening the balance of power in the country, but notes that this is not necessarily a result of reverence for the Constitution. The article also discusses a column by Dennis Prager, who argues that some conservatives who were Never-Trumpers during the election and remain anti-Trump today do not believe that America is engaged in a civil war, with the survival of the country at stake.

The article presents a neutral and factual analysis of the issues, avoiding personal opinions and subjective language. It provides a balanced view of the arguments presented, highlighting the complexities and nuances of the topics discussed.

Title: Hong Kong International Airport Closes Due to Pro-Democracy Demonstrations, Chinese Authorities Label Protests as "Terrorism"

Hong Kong International Airport, one of the busiest airports in the world, was forced to cancel all flights on Monday after thousands of pro-democracy protesters occupied the main terminal. The Chinese authorities described the protest as "terrorism," stating that it posed an "existential threat" to the population of Hong Kong.

According to officials, the protest "seriously disrupted" airport operations, with only flights that were already boarding or had been cleared for landing allowed to use the airport's runways. All other flights were canceled.

The protests in Hong Kong have been ongoing for over two months, with demonstrators demanding democratic reforms and an investigation into police conduct. The city's government, which is supposed to be separate from communist China's influence, introduced an extradition bill that critics say would threaten the liberties awarded to the city and allow people to be extradited to face the law in mainland China. The bill was temporarily suspended following protests, but the demonstrations have since morphed into a more general demand for greater freedoms and a check on the perceived use of excessive force by the authorities.

China's Cabinet, the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office in Beijing, used strong language to condemn the protests, stating that they are "beginning to show the sprouts of terrorism" and constitute an "existential threat" to the population of Hong Kong. The office called for "resolute action" against the protesters, saying that Hong Kong has reached an "inflection point" where all those concerned about the city's future must say "no" to lawbreakers and "no" to those engaged in violence.

Earlier on Monday, Hong Kong police showed off water cannons that could be deployed in the case of future demonstrations, a development that Amnesty International has warned could lead to serious injuries if the canons are misused within the densely-populated city's confined spaces.

Hong Kong is a former British colony that has been part of China since 1997, but which benefits from autonomy under the "one country, two systems" approach. The structure allows the city certain democratic rights that are not afforded to people on the mainland, but some people have accused the Communist Party-ruled central government of slowly stripping their freedoms.

Ma Ngok, a political scientist at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, told the South China Morning Post that heavy-handed tactics from police have alienated people, saying that they have lost confidence in the police enforcing the law fairly and would question the legitimacy of all their actions.

Title: Iowa's Democratic Primary: Warren and Sanders Draw Large Crowds, but Can They Split the Vote?

The Iowa State Fair saw a surge in attendance at rallies for Democratic presidential contenders Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, with both candidates drawing raucous crowds who chanted their names, waved signs, and cheered at their every pledge. The two senators, friends and liberal standard-bearers of the Democratic Party, share many of the same causes, including universal healthcare, taking on Wall Street, and raising the minimum wage.

As the Iowa caucuses approach in February, some voters are concerned that the two popular progressives running head-to-head could split the vote on the left, potentially benefiting a centrist candidate like former Vice President Joe Biden. Early opinion polls have consistently shown Biden in the lead, with either Sanders or Warren in second place.

The fact that combining support for Sanders and Warren would eclipse Biden's support buttresses progressives' arguments that the party is lurching leftward. Adam Green, co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, an advocacy group that supports Warren, said, "They are a 1-2 punch and they are having a gravitational pull on the rest of the field."

Despite sharing many of the same talking points, the two candidates are noticeably different on the stump. Warren casts herself as a sort of prairie populist, drawing upon her working-class Oklahoma roots, while Sanders talks more in terms of leading a "movement." There is evidence that the two do not chase the same kind of voters, with Warren appealing to women, particularly college-educated women, that Sanders cannot match.

Sanders' campaign views Biden as their primary challenge, as both are courting the kind of working-class voters and union voters who gravitated to Trump in 2016. Biden did little in Iowa to boost his status as a front-runner, making several gaffes, including when he said "poor kids are just as bright and just as talented as white kids" - a sensitive slip-up in an election where race is in the spotlight.

After Iowa, Sanders and Warren will clash in New Hampshire, which holds the first Democratic primary later in February. Many Warren voters fear Sanders will not yield if his fellow senator continues to gain momentum. Right now, the foremost concern of the two campaigns is not to siphon support off the other, but to convince large swaths of voters that a progressive Democrat can win the election against Trump.

Title: Trump Dismisses Recession Fears, Optimistic About Economy

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has expressed optimism about the economy, stating that it is "doing very well" and dismissing concerns of a recession. This comes after a recent steep drop in the financial markets. Trump's top economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, also played down fears of a looming recession, predicting the economy will perform well in the second half of 2019.

Kudlow attributed the strong economy to higher wages and increased consumer spending. He acknowledged a slowing energy sector but believes low interest rates will help housing, construction, and auto sales. The adviser also defended the president's use of tariffs on goods coming from China, stating that the "China story has to be changed and reformed."

However, not everyone shares Trump's optimism. Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke expressed concerns about the impact of the trade war on the global economy, stating that it is "hammering the hell out of farmers across this country." O'Rourke believes the U.S. needs to work with allies to hold China accountable on trade.

The Federal Reserve recently reduced its benchmark rate by a quarter-point to a range of 2% to 2.25%, citing concerns about the consequences of Trump's trade war and sluggish economies overseas. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stressed that weak global growth and trade tensions are having an effect on the U.S. economy.

Peter Navarro, who advises Trump on trade policy, disagreed with the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates, stating that it cost the economy a full percentage point of growth. Navarro also claimed that U.S. consumers are not affected by the administration's trade war with China, although tariffs are taxes paid by U.S. importers, not China, and are often passed along to U.S. businesses and consumers through higher prices.

The ongoing trade war with China has been a target of criticism by Democrats vying to challenge Trump in the 2020 election. Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, a Democratic presidential candidate, stated that there is no strategy for dealing with the trade war in a way that will actually lead to results for American farmers or consumers.

Title: Justice Department to Challenge Ruling on Emergency Contraceptives for Teenagers

The United States Department of Justice is set to appear before a federal judge on Tuesday to challenge a recent ruling that would make emergency contraceptives available to young teenage girls without a prescription. The ruling, issued on April 5, would allow the morning-after pill Plan B One-Step to be sold over-the-counter to all ages, without a prescription.

U.S. District Court Judge Edward Korman of New York has given the parties involved until Monday to respond to the Justice Department's notice of appeal. The judge's order to implement the ruling will not take effect until Friday, five days later than initially planned.

The debate over minors' access to emergency contraception is a contentious issue, with women's rights groups advocating for unrestricted access and pro-life groups opposing it. The Obama administration has taken a middle ground approach, with Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius deciding in 2011 to keep age restrictions on the pill in place. The FDA recently approved an application from Teva Women's Health Inc. to lower the age limit from 17 to 15, which has been met with criticism from some quarters.

The Justice Department has noted that the FDA's decision to lower the age limit coincides with the pending federal case, which has raised suspicions among some. Judge Korman has given the government two chances to put his ruling on hold, and if denied, will grant a stay to allow the government to seek a stay from the Court of Appeals.

Title: Sanders Supporters' Support for Free Services Dips When Asked to Pay for Them

A recent poll conducted by Vox and Morning Consult found that supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders have strong backing for initiatives like free college tuition and universal healthcare, with over 70% in favor of both. However, when asked how much they are willing to pay for these services, support drops significantly. According to the poll, two-thirds of Sanders supporters are unwilling to pay more than $1,000 for a single-payer healthcare system, and 14% are unwilling to pay any additional taxes for free public college tuition.

When asked what percentage of their income they would pay for these services, half of Sanders supporters said they are unwilling to pay or would pay less than 5%, while a quarter said they would pay between 5-10%. This reluctance to pay for these services is a significant departure from Sanders' plan, which would impose an additional $5,000 in federal taxes on households earning $50,000.

The poll highlights the disconnect between the ideals of Sanders' supporters and the reality of the costs associated with his proposed policies. While Sanders' plan would nationalize vital services currently in the private sector, the majority of his supporters are unwilling to pay enough to support these services. This raises questions about the sustainability of such a system, as seen in other countries where it has been implemented.

The poll also underscores the demographic makeup of Sanders' base, with young, college-educated whites being the core of his support. This demographic has been a key factor in Democratic losses in the South and nationally since the 1960s. The article concludes that Sanders' supporters want a lot of things from the government but are unwilling to pay for them, making it difficult to see his campaign as a revolution or a movement for change.

Title: Conservative Filmmaker Dinesh D'Souza Indicted on Campaign Finance Charges

Conservative filmmaker Dinesh D'Souza, known for his documentary "2016: Obama's America," has been indicted on charges of violating federal campaign laws. The 52-year-old author and activist is accused of illegally donating to a Senate campaign and making false statements to authorities.

According to the indictment, D'Souza directed various donors to give contributions to Republican Wendy Long's 2012 Senate campaign, totaling $20,000. However, individuals are only allowed to donate a maximum of $5,000 to a candidate per election cycle. D'Souza allegedly reimbursed the donors, which is illegal.

The FBI's Assistant Director in Charge, George Venizelos, stated, "Trying to influence elections through bogus campaign contributions is a serious crime. Today, Mr. D'Souza finds himself on the wrong side of the law."

D'Souza's co-producer, Gerald Molen, believes the filmmaker is being singled out by federal authorities. Molen, who won an Oscar for his work on "Schindler's List," expressed disappointment and called the charges a "selective prosecution." He stated that the filmmakers will not be deterred and are planning to release their new film, "America," in July 2014.

The indictment was announced by the FBI and U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, who was appointed by President Obama in 2009. D'Souza faces a maximum of two years in prison for the illegal contributions charge and a maximum of five years in prison for the false statements charge.

Title: Trump's Denials and Distractions Face Growing Challenges from Mueller Investigation

The President's latest attempts to shift attention away from the Russia investigation have failed to stem the tide of new revelations and legal developments that are deepening the threat he faces from Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Over the past week, a series of filings and court actions have revealed new evidence of contacts between Trump associates and Russians, as well as allegations of potential obstruction of justice and campaign finance violations.

Despite Trump's claims of "collusion illusion" and "no collusion whatsoever," the investigation continues to uncover a trail of questionable behavior by those close to the President. Mueller's latest filings have linked Trump's business interests to the Russian election meddling effort and revealed that work on a proposed Trump Tower Moscow project continued until deep into the 2016 campaign.

The President's legal team has insisted that Trump is in the clear, but the evidence suggests otherwise. The investigation has already led to charges against several Trump associates, and the President's own conduct is under scrutiny. The likelihood of a comprehensive picture emerging of what went on in the Trump campaign, transition, and White House is growing, and the President's denials and distractions are failing to keep up with the special counsel's accelerating pace.

The departure of Chief of Staff John Kelly, who had been a respected figure in the administration, has also raised questions about the stability of the White House and the President's inner circle. The search for a new chief of staff is ongoing, with Nick Ayers, the current chief of staff to Vice President Mike Pence, reportedly in talks for the position.

Meanwhile, Trump has taken to Twitter to promote violent demonstrations in France and to criticize the Macron government's handling of the crisis. The President's tweets have been met with criticism from many quarters, and his attempts to shift attention away from the Russia investigation have failed to distract from the growing threat he faces.

Title: Trump Frustrated with Senior Staff Over Russia Developments, Sources Say

Article:

President Donald Trump is reportedly frustrated with his senior staff and communications team for allowing the controversy surrounding Attorney General Jeff Sessions to overshadow his address to Congress, according to sources. The President is said to be "extremely upset" and feels that the communications team failed to prepare for the news, which the administration deemed a "non-story."

Sessions recused himself from any current or future investigations into ties between Russia and the Trump campaign after it was reported that he had met with the Russian ambassador to the US, something he had previously failed to disclose. The renewed focus on Russia is seen as a major letdown after Tuesday, when top officials were congratulating one another on Trump's speech to Congress.

The President was "hot" and exasperated Thursday night after Sessions' recusal, considering it "hasty and overkill." When Trump returned to the White House Thursday evening from a day trip to Virginia, there were "a lot of expletives." The source said that Trump had been lamenting that his senior staff "just keep getting in their own way" for more than a week.

The President voiced his frustration to his inner circle in the Oval Office Friday, expressing anger at the media, former Obama administration officials, and others, as well as frustration with non-stop leaks undermining his administration. Trump is upset because he does not believe he is getting the credit he thinks he deserves for his time in office so far due to self-inflicted wounds and missteps.

The President's mood is adding to tremendous pressure inside the West Wing, with aides having been seen in tears at multiple meetings. With so much on the administration's plate, including leaks, Russia developments, and pending executive orders, Chief of Staff Reince Priebus decided not to travel with the President to Florida this weekend, as had been previously planned.

Title: Conservatives Defend Chris Christie by Comparing Bridge Scandal to Benghazi and IRS Controversies

Article:

Conservatives are attempting to deflect criticism of the George Washington Bridge scandal by drawing comparisons to the Benghazi and IRS controversies, which occurred during the Obama administration. This strategy involves making ad hominem attacks on President Obama and Hillary Clinton, claiming that the media is unfairly targeting Chris Christie. However, this approach is seen as dishonest and unlikely to be effective.

The argument relies on the idea that the Obama administration was mired in scandal, which is not supported by evidence. The Benghazi and IRS controversies were thoroughly investigated and found to lack merit, with the media moving on from the stories due to the lack of evidence. Conservatives are now attempting to deflect attention from the bridge scandal by claiming the media is biased and ignoring the Obama administration's supposed scandals.

This tactic is seen as lame and unconvincing, as it involves complaining about the other side's political tactics rather than addressing the actual issues. Furthermore, the bridge scandal is still unfolding and could get much worse for Christie, making it unlikely that conservatives will be able to shift the focus to Benghazi and the IRS.

The article concludes that the best analysis of the scandal is that it is a follow-the-money investigation, which fits the facts better than the notion that it was an act of amateur, disproportionate retribution.

Title: Hillary Clinton Clarifies "Dead Broke" Comment, Acknowledges Inaccurate Choice of Words

Article: In a recent interview with Fusion TV's Jorge Ramos, Hillary Clinton clarified her previous statement that she and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, were "dead broke" when they left the White House in 2001. Clinton acknowledged that the phrase was "in-artful" but maintained that it was "accurate" in describing their financial situation at the time.

When asked if she regretted making the comment, Clinton replied, "I regret it. It was in-artful, but it was accurate." She then shifted the conversation to her concerns about working families in the United States, stating that she wants to create more opportunities for Americans to succeed.

Ramos pressed on, asking Clinton about her net worth and the value of her assets. Clinton responded that she and her husband have two "very nice houses" and are not planning to sell them anytime soon. When asked if she knew her net worth, Clinton replied, "Within a range," without providing a specific figure.

It's worth noting that Clinton's previous statement, made in a June 9 interview with ABC's Diane Sawyer, stated that the couple was "not only dead broke, but in debt" when they left the White House. According to CNN, Bill Clinton earned $106 million between 2001 and early 2013, while Hillary Clinton has earned an estimated $12 million since leaving the State Department in 2013.

Title: Trump Plans Rebuttal to Clinton's Foreign Policy Criticism, Defends Iraq War Stance

Article:

Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump has announced plans to deliver a rebuttal to Hillary Clinton's recent speech on foreign policy, which criticized his stance on various international issues. Trump told CNN's Jake Tapper on "State of the Union" that he may release his response as early as Monday.

In the interview, Trump mocked Clinton for working with speechwriters on her remarks and dismissed her criticisms, calling her claims that he is "temperamentally unfit" for the presidency and driven by personal feuds as "wrong." Trump also defended his claims that he opposed the Iraq War before it began, stating that he was against it from 2004 onwards.

However, Trump's claim has been disputed by Clinton, who pointed to an interview he gave to Howard Stern in 2002, in which he said he supported then-President George W. Bush's push to go to war. Trump has since cast his comments as wishy-washy, saying they show he was moving toward opposing the war.

Trump also criticized protesters who have clashed with his supporters outside campaign events, calling them "thugs" and claiming they are being sent by Democrats. He pointed to the presence of Bernie Sanders signs among the protesters as evidence of their supposed Democratic affiliation.

In addition, Trump defended his claims that a judge overseeing a lawsuit against Trump University is biased because of his Mexican heritage, pushing back against criticism that his objections are racist. Trump told Tapper that U.S. District Court Judge Gonzalo Curiel has made "rulings that people can't even believe" and that he is proud of his Mexican heritage.

Trump's comments on the judge have sparked controversy, with many accusing him of making racist remarks. Trump has denied any wrongdoing, stating that he is simply pointing out the judge's heritage and that he is building a wall between the U.S. and Mexico.

**Ferguson Protests Continue Amid Tensions and Arrests**

The city of Ferguson, Missouri, remains in turmoil as protests and unrest continue to unfold following the death of 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was fatally shot by a white police officer on August 9. Missouri Highway Patrol Captain Ron Johnson held a press conference early Tuesday, condemning "violent agitators" who he claimed were using peaceful protests as a cover to commit criminal acts.

According to Johnson, 31 people were arrested during a night of unrest, with two handguns and a Molotov cocktail confiscated by authorities. The captain also reported that officers had come under heavy gunfire from protesters, with at least two people shot. Four officers were injured, struck by rocks or bottles, although Johnson claimed that police had not fired a single shot.

Johnson urged protesters to hold their demonstrations during daylight hours, citing a "dangerous dynamic" at night, and expressed frustration that his forces could not force protesters to leave the streets after sunset. He also criticized the media for putting themselves and officers in danger by failing to clear areas when asked.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that police fired tear gas at a group of protesters who had defied orders to leave the parking lot of a burned-out convenience store. The newspaper also reported that a photographer for the Getty photo agency was arrested while covering the demonstrations and later released, as well as two German reporters who were arrested and detained for three hours.

A grand jury is set to begin hearing evidence on Wednesday to determine whether the officer involved in Brown's death, Darren Wilson, should be charged. The St. Louis County medical examiner's autopsy found that Brown was shot six to eight times in the head and chest, although the full findings are not expected for about two weeks. An independent autopsy conducted by lawyers for Brown's family and hired pathologists determined that Brown was shot six times, including twice in the head.

The Ferguson-Florissant School District announced late Monday that classes would be canceled for the remainder of the week due to the ongoing unrest.

Title: Trump Criticizes Republican Party's Delegate Selection Process, Calls it a "Scam"

Article:

Donald Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, has expressed frustration with the party's delegate selection process, calling it a "scam" and a "disgrace." In an exclusive interview with a news outlet, Trump criticized the Republican National Committee (RNC) and its chairman, Reince Priebus, for what he sees as an unfair and undemocratic system.

Trump is upset with several aspects of the delegate selection process, including how Colorado recently awarded all of its 34 delegates to Senator Ted Cruz without holding a primary or caucus. He does not agree that some delegates are not bound to vote for their state or district winner at this summer's GOP convention in Cleveland.

"It should go to a vote in Colorado like other places... The best way to do it would be just a vote, should be a vote of the people. That's the way it should be done. The delegate situation is a very unjust way of doing things," Trump said.

Trump also expressed frustration with the RNC's decision to allow some delegates to be unbound, which he believes gives an unfair advantage to certain candidates. He stated that he would like to see a more transparent and democratic process, where delegates are bound to vote for their state or district winner.

In response to Trump's criticism, Sean Spicer, the RNC's chief strategist and communications director, said that each state and territory submitted a plan on how to allocate and select their delegates last year, and those plans were made available to every campaign. He emphasized that understanding the delegate selection and allocation is a basic part of the campaign.

Trump has also floated the possibility of filing a lawsuit against the RNC, but has not yet made a decision. He has accused the Cruz campaign of not playing by the rules in its attempt to woo delegates, and has threatened to file several protests to the RNC.

Priebus has defended the RNC's nominating system, stating that the rules have not changed and that there is nothing mysterious about what Colorado Republicans did. The Colorado GOP opted to select unbound delegates to the Republican convention last summer.

The disagreement between Trump and Priebus is unusual, as the two had previously worked together to get Trump to sign a pledge backing the party nominee. However, Trump's tone has shifted in recent days, and he has become more critical of the party's process.

Title: White House Releases 42,000 Pages of Documents on Brett Kavanaugh's Time in the George W. Bush White House, Prompting Democratic Protests

The White House released 42,000 pages of documents related to Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's time working in the George W. Bush White House on Monday night, just hours before his confirmation hearing. The sudden release of the documents sparked controversy and protests from Democratic senators, who argued that they did not have sufficient time to review the information before the hearing.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer tweeted that the release of the documents was "exquisitely unfair" and that the Trump White House has been the "least transparent" in history. Schumer also stated that not a single senator would be able to review the records before the hearing.

During the hearing, Democratic senators Kamala Harris, Amy Klobuchar, and Richard Blumenthal objected to the late release of the documents, saying they had not had time to read or analyze them. They requested that the hearing be postponed or adjourned. Chairman Chuck Grassley responded by explaining that the committee had already reviewed 483,000 documents related to Kavanaugh's executive branch service, more than the last five Supreme Court nominees combined.

Judge Andrew Napolitano, appearing on Fox News, also criticized the White House's release of the documents, calling it "exquisitely unfair" and giving Democrats little time to prepare their questions. The controversy surrounding the document release dominated the early stages of the confirmation hearing, with Democrats voicing their concerns and frustration over the timing and transparency of the process.

Title: Pro-gun groups and politicians remain silent on gun control debate after Sandy Hook massacre

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, which left 20 children and six staff members dead, pro-gun organizations and politicians have remained largely silent on the issue of gun control. The silence is a departure from their usual swift response to previous mass shootings, where they often quickly counter calls for stricter gun laws.

The massacre, perpetrated by 20-year-old Adam Lanza, who killed his mother and then forced his way into the school, has sparked a national debate on gun control. While some conservative bloggers have pointed to instances where legal gun carriers have thwarted potential mass shootings, others have expressed concerns about the potential consequences of arming more Americans.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) and the Shooting Sports Foundation, a pro-gun rights group, have remained silent on the issue, as have many pro-gun politicians. Even conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh has criticized gun control proponents for trying to exploit the tragedy for political gain.

However, some pro-gun control advocates have seized on the tragedy as an opportunity to push for stricter gun laws. Robert Cavnar, a licensed gun owner and Huffington Post columnist, noted that the age and innocence of the victims have finally sparked a national conversation on the issue.

The conversation has been fueled by recent polls suggesting that a majority of Americans support some restrictions on gun ownership. While some have pointed to the Second Amendment as a reason for opposing stricter gun laws, others have questioned whether arming more Americans would ultimately save lives.

In the wake of the massacre, some have pointed to previous instances where legal gun carriers have thwarted potential mass shootings. However, others have expressed concerns about the potential consequences of arming more Americans. As one commenter on a blog noted, "A decade ago, or so, there were a few high school shootings. My interest would include why they occurred at that time, particularly since there didn't seem to be some novel change in the law or presence of guns. Why are we having another slew of cases now as compared to five years ago? Is this a cyclical thing?"

The debate is ongoing, with some calling for stricter gun control measures and others advocating for the protection of the Second Amendment.

Title: Obama Administration Cancels Arctic Oil Drilling Rights, Citing Shell's Disappointing Results

The Obama administration has announced that it will cancel its plans to sell oil drilling rights in the Arctic Sea through 2017. This decision comes after Royal Dutch Shell suspended its oil exploration in offshore Alaskan waters last month, citing disappointing results from a well in the Chukchi Sea. The Interior Department made the announcement, stating that it does not make sense to prepare for lease sales in the Arctic in the next year and a half, given the current market conditions and the amount of acreage already under lease.

The decision was met with applause from environmental groups, who had previously criticized the administration for approving permits for Shell to drill in the Arctic despite the risks of oil spills and climate change. The Natural Resources Defense Council called the decision an "essential reprieve" for Arctic waters.

However, Senator Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, criticized the decision, calling it "absurd" and "short-sighted." She argued that the Interior Department is throwing up regulatory roadblocks to prevent drilling and then using the lack of drilling to justify canceling the lease sales. The senator chairs the Senate Energy Committee and has been a vocal supporter of oil drilling in Alaska.

The administration also denied requests by Shell and Statoil to extend existing leases beyond 10 years. The companies had asked for five-year extensions, citing regulations that had prevented them from exploring for oil. Without the extensions, the leases will expire by 2020.

The decision marks a significant shift in the Obama administration's stance on Arctic drilling, which had previously approved new drilling permits for Shell earlier this year. The administration's decision to cancel the lease sales is seen as a response to the disappointing results from Shell's drilling efforts and the growing concerns about the impact of climate change on the Arctic region.

Title: US Diplomatic Posts Closed in Response to Credible Terror Threat

The US government has closed diplomatic posts in Central Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa, a decision praised by lawmakers from both parties as a response to credible intelligence suggesting a heightened terror threat. The closures, which will remain in place until at least next Saturday, affect 19 locations, with nine posts set to reopen on Monday.

Lawmakers have commended the administration's decision, citing the gravity of the intelligence and the need to protect Americans worldwide. "It's a very credible threat, and it's based on intelligence," said Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md.) on ABC-TV's This Week. "What we have to do now is the most important issue, is protect Americans throughout the world."

The terror threat has also shifted the focus of the debate on Capitol Hill regarding National Security Agency (NSA) surveillance programs. The debate, sparked by revelations from "NSA leaker" Edward Snowden, had previously centered on whether the programs should be curbed. However, the weekend's events have opened up a new front in the discussion, with some lawmakers crediting the NSA programs with helping to uncover a potential terrorist attack.

The closures affect diplomatic posts in Abu Dhabi, Amman, Cairo, Riyadh, Dhahran, Jeddah, Doha, Dubai, Kuwait, Manama, Muscat, Sanaa, Tripoli, Antanarivo, Bujumbura, Djibouti, Khartoum, Kigali, and Port Louis. Posts in nine locations, including Dhaka, Algiers, Nouakchott, Kabul, Herat, Mazar el Sharif, Baghdad, Basrah, and Erbil, will reopen on Monday.

Title: Biden Wins Maine, Secures 10 Victories on Super Tuesday, Narrowing Democratic Field

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden won the Democratic presidential primary in Maine, the last state to be called in the Super Tuesday contests. Biden's victories in 10 states, including Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Minnesota, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Virginia, and Maine, gave him a significant boost in the delegate count. He now leads Senator Bernie Sanders, his closest competitor, by 65 delegates.

Biden's campaign had been struggling after early primary contests, but a landslide victory in South Carolina last week gave him much-needed momentum. The consolidation of moderate candidates, including former Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Amy Klobuchar, further solidified Biden's position. Former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg also suspended his campaign and endorsed Biden, effectively making the race a two-candidate contest.

Senator Bernie Sanders, on the other hand, won his home state of Vermont, as well as Colorado and Utah. He also claimed victory in the delegate-rich state of California. Sanders remains in the race, but his campaign faces an uphill battle to catch up with Biden.

The next tests for the candidates will come on Tuesday, when voters in Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, North Dakota, and Washington state head to the polls, and on St. Patrick's Day, March 17, when Arizona, Florida, Illinois, and Ohio have their chance to vote. Georgia will hold its primary on March 24.

Title: The Rise of Donald Trump: A Sign of Growing Disillusionment with the Republican Party's Economic Message

The recent rise of Donald Trump's presidential campaign has sent shockwaves through the Republican Party, as the party's establishment has seen its candidates humiliated by an "aggressively ignorant demagogue" who has tapped into the economic anxieties of white middle and working-class voters. The article suggests that the GOP's economic message, which has been sold to its base for decades, is no longer resonating with voters.

The article argues that the Republican Party has long sold a myth that the economy boomed in the decades following World War II, and that government regulation, taxes, and an overly generous welfare system have killed the American dream. However, the article claims that this is a "fantastic lie," as the actual economic history of America since 1945 shows that the country is vastly wealthier today than it was 40 years ago.

The article provides statistics to support this claim, noting that per capita GDP in the U.S. grew from $17,490 in 1945 to $55,185 in 2014, a significant increase. However, the article argues that this growth has not trickled down to the majority of Americans, with the average household income of the bottom 50% of American households remaining stagnant, while the top 5% of households have seen significant increases.

The article suggests that Trump's appeal is based on his willingness to exploit racism and xenophobia, but also notes that his message resonates with many Americans who are angry about the empty promises of the Republican Party and the fact that the party is run for the benefit of the rich. The article concludes that the Republican Party's manipulation of culture war issues and racial and ethnic animosities has allowed it to hide the fact that its economic policies do not align with the interests of middle- and working-class Americans.

Title: Grand Jury Declines to Indict Officer Darren Wilson in Michael Brown's Death

A grand jury in St. Louis has declined to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown on August 9. The decision has sparked widespread protests and unrest in Ferguson, with reports of looting, arson, and gunfire. The St. Louis County Police Chief, Jon Belmar, stated that at least 150 gunshots were fired, and 12 buildings were set on fire, but no deaths or serious injuries have been reported.

Officer Wilson spoke publicly for the first time on Tuesday, telling ABC News that Michael Brown did not have his hands up when he was shot. The officer's account contradicts eyewitness testimony from several witnesses who claimed Brown was shot while surrendering.

The Ferguson mayor, James Knowles, criticized the National Guard for their slow response to the situation, stating that they did not deploy quickly enough to prevent violence and arson. The Missouri governor, Jay Nixon, promised to deploy over 2,200 troops to keep peace in Ferguson.

The Brown family's lawyer, Benjamin Crump, blasted the prosecutor's decision, stating that the process is broken and that the family will continue to fight for justice. The family's mother, Lesley McSpadden, was devastated by the news, screaming and sobbing when informed of the decision.

The protests in Ferguson turned violent, with demonstrators taunting police, shattering windows, and setting fire to two police cars. Scores of police officers used tear gas and bean bags to disperse the crowd. Looters plundered a Walgreens and Autozone store, while a Little Caesars pizza restaurant and local beauty shop were set ablaze.

Meanwhile, peaceful protests took place in several other cities, including New York, Oakland, Philadelphia, Detroit, and Washington, D.C. Demonstrators in New York chanted "No justice, no peace, no racist police" and carried signs reading "Jail Killing Cops" and "Resistance Is Justified." In Oakland, protesters laid in the middle of an intersection in silent protest, then marched down Broadway shouting "Hands up, don't shoot" and "Black lives matter — all lives matter."

President Obama condemned the "destructive" behavior in Ferguson, urging calm and recognizing the broader problems that the situation speaks to. The FAA issued a no-fly zone over Lambert-St. Louis International Airport to provide a safe environment for law enforcement activities.

Title: Mueller Unveils New Charges Against Gates and Manafort, Deepening Legal Peril

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election has taken a significant turn with the unveiling of new criminal charges against former Trump campaign aide Rick Gates and his longtime business partner, Paul Manafort. The superseding indictment accuses Gates and Manafort of a series of financial crimes, including tax evasion, bank fraud, and money laundering.

The new charges against Gates, a key figure in the investigation, come as observers had been expecting him to strike an agreement with Mueller to avoid going to trial. Seth Waxman, a former federal prosecutor, believes the timing of the filing aims to maximize the pressure on Gates to cooperate with the investigation. "It is designed to continue to ratchet up the pressure on Manafort and Gates to flip," he said.

Gates' testimony could prove especially damaging for Manafort, as they worked together for over a decade, including on lobbying work for a pro-Russia political party in Ukraine. If Gates were to strike a plea deal, it could put heavy pressure on Manafort to cut a deal of his own. This could potentially provide inside information about any contact between the Trump campaign and Moscow during the summer of 2016, a key period when Russia began orchestrating the release of hacked Democratic emails.

Former FBI Assistant Director Ron Hosko believes Gates' testimony could drive a final nail in the coffin for Manafort. "The Manafort indictment is serious, is ugly, and is very likely backed by large volumes of evidence," he said.

The possibility of Gates taking the witness stand could be enough to get Manafort to cooperate with Mueller's prosecutors, which is likely their main goal. Manafort worked for Trump's campaign for six months before resigning under pressure in August 2016 over reports of his dealings with a pro-Russia oligarch in Ukraine. He was in the room for a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower with a Russian lawyer who had promised Donald Trump Jr. damaging information on Hillary Clinton's campaign.

If Gates were to strike a plea deal, he would be the fourth known witness to cooperate with Mueller's investigation, following former national security adviser Michael Flynn, former Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos, and a California man ensnared in the probe for selling bank account numbers to foreigners committing identity fraud.

Former prosecutors say Gates' testimony could help prosecutors sort through their evidence against Manafort and fill in holes in timelines and complex financial transactions. "In most businesses and white-collar cases, the government really needs a cooperator to explain events," said Jack Sharman, a former Whitewater special counsel.

The larger question remains what the relation of any of these offenses is to the original core mission of the special counsel, who was appointed due to concerns over presidential campaign involvement.

Title: Monsanto Ordered to Pay $289m in Damages Over Glyphosate Cancer Claim

A California jury has ordered chemical giant Monsanto to pay $289m in damages to a man who claimed that herbicides containing glyphosate, a key ingredient in Roundup and RangerPro weedkillers, caused his cancer. The verdict is the first to go to trial alleging a link between glyphosate and cancer.

The jury found that Monsanto knew its products were dangerous and failed to warn consumers, and ordered the company to pay $250m in punitive damages, bringing the total to almost $290m. The claimant, groundskeeper Dewayne Johnson, was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 2014 and regularly used a form of RangerPro while working at a school in Benicia, California.

Monsanto denies that glyphosate causes cancer and has announced its intention to appeal the ruling. The company claims that more than 800 scientific studies and reviews, as well as conclusions from regulatory authorities, support the fact that glyphosate does not cause cancer and did not cause Johnson's cancer.

The implications of this verdict are likely to be felt far beyond Monsanto's headquarters in Missouri, as it could lead to hundreds of other claims against the company. Glyphosate is the world's most common weedkiller, and the science about its safety is still far from settled. The International Agency for Research on Cancer concluded in 2015 that glyphosate is "probably carcinogenic to humans," but the US Environmental Protection Agency continues to insist that it is safe when used carefully.

Title: Investigation into Boston Marathon Explosions Continues, New Leads Emerge

The investigation into the Boston Marathon explosions is ongoing, with investigators scrutinizing scores of videos and photographs from surveillance cameras, smartphones, and television crews to track down the buyers of the explosive devices used in the attack. The FBI has found remnants of kitchen pressure cookers, a torn backpack, and circuit boards and wires from timing devices, which they hope to trace back to their sellers.

A piece of the lid from one of the pressure cookers was found on a rooftop near the blast site, giving an indication of the tremendous force of the explosion. So far, no one has taken responsibility for the attacks.

As the investigation enters its third day, there are signs of heightened alertness across the country. New York City officials reported an increase in reports of suspicious packages, with 143 reports received between Monday afternoon and Tuesday midnight, a 300% increase over the same period last year. In Oklahoma City, City Hall was briefly evacuated as authorities examined a stolen rental truck parked outside, but no bomb was found.

In Washington, parts of two Senate office buildings were shut down as officials investigated reports of suspicious letters or packages, and the Secret Service arrested a suspect on Wednesday evening after intercepting a letter addressed to President Obama containing a suspicious substance.

The investigation is ongoing, with investigators working to track down the buyers of the explosive devices and identify those responsible for the deadly attacks.

Title: Senate Report on Benghazi Attack Sparks Media Frenzy, Misleading Coverage of Hillary Clinton

The recent release of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence's report on the 2012 Benghazi terrorist attack has sparked a media frenzy, with many outlets focusing on Hillary Clinton's leadership and potential blame. However, a closer examination of the report reveals that Clinton's name is not mentioned in the bipartisan portions of the review, and the only references to her come from partisan Republicans in an addendum.

Despite this, many media outlets have seized on the report as an opportunity to criticize Clinton's leadership, with some going so far as to accuse her of being "incurious" and having a "drip, drip, drip problem." However, a closer look at the report and Clinton's own statements reveals a more nuanced picture.

Clinton has acknowledged ultimate responsibility for any bureaucratic shortcomings that may have contributed to the tragedy, and has taken steps to implement the recommendations of the Accountability Review Board, an independent, nonpartisan review panel. The report itself singles out bureaucrats, not the Secretary of State, for scrutiny over diplomatic security failures, and four mid-level department officials were suspended as a result.

The media's focus on Clinton's leadership has been criticized for being one-sided and lacking context. The report's findings are not a reflection on Clinton's leadership, but rather a review of the events surrounding the attack and recommendations for future improvements. The Accountability Review Board's report, which was released in 2013, also laid out dozens of recommendations for preventing future tragedies, which are being implemented.

In conclusion, the media's coverage of the Senate report on Benghazi has been marred by misleading and one-sided reporting, which has been criticized for lacking context and nuance. A closer examination of the report and Clinton's own statements reveals a more complex picture, and it is essential to consider the full range of facts and context when evaluating the events surrounding the Benghazi attack.

Title: Trump's Trade War with China: A Losing Battle

The trade war between the United States and China, initiated by President Donald Trump in 2018, appears to be a losing battle for the US. The tariffs imposed by Trump on Chinese goods and the threatened additional tariffs may have slowed China's economy, with some data indicating a dip in growth in 2018. However, this slowdown was likely due to government efforts to constrain credit growth, rather than the tariffs themselves.

The trade war has given multinational companies an incentive to accelerate their plans to shift production out of China, and has likely made Chinese companies more cautious. The US, on the other hand, has been hit by the trade war, with tariffs raising prices for American consumers and factories alike. A pair of studies by trade economists estimate the losses to the US economy in the tens of billions of dollars annually.

The US has also been affected by Chinese retaliation, with tariffs hitting American farmers hard. Chinese tariffs on soybeans, for example, have led to a significant decline in US exports to China. The US agricultural sector, which had been growing exponentially, has seen a decline in exports and farm incomes. The US government has responded with direct payments to farmers, but this is not a sustainable business model, and a wave of farm bankruptcies has begun.

China's autocratic regime is less vulnerable to the shifting winds of politics than the US's democratically elected politicians, and its residents are more accustomed to enduring economic hardship. China's recent economic growth has also given it a buffer to absorb economic shocks. The US, on the other hand, is a more mature economy, and a slowdown would have a more significant impact.

The trade war has not been a success for the US, with most of its biggest goals remaining unfulfilled. The US has been forced to back down, with a trade truce leaving many of its demands unmet. The Chinese economy has also shown signs of bottoming out, with the government unleashing fresh stimulus.

The trade war is not the only front on which the US is struggling. The struggle to control the future of high technology is arguably even more important to the balance of economic power between the US and China. The US has been putting pressure on Huawei Technologies Co., China's leading telecommunications manufacturer, but has been met with resistance. The US has also implemented export controls on many technology products, which will hurt Chinese tech in the short term but could push China to accelerate its efforts to replicate and surpass US technology.

In the long term, this could lead to a more direct competition between Chinese and American companies, similar to what happened when Japanese companies began to compete with American ones in the 1970s and 1980s. Overall, Trump's trade war with China appears to be a losing battle, with the US struggling to achieve its goals and China adapting and fighting back effectively.

Title: Court Ruling on Trump's Twitter Account Raises Questions about Free Speech and Social Media

The Second Circuit Court of Appeals recently ruled that Donald Trump cannot block Twitter users from following his @realDonaldTrump account, citing the First Amendment. However, this decision has sparked controversy and raised important questions about the nature of free speech on social media platforms.

The court's reasoning was based on the idea that Trump's Twitter account represents an outlet for official communications and interactions, controlled by the President. However, this analysis is flawed. Twitter owns and controls Trump's account, and he has no legal right to wrest control from the platform.

The court's misunderstanding of the platform is evident in its failure to recognize the fundamental difference between a public forum and a private platform. When a politician rents a private venue, there is typically an exchange of money and a rental agreement that grants enforceable legal rights to access the property and control others' access. In contrast, Twitter's terms of service grant the platform absolute control over users' accounts, allowing it to suspend or terminate accounts at any time.

Moreover, the court's ruling ignores the government-speech doctrine, which recognizes that government officials have limited free-speech rights. Just as a politician does not have the right to control a public forum, Trump does not have the right to control Twitter's platform.

The article also highlights the importance of understanding the nature of social media platforms. When users share content on social media, they are not solely responsible for their own speech, as the platform grants itself the right to use, copy, reproduce, and distribute that content. This raises questions about the extent to which users have control over their own speech on social media.

The ruling has sparked debate about the role of government intervention in social media platforms. Some argue that the court's decision is an overreach, while others see it as a necessary step to protect free speech. Ultimately, the decision highlights the need for a nuanced understanding of the complex issues surrounding free speech and social media.

Title: Entrepreneurial Spirit: Meet Ms. Brodie, a Passionate Philanthropist Turning Food into Opportunity

Article:

In a recent conversation with Ms. Brodie, a 27-year-old entrepreneur, she shared her inspiring story of turning her passion for food and service into a unique philanthropic venture. Growing up, food and service ran in her family, with her grandmother publishing a well-known cookbook in the 1960s, which raised funds for the Union of Jewish Women, and her father teaching her how to drive while delivering leftover food from local restaurants to shelters. Ms. Brodie also spent her Sundays giving cooking lessons to friends and taking extra meals to shelters to eat with residents.

After college, she volunteered at a homeless shelter and worked at the Human Rights Campaign in Washington. This experience sparked an idea: "What would it look like to do this differently?" She began to think about how to make a more significant impact. With no background in the food industry, aside from scooping ice cream as a teenager, Ms. Brodie enrolled at the Institute of Culinary Education in Lower Manhattan and attended a food business boot camp in Harlem. She also started picking up shifts at restaurants to gain hands-on experience.

After discussing her idea with friends and meeting with philanthropists, Ms. Brodie set up her classroom cafe in June. The response was overwhelming, with nearly half of her students receiving job offers before completing the program. Ms. Brodie's entrepreneurial spirit and passion for making a difference are an inspiration to many, and her story serves as a reminder that anyone can turn their ideas into reality with determination and hard work.

Title: California's High-Speed Rail Project Faces Backlash from Farmers Over Land Seizure and Unpaid Compensation

The California High-Speed Rail project has faced criticism from farmers in the Central Valley, who claim the state has seized their land without paying them the hundreds of thousands of dollars owed to them. According to an order of possession by the Superior Court, California can take private land through eminent domain for the project. While landowners are expected to be reimbursed for their property and expenses, many farmers say state officials have offered excuses for the delay in payment.

John Diepersloot, a fruit farmer, told The Los Angeles Times that he is out $250,000 in infrastructure costs and has yet to receive a dime from the state. "I don't have that kind of money," he said. Mark Wasser, a Sacramento-based attorney representing over 70 farmers and businesses affected by the project, stated that property owners are frustrated with the California High-Speed Rail Authority's lack of transparency and changing plans.

Rail authority officials acknowledge that they have not yet paid numerous landowners, but have not provided a reason for the delay. In a statement to Fox News, Don Odell, the authority's chief of real property, said that they strive to work closely with affected property owners to minimize the impact of the project and ensure they receive fair market value for their land and expenses.

The California High-Speed Rail project has been plagued by delays, shifting plans, and questions over cost and funding since its inception. The projected $79 billion project is years behind schedule, with the latest estimate for completion set for 2033. The project has faced criticism from Republican lawmakers and President Trump, who has called it a "disaster" and demanded repayment of federal funds.

Title: Cuomo Fends Off Challenge, But Shift to the Left May Not Be Enough to Secure Future

The recent Democratic primary election in New York saw Governor Andrew Cuomo emerge victorious, spending $18 million to hold off a challenge from actress and political novice Cynthia Nixon. Cuomo's victory was marked by a shift to the left, with the incumbent agreeing to restore voting rights for parolees and moving closer to marijuana legalization. However, some remain skeptical of Cuomo's recent shift, and experts suggest he may need to demonstrate more progressive credentials to appeal to Democratic voters.

The election saw Cuomo's lieutenant governor, Kathy Hochul, narrowly avoid defeat, and several Democratic state senators lost their seats, giving the Republicans control of the state Senate. Cuomo has denied any plans to run for president in 2020, but the election results may indicate a shift in the political landscape.

The election was marked by high voter turnout, with nearly 1.5 million Democrats participating, compared to less than 600,000 in 2014. Cuomo's ability to run against Washington and the Trump administration may have helped draw energy from Democrats eager to participate in elections this year to check the President.

Experts suggest that Cuomo's shift to the left may not be enough to secure his future, as the Democratic Party nationwide is increasingly aligning itself with priorities like increased ballot access and single-payer healthcare. Cuomo will need to demonstrate more progressive credentials to appeal to Democratic voters, who are increasingly turning to the left.

The election results may indicate a shift in the political landscape, with voters nominating more liberal candidates to represent Democrats in governor's races in Florida and Georgia. The election also saw teachers going on strike in Oklahoma and West Virginia earlier this year in efforts to secure higher pay, and voters later defeating some lawmakers who voted against those efforts in Oklahoma's state contests.

Overall, the election results suggest that Cuomo's shift to the left may not be enough to secure his future, and he will need to demonstrate more progressive credentials to appeal to Democratic voters.

Title: President Obama Names Susan Rice as National Security Adviser, Despite Criticism Over Benghazi

President Barack Obama announced on Wednesday that Susan Rice, the current United States Ambassador to the United Nations, will replace Tom Donilon as his national security adviser. Rice's appointment comes despite persistent criticism from Republicans over her initial account of the 2012 Benghazi terror attack.

According to Obama, Rice is a "tireless advocate" for advancing America's interests. Rice will not require Senate confirmation for the job, as she is replacing Donilon, who is resigning from the post. Rice had previously been considered for the Secretary of State position, but withdrew from consideration amid the ongoing fallout over her role in the Benghazi attack.

Rice had appeared on five Sunday shows after the attack and claimed that it was triggered by protests over an anti-Islam film, an explanation many lawmakers deemed inaccurate. The administration later acknowledged that there were no protests on the ground in Benghazi, although they have not officially ruled out the possibility that protests elsewhere may have played a role.

Republicans have expressed skepticism over Rice's appointment, with Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.) accusing her of "misleading" the public over Benghazi. "How are they going to have the authority for people to believe what they're saying, when he's promoting someone who directly and deliberately misled the public over Benghazi?" Paul said on Fox News.

The administration had previously released the so-called "talking points" that showed officials drafting and re-drafting their storyline in advance of Rice's appearance. The intelligence community cited demonstrations as a factor in the attack, but references to militant and Islamic extremist groups, as well as prior security warnings and incidents, were ultimately removed after objections from various administration officials. It is unclear what level of involvement Rice had in this process.

Rice's predecessor, Tom Donilon, is resigning from the post after his wife took a job that involves a lot of foreign travel. Donilon has been in the administration since the start, serving as deputy national security adviser.

In related news, Samantha Power, a former Obama aide, was nominated to succeed Rice as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. Power was an aide to the Obama campaign in 2008 but resigned after a report was published in which she called then-candidate Hillary Clinton a "monster."

Title: Classified House Intelligence Committee Memo Raises Concerns of FISA Abuse and DOJ-FBI Misconduct

A classified memo compiled by the House Intelligence Committee has been described as "shocking" and "explosive" by Republican lawmakers who have viewed it. The memo reportedly reveals "extensive Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) abuse" and contains information about the Department of Justice (DOJ) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), as well as the infamous Trump-Russia dossier.

According to national security journalist Sara Carter, sources have told her that the memo's contents could lead to the end of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into President Trump and his associates. Another unnamed congressional member reportedly stated that the document may be released by the end of the month.

Several Republican lawmakers have publicly expressed their concerns about the memo's contents. Representative Louie Gohmert tweeted a link to Carter's story, stating that the truth may not set the guilty free but it needs to come out. Representative Ron DeSantis called the report "deeply troubling" and raised serious questions about the upper echelon of the Obama DOJ and Comey FBI as it relates to the so-called collusion investigation.

Representative Scott Perry described the memo's contents as "alarming," saying it's like something that would happen in a "KGB" country. Representative Matt Gaetz believes the consequences of the memo's release will be major changes in people currently working at the FBI and the Department of Justice. Gaetz also called for the document to be released to the public, stating that the facts contained in the memo are "jaw-dropping" and demand full transparency.

Representative Mark Meadows described the memo as "troubling" and "shocking," saying part of him wishes he didn't read it because he doesn't want to believe that such things could be happening in the country he loves.

Title: Paul Ryan's Path to Power: A Run for Leadership or the White House?

Paul Ryan, the current House Budget Committee Chairman, has reportedly given little thought to running for leadership, according to his handlers. Instead, he is focusing on amassing more power within Congress, using his influence in the House leadership to promote his trademark Medicare plan and engineer spending cuts. Ryan's friends suggest that this path could ultimately lead him to an eventual run for House GOP leader or speaker.

Ryan has been surprised at how central his governing role has been among House Republicans since returning from his failed run for vice president. He was instrumental in crafting the GOP's new debt ceiling strategy and will craft a budget plan that sets the direction for the GOP caucus on virtually every consequential issue. With this in mind, he calculates that naked national ambitions would only dilute his growing power as Speaker John Boehner's unofficial wing man.

Ryan continues to cultivate a national political and financial network that would serve him in any role. A top GOP source said Ryan recently met with Spencer Zwick, Mitt Romney's fundraising guru, who made plain much of the 2012 donor base stands ready to back him if he were to ever warm again to a White House run. Ryan also made a fundraising trip to Texas last month for his Prosperity PAC, where he was hosted by top Romney donors who urged him to run, convinced he has been totally vetted and passed the readiness test.

Some conservatives suggested Ryan challenge Boehner right after the election, but he would never do so. However, in conversations and others, longtime associates of Ryan noticed a subtle but significant change in his mood. He seemed open to ultimately running for leadership, suggesting to two friends that this was the best and safest way to get Medicare and budget cuts done.

Ryan would never challenge Boehner or his No. 2, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, for their current jobs. However, many Republicans think Boehner will leave in a few years, perhaps after the 2014 election, to make way for the next generation of leaders. The safest path of all would be his current trajectory: Run the Budget Committee until 2014 and then take over the Ways and Means Committee, to do to tax policy what he did for entitlements and spending.

**FBI Bias Allegations Spark Call for Special Counsel Investigation**

Senator Lindsey Graham has called for the creation of a special counsel to investigate the FBI and Justice Department, citing evidence that suggests the agencies treated Hillary Clinton more leniently than they did President Trump during the 2016 election campaign. The call comes as newly released documents reveal the extent of anti-Trump sentiment among FBI employees who were involved in handling the investigation into Clinton's secret email server and the Russia investigation that led to Robert Mueller's special counsel probe.

The documents, which include transcripts of interviews with fired FBI agent Peter Strzok and former FBI lawyer Lisa Page, show that they were determined to prevent Trump from becoming president and had impeachment on their minds once he did take office. Strzok and Page's testimony has sparked concerns about bias within the FBI and Justice Department.

Graham, a South Carolina Republican, plans to introduce legislation to create a special counsel to investigate the FBI and Justice Department. He argues that there is "overwhelming evidence" that suggests the agencies had a different standard for Clinton and Trump, and that someone outside the political system should investigate.

The Mueller investigation is nearing its end, and Democrats are pushing for the release of the final report. The House has approved a resolution urging Attorney General William Barr to release the report, but Senate Democrats have refused to support Graham's proposal for a special counsel investigation.

Graham's committee will hold hearings on bias at the FBI and Justice Department, and he has promised to get to the bottom of whether the bureau misled judges when it obtained a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act warrant to spy on Trump campaign figure Carter Page. The hearings will also focus on how the FBI obtained the warrant using a salacious, unverified dossier written by former British spy Christopher Steele.

The dossier, which claims Trump had ties to Russia, was used as part of the FBI's argument to obtain the surveillance warrant on Page. Republicans have claimed the FBI failed to disclose that the dossier's author was being funded by the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign as opposition research.

The House Judiciary and Oversight and Government Reform committees previously called in Strzok and Page to testify about their behavior, and their transcripts were released this week. The transcripts show that Strzok acknowledged that Clinton was not a target, subject, or suspect during the investigation, but rather a "critical player."

Title: Government Shutdown Looms Large in Washington D.C., But Is It Really a Cause for Concern?

Article:

The specter of a federal government shutdown has returned to Washington D.C., sending shockwaves through the halls of Congress.
