However, he also criticized the bill for containing unnecessary spending and not addressing issues such as the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and border wall funding.

The president had initially threatened to veto the bill, which would have led to a government shutdown. He ultimately decided to sign the bill, calling the legislative process "ridiculous." Trump stated that he will not sign another bill like this again, citing the need for changes to Congress's rules to make progress on vital issues.

The president called for the approval of a line-item veto and the elimination of the Senate's filibuster rule, which requires 60 votes to advance most legislation. However, it is worth noting that a line-item veto would require a constitutional amendment, as the Supreme Court ruled it unconstitutional in the 1998 decision Clinton v. City of New York.

Trump emphasized that the bill provides a historic boost to military spending, including the largest pay increase for troops in a decade. He claimed that the investments made by the bill reverse years of defense cuts and put the U.S. military back on track to becoming the most formidable fighting force in the world.

The president blamed the omnibus bill's huge price tag on Democrats, who he said demanded extra spending in exchange for funding the military. He claimed that Democrats oppose military spending and that the extra spending in the bill is a "wasted sum of money" that is not good for the country.

Title: Palin Responds to Bashir's Attacks, Says She's "Used to It"

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican vice presidential candidate, has spoken out for the first time since Martin Bashir's resignation from MSNBC. Bashir stepped down from his position after making controversial comments about Palin on his November 15 broadcast, calling her a "world-class idiot" and referencing a diary entry about a plantation manager forcing a slave to defecate in another slave's mouth.

In an interview on Fox News's "Fox & Friends," Palin dismissed Bashir's attacks, saying she's "used to it." She acknowledged that it's a "sad state of affairs" that she has to admit to being used to such treatment. Palin also expressed relief that many in the media condemned Bashir's comments, saying that those with a platform have a responsibility to uphold higher standards.

When asked if Bashir's resignation was sufficient, Palin said she has to move past it and accept his apology. She noted that she would have been "personally hurt" by such attacks five or six years ago, but now feels "kind of calloused" and accepts that attacks will come her way.

Palin also reiterated her previous statement that attacks on conservative women are often more severe and that there is an "obvious" double standard. She added that she hasn't received any support or condemnation from feminist groups or organizations.

Title: WikiLeaks' Assange Claims Obama Administration Focused on Russia to Delegitimize Trump Administration

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange stated in an interview with Fox News's Sean Hannity that the Obama administration's focus on Russia's alleged role in the Democratic hacks leading up to Donald Trump's election is an "obvious" attempt to delegitimize the Trump administration. According to a transcript of excerpts from the network, Assange claimed that the Obama administration is trying to say that President-elect Trump is not a legitimate president.

Assange reiterated the group's denial that Russia was the source of the Democratic documents released over the summer, stating that their source is not a state party. He also pointed to private comments from members of the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign in documents published by WikiLeaks, suggesting that these statements may have influenced the 2016 election.

When asked if WikiLeaks influenced the election, Assange said it is impossible to know for certain, but noted that if it did, the true statements of Hillary Clinton, her campaign manager John Podesta, and the DNC head Debbie Wasserman Schultz may have been the deciding factor.

It is worth noting that the exact details of the source of the leaked documents remain unclear, as Assange declined to disclose the identity of the source.

Title: Putin Calls for Talks on Future of War-Torn East Ukraine, Suggests "Statehood" Consideration

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin has called for immediate talks on the future of war-torn eastern Ukraine, stating that "statehood" should be considered for the region. In a televised address, Putin emphasized the need for "substantive talks" on the political organization of society and statehood in southeastern Ukraine, with the goal of protecting the lawful interests of the people who live there.

This marks a shift in Russia's stance, as it has previously only called for greater rights under a decentralized federal system to be accorded to the eastern regions of Ukraine, where predominantly Russian-speakers reside. Putin did not directly address Western sanctions on Russia during the program, but blamed the crisis in Ukraine on the West, accusing it of supporting a "coup" against pro-Kremlin President Viktor Yanukovych in February.

Putin denied that Moscow has sent regular troops to fight in Ukraine, but pro-Russian rebels have said that many Russian soldiers have volunteered while "on vacation." The West has accused Moscow of having its troops spearhead a lightning counter-offensive that has put Ukrainian government forces on the back foot in the nearly five-month conflict. NATO has reported that Moscow has over 1,000 troops on the ground in Ukraine and 20,000 massed by the border.

Analysts, including Russian experts, see Putin as aiming to create a statelet in eastern Ukraine, similar to Moscow's support for de facto separatist states in Moldova and Georgia. Putin has used the term "Novorossiya" (New Russia) to describe the region, a loaded term that has sparked outrage in Kiev and the West.

Despite calling for a negotiated political solution to the crisis, Putin has used fiery rhetoric in recent days, comparing the shelling of rebel-held cities to the Nazi siege of Leningrad. Aid groups have condemned indiscriminate shelling by both sides in the conflict, which has claimed almost 2,600 lives.

Title: Clinton's Image Control Apparatus: A Behind-the-Scenes Look at Her Campaign's Efforts

Article:

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign has been marked by a focus on building an approachable image, with the Democratic front-runner opting for town halls and less-scripted gatherings with voters. However, emails obtained by the Associated Press reveal a careful, behind-the-scenes effort to review introductory remarks and suggest questions that align with her campaign platform. This level of planning is not unusual for campaigns, but it does raise questions about the kind of image-control apparatus that could be deployed in a Clinton White House.

The campaign's attention to detail extends to the minute details of Clinton's appearances, including the stemless glassware in her green room. This fixation on planning has sometimes pulled local officials uncomfortably into the political arena. For example, the head of public relations for South Carolina's Greenville Technical College, Becky Mann, wrote in an email to the college's president, Keith Miller, that the campaign suggested questions that Miller could pose, such as "What do we need to do to make college affordable?" College affordability is one of Clinton's campaign issues.

The AP report also highlights the campaign's efforts to steer conversations with her audiences. This includes reviewing introductory remarks for college presidents and students presenting Clinton as a speaker. The exchanges preview the kind of image-control apparatus that could be deployed in a Clinton White House.

In related news, government sources view last week's Inspector General report as a potential boost to the likelihood of the FBI recommending a criminal indictment against Clinton. The report found that Clinton broke government rules with her personal email use, increasing the likelihood and pressure for the Justice Department to pursue criminal charges.

Meanwhile, some U.S. intelligence officials are concerned that Donald Trump's "shoot from the hip" style could pose national security risks as they prepare to give him a routine pre-election briefing once he is formally anointed as the Republican presidential nominee. Eight senior security officials told Reuters they had concerns over briefing Trump, whose brash, unpredictable campaign style has been a feature of his rise as an insurgent candidate.

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama's Campaign, Accusing it of Division and Anger

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, delivered a fiery speech in Ohio on Tuesday night, criticizing President Obama's campaign as a "campaign of division and anger and hate." Romney accused the president of running a negative campaign, citing recent remarks made by Vice President Biden. Romney's speech was written personally by him over the course of two days and set the tone for the rest of the week, as he plans to attend closed-camera fundraisers and hand off the campaign bullhorn to his new running mate, Paul Ryan.

In his address, Romney claimed that recent flare-ups on the trail were signs of a president's campaign gone bitter. He pointed to Biden's claim that Romney and the Republicans intend to "put y'all back in chains," which Romney's campaign called a "new low." Romney accused the president of being "intellectually exhausted" and out of ideas.

Romney also mocked Obama's statements during the 2008 campaign that without fresh ideas, "you use stale tactics to scare voters." Romney accused Obama of now making that strategy "the heart of his campaign."

The Obama campaign responded to Romney's speech, saying he "seemed unhinged" and that his negative ads are "demonstrably false." The campaign also defended Biden's comments, likening them to language used repeatedly by Republican officials.

Biden made the remarks during a stop in Danville, Va., where he took a swipe at Romney's plan to ease financial regulations, saying it would allow big banks to write their own rules and put Americans back in chains. The remark's context is unclear, with some conservative blogs claiming Biden made a reference to slavery. However, the Romney campaign did not accuse Biden of any racial reference.

In his speech, Romney accused Obama of seeking to divide America, whether by race, occupation, or party affiliation, as a campaign strategy. He championed himself as the savior of the middle class, citing areas where Obama's policies have failed the American people.

Title: France to Offer All-Expenses-Paid Grants to U.S. Scientists to Relocate and Focus on Climate Research

France's President Emmanuel Macron is set to announce the winners of the "Make Our Planet Great Again" competition, a initiative aimed at attracting international scientists to work on climate-related research in France. The competition was launched in June, following the United States' withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Macron had previously invited scientists who were dissatisfied with the decision to "come to France and work with us together" on climate policy-related research.

The competition received over 90 applications, with around 50 projects selected for funding. While the majority of applicants were from the United States, the competition was expanded to include climate scientists from other countries. The grants will be funded by the French state.

The initiative has sparked some criticism from French researchers, who argue that funding for domestic projects is lacking. However, the French government believes that the influx of international talent will help drive innovation and progress in the field of climate research.

The move is seen as a response to the United States' decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, which was signed by the Obama administration in 2015. The agreement aimed to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change. President Donald Trump announced the withdrawal of the United States from the agreement in 2017, citing concerns that it would harm the country's economy.

In his announcement, Trump stated that the agreement would disadvantage the United States and benefit other countries, and that it would lead to lost jobs, lower wages, and diminished economic production. The decision was met with widespread criticism from the international community and environmental groups.

The French government's initiative is seen as a way to counterbalance the United States' decision and promote international cooperation on climate change. The winners of the "Make Our Planet Great Again" competition are expected to be announced on Monday evening.

**Bernie Sanders: A Profile of the 78-Year-Old Senator Running for President**

Bernie Sanders, a registered independent senator from Vermont, has emerged as a front-runner in the Democratic race for president. Despite his age and a recent heart attack, Sanders has raised over $100 million in funds and is drawing crowds in the tens of thousands. But who is Bernie Sanders, and what does he stand for?

Born in Brooklyn, New York, to Jewish parents, Sanders grew up in a humble apartment, which made him class-conscious at an early age. He attended the University of Chicago and participated in anti-war and civil rights activism in the 1960s and 1970s. Sanders applied for conscientious objector status during the Vietnam War, although his application was rejected due to his age.

Sanders entered politics in 1971, running for a US Senate seat in Vermont as a Liberty Union candidate. He lost that race, as well as a couple of campaigns to become governor. His first major political success came when he was elected mayor of Burlington, Vermont, in 1980, beating a six-term incumbent. He went on to serve four terms.

Sanders has been a vocal critic of the political establishment, often taking on both Republican and Democratic politicians for being beholden to wealthy donors and industries. He is the longest-serving independent in congressional history and has been a strong advocate for progressive policies, including universal healthcare, paid leave for new parents, and free college education.

Sanders has been attacked for his voting record on gun control, including his opposition to various forms of the Brady Bill. However, he claims his record reflects the priorities of his Vermont constituents.

In 2016, Sanders ran for president as a long-shot candidate, but he confounded expectations by setting fundraising records and challenging Hillary Clinton's nomination. Now, he is running on a characteristically progressive platform, featuring Medicare for all, a $15 minimum wage, and tuition-free public college.

Despite some Democratic leaders expressing skepticism about his chances, Sanders remains a force to be reckoned with, drawing large crowds and endorsements from liberal leaders like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. With his unapologetic demeanor and authentic approach, Sanders may yet prove that he can beat the odds once again.

Title: States' Abortion Bans May Face Challenges Over Definition of 20-Week Limit

The recent trend of states banning most abortions after a certain point in pregnancy has sparked debate over the definition of that 20-week limit. The Texas law, signed by Governor Rick Perry, is the 12th state to impose such a ban, starting from fertilization. However, this definition may cause confusion for women and their doctors, and ultimately affect the constitutionality of these laws.

Doctors measure pregnancy from the date of the last normal menstrual period (LMP), which is typically two weeks before fertilization. This means that a 20-week post-fertilization ban would actually be equivalent to a 22-week pregnancy. The use of LMP as a measurement standard developed before the widespread use of ultrasound technology.

State laws and a bill passed by the U.S. House are written with a different definition, pegging the beginning of pregnancy to fertilization. This means that a 20-week post-fertilization ban would actually be equivalent to a 22-week pregnancy. Elizabeth Nash, who tracks state issues for the Guttmacher Institute, notes that the term "20-week law" is often used, even though it refers to a ban at 22 weeks of pregnancy.

The ban imposed by these laws is earlier than what is currently considered viability, or when a fetus can survive outside the womb. While there is consensus that viability does not occur before 24 weeks of pregnancy, the laws being proposed would ban abortion at least two weeks before that point. This raises concerns about the constitutionality of these laws, as current Supreme Court precedent prohibits states from banning abortion before viability.

The constitutionality of these laws will ultimately depend on the Supreme Court's interpretation of viability. While some argue that the laws are an attempt to challenge the court's precedent, others believe that the laws are simply a way to restrict abortion access. The debate highlights the complexities and nuances of reproductive rights and the ongoing efforts to shape the laws surrounding abortion.

Title: Obama to Seek Congressional Approval for Military Strike Against Syria

The White House announced on Saturday that President Barack Obama has decided to seek congressional approval for a military strike against Syria, a decision that caught many of his national security team off guard. According to three senior administration officials, Obama had not made a final decision on the matter until he convened his senior advisers on Friday night, at which point he revealed his plan to seek congressional authorization.

The decision to seek congressional approval was not without controversy, as some of Obama's national security team had advised against it. However, the president believes that seeking congressional authorization will strengthen the legitimacy of any military action and demonstrate the country's commitment to international law.

In his remarks on Saturday, Obama emphasized the importance of enforcing the international prohibition on the use of chemical weapons, which has been agreed upon by 98% of the world's governments and approved by the US Congress. He also noted that a "no" vote from Congress would send the wrong message to Syria and its allies.

The decision to seek congressional approval comes after the British Parliament rejected Prime Minister David Cameron's call for military action against Syria, making it clear that a groundswell of international support was not forthcoming. The president also consulted with French President Francois Hollande, who has endorsed a military strike against Syria.

Congress is expected to debate and vote on the authorization in the week of September 9. While Obama has not ruled out taking action immediately if Syria deploys chemical weapons before Congress votes, he believes that seeking congressional approval is the best course of action.

Title: Political Factions Clash Over Vote-by-Mail Options Amid Pandemic

The debate over expanding vote-by-mail options has become a contentious issue ahead of the November election, with President Donald Trump and his Republican allies voicing concerns about fraud and Democrats and voting rights groups advocating for the measure as a way to protect voters from the coronavirus pandemic.

Trump and his supporters argue that mail-in balloting is more susceptible to fraud since voters do not have to appear in person at a polling place. However, Trump acknowledged he cast an absentee ballot by mail in Florida's Republican primary, and Trevor Potter, a Republican former chairman of the Federal Election Commission, pointed out that Republicans often do well in mail-in balloting.

Democrats and voting rights groups counter that expanding vote-by-mail options will protect voters from the virus and ensure millions of Americans, particularly the poor and African Americans who are deemed more vulnerable to the virus, can exercise their right to vote. They argue that a failure to guarantee this option will disenfranchise millions of Americans.

A series of academic, government, and news investigations have found little evidence of election fraud of any kind. Utah and four other states that vote entirely by mail - Hawaii, Oregon, Washington, and Colorado - have reported little fraud.

Election experts say there have been scattered incidents of people collecting and manipulating absentee ballots in a process known as "ballot harvesting." The most recent example came in a 2018 North Carolina congressional race, the outcome of which was overturned when it was determined an operative gathered ballots for the Republican candidate.

More than a dozen states have already postponed primaries or expanded vote-by-mail to avoid forcing residents to go to crowded polling places. Vote-by-mail is hardly a novelty, with a report by the U.S. Election Assistance Commission stating that the process was used by about one-quarter of all voters in the 2018 midterm elections.

The Brennan Center for Justice estimates that ensuring vote-by-mail is available for all voters could cost up to $1.4 billion, with postage alone costing up to $600 million. Even advocates of vote-by-mail say states would need to keep the option of in-person voting for voters with disabilities, those who need language access assistance, or those who do not have regular mail access.

Democratic and Republican-aligned groups are already fighting in federal and state courts over whether and how to expand access to mail-in voting.

**Public Opinion Divided on COVID-19 Restrictions and Protests**

A recent poll conducted by the University of Chicago Divinity School and The NORC Center for Public Affairs Research has found that more Americans disapprove than approve of protests against COVID-19 restrictions. The survey, which polled 1,002 adults, found that 55% of Americans disapprove of the protests, while 31% approve.

The poll also found that support for stay-at-home orders and other restrictions has dipped in recent weeks. According to the survey, 71% of Americans favor requiring people to stay in their homes except for essential errands, down from 80% two weeks earlier. Similarly, 67% of Americans now say they favor requiring bars and restaurants to close, down from 76% in the earlier poll.

The poll also found that opinions on the protests are divided along party lines, with Democrats more likely to disapprove of the protests (67%) than Republicans (51%). However, 32% of Republicans and 25% of Democrats approve of the protests.

Some individuals who participated in the survey shared their thoughts on the matter. Dee Miner, a Democrat and retired dental office manager, disapproves of the protests but believes people have the right to express themselves. Adam Blann, a Republican-leaning voter, does not personally favor the protests but believes they should not be restricted.

As some states begin to ease restrictions on businesses and individuals, the poll found that 71% of Americans favor requiring people to stay in their homes except for essential errands. The poll also suggested dipping support for requiring Americans to limit gatherings to 10 people or fewer (from 82% to 75%) and requiring postponement of nonessential medical care (from 68% to 57%).

The poll's findings highlight the ongoing debate over COVID-19 restrictions and the protests against them. While some individuals believe the restrictions are necessary to prevent the spread of the virus, others argue that they are too restrictive and infringe on personal freedoms.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Struggles to Appeal to Younger Women Voters

The 2016 US presidential election has seen a significant shift in voter demographics, with younger women under 30 showing a strong preference for Bernie Sanders over Hillary Clinton. According to recent Iowa caucus results, 84% of women in this age group voted for Sanders, while only 14% supported Clinton. In New Hampshire, the trend continues, with 92% of women aged 30-39 backing Sanders.

The reasons behind this phenomenon are complex and multifaceted. Some argue that Hillary's association with her husband's past scandals, including the Lewinsky affair, has left a lasting impression on younger voters. Others believe that her email controversy and perceived elitism have contributed to her unpopularity.

The Clinton campaign has struggled to connect with younger women, who are increasingly disillusioned with the idea of a "Clinton dynasty" and perceive Hillary as an "entitled" and "arrogant" figure. The email scandal, which has led to an FBI investigation, has further eroded trust in her leadership.

In an effort to win back these voters, Hillary has been campaigning in key states, including Michigan, where she has focused on issues affecting African American communities. However, her recent comments alongside Madeleine Albright, who said "there's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other," have been met with skepticism. The statement was seen as a divisive and patronizing message, implying that women who support Bernie Sanders are somehow betraying the feminist cause.

The Clinton campaign faces a daunting task in winning over younger women, who are increasingly drawn to Bernie Sanders' socialist policies and promise of change. As the primary race continues, Hillary will need to find a way to connect with this demographic and address their concerns if she hopes to remain a viable candidate.

Title: Federal Budget Deficit Drops to Less Than $500 Billion for First Time Since Obama's Presidency

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released new estimates revealing a significant drop in the federal budget deficit, which has fallen to less than $500 billion for the first time since President Obama took office. The deficit for fiscal year 2014, which ended September 30, totaled $486 billion, a significant decrease from the previous year. This marks a slowdown in spending and a significant increase in taxes paid into the government.

The deficit as a percentage of the economy is even smaller than the 2008 figure, at 2.8% of gross domestic product (GDP). This is slightly below the average experienced over the past 40 years, according to the CBO.

The CBO report highlights a significant increase in taxes, with government revenue crossing the $3 trillion mark for the first time in history in 2014. In contrast, spending, which had surged to $3.6 trillion in 2011, fell in 2012 and 2013, and rose only 1% or $44 billion in 2014.

New spending on Medicaid and Obamacare's subsidies for health insurance purchased on the exchanges rose by $49 billion, while Social Security spending rose 5% or $37 billion. The government's student loan subsidies boosted education spending.

On the other side of the ledger, the Defense Department withstood a 5% cut, totaling $30 billion, and unemployment benefit spending dropped as the jobless rate declined.

The CBO report notes that spending began to drop after Republicans took control of the House in 2011 and began to battle President Obama over his budget plans. A series of spending cuts, including the budget sequesters, helped keep spending in check.

The report also highlights the impact of the recovering economy, which has helped boost corporate income taxes by 17.5% over the last year. However, outside budget analysts warn that the good news should be tempered by the dangers that still lurk ahead.

"While the deficit has indeed dropped significantly, this drop followed a massive increase, was largely expected, and does not suggest the country is on a sustainable fiscal path," said the Committee for a Responsible Federal Deficit in its analysis. "Currently, debt levels are at historic highs and projected to grow unsustainably over the long run."

The CBO's projections from over the summer signal that $1 trillion deficits will return within a decade, and debt will also steadily grow. Driving that long-term debt is entitlement spending, particularly major programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. Net interest on the debt will also rise quickly in future years as interest rates rise. However, for now, low rates continue to help keep the deficit down. The government paid $271 billion in interest costs in 2014, according to the CBO. Final 2014 numbers will be released by the Treasury Department later this month.

Title: Fox News Hosts and Allies Defend Roy Moore Against Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

Fox News host Sean Hannity and several right-leaning media outlets have come to the defense of Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore, who is facing allegations of sexual misconduct with a 14-year-old girl and dating three other underage girls. Moore has denied the claims, without providing specific details, and has accused his opponents of launching a "vicious and nasty" attack against him.

Hannity, who has been a vocal supporter of Moore, discussed the allegations on his radio show, initially appearing to downplay the seriousness of the claims. He later apologized for his comments, stating that he "misspoke" and was not clear earlier.

Other Fox News personalities, including Tucker Carlson and Mercedes Colwin, have also addressed the allegations. Carlson devoted only 46 seconds to the topic on his show, while Colwin claimed that women often make false sexual harassment allegations to make money.

Breitbart, a news outlet run by former Trump strategist Steve Bannon, began discrediting the Washington Post report before it was even published, calling the allegations "politics of self-destruction" and comparing them to the video of Trump bragging about sexual assault. Bannon also highlighted the fact that the Washington Post is owned by Jeff Bezos, a billionaire who is also the founder of Amazon.

National Review, a conservative publication, published two pieces urging fellow conservatives not to defend Moore, stating that the allegations are credible and that Moore's denials are not sufficient to prove the claims are false.

Other right-leaning websites, such as Hot Air, the Daily Caller, and the Blaze, have also published brief reports on the allegations, with some avoiding any further discussion of the topic.

Title: White House Denies "Amnesty" Accusations, Presents New Immigration Plan

The White House has denied accusations from conservatives that President Trump's new immigration plan is an "amnesty" for illegal immigrants, insisting that it is only a temporary solution that does not offer a full pathway to citizenship. Vice President Mike Pence told reporters that the plan does not provide amnesty and does not offer a pathway to citizenship.

The plan, presented by President Trump in an address from the Oval Office, aims to end the government shutdown and ensure that employees do not miss a second paycheck. It includes $5.7 billion for border wall construction, changes to make it easier to deport illegal immigrant families, and cuts to the asylum system. In exchange, it offers hundreds of millions of dollars in new humanitarian aid for the safety and health of illegal immigrants.

The plan also restores a program allowing Central American children to apply for U.S. asylum from their home countries and creates a three-year legal status for about 700,000 people currently in the United States under the Obama-era DACA program and 300,000 people under humanitarian protections. The deal also includes items both sides generally agree on, such as increased technology to scan for drugs at legal border crossings and a boost in the number of immigration judges to reduce the backlog of cases.

The Senate will vote on the plan next week, and Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney said the fate of the shutdown and workers' paychecks rests on it. Some Democrats have attacked the bill from the left, while some of President Trump's supporters on the right have expressed frustration that it offers legal status to some illegal immigrants.

Vice President Pence and Senior White House Adviser Jared Kushner have emphasized that the plan is a good-faith attempt to find a middle ground between the hard-right and hard-left, and that it could build trust to open the door to broader negotiations on major immigration reforms.

Title: North Charleston Police Chief Distances Officer's Actions from Force, Acknowledges Officer's Fatal Mistake

Article:

In the wake of the video recording by Feidin Santana showing officer Michael Thomas Slager killing Walter Scott, Ed Driggers, the chief of the North Charleston Police Department, spoke to the press. Driggers' public appearance was reminiscent of similar situations in Ferguson, Missouri, Cleveland, Ohio, Staten Island, New York, and Los Angeles, California, where law enforcement officials are faced with explaining the use of deadly force against an unarmed African-American. However, the substance was different. Driggers did not mount a defense of officer Slager, who claimed that he shot Scott after a routine stop over a busted taillight led to a physical altercation. Instead, Driggers expressed his disgust and sadness over the incident.

Driggers' comments were a departure from the typical defense of officers seen in similar situations. He acknowledged that he had watched the video and was "sickened" by what he saw, stating that he had not watched it since. This sentiment was echoed by Mayor Keith Summey, who said, "When you're wrong, you're wrong, and if you make a bad decision... you have to live by that decision."

The chief and mayor distanced Slager's actions from those of the overall North Charleston police force, emphasizing that the incident was an isolated mistake. Driggers noted that the force is composed of over 340 officers and that the video showed a single individual making a "horrible, horrible mistake."

The article also highlights the presence of officer Clarence Habersham, who arrived at the scene after Scott had fallen to the ground. Habersham's body language indicated that he had seen similar scenes before, and he made no attempt to save Scott's life. The article notes that the exact circumstances of what transpired between Slager, Habersham, and the third officer who joined them are unknown.

The article concludes by noting that the North Charleston police department was content to accept Slager's story as fact, and that this was not the first time a member of the force had engaged in questionable behavior. The article also highlights the fact that police officers in South Carolina have used their guns against 209 people in the past five years, with no one being held accountable.

Title: Kentucky's Non-Profit Health Plan Collapse Ignites Political Firestorm in Governor's Race

The sudden collapse of Kentucky Health Cooperative, a non-profit health plan supported by tens of millions of dollars in Obamacare loans, has sparked a heated political debate in the state's gubernatorial race. The failure of the co-op, which dominated exchange enrollment during its first two years of operation, has left thousands of Kentuckians scrambling to find new coverage during the looming open-enrollment period.

The collapse is part of a larger trend, with more than a third of the 23 non-profit health plans created under Obamacare with $2.4 billion in federal loan dollars having failed. Experts predict more failures are on the horizon. The recent demise of South Carolina's co-op, the ninth to fail, has added to the growing concern.

The collapse has become a key issue in the Kentucky governor's race, with Republican challenger Matt Bevin seizing on the failure as evidence of Obamacare's shortcomings. Bevin has blamed the collapse on the health law, while Democratic candidate Jack Conway attributes it to "market forces" and argues that Kentucky consumers still have more choice as a result of the health law.

The non-profit co-op program was designed to provide an alternative to traditional insurance companies, but was saddled with rules that prohibited the use of federal funds for marketing and restricted which customers they could target. Republicans have criticized the program as a failed experiment, while Democrats argue that it was undermined from the outset.

The collapse of the co-op is not the only health care issue with political salience in the Kentucky governor's race. The vast majority of Kentuckians who have gained coverage under Obamacare are enrolled in public programs, with over 500,000 individuals added to the Medicaid and CHIP rolls since 2013. The candidates have taken different stances on the Medicaid expansion, with Bevin wanting to roll it back and Conway seeking to maintain it.

While some political observers are skeptical that health care issues will ultimately prove decisive, others believe that the collapse of the co-op, combined with plan cancellations and rate hikes, could alter the race. The outcome of the election remains uncertain, with the Republican Governor's Association announcing a $1.6 million ad buy backing Bevin in the final two weeks of the campaign.

Title: Representative Adam Schiff Links Wuhan Coronavirus Victims to Failed Impeachment of President Trump

Representative Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, made a statement on MSNBC Monday night, suggesting that the victims of the Wuhan coronavirus are, in a sense, victims of the failed impeachment of President Trump. Schiff claimed that the number of casualties from the virus is equivalent to the number of people lost on 9/11, stating that the country was not prepared to handle the consequences of Trump's actions.

Schiff's comments were met with criticism from Fox News's Sean Hannity, who argued that the Democrats were too focused on impeachment and not enough on addressing the threat of the virus. Hannity pointed out that the first case of coronavirus was reported in the US on January 21, while the impeachment proceedings were underway. He noted that China had sealed off the province of Wuhan on January 23, and the US declared a national health emergency and imposed travel restrictions on January 31, but the Democrats were still focused on impeachment.

Schiff's statement and Hannity's response highlight the ongoing debate over the handling of the Wuhan coronavirus pandemic and the role of politics in responding to the crisis. While Schiff's comments were intended to emphasize the consequences of Trump's actions, Hannity's criticism suggests that the Democrats were too focused on impeachment and not enough on addressing the threat of the virus.

Title: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard Calls on Biden and Sanders to Support Her Participation in Next Democratic Debate

Article: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) has issued a direct call to fellow Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders to urge the Democratic National Committee (DNC) to allow her to participate in the next primary debate. The call comes after the DNC announced new qualifications for the March 15 debate in Phoenix, which require candidates to have garnered at least 20 percent of the delegates awarded thus far. Gabbard has not met this threshold, having secured only two of the 1,385 delegates awarded.

Gabbard took to Twitter to express her frustration, stating that the DNC is attempting to exclude her from the debates. She pointed out that the committee had previously changed the debate qualifications to allow former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg to participate, and is now using the same tactics to keep her off the stage. Gabbard is urging Biden and Sanders to stand with her against the DNC's "transparent effort to exclude me from the debates."

The Hawaii Democrat has been a vocal critic of the DNC, accusing the committee of trying to kneecap her campaign. She has centered her presidential bid on reducing America's military entanglements abroad, but has faced criticism over a 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad and her past positions opposed to LGBTQ rights. With six states set to hold primaries and caucuses on Tuesday, it is unlikely that Gabbard will secure enough delegates to meet the 20 percent threshold and qualify for the next debate.

Title: Wall Street Prepares for Tariffs as Gary Cohn Leaves the White House

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by as much as 349 points on Wednesday, but recovered most of its losses and closed down 82 points. The market volatility was attributed to the news that Gary Cohn, the White House's top economic adviser, is leaving his position. Cohn had been a key figure in shaping the administration's economic policies, including the tax cuts and free trade agreements.

The market is bracing for the potential implementation of tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, with a 25% tariff on steel and a 10% tariff on aluminum. The White House has announced that it will move forward with the plan, despite Cohn's opposition. Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated that the president is expected to sign the tariffs by the end of the week, with the possibility of "carve-outs" for Canada and Mexico.

Investors are concerned that the tariffs could lead to a trade war, which could damage the economy. The news has also sparked fears that the administration's trade policies may become more protectionist, which could negatively impact business and investor confidence.

The departure of Cohn, a former Goldman Sachs president, has left investors feeling uncertain about the future of the administration's economic policies. Cohn was seen as a calming influence on the market and a proponent of free trade. His replacement will be closely watched by investors, who are hoping for a more moderate approach to trade.

The market is also awaiting the outcome of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) renegotiations between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The three countries have made little progress on a re-negotiated deal since beginning talks in August.

In the meantime, US companies with less investment overseas are emerging as winners from the trade uncertainty. The Russell 2000 index, which tracks small companies, closed up for the fifth straight day.

Title: Islamic State's Global Reach and Threat to Homeland Security

The debate surrounding the Islamic State's (ISIS) threat to the United States has been a topic of discussion in the mainstream media. Some commentators argue that ISIS poses a threat to the country, while others claim it is not a direct threat. However, recent events suggest that ISIS's reach and influence extend far beyond the Middle East.

In Australia, the largest police operation in the country's history was conducted last week, resulting in the detention of 15 people suspected of being involved with ISIS. The operation was prompted by intelligence that the group was planning public beheadings in two Australian cities to demonstrate its reach.

In the United States, there have been several instances of ISIS-inspired terrorism. In June, a 19-year-old man was murdered in cold blood by a self-proclaimed jihadi who claimed it was an act of retribution for U.S. military action against Muslims in the Middle East. The killer has also confessed to killing four other men in similar circumstances.

Additionally, the New York Police Commissioner has warned that ISIS is targeting the city, and an online chat room affiliated with the group has called for "lone wolf" attacks on Times Square, providing instructions on how to prepare a bomb in the kitchen and listing tourist spots that will create "pictures of horror."

These incidents demonstrate that ISIS's influence extends beyond the Middle East and that its propaganda can inspire sociopaths around the world. The group's plans to enact terrorism in the United States are already underway, with warnings of attacks on military personnel and tourist spots.

It is essential to acknowledge the reality of the ISIS threat and not pretend otherwise. The Brendan Tevlin family's tragic loss serves as a reminder that jihad is a very real and painful reality. The Australians have taken a proactive approach to combating ISIS, and their efforts have saved untold lives on their soil.

In conclusion, the Islamic State's global reach and influence are a threat to homeland security, and it is crucial to acknowledge this reality.

Title: Pope Francis Brings Moral Authority to Global Issues

Pope Francis, known for his humble lifestyle and personal gestures, has brought a unique moral authority to the world stage. As the first Latin American pope, he has navigated complex issues like immigration and climate change with subtlety and shrewdness. During his recent trip to the United States, Francis addressed the country's most divisive political issues, including immigration and climate change, with a focus on the human impact.

In his speeches and gestures, Francis emphasized the importance of compassion, reconciliation, and pastoral service. He praised President Obama's proposals to combat air pollution and acknowledged the urgency of climate change. The pope also made an unplanned stop at the convent of the Little Sisters of the Poor, showing support for the nuns suing the president over Obamacare's birth control provision.

Francis's visit to Cuba was marked by subtle gestures, including his decision to visit a group of students at the Felix Varela Institute, a Catholic school that offers workshops on business and economics. He also invoked symbols of Cuban heritage, such as the Virgin of Charity of El Cobre, and spoke of a "revolution of tenderness."

In his address to a joint session of Congress, Francis urged lawmakers to defend and preserve the dignity of their fellow citizens in the pursuit of the common good. He used four American figures – Abraham Lincoln, Martin Luther King Jr., Dorothy Day, and Thomas Merton – to emphasize the importance of compassion and social justice.

Throughout his trip, Francis remained circumspect, framing his comments on politics as gentle moral exhortations rather than taking a stance on specific issues. His focus on the human impact of global issues has resonated with people around the world, making him a unique and influential moral authority.

Title: Trump Meets with Network Executives, Expresses Dissatisfaction with Coverage

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump met with network executives and anchors at Trump Tower, a move seen as a step towards bridging the gap between the incoming administration and the media. The meeting was described as "cordial" and "productive" by Kellyanne Conway, Trump's campaign manager. However, Trump reportedly expressed his unhappiness with certain aspects of the coverage, reserving particularly harsh words for CNN and NBC News.

According to Variety, Trump "reserved particularly harsh words for CNN and NBC News," while The New York Post reported that he told CNN President Jeff Zucker, "I hate your network, everyone at CNN is a liar and you should be ashamed." The meeting was described as "off-the-record" and "very candid and very honest" by Conway.

The meeting comes as Trump prepares to meet with executives from the "failing" New York Times and other outlets, a move seen as an attempt to improve relations between the administration and the media. Trump's campaign was marked by hostility towards the press, with him frequently labeling certain outlets as "dishonest" and "fake news."

The article also touches on the growing culture war surrounding Trump's presidency, with some entertainers and cultural figures refusing to "normalize" him. However, the author notes that this is not a new phenomenon, citing examples of hostility towards previous presidents.

The article concludes by highlighting a hopeful sign, with the new ombudsman at the New York Times, Liz Spayd, noting that readers are dissatisfied with the coverage and want a more balanced approach.

Title: Facebook Removes 32 Pages and Accounts Linked to Russian-Based Group Ahead of US Midterm Elections

Facebook has removed 32 pages and accounts from its platform and Instagram that were pushing American political stances and organizing events, including a protest against a Unite the Right rally due to take place in Washington next week. The social network has detected "coordinated inauthentic behavior" that could be linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA), a Russian-based group with ties to the Kremlin.

According to Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, the individuals behind the removed accounts went to greater lengths to obscure their identities than the IRA did in the run-up to the 2016 presidential election. The accounts had a total of 290,000 followers and used virtual private networks (VPNs) to conceal their locations and internet phone services to hide their identities. They also paid third parties to spend approximately $11,000 for about 150 ads on Facebook and Instagram.

Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, Nathaniel Gleicher, stated that while the company doesn't have enough technical evidence to definitively identify who is behind the activity, the individuals have shown similar activity and have connected with known IRA accounts. In one case, a known IRA account was a co-admin on one of the pages for seven minutes before the account was removed from Facebook.

Facebook's chief security officer, Alex Stamos, noted that intelligence agencies are better equipped to make an attribution by combining the technical details from Facebook with their own knowledge of the political motivations and goals of countries and other threat actors. Stamos stated that it's unclear whether this is the IRA with improved capabilities or a separate group.

Members of Congress who were briefed by the company this week were quick to ascribe blame to Russia. Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, said, "Today's disclosure is further evidence that the Kremlin continues to exploit platforms like Facebook to sow division and spread disinformation."

The removed pages included "Aztlan Warriors," "Resisters," and "Black Elevation." The "Resisters" page created a Facebook event for a protest on August 10-12 titled "No Unite The Right 2." Admins for the page connected with the admins of five legitimate pages to promote the event and post logistical information for protesters. About 600 users said they would attend the event, and 2,600 expressed an interest in attending.

Facebook has pledged to continue investigating the activity and share any further findings with law enforcement and Congress. The company's chief executive officer, Mark Zuckerberg, stated, "Security isn't a problem you ever completely solve. We face sophisticated and well-funded adversaries, including nation-states, that are always evolving and trying new attacks."

Title: Employers Consider Cutting Hours to Avoid ObamaCare Costs, Raising Concerns About Part-Time Work

The Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, has been criticized by big labor unions and other groups for its potential impact on employers and employees. According to recent reports, some businesses are already preparing to reduce employee hours to avoid the costs associated with the law. The Affordable Care Act requires mid-sized and large employers to sponsor health insurance for all full-time employees, defined as those who work 30 hours a week or more. This has led some employers to consider capping hours on employees, which could have a significant impact on millions of families across the United States.

The United Food and Commercial Workers Union has expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the law, stating that it will lead to reduced hours and incomes for workers. American Enterprise Institute researcher Christopher Conover has also argued that the law is accelerating a trend towards a nation of part-timers. According to Conover, a review of anecdotal evidence suggests that ObamaCare is causing employers to reduce hours and shift employees to part-time status.

Some specific examples of employers preparing to cut hours include Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Indiana, which are planning to reduce school workers to part-time status. This could affect hundreds of teacher aides, bus drivers, and cafeteria workers. In California, Texas, and Michigan, government workers, including parks and recreation officials, librarians, and secretaries, may also see their hours and benefits reduced.

Fast-food CEOs at Subway and Papa John's have also expressed concerns about the impact of the law. Papa John's CEO John Schnatter estimates that the company will face costs of $5 million to $8 million annually due to the law, and expects franchise owners to cut employee hours as a result. NBC News conducted an informal survey of 20 businesses and found that many were already cutting workers to 29 hours a week due to the health care law.

However, not everyone agrees with the critics' claims. A recent Bloomberg analysis questioned the methodology used by Conover and argued that the Bureau of Labor Statistics household survey data is too volatile to draw reliable conclusions from small samples. The analysis also suggested that the 30-hour rule in ObamaCare is bad public policy that will eventually hurt full-time work.

The White House has brushed off concerns about the impact of ObamaCare, stating that there is no systematic evidence to support claims that the law is having an adverse impact on job growth or the number of hours employees are working.

Title: Trump Praises Electoral College System, Reflects on Campaign and Election

President-elect Donald Trump praised the Electoral College system, saying it allowed him to campaign across the country and connect with voters directly. Speaking at his final "Thank You" tour stop in Mobile, Alabama, Trump expressed appreciation for the system, which required him to visit 17 states in the last month of the campaign.

Trump noted that the Electoral College system allowed him to focus on states that might not have been as prominent in a popular vote system. He emphasized that this approach helped him connect with voters in places that are often overlooked, such as Alabama.

The president-elect also touched on his campaign's success, stating that he won more than 2,600 counties, including 200 that flipped from President Barack Obama in 2012. He also mentioned that he would have won the popular vote if the Electoral College system was not in place.

Trump's "Thank You" tour, which included stops in Michigan, North Carolina, Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Florida, marked the end of his campaign rallies. He pledged to continue holding rallies after moving into the White House, despite some critics advising against it.

The event featured appearances by campaign manager Kellyanne Conway, who highlighted Trump's victory statistics, and Alabama Senator Jeff Sessions, who endorsed Trump early in the campaign. Sessions praised the rally in Mobile as a turning point in the election, saying it marked the beginning of a movement.

The article does not provide information on Trump's meeting with the Obamas after the election, but it does quote Trump's response to Michelle Obama's statement that "we are feeling what not having hope feels like" as his administration takes power. Trump interpreted her statement as referring to the past, rather than the future, and expressed his belief that there is tremendous hope for the country.

Title: Presidential Candidates Focus on Corporate Criticism, Targeting Companies for Tax Avoidance and Labor Practices

Article:

A recent analysis by High Lantern Group, a firm specializing in corporate reputation analytics, has found that presidential candidates are generating the most online engagement when they target corporations for paying little or no taxes. The data suggests that companies are facing increased pressure to comply with Democratic candidates' visions for the future, which include offering employees a living wage, paying more in taxes, and allowing workers to unionize.

According to the analysis, companies like Amazon, Facebook, McDonald's, and Walmart have been called out the most by presidential hopefuls. This is a departure from the 2016 election, when Wall Street was the primary target. Notably, no banks have cracked the top 10 list of companies facing criticism on Twitter from the 2020 field of presidential hopefuls.

Several 2020 Democrats have taken aim at companies like McDonald's, joining workers in their strike against sexual harassment in the workplace and low wages. Matt Levy, director of issue analysis at HLG, noted that companies pay attention when they or their competitors are called out by influential players.

Amazon has responded to criticism by calling out candidates who have threatened to break up Big Tech if they become president. Walmart has urged candidates to engage with the company to learn more about its practices and initiatives before recycling critiques that haven't been relevant for years.

Interestingly, President Trump is the next most-likely 2020 candidate to publicly criticize companies on Twitter, with his lines of attack often focusing on issues unrelated to a living wage or workplace safety. Twitter itself is among the top companies called out by candidates, ranking eighth on the list.

Title: Trump's Immigration Plan Draws Criticism from Labor Unions

Article:

Donald Trump's recent visit to Phoenix, Arizona, saw him unveil a hardline plan to tackle undocumented immigration, promising to deport individuals on an unprecedented scale. The plan, which he claims will benefit native-born workers, has been met with skepticism from labor unions, who argue that immigrants are not a threat to American jobs.

Trump tied his promise to carry out deportations to anti-globalist economic ideas, stating that many undocumented immigrants are lower-skilled workers who compete directly against vulnerable American workers. However, labor unions have long recognized that immigrants are not a threat to jobs, with many union members having worked alongside immigrants without experiencing any negative impact.

According to Lowell Turner, a professor at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, "If you have a union job, you know that immigrants are not stealing your jobs. You see your reality around you and know that's not happening." This sentiment is echoed by many union members who have worked alongside immigrants without experiencing any negative consequences.

Despite Trump's claims, labor unions have historically been opposed to anti-immigrant policies. In the past, unions have viewed certain groups of immigrants with suspicion, and the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 was passed largely at the behest of organized labor. However, changes in unions' attitudes began in the late 1970s, as deregulation measures sent membership numbers reeling, and urban areas like Los Angeles saw deteriorated wages, benefits, and working conditions causing many native-born workers to abandon certain lines of low-skilled manual jobs.

As immigrants stepped in to take their place, mostly from Central America and Mexico, union leaders in favor of organizing immigrants thought they were likely to be too nervous for collective action. However, campaigns like the Service Employees International Union's Janitors for Justice, first conceived in 1985, won important victories from employers and showed unions that immigrants, including the undocumented, were capable of loud advocacy.

The shift in union attitudes towards immigration has been significant, with the AFL-CIO, the largest union confederation in the country, calling for an end to employer sanctions and legal status for 6 million undocumented immigrants in 2000. The move came largely as a result of pressure from an immigrant-led coalition known as the Change to Win Federation, and it caused a sea change in thought.

As historian Mae Ngai, a specialist in immigration and labor, notes, "I think there was a shift in consciousness. Even if some of these older unions like the Machinists were not organizing immigrants, they could see other people doing it. They could see that immigrants were not their enemy, not their competition, not their enemy they had to fear."

Title: Obama's Strong Ground Game and Debate Performance Boost His Chances in the Election

The final presidential debate has come to a close, and David Gergen, a veteran journalist and analyst, believes that President Obama has shored up his chances of winning the election. According to Gergen, Obama's superior ground game and strong debate performance have given him an edge over his opponent, Mitt Romney.

Gergen notes that Obama has proven himself to be better when behind, and his recent debate performances have restored faith and energy among his supporters. He has also effectively cut Romney down to size, highlighting his inconsistencies and lack of clarity on key issues.

In the final debate, Obama focused on appealing to key parts of his constituency, including minorities, women, and youth. He has advanced policies tailored to their interests over the past four years, and his efforts seem to have paid off.

Gergen believes that Obama's strong ground game will be a crucial factor in the election. His campaign has constructed a superior field organization, with three times as many offices in the pivotal state of Ohio. In contrast, the Romney campaign's field team has been criticized for being inexperienced and disorganized.

Romney, on the other hand, has gained ground in the debates, particularly in terms of likability. He has managed to avoid being labeled as a warmonger and has passed the commander-in-chief test. However, Gergen notes that Romney's strategy of being more deliberative and above the fray may not have been as effective in terms of debate points.

The online prediction market Intrade shows that Obama's odds of winning have dropped slightly since the debates, but Gergen believes that the race remains too close to call. Ultimately, the outcome will depend on how voters respond to the candidates' performances and the issues that matter most to them.

Title: Gun Owners in Texas Reflect on Recent Shooting Incident

Article:

In the wake of the recent shooting incident in Dallas, gun owners in the area are reflecting on the events that unfolded. Vickie Kale, a certified firearms instructor, expressed her disbelief at the actions of Micah Xavier Johnson, who killed five police officers and injured several others. "How can you point your gun at someone and shoot them?" she asked. "What can make someone so mad they would do that?"

Kale runs Gibson's Outpost & Shooting Range, which is located near Johnson's home. While no one at the range remembers Johnson or recalls him practicing there, authorities believe he must have practiced elsewhere. The exact details of the rifle Johnson used and the location where he practiced are still unknown.

Gun owners at the range are concerned about the media's focus on the availability of firearms rather than the individuals who misuse them. Many argue that millions of Americans own guns that will never be used against another person. They question where the individual accountability is and why the media does not focus on the people who use guns improperly.

Kale believes that the government's handling of the situation has contributed to a lack of respect for police officers. "Our government has pushed this situation to the point where police officers aren't respected," she said.

Johnson, a former U.S. Army Reserve member, had served one tour of duty in Afghanistan and had a specialty in carpentry and masonry. He was killed by police using a remote-controlled robot after a long standoff.

The investigation into the shooting is ongoing, and authorities have not yet released a complete timeline of Johnson's movements during the incident. However, they have found a personal journal of combat tactics, bomb-making materials, ballistic vests, rifles, and ammunition in his home.

Gun-control advocates have used the incident to rally support for stricter laws, including against open carrying of firearms, which is legal in Texas. However, gun owners in the area argue that the focus should be on the individuals who misuse firearms rather than the guns themselves.

Title: Supreme Court to Revisit Workplace Discrimination Case, Highlighting Need for Congressional Action

Article:

The Supreme Court is set to hear oral arguments in two cases this week that will test the boundaries of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and its prohibition on workplace discrimination based on "sex." The cases revolve around the question of whether "sex" includes discrimination based on sexual orientation. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit has previously ruled that Congress did not intend to include sexual orientation in the 1964 law, but the dissenting judges disagreed, citing the broader context of the statute and the changing attitudes towards sex and sexual orientation over the years.

The case involves Kimberly Hively, a part-time adjunct professor at an Indiana community college who claims she was denied a full-time position and had her part-time contract not renewed due to her sexual orientation. The Seventh Circuit majority argued that the question is what it means to discriminate on the basis of sex, and whether actions taken on the basis of sexual orientation are a subset of actions taken on the basis of sex. The majority acknowledged that Congress has declined to add sexual orientation to the Act, but professed to have "no idea what inference to draw from congressional inaction."

The dissenting judges, on the other hand, argued that the meaning of the statute has changed over time, and that the word "sex" now connotes both gender and sexual orientation. They believe that the passage of time and changing attitudes towards sex and sexual orientation justify a fresh interpretation of the statute.

The minority judges, however, emphasized that their role is to give effect to the enacted text, interpreting the statutory language as a reasonable person would have understood it at the time of enactment. They argued that the majority has engaged in "judicial statutory updating" that cannot be reconciled with the constitutional design, which requires bicameralism and presentment.

The case highlights the need for Congress to take action and update the 1964 Civil Rights Act to include protections for individuals based on sexual orientation. The Supreme Court's decision will have significant implications for the interpretation of the law and the rights of individuals in the workplace.

Title: US Intelligence Agencies' Verification Process Key in Afghanistan Withdrawal Decision-Making

The recent debate surrounding the potential withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan has sparked concerns about the reliability of intelligence information. Republican Representative Michael Waltz and Fox & Friends co-hosts Brian Kilmeade and Ainsley Earhardt discussed the issue on the June 30, 2020, edition of Fox & Friends.

According to Representative Waltz, Russia has supported the Taliban through arms, while Iran and Pakistan have provided cash, equipment, and training. Earhardt emphasized that the US intelligence agencies' verification process is crucial in ensuring the accuracy of information before it reaches the president's desk. She noted that the president must make decisions based on verified intel, and if the information is not verified, it may not be acted upon.

The discussion also touched on the importance of the president being briefed on intelligence information. Co-host Steve Doocy mentioned that the president may not always read his daily briefings, and even if information is printed in them, it may not necessarily be conveyed to the president. This highlights the need for a reliable verification process to ensure that the president is informed and can make informed decisions.

The conversation underscores the significance of the US intelligence agencies' role in providing accurate and reliable information to the president, which is essential for informed decision-making, particularly in situations like the potential withdrawal from Afghanistan.

Title: Christie Spends Weekend in Florida, Raising Funds and Defending Himself Amid Scandal

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey is spending the weekend in Florida, where he is helping Republican Governor Rick Scott raise funds and defend himself against allegations of political retaliation. The scandal, which has been ongoing for over a week, centers around claims that Christie's team caused a massive traffic jam in the town of Fort Lee as political retribution against the town's mayor.

Christie's itinerary includes stops in Orlando, Fort Lauderdale, and Palm Beach, but all meetings are closed-door, making it difficult to assess the impact of the scandal on his star power. Traveling with Christie, Governor Scott has shown no hesitation in defending him, stating that Christie "did the right thing" and apologized for the incident.

As chairman of the Republican Governors Association, Christie is also raising money for the organization and networking with potential donors who could be key players if he decides to run for president in 2016. A main event is scheduled for Saturday night at the home of billionaire Ken Langone, co-founder of Home Depot, who has received numerous requests to meet the governor, scandal or not.

Meanwhile, Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz has been following Christie's every move, criticizing the fact that all his campaign events are private. "I think that means that Chris Christie doesn't want to answer any questions or Rick Scott doesn't want to be seen with Chris Christie in public – probably a little of both," she said.

Florida Republican Party Chairman Lenny Curry, on the other hand, accused Democrats of trying to turn Christie's visit into a circus, stating that Christie apologized, took action, and is doing his job as head of the Republican Governors Association by raising money to support Governor Scott's re-election bid.

**Trump Announces New CDC Guidance Classifying Houses of Worship as "Essential"**

President Trump announced on Friday that new Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance will classify houses of worship as "essential," urging governors to allow them to open "right now" after being closed during the coronavirus lockdowns. The President made the announcement during a briefing at the White House, stating that governors need to "do the right thing" and allow these essential places of faith to open.

The CDC released interim guidelines for communities of faith, acknowledging that millions of Americans consider worship an essential part of life, but also warning that gatherings present a risk for increasing the spread of COVID-19. The guidelines encourage the use of cloth face coverings during services, limiting the size of gatherings, social distancing during services, and suspending or decreasing choirs and singing in church.

The White House's announcement comes after Trump had a conference call with 1,600 pastors and faith leaders from around the country, including Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council. The President reassured them he wants to get churches reopened, citing the importance of prayer during these challenging times.

Some faith leaders have argued that social distancing rules have violated First Amendment religious freedoms, while others have defied state and local rules and tried to reopen. However, others have expressed concerns about the risks of congregating during the pandemic.

The CDC's report on the spread of the virus at church events in rural Arkansas showed that two symptomatic people who later tested positive for COVID-19 attended church events in early March, resulting in at least 35 of 92 attendees contracting the virus and three deaths. The report highlights the importance of caution and responsible decision-making when it comes to reopening houses of worship.

Title: HealthCare.gov Website Troubles Continue, Obama and Sebelius Take Responsibility

The HealthCare.gov website, the main platform for Americans to buy insurance from state-based health care exchanges, has been plagued by glitches since its launch on October 1. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius apologized for the issues and acknowledged that it will take another month to fix the website. Despite the problems, Sebelius defended the Affordable Care Act (ACA) as a good deal for most Americans, stating that it helps not only the uninsured but also the underinsured.

President Barack Obama also weighed in on the issue, using a campaign-style speech in Boston to clarify his 2010 vow that his health care program wouldn't force Americans out of their existing insurance. While some may be kicked off their plans, Obama emphasized that they will end up getting better deals from their insurance companies.

Sebelius took responsibility for the website's problems, saying she is accountable for the "debacle" and that she is responsible. However, she also pointed out that insurance companies cancel individual policies year in and year out, and that some consumers will gain better health plans at similar or lower costs with the help of government subsidies.

The website's issues have been overshadowed by concerns that many Americans in the individual market will not be able to keep their health care plans, as Obama had promised. Committee Chairman Fred Upton, Michigan Republican, said Obama's vow has been cast into doubt by a flood of cancellation notices nationwide.

Sebelius testified to the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday, answering questions about the website's problems and the Affordable Care Act. She explained that if a plan was in place in 2010, when Congress passed the legislation, it could have been grandfathered in as long as the companies didn't make major changes. She also reminded lawmakers that the individual market covers a small percentage of Americans, many of whom are covered by their employers or by programs such as Medicare.

The website's problems have been attributed to the lead company hired to help build the site, with vendors saying the Obama administration did not test the system "end to end" until days before its launch. A CMS memo stated that the website hadn't completed security testing as of September 27.

Title: Biden's Financial Reform Efforts Highlighted in Primary Campaign

Article: During his time as Vice President, Joe Biden played a significant role in promoting financial reform and consumer protection, according to his former chief economist and economic adviser, Jared Bernstein. As part of the Middle Class Task Force, Biden sponsored a meeting five years ago that led to the passage of legislation requiring clearer monthly statements, protecting against retroactive interest rate increases, and limiting fees charged by banks to merchants on debit card purchases.

Biden's efforts were praised by his spokesman, Stephen Spector, who noted that the Vice President's support for the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility, and Disclosure Act and the Dodd-Frank Act, which created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, made the administration "unparalleled in its support for financial reform and consumer protection."

Jared Bernstein emphasized that Biden's involvement in the passage of these bills was significant, stating that "he was very much on the team" and that it was crucial that the measures were passed and elevated for public awareness. Christopher J. Dodd, a former Democratic senator from Connecticut, described Biden as a "classic progressive Democrat" on economic issues, but did not recall him playing a central role in the passage process.

Barney Frank, former chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, also did not recall Biden playing a significant role behind the scenes, either for or against credit-card companies. However, Frank noted that the Obama administration's record on financial issues could be a "pretty good defense" for Biden against criticism of his earlier ties to the credit-card industry, which he left behind when he became Vice President.

Title: Former Prosecutor Believes Trump May Face Indictment on Campaign Finance Charges

A former Assistant U.S. Attorney, Andrew McCarthy, has expressed his opinion that prosecutors may attempt to indict President Donald Trump on campaign finance charges, based on the sentencing memo filed by federal prosecutors for Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal attorney, on Friday. McCarthy, a conservative legal analyst who worked in the same Southern District of New York jurisdiction as Cohen, argued in a column on Fox News that the prosecutors would not have drawn attention to Cohen's relatively minor campaign finance violations if they did not intend to charge Trump over payments of hush money to two women before he became president.

According to McCarthy, the major takeaway from the 40-page sentencing memorandum is that President Trump is likely to be indicted on a charge of violating federal campaign finance laws. He believes that the payments made to the women were made "in coordination with and at the direction of" the candidate for federal office, Donald Trump, and that prosecutors would not have done this if the president was not on their radar screen.

McCarthy acknowledges that Trump has a strong case in his defense, but suggests that prosecutors may be focusing on him anyway. Rudy Giuliani, Trump's lawyer, dismissed the legal danger to the president, pointing to Cohen's conviction for lying to the FBI, which would make his testimony on other matters unreliable.

Title: Connecticut's Former Attorney General Questions Effectiveness of Gun Control Measures

Article:

Connecticut's former Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, has sparked a debate on the effectiveness of gun control measures in the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. In an interview, Blumenthal tacitly acknowledged that the current bill, as it stands, would not have prevented the tragedy. He emphasized the need for further action, specifically citing the need to ban high-capacity magazines.

Blumenthal's comments have sparked a rift within the Democratic party, with some advocating for stricter gun control measures and others expressing concerns about the potential impact on Second Amendment rights. The debate has also raised questions about the effectiveness of proposed legislation.

Critics argue that the current bill would not have prevented the Newtown shooting, citing several reasons. Firstly, the shooter obtained his weapons from his mother, who purchased them legally. Secondly, there is no foolproof method to prevent individuals determined to obtain a gun illegally from doing so. Additionally, law enforcement lacks the resources to track down the majority of prospective gun buyers who fail background checks.

Furthermore, the proposed assault weapons ban and high-capacity magazine prohibition would not have prevented the Sandy Hook shooting. Connecticut already has a federal-style ban in place, and the weapons used in the shooting were not prohibited by that law. Moreover, forcing a spree shooter to reload may provide an opportunity for bystanders to intervene, as seen in the Tucson shooting.

The debate highlights the need for a nuanced discussion about gun control measures.
