While some advocate for stricter regulations, others express concerns about the potential impact on law-abiding citizens' Second Amendment rights. The debate must consider whether proposed restrictions will actually work, are duplicative, or unduly restrictive.

In conclusion, the effectiveness of gun control measures is a complex issue that requires careful consideration of the pros and cons. While some may argue that any measure is better than none, it is essential to address the questions raised by critics and consider the potential consequences of proposed legislation.

Title: US Re-Imposes Sanctions on Iran, Warns Against Trading with the Country

The United States has re-imposed sanctions on Iran, with President Donald Trump warning that anyone doing business with the country will not be doing business with the US. The sanctions, which took effect overnight, target the purchase or acquisition of US banknotes by Iran's government, as well as graphite, aluminium, steel, coal, and software used in industrial processes. A second phase of sanctions is set to come into effect on November 5, which will have implications for Iran's energy and shipping sectors, petroleum trading, and transactions by foreign financial institutions with the Central Bank of Iran.

Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has described the sanctions as "psychological warfare" aimed at "sowing division among Iranians." The European Union, which remains committed to the original Iran nuclear deal, has spoken out against the sanctions, vowing to protect firms doing "legitimate business" with Iran.

The sanctions follow the US withdrawal from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, also known as the Iran nuclear deal, earlier this year. The deal, negotiated during the presidency of Barack Obama, saw Iran limit its controversial nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief. President Trump has called the deal "one-sided," "disastrous," and the "worst I've ever seen," and believes renewed economic pressure will force Iran to agree to a new deal.

The sanctions may bite hardest in November, when the US blocks Iranian oil sales, which could halt about half of Iran's exports of some two million barrels a day. Iran may look to China and Russia to keep its industry afloat. The International Monetary Fund said in March that Iran's net official reserves could decline this year to $97.8 billion, which would finance about 13 months of imports. Analysts at BMI Research say Iran's economy could contract by 4.3% in 2019.

Young Iranians have been sharing their stories with BBC Persian, with many already feeling the effects of the sanctions. Many have lost their jobs, and those who are still employed are struggling to make ends meet. The sanctions have also led to a decline in Iran's currency, the rial, which has lost around half of its value since the US withdrawal from the nuclear deal.

Title: Trump's Decision to Reimpose Sanctions on Iran Forces Global Reckoning

The United States' decision to reimpose sanctions on Iran and withdraw from the 2015 nuclear deal has sent shockwaves across the globe, leaving countries like Europe, China, and Russia scrambling to respond. The move, announced by President Trump on Tuesday, has sparked concerns about the potential economic implications and the future of the agreement.

The deal, which was negotiated by the Obama administration, aimed to limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for relief from economic sanctions. However, Trump has long been critical of the agreement, calling it a "horrible, one-sided deal" that "didn't bring peace" and "never will."

The decision to reimpose sanctions will have a "devastatingly chilling effect" on economic activity between Europe and Iran, according to Tony Blinken, a former deputy secretary of state under President Obama. The practical effect will be to put banks, businesses, and purchasers of Iranian crude oil on notice that they must either stop importing Iranian crude oil or make significant reductions by November.

The move is seen as a major blow to the international community, with European leaders urging the US to stay in the deal. French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson have all met with Trump in recent weeks, urging him to stay in the deal and work to address his concerns.

However, Trump has refused to budge, citing weaknesses in the deal, including the lack of expiration dates on the most important restrictions on Iran's nuclear activity and the lack of inspections of military sites. He has also expressed concerns about Iran's support for terrorist groups across the Middle East.

The decision has left Iran's President Hassan Rouhani vowing to respond to the US action, while the European Union has announced plans to protect companies affected by the sanctions. However, experts warn that it may be difficult for the EU to achieve this goal, as banks and businesses are already wary of doing business in Iran due to its poor economic management and corruption.

The move has also raised questions about the future of the deal, with some experts predicting that Iran will refuse to negotiate a new deal and the US will be forced to reimpose sanctions. However, Trump has expressed optimism that a new deal can be reached, saying "great things can happen for Iran."

The decision has sent shockwaves across the global energy market, with oil prices rising in response to the news. The move is also seen as a major blow to the global economy, with experts warning of potential economic instability and uncertainty.

Title: Opponents of Iran Nuclear Deal Gearing Up to Ensure Consequences for Non-Compliance

The negotiations between the six world powers and Iran over an interim nuclear deal have stalled, with some officials suggesting that the gaps between the two sides may have widened. Despite this, opponents of the deal are preparing to ensure that Iran faces immediate consequences if it fails to abide by the agreement's provisions. The deal would freeze progress in Iran's nuclear program while a comprehensive agreement verifiably stopping Iran's program short of a nuclear weapon is worked out.

Opponents of the deal, including Senator Bob Corker (R-TN), are concerned that an interim deal could become permanent, allowing Iran to maintain its enrichment program and move closer to obtaining a nuclear weapon. Corker has introduced legislation that would require any additional sanctions relief to be tied to Iran's compliance with the deal's obligations and would allow sanctions to "snap back" if Iran violates the agreement.

Other critics, such as former US Ambassador to the United Nations John Bolton, argue that the deal would be "fatally flawed" because it accepts uranium enrichment, which could be used to produce fuel for a nuclear weapon. Bolton believes that the deal would not address the fundamental nature of Iran's nuclear program, which he views as a weapons program.

Members of Congress, including Representative Brad Sherman (D-CA), have met with administration officials to express their concerns about the deal. Sherman, who is a skeptic of the deal, believes that the administration is focused on getting a deal, but is concerned that it may not be a good one. He and other members of Congress plan to continue pressing the Senate to consider new sanctions legislation to keep pressure on Iran to reach a comprehensive agreement on its nuclear program.

The debate over the Iran nuclear deal highlights the challenges of balancing the need for a diplomatic solution with the need to ensure that Iran does not obtain a nuclear weapon. While some Americans favor reaching a diplomatic solution, others are concerned that any deal that allows Iran to continue moving towards a nuclear weapon is unacceptable.

Title: White House Seeks to Expand Childcare and Family Leave Options

The White House has announced a push to expand access to childcare and family leave options, a move aimed at appealing to women voters and addressing a key issue emphasized by Democratic challengers in the 2020 election. President Donald Trump spoke at a White House meeting on the topic, advocating for the expansion of in-home and faith-based programs for children.

Trump emphasized the need to reduce regulations and increase childcare options, stating, "We want to expand childcare options and reduce unnecessary regulations so that parents can choose the best care for their children." The meeting was arranged by Trump's daughter, Ivanka Trump, who has been a vocal advocate for policies benefiting working parents.

The White House's efforts come as Democrats have made childcare and family leave a central focus of their campaigns. Senators Cory Booker, Elizabeth Warren, and Amy Klobuchar have proposed various legislation aimed at increasing access to childcare and paid family leave. House Democrats have also reached a deal with the White House to provide 12 weeks of paid parental leave for federal workers in exchange for establishing the president's proposed Space Force as a new branch of the government.

The White House is also seeking to reauthorize and overhaul a block-grant program that provides childcare subsidies to low-income working families. The program, which was increased by $2.4 billion to $5.6 billion last year, could benefit more families if lawmakers removed "overly stringent regulations" on facilities and staff, according to the administration.

A report by the Council of Economic Advisers found that while women with young children are more likely to participate in the labor force than they were 50 years ago, some 3.8 million parents with children under the age of 6 are currently outside the labor force. The report argues that expanding childcare options, particularly by removing some regulations, could increase the number of Americans who work rather than stay home due to childcare costs.

Title: Rubio Downplays Poll Numbers, Emphasizes Focus on Policy

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and Republican presidential candidate, does not believe his recent surge in the polls marks a turning point in his campaign. According to a CNN/ORC poll, Rubio has jumped into fourth place with 11% support, but he downplayed the significance of the numbers.

In an interview with ABC's "This Week" host George Stephanopoulos, Rubio stated that polls are not a reliable indicator of success at this stage in the campaign. "These polls don't really mean anything at this stage, George. You're a veteran of campaigns, and I'm not sure the mid-September winners are where you want to be," Rubio said.

Rubio also discussed his views on Pope Francis' upcoming visit to Washington, emphasizing his respect for the pontiff's authority on matters of doctrine and theology. "For me, the pope is the successor of [St.] Peter. He's the spiritual head of the church, who has authority to speak on matters, doctrinal matters and theological matters. And I follow him 100 percent on those issues," Rubio said.

However, Rubio also noted that the pope's political opinions are subject to disagreement. "The pope, as an individual, an important figure in the world, also has political opinions. And those, of course, we are free to disagree with," Rubio added.

Rubio also expressed his support for the pope's efforts to bring people together on issues like climate change and economics. "On the economic issues, the geopolitical issues, the pope is just trying to bring people together. That's his role as a spiritual leader. And I respect that very much," Rubio said.

In a separate topic, Rubio suggested that Pope Francis should meet with dissidents during his nine-day visit to Cuba and the United States, which began on Saturday. Additionally, Rubio noted that President Barack Obama is a Christian born in the United States.

Title: Facebook Identifies Inauthentic Groups, Including "Resisters," Behind Coordinated Events

Article: Facebook has identified at least three events co-organized on its platform by a group called the Resisters, which appears to be part of a coordinated disinformation network. The events, held in New York City and Springfield, Missouri, were critical of President Trump and attracted hundreds of attendees.

Archived versions of the event pages showed that 674 people responded on Facebook to say they would attend the "We Stand with DREAMers! Support DACA!" event in New York on September 9, 2017. Another 3,000 said they were interested in attending. The New York Post reported that thousands of people gathered in Midtown on September 9 to protest Trump's decision to unwind the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

In Springfield, Missouri, more than 2,000 people said they were interested in attending "The People's Protest. Springfield against Trump" on August 30, and 726 said they planned to attend. Local news outlets reported that hundreds of protesters showed up on that date to protest President Trump's trip to Springfield.

The third event, titled "Protest Trump and ideology of hate at Trump Tower!", attracted around 4,700 interested attendees and 1,400 attendees on the Facebook page. DNAInfo reported that thousands protested Trump at Trump Tower on August 14, 2017, the same day and location of the event promoted on Facebook.

Facebook has identified around 30 events created by inauthentic groups, including Resisters, but has no evidence on whether the events actually took place. Some evidence suggests that the events set up by Resisters were meant to piggy-back on existing, legitimate events by opponents of Trump. Indivisible St. Louis told a reporter that its Springfield event was already being organized when Resisters contacted them on Facebook, and they did not encounter any representatives from Residers at the protest.

The Columbus Circle in New York protest may have capitalized on nationwide outrage over Trump's DACA policy and may have been organized regardless. Protests against the policy had already occurred early in September 2017. Roger Ray of the Emerging Church in Springfield said that the protest he was involved in would have happened regardless.

Facebook executives did not blame Russia or the Russian troll group the Internet Research Agency (IRA) for the events, but said that the behavior matched past work by the IRA. The IRA created events that were highlighted on Facebook during the 2016 presidential election, including one in New York City attended by thousands.

Title: Pennsylvania Voters Embracing Donald Trump as GOP Nominee

Article:

In the aftermath of Donald Trump's presumptive nomination, voters in Pennsylvania are showing no hesitation in embracing the billionaire businessman as their candidate. A recent survey revealed that voters who backed Trump's opponents in the primary are now ready to get behind him, and he appears to be winning over independents and Democrats, crucial to winning the deep-blue states of Pennsylvania and Delaware.

A Pennsylvania State Police trooper, who wished to remain anonymous due to their job, voted for Senator Ted Cruz in the primary but is now ready to back Trump in November. The trooper cited Trump's ability to address the country's financial management issues as a major reason for their support.

In Harrisburg, gun shop owner Joe Staudt, a former Marine, also voted for Cruz in the primary but has now joined the "Trump Train." Staudt expressed frustration with top Republicans who refused to support Trump, calling it "childish or maybe even selfish."

The Republican Party of Pennsylvania has taken a unified stance behind Trump, with party officials falling in line after his landslide win in the state's primary. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus has also called for party unity behind Trump.

However, establishment figures, including House Speaker Paul D. Ryan and several of Trump's primary rivals, have refused to pledge their support. Trump and Ryan plan to meet on Thursday in Washington, with Ryan offering to give up his role presiding over the Republican National Convention this summer in Cleveland if requested by Trump.

According to Republican strategist and pollster Jim McLaughlin, Trump is winning over the conservative base, citing his victories in the Pennsylvania primary among evangelicals and self-described conservatives. Trump has set his sights on blue states like Pennsylvania, where his economic message of getting America to "win" again resonates with disaffected working-class voters.

Pennsylvania was one of five Northeast states, including Delaware, that Trump swept in the primary, winning every county. The state's Republican Party chair, Megan Sweeney, noted that Trump's support is "unprecedented" and "everywhere that you look, there is just this groundswell of support."

Even some Democrats are considering supporting Trump, including Katie Nimon, a registered Democrat who plans to vote for Trump in November if he faces likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. Nimon cited Clinton's perceived dishonesty as a reason for her support.

In Delaware, which hasn't voted for a Republican since George H.W. Bush in 1988, Trump also enjoys strong support. Donna Pusey, a barber and registered Democrat, vowed to vote for Trump in November, citing her frustration with the treatment of Trump by GOP leaders and her desire to see change.

Title: Bill Cosby Convicted of Drugging and Sexually Assaulting Andrea Constand

Bill Cosby, the American comedian and actor, has been convicted of drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand, a former friend, in 2004. The verdict marks the first conviction of a celebrity since the #MeToo movement, which has brought down numerous powerful men accused of sexual misconduct.

Cosby, 80, faces up to 10 years in prison for each of the three counts of aggravated indecent assault against Constand, 45. The trial took place at the Montgomery County courthouse in Norristown, Pennsylvania, and lasted three weeks.

During the trial, Cosby maintained his innocence, but his outburst after the verdict, in which he denied owning a plane, was seen as a rare glimpse into his true character. District Attorney Kevin Steele commented that the outburst showed "who he really was."

The verdict was met with a mix of emotions from Cosby's accusers, with some celebrating the conviction and others expressing sadness and relief. Lili Bernard, one of his many accusers, began sobbing, while Constand sat stone-faced.

Judge Steven O'Neill ruled that Cosby could remain out of jail on $1 million bail pending sentencing, as long as he surrenders his passport and remains at home. Cosby's lawyers have announced plans to appeal the conviction.

The conviction marks the downfall of a man once celebrated as "America's Dad," but whose reputation was ruined after over 50 women accused him of similar offenses going back decades. Cosby's defense team had argued that the accusers were fabricating their stories in search of wealth and fame.

The case against Cosby was bolstered by the testimony of five additional accusers, each of whom said they were drugged and violated. The prosecution's case was also supported by Constand's own testimony, in which she described being drugged and sexually assaulted by Cosby.

The verdict is seen as a significant victory for the #MeToo movement, which has encouraged women to come forward and share their stories of sexual harassment and assault. The movement has led to the downfall of numerous powerful men accused of sexual misconduct, including Harvey Weinstein, Matt Lauer, and Louis C.K.

In a statement, Attorney Gloria Allred, who represents 33 of Cosby's accusers, said, "We are so happy that finally we can say, women are believed, and not only on #MeToo, but in a court of law."

Title: House Democrats' Impeachment Inquiry Debate: A Semantics Game

Article: The debate among House Democrats regarding an impeachment inquiry has garnered significant attention, with 116 lawmakers now supporting the move, just shy of a majority of the party. However, the full story is more complicated than it seems. Those who do not support an impeachment inquiry instead favor continuing the current investigations, which, under current House rules and procedures, amount to the same thing.

The illusion of a dispute is useful for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, as a formal vote in the full House would increase pressure to make a decision on impeachment one way or the other. Pelosi is wise to duck this pressure on behalf of her caucus, as it is both in the party's interest and the responsible thing to do to keep the inquiry going. However, actual articles of impeachment might not have the votes on the House floor, and a failed effort would be a victory for President Donald Trump.

The debate surrounding impeachment is a semantic game, with both sides using it as a way to pressure the other. Those who support an impeachment inquiry claim it will bring accountability, while those who oppose it argue it will be a waste of time. However, under current House rules, an impeachment inquiry is largely a formality, and those who oppose it are not preventing anything.

In reality, the debate is about the best way to proceed with the current investigations, and keeping the pressure on the administration to cooperate. The House Democrats' decision to continue the inquiry is a responsible one, and the pressure it puts on the administration to comply with subpoenas and cooperate with investigations is a necessary step in the process.

The debate surrounding impeachment is a useful fiction, allowing House Democrats to "vote" on the inquiry itself and maintain the pressure on the administration. It is a tactic that is both political and responsible, and one that will continue to play out in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Researchers Link WannaCry Ransomware to Lazarus Group, Possibly Tied to North Korea

The WannaCry ransomware, which affected computers in over 150 countries, has been linked to the Lazarus Group, a hacking collective known to be associated with North Korea. The connection was made by Google security researcher Neel Mehta, who identified similarities between WannaCry and malware used by Lazarus in previous attacks. Other researchers have since confirmed the similarities, which include identical lines of code and malware tools used by the group.

While the discovery is significant, it does not necessarily implicate North Korea as the perpetrator of the attack. The Lazarus Group has been linked to several other cyberattacks, including the 2014 Sony Pictures hack and the 2016 Bangladesh bank heist. The group's malware has been used in attacks dating back to at least 2013, when South Korean media companies were targeted.

The WannaCry attack, also known as WannaCrypt, Wana Decryptor, or WCry, has been linked to the exploitation of a vulnerability in Windows, which was stolen from the National Security Agency (NSA). The malware was published online in April, and Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith criticized the U.S. government for "stockpiling" vulnerabilities.

The WannaCry attack has affected over 300,000 computers worldwide, with no signs of targeting specific countries or regions. At least 12 South Korean companies have been hit by the virus, but the country does not appear to be disproportionately affected.

Security firm Symantec has identified the presence of tools exclusively used by Lazarus on machines infected with earlier versions of WannaCry, which could have been used to spread the worm to vulnerable computers. However, malware researcher Paul Burbage of Flashpoint has not seen a solid connection between the ransomware and North Korea, stating that the only similarities are public libraries.

The investigation into the WannaCry attack is ongoing, with the White House homeland security adviser Tom Bossert stating that while investigators do not know who is responsible, there are clues to follow.

Title: Trump's Train to Leave Station, But Will Ted Cruz Board?

Article:

The Republican National Convention is underway in Cleveland, with Donald Trump set to accept the party's nomination. However, one question remains: will Ted Cruz, Trump's bitter rival, join the train or stay off? The Texas senator is scheduled to deliver a prime-time address, but it is unclear whether he will endorse Trump. Cruz's speech is seen as a reconciliation of sorts with Trump, but his campaign manager stopped short of predicting an outright endorsement.

Cruz's speech is expected to focus on his vision for America, and his campaign manager, Paul Manafort, said they have been discussing the speech with Cruz's team. While party unity was on display Tuesday night, Cruz's address could have an impact, as he placed second in the delegate count during the nominating process and still has loyal supporters in the convention hall.

Other party leaders, including House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, called for unity and emphasized the importance of defeating Hillary Clinton. Ryan, who has had his share of disagreements with Trump, closed his address by saying, "Only with Donald Trump and Mike Pence do we have a chance at a better way."

Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, a former primary rival turned supporter, warned that the country "may never recover" from another Clinton presidency and expressed his support for Trump. Trump himself addressed the convention hall via video message, saying, "This is a movement... but we have to go all the way."

Many speakers focused heavily on Hillary Clinton, with New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie delivering one of the toughest speeches of the night. His address was frequently interrupted by chants of "lock her up," and he said, "We can not promote someone to commander-in-chief who has made the world a more violent and dangerous place with every bad judgment she has made."

Title: Trump Administration Considers Six Candidates for 5th Circuit Vacancies

The Trump administration is moving quickly to fill two vacancies on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which covers federal districts in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas. According to a recent report by Legal Times, a shortlist of six candidates is being considered for the two jobs. The candidates include Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett, U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor of Fort Worth, former Texas solicitor general James Ho, Andy Oldham, a deputy general counsel to Gov. Greg Abbott, Michael Massengale, a justice on Houston's First Court of Appeals, and Brett Busby, a justice on Houston's Fourteenth Court of Appeals.

Two names on the list stand out: Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett and former Texas solicitor general James Ho. Willett is a rising star in conservative and libertarian legal circles, known for his concurring opinion in the 2015 case of Patel v. Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation. In his opinion, Willett emphasized the broader issues at stake, writing that the case was "fundamentally about the American Dream and the unalienable human right to pursue happiness without curtsying to government on bended knee."

If appointed to the 5th Circuit, Willett would be one of the most libertarian-minded federal judges in the country. Ho, on the other hand, is a former clerk to Justice Clarence Thomas and is known for his 2006 law review article defending the constitutionality of birthright citizenship for the U.S.-born children of undocumented immigrant parents. His position is at odds with the views of Donald Trump, who has vowed to end birthright citizenship.

It is worth noting that Trump has previously expressed opposition to birthright citizenship, stating that it is a "biggest magnet for illegal immigration." In an interview with Fox News host Bill O'Reilly, Trump said, "I don't think they have American citizenship. It's not going to hold up in court, it's going to have to be tested."

Title: Stock Market Rebounds as Tensions Ease After Iranian Missile Strike

The US stock market experienced a significant rebound on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes reaching intraday records, just hours after an Iranian missile strike on US Iraqi bases. The strike, in retaliation for the killing of Iranian Major General Qassem Soleimani, had put the US on the brink of all-out war with Iran.

President Donald Trump addressed the nation, stating that no American soldiers were harmed in the attack and that the US military bases sustained only minimal damage. He also noted that Iran appears to be "standing down," which is a positive development for all parties concerned.

The market's resilience in the face of geopolitical tensions is not unusual. According to LPL Financial senior market strategist Ryan Detrick, stocks have historically been good at shaking off or discounting the impact of military conflicts. The S&P 500 has declined 5% on average in 20 major geopolitical events since the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, but has recovered those losses in fewer than 50 calendar days on average.

Crude oil prices, which had surged in response to the rising tensions, fell back on Wednesday, with West Texas Intermediate crude oil settling at $59.61 a barrel, down $3.09 or 4.9% from the previous day's close. Some investors attribute the pullback to the strong gains oil has seen in the face of rising Mideast tensions.

Futures contracts on the Dow and S&P 500 had indicated a more severe response to the conflict late Tuesday, but the market's rebound suggests that investors are not overly concerned about the situation. As Detrick noted, "Stocks could be volatile for a while, but the impact to stocks from geopolitical events historically has tended to be short-lived."

Title: Tax Reform Proposal: A Mixed Bag for Individual Taxpayers

The proposed tax reform plan put forth by Republicans aims to make significant changes to the tax code, with varying effects on individual taxpayers depending on their income level, location, and tax breaks claimed. For those earning up to $24,000, no income tax will be owed. For married taxpayers filing jointly, earnings up to $90,000 will fall in the 12% bracket, while earnings up to $260,000 will be taxed at 25%, and earnings up to $1 million will be taxed at 35%. Unmarried individuals and those filing separately will have different bracket thresholds, with the 35% bracket applying to earnings up to $200,000.

The proposal also increases the standard deduction for middle-class families, expanding it to $24,000 for married couples (up from $12,700) and $12,000 for individuals (up from $6,530). The child tax credit will be expanded to $1,600, and a $300 credit will be added for each parent and non-child dependent, such as older family members. However, this credit will expire after five years.

The plan also tightens rules for claiming the child tax credit, which will affect immigrant parents whose children were born in the United States. Filers will need to provide a "work-eligible Social Security number" rather than just a taxpayer identification number to claim the credit. The Center on Budget Policy and Priorities estimates that this change will roll back eligibility for about three million children in working families, including about 80% of those born in the United States.

The bill includes several other changes that will affect taxpayers differently. It repeals certain tax credits, including the 15% credit for individuals aged 65 or over or retired on disability, which currently allows up to $7,500 for a joint return, $5,000 for a single individual, or $3,750 for a married individual filing jointly. The adoption tax credit will also be repealed, as well as deductions for tax preparation and alimony payments. Additionally, deductions for moving expenses will no longer be allowed.

One of the most contentious points is the proposed change to the popular mortgage interest deduction. Existing homeowners will be able to keep the deduction, but future purchases will be capped at $500,000, down from the current $1 million limit.

Title: FBI Won't Recommend Charges Against Hillary Clinton for Email Controversy

The FBI has concluded its investigation into Hillary Clinton's handling of classified emails on her private server, and Director James Comey announced on Tuesday that the agency will not recommend that the Department of Justice bring criminal charges against the former Secretary of State. According to Comey, the FBI found that Clinton was "extremely careless" in her handling of classified information, but there was no evidence to suggest she intended to violate laws governing the handling of classified information.

The FBI investigation found that 110 emails on Clinton's server contained classified information, and it is possible that hostile actors could have gained access to her personal email account. However, Comey stated that there was no clear evidence that Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate laws governing the handling of classified information.

Clinton's spokesman, Brian Fallon, issued a statement saying that the campaign is "pleased" with the decision and that Clinton would not do it again. Clinton herself has consistently downplayed the investigation, calling it a "security review" and stating that there was "absolutely no possibility" she would be indicted.

The decision not to prosecute Clinton does not necessarily mean that the email controversy is over. The issue is likely to remain a campaign issue, with Republicans continuing to criticize Clinton's actions and Democrats defending her. The decision also does not address the question of whether Clinton's actions were appropriate or not, with Comey stating that she was "extremely careless" in her handling of classified information.

The FBI's decision comes more than a year after the controversy first became public, and it has been a major issue in Clinton's presidential campaign. The controversy has led to criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some arguing that Clinton's actions were a threat to national security and others defending her as a victim of political witch-hunting.

Title: Tennessee Woman Serving Life Sentence for 2004 Murder Granted Clemency After 15 Years

A Tennessee woman, Cyntoia Brown, has been granted clemency by Governor Bill Haslam and will be released from prison after serving almost 15 years behind bars. Brown was convicted of murdering a 40-year-old estate agent, Johnny Allen, in 2006, when she was 16 years old. Prosecutors alleged that the murder was committed during a robbery, while Brown claimed she acted in self-defense.

Brown's case drew widespread attention and support from celebrities, including Rihanna, Kim Kardashian West, LeBron James, and others. Her story was also featured in the 2011 documentary "Me Facing Life: Cyntoia's Story." According to Brown, she was forced into prostitution by her pimp, known as "Kutthroat," and was picked up by Allen, who agreed to pay her $150 for sex. However, she claimed that Allen became violent and she shot him in self-defense.

The jury found Brown guilty of first-degree premeditated murder, first-degree felony murder, and aggravated robbery. Brown's defense team argued that she was motivated by fear of returning home empty-handed to her violent pimp, while prosecutors claimed she was driven by greed.

In a statement, Governor Haslam said that while Brown committed a "horrific crime" at the age of 16, her sentence was too harsh, especially considering the steps she has taken to rebuild her life while in prison. Brown has earned an associate degree and will be eligible for release on August 7.

Nashville Mayor David Briley called the decision a "great day for social justice and our city." Brown expressed gratitude for the support she has received and vowed to make the most of her second chance. She will be released to parole supervision on August 7.

Title: Hillary Clinton Calls for Adult Summer Camps to Bridge Political Divide

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recently delivered a speech to over 3,000 camp professionals at the American Camp Association of New York and Jersey's annual Tri-State CAMP Conference in Atlantic City, New Jersey. In her remarks, Clinton emphasized the need for Americans to come together and bridge the political divide. She jokingly advocated for adult summer camps, where people from different political backgrounds could come together and learn to listen to each other.

Clinton also lamented the growth of political division and partisanship, pointing to changes in the media and campaign finance laws as contributing factors. She criticized the Supreme Court's Citizens United decision, saying it has led to an "insatiable pressure to raise money" that is "crazy" and "no way to run a country." Clinton also expressed concern that not enough lawmakers are working across the political aisle and spending too little time in Washington.

The former senator and presidential candidate also spoke about her advocacy for children and praised camp professionals for teaching life skills to kids. She reiterated her call for universal pre-kindergarten education, which she believes is an economic and national security issue.

Clinton's speech was light on policy specifics, but she did touch on her desire to get Americans into a "nice warm purple space" to come together. She also poked fun at former Vice President Al Gore, praising American ingenuity and joking about the invention of the internet.

The conference was one of Clinton's last events as a private citizen before she is expected to launch her 2016 presidential campaign in April.

Title: Trump to Participate in Debates, Predicts Ocasio-Cortez-Chuck Schumer Showdown

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced that he will participate in debates this fall, despite previously expressing concerns about the Commission on Presidential Debates' alleged bias against him. Trump also made several other comments during a recent speech, including predictions about the upcoming Democratic primary and a potential award for conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh.

According to sources in the room, Trump mentioned that Limbaugh, who recently announced he has advanced lung cancer, might be in attendance, and he expressed a willingness to award him the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Trump also expressed his feelings about Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who orchestrated his impeachment, saying that she will be sitting behind him and next to Vice President Mike Pence during the speech, with one person being friendly and the other not.

Trump also took aim at former National Security Adviser John Bolton, whose unpublished book confirms a central allegation of the impeachment charges. Trump described Bolton as having "turned on" him.

The news comes as Trump's approval rating has climbed to 49% in a recent Gallup survey, its highest since his presidency began. While polls have shown that most Americans want the Senate to call witnesses in the impeachment trial, it is expected to end with an acquittal, with the possibility of one or more Democratic senators voting with Trump.

According to Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union, Trump's impeachment trial has actually worked in his favor, making him appear like the "adult in the room." Schlapp also believes that the delayed count in Iowa will sow discord and suspicion within Democratic ranks, making people assume the fix is in again because they don't like who is leading.

It is worth noting that the article does not provide information on Trump's stance on the delayed count in Iowa, and it is unclear what he meant by his comment about the fix being in.

Title: Trump's Use of Presidential Pardon Power Under Scrutiny After Dinesh D'Souza Pardon

The recent decision by President Donald Trump to pardon conservative commentator Dinesh D'Souza has raised questions about the political nature of his use of the presidential pardon power. This move comes on the heels of recent pardons for late heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson and Lewis "Scooter" Libby, a former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney during the George W. Bush administration.

D'Souza had pleaded guilty to making illegal campaign contributions, although he claimed to be the victim of a politically-motivated prosecution by the Obama-era Department of Justice (DOJ). The judge at his 2014 sentencing hearing described his claims as "all hat, no cattle."

The pardons have sparked concerns among critics that Trump is using his power to reward loyalty and punish political enemies. Lisa Gilbert of Public Citizen, a not-for-profit watchdog group, stated, "It makes us increasingly worried. Trump's feeling that people who say the right things or show some kind of loyalty or play on his team should be pardoned is completely antithetical to how our justice system works."

Grant Reeher, a professor of political science at Syracuse University, noted that Trump's pardons appear "more politically oriented" compared to those of other recent presidents. He is focusing on people whose political actions are consistent with his own, advancing points of view that he shares, or working towards his goals.

Defenders of the president argue that he is not unusual in this regard. One of the most controversial pardons issued by President Clinton benefited Marc Rich, a fugitive financier whose ex-wife, Denise Rich, was a major fundraiser for the Democratic Party.

Trump's defenders also point out that he has considered pardons for non-political figures, such as businesswoman Martha Stewart and Rod Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois. Matt Mackowiak, a Republican strategist, stated, "I think he is trying to use the pardon power to right wrongs that he sees. The fact that he is seriously looking at Blagojevich and Martha Stewart is a sign that he is not focused exclusively on partisan background."

The pardons have also raised questions about whether Trump is seeking to send a signal to erstwhile aides who are now feeling the heat from the Mueller investigation into allegations of collusion with Russia. However, there is no hard evidence to support this theory.

Some critics have also raised concerns about Trump's potential bias towards celebrities or celebrity-backed causes. The Jack Johnson pardon was prominently backed by actor and director Sylvester Stallone, and Trump told reporters he did not know D'Souza personally but "I read the papers, I see him on television." The pardon of D'Souza came the day after Trump received an Oval Office visit from Kim Kardashian, who is advocating for prison reform and a pardon for Alice Marie Johnson, a 63-year-old woman serving a life sentence for drug offenses.

The White House has pushed back on suggestions that the president is mostly focused on celebrity pardons, stating that there are many people being considered for pardons. However, the fact that Trump has tended to issue pardons without going through the usual process of review at the DOJ has raised concerns among some skeptics.

The decision to pardon D'Souza will continue to be felt, with the lead prosecutor in his case, Carrie H. Cohen, releasing a statement critical of Trump's decision.

Title: Democrat Conor Lamb Wins Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District Special Election

The special election in Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District has seen Democrat Conor Lamb emerge as the likely winner, pending a possible recount. The outcome is a significant blow to the Republican Party, which had been confident about retaining the seat. Here are three key takeaways from the election:

1. The GOP should be concerned about November's midterm elections. Historical trends suggest that the president's party often performs poorly in midterm elections, and President Trump's approval rating is currently in the low 40s. Additionally, the Democratic base is more energized than the Republican base, which could lead to a significant shift in the political landscape.

2. Candidates matter. Republican candidate Rick Saccone was seen as an underwhelming candidate, lacking enthusiasm among grassroots voters and struggling with fundraising. In contrast, Democrat Conor Lamb's robust fundraising operation and retail politics skills proved to be a potent combination. Lamb's moderate stance on social issues, such as abortion and gun control, also resonated with voters in the district.

3. The Pelosi Factor will continue to be a challenge for Democrats. The Lamb campaign's decision to distance themselves from House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi helped to blunt some of the Republican attacks. Other Democrats in purple-to-red districts may follow suit, as the inability to take a clean hit at Pelosi hurt Republicans in PA-18. The tax reform law, which has been a major selling point for Republicans, also failed to resonate with voters in this district.

The outcome of the election highlights the challenges facing the Republican Party, particularly in districts that were previously considered safe. The Democratic Party, on the other hand, is gaining momentum and confidence, with 23 lower chamber seats represented by Republicans in districts carried by Hillary Clinton in 2016 being seen as potential pickup opportunities.

Title: House Republicans Plan to Release Alleged Government Surveillance Memo to the Public

The House Intelligence Committee is set to begin the process of releasing a secret memo detailing alleged government surveillance abuses, according to Representative Dave Joyce (R-Ohio). The memo, which has been the subject of much controversy, is expected to be released within the next 19 congressional working days, with the earliest possible release date being mid-March.

The memo, which is classified as highly confidential, allegedly provides evidence that the Obama administration used the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISA) to unlawfully spy on the Trump campaign and transition team. This has led to demands from numerous GOP lawmakers for the memo to be released to the public, with some even suggesting it could lead to the end of the special counsel's Trump-Russia investigation and the firing of senior FBI and CIA officials.

Led by Representative Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.), 65 GOP lawmakers wrote to House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) on Friday demanding the memo's release. Gaetz described the memo as "shocking" and stated that it will "shock the conscience of this country" when it is released.

The release process will involve multiple levels of approval, including review by federal records reviewers and clearance from the House Intelligence Committee and President Donald Trump. Representative Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) explained on Fox News that the document's release would first need approval from the House Intelligence Committee and then President Trump's green light.

Title: The Complexity of Fairness: A Call for Neutral Rules in Society

The concept of fairness is often complicated by tribal identities and partisan allegiances, making it challenging to establish neutral rules that apply to everyone equally. This was exemplified by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's recent comments on NBC's Meet the Press, where she defended Representative John Conyers' right to due process despite allegations of improper conduct. Pelosi's stance has been criticized by both liberals and populists on the left and right, who see it as a double standard.

Pelosi's defense of Conyers and Senator Al Franken, who have both been accused of sexual misconduct, has been met with anger and frustration from many Republicans who believe that liberals selectively apply standards of conduct to delegitimize and destroy their political opponents. This perceived hypocrisy has led to a sense of mistrust and skepticism towards the political establishment.

The concept of due process is not unique to Congress; it is also applied in the context of Title IX regulations, which have been used to address sexual assault allegations on college campuses. However, this has led to concerns about the erosion of due process for accused individuals.

In an effort to move beyond partisan politics, the author suggests considering the "original position" thought experiment proposed by philosopher John Rawls. This thought experiment involves imagining oneself in a state of ignorance about one's identity, including gender, race, and socioeconomic status, and considering what rules would be fair for society. The idea is to consider fairness through the lens of self-interest, rather than tribal allegiances.

The author notes that this concept is not new and is embedded in classical liberalism, which emphasizes the importance of equal treatment under the law. The complexity of fairness is that everyone wants to make it complicated, often using their own tribal identity as a justification for their stance. The author concludes that it is time to revisit the simplicity of fairness and consider what rules would be fair for everyone, regardless of their identity.

Title: President Obama Urges House Republicans to Pass "Clean" Spending Bill to End Shutdown

Article:

President Barack Obama continued to pressure House Republicans to pass a "clean" spending bill to end the federal government shutdown, which is now in its second week. In his weekly radio and internet address, the president shared the stories of two Americans affected by the shutdown, including an Alabama woman whose Head Start agency had to close its doors and a North Dakota family in danger of losing its federal home loan.

The president emphasized that there is only one way to end the shutdown: pass a budget that funds the government without any partisan strings attached. He urged Speaker John Boehner to allow a vote on a "clean" spending bill, which he believes could pass with bipartisan support. However, Boehner has not allowed such a bill to come up for a vote.

The White House has been trying to turn House Republicans against each other, pitting moderate members against their tea party counterparts, by highlighting the impact of the shutdown on everyday Americans. The administration maintains that a "clean" spending bill could pass the House with bipartisan support.

As the shutdown continues, Obama is also looking ahead to the nation's debt ceiling, which is expected to be reached in late October or early November. The administration is warning that a default would have much worse economic consequences than the current shutdown. Obama emphasized that the government should not be held hostage by partisan politics and that the American people should not be forced to pay the price for political disagreements.

The president's message is clear: the only way to end the shutdown is for House Republicans to pass a "clean" spending bill, and he is urging them to take action to get the government back up and running.

Title: Groups Seize on 50th Anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s March to Champion Various Causes

Article:

The 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s historic march on Washington has become a platform for various groups to promote their individual causes, some of which may seem tenuously connected to King's legacy of fighting racial injustice. Gun control advocates, advocates for D.C. statehood, and even the Republican National Committee are among those seizing on the occasion to push their agendas.

The event, which began with a march retracing the 1963 route and continues with a day of speeches at the Lincoln Memorial, has sparked debate over what it means to continue the civil rights movement. Martin Luther King III, the civil rights leader's oldest living child, emphasized the need to "arouse a new coalition of conscience" to counter the energy of the tea party movement.

However, not everyone agrees on what King would have thought about certain issues. Alveda King, his niece, worries that tying specific social causes to his legacy diminishes his overarching significance. She believes the celebrations should focus on a unifying message of love.

The debate is particularly intense when it comes to gay rights. The gay community has closely aligned itself with the tributes, with multiple events honoring Bayard Rustin, who helped organize the 1963 march and was openly gay. A coalition of over 40 groups signed an open letter calling for federal laws protecting against discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity.

However, not all African-Americans support gay marriage, and some have criticized the alignment of the gay community with King's legacy. Grammy-winning gospel singer Donnie McClurkin was initially invited to perform at a concert at the King Memorial but was uninvited after activists complained about his past comments calling being gay "a curse."

The article does not provide a clear stance on what Martin Luther King Jr. would think about specific issues like gay marriage, drones, or Republicans.

Title: Sanders' Wealth and Political Power: A Complex Issue

The article discusses the controversy surrounding Bernie Sanders' millionaire status and its implications on his political views and policy proposals. Some argue that his wealth does not disqualify him from advocating for progressive policies, as he is not a lobbyist and his campaign is funded by small donors. Others claim that his wealth is a result of his fame and that he could use his resources to benefit society.

The article also touches on the concept of socialism and the idea that only poor people can hold leftist views. It references Oscar Wilde's criticism of charity and the notion that private property can be used to alleviate the effects of private property. The author questions why Sanders would keep his millions if he believes they should be taxed away.

Regarding the Fox News town hall, the article describes it as a success, with Sanders offering policy proposals and rallying a majority of Americans. The event focused on issues affecting the working class, such as stagnant wages and living standards.

The article also discusses the controversy surrounding President Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president, which has sparked impeachment proceedings. The call is described as a "wild look into the president's mindset and approach to his job," with Trump using his position to pursue conspiracy theories and engage in a quid pro quo with a foreign government. The article notes that circumstantial evidence can be enough to prove criminal wrongdoing and that the investigation will focus on the context and circumstances surrounding the call.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced discussion on the complex issues surrounding Bernie Sanders' wealth and political power, as well as the controversy surrounding President Trump's actions.

Title: Campaigns Cancel Events as Storm Approaches East Coast

The approaching Hurricane Sandy has led to a series of event cancellations and adjustments in the final week of the presidential campaign. Both President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney have suspended their campaign trips to the swing state of Virginia, which is expected to be heavily affected by the storm.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has been activated, and President Obama has canceled his trips to Florida and Colorado to focus on monitoring the storm's progress. The president's decision has been met with skepticism from some Republicans, who point to his response to the Benghazi attack in Libya as a comparison.

Meanwhile, Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell has announced plans to keep voting machines running and has prioritized restoring power to hospitals, police stations, and polling stations. Maryland has already canceled early voting for Monday.

The storm's impact on the election is uncertain, with some experts predicting it could affect voter turnout and others believing it will not have a significant impact. Obama senior adviser David Axelrod expressed concerns about the potential disruption to the polls, stating, "We want unfettered access to the polls because we believe that the more people come out, the better we're going to do."

The Romney-Ryan ticket has taken a more low-key approach, with Mitt Romney expressing sympathy for those affected by the storm and making campaign resources available for relief efforts. The campaign has also suspended fundraising emails to affected states and is collecting donations in campaign offices.

As the storm approaches, the campaigns are facing a difficult decision: whether to continue campaigning or prioritize disaster relief efforts. The uncertainty surrounding the storm's impact on the election has left many politicos scratching their heads, with some predicting a possible "paralysis" in the campaign.

Title: Mondelez International Updates Animal Cracker Packaging to Show Animals in Natural Habitat

Mondelez International, the parent company of Nabisco, has introduced a new design for its Barnum's Animals crackers, featuring the animals in a natural habitat instead of behind bars. The change comes after over a century of the iconic packaging showing the animals confined in a circus boxcar. According to a Mondelez International spokeswoman, Kimberly Fontes, the company felt it was time for a design evolution to keep the brand relevant for years to come.

The new design shows the animals standing shoulder to shoulder, proudly walking in their natural environment. The packaging still promises "Same Great Taste!" The change is seen as a nod to the cultural shift towards animal welfare and compassion. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) had been advocating for a change in the design, citing concerns about the use of animals in circuses. The organization participated in discussions with the company about the redesign and sees the new packaging as a reflection of society's growing intolerance for animal exploitation.

The company has previously used its packaging to raise awareness about animal and environmental issues through limited-time special editions. The new design is seen as a continuation of this effort. The change is also seen as a response to the decline of the circus industry, with Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus shutting down last year due to pressure from animal rights groups and declining ticket sales. The company had already stopped featuring elephants in its shows in 2015, citing declining attendance.

Title: House Rules Committee Finds Speaker Pelosi's Criticism of President Trump Violates Chamber's Rules

Article:

The House of Representatives ruled on Tuesday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi's criticism of President Trump violates the chamber's rules. Despite this finding, members voted to keep her words in the official record, with a 232-190 vote. The House also allowed Pelosi to continue debating on the House floor, with a 231-190 vote.

Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer took over the gavel to make the announcement about Pelosi's violation of the rules, stating that her words contained an accusation of racist behavior against the president. Hoyer emphasized that such language should not be used in debate.

Pelosi had previously called President Trump's comments about four freshman congresswomen, including Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Ilhan Omar, Ayanna Pressley, and Rashida Tlaib, "divisive and dangerous" to the country. She also urged her colleagues to join her in condemning the president's "racist tweets."

House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy criticized Pelosi for not apologizing for her words and accused her of breaking the rules. "What we just saw was a very sad day in this House – probably a historic day," he said.

The House rules, which date back to Thomas Jefferson's writings, allow members to criticize the government or the president on the House floor in an official capacity, but prohibit language that is "personally offensive" to the president. The rules explicitly state that any reference to "racial or other discrimination on the part of the President" is not allowed.

Pelosi told reporters after the vote that she stood by her statement, saying she was proud of the attention being called to the president's "inappropriate" comments. Rep. Doug Collins, ranking member of the Judiciary Committee, had initially called for Pelosi's comments to be taken down, calling them "unparliamentary."

The House Freedom Caucus Chairman, Mark Meadows, said that while Pelosi's words violated the House rules, Democrats will likely keep them in the official record. He called on lawmakers to maintain civil discourse, as the chamber has for more than two centuries.

The rules committee's decision does not automatically remove Pelosi's words from the record, but she could face punishment, including being barred from speaking on the floor for the rest of the day.

Title: Senator Rand Paul to Join Bipartisan Group at White House for "Promise Zones" Announcement

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, is set to join a bipartisan group of senators at the White House on Thursday for an announcement by President Obama on the designation of "Promise Zones" to help communities tackle poverty. Paul, a frequent critic of the administration, is also expected to participate in a private meeting with the president and other lawmakers to discuss the initiative.

The "Promise Zones" program, first announced by Obama during last year's State of the Union speech, provides tax incentives and grants to areas designated as such. The president is expected to announce five new locations, including an eight-county region in southeastern Kentucky, San Antonio, Texas, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, and the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma.

Senator Paul, who has been a thorn in the president's side on several occasions, has introduced his own legislation to create "economic freedom zones" in cities like Detroit, which would cut taxes and red tape to encourage growth. He has questioned why Obama's plan does not include Detroit, as his does.

The invitation to Senator Paul could be seen as part of the president's efforts to reach out to Republicans, similar to his "charm offensive" earlier in 2013 to achieve a "grand bargain" budget deal. However, Paul has been a vocal critic of the administration on several issues, including his recent class-action lawsuit against the National Security Agency's spying practices and his filibuster over the administration's drone policy.

Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky, expressed his support for the "Promise Zones" designation, stating that the region has suffered economic hardship due to the administration's policies towards the coal industry.

Title: White Supremacist Violence and the Trump Administration's Connection

The recent terrorist attack in Christchurch, New Zealand, which killed 50 Muslims, has sparked concerns about the growing threat of white nationalism worldwide. In response to a reporter's question, President Donald Trump denied the existence of white nationalism, stating it is a "small group of people." White House adviser Kellyanne Conway dismissed the shooter's racist motivations, labeling him an "eco-terrorist." Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney also downplayed the issue, saying the president is not a white supremacist.

However, Trump's record speaks louder than his words. In January 2017, a man stormed a Quebec City mosque and killed six people while they prayed, citing Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric as motivation. The New Zealand shooter mentioned Trump's name in his manifesto, praising him as a symbol of white identity and common purpose.

According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), far-right attacks in Europe have increased by 43% between 2016 and 2017, while domestic attacks in the United States have more than quadrupled. The connections between Trump and white nationalists are well-documented, including his refusal to condemn white nationalists who marched through Charlottesville, Virginia, in 2017.

Trump's rhetoric has also contributed to the rise of anti-Muslim hate groups, which nearly tripled in 2017, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center. Hate crimes across the board rose by 17% in 2017, according to FBI statistics.

The president's actions have emboldened a lunatic and racist fringe, violating the custom of the modern presidency by prioritizing division over unity. Before the Christchurch victims were even buried, Trump tweeted in support of Fox News host Jeanine Pirro, who had made anti-Muslim comments about Representative Ilhan Omar. He also used the term "invasion" to describe immigrants, echoing the shooter's manifesto.

While Trump is not criminally responsible for these acts, he is politically responsible. Understanding this distinction is the first step towards rejuvenating our politics and addressing the growing threat of white supremacy.

Title: Four Killed, Including Suspect, and 12 Injured in Gilroy Garlic Festival Shooting

A shooting occurred at the annual Gilroy Garlic Festival in Christmas Hill Park, California, on Sunday, resulting in the deaths of four people, including the suspect, and at least 12 others injured. The shooting took place around 5:41 pm local time, with the suspect using an assault-style rifle to fire multiple rounds.

According to eyewitness accounts, the shooter was wearing Army fatigues and began firing randomly, with one witness describing the scene as "chaotic." Police responded quickly, engaging the shooter within one minute and killing him.

Security at the event included bag searches and metal detector wands, but the suspect managed to enter the festival by cutting through a perimeter fence. Festivalgoers fled in panic as shots rang out, with videos of the chaotic scene posted to social media.

The victims included a 6-year-old boy named Stephen Romero, as well as a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s. Their names have not been released. A witness who had a brief interaction with the shooter reported that the suspect replied "because I'm really angry" when asked why he was doing this.

An Instagram page reportedly belonging to the shooter was tracked down by Heavy, which found a post recommending a book promoting racist and misogynistic principles, posted just before the shooting. A search is ongoing for a possible second suspect, although it is unclear if they were involved in the shooting or assisted the gunman in some way.

Title: Trump's Surprise Decision to Withdraw US Troops from Syria Stuns Turkey and Changes Battlefield Dynamics

The sudden announcement by President Donald Trump that the United States will withdraw its troops from Syria has left Turkey scrambling to respond to the changing battlefield dynamics on its southern border. The decision, made during a phone call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has stunned both Ankara and Washington, catching many off guard.

According to Turkish officials, Trump asked Erdogan if Turkey could take on the task of finishing off Islamic State (ISIS) in Syria, and Erdogan agreed. Trump then instructed his national security adviser, John Bolton, to begin the process of withdrawing US troops from the region.

The decision was met with shock in Washington, where senior administration officials, including Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis and Brett McGurk, a senior official coordinating the fight against ISIS, resigned in protest. Trump's decision to withdraw the troops was seen as a major shift in US policy in the Middle East, abandoning a quarter of Syrian territory and handing Ankara the responsibility of finishing off ISIS.

The move has significant implications for the region, as it potentially frees Turkey's military to push back against the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) from the border, which Turkey considers a terrorist organization. However, it also opens up an area of Syria far larger than Turkey had expected to fill, potentially pitting it against not just Kurdish forces but also the Damascus government and its Russian and Iranian backers.

The YPG has asked the Syrian government to take over the town of Manbij, which the Kurdish militia currently controls with US support, to protect it from Turkish attack. Meanwhile, Turkey's intelligence chief and defense and foreign ministers are set to visit Moscow to discuss the new developments.

The US is also grappling with what to do with the weapons it provided to the YPG militia and promised to take back after the campaign against ISIS ended. Turkey says the weapons must be collected so they are not used against Turkish troops, but US officials say they cannot disarm their own allies when the fight is not yet over.

The Turkish military has already carried out two incursions into north Syria, backed by pro-Turkey Syrian rebels, but Ankara and its allies alone do not have the capacity to take over the whole region. Turkey's priority may be to secure its southern frontier, with a security official stating that "distancing the YPG from the border and wiping out these elements is of critical importance."

The implications of Trump's decision are still unfolding, with US military planners drafting plans for a withdrawal over the course of several months, including a 120-day withdrawal period. The US is also launching intensive talks with Turkey and Russia to address the new developments.

**Congressional Baseball Practice Shooting Leaves Several Wounded, One Dead**

A shooting occurred during a congressional baseball practice in Northern Virginia on Wednesday morning, leaving several individuals wounded and one dead. House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, a Republican from Louisiana, was among those injured, suffering a gunshot wound to the hip. He underwent surgery and is currently in critical condition at MedStar Washington Hospital Center.

Four others, including a congressional staffer, a lobbyist, and two members of the Capitol Police, were also hit in the attack. The shooter, identified as James T. Hodgkinson, a 66-year-old man from Illinois, was shot by police during the incident and died of multiple gunshot wounds to the torso.

The shooting occurred during an early morning practice for an annual charity baseball game between Democratic and Republican lawmakers. The game was scheduled for Thursday evening.

The FBI and Alexandria Police Department are actively investigating the incident, which is still unfolding. The FBI has identified Hodgkinson's associates, social media impressions, and potential motivations as areas of focus. The agency is also tracing two weapons, a 9mm handgun and a 7.62-caliber rifle.

Capitol Police reported that the two weapons were a 9mm handgun and a 7.62-caliber rifle. The FBI and Alexandria Police released a statement detailing the incident, which occurred at approximately 7:09 a.m. on June 14. The Alexandria Police Department responded to the scene, and officers arrived three minutes later.

The investigation is ongoing, and the FBI has not yet determined the motive behind the shooting. The agency believes it was not an assassination attempt.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Arizona Immigration Law Provision, Despite Initial Concerns of Racial Profiling

The Supreme Court's recent ruling on Arizona's immigration law has sparked renewed debate about the potential for racial profiling and discrimination. The law, signed by Governor Jan Brewer in 2010, allows police to check the immigration status of individuals they reasonably suspect are in the country illegally. Initially, President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder expressed concerns that this provision would lead to racial profiling, with Holder even testifying to Congress that he believed it would.

However, the Supreme Court ultimately upheld this provision in a 5-3 ruling, with Justice Anthony Kennedy writing that it is unclear how the law will be implemented and enforced, and that it is too early to assume it will create a conflict with federal law. The court did strike down three other provisions of the law, which set up state criminal penalties for immigration violations.

The provision that was upheld allows police to check the status of individuals they reasonably suspect are in the country illegally, and report their identity to federal authorities. The federal government can then decide whether to deport the individual or let them go. While some critics, such as Representative Luis Gutierrez, have expressed concerns that this provision will lead to racial profiling, the Supreme Court left open the possibility for further challenges if the law becomes discriminatory.

In a statement, Governor Brewer emphasized the importance of police being aware of potential challenges and allegations of discrimination, saying that opponents are already preparing new litigation tactics. The Justice Department has also stated that it will closely monitor how the law is implemented to ensure it does not lead to discrimination.

The Supreme Court's decision has sparked a renewed debate about the balance between state and federal power over immigration, as well as the potential for racial profiling and discrimination.

Title: The Futility of the Iraq War: A Lesson in the Complexity of the Middle East

The Iraq War, which began in 2003, has been marked by a series of tragic missteps and failed expectations. The initial invasion was launched under the pretext of destroying weapons of mass destruction, but these were never found. The subsequent occupation aimed to nation-build and establish a democratic government, but this effort ultimately failed.

The war has resulted in significant human and financial costs, with thousands of American deaths, tens of thousands of casualties, and trillions of dollars spent. Despite the efforts of American forces, the conflict has not brought about a lasting peace. Instead, it has created a power vacuum that has allowed extremist groups to flourish.

The article argues that the war was marked by a failure to understand the complexities of the Middle East, where war is often the default state and peace is a temporary pause between conflicts. The author notes that American forces left Iraq in 2011, but the conflict has continued, with the city of Fallujah being a prime example.

The article also places blame on both President Bush and President Obama for their handling of the war. President Bush's decision to invade Iraq was based on questionable intelligence, while President Obama's decision to withdraw troops too quickly allowed extremist groups to regroup and reconstitute.

The article concludes that the Iraq War was a failure, but it is not the end of the story. The author notes that the war has been marked by a series of tragic missteps, but that the United States has recovered from past failures and can learn from its mistakes. The article ends on a hopeful note, suggesting that the United States can rise again and lead the world with a more sober, shrewd, and strategic approach.

Title: Business Groups Launch Nationwide Effort to Lobby for TPP Approval

Article:

Despite opposition from both major-party presidential candidates and a majority of Democratic leadership outside the White House, business groups are launching a well-funded, national effort to lobby for the approval of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). Caterpillar Inc. hosted lawmakers at its factories to meet face-to-face with workers who will benefit from the agreement. Trade Benefits America, a leading business coalition, is coordinating a grassroots advertising campaign, sending members of Congress between 60 and 70 pro-TPP letters daily. The Association of Equipment Manufacturers is driving around the Midwest in a truck outfitted with interactive displays on trade, part of a six-figure effort to highlight the tangible benefits of the sweeping 12-nation agreement.

Leading supporters of TPP remain optimistic, insisting the agreement still has a shot at approval later this year. They point to opinion polls showing a majority of Americans support free trade and say back-to-back party conventions have magnified a few loud anti-TPP voices that don't understand all the facts. They believe lawmakers will vote in the interests of their districts rather than follow the positions of those at the top of the ticket.

Proponents of the agreement are working harder to get it approved before Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump becomes president and the agreement is either junked or put into a deep freeze for years. They hope the issue will make it onto the crowded legislative agenda during the lame-duck period after the election.

Trade supporters recognize that to get the votes they need in Congress, the administration needs to work with lawmakers who want changes in particular provisions, such as protections for biologic drug firms and tobacco companies. A third concern, involving financial services companies, was largely settled the week before the Republican convention in a compromise that could serve as a model for solving the remaining problems.

Lobbying groups are quick to talk up all the ways they plan to connect with lawmakers, including penning op-eds, attending town halls, and flooding congressional offices with handwritten letters from company employees. Some groups are focusing on taking advantage of summer recess to show lawmakers the importance of trade deals on their home turf. For the agriculture community, summer months mean "it's fair time," said David Salmonsen, senior director of congressional relations at the American Farm Bureau Federation.

In the end, proponents of the agreement are confident that despite the difficult political environment, it is still possible to put together enough votes to pass the agreement.

Title: Former Guantanamo Detainee's Conviction Overturned, Raising Questions About Military Trials

Article:

A former Guantanamo Bay detainee, Mr. Hamdan, has had his conviction overturned by the US Court of Appeals, raising questions about the legitimacy of military trials for terrorism suspects. Hamdan was captured in Afghanistan in 2001 and was sent to Guantanamo Bay soon after. He was charged with conspiracy and material support for Al Qaeda, but was acquitted of the conspiracy charge and sentenced to 66 months of confinement.

Hamdan's legal journey has been marked by controversy, with his case proceeding slowly due to legal challenges to the Bush administration's new system of military commissions for terrorism suspects. He has claimed to have been beaten and kept in isolation for months during his detention.

In 2008, Hamdan was acquitted of the conspiracy charge, which could have resulted in a longer sentence. He was sentenced to 66 months of confinement, with credit for time already served. The verdict was a setback for military prosecutors, who had argued that they could detain him indefinitely.

The Court of Military Commission Review upheld Hamdan's conviction in 2011, but the Appeals Court has now reversed the decision. The ruling has implications for other Guantanamo detainees accused of being part of Al Qaeda but not of plotting any specific terrorist attack.

The opinion was written by Judge Brett Kavanaugh, who worked as a lawyer in the White House for President George W. Bush before being appointed to the bench. The decision was joined by Chief Judge David Sentelle and Judge Douglas Ginsburg, both appointees of Ronald Reagan.

Zachary Katznelson, senior staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union, said the decision "strikes the biggest blow yet against the legitimacy of the Guantanamo military commissions, which have for years now been trying people for a supposed war crime that in fact is not a war crime at all."
