He argued that the government should prosecute Guantanamo prisoners in civilian courts if they have enough admissible evidence.

Title: Cities Across the Nation Mark 50th Anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's Assassination

As the United States marks the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, cities nationwide are hosting events to commemorate the occasion. Dallas, where the president was murdered, will host a variety of events, including an observance on the actual anniversary day, November 22, at Dealey Plaza. The event will feature Pulitzer-winning presidential historian David McCullough reading parts from Kennedy's presidential speeches, a 73-member U.S. Naval Academy Men's Glee Club singing, and religious leaders offering prayers and a benediction. Approximately 5,000 tickets have been issued for this public event.

In Washington, D.C., the Newseum will host "JFK Remembrance Day" on November 22, featuring a rebroadcast of three hours of CBS News' live television coverage of the assassination. President Obama will give a speech at the Smithsonian American History Museum on November 21 on Kennedy's legacy of service, and will meet privately with leaders and volunteers from the Peace Corps, an organization Kennedy established in 1961. The Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, where Kennedy's funeral took place, will host a Choral Mass of Remembrance on November 22.

In Arlington, Virginia, the eternal flame at Kennedy's grave site at Arlington Cemetery was restored last month and is open to the public. President Obama will visit the grave on November 21, accompanied by First Lady Michelle Obama, former President Bill Clinton, and former First Lady and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Other cities across the country are also hosting events to mark the anniversary. In Brookline, Massachusetts, the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site will provide free admission to the public on November 23 and 24, and will hold a brief memorial ceremony at the president's birthplace on November 24. In Pleasant Hill, California, John F. Kennedy University will hold a memorial on November 22, featuring an unveiling of a bust of Kennedy and the announcement of a project for students to honor the president's service legacy.

In Chicago, city officials have passed a resolution calling for all city and state flags to fly at half-staff on November 22, a citywide moment of silence at 1 p.m., and church bells to toll to commemorate the assassination of the president. The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan, will offer special programs this week, including sold-out events with newscaster Dan Rather, who covered the assassination, and former Secret Service agent Clint Hill, who was on duty that day in Dallas.

In San Antonio, Kennedy's last official act as president took place when he dedicated buildings at the Brooks Air Force Base School of Aerospace Medicine and gave his "Cap over the Wall" speech, one day before his death. Brooks City-Base will hold a commemorative event at the same location on November 21, featuring remarks by San Antonio Mayor Julián Castro and Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff.

Title: Federal Report on School Safety Highlights Importance of Infrastructure Security and Mental Health Services

A recent report by the Federal Commission on School Safety, established in the wake of the Parkland high school massacre, has concluded that one of the key recommendations to prevent mass shootings is to rescind policies protecting black and other minority students from being disciplined at disproportionate rates. The report, which evaluated best practices to keep schools safe, did not make any recommendations on changing state or federal gun laws and instead focused on guidelines for arming "highly trained school personnel" in rural areas.

The report also emphasized the importance of reviewing school infrastructure security, including windows, hallways, and doors, and having someone on school grounds armed with a firearm who would collaborate with law enforcement. Additionally, it encouraged more coordination between schools and local law enforcement, as well as hiring military veterans or retired law enforcement officers into school roles.

The report also included recommendations aimed at reporters, suggesting they be more responsible in how they cover school shootings and not publish pictures of the perpetrator. It also recommended ensuring students have better access to mental health services at school, enhancing social and emotional learning for students, and suggested states consider adopting "extreme risk protection orders" that would temporarily withhold guns from those who post a risk to themselves or others.

The report's findings were met with mixed reactions from those affected by school shootings. While some, like Andy Pollack, whose daughter Meadow died in Parkland, praised the report as a "huge step towards making our schools safe," others, like Fred Guttenberg, whose daughter Jaime was killed in Parkland, expressed disappointment that the report did not consider the role of guns in school shootings. Mark Barden, whose son Daniel was one of the 20 first-graders killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School, agreed with some of the recommendations but expressed concern about the report's support for putting more firearms in schools.

The report's release comes as the nation continues to grapple with the issue of school safety and mass shootings. While the report provides some recommendations for improving school safety, it is clear that there is no single solution and that different approaches may be effective in different schools and communities.

Title: ObamaCare Enrollees May Face Limited Doctor Access Due to Low Payments

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as ObamaCare, has seen a surge in enrollments, with hundreds of thousands signing up for coverage starting January 1. However, analysts warn that the plans may not provide access to the doctors and hospitals they need. Insurers are likely to limit the number of providers they contract with, leading to a system that resembles Medicaid, the healthcare program for low-income Americans.

Experts suggest that the only way insurers can control costs is by reducing the amount they pay doctors and hospitals. This could lead to a situation where patients have insurance but struggle to find a doctor willing to treat them. "About half of the physicians in many communities refuse to take Medicaid patients because the payment system is just too low," said James Capretta, of the Ethics and Public Policy Center.

The Obama administration aims to increase the number of people on Medicaid by 9 million and those in private plans by 7 million by the end of March. New Medicaid enrollments have already outpaced those in private plans on the exchanges. However, expanding Medicaid while opening the door to lower payments for private insurance raises concerns about rationing, as too many people may chase too few doctors.

Experts warn that the networks will be overwhelmed, with more people seeking care than doctors can handle. "These networks are going to be jammed with people," said Robert Laszewski, president of Health Policy and Strategy Associates. "Far more than they're treating now, and I don't doubt that we're going to have problems with access to these doctors. There just aren't going to be enough of them."

The Obama administration is encouraging people to sign up during the final three months of open enrollment, citing progress in addressing issues with the federal exchange website. President Obama emphasized that the law is providing health insurance to those previously unable to get it, stating that thousands of Americans are signing up for coverage every day.

Title: Biden Should Focus on Replacing Trump, Not Engaging with Sanders

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden's decisive win in the latest Democratic debate has led some to suggest that he should focus on engaging with his remaining opponents, particularly Senator Bernie Sanders. However, Biden's strategy should be to emphasize replacing President Trump, which is the unifying message for all of his potential voters.

Biden's debate performance was marked by a disciplined and surgical approach, which allowed him to avoid gaffes and showcase his views. In contrast, Sanders' performance was marred by repetitive and canned answers, making him seem like an "old man past his prime." While Biden won the debate, it was not a scintillating performance, with the two senators engaging in old-man senatorial arguments.

Biden's strategy should be to focus on the imperative of replacing Trump, which is the unifying message for all of his potential voters. He should not try to win over Sanders' supporters, as his historic comeback is due to voters seeing him as a viable alternative to Sanders. Biden will never win over the socialist die-hards and attempting to do so risks losing the suburban moderates who came out for him in droves and giving Trump the line of attack he desperately wants.

Sanders' message has been one of single-issue politics, focusing on issues like healthcare and income inequality. However, in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, voters want to hear more immediate and practical solutions, not ideological ax-grinding. Biden's performance did not fully grasp this dynamic, and he seemed to be under the impression that his top priority is to win over Sanders' voters.

In the past, nominees have tacked to the center once they secured the nomination. However, Biden is not running as a polarizing figure like Barack Obama or Donald Trump. He is running as vanilla ice cream, the most popular flavor not because it's everyone's favorite, but because it's the least objectionable flavor. Letting Sanders pull him leftward would be a huge mistake. Biden should focus on the imperative of replacing Trump, which is the unifying message for all of his potential voters.

Title: Trump Increases Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum from Turkey Amid Diplomatic Tensions

The United States has increased tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Turkey, citing concerns over the country's economic policies and the imprisonment of an American pastor. President Donald Trump announced the decision on Twitter, stating that the tariffs would be doubled, with aluminum duties rising to 20% and steel duties to 50%. The move is seen as a response to Turkey's currency, the lira, sliding against the US dollar.

The tariffs are the latest development in a growing diplomatic crisis between the two nations. The Trump administration had previously imposed sanctions on Turkish officials over the imprisonment of American pastor Andrew Brunson, whom the US considers to be unjustly detained. Turkey accuses Brunson of being a spy and involvement in an attempted coup, while the US claims he is a victim of false charges.

The decision to increase tariffs on Turkish steel and aluminum is seen as a way for the US to exert pressure on Turkey to resolve the Brunson case. However, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has responded defiantly, stating that Turkey will not be intimidated by the US sanctions and will not give in to "threatening language."

The move is also seen as a way for the US to address concerns over Turkey's economic policies, particularly its currency, which has been sliding against the US dollar. The US has previously imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Turkey, citing national security concerns.

The decision has been met with criticism from Turkish officials, who argue that the tariffs are "groundless" and will boomerang back to hurt US companies and consumers. The Turkish trade minister, Ruhsar Pekcan, has called on the US to return to the negotiating table and resolve the issue through dialogue and cooperation.

The diplomatic tensions between the US and Turkey are likely to continue, with the two nations at odds over a range of issues, including the Brunson case and economic policies.

Title: Ellen DeGeneres Defends Friendship with George W. Bush Amid Controversy

Article:

Comedian and TV host Ellen DeGeneres recently sparked controversy when she was spotted attending a Dallas Cowboys game with former President George W. Bush. The pair were seen enjoying the game together, with their respective partners, Portia de Rossi and Laura Bush, also in attendance. The news quickly went viral, with many taking to social media to express their disapproval.

Some critics accused DeGeneres of "rehabilitating" a "war criminal" and "sanitizing" Bush's legacy. Others pointed out that Bush's presidency was marked by controversial decisions, including the invasion of Iraq. DeGeneres addressed the controversy on her show, stating that she is friends with people who don't share her beliefs and that she believes it's okay to disagree with someone without canceling them.

DeGeneres emphasized that her message of "being kind to one another" applies to everyone, regardless of their political beliefs. She believes that it's possible to disagree with someone without being cruel or hurtful. This perspective is a refreshing reminder that, in a world where political differences often lead to division and hostility, it's still possible to find common ground and be civil towards those with whom we disagree.

Title: NSA Releases Declassified Documents on Metadata Collection Programs

The National Security Agency (NSA) has declassified a set of documents related to its metadata collection programs, providing more insight into the agency's procedures and safeguards. The release includes a 17-page ruling from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) outlining minimization procedures, as well as briefing papers from 2009 and 2011.

The documents, which were released in response to a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, provide more information on the NSA's bulk collection of metadata, including phone call and email data, both domestically and internationally. The agency's Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, stated that the release was "in the public interest."

The documents also include two briefing papers to Congress, which outlined the bulk collection of metadata as an "early warning system" that allowed the government to quickly identify links between individuals and terrorism suspects. The papers noted that only a tiny fraction of the collected data is ever viewed by NSA intelligence analysts.

The released documents include redactions, and at first glance, they do not appear to reveal significantly more information than what was previously known through leaked documents provided by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden. However, the briefing documents presented to the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence provide some insight into the legal rationale for the bulk collection of electronic data.

The government explains that the collection of phone metadata is authorized by Section 215 of the USA Patriot Act, and that the program only collects information deemed "not protected by the Fourth Amendment." However, legal scholars and civil libertarians have been waiting for the Judicial Branch's interpretation of the law, which has not been provided.

The FISC order also includes an exception for technical personnel, who are allowed to query the data without adhering to safeguards, but any queried information cannot be used for "intelligence analysis purposes." The release of the documents is expected to continue, and the public is invited to provide feedback and insights in the comments.

Title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Donald Trump's Political Philosophy in Reno Speech

Article: In a speech in Reno, Hillary Clinton launched a scathing attack on her opponent, Donald Trump, accusing him of building his campaign on prejudice and paranoia. She claimed that Trump has taken hate groups mainstream and is helping a radical fringe take over the Republican Party. Clinton's speech was an extended argument that Trump is a racist, a conspiracy theorist, and a man temperamentally unfit to be president.

Clinton's campaign had promoted the speech as an address about Trump and his advisors' embrace of the "alt-right" political philosophy, which is an umbrella term for an assortment of racist micro-movements and online subcultures. However, the alt-right was not the main focus of the speech, with Trump being the primary target. Clinton accused Trump of retweeting white nationalists, making false claims, and having a habit of overstating his accomplishments.

Some of Clinton's arguments were criticized for not making sense, including her claim that Trump's recent remarks about the struggles faced by African Americans were a "dog whistle" to his most hateful supporters. She also overstated the influence of the alt-right, stating that the "de facto merger between Breitbart and the Trump campaign" means the alt-right has "effectively taken over the Republican Party."

Despite the criticisms, Clinton's speech was an attempt to paint Trump as a bigot and a nut, an idea that has been circulating since Trump entered the race. The speech is likely to fire up Clinton's supporters and may even lead some curious conservatives to research the term "alt-right." The speech also gave a boost to Alex Jones, a conspiracy theorist who was mentioned by name and will likely be featured in clips from the speech for a long time.

Title: Republicans and Fox News Seek to Dim Partisan Voices

Article:

The Republican Party and Fox News are taking steps to tone down their loud and partisan voices, which they believe damaged their reputation and credibility in the 2012 election. The party and the network are seeking to distance themselves from controversial figures and messages that may have scared off moderate voters.

Fox News has already ousted contributors Sarah Palin and Dick Morris, two of the most partisan figures on the network. Karl Rove, a former Fox contributor, has started a new super PAC, the Conservative Victory Fund, aimed at supporting more moderate Republican candidates.

Senate Republican leaders have also created a "buddy system" with popular tea party members, Senators Rand Paul and Ted Cruz, to help tame anti-establishment conservatives. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has been warning Republicans that they must stop nominating extreme candidates.

One high-ranking Republican strategist, who wished to remain anonymous, said there is a deliberate effort to "marginalize the cranks, haters, and bigots" within the party. Establishment Republicans see this as a matter of survival, as two consecutive elections have seen extremely conservative candidates blow Senate races that Republicans should have won. For Fox News, it's about credibility, as its ratings have dipped since the election, partly due to conservatives feeling duped by its coverage.

Roger Ailes, Fox News' chairman and CEO, has a politician's sense of his base, Fox viewers. He revolutionized television by tapping into Republican disgust and anger with the mainstream media. However, this strategy has led to the creation of political celebrities, some of whom dominated Republican politics in the 2012 cycle. While ratings were strong, the network had a bumpy election night, capped off by Karl Rove's argument that everyone else was premature in calling Ohio for President Barack Obama.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Retaliation for Christian Massacre

Egypt's military launched a series of airstrikes against ISIS militants in Libya on Monday, targeting training and storage facilities in the city of Derna. The bombing raids were in response to the brutal slaughter of 21 Egyptian Christians by the jihadist group, which was released in a gruesome video on Sunday.

According to Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry, the airstrikes were "surgical strikes based on very accurate intelligence" aimed at degrading ISIS's capabilities in the city. However, an umbrella group of Islamist militias in Derna claimed that the city "woke up to a disaster" as Egyptian military jets targeted civilians in residential areas, killing women and children.

The Egyptian military's actions were condemned by an umbrella group of Islamist militias in Derna, which warned of a "harsh and painful" response to come. The exact extent of the damage and casualties caused by the airstrikes remains unclear.

The Egyptian airstrikes mark the country's involvement in the international fight against ISIS, which has been expanding its presence in North Africa. The group's affiliate in Libya has claimed responsibility for the kidnapping and beheading of the 21 Egyptian Christians, who were from impoverished villages and had gone to Libya in search of work.

The ISIS video, which shows the mass killing of the Egyptian Christians, has sparked international concern about the group's growing reach and influence. The video features masked English-speaking jihadis, including one who threatens Egypt and Europe, and shows the victims being pushed to their knees and crying out for help.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has warned that his country "reserves the right of retaliation and with the methods and timing it sees fit for retribution for those murderers and criminals who are without the slightest humanity." The U.S. government has also condemned the killings, calling ISIS's "barbarity" a "grave threat to regional and global security."

The Egyptian airstrikes come as concerns grow over ISIS's influence in Libya, which has been plagued by a power and security vacuum since the 2011 uprising that overthrew former dictator Moammar Gadhafi. The group has claimed responsibility for a series of attacks in the country, including a deadly attack on a luxury hotel in Tripoli that killed 10 people, including one American.

The extent of ISIS's command and control over its North African affiliates remains unclear, but experts say that the group's ties to its affiliate in Syria and Iraq are well-established. The links between Libyan jihadists and ISIS's precursor, al Qaeda in Iraq, date back a long time, and the group's presence in North Africa presents a "real challenge" for Western leaders.

Title: Trump to Meet with Congressional Leaders, Business Executives, and Union Leaders in First Week in Office

Article:

Washington, D.C. - President Donald Trump is set to meet with congressional leaders from both parties to discuss his agenda, as he begins his first official week in the White House. Trump has said that Monday marks his first real day in office, and he is packing his schedule with meetings to focus on jobs and national security.

The president's day is filled with a breakfast and listening session with business leaders, followed by a meeting with union leaders and workers, and a reception with members of Congress. He will also hold his first meeting as president with the Speaker of the House, Paul Ryan.

Trump's outreach effort comes after a tumultuous first weekend in the White House, which included criticism of news organizations for reporting on the size of his inauguration crowds and mass protests against his presidency. On Sunday, Trump delivered a more unifying message, urging Americans to put aside their differences and work together.

In a swearing-in ceremony for his top aides, Trump warned of the challenges ahead but expressed confidence in his team's ability to overcome them. "With faith in each other and faith in God, we will get the job done," he said.

Trump also met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accepted an invitation to visit the White House in early February. The prime minister expressed hope for a "common vision" with the newly inaugurated U.S. president, which could include expanded settlement construction and a tougher policy toward Iran.

Trump also announced meetings with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, with discussions expected to focus on NAFTA, immigration, and security at the border. He has promised to build a wall along the southern border and insisted that Mexico will pay for it.

Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, said the president plans to spend his first full week in office undoing some of former President Barack Obama's agenda and signing executive orders on immigration and trade. However, it is unclear which executive orders Trump will sign on Monday.

Title: Actress Eva Longoria Advocates for Immigration Reform as Top Priority in Obama's Second Term

Actress Eva Longoria, a prominent supporter of President Obama and a co-chair of his reelection campaign, has emphasized the importance of immigration reform as a top priority in his second term. In an interview, Longoria highlighted the need for a comprehensive overhaul of the current immigration system, stating that it is "a very broken system" and that people are often unaware of the numerous lines and processes involved.

Longoria, who has been labeled a "Hispanic activist and power player in Washington, D.C." by the Wall Street Journal, has been a vocal supporter of the President and has taken center stage at the Democratic National Convention. She is also an executive producer and host of the Latino Inaugural, a concert featuring performances by several artists, and a co-chair of the Presidential Inauguration Committee.

Longoria emphasized that immigration reform is not only a moral imperative but also an economic one, citing the importance of the agricultural industry and the need for a reliable labor force. She believes that both Republicans and Democrats can find common ground on the issue and that it is a matter of "economic imperative" for the country.

The actress also acknowledged the historic mobilization of the Latino vote in the recent election and believes that Republicans will come to realize the political benefits of addressing the issue. She plans to remain politically active but has ruled out running for office in her home state of Texas, stating that it is a "very big job" and not her "day job."

Title: President Obama Issues Executive Order on Guns and Background Checks: A Look at the Legalities

Article:

President Obama has issued an executive order aimed at strengthening background checks and gun control measures in the United States. The order requires occasional sellers of firearms to become federal licensees and imposes reporting requirements on physicians. However, experts argue that the president's actions may be unconstitutional and could be challenged in court.

An executive order is a written instruction to the executive branch of the federal government, informing them of the manner in which the president wants federal laws or regulations enforced. However, executive orders do not direct private individuals or persons in the legislative or judicial branches of government. They remain in effect until abandoned or rescinded by the president who issued them or by a successor president.

The president's order addresses the requirement for background checks in occasional sales and the requirement that occasional sellers become federal licensees. However, Congress has explicitly exempted occasional sales from the obligation of obtaining federal licenses and conducting background checks. The president's attempt to negate congressional will on this issue may be invalidated by the courts.

The order also requires physicians to report conversations with patients about guns to the Department of Homeland Security. This move has raised concerns about the government invading the patient-physician privilege. The Supreme Court has made it clear that the right to keep and bear arms is a fundamental liberty, and any attempt to restrict it must be done through due process.

The Constitution grants Congress the power to write laws, the president the power to enforce them, and the courts the power to interpret them. The president cannot write his own laws or impose his own interpretations upon them. The courts will likely ignore the president's interpretation and impose their own.

In conclusion, the president's executive order on guns and background checks may be challenged in court and may be deemed unconstitutional. The Constitution grants Congress the power to regulate firearms, and any attempts to restrict the right to bear arms must be done through due process.

Title: NASA Launches Parker Solar Probe to Explore Sun's Corona

NASA has successfully launched its Parker Solar Probe, a spacecraft designed to explore the Sun's corona, the outer atmosphere of our star. The probe, named after astrophysicist Eugene Parker, who first described solar wind in 1958, is set to become the fastest-moving man-made object in history.

The Delta-IV Heavy rocket carrying the probe lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, at 03:31 local time (07:31 GMT) after a failed attempt the previous day due to a last-minute alarm. The spacecraft successfully separated and was released into space just under an hour after launch.

The Parker Solar Probe aims to dip directly into the Sun's corona, studying the physics of this region, which is believed to be the source of many solar phenomena that affect Earth. Over the course of seven years, the probe will make 24 loops around the Sun, sampling conditions and getting as close as 6.16 million kilometers (3.83 million miles) from the Sun's surface.

Dr. Nicky Fox, the UK-born project scientist affiliated with the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, explained that the probe will be traveling at speeds of up to 430,000mph (690,000km/h), making it the fastest man-made object ever. To put that into perspective, it would be equivalent to traveling from New York to Tokyo in under a minute.

The mission promises to crack longstanding mysteries about the Sun's behavior and provide valuable insights into the solar wind, which affects Earth's magnetic field and climate. The data collected by the Parker Solar Probe will help scientists better understand the Sun's impact on our planet and improve predictions of space weather events.

Title: Reporters Committee Urges Court to Quash Subpoena Demanding News Outlets Hand Over Protest Footage

The Reporters Committee, a non-profit organization that advocates for journalists' rights, has filed a friend-of-the-court brief with the King County Superior Court, urging the court to quash a subpoena requiring Seattle news outlets to turn over video and photographs from a May protest. The Seattle Police Department served five news organizations with subpoenas earlier this month, demanding they hand over all raw footage and photographs taken within a several-block radius over a 90-minute period during the May 30 protest.

The police are seeking the footage to help identify suspects involved in the torching of a police car and theft of firearms. The Reporters Committee argues that compelling journalists to share materials acquired during newsgathering violates the Washington shield law and the First Amendment. The brief also raises concerns that enforcement of the subpoena could lead to further violence against journalists, as some protesters have already begun to view journalists as being associated with the police.

The brief notes that protests are already the most dangerous place for journalists, and enforcement of the subpoena could further erode public trust in the news media and increase the risk of physical harm to journalists. The Reporters Committee regularly files friend-of-the-court briefs and represents journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases involving First Amendment freedoms, newsgathering rights, and access to public information.

Title: Morgan Stanley's Wilson Sees Similarities Between Current Market and 2009 Recovery

Article:

Morgan Stanley's head of U.S. equity strategy, Michael Wilson, believes the current stock market is mirroring the recovery period of 2009, when the S&P 500 index began its longest bull-market run in history. Wilson notes that stocks have rebounded in a similar pattern, with small-capitalization stocks, typically leading the way, and the number of individual stocks trading above their 200-day moving average increasing.

One key similarity between the two periods is the equity-risk premium, which measures the expected earnings yield for the S&P 500 minus the 10-year Treasury yield. According to Wilson, this premium has reached similar levels observed in March 2009, a key indicator of a potential market bottom. He believes that when the risk premium appears, investors should "grab it before it disappears," as it can fall when bond prices fall and interest rates rise or when equity prices rise, reducing their expected return.

While traditional cyclical stocks like small-caps have outperformed recently, financial stocks have not. Wilson attributes this to the Federal Reserve's stimulus, which has repressed government bond yields, scaring bank investors. He believes the market is underestimating the chances of longer-term bond yields rising significantly as the economy rebounds from the coronavirus, which could lead to a huge rally in financial-sector stocks.

Wilson points to Congress passing at least $3 trillion in fiscal stimulus, the potential for a faster and more sustained recovery in the post-coronavirus economy, and unexpected inflation as catalysts for higher inflation and long-term interest rates. He believes that while these are hypothetical possibilities, they are worth considering given current levels of inflation and 10-year Treasury yields.

Title: Key Democrats and Labor Unions Remain Neutral in Democratic Primary

The Democratic presidential primary is heating up, with Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders vying for the nomination. However, some key Democrats and labor unions are choosing to remain neutral, refusing to endorse either candidate. According to reports, President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden, and top Democrats in Congress, including Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, have not publicly endorsed either Clinton or Sanders.

Additionally, Richard Trumka, the head of the AFL-CIO, has praised both Sanders and Biden, but has not taken a stance on the primary. Governor Jerry Brown, who challenged Bill Clinton for the nomination in 1992, has also remained neutral, although he has spoken warmly of Hillary Clinton in recent months.

In contrast, Clinton has received endorsements from 145 House members, 38 senators who caucus with Democrats, 12 governors, and 17 national unions, according to her campaign. Sanders, on the other hand, has been endorsed by two members of Congress and three labor groups.

It remains to be seen whether these key Democrats and labor unions will eventually take a stance on the primary, or if they will continue to remain neutral as the race continues to unfold.

Title: Trump Denies Agreement with Julian Assange, Blames Media for Perception

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has denied any agreement with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, stating that the media is to blame for any perception that he has taken the side of the whistleblower. In a series of tweets, Trump claimed that the media is "dishonest" and that he is simply stating what Assange says, leaving it up to the public to decide what is true.

Trump's comments come after he cited Assange in a tweet, saying that the WikiLeaks founder believed a 14-year-old could have hacked into the email account of Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta. Trump also stated that Assange said the Russians did not provide him with the information, which has led to speculation that he may be more inclined to believe Assange's claims over those of the U.S. intelligence community.

However, Trump's stance on WikiLeaks has changed significantly since 2010, when he expressed strong disapproval of the website and its founder. At the time, Trump told Fox News that the release of classified information by WikiLeaks was "disgraceful" and that those responsible should face severe punishment.

Trump's willingness to cite Assange has sparked concerns among some lawmakers, including Senator Tim Kaine, who ran against Trump as Hillary Clinton's running mate. Kaine expressed shock that Trump would cite Assange and questioned whether the president-elect is receiving accurate intelligence briefings. Kaine, a member of the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations committees, stated that the intelligence community has concluded that Russia sought to aid Trump's campaign, and that Trump's refusal to accept this assessment is "unusual" and "suspicious."

The president-elect is scheduled to receive a briefing on Friday from the nation's top intelligence officials outlining the government's evidence blaming Russia for the cyberattacks. Trump had previously stated that the briefing was delayed, but a U.S. official disputed this claim, saying it was always scheduled for Friday.

Title: Obama's National Security Legacy: Balancing Surveillance and Privacy

The Obama administration's approach to national security has been a topic of debate, with some critics arguing that the president has not done enough to reform the intelligence community, while others believe he has gone too far in expanding surveillance programs. Michael Allen, a former Bush aide and author of "Blinking Red," a book on the creation of the intelligence architecture after the 9/11 attacks, expressed concerns that President Obama may be too quick to make major changes to the country's national security policies.

Allen, now managing director of Beacon Global Strategies, stated that the pressure to reform the intelligence community may lead Obama to make decisions that could put the country at risk. He believes that the president may be tempted to make a "major course correction" without fully considering the implications.

When Obama took office, he inherited the Bush administration's counterterrorism program, which had already undergone some changes. The new president made some adjustments, but kept much of the program intact, including drone strikes. His thinking was shaped by a foiled terrorist plot during his first presidential Christmas in Hawaii.

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican critic, believes that Obama is more authoritarian on privacy issues than his predecessor, citing the disclosures about NSA programs as more alarming than he had anticipated. White House officials reject these characterizations, but the momentum to revamp NSA rules comes at a time when Obama faces other decisions on how much to shift course.

The president is also being pressured to support the release of a comprehensive Senate report on the history of interrogations and torture, as well as scaling back drone strikes. Admiral Dennis C. Blair, Obama's first director of national intelligence, believes that the president should take a deeper look at national security policies beyond simply surveillance. He argues that the administration's approach is a "small-ball play" and that what is needed is a debate about the level of security versus privacy.

Title: Obama Escalates Efforts to Achieve Policy Goals Without Congressional Approval

President Barack Obama has intensified his efforts to accomplish his policy goals without winning approval from Congress, a strategy that may produce results quickly but carries the risk of being undone by lawmakers or a future president. The latest example is his policy to shield more than four million illegal immigrants from deportation, announced on Thursday. The White House has also explored options to allow the president to close the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay without Congressional approval.

The president has long promised to press ahead on his agenda with or without lawmakers' support, but the new actions are more sweeping in scope than earlier moves, such as raising the minimum wage for federal contractors. The strategy comes with risks, as Republican lawmakers have raised the specter of trying to undo the president's actions, and a future president could reverse some of his moves on immigration and climate change.

Some Republicans have warned that the president's decision to sidestep lawmakers could diminish the chances of forging agreements with Republican leaders on other issues. Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said, "We've stopped having a constitutional system of checks and balances that's protected our liberty. It's the power of a monarch or an emperor." He suggested that Republicans in the Senate respond to the president's actions on immigration by blocking his nominees.

In an interview, President Obama said, "What the American people expect is that if we disagree on one thing...then we work on everything else." Some Republicans have suggested that the party should respond to Mr. Obama by taking the reins on policy and passing GOP-sponsored immigration bills, although it remains unclear what policy the party would put forward and whether Mr. Obama would sign on.

The president has also announced an aggressive climate deal with China, laid out limits on power-plant emissions, and pursued nuclear negotiations with Iran. The White House has discussed ways to override a congressional ban on bringing detainees to the U.S. to close the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

While the president has said he wants to work with Congress, he and his advisers have recently struck a more defiant tone about Mr. Obama's powers to act on his own. The president has said he has an answer for lawmakers who question his authority on immigration: "Nobody is stopping them from passing a bill."

Title: Republican Party Confronts Unlikely Challenger in Trump's Rise

The Republican Party is facing an unprecedented challenge as Donald Trump's presidential campaign gains momentum, driven by his appeal to downscale voters who feel neglected by the party's traditional elite. According to Laura Ingraham, a conservative activist and talk-radio host, the party's leaders are reluctant to acknowledge the unpopularity of their policies.

The 2010 Supreme Court decision in the Citizens United case has given wealthy donors increased influence in Republican circles, despite signs that downscale voters are demanding more representation. Trump's campaign has tapped into this sentiment, promising to expand Social Security, refuse big donors' money, and protect American workers from foreign competition.

The Democratic Party is also grappling with its own populist insurgency, driven by economic pain and anger towards Washington and Wall Street. While Senator Bernie Sanders trails Hillary Clinton in delegates, Trump's campaign has become a seemingly unstoppable force, catching Republican lawmakers, donors, and activists off guard.

Foster Friess, a Wyoming investor and philanthropist, believes the Republican Party has neglected the people who truly make the country work, such as truck drivers, farmers, welders, and hospitality workers. Six years ago, Republicans celebrated an impending repudiation of President Obama in congressional races, but the party's leaders are now facing an unexpected challenger in Trump's rise.

Paul Singer, a billionaire investor and host of a 2010 fund-raiser for Republican Senate candidates, had publicly lamented "indiscriminate attacks by political leaders against anything that moves in the world of finance." In 2010, Singer tripled his campaign giving, doling out almost $3 million in contributions to Republicans.

**Mueller Recommends Up to Six Months in Jail for Former Trump Aide George Papadopoulos**

Special counsel Robert Mueller has recommended that a judge sentence former Donald Trump campaign aide George Papadopoulos to up to six months in jail for lying to the FBI. The recommendation comes after Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to charges of making false statements to investigators about his contacts with a professor who had connections to Russian government officials.

According to court documents, Papadopoulos repeatedly withheld key details about his contacts with Russians and neglected to turn over his cell phone until the government explicitly asked for it. The government argues that Papadopoulos' lies negatively affected the FBI's Russia investigation and prevented the agency from effectively identifying and confronting witnesses in a timely fashion.

Papadopoulos' wife, Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos, has been vocal about her husband's cooperation with the investigation, stating that federal authorities have ignored evidence favorable to her husband. She has also suggested that her husband may have been the target of an entrapment scheme.

The government's sentencing recommendation includes clear signs that the Mueller team felt betrayed by Papadopoulos after he struck a plea agreement and pledged his full cooperation. The filing says Papadopoulos repeatedly withheld key details about his contacts with Russians and neglected to turn over the cell phone he used to communicate with the professor until the government expressly asked for it.

Papadopoulos' legal team will file their own sentencing assessment to the court in two weeks and is expected to ask for probation. The sentence recommendation comes as Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos has mounted a publicity campaign suggesting her husband has misgivings about his plea agreement.

Title: Judge Brett Kavanaugh's Ruling on Illegal Immigrant Abortion Case Sparks Controversy

Article:

Judge Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's nominee to the Supreme Court, has been at the center of a heated controversy surrounding his opinions on a case involving an illegal immigrant teenager seeking an abortion. The case, known as Garza v. Hargan, has sparked intense debate among pro-life and pro-choice activists.

The case involved a 17-year-old girl, identified as Jane Doe, who was held in government custody after being brought to the United States as part of the surge of Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC). After being given a medical exam, she was found to be pregnant and sought an abortion. However, the Trump administration delayed the procedure, citing its interest in protecting the fetus.

A lower court ruled in favor of the girl, but Judge Kavanaugh, who authored key opinions in the case, sided with the government, overturning the lower court's decision. The full D.C. Circuit later overturned the three-judge panel, ruling that illegal immigrants have a right to abortion and that the Trump administration's efforts to delay the procedure were unconstitutional.

Judge Kavanaugh penned a dissent, stating that the majority had broken with 40 years of Supreme Court precedent to establish a new right for unlawful immigrant minors in U.S. government detention to obtain immediate abortion on demand. He argued that the majority's decision represented a radical extension of the Supreme Court's abortion jurisprudence.

The Supreme Court ultimately erased the lower court's opinion, ruling that since Jane Doe had already obtained an abortion, there was no longer a live controversy and therefore no precedent. The ruling has left activists on both sides furious.

Senator Kamala Harris, a Democrat from California, expressed her opposition to Judge Kavanaugh's nomination, stating that he disregarded Supreme Court precedent and opposed the healthcare rights of a vulnerable young woman. The American Family Association also expressed concerns over Judge Kavanaugh's ruling, finding it not strong enough against abortion rights.

On the other hand, the Rev. Frank Pavone, national director of Priests for Life, expressed delight at Judge Kavanaugh's selection, while the Susan B. Anthony List, a major pro-life advocacy group, praised Judge Kavanaugh's decisions in both the Garza and Priests for Life cases, stating that he rejected the ACLU's assertion of a constitutional right to abortion on demand for illegal immigrants.

The controversy surrounding Judge Kavanaugh's opinions on this case highlights the ongoing debate over abortion rights and the role of the Supreme Court in shaping those rights.

Title: Deficit Reduction Goals: A Modest Approach or a Path to Fiscal Peril?

The article discusses the recent deficit reduction goals set by some on the left, which aim to stabilize the federal debt at around 70% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by 2022. While this goal may seem modest, it is far from sufficient to ensure a stable fiscal future. The article argues that a more aggressive approach is needed to reduce the deficit and prevent a sovereign debt crisis.

According to the article, the current deficit reduction plan would require combined reductions in spending growth and/or increases in taxes of $1.4 trillion over the 2014-2022 period, which is significantly less than the total deficit reduction provided by the 2011 Budget Control Act (BCA) and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2013 (ATRA). The article suggests that this goal is too modest and may leave the country facing a debt-GDP ratio above 70% in the future.

The article also highlights the risks associated with a debt-GDP ratio above 70%, particularly in the event of a recession. It notes that the deficit associated with stabilizing the debt-GDP ratio at 70% is more than 10% higher than that consistent with a 60% ratio, which is the limit chosen by the drafters of the Maastricht treaty that created the Euro.

The article also discusses the potential risks of defense spending cuts, as well as the need for true reforms in Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. It notes that the BCA excludes Social Security and Medicaid from cuts and includes only modest reductions in payments to Medicare providers.

Overall, the article argues that a more aggressive approach to deficit reduction is necessary to ensure a stable fiscal future and prevent a sovereign debt crisis.

Title: Supreme Court's Biggest Abortion Case in a Decade to Proceed Without Scalia's Influence

The upcoming Supreme Court case challenging Texas's abortion restrictions will likely be impacted by the absence of Justice Antonin Scalia, who passed away over the weekend. The case, which involves a Texas law requiring doctors to have local hospital admitting privileges and clinics to make costly building upgrades, was expected to receive a fifth vote from Scalia to uphold the restrictions. Without him, the court may not see a significant change, as a 4-4 split would maintain the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals' ruling upholding the provisions.

The absence of Scalia's vote may not have a significant impact on Texas, as the 4-4 split would leave the current restrictions in place. However, it would mean that other appeals court rulings striking down similar laws would also stand. Ilyse Hogue of NARAL Pro-Choice America notes that this could lead to the closure of several clinics that perform abortions, leaving some women to travel hundreds of miles to obtain the procedure.

The vacancy left by Scalia's death has broader implications for reproductive rights, with many cases challenging abortion restrictions and other reproductive rights issues pending before the court. Abortion opponents had hoped to have these restrictions affirmed by the Supreme Court, with Scalia's support. Clarke Forsythe, senior counsel with Americans United for Life, notes that Scalia was one of the two justices who had publicly opposed Roe v. Wade in prior cases and votes.

With the possibility of a liberal majority on the court, Forsythe foresees a potential rolling back of decades of abortion restrictions, including the Hyde Amendment, which bans public funding for the procedure. He also predicts that a liberal court would overturn parental notice and consent laws, informed consent laws, and virtually any regulation, creating an absolute right to abortion for any reason at any time.

Abortion rights groups, however, view these predictions as speculation. Both sides of the contentious issue are now focused on the fierce battle over choosing Scalia's replacement.

Title: Census Bureau Reports Significant Income Growth and Poverty Rate Decline in 2015

The United States Census Bureau has released its annual estimates of Americans' incomes and poverty rates, revealing a significant increase in median household income and a decline in the poverty rate. According to the report, the typical household saw a 5.2% increase in real terms, or $2,800, in 2015. This growth was concentrated at the bottom of the income distribution, with those at the 10th percentile experiencing a 7.9% increase, compared to a 3.7% growth for those at the 95th percentile.

The report also shows that the poverty rate fell from 14.8% to 13.5%, with 3.5 million fewer people falling under the poverty threshold. However, the official poverty rate is considered flawed by many economists, as it does not account for important social programs like the earned income tax credit (EITC) and food stamps, and is based on the price of food in 1955.

A more accurate measure of poverty, the supplemental poverty measure (SPM), shows a decline of 1 percentage point, from 15.3% to 14.3%. According to the SPM, 45.7 million people were in poverty in 2015, 2.7 million fewer than in 2014. Government programs, particularly Social Security retirement and disability insurance and refundable tax credits like the EITC, played a significant role in keeping the poverty rate down.

The report also covers health insurance, with the ongoing rollout of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) continuing to drive a decline in uninsured rates. The rate for 2015 was 9.1%, and more recent federal data shows that the rate fell even further to 8.6% in the first quarter of 2016, the lowest on record. The decline in uninsurance was concentrated in states that participated in the ACA's Medicaid expansion, but even non-expanding states saw some declines.

Overall, the report suggests that the gains of the ongoing economic recovery are finally being broadly shared, with income growth concentrated at the bottom of the income distribution and a decline in poverty rates. While it would take a lot of reports like this to reverse longstanding trends in income inequality and poor median income growth, the news is still encouraging.

Title: Netanyahu's Visit to the US: A Platform for Discussion and Debate

Article:

The recent visit of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to the United States has sparked a heated debate, with some viewing it as a chance for the two nations to strengthen their alliance, while others see it as a divisive and provocative move. The controversy surrounding Netanyahu's visit has brought attention to the complex and often contentious issues surrounding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Netanyahu's speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) highlighted the importance of the US-Israel relationship, which has been a cornerstone of American foreign policy for decades. He emphasized the shared values and interests between the two nations, as well as the need for continued cooperation to address regional and global challenges.

However, some critics have accused Netanyahu of using his visit to undermine the US government's efforts to broker a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians. Others have expressed concern that his presence in the US could further polarize the debate on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and undermine the prospects for a lasting peace.

The visit has also brought to light the complex and often fraught history of the US-Israel relationship. Netanyahu's speech touched on the three occasions when Israel had to take matters into its own hands to ensure its survival, despite American misgivings. These instances included Israel's declaration of statehood in 1948, its actions during the Six Day War in 1967, and its bombing of the nuclear reactor at Osirak in 1981.

The visit has also sparked questions about the role of the US in the Middle East and the extent to which it should be involved in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Some have argued that the US should take a more active role in brokering a peace deal, while others believe that the US should maintain its traditional policy of supporting Israel's right to self-defense.

Ultimately, the visit of Benjamin Netanyahu to the US has highlighted the complexity and nuance of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as well as the importance of continued dialogue and cooperation between the two nations.

Title: World Bank Warns of Global Economic Uncertainty Amid European Turmoil

The World Bank has released its latest forecast, painting a picture of a global economy beset by uncertainty and volatility. According to the report, the bank's predictions are slightly more pessimistic than those of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which foresees growth of 3.5 percent in 2012 and 4.1 percent in 2013.

The report notes that the global outlook brightened earlier in 2012, as European leaders promised to devote more money to address their crisis and implement policy changes to unite the continent. As a result, European bond yields fell and investment ticked up. However, the calm has since dissipated, with investors returning to punishing European bonds and pushing Spain to request a bailout for its faltering banks.

The World Bank warns that market fluctuations are likely to be common in the post-crisis period and will have global implications. "Sharp swings in investor sentiment and financial conditions will continue to complicate the conduct of macro policy in developing countries," the report states.

Despite the uncertainty, the bank predicts that Europe will muddle through its sovereign debt crisis without a market catastrophe, and the world will maintain its lackluster but steady growth path. However, economists at the World Bank, like most forecasters, have failed to foresee crises in the past and are warning of significant uncertainties ahead.

The report urges developing countries to prepare for market turbulence by strengthening their balance sheets, such as by cutting deficits and reducing short-term debt exposures. The bank notes that about 40 percent of developing countries were running a surplus in 2007, before the global downturn began, but last year, just 19 percent were.

The World Bank's economists also emphasize that while Europe may pose a short-term threat to middle- and lower-income countries, their prospects and growth trajectories remain strong in the long term. In the case of China, growth is expected to come largely from within the country and other poorer but fast-growing economies.

The report also warns that high-income countries are not making the necessary changes to ensure their economies will be competitive, prolonging their periods of economic malaise and losing ground to the rest of the world. The bank urges countries to reduce long-term deficits, make certain industries more competitive, or invest in infrastructure.

The International Monetary Fund's managing director, Christine Lagarde, also warned of a global growth slowdown and renewed threats to financial markets, urging "very accommodating monetary policy," "direct support to banks," and "growth-friendly" fiscal policies.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Surges in Presidential Polls, Narrowly Leading Joe Biden

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has taken the top spot in several recent national presidential primary polls, surpassing former Vice President Joe Biden. According to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Tuesday, Warren leads Biden 29% to 26%, with Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont coming in third at 16%. The poll found that Warren maintains her strength across various demographics, including men and women, and holds a 12-percentage-point lead among white voters.

Warren's rise in the polls comes as she has consistently performed well in early primary states, including Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada. A Des Moines Register/CNN/Mediacom Iowa Poll found her leading in the first-in-the-nation caucus state, while a Monmouth University poll put her narrowly ahead of Biden in New Hampshire. A Suffolk University/███ Network Poll released on September 24 placed her just 4 points behind Biden in Nevada.

Biden, however, still maintains a comfortable lead in South Carolina, the fourth state on the primary calendar, according to a recent Fox News poll. The former vice president's drop in the polls comes as President Donald Trump and his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani have mounted a public campaign accusing Biden of impropriety in Ukraine during his time in office.

The Quinnipiac poll also found that voters approve of the impeachment inquiry, with 53% supporting it and 43% opposing it. The poll also showed that 45% of voters believe Trump should be removed from office, while 49% do not.

Despite the controversy surrounding Biden, both Warren and Biden would beat Trump in a hypothetical election, according to the Quinnipiac poll. Warren would win by a margin of 49% to 41%, while Biden would win by a margin of 51% to 40%.

Trump indirectly acknowledged Warren's rise in the polls in a tweet, calling on Hillary Clinton to "enter the race to try and steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren."

Title: Trump Campaign Workers Face Resistance in Federal Agencies, Report Says

A growing number of Donald Trump's campaign workers are struggling to secure permanent positions in federal agencies, according to a recent report by Politico. The "originals," as they call themselves, claim they are being pushed aside and targeted by damaging leaks, which has led to some quitting their jobs.

The campaign staffers, who were placed in agencies on Inauguration Day to help with the presidential transition, are often referred to as the "beachhead" team. However, about a dozen members of this team at the U.S. Agriculture Department have been told their jobs will not be permanent, and similar notifications have been made at the Treasury and Transportation departments, according to CBS News.

Some Cabinet secretaries have privately expressed frustration with having to take on employees with little or no relevant expertise, Politico reported. In contrast, the Trump loyalists argue they are being unfairly targeted and dismissed.

Sid Bowdidge, a former Trump campaign staffer who quit his Energy Department job, blamed rival coworkers for leaking damaging information about him, including reports of anti-Muslim slurs on social media. He expressed concerns about the impact of this kind of behavior on the team's ability to work together towards a common goal.

As the distance from Inauguration Day grows, some former campaign aides feel they are being abandoned and left to fend for themselves. "The swamp is winning the battle," said one former campaign aide. "And longtime campaign staffers are proving to be the first casualties."

Title: Trump Denies Firing Comey Over Russia Investigation, Despite Contrary Evidence

Article:

President Donald Trump has denied firing FBI Director James Comey due to the Russia investigation, despite video and documentary evidence suggesting otherwise. In a tweet, Trump stated, "Not that it matters but I never fired James Comey because of Russia!" He also claimed that the media is pushing a false narrative and that he would have fired Comey regardless of the Russia investigation.

However, Trump's statement contradicts his own words from two days after the May 9, 2017, dismissal, when he told NBC News that he would have taken the same action even without Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein's recommendation, citing Russia as a reason. Trump also told NBC's Lester Holt that he believed the Russia investigation was a "made-up story" and an excuse by the Democrats for losing the 2016 election.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., responded to Trump's tweet, saying, "Let's go to the videotape." The tweet referred to a memo authored by former Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe, which quotes Rosenstein as saying that Trump asked him to mention Russia as a reason for recommending Comey's dismissal. However, the memo only referred to Comey's overall management of the FBI, including his handling of the Hillary Clinton private email server case.

The day after Comey's firing, Trump reportedly told Russian diplomats that he had fired the FBI director because of pressure from Russia. Trump and his aides also claimed that Comey privately told the president he was not the subject of an investigation, but would not say that publicly. Comey has said he believes he was fired because he rebuffed Trump's request to go easy on a central figure in the Russia probe, former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn.

The FBI director's firing is central to an obstruction of justice investigation being conducted by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is also investigating Russian attempts to influence the 2016 election in order to help Trump.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Nadler Discusses Plans to Uncover Special Counsel Mueller's Findings

The House Judiciary Committee Chairman, Jerrold Nadler, appeared on ABC's This Week, where he discussed the committee's plans to uncover the results of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe. Nadler stated that Democrats will request documents from 60 people, including Donald Trump Jr. and Trump Organization chief financial officer Allan Weisselberg, as part of investigations into obstruction of justice, corruption, and abuse of power.

Nadler emphasized that the committee's goal is to gather evidence and convince the American public that impeachment is necessary. He noted that before impeachment proceedings can begin, the committee must persuade Trump supporters that it is the right course of action. "We do not now have the evidence all sorted out to do an impeachment," Nadler said. "Before you impeach somebody, you have to persuade the American people that it ought to happen."

The chairman also expressed his desire for the public and Congress to see the evidence uncovered by the special counsel, including information about Russian meddling in the 2016 campaign. He stated that the committee will subpoena the information if the Justice Department keeps it under wraps. "We do want the underlying evidence," Nadler said. "The American people are entitled to know."

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, however, dismissed the Democrats' efforts as a "fishing expedition" and claimed that they will latch onto any evidence they can find to impeach the president. "There's no collusion, so they want to build something else," McCarthy said.

Nadler responded by stating that the committee is conducting due diligence after Michael Cohen, Trump's former attorney and "fixer," implicated the president in crimes, including pay-offs to a porn actress Stormy Daniels on the cusp of the 2016 election. "Seeking to sabotage a fair election would be an impeachable offense," Nadler said. "We'll see about that, but we're far from making decisions about that."

McCarthy countered that Cohen, as an attorney, had a responsibility to advise Trump on the law and that any violations would not be impeachable.

Title: Trump Administration Freezes Obamacare Payments, Sparking Industry Backlash

The Trump administration announced on Saturday that it is temporarily freezing billions of dollars in payments to health insurance companies intended to help them manage higher-risk patients. The decision has sparked backlash from the insurance industry, which is already struggling to adjust to the administration's repeated attacks on Obamacare.

The federal government provides risk adjustment payments to insurers to cushion them from taking steep losses on high-risk patients in the Obamacare marketplace. The government paid out over $10 billion in these payments in 2017. However, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) announced the abrupt halt of these payments, citing a February 2018 ruling from the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico that invalidates them.

CMS Administrator Seema Verma stated, "We were disappointed by the court's recent ruling. As a result of this litigation, billions of dollars in risk adjustment payments and collections are now on hold. CMS has asked the court to reconsider its ruling and hopes for a prompt resolution that allows CMS to prevent more adverse impacts on Americans who receive their insurance in the individual and small group markets."

The insurance industry is already speaking out against the administration's decision, calling it a crucial blow during a time when insurance companies are trying to come up with premiums and packages for 2019. America's Health Insurance Plans (AHIP) stated, "We are very discouraged by the new market disruption brought about by the decision to freeze risk adjustment payments. This decision comes at a critical time when insurance providers are developing premiums for 2019 and states are reviewing rates. We encourage the Administration to reevaluate its decision and work with all stakeholders to make health care more affordable for all Americans."

Insurers themselves are voicing concerns for market destabilization following the announcement. Blue Cross Blue Shield Association President and CEO Scott Serota stated, "This action will significantly increase 2019 premiums for millions of individuals and small business owners and could result in far fewer health plan choices. It will undermine Americans' access to affordable coverage, particularly those who need medical care the most."

The Trump administration's decision to freeze Obamacare payments is the latest in a series of moves intended to undermine the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The president has rolled back funding for a program intended to help individuals navigate the insurance marketplace, signed an executive order to allow for groups to purchase insurance across state lines, stopped federal funding for Obamacare subsidies, pushed for consumer access to more affordable short-term, limited-duration health insurance plans, cut Obamacare's open enrollment period in half and its advertising budget 90 percent.

Despite the administration's efforts to repeal and replace Obamacare, the president has been unable to materialize that goal. House Republicans passed a bill, the American Health Care Act, in May 2017, but Senate Republicans were unable to pass a repeal and replace bill.

Title: US Ambassador to EU Gordon Sondland Recalled, Lt. Col. Vindman Ousted from White House Job

The United States Ambassador to the European Union, Gordon Sondland, has been recalled by President Donald Trump, effective immediately. This move comes hours after Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, another witness in the impeachment inquiry, was ousted from his White House job with the National Security Council.

In a statement, Sondland expressed gratitude to Trump for the opportunity to serve and acknowledged his recall. Sondland testified during the House impeachment inquiry that "everyone was in the loop" about an effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic presidential candidate Joseph R. Biden, an allegation at the heart of Democrats' impeachment case against the president.

Sondland's recall and Vindman's ouster have sparked criticism from Democratic lawmakers, who view the moves as political retaliation. Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon tweeted that "firing Ambassador Sondland and a hero like LTC Vindman for telling the truth is yet more abuse of power by the president." Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey called the ousters "clear political retaliation, the likes of which is seen only in authoritarian countries around the world."

On the other hand, Tom Fitton, an ally of the president who heads the watchdog group Judicial Watch, called the personnel moves "cleaning house." Senator Marco Rubio of Florida noted that Sondland is a political appointee who serves at the pleasure of the president and that Lt. Col. Vindman was not "fired," but rather reassigned as an Army officer.

The controversy surrounding Sondland's recall and Vindman's ouster highlights the ongoing tensions surrounding the impeachment inquiry and the president's handling of the situation.

Title: Unintended Consequences of the Affordable Care Act: A Shift in Employment and Healthcare

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has been criticized by Republican strategist Karl Rove for having several negative unintended consequences. In a recent opinion piece in the Wall Street Journal, Rove highlights the impact of the ACA on employment and healthcare.

According to Rove, the ACA requires companies with at least 50 workers to provide health insurance to employees who work more than 30 hours a week or pay a fine. This has led to a decline in the number of hourly employees working 30-34 hours a week, with a decrease of 146,500 per month over the past year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Conversely, the number of employees working 25-29 hours per week has increased by 119,000 per month.

Rove argues that this shift in employment patterns particularly affects single working mothers and younger workers. Additionally, the 50-employee threshold may discourage businesses from growing beyond that size, potentially stifling economic growth.

The ACA also affects businesses with self-funded health plans, which serve as their own insurer, gathering premiums and paying claims filed by their workers. According to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey, 61% of workers are in self-funded plans. Rove claims that the ACA's regulations will make it less attractive for companies to maintain these plans, as they will be subject to the same rules as fully insured plans. This could lead to increased costs and reduced options for employees.

Rove also notes that some states, such as Delaware, New York, and Oregon, have already prohibited small- and mid-size companies from using self-insurance plans. He expresses concern that the new Labor Secretary, Thomas Perez, may issue regulations that erode the attractiveness of self-funded plans and push more companies' health policies into the ACA's system.

Finally, Rove points out that the Congressional Budget Office predicts that the number of uninsured Americans will not drop below 30 million in the next 10 years, contradicting the ACA's promise of "universal" coverage.

Title: Trump University Documents Reveal Aggressive Sales Techniques and Media Guidelines

The release of hundreds of pages of court documents related to Trump University, a real estate and investment training venture founded by Donald Trump, has shed light on the aggressive sales techniques and media guidelines used by the company. The documents were released in response to a request from The Washington Post and include depositions from Trump executives and "playbooks" outlining marketing and strategy plans for selling courses and mentoring sessions to students.

The playbooks, which date back to 2008, provide guidance on how to sell courses and respond to customer objections. One tip suggests that sales staff should be "deliberate" in their communication with potential students, planning and developing questions and commands to lead them into a "flow" that they must deal with and respond to. Another tip advises sales teams not to let a lack of money be used as an excuse for turning down Trump University's three-day training, stating that "money is never a reason for not enrolling in Trump University."

The documents also include guidelines for dealing with the news media, with the 2008 edition of the playbook advising employees to direct reporters to a Trump media contact and reminding them that "courtesy gets you a long way." The playbook also includes suggested responses to customers who balk at a sale, offering rebuttals to objections ranging from a need to consult a spouse to a reluctance to go into debt.

The release of the documents comes as Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has faced criticism for his treatment of the media. During a news conference, Trump called an ABC News reporter a "sleaze," prompting CNN to declare that Trump's criticism of the media has reached "Nixonian levels" – only Trump is not doing the name-calling in private.

The documents were ordered to be released by U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel of the Southern District of California, who has come under personal attack from Donald Trump. Trump previously questioned whether Curiel's Hispanic heritage made him biased due to Trump's support for building a wall on the Mexican border.

Title: Menendez Corruption Trial Ends in Mistrial, Leaving Uncertainty for Future Proceedings

The corruption trial of New Jersey Democratic U.S. Senator Bob Menendez ended in a mistrial on Thursday, with the jury declaring itself hopelessly deadlocked on bribery, fraud, and other charges. Menendez, 63, was accused of accepting private flights, campaign contributions, and other benefits from Florida ophthalmologist Salomon Melgen in exchange for official favors.

The hung jury was a victory for Menendez and a significant setback for federal prosecutors, who had been seeking to prove that Menendez had engaged in a pattern of corruption. The outcome is a major blow to the Justice Department, which had been investigating Menendez since 2012.

The trial was the Justice Department's first high-profile corruption case since the U.S. Supreme Court's decision last year limited its ability to bring such cases. The mistrial raises questions about whether prosecutors will choose to retry Menendez, who is expected to run for re-election next year.

In a statement, the Justice Department said it would "carefully consider next steps." Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell immediately called for the Senate Ethics Committee to investigate the allegations against Menendez, and the committee announced it would resume its inquiry, which was put on hold in 2013 to allow the criminal probe to proceed.

Menendez thanked his family, jurors, and character witnesses outside the courthouse, saying the case was "wrong" from the start. He also warned those who had sought to take advantage of his situation, saying, "I know who you are, and I won't forget you."

The mistrial provides temporary relief for Menendez's Democratic colleagues in the Senate, who would have likely pushed for his resignation or expulsion if he had been convicted. The case was seen as a test for prosecutors in the wake of the Supreme Court's ruling vacating the bribery conviction of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell.

Title: Intelligence Community Concludes Russia's President Ordered Influence Campaign to Undermine American Democracy

The United States intelligence community has concluded with high confidence that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered his security services to undertake an influence campaign aimed at undermining confidence in American democracy and sowing chaos in the electoral system. This campaign includes hacking political organizations and state election boards, as well as Russian disinformation campaigns on social media platforms.

Russia's efforts to spread disinformation and chaos are well-documented, dating back to the Soviet era. The country has developed a reputation for using modern tools to spread disinformation, which has spread like a virus throughout the Western world. Russia has pursued an aggressive foreign policy aimed at spreading disorder and expanding its influence in states formerly under Soviet control.

The threat of Russian meddling in United States elections is not behind us.
