Just last week, Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats warned that "the warning lights are blinking red" that Russia and other adversaries will undertake further cyberattacks on the country's digital infrastructure, including energy companies in Texas.

Congress has taken steps to address the threat of Russian interference. In recent years, Congress has pressed the president to take action on European security issues, such as sending lethal weaponry to Ukraine to assist in its fight against Russian-backed separatists. Last year, Congress passed the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act to impose severe sanctions on Russia in retaliation for its meddling in the presidential election. This year, the House passed the Ukraine Cybersecurity Cooperation Act to improve Ukraine's ability to respond to Russian-supported disinformation and propaganda efforts.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has also taken steps to address the issue, requesting testimony from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on the president's recent meetings with both Kim Jong-un and Vladimir Putin.

Title: Leaked Trump Tax Return Raises Questions About Business Losses and Tax Code

The recent leak of Donald Trump's 1995 tax return, showing a loss of over $900 million, has sparked controversy and raised questions about the Republican presidential nominee's business dealings and tax strategy. The leak, obtained by the New York Times, suggests that Trump carried forward this loss to minimize his tax burden in subsequent years, a practice allowed by the tax code.

The article argues that Trump's loss in Atlantic City, where his casinos went bankrupt, was a reflection of the market's decline in the early 1990s. While this is a common occurrence in business, the article notes that Trump's losses were significant and could have been a major blow to his reputation.

The article also highlights the fact that the tax code allows businesses to carry forward losses, which can be used to offset income in future years. This practice is not unique to Trump and is used by many businesses and individuals to manage their tax liability.

The article criticizes the New York Times for publishing the leak, stating that it is a violation of Trump's privacy and could be a breach of confidentiality. The article also questions the identity of the leaker and suggests that it could be a conspiracy involving the IRS, state revenue departments, or a lawyer or accountant.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual account of the situation, highlighting the complexities of the tax code and the potential implications for Trump's business and political careers.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accuses Special Counsel of Unlawfully Obtaining Emails, Mueller's Office Pushes Back

The Trump transition team has accused Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office of unlawfully obtaining tens of thousands of emails from the General Services Administration (GSA), claiming that the agency handed over private materials, including privileged communications, without their consent. The transition team's lawyer, Kory Langhofer, sent a seven-page letter to the Senate Homeland Security Committee and the House Oversight Committee, alleging that the GSA's actions violated attorney-client privilege and the Fourth Amendment.

The GSA, which holds all transition documents, provided copies of emails, laptops, cell phones, and other materials from 13 members of the transition team, despite not owning or controlling the records in question. Langhofer claimed that the transition team was never informed that the documents were handed over and that there were potential violations of attorney-client privilege and the Fourth Amendment.

The emails in question include sensitive exchanges on matters such as potential appointments, gossip about senators involved in the confirmation process, speculation about vulnerabilities of Trump nominees, and policy planning on issues like war and taxes. A source told Axios that the transition team will send a letter to Mueller asking for some emails to be returned because they are privileged.

Mueller's office pushed back against the claims, stating that they obtained the emails through appropriate criminal process or with the account owner's consent. GSA Deputy Counsel Lenny Loewentritt also contradicted the claims made by the Trump transition team, saying that the truth is the exact opposite.

Former federal prosecutor Renato Mariotti weighed in on the issue, stating that the Trump transition team is "playing politics" but the issue itself is a "bad sign for them." Mariotti noted that what is unusual in this case is that Mueller's team obtained the emails from the GSA rather than the Trump transition, suggesting that Mueller was concerned that he wouldn't receive all the emails if he obtained them from the Trump team.

Rep. Eric Swalwell also dismissed the supposed complaints by the transition team, calling it "much ado about nothing" and stating that the claims are an attempt to discredit Mueller's investigation.

Title: Bolton's Departure from Trump Administration: A Complex Mix of Principles and Personal Factors

The sudden departure of John Bolton from his position as National Security Adviser under President Donald Trump has sparked much speculation about the reasons behind his decision. While some have attributed his departure to personal and financial motivations, others believe it was a principled stand against Trump's unconventional approach to foreign policy. 

Bolton, a seasoned government professional with a background in diplomacy and law, reportedly expressed distress when Trump considered withdrawing the US from NATO in 2018. He also questioned fellow Republican Jon Huntsman's decision to serve as ambassador to China, stating that there is no patriotic obligation to advance the career of someone whose values are antithetical to one's own. This suggests that Bolton may have been concerned about Trump's actions and their impact on American foreign policy.

Bolton's professional principles and sense of duty may have also played a role in his decision to leave. As a seasoned government official, he has a deep respect for the institutional architecture and ethos of American foreign policy. He reportedly characterized Trump's meddling with aid to Ukraine as a "drug deal" and disdained the president's circumvention of normal diplomatic channels by enlisting Rudolph Giuliani, his personal lawyer.

Some have speculated that Bolton's departure may be motivated by personal indignation and greed, as he had long lobbied for the national security adviser position and received a reported $2 million advance for his upcoming book. However, it is also possible that Bolton was driven by a desire to protect the integrity of the foreign policy structure and the principles of American diplomacy.

It is worth noting that Bolton lasted almost a year and a half in the position and was reportedly unhappy with it towards the end. His book, which is set to be released on March 17, did not need the recent revelations to make it a bestseller. While Bolton may have enjoyed a taste of revenge and higher book sales, it is likely that his decision to leave was driven by a mix of principles and personal factors.

Title: Civil Rights Leader Jesse Jackson Criticizes Presidential and Vice Presidential Debates for Ignoring Key Issues

The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader and activist, expressed disappointment and frustration with the recent presidential and vice presidential debates, stating that the candidates have failed to address several critical issues facing the country, including poverty, gun violence, and voter suppression. In an interview, Jackson emphasized that the debates have focused too much on abstract numbers and tax plans, neglecting the real-life struggles of everyday Americans.

According to Jackson, the moderators of the debates have missed opportunities to discuss pressing issues like poverty and gun violence, particularly in areas where these problems are most prevalent. He cited the examples of Aurora, Colorado, and Columbine, Colorado, where mass shootings have occurred, and the state of Kentucky, where the poorest county in America is located.

Jackson also highlighted the issue of low credit scores, stating that 50 million people are in poverty and another 50 million are "unbankable" due to poor credit scores. He emphasized that these individuals often attend underfunded schools and have limited life options, yet are disproportionately represented in the military.

The civil rights leader also expressed concern about the lack of attention given to voter suppression, stating that it is a critical issue that could impact the outcome of the election. He noted that voter suppression tactics, such as voter roll purging, are being used to disrupt the democratic process and undermine the right to vote.

Despite his criticisms, Jackson praised President Obama's performance in the recent debate, stating that he was "alive and vibrant" and effectively countered his opponents' arguments.

Title: Biden Unveils Proposal for Combating Coronavirus, Criticizes Trump's Handling

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden unveiled his proposal for containing the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, which included a critique of President Donald Trump's handling of the crisis. Biden's speech was billed as a "commander-in-chief-worthy" address, but it failed to live up to the hype. Instead of urging unity and calm, Biden took the opportunity to lambast Trump for ignoring science, having an "adversarial relationship with the truth," and promoting racism.

Biden argued that the pandemic has exposed the shortcomings of the current administration, citing a "pervasive lack of trust" in Trump. He emphasized the need for leadership that is open-minded and willing to cooperate across national boundaries to combat the virus. Biden claimed that the government's ability to respond effectively has been undermined by the hollowing out of agencies and the disparagement of science.

The former vice president also accused Trump of sowing fear and racial division, specifically citing his attempts to hold China accountable for failing to contain the virus as emboldening racism and "xenophobia." Biden emphasized that the coronavirus does not have a political affiliation and that acts of racism and xenophobia against the Asian American and Pacific Islander community must not be tolerated.

The speech comes one day after the Biden campaign unveiled its "Public Health Advisory Committee," which is tasked with providing guidance on the pandemic. The committee's proposals include rejoining the Paris climate accord, which was a key issue during Biden's time as vice president.

Title: Pennsylvania Woman Dies in Jail Cell After Serving Sentence for Unpaid School Fines

A 55-year-old Pennsylvania woman, Eileen DiNino, died in her jail cell over the weekend while serving a 48-hour sentence for her children's unpaid school fines. DiNino was midway through her sentence, which was intended to eliminate around $2,000 in fines and related court fees related to her children's attendance at school.

According to District Judge Dean Patton, DiNino's death is not considered suspicious, but the cause of death has yet to be determined. Patton, who sentenced DiNino, expressed regret over her death, stating that she did not need to be in jail and that the system is flawed.

More than 1,600 people, mostly women, have been jailed in Berks County alone due to similar fines. Patton acknowledged that a short jail stint can sometimes "break the habit" of parents who struggle to take their children to school, but he also emphasized that DiNino's situation was unique.

The county started a program a few years ago that gives families 30 to 60 days to keep daily logs of each class and assignment, which has resulted in a more than 30% drop in the district truancy rate. DiNino did not work and appeared to have little help with her four children still at home, according to Patton.

Berks County Commissioner Kevin Barnhardt expressed outrage over DiNino's death, stating that she died alone and away from her family while serving a sentence for being poor. The circumstances of DiNino's death serve as a stark reminder of how being poor is considered a crime worthy of punishment in the United States.

The incident highlights the issue of court fees and fines being used as a means of punishment, which has led to thousands of people being jailed across the country. A recent investigation by National Public Radio revealed that a homeless man was sentenced to a year in jail for not paying a $2,600 penalty after shoplifting a $2 can of beer, and a teenager was jailed for three days for not paying the fine associated with catching a fish out of season.

**Trump Welcomes Home Three Americans Released from North Korean Detention**

In a surprise move, three American citizens, Kim Dong Chul, Kim Hak Song, and Kim Sang Dok, were released from detention in North Korea and returned to the United States on Thursday morning. The men, who were detained on charges of espionage and hostile acts, were welcomed home by President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump at Joint Base Andrews.

The release of the three men clears an obstacle to direct talks between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, with the president stating that he expects to announce a date and location for the summit within days. The U.S. aims to persuade Kim to give up his country's nuclear arsenal, and Trump has engaged in a "maximum pressure" campaign to ratchet up sanctions on North Korea and lean on other nations to cut diplomatic ties.

The three men, who share the common surname Kim but are not related, were handed over to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo during his second trip to Pyongyang this year. They were sentenced to hard labor and imprisonment, with Kim Dong Chul serving 10 years for conducting espionage for South Korea.

The men expressed gratitude to the U.S. government, President Trump, and the people of the United States for bringing them home, stating that they thank God and their families and friends who prayed for their return. The homecoming event was broadcast live on cable news networks, with the men being greeted by a large American flag strung between two fire trucks parked on the tarmac.

Vice President Mike Pence, who joined Trump at the homecoming, stated that the men "seem to be in good health" and were glad to be heading home. Pence also spoke with the parents of Otto Warmbier, an American college student who died shortly after being returned home from North Korea in a coma last year.

The release of the three men gives hope that a deal can be reached to rid the Korean Peninsula of nuclear weapons, according to Pence. The former detainees are expected to undergo evaluation and any treatment at Walter Reed military hospital in Bethesda, Maryland.

Title: CNN Dumps Donna Brazile from On-Camera Contributors

CNN has removed Donna Brazile, the interim chair of the Democratic National Committee, from its roster of on-camera contributors. The decision comes after hacked emails revealed that Brazile had tipped off the Hillary Clinton presidential campaign about questions that would be asked in the primary debates.

According to the leaked emails, Brazile had given the Clinton campaign advance notice of questions, including one about Flint, Michigan, and what Clinton would do as president to address the city's water crisis. The emails were obtained by WikiLeaks and published in 2016.

While Brazile's actions were deemed wrong, the article argues that the real issue is not a single corrupt act, but the entire ecosystem of paid partisan commentators. The article claims that these commentators, who are often former politicians or political operatives, are hired for their ability to provide safe and predictable opinions, rather than their expertise or insight.

The article lists a number of notable politicians and political operators who have worked as TV commentators, including Tim Russert, Bill Bradley, and Sarah Palin. The article suggests that these individuals are hired not for their political insights, but for their ability to provide a predictable and safe opinion.

The article concludes that what transpires during paid contributor segments is not journalism, politics, or even entertainment, but rather a form of "tasteless soy filler." It suggests that news shows would be better off hiring journalists who can extract meaningful information from political operatives, rather than paying them to provide opinions.

Title: Washington State City to Implement Highest Minimum Wage in the Nation, Employers Scramble to Adapt

Article:

In a move aimed at boosting the income of low-wage workers, the city of SeaTac, Washington, is set to implement a minimum wage of $15 per hour on January 1, a 60% increase from the state's current minimum wage of $9.32. This hike will affect an estimated 1,600 hotel and transportation workers in the city. While some workers are looking forward to the increased pay, employers are scrambling to absorb the higher labor costs.

Some businesses, like the Cedarbrook Lodge, plan to reduce employee hours, benefits, and eliminate some positions to offset the increased costs. General Manager Scott Ostrander stated, "We're going to be looking at making some serious cuts. We're going to be looking at reducing employee hours, reducing benefits, and eliminating some positions." However, the lodge plans to increase revenue by building an addition to the hotel to offset the higher labor costs.

Not all employers are taking the same approach. One company has announced plans to close one of its two restaurants, eliminating 200 jobs. Hotel Concepts, a company that owns and manages 11 hotels in Washington state, has shelved plans to build a new hotel in SeaTac due to the uncertainty caused by the minimum wage hike. Han Kim, the company's owner, stated, "Uncertainty is bad for business, and right now we're right in that area, so we're just putting everything on hold."

A recent legal victory for opponents of the $15 minimum wage has also caused some uncertainty. A King County judge ruled that the wage hike does not apply to workers at the SeaTac airport, eliminating 4,700 workers from the successful ballot initiative. Backers of the minimum wage hike plan to appeal the ruling to the state Supreme Court.

Kshama Sawant, a socialist and Seattle City Council member, is a strong supporter of the $15 minimum wage and plans to make Seattle the next city to implement the wage. She believes that while some jobs may be lost, the benefits of the wage hike will outweigh the costs. The American Car Rental Association estimates that 5% of low-wage jobs will be cut and another 5-10% of those workers will be replaced by more experienced workers.

The owner of Dollar Rental Cars has stated that she will outsource some functions, change schedules, and cut some staff in response to the new policy. As the city of SeaTac implements its new minimum wage, employers and workers alike will be watching to see how the effects of the hike play out.

Title: Minneapolis Mayor and City Council Members Disagree on Police Force Abolition

Article:

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has reiterated his stance against abolishing the city's police force, despite a veto-proof majority of city council members advocating for its disbandment. The move comes in the wake of the in-custody death of George Floyd and ongoing protests against systemic racism and police brutality.

Frey stated that he will work with Chief Medaria Arradondo and the community to implement deep, structural reforms and address systemic racism in police culture. However, he does not support abolishing the Minneapolis Police Department. The mayor's stance was met with resistance from protesters outside his home, who shouted "It's not about you!" and "Go home, Jacob, go home!"

Nine city council members, including Council President Lisa Bender, Vice President Andrea Jenkins, and Councilmembers Alondra Cano, Jeremiah Ellison, Steve Fletcher, Phillipe Cunningham, Cam Gordon, and Jeremy Schroeder, held a rally at Powderhorn Park, where they expressed their commitment to ending the city's toxic relationship with the police department. They believe that incremental reforms have failed and that a new approach is needed to create safer communities.

The city council members' stance is not without controversy, with some critics arguing that abolishing the police force would leave communities without a dedicated law enforcement agency. Nationally, efforts to defund the police have been met with widespread disapproval, with only about 20% of Americans supporting reductions in police forces.

Data analysis has also raised questions about the existence of systemic racism in policing. According to Heather Mac Donald, writing for The Wall Street Journal, African-Americans make up 53% of known homicide offenders in the US, and commit about 60% of robberies, despite being 13% of the population. Mac Donald also cites research by Harvard economist Roland G. Fryer Jr., which found no evidence of racial discrimination in shootings.

The debate over police reform and abolition is ongoing, with the city's civil rights investigation likely to unfold over the next several months.

Title: Voter Fraud Ring Busted in Los Angeles, Accused of Swapping Cigarettes for Fake Signatures

A voter fraud ring in Los Angeles has been accused of targeting homeless individuals on Skid Row, offering them cigarettes or small amounts of cash in exchange for forged signatures on ballot measure petitions and voter registration forms. The Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) and the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office announced criminal charges against nine individuals involved in the scheme, which allegedly took place during the 2016 election cycle and again this year.

According to the LAPD, the defendants would approach homeless individuals on Skid Row and ask them to forge signatures on state ballot measure petitions and voter registration forms. The accused face charges including circulating a petition with fake names, voter fraud, and registering a fictitious person.

Los Angeles County Elections Chief Dean Logan expressed confidence that his staff's manual signature verification process did not allow the forgeries to go undetected. However, he acknowledged that any activity that undermines public trust in the electoral system is disturbing.

This incident is not an isolated case, as voter fraud has been reported in other states, including Pennsylvania, Texas, and Wisconsin. The LAPD's Senior Lead Officer on Skid Row, Deon Joseph, described the scheme as an "assault on our democracy." The case serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance and transparency in the electoral process.

Title: Trump Attorney Michael Cohen Reveals Third Client: Fox News Host Sean Hannity

Article:

In a federal court hearing on Monday, Michael Cohen, the longtime attorney for former US President Donald Trump, revealed that he had been representing Fox News host Sean Hannity, in addition to Trump and Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy. The revelation came after a judge ordered Cohen's attorney to disclose the identity of a third client, which had been withheld in earlier court documents.

Cohen's attorney had previously identified Trump and Broidy as his clients, both of whom are involved in cases related to alleged payments made to women to keep them quiet about alleged sexual encounters. Cohen has acknowledged paying $130,000 to adult film star Stormy Daniels, who claims to have had an affair with Trump in 2006. Broidy has acknowledged an affair with model Shera Bechard, for which he paid $1.6 million when she became pregnant.

Hannity, a vocal supporter of Trump and Cohen, issued a statement denying any involvement with Cohen in any legal matters. He stated that his discussions with Cohen were limited to legal questions about real estate and were confidential. However, he did not provide any further details about the nature of his conversations with Cohen.

The revelation about Hannity's involvement with Cohen raises questions about the extent of his relationship with the former president and his attorney. Hannity has been a vocal critic of the FBI and Justice Department, and has used his platform to defend Trump and Cohen. The FBI raided Cohen's home and office earlier this month, seizing evidence related to his business dealings and alleged payments to women.

The judge in the case, Kimba Wood, has yet to rule on whether to appoint a "special master" to review the seized evidence or permit the Justice Department's "filter team" to continue its work. The investigation is ongoing, and it remains unclear what specific information the seized evidence may contain.

Title: Americans' Approval of Obama's Handling of ISIS Wanes, Poll Suggests

Article:

A recent CNN/ORC survey has revealed that Americans are increasingly dissatisfied with President Barack Obama's handling of the fight against ISIS. The poll found that 57% of respondents disapprove of his handling of foreign affairs, with 54% disapproving of his handling of terrorism specifically. Additionally, 60% rate Obama negatively on his handling of electronic national security.

The declining approval ratings come as international turmoil continues to unfold, with Egypt launching airstrikes against Islamic State strongholds in Libya in response to the beheading of 21 Egyptian Christians. Obama issued a statement condemning the killing, but his Republican opponents have criticized his leadership as weak.

The survey also found that Americans are increasingly skeptical about the effectiveness of the U.S. military action against ISIS, with 58% saying the fight is going badly, up from 49% in October. Even among Democrats, nearly half (46%) say things are not going well in the battle against ISIS.

The poll suggests that Americans are warming up to the idea of sending ground troops to combat the terrorist organization, with 47% now supporting deployment, up from 43% in November. However, the parties remain divided on the issue, with 61% of Democrats opposed and 55% of Republicans in favor.

The survey also found that 78% of Americans believe Congress should give Obama the authority to fight ISIS, a slight decline from 82% in December. A similar majority (79%) say Obama was right to ask Congress for the authority, rather than proceeding with the battle unilaterally.

The survey was conducted among 1,027 adult Americans from February 12-15, with a margin of sampling error of 3%.
